event: The Universe forms in a giant "Big Bang".
Formation of the first galaxies.
The Universe cools sufficiently to permit clouds of hydrogen to collapse due to gravity. The first stars ignite.
Elements heavier than hydrogen and helium are injected into the Universe as the first stars end their lives in Super Novas, Novas, and White Dwarves.
A nearby Super Nova disturbs a cloud of gas and dust, starting a process of gravitational collapse that results in our solar system's formation.
Particles begin to acrete into planetesimals around the dense cloud of hydrogen at the center of the newly formed solar system. The sun ignites in an explosive nuclear fusion explosion.
Formation of the earth.

Formation of the Moon. A mars-sized planetesimal collides with the earth in a cataclysmic explosion. The iron cores of the Earth and planetesimal merge while lighter material forms an incandescent ring around the earth which accretes into the Moon in a matter of decades. The Earth is fractured, tilted 23 degrees on its axis and its rotation greatly increases. A sea of molten magma 1000 feet thick covers the planet. Any geological features present before this event are obliterated.

Melting of the interior of the Earth due to radioactive and gravitational heating which leads to its differentiated interior structure as well as outgassing of molecules such as water, methane, ammonia, hydrogen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide. Atmospheric water is photodissociated by ultraviolet light to give oxygen atoms which are incorporated into an ozone layer and hydrogen molecules which escape into space.
Bombardment of the Earth by planetesimals stops
The Earth's crust solidifies--formation of the oldest rocks found on Earth. Condensation of atmospheric water into oceans.

The oldest known fossils are calcareous structures called stromatolites that were produced by cyanobacteria. Beginning of photosynthesis by blue-green algae which releases oxygen molecules into the atmosphere and steadily works to strengthen the ozone layer and change the Earth's chemically reducing atmosphere into a chemically oxidizing one.
The Early Period within the Proterozoic Period within the Precambrian Era begins.
Rise in the concentration of oxygen molecules stops the deposition of uraninites (since they are soluble when combined with oxygen) and starts the deposition of banded iron formations.

It is postulated that the formation of oxygen by plants in the ocean reacted with and removed the free methane in the atmosphere. The loss of this greenhouse gas caused the earth to cool and completely freeze over - "snowball earth". This period may have lasted hundreds of millions of years until enough volcanic gas was released to trap atmospheric heat and melt the ice.
The Middle Period within the Proterozoic Period within the Precambrian Era begins.
The last reserves of reduced iron are used up by the increasing atmospheric oxygen--last banded iron formations.
Eukaryotic cell organisms develop. Rise of multicellular organisms.
The Late Period within the Proterozoic Period within the Precambrian Era begins.

The Varangian glaciation. It is believed that at this point that the earth's oceans again completely froze over and the entire planet was buried under miles of ice, with only the earth's core temperature to keep some water liquid under the ice. This "snowball earth" was caused by silicate rocks eroding and reacting with the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, and may have lasted as long as 170,000,000 years, until just before the "Cambrian Explosion".
Fossils of Ediacaran organisms are made.
Cambrian explosion of hard-bodied organisms.
The Cambrian Period within the Paleozoic Era begins.
The land that became Ohio is located south of the equator.
The Ordovician Period within the Paleozoic Era begins.
Rise of the fish--first vertebrates.
The breakup of a 96 mile wide asteroid between Mars and Jupiter leads to a 2,000,000 year influx of dust that cools the earth and leads to an ice age.
The Silurian Period within the Paleozoic Era begins.
Waxy coated algae begin to live on land.
Millipedes have evolved--first land animals.
The Devonian Period within the Paleozoic Era begins.
The COLUMBUS LIMESTONE is formed when Ohio is covered by a warm, very clear shallow sea.
The DELAWARE LIMESTONE is formed when Ohio is covered by a warm, very clear shallow sea.
The OLENTANGY SHALE is formed from thick deposits of mud.

The Appalachian mountains are formed via a plate tectonic collision between North America, Africa, and Europe. Appearance of primitive sharks. Outwash from their subsequent erosion will form large beds of sandstone across Ohio.
The OHIO SHALE is formed is formed from thick deposits of mud.
Trees first appear on land. Archaeopteris looks similar to a Christmas tree with buds, reinforced branch joints and wood similar to today's timber. Its branches and leaves resembled a fern.
The Mississippian Epoch within the Carboniferous Period within the Paleozoic Era begins.
Rise of the amphibians. Primitive insects have evolved. Primitive ferns evolve--first plants with roots.
The Pennsylvanian Epoch within the Carboniferous Period within the Paleozoic Era begins.
The land that became Ohio is located on the equator.
The BEDFORD SHALE,  BEREA GRIT, SUNBURY SHALE, CUYAHOGA SANDSTONE and BLACK HAND SANDSTONE are formed.
A period of massive glaciation.
Rise of the reptiles. Winged insects have evolved.
Meteor Impact: Clearwater Lakes, Quebec, Canada. Twin craters, 32km and 22km in diameter.
The Permian Period within the Paleozoic Era begins.
Beetles and weevils have evolved.
Most modern connifer trees now exist.
Permian period mass extinction. Possibly due to a supervolcano in the Siberian Traps?
Melanosaurus walked the earth.
The Triassic Period within the Mesozoic Era begins.
Roaches and termites have evolved.
Modern ferns have evolved. Bees have evolved.
Coelophysis, one of the oldest known dinosaurs, walked the earth.
The land that became Ohio is located where Florida is located today.
The Jurassic Period within the Mesozoic Era begins.
Meteor Impact: Manicouagan, Quebec, Canada. Crater diameter 100km. The largest still preserved impact crater on the planet.
Ingentia prima, which means "first giant" in Latin — weighed up to 11 tons (10 metric tons) and measured up to 32 feet (10 meters) long. Eqypt.
Meteor Impact: Aorounga, Chad, Africa. 17km crater.
Pangaea starts to break apart. Primitive crocodiles have evolved. Appearance of mammals.
Apatosaurus (formerly known as Brontosaurus), Brachiosaurus walk the earth. Ichthyosaurus and Plesiosaurus swim in the sea. Pterodactyl flies in the sky.
Archaeopteryx, Ankylosaurus, Gallimimus, Iguanodon, Protoceratops, Spinosaurus, Triceratops, Tyrannosaurus, and Velociraptor walk the Earth.
The Cretaceous Period within the Mesozoic Era begins.
Meteor Impact: Gosses Bluff, Northern Territory, Australia. 24km crater.
Primitive kangaroos have evolved.
Massive eruption at Guarapuava —Tamarana—Sarusas Brazil ejects 8000 km3 of material.
Meteor Impact: Deep Bay, Saskatchewan, Canada. 13km crater.
Primitive cranes have evolved.
The flowering plants, angiosperms, appear. They quickly radiate and today there are 200.000 species.
Modern sharks have evolved.

Meteor Impact: Chicxulub, Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico. An asteroid 10 to 20 kilometers (6 to 12 miles) in diameter hit a geologically unique, sulfur-rich region of the Yucatan Peninsula and kicked up billions of tons of sulfur and other materials into the atmosphere. Darkness prevailed for about half a year after the collision. This caused global temperatures to plunge near freezing. Half of the species on Earth became extinct including the dinosaurs. Energy was 250 teratons.

Gymnosperma trees have largely take over from the conifers. Amongst the genera that had evolved were platanus, the oak family, hollies (like American holly or hulst), the walnut family, palm trees and the family that now includes birches and alnus.
The Paleocene Epoch within the Tertiary Period within the Cenozoic Era begins.
Rats, mice, and squirrels have evolved. Herons and storks have evolved.
The Eocene Epoch within the Tertiary Period within the Cenozoic Era begins.
Rabbits and hares have evolved.
Primitive monkeys have evolved.
La Garita Caldera formed when 3000 cubic miles of lava are ejected, covering most of modern Colorado to a depth of 100 m. Energy is 25,000 megatons.
The first rose species appears.
The Oligocene Epoch within the Tertiary Period within the Cenozoic Era begins.
Koalas have evolved.
Meteor Impact: Mistastin Lake, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada. 28km crater.
Volcano, Fish Canyon, San Juan Mtns, Colorado: ejects 3,000 km3 of material.
The number of "herb" species, or small non-woody plants, explodes due to a drier climate reducing forests.
The Miocene Epoch within the Tertiary Period within the Cenozoic Era begins.
Most major groups of oak trees have appeared.
Parrots and pigeons have evolved.
The chimpanzee and hominid lines evolve.
Volcano, Yellowstone: Massive eruption ejects 280 km3 of material.
Meteor Impact: Kara-Kul, Tajikistan. 45km crater.
Ramapithecus exist.
The star Betelgeuse forms.
The Pliocene Epoch within the Tertiary Period within the Cenozoic Era begins.
The Hawaii island of Kauaʻ forms.
Meteor Impact: Roter Kamm, South West Africa/Namibia. 2.5km crater.
The Hawaii island of Niʻihau forms.
Development of hominid bipedalism.
The Hawaii island of Oʻahu forms.
The Australopithecus Lucy walks the Earth.
Oldest stone tools found, used by an ancestor of Homo Erectus
Volcano, Yellowstone: Massive eruption ejects 2,500 km3 of material.
Widespread use of stone tools.
The Hawaii island of Molokaʻi forms.
The Pleistocene Epoch within the Quaternary Period within the Cenozoic Era begins.
Homo Erectus exist.
Meteor Impact: Bosumtwi, Ghana. 10.5km crater.
The Hawaii island of Lānaʻi forms.
The Hawaii island of Maui forms.
The Kansan glaciation begins.
Homo erectus tames fire.
The Hawaii island of Kahoʻolawe forms.
Volcano, Yellowstone: Massive eruption ejects 1,000 km3 of material.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature peaks at +2 deg C above normal, signalling the beginning of an interglacial period.
The Hawaii island of Hawaii forms.
The Illinoian glaciation begins.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature reaches a minimum of -8 deg C below normal, signalling the peak of a glacial period.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature peaks at +3 deg C above normal, signalling the beginning of an interglacial period.
Archaic Homo Sapiens appear, possibly evolved from Homo Erectus.
Geminga supernova explosion at a distance of roughly 60 pc--roughly as bright as the Moon.
Meteor Impact: Wolfe Creek, Australia. 0.875km crater.
Evidence of early humans living in Denisovo Cave in Siberia.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature reaches a minimum of -8.5 deg C below normal, signalling the peak of a glacial period.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature peaks at +2 deg C above normal, signalling the beginning of an interglacial period.
Homo Sapiens Neanderthalensis exist. Dead end evolutionary branch for humans, Neanderthals go extinct around 33,000 BC.
Neanderthals lived along side Homo Sapiens in Denisovo Cave in Siberia, Russia.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature reaches a minimum of -9 deg C below normal, signalling the peak of a glacial period.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature peaks at +3 deg C above normal, signalling the beginning of an interglacial period.
Modern Homo Sapiens, evolved from Archaic Homo Sapiens, exists in Africa.
Neanderthals no longer present in Denisovo Cave in Siberia, Russia. They lived along side Homo Sapiens in that area for 190,000 years.

The eruption of 2,800 km3 of magma at Toba caldera is the largest eruption in the last 2 million years. The eruption may have release as much as 10E+12 kg of sulfuric acid, an order of magnitude more than Laki in 1783 and Tambora in 1815, two of the greatest Holocene eruptions. The Toba eruption may have caused about 3 to 4 degree C cooling at the surface but this impact is hard to detect because of concurrent glacial conditions. The world's population of homo sapiens decreased from over one hundred thousand to less than two thousand, basically because global temperatures dropped five degrees for many years.
The Wisconsin glaciation began with the accumulation of ice in northeastern Canada.
The Wisconsin glaciations reaches Columbus.
A needle is used in Denisova Cave in the Bashelaksky Range of the Altai mountains, Siberia, Russia. It is the earliest known use of a needle found.
Modern Homo Sapiens migrate out of Africa and appear in Europe and Asia.
Meteor Crater, AZ created.
Homo Sapiens Sapiens enter Australia from southeastern Asia and North America from northeastern Asia.
The Wisconsin glaciation reaches Dayton.
Homo Sapiens Neanderthalensis goes extinct.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature reaches a minimum of -9 deg C below normal, signalling the peak of a glacial period.
Homo sapiens sapiens paint the Altamira Cave.
The Wisconsin glaciation reaches Cincinnati. Galciation peaks.
The Wisconsin glaciation retreats to Cleveland.
Evidence that Paleo-Indian people settled in Ohio.
The Younger Dryas begins, a return to glacial conditions which temporarily reversed the gradual climatic warming after the Last Glacial Maximum
Homo sapiens sapiens have domesticated dogs in Kirkuk, Iraq.
The Younger Dryas ends, and glacial conditions resume abating.
Rye is cultivated in Mesopotamia. Pigs and sheep are domesticated.
Early inhabitants of North America at the site of what is now Monte Verde, Chile, leave spear tips behind. This is the oldest confirmed evidence of humans in North and South America.
First permanent Homo sapiens sapiens settlements. Homo sapiens sapiens learn to use fire to cast copper and harden pottery.
The eight Neolithic founder crops—emmer wheat, einkorn wheat, hulled barley, peas, lentils, bitter vetch, chick peas, and flax—were cultivated in the Levant.
Beginning of the stone age.
Early inhabitants of North America at the site of what is now Clovis, New Mexico, leave spear tips behind.
The Wisconsin glaciation retreats into Canada.
The Holocene Epoch within the Quaternary Period within the Cenozoic Era begins.
Archaic hunter-gathers follow rivers in seasonal migrations in Ohio.
The potato is domesticated in South America.
Settlement of the Indus Valley begins. Evidence found at Mehrgahr.
Settlement of the Nile Valley begins.
The northern hemisphere's average temperature peaks at +3 deg C above normal, signalling the beginning of an interglacial period.
Rice is domesticated in China.
The Sumer civilization is settled in Iraq.

The world's first city, Eridu, is founded, close to the Persian Gulf near the mouth of the Euphrates River. Excavation has shown that the city was founded on a virgin sand-dune site with no previous occupation.
Volcano, Crater Lake, Oregon:  A massive eruption ejects 30-40 km3 of material and forms a caldera lake 590m deep. Wizzard Island is a post caldera cinder cone.
Volcano, Kikai-Akahoya, Japan: A massive eruption ejects 30-40 km3 of material.
Carbon (6) Ancient Eqyptions and Summarians discover carbon in the form of soot and charcoal.
Beginning of the Bronz Age.
Texts from the Sumer civilization in Iraq found in Uruk and Jemdet

Kingdoms of Upper and Lower Egypt unite. Successive dynasties witness flourishing trade, prosperity and the development of great cultural traditions. Writing, including hieroglyphics, is used as an instrument of state.
Sphinx constructed in Egypt.
Beginning of the Old Kingdom in Eqypt
King Seferu rules Egypt. He built three pyramids and perfected the art of pyramid building. He is the first king of the fourth dynasty of Egypt.
The mature phase of the Indus Civilization begins.
Construction of the Great Pyramid of Ghiza by King Khufu.
"The Standard of Ur" is found in a tomb, depicting life in the Early Dynastic Period in mesopotamia.
The fall of the Old Kingdom in Egypt and the 1st Intermediate period begins.
The Middle Kingdom begins; Egypt is united and powerful again.
Hammurabi rules Babylon, writes great code of laws.
The fall of the Middle Kingdom leads to the 2nd Intermediate period, and the occupation of norhern Egypt by the Hyksos.

The eruption of Santorini in Greece in 1,650 B.C. was one of the largest (VEI=6) in the last 10,000 years. About 7 cubic miles (30 cubic km) of rhyodacite magma was erupted. The plinian column during the initial phase of the eruption was about 23 miles (36 km) high. The removal of such a large volume of magma caused the volcano to collapse, producing a caldera. Ash fell over a large area in the eastern Mediterranean and Turkey. The eruption probably caused the end of the Minoan civilization on the island of Crete.
The reunification of Egypt and the expulsion of the Hyksos begins the New Kingdom, a period when Egypt became a leading power in the Middle East.
The Shang Dynasty begins in China.
Volcano, Aniakchak, Alaska: A massive eruption ejects 50 km3 of material.
Tutankhamen reigns.
The reign of Ramses II brings Egypt to the height of its power.
Beginning of the Iron Age.
Troy falls to the Greeks.
The New Kingdom falls into decline in Eqypt.
Reigns of last Shang king, and of King Wen of Zhou in China.
Death of Zhou founder, King Wu, leads to civil war; regency of Duke of Zho.
Ohio's Adena Indians develop agriculture and their society begins to fluorish.
Ohio's Hopewell culture fluorishes.
Fall of the Western Zhou capital at Zong-Zhou; flight of infant king to Eastern capital at Cheng-Zhou.
Romulus founds Rome.
Egypt is conquered by Nubian kings.
Assyrians from Mesopotamia conquer and rule Egypt.
Thales of Miletus is born. He was a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher, mathematician, and astronomer from Miletus in Asia Minor (present-day Milet in Turkey).
Hanging Gardens of Babylon constructed.
Xenophanes is born. His surviving writings display a skepticism about religion.
Pythagorus is born.
Guatama (Sakyamuni) Buddha born. Taught that painful life is caused by desire.
K'ungfutze (Confucius) born. Taught that you should not do to others what you do not want done to you.

Heraclitus is born. Heraclitus was famous for his insistence on ever-present change as being the fundamental essence of the universe, as stated in the famous saying, "No man ever steps in the same river twice"
Pythagorus travels to Croton, where he founded a school in which initiates were sworn to secrecy and lived a communal, ascetic lifestyle.
Egypt is conquered by the Persians.
Start of the Roman Republic after the overthrow of Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, the seventh and last King of Rome.

Zeno is born. Zeno's paradoxes are a set of philosophical problems generally thought to have been devised by Greek philosopher Zeno of Elea (c. 490–430 BC) to support Parmenides' doctrine that contrary to the evidence of one's senses, the belief in plurality and change is mistaken, and in particular that motion is nothing but an illusion.
Democritus is born. He is famous for formulating the atomic theory of the universe.
Antisthenes is born. A disciple of Socrates, he founds the Cynic philosophy.
Pantheon constructed in Rome.
Plato is born. He is a student of Socrates.
Socrates, condemned by Athenian state, drank hemlock. Plato, his disciple, recorded 35 dialogues.

The Battle of the Allia was fought between the Senones (one of the Gallic tribes which had invaded northern Italy) and the Roman Republic. It was fought at the confluence of the rivers Tiber and Allia, eleven Roman miles (16 km) north of Rome. The Romans were routed and subsequently the Senones sacked Rome.
Aristotle is born. Socretes most famous student.
Qin reforms:  establishment of centralized bureaucracy,  fixed codes of penal and administrative law in China.
Alexander the Great born.
Egypt is conquered by Alexander the Great.
Aristotle dies.

Epicurus believed that what he called "pleasure" was the greatest good, but that the way to attain such pleasure was to live modestly, to gain knowledge of the workings of the world, and to limit one's desires.
Ptolemy, one of Alexander the Great's generals, founds a Greek-speaking dynasty in Eqypt.
Mayan calendar invented in the Yucatan.
Qin extinguishes the Zhou royal house (the end of the Zhou Dynasty) in China
Qin armies conquer Han, Zhao, Yan, Wei, Chu, and Qi in China.
Qin state re-unifies China. Feudalism abolished on recommendation of Li Si, who becomes Prime Minister.
Han takes control (official date 206 B.C.): Liu Bang becomes emperor.
Crates of Mallus brought Stoicism to Rome. See Zeno.
Reign of Emperor Wu (Wu-di). Era of massive state expansion through war, financed by heavy taxation.

Caesar, Crassus and Pompey formed a political alliance that dominated Roman politics for several years. Their attempts to amass power as Populares were opposed by the Optimates within the Roman Senate, among them Cato the Younger with the frequent support of Cicero.
Julius Caesar enters Britain. An important Roman General, his ascension will end 500 years of the Roman Republic.
Battle of Carrhae - The Parthian general Surena decisively defeated a numerically superior Roman invasion force under the command of Marcus Licinius Crassus.
Julius Ceaser crosses the Rubicon River into Italy with an army, which is against the law. He enters Rome and declares himself Dictator for Life.
Julius Caesar is assassinated by Cassius and Brutus.
Cleopatra, the last queen of independent Egypt in ancient times, dies, and Egypt is annexed by the Roman Empire.
Octavian is granted extrordinary powers by the Senate and becomes Augustus, dictator for life. The Roman Republic is replaced by the Roman Empire.
Birth of Jesus Christ of Nazareth.
Cornerstone-laying ceremony for the administration and seminary wings of the Pontifical College Josephinum. Monsignor Joseph Och presiding.
Jesus Christ is crucified in reign of emperor Tiberius, Pontius Pilate procurator in Judea.
Volcano, Ambrym, Vanuatu: A massive eruption ejects 19-25 km3 of material.
Rome burns under emperor Nero.
Emporer Nero commits suicide after he is declared an enemy of the people.
Mt. Vesuvius erupts, destroying Pompeii, Hurculaneum and Stabii.
Beginning of the reign of the five good emporers of Rome, a team of peace and prosperity for the Roman Empire.
Ohio's Adena Indians vanish. Built conical mounds and effigy mounds but no earth work complexes.
The "Jeffers" Indian Mound located on Plesenton Drive is constructed by the Hopewell people.
Death of Marcus Aurelius, onset of decline of Rome.
Volcano, Taupo, New Zealand: A massive eruption ejects 100 km3 of material.
Fall of the Han Dynasty -- China enters long era of political division known as the Six Dynasties period.

Beginning of the Crisis of the Third Century, a 50 year period where Rome's internal trade network fell apart and localism open the way for the early middle ages. It begins with the assassination of Emperor Severus Alexander by his own troops.

End of the Crisis of the Third Century. The Roman Empire nearly collapsed under the combined pressures of invasion, civil war, plague, and economic depression. The crisis ended with the ascension and reforms of Diocletian.
The Roman Solidus coin is minted, solid gold and 60 to the Roman pound.
Constantine becomes Roman emporer
Constantine mints the Roman Solidus in quantity at 72 to the Roman pound.
Emperor Constantine makes Christianity legal in the Roman Empire with the Edict of Milan.
Byzantium is refounded as Constantinopolis.
Emporer Constantine dies.
Alaric becomes Chief of the Goths.
The Roman Empire is divided into Western and Eastern parts after the death of Theodosis I.
Ohio's Hopewell Indians vanish. They leave earthworks behind.

The sack of Rome by the Visigoths. This was the first time in almost 800 years that Rome had fallen to a foreign enemy. The city's citizens were devastated. Many Romans were taken captive, including the Emperor's sister, Galla Placidia. Some citizens would be ransomed, others would be sold into slavery, and still others would be raped and killed. The population of Rome is estimated to be as high as 800,000 at this time.

After three days of looting and pillage, Alaric quickly left Rome and headed for southern Italy. He took with him the wealth of the city and a valuable hostage, Galla Placidia, the sister of emperor Honorius. The Visigoths ravaged Campania, Lucania, and Calabria. Nola and perhaps Capua were sacked, and the Visigoths threatened to invade Sicily and Africa. However, they were unable to cross the Strait of Messina as the ships they had gathered were wrecked by a storm.

Alaric died of illness at Consentia in late 410, mere months after the sack of Rome. According to legend, he was buried with his treasure by slaves in the bed of the Busento river. The slaves were then killed to hide its location.
Bishop Patrick, native of Severn valley, sent as missionary to Ireland.

The third sack of Rome by the Vandals. Before approaching the city, the Vandals knocked down all of the city's aqueducts. At the sight of the approaching Vandals, Maximus and his soldiers tried to flee the city but he was spotted and killed by a Roman mob outside the city, possibly together with his son Palladius. Upon the Vandal arrival, according to the chronicler Prosper of Aquitaine, Pope Leo I requested that Genseric not destroy the ancient city nor murder its inhabitants. Genseric agreed and the gates of Rome were thrown open to him and his men. Genseric looted great amounts of treasure from the city, damaging objects of cultural significance such as the Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus by stripping away the gilt bronze roof tiles (hence the modern term vandalism).

Fall of the Roman Empire and beginning of the middle ages. Odoacer deposed the Emperor Romulus, the Western Roman Emperor wielded negligible military, political, or financial power and had no effective control over the scattered Western domains that could still be described as Roman. Invading barbarians had established their own power in most of the area of the Western Empire. While its legitimacy lasted for centuries longer and its cultural influence remains today, the Western Empire never had the strength to rise again. Many Roman citizens were sold into slavery.
Emporer Justinian rules the Eastern Roman Empire.
Justinian secures the Eastern Border of the Eastern Roman Empire by paying 11,000 pounds of gold to Khosrau I of Persia.
Justinian's troops defeat the Vandals at Ad Decimum in Tunisia.

The extreme weather events of 535–536 were the most severe and protracted short-term episodes of cooling in the Northern Hemisphere in the last 2000 years.[1] The event is thought to have been caused by an extensive atmospheric dust veil, possibly resulting from a large volcanic eruption in the tropics,[2] or debris from space impacting the Earth.[3] Its effects were widespread, causing unseasonal weather, crop failures, and famines worldwide
Tierra Blanca Joven (TBJ) eruption of the Ilopango caldera in central El Salvador ejects an estimated 80 km3 of material.
King Khosrau I broke the "Eternal Peace" and invaded Roman territory
Belisarius took the Ostrogothic capital Ravenna.

The fourth sack of Rome was carried out by the Gothic king Totila during the Gothic War of 535–554 between the Ostrogoths and the Byzantine Empire. Totila was based at Tivoli and, in pursuit of his quest to reconquer the region of Latium, he moved against Rome. The city endured a siege lasting almost a year before falling to the Goths. Totila determined to turn the city into sheep pasture, but only succeeded in tearing down one third of the defensive walls.
Narses retakes Italy for the Eastern Roman Empire, slaying Totila.
Life is considerably more primitive in Italy with the collapse of the Roman Empire.
A large-scale Frankish invasion was defeated at Casilinum, and Italy was secured for the Empire by Narses. This marks the maximum extent of the Byzantine Empire.

The continual war around Rome in the 530s and 540s left it in a state of total disrepair — near-abandoned and desolate with much of its lower-lying parts turned into unhealthy marshes as the drainage systems were neglected and the Tiber's embankments fell into disrepair in the course of the latter half of the 6th century. Here, malaria developed. The aqueducts except for one were not repaired. The population, without imports of grain and oil from Sicily, shrank to less than 50,000 concentrated near the Tiber and around the Campus Martius, abandoning those districts without water supply. There is a legend, significant though untrue, that there was a moment where no one remained living in Rome.
Invasion of Italy by the Lombards further impoverishes Rome. The Lombards, a Germanic people, will rule Italy through the 700's.
Mohammed born in Mecca.
The Sui Dynasty reunites China.

Lombard King, Phocas, rules Rome. His reign saw the erection of the last imperial monument in the Roman Forum, the column bearing his name. He also gave the Pope the Pantheon, at the time closed for centuries, and thus probably saved it from destruction.
The Persians conquer much of the Levant, Egypt, several islands in the Aegean Sea and parts of Anatolia from the Byzantine Empire.
Capital of Chang'an the most developed site of world culture, influenced by contacts with India and West through "Silk Route" across Central Asia.
The Persians are defeated while attempting to take Constantinople.
Heraclius invaded the heartland of Persia. A civil war broke out in Persia, during which the Persians killed their king, and sued for peace.
The first major pitched battle between the Byzantine (Roman) Empire and the army of the Arab Rashidun Caliphate. The result of the battle was a decisive Muslim victory.
At the battle of Yarmuk the Arabs were victorious, defeating Heraclius. The Byzantine Empire abandons Syria to the Muslim Caliphate.
Jerusalem falls to the Muslim Caliphate.

The Battle of Nahāvand (also Nihāvand or Nahāwand) (Arabic: معركة نهاوند‎, Persian: نبرد نهاوند) was fought between Arab Muslims and Sassanid armies. The battle is known to Muslims as the "Victory of Victories." The Sassanid King Yazdegerd III escaped to the Merv area, but was unable to raise another substantial army. It was a decisive victory for the Rashidun Caliphate and the Persians consequently lost the surrounding cities including Sephahan (renamed Isfahan).
Eqypt falls to the Muslim Caliphate.

Rome is plundered by Constans II, emperor of the Byzantine Empire. He removes all remaining metal from Roman buildings to equip his army with shields. Rome's population of 80,000 are supported from Papal estates mainly in Sicily.
A Muslim fleet seized Rhodes and then laid siege to Constantinople, but the mighty walls held.
Muslim forces conquer Carthage.
Muslim forces conquer Tangiers.
General Muhammad bin Qasim invaded Sindh in after a coastal march through Makran. Three years later the Arabs controlled all of the lower Indus valley.
The Iberian Peninsula is almost entirely under Muslim control.

Pope Gregory II refused to accept the decrees of Emperor Leo III, which promoted the Emperor's iconoclasm. Leo reacted first by trying in vain to abduct the Pontiff, and then by sending a force of Ravennate troops under the command of the Exarch Paulus, but they were pushed back by the Lombards of Tuscia and Benevento. Roman general Eutychius sent west by the Emperor successfully captured Rome and restored it as a part of the empire in 728.
Great period of Mayan Empire begins.

The Battle of Tours marked the victory of the Frankish and Burgundian forces under Charles Martel over the invasion forces of the Umayyad Caliphate led by Abdul Rahman Al Ghafiqi, Governor-General of al-Andalus. It was fought in an area between the cities of Poitiers and Tours, in the Aquitaine of west-central France.
Charlemagne becomes King of the Franks.
Charlemagne becomes King of the Lombards.
Charlemagne becomes Holy Roman Emporer in the west, beginning the Carolingian Empire. This is the formal break with the Byzentine empire and the formation of the Holy Roman Empire.
Severe drought killed millions of Maya people due to famine and thirst and initiated a cascade of internal collapses that destroyed their civilization.
Charlemagne dies.
The accession of Basil I to the Byzantine Empire throne in marks the beginning of the Macedonian dynasty, which would rule for the next two and a half centuries.
Alfred The Great becomes the first King of The Anglo Saxons.
At the Battle of Edington an army of the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Wessex under Alfred the Great defeated the Great Heathen Army led by Guthrum on a date between 6 and 12 May
Weak leadership since the death of Charlemagne leads Rome to its lowest point, when when a raging crowd exhumed the corpse of a dead pope, Formosus, and put it on trial.
Alfred The Great dies.

Fort Ancient Indians (900 A.D. to 1500 A.D.).  One of their villages, Anderson Village, is located on the east side of the Little Miami in the shadow of Fort Ancient.  Another "Fort Ancient" Indian site is located on the west bank of the Great Miami River south of Dayton, Ohio, SunWatch Village

Beginning of the Saeculum obscurum. During this 60 year period, the popes were influenced strongly by a powerful and corrupt aristocratic family, the Theophylacti, and their relatives. The period begins with Pope Sergius III and ends with Pope John VII whose term ends in 964.
The Kingdom of England becomes a unified state.
Paektu Mountain, on the border of North Korea and China, erupts ejectings 100-120 km3 material.

The Battle of Lechfeld was a decisive victory for Otto I the Great, King of East Francia, over the Hungarian harka Bulcsú and the chieftains Lél (Lehel) and Súr. It is often seen as the defining event in the repulsion of the Hungarians' incursions into Western Europe.
Beginning of medieval China's "commercial revolution". Era of Confucian dominance.
Otto I revives the title of Holy Roman Emporer. Otto and his heirs will rule Rome until 1024.
Great period of Mayan Empire ends.
Lief Ericsson's Norsemen reach Labrador, the New England Coast and Martha's Vineyard.
Cnut is King of England
Henry II dies, ending the Ottonian dynasty that has ruled Rome since 962.

Basil II dies. He is considered among the most capable Byzantine emperors and his reign as the apex of the empire in the Middle Ages. By 1025, the date of Basil II's death, the Byzantine Empire stretched from Armenia in the east to Calabria in Southern Italy in the west.[94] Many successes had been achieved, ranging from the conquest of Bulgaria to the annexation of parts of Georgia and Armenia, and the reconquest of Crete, Cyprus, and the important city of Antioch. These were not temporary tactical gains but long-term reconquests.
Cnut, King of England, dies.
Famine forced the Toltecs to migrate from a stricken region in what is now central Mexico.
Eastern Orthodox and Western Churches break in the great East-West Schism.

Rome is sacked by the Normans. The Normans had mainly pillaged the old city, which was then one of the richest cities in Italy. After days of unending violence, the Romans rose up causing the Normans to set fire to the city. Many of the buildings of Rome were gutted on the Capitol and Palatine hills along with the area between the Colosseum and the Lateran. In the end the ravaged Roman populace succumbed to the Normans.
Sunset Crater is formed in Arizona. Sunset Crater is the youngest in a string of volcanoes (the San Francisco volcanic field) that is related to the nearby San Francisco Peaks.
First Crusade, under Pope Urban II, raises 100,000 men and captures Jerusalem.
Southern Song Dynasty in China. Era of growth of Neo-Confucianism.
Genghis Khan, Mongol chief, born.
Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, is killed by knights loyal to Henry II.

Third Crusade -  elderly Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa responded to the call immediately. He took up the Cross at Mainz Cathedral and was the first to set out for the Holy Land with an army of 12,000–15,000 men, including 4,000 knights.
King Henry II of England died after a surprise attack by his son Richard the Lionheart and King Philip II.

Third Crusade - the Crusader army was surprised in camp by a 10,000-man Turkish force of the Sultanate of Rûm near Philomelion on the evening of 7 May. The Crusader army counterattacked with 2,000 infantry and cavalry under the leadership of Frederick VI, Duke of Swabia and Berthold, Duke of Merania, putting the Turks to flight and killing 4,174–5,000 of them
Third Crusade - While crossing the Saleph River, Frederick's horse slipped, throwing him against the rocks; he then drowned in the river.
Ohio's groups Late Woodland Indians live in the "South Fort" and in the valley of the Little Miami. Did not build earthworks.
The Mongols defeat Northern China.

John, King of England, puts an embargo on wheat exported to Flanders, in an attempt to force an allegiance between the states. He also puts a levy of a fifteenth on the value of cargo exported to France, and disallows the export of wool to France without a special license. The levies are enforced in each port by at least six men, including one churchman and one knight.

The Fourth Crusade gathers in Venice. Summoned by Pope Innocent III, they are tasked with taking Jerusulem. The crusading army was expected to consist of 4,500 knights (as well as 4,500 horses), 9,000 squires, and 20,000 foot-soldiers. Venice supplied ships to take them on their crusade.

Fourth Crusade – Siege of Zara (Zadar in Croatia): In the first major action of the Crusade, the Crusaders besiege and conquer Zadar in Dalmatia. Unable to pay the Republic of Venice in cash for its contributions to the Crusade, the Crusaders agree to sack the city (an economic rival to Venice), despite letters from Pope Innocent III forbidding such an action, and threatening excommunication (which is carried out at the urging of Emeric, King of Hungary). This is the first attack against a Catholic city by Catholic Crusaders.

Fourth Crusade - en-route to Jerusalem, the Crusader leadership entered into an agreement with the Byzantine prince Alexios Angelos to divert the Crusade to Constantinople and restore his deposed father as Emperor.
Pope Innocent III rescinds the excommuniction of the non-Venetians in the Fourth Crusade.
Fourth Crusade - the bulk of the Crusaders reached Constantinople, while smaller contingents continued to Acre.
Fourth Crusade - following clashes outside Constantinople, Alexios was crowned co-Emperor.
Fourth Crusade - Alexios is deposed by a popular uprising.
Alexios is killed.

Fourth Crusade - After the death of Alexois, the crusaders are unable to recieve any payments from him, so they captured and plundered the city's enormous wealth. Only a handful of the Crusaders continued to the Holy Land thereafter.

The streets of Rome were again in flames when the struggle between Pope Innocent III's family and its rivals, the powerful Orsini family, led to riots in the city. Many ancient buildings were then destroyed by machines used by the rival bands to besiege their enemies in the innumerable towers and strongholds which were a hallmark of the Middle Age Italian towns.
Famine in England, 20,000 died in London alone.
Mongols burn Moscow.

In Rome, the papacy experienced increasing conflict with the leaders and churches of the Holy Roman Empire and the Byzantine Empire. The latter culminated in the East-West Schism, dividing the Catholic Church and Eastern Orthodox Church.

Nicaean Empire recovered Constantinople and restored the Byzantine Empire after the conquest of Constantinople by the Fourth Crusade caused the fragmentation of the Empire into three rump states centred in Nicaea, Trebizond and Epirus.
Thomas Aquinas dies.
Collapse of the Anasazi civilization (near the four corners area so southern Utah), widespread famine occurred
Conquest of North and South China by Mongol armies -- establishment of Mongol ruling house, the Yuan in China. Capital moved to Beijing.
The Jubilee of Pope Boniface VIII is celebrated. It is at this celebration that Giovanni Villani decides to write his universal history of Florence, the Cronica.
A census in Imperial China finds that it has roughly 60 million inhabitants.
Amsterdam is officially declared a city.
The Dulcinian sect begins when Gherardo Segarelli, founder of the Apostolic Brethren, is burned at the stake in Parma, during a brutal repression of the Apostolics.

The Battle of Bapheus between an Ottoman army under Osman I and a Byzantine army under George Mouzalon. The battle ended in a crucial Ottoman victory, cementing the Ottoman state and heralding the final capture of Byzantine Bithynia by the Turks. Osman I lays the seeds for the future Ottoman Empire.

The Great Famine of 1315–1317 (occasionally dated 1315–1322) was the first of a series of large-scale crises that struck Europe early in the 14th century. Most of Europe (extending east to Russia and south to Italy) was affected. The famine caused millions of deaths over an extended number of years and marked a clear end to the period of growth and prosperity from the 11th to the 13th centuries.
Osman the First's son, Orhan, captured the northwestern Anatolian city of Bursa, making it the new capital of the Ottoman state and supplanting Byzantine control in the region.

A great famine takes place in Southern Europe. It is known to historians of Catalonia as Lo mal any primer, "the First Bad Year" (equivalent to the Great Famine of 1315–1317 further north), an early notice of the catastrophes of the second half of this century.

The Hundred Years' War begins, a series of conflicts waged from 1337 to 1453 by the House of Plantagenet, rulers of the Kingdom of England, against the French House of Valois, over the right to rule the Kingdom of France.

Edward and his fleet sailed from England and arrived off the Zwin estuary the next day. The French fleet assumed a defensive formation off the port of Sluis. The English fleet deceived the French into believing they were withdrawing. When the wind turned in the late afternoon, the English attacked with the wind and sun behind them. The French fleet was almost completely destroyed in what became known as the Battle of Sluys. England dominated the English Channel for the rest of the war, preventing French invasions.
Edward mounted a major invasion across the channel, landing in Normandy's Cotentin, at St. Vaast. The English army captured the completely unguarded Caen in just one day, surprising the French.

Philip of France appealed to his Scottish allies to help with a diversionary attack on England. King David II of Scotland responded by invading northern England, but his army was defeated and he was captured at the Battle of Neville's Cross.
Edward proceeded north unopposed and besieged the city of Calais on the English Channel, capturing it.
Black Death (Plague) kills one-quarter of Europe's population.

The plague had passed and England was able to recover financially, King Edward's son and namesake, the Prince of Wales, later known as the Black Prince, led a Chevauchée from Gascony into France, during which he pillaged Avignonet and Castelnaudary, sacked Carcassonne, and plundered Narbonne.

Black Monday. A freak hail storm struck and killed an estimated 1,000 English soldiers. The storm was so devastating that it caused more English casualties than any of the previous battles of the war.

The Treaty of Brétigny is ratified, between King Edward III of England and King John II of France (the Good). In retrospect it is seen as having marked the end of the first phase of the Hundred Years' War (1337–1453)—as well as the height of English power on the Continent.

The Battle of Cocherel, between the forces of Charles V of France and the forces of Charles II of Navarre (known as Charles the Bad), over the succession to the dukedom of Burgundy. The result was a French victory.
Dynastic founder Zhu Yuanzhang leads military rout of remnants of Yuan forces and reestablishes Chinese rule in China.

John of Gaunt, accompanied by John de Montfort, Duke of Brittany leads a force of 9,000 men out from Calais on a major chevauchée. While initially successful as French forces were insufficiently concentrated to oppose them, the English began to meet further resistance as they moved south. By the end of December they were in Bordeaux, starving, ill-equipped and having lost over half of the 30,000 horses with which they had left Calais. Although the march across France had been a remarkable feat, it was a military failure.

Henry le Despenser published the bull Nuper cum vinea of Urban VI offering plenary indulgences to both the living and the dead in return for contributions proportional to or consistent with the donor's wealth to the general crusade against the Clementists
Charles VI ascends to the French throne.

The Peasant's Revolt. A royal official, John Bampton, in Essex, attempts to collect unpaid poll taxes in Brentwood which ends in a violent confrontation that rapidly spread across the south-east of the country. A wide spectrum of rural society, including many local artisans and village officials, rose up in protest, burning court records and opening the local gaols. The rebels sought a reduction in taxation, an end to the system of unfree labour known as serfdom, and the removal of the King's senior officials and law courts.
The Peasant's Revolt. English King Richard, 14 years old, left the city to meet Wat Tyler and the rebels at Smithfield. Violence broke out, and Richard's party killed Tyler.
The Peasant's Revolt. Unrest continued until the intervention of Henry le Despenser, who defeated a rebel army at the Battle of North Walsham

John Wycliffe formulated his doctrine of the Lord's Supper in twelve short sentences, and made it a duty to advocate it everywhere. Then the English hierarchy proceeded against him. The chancellor of the University of Oxford had some of the declarations pronounced heretical. When this was announced to Wycliffe, he declared that no one could change his convictions. He then appealed – not to the pope nor to the ecclesiastical authorities of the land, but to the king. He published his great confession upon the subject and also a second writing in English intended for the common people.
The Peasant's Revolt. Richard mobilised 4,000 soldiers to restore order. Most of the rebel leaders were tracked down and executed; by November, at least 1,500 rebels had been killed.

John Wycliffe was summoned before a synod at Oxford. He still commanded the favour of the court and of Parliament, to which he addressed a memorial. He was neither excommunicated then, nor deprived of his living.
Henry le Despenser sets sail from Sandwich for Calais, France on the Norwich Crusade.
Henry le Despenser sieges Ypres.
Henry le Despenser attacked the defences of Ypres with artillery, firing on the Messines Gate and damaging it, but not enough to cause the city defences to be breached.
Henry le Despenser abandons the siege of Ypres after failing to breach the city.
Henry le Despenser's Ghent allies abandon the siege of Ypres.
Henry le Despenser is impeached in parliment in front of the King for his failed crusade to France.
Henry le Despenser's captains turn over Francs to the English government that they recieved as bribes during the failed crusade to France.
John Wycliffe dies of a stroke while saying mass.
Peace of Tournai was an agreement between the Burgundian Duke Philip II and the rebellious city of Ghent (France).
The Ottoman victory at Kosovo effectively marked the end of Serbian power in the region, paving the way for Ottoman expansion into Europe.
The Battle of Nicopolis, widely regarded as the last large-scale crusade of the Middle Ages, failed to stop the advance of the victorious Ottoman Turks.
William Sawtry, a priest in England, was reportedly burned for his belief that "bread remains in the same nature as before" after consecration by a priest.

The rival geniuses Lorenzo Ghiberti and Filippo Brunelleschi competed for the contract to build the bronze doors for the Baptistery of the Florence Cathedral (Ghiberti won). This marks the beginning of the Renaissance.
In the Battle of Ankara, Timur defeated the Ottoman forces and took Sultan Bayezid I as a prisoner, throwing the empire into disorder.
Mehmed I emerged as the sultan and restored Ottoman power.
The Council of Constance declared Wycliffe a heretic, and banned his writings, effectively both excommunicating him retroactively and making him an early forerunner of Protestantism.
Prince Henry the Navigator of Portugal ventures into the Atlantic Ocean, discovering how to use winds to return back to Portugal. This begins the age of discovery.

Masaccio paints "The Tribute Money". The fresco is located in the Brancacci Chapel of the basilica of Santa Maria del Carmine, Florence. It is the first use of linear perspective since ancient Roman times, and is an outstanding example of early renaissance art.
Charles VII ascends to the French throne.
Vlad the Impaler born in Wallachia, now southern Romania.
Joan of Arc burned to death by the English. Fought bravely for the French.

Ottoman King Murad II repelled the Crusade of Varna by defeating the Hungarian, Polish, and Wallachian armies under Władysław III of Poland (also King of Hungary) and John Hunyadi at the Battle of Varna, although Albanians under Skanderbeg continued to resist.
Donato Bramante, born as Donato di Pascuccio d'Antonio and also known as Bramante Lazzari is born.in Fermignano near Urbino.

Under Pope Nicholas V, the Renaissance can be said to have begun in Rome, heralding a period in which the city became the centre of Humanism. He was the first Pope to embellish the Roman court with scholars and artists, including Lorenzo Valla and Vespasiano da Bisticci.
John Hunyadi attacked the Ottomon Empire with an army of Hungarian and Wallachian forces, but was defeated at the Second Battle of Kosovo.
Famine in the Aztec Empire, interpreted as the gods' need for sacrifices.
Leonardo da Vinci is born in the Tuscan hill town of Vinci, in the lower valley of the Arno river in the territory of the Medici-ruled Republic of Florence.
Volcano, Kuwae, Vanuatu: A massive eruption ejects 32-39 km3 of material.

Ottoman King Mehmed the Conqueror, reorganized both state and military and conquered Constantinople. Mehmed allowed the Orthodox Church to maintain its autonomy and land in exchange for accepting Ottoman authority.
Louis XI ascends to the French throne.
Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni is born in Caprese, known today as Caprese Michelangelo, a small town situated in Valtiberina, near Arezzo, Tuscany.

Tomás de Torquemada is appointed Grand Inquistor in Spain, and reorganized the Spanish Inquisition (originally based in Castile in 1478), establishing tribunals in Sevilla, Jaén, Córdoba, Ciudad Real, and (later) Saragossa. His quest was to rid Spain of all heresy. Over 2000 people are killed.
Charles VIII ascends to the French throne.
Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino is born in the central Italian city of Urbino in the Marche region, where his father Giovanni Santi was court painter to the Duke.
Antonio da Correggio is born in Correggio, Italy, a small town near Reggio Emilia.

The Alhambra Decree (also known as the Edict of Expulsion; Spanish: Decreto de la Alhambra, Edicto de Granada) is issued by the joint Catholic Monarchs of Spain (Isabella I of Castile and Ferdinand II of Aragon) ordering the expulsion of practising Jews from the Kingdoms of Castile and Aragon and its territories and possessions by 31 July of that year.
Christopher Columbus lands on Guanahani, Bahamas.
Louis XII ascends to the French throne.
Leonardo da Vinci completes the Last Supper. It covers an end wall of the dining hall at the monastery of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Milan, Italy.
Leonardo da Vinci completes the Mona Lisa.
Work begins on the reconstruction of St. Peter's Basilica. The architect Bramante designs the new monumental structure - the grandest European architectural commission of the 16th century,
Michelangelo begins decorating the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in Rome.
Henry VIII becomes king of England.
Bramante designs one of the most harmonious buildings of the Renaissance: the Tempietto of San Pietro in Montorio on the Janiculum.

Raphael completes The Stanza della segnatura ("Room of the Signatura") was the first to be decorated by Raphael's frescoes. It was the study housing the library of Julius II, in which the Signatura of grace tribunal was originally located.
Michelangelo completes the Sistine Chapel in Rome.
Raphael completes a portrait of Pope Julius II.
Ottoman Empire Sultan Selim I dramatically expanded the Empire's eastern and southern frontiers by defeating Shah Ismail of Safavid Persia, in the Battle of Chaldiran.
Francis I ascends to the French throne.
Martin Luther, Augustinian monk, preaching faith over works, attacked abuse of selling papal indulgences by posting 95 theses (propositions) on Wittenberg's church door.
Tiziano Vecelli , known in English as Titian, completes The Assumption of the Virgin on the high altar of the Basilica di Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari or Frari church in Venice.
Hernando Cortez begins conquest of Mexico.
Fernando Magellan discovered the Straights of Magellan, Tierra del Fuego, Ladrones and Philippines for Spain.
Suleiman the Magnificent captured Belgrade.

Titian completes Bacchus and Ariadne. It is one of a cycle of paintings on mythological subjects produced for Alfonso I d'Este, Duke of Ferrara, for the Camerino d'Alabastro – a private room in his palazzo in Ferrara decorated with paintings based on classical texts.
Correggio completes The Lamentation of Christ.
Giovanni da Verrazano, Italian employed by the French, explored New England Coast and New York Bay.

Suleiman the Magnificent conquered the southern and central parts of the Kingdom of Hungary as part of the Ottoman–Hungarian Wars, and, after his historic victory in the Battle of Mohács, he established Turkish rule in the territory of present-day Hungary (except the western part) and other Central European territories.

Rome is sacked by unruly Imperial troops of Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor. After the execution of some 1,000 defenders, the pillage began. The city was devastated for several days, many of the citizens were killed or took shelter outside the walls. Of 189 Swiss Guards on duty only 42 survived. The Pope himself was imprisoned for months in Castel Sant'Angelo. The sack marked the end of one of the most splendid eras of modern Rome, and the end of the High Renaissance.
Correggio completes The Assumption of the Virgin decorating the dome of the Cathedral of Parma, Italy.
Ottoman Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent fails to take Vienna in the Siege of the Guns.
Jacques Cartier discovers St. Lawrence, reaches site of Montreal.
Francisco Coronado, searching for gold, explored the Southwest north of the Rio Grande. Hernando de Alarcon discovers the Colorado River. Don Garcia Lopez de Cardenas discovers the Grand Canyon.
The French conquer Nice with the help of the Ottoman Empire.
Nicolas Copernicus publishes De revolutionibus orbium coelestium which proposes that the sun, not the earth, is at the center of the universe.
Francisco Coronado dies of an infectious disease, bankrupt from his failed expedition, and is buried under the alter of the Church of Santo Domingo in Mexico City.
Henry II ascends to the French throne.
The French conquer Corsica with the help of the Ottoman Empire.
Macao ceded to Portugal as colony by China.
Frances II ascends to the French throne.
Charles IX ascends to the French throne.

The Massacre of Wassy. The second Duke of Guise, travelling to his estates, stopped in Wassy (aka Vassy) and decided to attend Mass. He found a large congregation of Huguenots holding religious ceremonies in a barn that was their church. Some of the duke's party attempted to push their way inside and were repulsed. Events escalated, stones began to fly, and the Duke was struck. Outraged, he ordered his men to fortify the town and set fire to the church, killing 63 unarmed Huguenots and wounding over a hundred.
William Shakespeare born.

St. Bartholomew's Day massacre. King Charles IX of France ordered the killing of a group of Huguenot leaders, including Coligny, and the slaughter spread throughout Paris. Lasting several weeks, the massacre expanded outward to other urban centres and the countryside. Modern estimates for the number of dead across France vary widely, from 5,000 to 30,000.
Henry III ascends to the French throne.
Famine in England which gave rise to the Poor Law system.
Henry IV ascends to the French throne. This is the beginning of the House of Bourbon.
Jamestown Settlers: A fleet of ships leaves England for America.
Jamestown Settlers: Ships at Cape Comfort, a vanguard boat stopped at Kecoughtan where the natives welcomed the English.

Jamestown Settlers: "The thirteenth day, we came to our seating place in Paspihas Countrey, some eight miles from the point of Land, which I made mention before: where our shippes doe lie so neere the shoare that they are moored to the Trees in six fathom water."

Jamestown Settlers: "Hereupon the President was contented the Fort should be pallisadoed, the ordinance mounted, his men armed and exercised, for many were the assaults and Ambuscadoes of the Salvages ..." John Smith, Proceedings (Barbour 1964). 200 armed Indians attack Jamestown, killing 1 and wounding 11.
Jamestown Settlers: John Smith released from arrest and sworn in as member of the Council.
Jamestown Settlers: Newport sails for England.
Jamestown Settlers: Newport returns with the First Supply and about 100 new settlers, finds only 38 survivors.
Seven ships arrive at Jamestown, Sea Venture wrecked on Bermuda. 200-300 men, women, and children.
Louis XIII ascends to the French throne.

Gates (acting as Virginia's first governor until arrival of Thomas West-Lord De La Warr), John Rolfe, Ralph Hamor, Sir George Somers, and other survivors of the Sea Venture wrecked at Bermuda arrive at Jamestown. Find 60 survivors of the starving time.

Gates decides to abandon Jamestown. "This consultation taking effect, our governor, having caused to be carried aboard all the arms and all the best things in the store which might to the adventurers make some commodity upon sale thereof at home, and burying our ordnances before the fort gate which looked into the river, ..." William Strachey (Wright 1964:76)
Gates' convoy meets Lord De La Warr's ships at Mulberry Island.

" ... relanded all his men at the fort again." William Strachey (Wright 1964:77) "Upon His Lordship's landing at the south gate of the palisade (which looks into the river), our governor caused his company in arms to stand in order and make a guard. ... and after marched up into the town, where at the gate I bowed with the colors and let them fall at His Lordship's feet, who passed on into the chapel .. " William Strachey (Wright 1964:84)

English launch major attack on the Paspahegh village, capturing and executing the Queen and her children, burning houses and cutting down corn fields. Subsequent use of word Paspahegh in documents refers to their former territory.
De La Warr leaves for England, George Percy is Deputy Governor until arrival of Thomas Dale, about 150 people left.

Sir Thomas Gates, Lt.-Governor returns to Virginia with 280 people and assumes control. "Sir Thomas Gates ... happily arrived about the second of August, with sixe good Shippes, men, provisions and cattle ... the resolution of Sir Thomas Dale, now wholy busied (our land fortifications to weake to withstand a forraigne Enemy) ..." Hamor (1957:28).
John Rolfe imports tobacco seeds from Trinidad, Nicotiana tabacum, native tobacco was Nicotiana rustica to the colony in Virginia.
John Rolfe exports first crop of improved tobacco from Virginia.
Pocahontas captured and brought to Jamestown.
John Rolfe makes first shipment of West Indian tobacco grown in Virginia to England.
John Rolfe and Pocahontas married at Jamestown.
Galileo Galilei is forced to recant heliocentrism by the Catholic Church and spends the rest of his life under house arrest.

Nicolas Copernicus "De revolutionibus orbium coelestium" which proposes that the sun, not the earth, is at the center of the universe, is banned by the Catholic Church. It was first published 70 years earlier.
John Rolfe, Pocahontas, and son depart Virginia for England.

John Rolfe lists settlements at Henrico with 38 men under Capt. Smalley, Bermuda Nether Hundred with 119 under Capt. Yeardley, West and Sherley Hundred with 25 under Capt. Maddeson, James Towne with 50 under Lt. Sharpe, Kequoughtan with 20 under Capt. George Webb, and Dales Gifte with 17 under Lt. Cradock.
Johannes Kepler publishes "Epitome Astronomiae Copernicanae" which extends Copernicus' ideas of a heliocentric universe with three laws of planetary motion.

The Thirty Years' War begins in Central Europe between. One of the most destructive conflicts in human history, it resulted in eight million fatalities not only from military engagements but also from violence, famine, and plague. Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire, most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies.
Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor dies, leaving the Holy Roman Empire without an official leader, to deal with the Bohemian Revolt.
Battle of Sablat: Protestant forces are defeated.
In Jamestown, Virginia, the first representative assembly in the Americas, the House of Burgesses, convenes for the first time.
Battle of Věstonice – Bohemian forces defeat the Austrians.
Frederick V of the Palatinate is elected King of Bohemia by the states of the Bohemian Confederacy.
Ferdinand II, Archduke of Austria and King of Bohemia, is elected Holy Roman Emperor by the prince-electors.
The first African slaves are brought to North America, on an English privateer ship, to the English Colony of Point Comfort, Virginia.
The Treaty of Munich is signed by Ferdinand II and Maximilian I, Elector of Bavaria.
Battle of Humenné – Polish Lisowczycy troops assist the Holy Roman Emperor by defeating a Transylvanian force, forcing Gabor Bethlen to raise his siege of Vienna.
Thirty-eight colonists from England disembark in Berkeley Hundred, Virginia from the Margaret of Bristol and give thanks to God (considered by some to be the first Thanksgiving in the Americas).
Prince Bethlen Gabor signs a peace treaty with Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor.
The oldest stone church in French North America, Notre-Dame-des-Anges, is begun at Quebec City, Canada.
Under the terms of the Treaty of Ulm, the Protestant Union declares neutrality, and ceases to support Frederick V of Bohemia.
Mayflower departs from Plymouth, England.
Battle of Cecora: The Ottoman Empire defeats Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth–Moldavian troops.
Battle of White Mountain: Catholic forces are victorious in only two hours near Prague.
Mayflower arrives at Cape Cod. The Mayflower Compact is signed.
Pilgrims land at Plymouth, MA.
Myles Standish is appointed as the first commander of Plymouth Colony.
Samoset, a Mohegan, visits the settlers of Plymouth Colony and greets them: "Welcome, Englishmen! My name is Samoset."
The Pilgrims of Plymouth Colony sign a peace treaty with Massasoit of the Wampanoags.
The Mayflower sets sail from Plymouth, on a return trip to England.
The Twelve Years' Truce between the Dutch Republic and the Spanish Empire expires, and both sides prepare to resume the Eighty Years' War.
The Protestant Union is formally dissolved.
Twenty-seven Czech lords are executed on the Old Town Square in Prague, as a consequence of the Battle of White Mountain.
Huguenot rebellions: Saint-Jean-d'Angély is taken, after a 26-day siege by Royal forces.
Battle of Neu Titschein: Remnants of the Bohemian army temporarily hold off the Imperial advance in Silesia.
Battle of Khotyn: Polish troops hold off a large Ottoman army for over a month.[2]
The Pilgrims of Plymouth Colony and Wampanoags celebrate a harvest feast (three days), later regarded as the First Thanksgiving, noted for peaceful co-existence.
The ship Fortune arrives at Plymouth Colony, with 35 more settlers.

The Peace of Nikolsburg is signed between Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor and Gabor Bethlen, Prince of Transylvania. Bethlen agrees to renounce his claims to Hungary. In return Bethlen receives several counties and lands along the eastern border of the Holy Roman Empire, and Moravia is granted religious freedom.
In the Gregorian calendar, January 1 is declared as the first day of the year, instead of March 25.
King James I of England disbands the English Parliament.
Jamestown massacre: Algonquian natives kill 347 English settlers outside Jamestown, Virginia (⅓ of the colony's population), and burn the Henricus settlement. This begins the American Indian Wars.

Skirmish at Mingolsheim: Protestant forces under Mansfeld and Georg Friedrich of Baden-Durlach defeat the Imperial forces under Tilly. The Protestants win, but afterwards Tilly links up with a Spanish army under Gonzalo de Córdoba, greatly increasing his strength.

While waiting for the Protestant forces of Christian the Younger of Brunswick to join them, Mansfeld and Georg Friedrich of Baden-Durlach split up their forces as a diversion for the Imperial army of Tilly. Their plan fails, as Tilly manages to cut off Georg Friedrich at Wimpfen. At the ensuing Battle of Wimpfen, Georg Friedrich's army is almost completely destroyed.
The Huguenot city of Royan is taken by royal forces, after a short siege.
The Huguenot city of Nègrepelisse is taken, after a short siege by royal forces. The entire population of the city is subsequently massacred, and the city is burned to the ground.

Imperial forces under Tilly attempt to prevent Christian the Younger of Brunswick from moving his army across the Main River, to link up with Mansfeld. At the Battle of Höchst, Tilly manages to inflict considerable casualties on the Protestant forces, as well as seizing Brunswick's baggage train. Nonetheless, the bulk of Brunswick's forces manage to unite with Mansfeld.

After Mansfeld fails to relieve the siege of Heidelberg, Frederick V of the Palatinate cancels Mansfeld's contract and disbands his army. The unemployed army of Mansfeld and Christian the Younger of Brunswick is subsequently hired by the Dutch.

While on their way to relieve the Siege of Bergen-op-Zoom in the Netherlands, the army of Mansfeld and Christian of Brunswick is blocked by a Spanish army, led by Gonzalo de Córdoba. In the Battle of Fleurus, Cordoba manages to fight off the Protestant assault. The next day, Cordoba surprises the retreating Protestant army with his cavalry, resulting in the destruction of most of the Protestant army.
Armand Jean du Plessis becomes Cardinal Richelieu.
The first Huguenot rebellion ends, with the signing of the Treaty of Montpellier.
A white oak seed germinates in Dysart Woods near Athens, Ohio. It will live 373 years, until 1998, and at the time of its fall (due to storm) will be the oldest known tree east of the Mississippi.
Peter Minuit buys Manhattan from the Indians for $24 worth of trinkets.
Louis XIV ascends to the French throne.
Manchu military forces complete invasion and conquest of China.  Found Manchu ruling house, the Qing.
The Thirty Years' War ends. The Holy Roman Empire is replaced by the state system.
Taj Mahal completed by 20,000 workers for Emperor Shah Jahan's wife.
Famine throughout much of Ireland during the Cromwellian conquest of Ireland.

James, Duke of York conveyed the portion of the land that eventually became New Jersey to Sir George Carteret and Lord John Berkeley, friends and advisors to the king of England and the court of Charles II
Great Plague in London kills 68,000 people.
Great Fire in London destroys 13,200 houses and 89 churches.
John Milton publishes "Paradise Lost". Milton redefines the concept of the Devil into the form that is commonly accepted today.

Father Jacques Marquette and Louis Jolliet, a French-Canadian explorer, leave St. Ignace, Michigan on May 17, with two canoes and five voyageurs of French-Indian ancestry. They followed Lake Michigan to Green Bay and up the Fox River, nearly to its headwaters. From there, they were told to portage their canoes a distance of slightly less than two miles through marsh and oak plains to the Wisconsin River.
Father Jacques Marquette and Louis Jolliet entered the Mississippi near present-day Prairie du Chien, Wisconsin.

Following the river to the mouth of the Arkansas River—within 435 miles of the Gulf of Mexico—Marquette and Joliet learned that it flowed through hostile Spanish domains. Fearing an encounter with Spanish colonists and explorers, they decided to return homeward by way of the Illinois River
Father Jacques Marquette and Louis Jolliet winter in what will later be Chicago.
French map first depicts the Ohio River and credits its discovery to LaSalle, although Marquette and Jolliet may have been the first to discover it.
Lord Berkeley eventually sold his half of New Jersey to Quakers Edward Byllynge and John Fenwick in 1674, hence dividing the territory into West Jersey and East Jersey.
Father Jacques Marquette dies of dysentary will journeying from his mission in Green Bay back to St. Ignacious, Michigan.

The resident proprietors created the West Jersey Council of Proprietors, consisting of 100 shares, with dividends paid in real land. Soon after, the West Jersey Society was formed; it consisted of English businessmen who purchased 20 of these shares from Dr. Daniel Coxe, later chief physician to Queen Anne.
Famine throughout Scotland which killed 5–15% of the population.
Nineteen persons are hanged and one man crushed to death in Salem, MA due to accusations of witchcraft.
Great Famine of Estonia killed about a fifth of Estonian and Livonian population (70,000–75,000 people). Famine also hit Sweden (80,000–100,000 dead).
The West Jersey Society surrendered its claims to the government of West Jersey to the Crown in 1702, due to instability and political strife, but it retained title and right to the land.
British take Gibraltar from Spain.
Famine in East Prussia killed 250,000 people or 41% of its population.
The Ottoman Empire declares war on Russia.

The Treaty of the Lutsk was a secret agreement signed in Lutsk, Poland-Lithuania (now in Ukraine) between the Tsardom of Russia and the Ottoman Protectorate of Moldavia, allowing the Russian army to cross its territory and place garrisons in Moldavian fortresses.

The Russian Army, having gathered near the Moldavian capital lași, the combined army started the march southwards along the Prut River with the intention of crossing the Danube and invade the Balkan peninsula.

The four-day Battle of Stănileşti, an ill-prepared operation on the Prut floodplain during which the joint Moldavian and Russian troops, the former under the command of Cantemir and the latter under Peter the Great and Boris Sheremetev, were surrounded and forced to surrender to the larger Ottoman army commanded by Grand Vizier Baltacı Mehmet Pasha.

The Treaty of the Pruth was signed on the banks of the river Pruth between the Ottoman Empire and the Tsardom of Russia, ending the Russo-Turkish War. The treaty was a political victory for the Ottoman Empire.
Louis XV ascends to the French throne.
The new Ottoman Grand Vizier Damat Ali re-conquered Morea from the Venetians.
Prince Eugene of Savoy (Austria) defeated the Turks at Petrovaradin. The Banat and its capital Timişoara was conquered.

The Treaty of Passarowitz or Treaty of Požarevac was the peace treaty signed in Požarevac, a town in the Ottoman Empire (modern Serbia), between the Ottoman Empire on one side and Austria of the Habsburg Monarchy and the Republic of Venice on the other.
Wyandotte, Mingo, Ottawa, Delaware, Shawnee and Miami Indians are established in several villages across Ohio. The southern of two known Mingo towns was located in present day Columbus.
Baroque and Rococo architecture flourishes in Rome. Work on the Trevi Fountain begins.

The Treaty of Belgrade, known as the Belgrade peace was the peace treaty signed in Belgrade, Habsburg Kingdom of Serbia (today Serbia), by the Ottoman Empire on one side and the Habsburg Monarchy on the other, that ended the Austro–Turkish War (1737–39).
Irish Famine (Irish: Bliain an Áir, meaning the Year of Slaughter) in the Kingdom of Ireland, is estimated to have killed between 13% and 20% of the 1740 population of 2.4 million people.
Union Furnace established on the Spruce Run near High Bridge.

English iron investors William Allen, later a Supreme Court justice and possibly the wealthiest man in Philadelphia, and Joseph Turner, a sea captain also active in politics, initially leased 3,000 acres from the West Jersey Society along the South Branch of the Raritan River, and established the Union Iron Works in High Bridge.
British fort erected on Sandusky Bay.
Benjamin Franklin, flying a kite in a thunderstorm, proves lightning is electricity.
George Washington surrenders Fort Necessity to the French near Pittsburgh, during French and Indian Wars.

One of the first reportings of All Fools' Day was in "Poor Robin's Almanack" (no, not Poor Richard; but Poor Robin) on this day. Poor Robin said, 'The first of April, some do say, is set apart for All Fools' Day, but why the people call it so, nor I nor they themselves do know.
End of French and Indian Wars.
Hydrogen (1) Henry Cavendish discovers hydrogen.
Scottish inventor James Watt receives his first patent for an early version of his revolutionary Watt steam engine.
Pope Clement XIII dies the night before preparing an order to dissolve the Jesuits.

James Cook arrives in Tahiti, on the ship HM Bark Endeavour, preparing for the 1769 Transit of Venus observed from Tahiti on June 3. After the voyage, the data is found to be inaccurate in determining the distance between the Sun and Earth.

James Watt is granted a British patent for "A method of lessening the consumption of steam in steam engines" – the separate condenser,[4] a key improvement (first devised by Watt in 1765) which stimulates the Industrial Revolution.
Charles III of Spain sends Spanish missionaries, who found California missions in San Diego, Santa Barbara, San Francisco and Monterey, and begin the settlement of California.

A transit of Venus is followed five hours later by a total solar eclipse, the shortest such interval in historical times. The transit is viewed by King George III of Great Britain, at the Kew Observatory.
Father Junípero Serra founds Mission San Diego de Alcalá, the first of the 21 California missions.

Recently-appointed as the Governor of Spanish Louisiana, Irish-born soldier of fortune Alejandro O'Reilly sails into the French fort of La Balize with 21 Spanish ships, along with 2,056 soldiers, cannons and ammunition, and informs French Louisiana Governor Charles Philippe Aubry of his royal commission to take Louisiana on behalf of the King of Spain.
The party of Gaspar de Portolà becomes the first white group to set foot in the area now known as Santa Monica, California.
Napoleon Bonaparte born in Corsica.

Brescia Explosion: The city of Brescia, Italy is devastated when the Church of San Nazaro is struck by lightning. The resulting fire ignites 200,000 lb (90,000 kg) of gunpowder being stored there, causing a massive explosion, which destroys 1/6 of the city and kills 3,000 people. The disaster prompts the Roman Catholic Church to abandon their religious objection to using lightning rods to protect their property.

Massive droughts in Bengal lead to the Bengal famine of 1770, in which ten million people, a third of the population, will die, the worst natural disaster in human history (in terms of lives lost). The Maharajah of Mysore forces the British to agree to a treaty of mutual assistance in view of the famine, but the British East India Company increases its demands on the Bengali people to keep profits up.
James Cook lands in New Zealand, at Poverty Bay.
Dartmouth College is established in Hanover, New Hampshire, as John Wentworth, the Royal Governor, conveys a charter from King George III of England.
The Authorized King James Version of the Bible, in the Oxford standard text edited by Benjamin Blayney, is published in England.
Robert Taylor, an Irish immigrant, became works manager of the Union Forge in High Bridge.
Thomas Jefferson's home at Shadwell, Virginia is destroyed by fire and most of his books.

Christopher Seider, an 11-year-old boy in Boston at the British colony of Massachusetts, is shot and killed by a colonial official, Ebenezer Richardson. The funeral sets off anti-British protests that lead to the massacre days later.
Boston Massacre: Eleven American men are shot (five fatally) by British troops, in an event that helps start the American Revolutionary War five years later.
First voyage of James Cook: English explorer Captain James Cook and his crew aboard HMS Endeavour complete the circumnavigation of New Zealand.

The Townshend Acts were repealed by Britain's Parliament by the efforts of Prime Minister Frederick North, with the exception of the increased duties on imported tea. The American colonists, in turn, stopped their embargo on British imports.
A stampede, at a celebration of the newly wedded Marie Antoinette and Louis-Auguste in Paris, kills more than a hundred people.

Falklands Crisis (1770): Some 1,600 Spanish marines, sent by the Spanish governor of Buenos Aires in five frigates, seize Port Egmont in the Falkland Islands. The small British force present promptly surrenders.
Lexell's Comet (D/1770 L1) passes the Earth at a distance of 2184129 km, the closest approach by a comet in recorded history.
Phillis Wheatley becomes the first African American woman to have her work published, after having written a poetic elegy to the late Reverend George Whitefield.
Joseph Priestley, British chemist, recommends the use of a rubber to remove pencil marks.
Colonel Ebenezer Zane founds Wheeling.
War of the Regulation: North Carolina Governor William Tryon raises a militia, to put down the long-running uprising of backcountry militias against North Carolina's colonial government.
The first quarantines are started in Moscow and Saint Petersburg to fight the bubonic plague. Over the next 12 months, more than 52,000 people die from the plague in Moscow alone.

War of the Regulation – Battle of Alamance: Regulators reject an appeal by Governor Tryon to peacefully disperse. Governor Tryon's forces crush the rebellion, causing many Regulators to move to frontier areas outside of North Carolina.

The Society of Gentlemen Supporters of the Bill of Rights meets in the London Tavern and changes its platform from to a comprehensive program for British parliamentary reform in advance of the next election.
The first voyage of James Cook around the world ends as HMS Endeavour returns to England after almost three years.
Bloody Falls massacre: Chipewyan chief Matonabbee, traveling as the guide to Samuel Hearne on his Arctic overland journey, massacres a group of unsuspecting Inuit.
The Moscow plague riot results from an outbreak of bubonic plague, which kills 57,000.
The opera Ascanio in Alba by Wolfgang Mozart, age 15, premieres in Milan.
During the night the River Tyne, England, floods, destroying many bridges and killing several people; the replacement main bridge at Newcastle upon Tyne will not be completed until 1781.
