The cause of action in Sommersett's Case, which eventually leads to the end of slavery in Great Britain, begins when escaped slave James Sommersett is found imprisoned on the ship Ann and Mary.

Men, women and children of the Choctaw and Chickasaw tribes begin a 23-day encampment at Mobile, part of the British colony of West Florida, at the invitation of British Southern Indian superintendent John Stuart, as their leaders negotiate a treaty.

Oxygen (8) Car Willhelm Scheele obtains oxygen by heating mercuric oxide, silver carbonate, magnesium nitrate, and other nitrate salts. Scheele wrote about his findings to Lavoisier who was able to see the significance of the results.

Massachusetts legislator Samuel Adams persuades his colleagues to approve his plan for creating a Committee of Correspondence to begin a dialogue with the other American colonies concerning mutual problems with the United Kingdom.
Gaspee Affair: In an act of defiance against the British Navigation Acts, American patriots, led by Abraham Whipple, attack and burn the British customs schooner HMS Gaspee off of Rhode Island.
Somersett's Case: Lord Mansfield, the Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales, delivers the decision that leads to the end of slavery in England.

The second voyage of James Cook departs from Plymouth on Captain Cook's new ship, HMS Resolution and the companion ship HMS Adventure in an attempt to prove the existence of an uncharted continent even further south than New Zealand.
Samuel Adams and Joseph Warren form the first Committee of Correspondence.
Russian government offices reopen at Moscow and Saint Petersburg after being closed for 15 months because of an epidemic of bubonic plague.
Scottish scientist Daniel Rutherford isolates nitrogen gas from air.

Nitrogen (7) is discovered by the Scottish physician Daniel Rutherford who called it noxious air. Though he did not recognise it as an entirely different chemical substance, he clearly distinguished it from Joseph Black's "fixed air", or carbon dioxide.
Boston Tea Party.
An angry crowd in Boston, Massachusetts seizes, tars and feathers British customs collector and Loyalist John Malcolm, for striking a boy and a shoemaker, George Hewes, with his cane.

The Boston Journal makes the first reference to the "Stars and Stripes" flag to symbolize the American colonies, reporting that "The American ensign now sparkles a door which shall shortly flame from the skies."
The British Parliament passes the Boston Port Act, closing the port of Boston, Massachusetts as punishment for the Boston Tea Party.
Louis XVI ascends to the French throne.
The colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations issues the first call for an "Intercolonial Congress" that eventually is set up as the Continental Congress.

The Parliament of Great Britain passes the Quebec Act, setting out rules of governance for the colony of Quebec in British North America, enlarging its territory as far south as Ohio and granting freedom of religion for Roman Catholics.

The element oxygen is discovered for the third (and last) time – the second quantitatively, following the somewhat earlier work of Carl Wilhelm Scheele (1771–1772) by Joseph Priestley, who publishes the fact in 1775, and so names the element (and usually gets all the credit, because his work was published first).
The First Continental Congress assembles in Philadelphia.
George Mason and George Washington found the Fairfax County Militia Association, a military unit independent of British control.
English explorer James Cook becomes the first European to sight (and name) Norfolk Island in the Pacific Ocean, uninhabited at this date.
The Continental Congress in America adopts the first "Declaration of Rights", with 10 principles.
The word Liberty is first displayed on a flag raised by colonists in Taunton, Massachusetts, in defiance of British rule in Colonial America.
The first Continental Congress adjourns in Philadelphia.
The government of the Republic of Venice allows adventurer and ladies' man Giacomo Casanova to return home after a 17-year absence.
Daniel Boone retires from the Virginia colonial militia in order to devote his full time to establishing a settlement in Kentucky.
English chemist Joseph Priestley becomes the first person to discover and identify sulfur dioxide

A boycott called by the Continental Congress goes into effect, as participating merchants and supporters cease the importation or consumption of products from Great Britain, Ireland or the British West Indies.
Intense battle fought between whites and Indians at Point Pleasant.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart finishes a Sonata for Keyboard in C.
Francis Salvador is elected to the Provincial Congress of South Carolina, becoming the first Jewish public officeholder in North America.

Second voyage of James Cook: Captain James Cook circumnavigates, makes the first landing on and (on January 17) takes possession of South Georgia in the southern Atlantic Ocean, for the Kingdom of Great Britain. The following month he discovers the South Sandwich Islands.
The Parliament of Great Britain declares the Province of Massachusetts Bay to be in rebellion.
Daniel Boone begins blazing the widely-used Wilderness Road used by white settlers to reach Kentucky and Tennessee.
The first anti-slavery society in the United States is formed by a group of Quakers in Philadelphia.

Paul Revere and William Dawes, instructed by Dr. Joseph Warren, ride from Boston to Lexington, to warn John Hancock and Sam Adams that British forces are coming to take them prisoner, and to seize colonial weapons and ammunition in Concord.
Battles of Lexington and Concord: Hostility between Britain and its American colonies explodes into bloodshed, igniting the American Revolution.
The Second Continental Congress meets, elects John Hancock president, raises the Continental Army under George Washington as commander, and authorizes the colonies to adopt their own constitutions.
Col. Ethan Allen (joined by Col. Benedict Arnold) capture Ft. Ticonderoga.
The Continental Congress bans trade with Canada.
Battle of Lexington: American militiamen drive British troops back to Boston.
The British forces offer a pardon to all colonists who lay down their arms.
The Continental Congress names George Washington as commander of the Continental Army.
Over 1000 of British General William Howe's troops killed in the battle of Bunker Hill.
George Washington takes command of the 17,000-man Continental Army at Cambridge.

The Continental Congress issues the Declaration of the Causes and Necessity of Taking Up Arms, which contains the words: "Our cause is just. Our union is perfect... being with one mind resolved to die freemen rather than to live slaves...".
The Second Continental Congress appoints Benjamin Franklin to be the first Postmaster.
Second voyage of James Cook: HMS Resolution anchors off the south coast of England, Captain Cook having completed the first eastabout global circumnavigation.
Refusing to even look at the Olive Branch Petition, King George III issues a Proclamation of Rebellion against the American colonies.
The Continental Congress orders the establishment of the Continental Navy (later the United States Navy).
George III announces to Parliament that the American colonies are in an uprising, and must be dealt with accordingly.

Dunmore's Proclamation – Lord Dunmore, colonial governor of Virginia, signs a proclamation promising freedom for slaves of Patriots if they join Loyalist forces, thus losing the support of slaveowning planters.
Battle of Great Bridge: Victory by the Continental Army and militia leads to withdrawal of the British from the Colony of Virginia.
Battle of Quebec: British forces repulse an attack by Continental Army generals Richard Montgomery and Benedict Arnold, at Quebec City.
Burning of Norfolk: The town of Norfolk, Virginia is destroyed, by the combined actions of the British Royal Navy and occupying Patriot forces.
Thomas Paine publishes his pamphlet Common Sense ("written by an Englishman" in Philadelphia), arguing for independence from British rule in the Thirteen Colonies.
Edward Gibbon publishes the first volume of The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire.
American Patriots capture Dorchester Heights, dominating the port of Boston.
Threatened by Patriot cannons on Dorchester Heights, the British evacuate Boston, ending the 11‑month Siege of Boston.
Harvard College conferred the first honorary Doctor of Laws degree to George Washington.
Adam Weishaupt founds the Illuminati in Ingolstadt, Bavaria.
Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to renounce allegiance to King George III of Great Britain.
The Continental Congress appoints a Committee of Five to draft a Declaration of Independence.

Lt. José Joaquín Moraga leads a band of colonists from Monterey Presidio, landing on June 29 and, with Father Francisco Palóu, constructing the Mission San Francisco de Asís ("Mission Dolores") of the new Presidio of San Francisco, the oldest surviving building in the modern-day city.
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Turtle Gut Inlet: The American Continental Navy successfully challenges the British Royal Navy blockade off New Jersey.

Marquis Claude de Jouffroy and his colleagues had made a 13-metre (42 ft 8 in) working steamboat with rotating paddles, the Palmipède. The ship sailed on the Doubs River in June and July 1776, apparently the first steamship to sail successfully.
The final U.S. Declaration of Independence (with minor revisions) is written. The Continental Congress passes the Lee Resolution.
United States Declaration of Independence: The Continental Congress ratifies the declaration by the United States of its independence from the Kingdom of Great Britain
American Revolution – The Liberty Bell rings in Philadelphia, for the first public reading of the Declaration of Independence.
American Revolution – An angry mob in New York City topples the equestrian statue of George III of Great Britain in Bowling Green.
Most of the American colonies ratify the Declaration of Independence.
Hurricane: N.C. to Nova Scotia: called the Hurricane of Independence, it is believed that 4,170 in the U.S. and Canada died in the storm.
The Continental Congress officially names its union of states the United States.
Nathan Hale, executed by the British as a spy, says "I regret but that I have but one life to lose for my country."
Battle of Pell's Point: Troops of the American Continental Army resist a British and Hessian force in The Bronx.
Battle of White Plains: British forces arrive at White Plains, attack and capture Chatterton Hill from the Americans.
Battle of Fort Lee: The invasion of New Jersey, by British and Hessian forces, leads to the subsequent general retreat of the American Continental Army.
The second Continental Congress ends after a session that began on May 10, 1775, and continued for 582 days.

American Revolutionary War – Battle of Trenton: Washington's troops surprise the 1,500 Hessian troops under the command of Col. Johann Rall at 8 a.m. outside Trenton and score a victory,[2] taking 948 prisoners while suffering only five wounded.

American Revolutionary War: Battle of the Assunpink Creek, also known as the Second Battle of Trenton: American forces under the command of George Washington repulse a British attack near Trenton, New Jersey.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Princeton: American general George Washington defeats British general Charles Cornwallis.
Mission Santa Clara de Asís founded in what is now Santa Clara, California.
Vermont declares its independence from New York, becoming the Vermont Republic, an independent country, a status it retains until it joins the United States as the 14th state in 1791.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Spanktown, part of the Forage War

American Revolutionary War: Battle of Bound Brook: A British and Hessian force led by Lieutenant General Charles Cornwallis surprises a Continental Army outpost in New Jersey commanded by Major General Benjamin Lincoln.

American Revolutionary War: 16-year-old Sybil Ludington rides 40 miles through the night to warn militiamen under the control of her father Henry that British troops are planning to invade Danbury, Connecticut.
American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Ridgefield: A British invasion force engages and defeats Continental Army regulars and militia irregulars at Ridgefield, Connecticut.
Lachlan McIntosh and Button Gwinnett shoot each other during a duel near Savannah, Georgia. Gwinnett, a signer of the United States Declaration of Independence, dies three days later.

American Revolution: The Marquis de Lafayette lands near Charleston, South Carolina to help the Continental Congress train its army.
June 14 – The Stars and Stripes is adopted by the Continental Congress as the flag of the United States.
American Revolutionary War: Siege of Fort Ticonderoga – After a bombardment by British artillery under General John Burgoyne, American forces retreat from Fort Ticonderoga, New York.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Hubbardton – British forces engage American troops retreating from Fort Ticonderoga.

The U.S. Second Continental Congress passes a resolution that the services of Marquis de Lafayette "be accepted, and that, in consideration of his zeal, illustrious family and connexions, he have the rank and commission of major-general of the United States."
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Oriskany – Loyalists gain a tactical victory over Patriots; Iroquois fight on both sides.
George Washington is driven from Philadelphia by General Howe, winters at Valley Forge.
American Revolution – Battle of Germantown: Troops under George Washington are repelled by British troops under Sir William Howe.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Forts Clinton and Montgomery: British troops capture Fort Clinton and Fort Montgomery (Hudson River) and are able to dismantle the Hudson River Chain.
American Revolution – Second Battle of Saratoga: Battle of Bemis Heights: British General John Burgoyne is defeated by American troops.
General Burgoyne surrenders 5000 troops at Saratoga, New York to American General Horatio Gates.
The Articles of Confederation are submitted to the states for ratification.
San Jose, California is founded. It is the first pueblo in Spanish Alta California.
The United States celebrates its first Thanksgiving as a nation, marking the victory by the Americans over General John Burgoyne in the Battle of Saratoga in October.
American Revolution: George Washington's Continental Army goes into winter quarters at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania.
The third Pacific expedition of Capt. James Cook, with ships HMS Resolution and HMS Discovery, first view O'ahu then Kaua'i in the Hawaiian Islands, which he names the Sandwich Islands.
South Carolina becomes the first state to ratify the Articles of Confederation.
American Revolutionary War: In Paris the Treaty of Alliance and the Treaty of Amity and Commerce are signed by the United States and France, signaling official recognition of the new republic.
American Revolutionary War: Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben arrives at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania and begins to train the American troops.
Benedict Arnold signs US oath of allegiance at Valley Forge.
A total solar eclipse takes place across parts of USA from Texas to Virginia.
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Monmouth: George Washington's Continental Army battles the British general Sir Henry Clinton's army to a draw near Monmouth, New Jersey.
American Revolutionary War: the Wyoming Massacre takes place near Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, ending in a terrible defeat of the local colonists.
American Revolution – First Battle of Ushant: British and French fleets fight to a standoff.
American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Rhode Island takes place when the Continental Army attempts to retake Aquidneck Island from the British.
The Continental Congress passes the first budget of the United States.
The Massachusetts Banishment Act, providing punishment for Loyalists, is passed.
American Revolutionary War: the Cherry Valley massacre.
In the Hawaiian Islands, Capt. James Cook becomes the first European to land on Maui.
The first settlement is made in the area of what is now Louisville, Kentucky by 13 families under Colonel George Rogers Clark.
American Revolutionary War: Claudius Smith is hanged at Goshen, Orange County, New York for supposed acts of terrorism upon the people of the surrounding communities.
Captain James Cook dies on the Sandwich Islands (later known as the Hawaiian Islands) on his third and last voyage.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Vincennes.
American Revolutionary War: Benedict Arnold is court-martialed for malfeasance in his treatment of government property.
American Revolutionary War: In support of the U.S., Spain declares war on England.
American Revolutionary War: United States forces led by General Anthony Wayne capture Stony Point, New York from British troops.

American Revolutionary War: American forces led by Commodore Dudley Saltonstall launch the Penobscot Expedition in what is now Castine, Maine, resulting in the worst naval defeat in U.S. history until Pearl Harbor.
American Revolutionary War: Siege of Savannah.

American Revolution – Battle of Flamborough Head: The American ship Bonhomme Richard, commanded by John Paul Jones, engages the British ship Serapis. The Bonhomme Richard sinks, but the Americans board the Serapis and other vessels, and are victorious.
Battle of Baton Rouge: Spanish troops under Bernardo de Galvez capture the city from the British.
The Fort Wilson Riot takes place.
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Cape St. Vincent: British Admiral Sir George Rodney defeats a Spanish fleet.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Young's House
Pennsylvania is the first American state to abolish slavery.
American Revolutionary War: Siege of Charleston
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Monck's Corner
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Lenud's Ferry
American Revolutionary War: Charleston, South Carolina is taken by British forces.
Cumberland Compact signed by American settlers in the Cumberland Valley of Tennessee.
New England's Dark Day: An unaccountable darkness spreads over New England, regarded by some observers as a fulfillment of Bible prophecy.
American Revolutionary War: Bird's invasion of Kentucky,
American Revolutionary War: Waxhaw Massacre: Loyalist forces under Col. Banastre Tarleton kill surrendering American soldiers.
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Springfield: The American victory at Springfield effectively ends British ambitions in New Jersey.
Expédition Particulière: French soldiers arrive in Newport, Rhode Island to reinforce colonists in the American Revolutionary War.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Camden: British troops inflict heavy losses on a Patriot army at Camden, South Carolina.
Benedict Arnold gives detailed plans of West Point to Major John André. Three days later, André is captured with papers revealing that Arnold was planning to surrender West Point to the British.
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Kings Mountain: Patriot militia forces annihilate a Loyalists under British Major Patrick Ferguson at Kings Mountain in South Carolina.
American Revolutionary War – Battle of Blackstock's Farm
General Cornwallis surrenders at Yorktown.
Immanuel Kant publishes "Critique of Pure Reason"
The planet Uranus is discovered by William Herschel.
Superintendent of Finance Robert Morris goes before the United States Congress to recommend establishment of a national mint and decimal coinage.
Ninety six Delaware Indians, all peaceable Christians, are slaughtered at Gnadenhutten.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Little Mountain.
American Revolutionary War: Crawford expedition
Congress accepts Charles Thomson's design for the Great Seal of the United States. The bald eagle becomes the national bird of the United States.

George Washington orders the creation of the Badge of Military Merit (or the Order of the Purple Heart) to honor soldiers' merit in battle (reinstated later by Franklin D. Roosevelt and renamed to the more poetic "Purple Heart" to honor soldiers wounded in action).
American Revolutionary War: Review of the French troops under General Rochambeau by General George Washington at Verplanck's Point, New York.
American Revolutionary War: In Paris, representatives from the United States and the Kingdom of Great Britain sign preliminary peace articles (later formalized in the Treaty of Paris).

American Revolutionary War: Action of 12 December 1782: A naval engagement off Ferrol, Spain, in which the British ship HMS Mediator (1782) successfully attacks a convoy of French and American ships attempting to supply the United States.
Treaty of Paris, signed at the Palace of Versailles, ends Revolutionary War
General Washington orders the continental army disbanded.
Famine in Iceland caused by Laki eruption killed one-fifth of Iceland's population.
The Confederation Congress ratifies the Treaty of Paris with Great Britain to end the American Revolutionary War.
Jefferson creates a ban on slavery in a new territory.

Governor George Clinton of New York writes to Congress asking them to declare war against Vermont, which at this time is an unrecognized de facto independent state claimed by New York. Congress declined to do this.

The Land Ordinance of 1784 resolves that the territory ceded to the United States by the Treaty of Paris, or by individual states, and that already purchased or to be purchased from the Indian inhabitants, will be offered for sale by Congress and divided into future states.
Russia establishes their first colony in Kodiak, Alaska.
The Roman Catholic Apostolic Prefecture of the United States is established.
The Methodist Episcopal Church, USA is officially formed at the so-called "Christmas Conference" led by Thomas Coke and Francis Asbury.
Frenchman Jean-Pierre Blanchard and American John Jeffries travel from Dover, England to Calais, France in a hydrogen gas balloon, becoming the first to cross the English Channel by air.
The Confederation Congress reconvenes in New York City having previously convened in Trenton, New Jersey.
The Land Ordinance of 1785 is adopted by the United States Congress to raise money by selling land acquired from the Treaty of Paris.
John Adams, the first American ambassador to Great Britain, has his first meeting with King George III at the Court of St. James's.
The dollar is unanimously chosen as the money unit for the United States (the first time a nation has adopted a decimal coinage system).

The Treaty of Amity and Commerce (Prussia-USA) between the Kingdom of Prussia and the United States of America is signed, promoting free trade and demanding the unconditionally humane custody for war prisoner, a novelty at the time.
The Treaty of Hopewell is signed between the United States of America and the Choctaw Nation.
Shays' Rebellion begins in Massachusetts.
James Rumsey tests his first steam boat in the Potomac river at Shepherdstown Virginia (now West Virginia).
Mission Santa Barbara is founded by Father Fermín Francisco de Lasuén, becoming the 10th mission in the California mission chain.

Congress enacts the Northwest Ordinance to establish government for the Northwest Territory, a region that includes the future states of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan and Wisconsin. The ordinance outlaws slavery in the region.
John Fitch makes the first successful trial run of his steamboat "Perseverance" on the Delaware River, in the presence of delegates from the Constitutional Convention.
Delaware admitted to the United States.
Pennsylvania admitted to the United States.
New Jersey admitted to the United States.
The planet Uranus's moons Titania and Oberon are discovered by William Herschel.
Quakers in Pennsylvania emancipate their slaves.
Georgia admitted to the United States.
Connecticut admitted to the United States.
Massachusetts admitted to the United States.
Forty eight members of the Ohio Company's advance party land at junction of Muskingum and Ohio Rivers to establish Marietta, the first permanent white settlement in Ohio.
Maryland admitted to the United States.
South Carolina admitted to the United States.
New Hampshire admitted to the United States.
Virginia becomes a state.
New York becomes a state.
Arthur St. Clair, Governor of the Northwest Territories, arrives at Fort Harmar to assume duties.
New York admitted to the United States.
Mutiny on the Bounty occurs.
George Washington inaugurated as President.
French Revolution begins.
The storming of the Bastille, a prison used to hold political prisoners by the French Monarchy.
John Jay takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
North Carolina admitted to the United States.
Rhode Island admitted to the United States.
Samuel Hopkins is issued the first United States Patent for a process of making potash, an ingredient used in fertilizer. The patent was signed by President George Washington.
Chief Little Turtle defeats Brigadier General Josiah Harmar's American army.
Vermont admitted to the United States.
General Arthur St. Clair surprised near Wabash River, lost 630 men.
General Anthony Wayne replaces Arthur St. Clair.
The Bank of the United States is chartered. First "central bank," banknotes receivable by the U.S. Government.
The Postal Service Act, establishing the United States Post Office Department, is signed by President George Washington.
The Coinage Act is passed establishing the United States Mint.
United States President George Washington vetoes a bill designed to apportion representatives among U.S. states. This is the first time the presidential veto is used in the United States.
Robert Gray's Columbia River expedition: Captain Robert Gray becomes the first explorer to enter the Columbia River.
The Buttonwood Agreement is signed, beginning the New York Stock Exchange.
Kentucky admitted to the United States.

There was a fear that foreign and royalist armies would attack Paris and that the inmates of the city's prisons would be freed and join them. As a counter-revolution would mean the end, the radical Jean-Paul Marat, member of the "Comité de surveillance", called for preemptive action. More than 1,000 prisoners were killed within 20 hours.
The French Monarchy is abolished.
The first Columbus Day celebration in the United States is held in New York City, 300 years after his arrival in the New World.
Foundation of Washington, D.C.: The cornerstone of the United States Executive Mansion, known as the White House after 1818, is laid.
Mount Hood (Oregon) is named after British Admiral Lord Hood by Lt. William Broughton of the Vancouver Expedition, who spots the mountain near the mouth of the Willamette River.
George Washington is re-elected President of the United States.

Jean-Pierre Blanchard becomes the first to fly in a gas balloon in the Western Hemisphere, from Walnut Street Jail in Philadelphia to Deptford Township, New Jersey. George Washington, John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison and James Monroe are among the spectators.
King Louis XVI beheaded in French Revolution.
The Fugitive Slave Act is passed by Congress as the first of the federal fugitive slave laws under the U.S. Constitution.
George Washington holds the first Cabinet meeting as President of the United States.
President George Washington is sworn in for his second term, in Philadelphia.
George Washington signs the Neutrality Proclamation.
The yellow fever epidemic of 1793 hits Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; 5,000 die.

In France, the Law of Suspects was passed, which ordered the arrest of suspected counter-revolutionaries and people who had revealed themselves as "enemies of freedom". This begins a reign of terror where 17,000 legal death sentences are carried out.
The contents of the Palace at Versailles are sold at auction.
Marie Antoinette is guillotined after a brief trial. Her body is thrown in an unmarked grave.
Eli Whitney applies for patent for his cotton gin (the patent is granted the following March).
Atheists in France light the "Flame of Reason" in Notre Dame Cathedral.
New York City's first daily newspaper, the American Minerva, is established by Noah Webster.
General Anthony Wayne establishes Ft. Washington (Cincinnati) and Ft. Recovery.
Eli Whitney is granted a patent for his "new and useful improvement in the mode of Ginning cotton."
Robespierre supported a decree passed by the Convention that established an official religion, known historically as the Cult of the Supreme Being.
Maximilien Robespierre's address to the National Convention on 8 Thermidor Year II is met with hostility instead of the usual thunderous applause.
Maximilien Robespierre is executed along with other Jacobians.
The battle of fallen timbers just south of Toledo. General "Mad Anthony" Wayne defeats Blue Jacket's force of more than 1000 warriors.
Whiskey Rebellion suppressed by U.S. Government in west Pennsylvania.
General Anthony Wayne establishes Ft. Greenville, Ft. Deposit and Ft. Defiance.
Chief Justice John Jay of the United States Supreme Court resigns.
Indian representatives sign Treaty of Greenville surrendering all Ohio lands east and south of a line from Ft. Laurens to Ft. Laramie to Ft. Recovery.
John Rutledge takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court. He is forced to abdicate four months later when congress refuses to confirm him.

The Battle of Krtsanisi was fought between the Qajars of Iran and the Georgian armies of the Kingdom of Kartli-Kakheti and Kingdom of Imereti at the place of Krtsanisi near Tbilisi, Georgia. Tbilisi is destroyed. The cause of the war is Georgia's new alliance with Russia.
Oliver Ellsworth takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
Napoleon marries Josephine.
Congress establishes a U.S. Military District to satisfy land claims of Revolutionary War veterans. This includes the northern half of the future Franklin County.
Tennessee admitted to the United States.

Surveyors of the Connecticut Land Company laid out Connecticut's Western Reserve into townships and a capital city. They named it "Cleaveland" after their leader, General Moses Cleaveland. Cleaveland oversaw design of the plan for what would become the modern downtown area, centered on Public Square, before returning home, never again to visit Ohio
George Washington's farewell address as President.
White Lotus Uprising signals anti-Manchu unrest and social decay in China.

Ebenezer Zane improves Indian trails to construct Zane's Trace, Ohio's first "road." Zane's Trace runs from Wheeling in an arc across Ohio to Maysville on the Kentucky border. For his efforts, Zane receives a square mile of land at three locations where his Trace crosses water; these later become Zanesville, Lancaster and Chillicothe.
John Adams inaugurated as President.
Lucas Sullivant surveys and founds the town of Franklinton on the west bank of the Scioto River.

Matthew Hueston, after serving with General "Mad" Anthony Wayne in the Indian wars, bought land for a farm in Butler and Preble counties. He left a remnant of the woods standing for his descendants. This later became Hueston Woods State Park.
Eli Whitney manufactures 10,000 muskets for the U.S. Government with, for the first time, interchangeable parts.
Henry Maudslay invents a screw cutting lathe with a lead screw driven by interchangable gears for various screw pitches.
Federalist Congressman Roger Griswold of Connecticut attacks Vermont Representative Matthew Lyon with a walking stick in the chambers of the United States House of Representatives.
The Mississippi Territory is organized from territory ceded by Georgia and South Carolina and is later twice expanded to include disputed territory claimed by both the U.S. and Spain.
The United States Marine Corps is established by Congress
Eli Whitney contracts with the U.S. federal government for 10,000 rifles, which he produces with interchangeable parts.
Beryllium (4) Louis-Nicolas Vauquelin eported that he found a new "earth" by dissolving aluminium hydroxide from emerald and beryl in an additional alkali.

Congress passes the Logan Act, forbidding unauthorized citizens from negotiating with foreign governments, in response to George Logan's unofficial attempt to negotiate peace between the U.S. and France.

Fries's Rebellion, an armed tax revolt among Pennsylvania Dutch farmers, begins as John Fries organizes meetings to discuss a collective response to the taxes imposed to raise funds for the Quasi-War.
New York passes a law aimed at gradually abolishing slavery in the state.
After a coup, Napolean I becomes the ruler of France.
Former President George Washington dies at his home in Mount Vernon, Virginia.
The U.S. Library of Congress is founded.
Indiana Territory is formed by an Act of Congress as the first new territory created from the lands of the Northwest Territory.
Connecticut cedes its Western Reserve (an area in present-day northeastern Ohio) to the federal government, which adds it to the Northwest Territory.
The 2nd United States Census is conducted. It finds 5,308,483 people living in the U.S. of which 893,602 are slaves.
Chief Justice Oliver Ellsworth of the United States Supreme Court resigns.
U.S. President John Adams becomes the first President of the United States to live in the Executive Mansion (later renamed the White House).
The U.S. Congress holds its first Washington, D.C. session.
First lots offered for sale in Lancaster by John and Noah Zane, sons of Ebenezer Zane.
Zane's Trace is widened from Wheeling to Zanesville.
John Marshall takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

At a time when steam power was finding its first uses in America, Philadelphia opened two steam pumping stations to lift water from the Schuylkill River and distribute it through the city's wooden pipes and mains.
Thomas Jefferson inaugurated as President.
Tripoli declares war on the United States, who refused to pay tribute to commerce raiders (pirates).

France sent General Charles Leclerc to Saint-Domingue (present-day Haiti) to re-establish slavery, which had been abolished by the constitution of the French Republic of 1795, as well as to reduce the rights of free people of color and take back control of the island from Toussaint Louverture.
President Jefferson signs the Enabling Act for Ohio statehood.
The Scioto Company organizes at Granby, Conn.
James Kilbourne and Nathaniel Little travel to Ohio to look at land available for the Scioto Company to purchase.
James Kilbourne and Nathaniel Little return to Connecticut.
Thirty five delegates meet at Chillicothe to write Ohio's constitution.
Constitution of the State of Ohio is ratified.
William Symington's paddle wheel steam boat, Charlotte Dundas, makes its first run in Glasgow. It is designed to tow canal boats.

The first set of metal machines to make medium naval blocks is installed by Marc Isambard Brunel at the Portsmouth Block Works in England. This is the first time all metal machinery is configured to make products in an assembly line fashion, kicking off the industrial revolution. The machines were built by Henry Maudslay, and were of 22 types and totalled 45. They were driven by two 30 hp (22.4 kW) steam engines.
President Jefferson signs Congressional bill admitting Ohio as the 17th state.
State of Ohio admitted to the union. No proper vote is taken in congress. See 08/07/1953 for official vote.

Scioto Company members contract to purchase 16,000 acres in the U.S. military district from Jonas Stansbury and Jonathon Dayton for $1.25 per acre. Half of this becomes Worthington and half is in Clinton Township and Delaware County.
Napolean begins preparing for an invasion of England.
Spray Gun invented by Dr. Alan de Vilbiss of Toledo, Ohio; to replace swabs as the method of applying medication to oral and nasal passages.

William Symington's Charlotte Dundas towed two 70 ton barges 30 km (almost 20 miles) along the Forth and Clyde Canal to Glasgow, and despite "a strong breeze right ahead" which stopped all other canal boats it took only nine and a quarter hours, giving an average speed of about 3 km/h (2 mph). Due to erosion of the banks, the project was abandoned and Charlotte Dundas was broken up in 1861.
The French offer the Louisiana Territory to the United States for $15,000,000 - just 3 cents per acre.
The Louisiana Purchase Treaty is signed by Robert Livingston, James Monroe, and François Barbé-Marbois at the Hôtel Tubeuf in Paris.
Kilbourne leads an advance party to clear land, plant corn, survey town lots and erect temporary shelters in Worthington.

Thomas Jefferson announces the Louisiana Purchase to the American people. The United States payed $15,000,000 (equivalent to $600 billion in 2017 dollars). The United States made a down payment of $3,000,000 in gold and financed the rest through the sale of bonds, handled by Francis Baring and Company in London.
Scioto Company votes to name town for Thomas Worthington, one of Ohio's first two senators, and for each member to contribute $2 (about four days wages) to support a library.
The first settlers leave for Worthington by oxcart.
The Senate confirms the Louisiana Purchase treaty 24-7.
The House confirms the Louisiana Purchase.
Ezra Griswold is the first settler to arrive at the future site of Worthington.
The French are defeated at the battle of Vertières, ending their ambition to reestablish slavery in Santo Domingo.
The Spanish turn over administration of the Louisiana Territory to France.
The Scioto Company holds its first meeting in Worthington.
The Scioto Company grants Ezra Griswold the right to "keep a publick house for the Entertainment of Travelers".
France turns over New Orleans to the United States.
Worthington subscription library bylaws approved.
First Christmas celebration in Worthington includes toasts and a ball.
The French depart Santo Domingo, withdrawing their 7,000 surviving troops.
Franklin County established with Franklinton as county seat.
Ohio legislature passes 1st laws restricting free blacks movement.
Ezra Griswold granted a license to keep a tavern by the county court at Franklinton.
The Scioto Company petitions the county court at Franklinton for a road from Franklinton to Worthington.
Articles of agreement executed to form St. John's Church, the first Episcopal society in Ohio.
The double wedding of Abner P. Pinney and Polly Morrison, and Levi Pinney and Charlotte Beach was the first wedding in Worthington.
Thomas Phelps teaches first subscription school in a log cabin on the northeast quadrant of public square.
Louis and Clark expedition leaves St. Louis.
Scioto Co. members sign partition deed to divide 8,000 acres into farm lots and 164 town lots, reserving two on the public square or the Episcopal Church.
Abner Pinney's death is the first in Worthington and the first burial in St. John's churchyard.
Ohio University in Athens is chartered, the first college in Ohio
Beethoven's Symphony No. 3, Eroica, has its public premiere at the Theater an der Wien in Vienna under his baton.
Napoleon is crowned King of Italy.
William Eaton forces Tripoli to conclude peace with the United States. The First Barbary War ends between Tripoli and the United States of America.

Lewis and Clark Expedition in the United States: Scouting ahead of the expedition, Meriwether Lewis and four companions sight the Great Falls of the Missouri River, confirming they are heading in the right direction.

Lewis and Clark Expedition: U.S. Army Captain Meriwether Lewis becomes the first white person to reach the Continental Divide, that marks the division between the east and west sections of the North American continent, crossing at Lemhi Pass.
Admiral Nelson of the Royal Navy takes command of the fleet off of the coast of Cadiz, in order to counteract the navies of France and Spain.
Battle of Trafalgar: The British fleet, led by Admiral Horatio Nelson, defeats a combined French and Spanish fleet off the coast of Spain; however, Admiral Nelson is fatally shot.

The French Republican Calendar (which featured a 10-day week until 1802) is used for the last time, 8 days after being annulled by Napoleon, with the final official date being "9 Nivôse in Year XIV of the Revolution".
Presbyterian ministry licentiates sent to Worthington area to contact Presbyterians and conduct worship.
Emperor Francis II dissolved the Holy Roman Empire after the creation of the Confederation of the Rhine by Napoleon.
Louis and Clark expedition returns.
Lucas Sullivant builds a log cabin for use as a school in Franklinton
The National Road (also known as The Cumberland Pike) is authorized by an act of Congress and signed by President Thomas Jefferson.
The United Kingdom abolishes the slave trade in all of its colonies, effective March 1, 1808.
St. John's Episcopal Church in Worthington is incorporated by an act of the legislature
The United States Coast Survey is established; work begins on August 3, 1816.
In Alabama, former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr is tried for conspiracy, but acquitted.

The U.S. Congress passes an act to "prohibit the importation of slaves into any port or place within the jurisdiction of the United States ... from any foreign kingdom, place, or country (to take effect 1 January 1808).
Nathaniel Little becomes postmaster of Worthington's first post office.
A grand jury indicts former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr for treason.
The Geological Society of London is founded.
The first Fairfield County Courthouse is built in Lancaster.
Worthington Academy is incorporated by the Ohio legislature and a brick building is begun facing the northeast quadrant of the public square. Its bell now adorns Kilbourne middle school.

John and Abijah Smith shipped the first commercially mined load of anthracite down the Susquehanna River from Plymouth, Pennsylvania, marking the birth of commercial anthracite mining in the United States.

Boron (5) Sir Humphrey Davy observed that electric current sent through a solution of borates produced a brown precipitate on one of the electrodes. In his subsequent experiments, he used potassium to reduce boric acid instead of electrolysis. He produced enough boron to confirm a new element and named the element boracium.
The first settlers arrive in the Pickerington area.
James Kilbourne erects a commercial building for a newspaper. This building stands at 679-681 High St. as the oldest commercial building in continuous use in the state.
Methodist circuit riders first preach to a group of settlers at the home of Samuel Beach south of the village.
The Illinois Territory is created.
Franz I of Austria declares war on France.
Robert Fulton patents the steamboat in the United States.
Miami University (Ohio) is established (by Act of February 2) on the township of land required to be set aside for it, under the conditions of the Miami Purchase in 1794.
James Madison inaugurated as President.
A military coup ousts Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden; he is confined in Gripsholm Castle.
Napoleonic Wars – Battle of the Basque Roads: The British Royal Navy defeats the French fleet in the mouth of the Charente, although officers on both sides face subsequent courts-martial.
Battle of Eckmühl: French troops under Napoleon I and Marshal Davout defeat the Austrians, under Archduke Charles.
Battle of Wagram: Napoleon defeats the Austrians.
The city of La Paz (current Bolivia) declares its independence from the Spanish Crown and forms the Junta Tuitiva, the first independent government in Spanish America, led by Pedro Domingo Murillo.
A new theatre for the Royal Opera House opens in London to replace the first, burnt down in a fire in 1808. The price increases lead to the Old Price Riots, which last for 64 days.

Lewis and Betsey Gay purchased farmland situated along the Olentangy River from John Rathbone, the original owner under the United States Military Land grants. The land would later become Whetstone Park.
The marriage of Napoleon and Joséphine is annulled.
Peninsular War: The French Army, under the command of André Masséna, retreats from Portugal.

Venezuela achieves home rule: Vicente Emparán, Governor of the Captaincy General of Venezuela, is removed by the people of Caracas, and a junta is installed. Venezuela is the first South American state to proclaim independence from Spain.
The Kingdom of Hawaii is unified.
Macon's Bill Number 2 becomes law in the United States, intending to motivate Britain and France to stop seizing American vessels during the Napoleonic Wars.
May Revolution: Armed citizens of Buenos Aires expel the Viceroy and establish a provincial government for Argentina (the Primera Junta).

The Tonquin sets sail from New York Harbor, with 33 employees of John Jacob Astor's newly created Pacific Fur Company on board. After a six-month journey around the tip of South America, the ship arrives at the mouth of the Columbia River, and Astor's men establish the fur-trading town of Astoria.
The Republic of West Florida declares independence from Spain.
First Oktoberfest: Bavarian royalty invites the citizens of Munich to join the celebration of the marriage of Crown Prince Ludwig of Bavaria, to Princess Therese of Saxe-Hildburghausen.
Invasion of Isle de France: British forces force the French to surrender Isle de France (Mauritius).
Chief Leatherlips executed along the Scioto River north of Dublin by fellow Wyandotte tribesmen angered by his refusal to fight the white settlers.
The population of Lancaster reaches 400.

Fluorine (9) French physicist André-Marie Ampère suggested that hydrogen and an element analogous to chlorine constituted hydrofluoric acid.[81] Sir Humphry Davy proposed that this then-unknown substance be named fluorine from fluoric acid and the -ine suffix of other halogens.
The Great Comet of 1811 is discovered by Honoré Flaugergues.
The Great Podil fire breaks out in Kiev, Ukraine.
The Western Intelligencer, Franklin County's first newspaper, begins publication.
Forest fires break out in the Tyrol region of Switzerland, reportedly destroying 64 villages and hamlets.
Inventor John Stevens' boat, the Juliana, begins operation as the first steam-powered ferry service, between New York City and Hoboken, New Jersey.

Luddite uprisings. The first attack on textile machines by men who used the name 'General Ludd' and called themselves his followers, was in the village of Bulwell, four miles north of Nottingham, when a small band of men gathered in the darkness and marched to the home of a master weaver called Hollingsworth, then destroyed six of his weaving machines.

The Battle of Tippecanoe is fought in what is now Battle Ground, Indiana, between American forces led by Governor William Henry Harrison of the Indiana Territory and Native American warriors associated with the Shawnee leader Tecumseh.

The 400 terrified residents in the town of New Madrid (Missouri) were abruptly awakened by violent shaking and a tremendous roar. This was the first of three magnitude-8 earthquakes and thousands of aftershocks to rock the region that winter. Shaking was noted at 2:24 am in Cincinnati.
The Richmond Theatre fire in Virginia kills 72 people, including the Governor of Virginia George William Smith and the president of the First National Bank of Virginia, Abraham B. Venable.
National Road construction begins in Cumberland, Maryland.
First Bank of the United States' charter expires.
Ezra Griswold builds a large south-facing brick tavern on the lot north of the northeast quadrant of the public square.
The Orange Johnson House built in Worthington.
The Ohio Legislature passes a resolution to the effect that a canal connecting the Great Lakes with the Hudson was a project of national concern and that the U.S. should defray the cost.
A second large earthquake strikes the center of the continent near New Madrid, MO.
A third massive earthquake strikes the center of the continent, destroying the town of New Madrid, MO.
A proposal, including $50,000 to build a statehouse, is made to the state legislature to found the City of Columbus, Ohio.
The Ohio Legislature designates a new town to be called Columbus as the state capital. Worthington, Delaware, Dublin and Franklinton were among the losing contenders.

A food riot in Middleton in the North of England is joined by Luddites and the steam powered looms at the Daniel Burton & Sons mill becomes their target. Burton has armed his employees and they kill 5 and wound 18.

A militia protects the mill of Daniel Burton & Sons, so angry crowds loot and destroy the homes of Burton family members and his workers. British soldiers put down the revolt, killing 12 and wounding 60 - 100.
Daniel Burton closes his mill and lays off 400 workers.
Louisiana admitted to the United States.
The Worthington Manufacturing Company acquires property on the Olentangy River to begin diverse manufacturing operations.
The United States declares war against England.
Several Worthington Militia march north with Hull's army and are surrendered at Detroit
Summer revival meetings lead to the formation of a Methodist "class meeting" led by Joab Hoyt.
Orders issued by General William Henry Harrison from "Northwest Army Headquarters, Worthington, Ohio" indicate the commander, like his supply wagons, was using the road north from the capital.

The future founder of Clintonville, Thomas Bull, a Methodist minister, along with his wife, four sons and one of his two daughters move to Central Ohio from Vermont. His second daughter, Chloe Brevoort and her family, joined the rest of the Bull family about a year later. The family first settled in the Worthington area while they searched for land to purchase at a suitable price.

A period of cold weather and low crop yields begins in New England, culminating in 1816, the year without a summer. The period abates in 1819. Many New England farmers faced ruin and migrated to Central New York and the Midwest.
The French frigate Aréthuse (1812) and the British ship HMS Amelia (1796) engage in battle in the Îles de Los on the Guinea Coast; both ships retire unbeaten.
Construction begins on Fort Meigs in Ohio, under the command of General William Henry Harrison. Major Amos Stoddard assumes command of its artillery.

General Harrison sends out an expedition to burn the British vessels at Fort Malden, by going across Lake Erie via the Bass Islands in sleighs, but the ice is not hard enough, and the expedition returns.
Battle of Rosillo Creek: The Republican Army of the North defeats the Spanish Royalist Army in present-day Bexar County, Texas.
James Kilbourne takes his seat as a newly elected representative to the U.S. Congress.
In Canada, American forces capture Fort George.
Capture of USS Chesapeake in Boston Harbor by British Royal Navy frigate HMS Shannon.
Battle of Stoney Creek – A British force of 700 under John Vincent defeats an American force three times its size, under William H. Winder and John Chandler.
Peninsular War: Battle of Vitoria – A British, Spanish and Portuguese force of 78,000 with 96 guns under Wellington defeats a French force of 58,000 with 153 guns under Joseph Bonaparte.
Three weeks of British raids on Fort Schlosser, Black Rock and Plattsburgh, New York begin.
The first sea-going steamboat in Europe was Richard Wright's first steamboat "Experiment", an ex-French lugger; she steamed from Leeds to arrive this day an Yarmouth.
Battle of Lake Erie: An American squadron under Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry defeats a British squadron, capturing 6 ships.
Harrison's army catches up with that of Procter at Moravian Town on the Thames River (Toronto). Procter is decisively defeated. Tecumseh is killed, and the war in the Northwest is over.

Battle of Leipzig: Napoleon is defeated by the forces of the Sixth Coalition. More than 600,000 troops are in the field, with well over 10% killed, wounded or missing. Many of the German states forming the Confederation of the Rhine defect from Napoleon to the Coalition, as a result of the battle.
Battle of Crysler's Farm: An outnumbered British–Canadian force repels an American attack, forcing the Americans to give up their attempt to capture Montreal.
British soldiers and native allies invade the United States, and are successful in the Capture of Fort Niagara, and attack Lewiston, New York.
British soldiers burn Buffalo, New York.

Clintonville: Thomas Bull purchased 600 acres along the Columbus-Worthington Pike from John Rathbone. Before the Adams administration patented the land to Rathbone, it had been part of the United States Military Lands -- land which was set aside to be given to Revolutionary War soldiers as both a pension and as a payment for their service in the War of Independence. Rathbone was a New Yorker who had never set foot in Ohio. Nonetheless, he owned a quarter section of Clinton Township which was named for George Clinton, the vice president in the Adams administration. To attract "mechanics" to the area, Alanson, Thomas Bull's oldest son, built houses and shops along what is now High Street, and gave them to anyone with a skill who would stay and practice their craft. The idea caught on and after a time, there was a little hamlet along High Street centered on what today we call Oakland Park. Since the hamlet was nearly in the center of Clinton Township, it became known as Clintonville.
Orange Johnson, a young entrepreneur, moves to Worthington and begins to manufacture wood and horn combs.
The Great Stock Exchange Fraud is exposed in London.
American naval schooner USS Enterprise reaches Wilmington, North Carolina, returning from participating in the War of 1812 against the United Kingdom in the Caribbean.
Editor Joel Buttles moves the Western Intelligencer to Columbus.
Battle of Horseshoe Bend: In northern Alabama, United States forces under General Andrew Jackson defeat the Creek Indians.
Battle of Valparaíso: Two British Royal Navy ships easily defeat and capture USS Essex and a sister ship off the coast of Chile.
Napoleon abdicates the French throne unconditionally.
British forces attack Fort Ontario at Oswego, New York.
Napoleon arrives at Portoferraio, Elba to begin his exile.
Battle of Chippawa: American Major General Jacob Brown defeats British General Phineas Riall at Chippawa, Ontario.
General Phineas Riall advances toward Niagara Falls, Ontario to halt Jacob Brown's American invaders.
Four thousand British troops defeat five thousand American troops, take Washington and burn the White House and the Capital.
Alexandria, Virginia, offers surrender to the British fleet without a fight.
Zophar Topping dies while serving with Indian scouts, Worthington's only casualty in the War of 1812.
Battle of Lake Champlain: An American squadron under Thomas Macdonough defeats the British squadron, ultimately forcing the invading army to retreat back into Canada.
Maryland Militia halts British advance on Baltimore.

The British bombard Fort McHenry at Baltimore. The British failure at the Battle of Baltimore is a turning point in the war, and the American defense of the fort inspires Francis Scott Key to compose the poem (later set to music as) The Star-Spangled Banner.
London Beer Flood: A large vat full of porter (beer) owned by Meux's Brewery of London bursts, demolishing buildings and killing 9.
The Treaty of Ghent is signed, formally ending the war of 1812.
Ohio erects a two story state house, partly with bricks from a pre-historic Indian mound destroyed at Mound and High Streets.
British evacuate New Orleans after being defeated by Major General Andrew Jackson's troops.
Treaty of Ghent, ending the war of 1812, ratified by the U.S. Senate.
Napoleon escapes from exile in Elba to France. He lands at Golfe-Juan with 700 men and starts heading north.
The 5th Regiment, sent to intercept Napoleon, instead betrays the Bourbon dynasty and marches together with Napoleon towards Paris.
The Congress of Vienna declares Napoleon an outlaw.
Great Britain, Russia, Austria, and Prussia each pledged to put 150,000 men into the field to end Napoleon's rule.
Napoleon assumes power in Paris.
Volcano, Tambora, Indonesia: A moderately large explosive eruption occurrs from which ash falls in east Java and thunderlike sounds are heard up to 1,400 kilometers away.

Volcano, Tambora, Indonesia: A larger eruption than the April 5th one occurrs, beginning as "three columns of fire rising to a great height" and ultimately ejecting about 50 cubic kilometers of magma (dense rock equivalent) The eruption left a deep summit caldera where previously a much higher stratovolcano had stood. Earthquakes were felt as far away as Surabaya (500 kilometers), possibly reflecting the caldera collapse. 90,000 people died.
The Congress of Vienna concludes an agreement to divide up Europe in a way that balances large powers and maintains peace.
Napoleon is defeated at the battle of Waterloo by Wellington, leading British and Prussian troops.
Napoleon flees from Paris
Coalition forces enter Paris.
Napoleon demanded asylum from the British Captain Frederick Maitland on HMS Bellerophon.
Napoleon is moved to Longwood House on Saint Helena island. A garrison of British troops on Ascension Island guard him. He will remain there until his death in 1821

Abraham Pickering laid out the original plat of old Pickerington.  For one hundred and fifty years relatively few people lived in the area, and Pickerington slumbered as an agricultural and dairy community, seemingly distant from both the county seat, Lancaster, and the state capital, Columbus.

The first City Council (Robert W. McCoy, John Cutler, Robert Armstrong, Henry Brown, Caleb Houston, Michael Patton, Jeremiah Armstrong and Jarvis Pike)and Mayor (John Kerr) of Columbus Ohio are elected. The election takes place at the Columbus Inn.

The first in a series of late Spring cold waves crossed the St Lawrence River from northeastern Canada. By the 15th, frost had penetrated into Pennsylvania and Virginia. Frost was reported in Quebec City from the 12th to the 19th and snow fell on the 14th. The cold in New England lasted to the 18th. The unusual aspect of this frost was its southern penetration. While frosts in mid-May are not uncommon in northern New England, May frosts in New Haven, Connecticut are rare--the last frost of spring normally occurring around April 20.

Danville, VT: This was perhaps as warm and sultry a day as we have had since September--At night heat lightning was observed, but on Thursday morning the change of weather was so great that a fire was not only comfortable, but actually necessary. The wind during the whole day was as piercing and cold as it usually is the first of November and April. Snow and hail [ice pellets] began to fall about ten o'clock A.M., and the storm continued till evening, accompanied with a brisk wind, which rendered the habiliments of winter necessary for the comfort of those exposed to it....Probably no one living in the country ever witnessed such weather, especially of so long continuance."

A second cold front crossed the region, bringing significant snowfall to the area. From the highlands of Vermont came reports of 5 to 6 inches of snow with drifts to over a foot. At Lunenberg, Vermont, Dr Hiram Cutting measured 5 inches on the ground. Amounts at other locations ranged from "a plentiful fall" at Portland, Maine, a foot at Cabot, Vermont, and 6 inches at Barnard, Vermont to "a few flakes" at Middlebury, Connecticut, Waltham, Massachusetts and Salem, Massachusetts. The Danville North Star reported a "kind of sleet or exceedingly cold snow."

Danville, VT: "Some account was given in last week's issue of the unparalleled severity of the weather. It continued without any essential amelioration, from the 6th to the 10th instant--freezing as hard five nights in succession as it usually does in December....Saturday morning the weather was more severe than it generally is during the storms of winter. It was indeed a gloomy and tedious period."
Eleven persons meet at the home of Peter and Zilpha Barker to organize a Presbyterian congregation.

With the passing of the arctic air mass into the Atlantic, the temperatures rose to seasonable values for the rest of June. A heat wave from the 22nd to the 24th brought temperatures in excess of 90 oF at Waltham, with a peak of 99 oF the afternoon of the 23rd. Williamstown reached 93 oF on the 24th. The only mention of wintery weather came in reports from St. David, Quebec where severe frosts struck on the 28th and 29th. Optimism re-emerged as replanted vegetable gardens grew quickly under the warm June sun. As the first week of July passed there were hopes of making up for lost time.

Williamstown reported a wind shift to northwest with falling temperatures. The arrival of a cold front during July more often than not is a welcomed event in New England. But the memories of earlier weather events must have brought apprehension to those weatherwise to the sign of approaching cold air. Any fears were well founded, for this cold front would also leave its mark on the fields. Though not as severe as its predecessors, it did bring extreme cold to Waltham, Massachusetts, and as far south as Chambersburg, Pennsylvania, and Richmond, Virginia. Temperatures in the 40 oF range were reported in Connecticut at both Hartford and New Haven. Robbins in East Windsor noted temperatures almost cold enough for a frost.

The brunt of this cold air settled in northern New England with frost probably occurring on the uplands or in low-lying areas. In Francona, New Hampshire, the frost was severe enough on the 8th to completely kill the local bean crop. The cold ended on the 9th as morning temperatures of 44 oF at Waltham and 43 oF at Williamstown were reported at 7 am.

The combination of cold and drought which had gripped New England for most of the growing season began to elicit fears of a general famine. Estimates of the hay crop were one-third to one-half of that expected--presaging an equivalent reduction in livestock which could be housed over the winter of 1816-17. Reports from Kennebunk, Maine stated that this July frost killed beans, cucumbers and squash.

Another series of cold waves would cross New England, forever dashing hopes of a normal harvest. The first wave brought frost to the interior of New York and northern New England on the 13th and 14th of August. Corn was again laid low. New England south of Concord, New Hampshire was given a respite from this invasion, but it was only to last a week.

There was a frost, which at Keene and at Chester, N.H., killed a large part of the corn, potatoes, beans, and vines, and also injured many crops in Maine. It was felt as far south as Boston and Middlesex county in eastern Massachusetts...It put an end to the hopes of many farmers of ripening their corn, especially in the low lands, and they immediately cut the whole stalkes [sic] up for fodder, but being in the milk it heated in the shocks and spoiled....If the frost had kept off two weeks longer, there would have been a very good crop of corn in Massachusetts."
The Ohio Legislature opens its first session in the new capital.
Indiana becomes a state.

Ohio Governor Thomas Worthington sent to the Ohio Legislature a communication from Governer DeWitt Clinton of New York showing the benefits that a canal connecting the Great Lakes with the Hudson River would acrue to Ohio, and to ask Ohio to participate in the expense.
Indiana admitted to the United States.
Lucas Sullivant constructs the first bridge across the Scioto.
Columbus, Ohio's population is 700.
Second Bank of the United States is chartered.
Franklin Bank is incorporated, Franklin County's first, with 4 of its 13 directors Worthington men.
In the absence of a bank, Ezra Griswold issues shinplasters redeemable at his tavern.
An army of 5,423 soldiers, led by General José de San Martín, starts crossing the Andes from Argentina, to liberate Chile and then Peru.
President James Madison vetoes John C. Calhoun's Bonus Bill.
James Monroe inaugurated as President.
The first services of Trinity Episcopal Church were held in the residence of Dr. Lincoln Goodale.
German inventor Karl Drais drives his dandy horse ("Draisine" or Laufmaschine), the earliest form of bicycle, in Mannheim.
At Rome, New York, construction on the Erie Canal begins.

The Era of Good Feelings reflects a sense of national purpose and a desire for unity among Americans in the aftermath of the War of 1812. The phrase Era of Good Feelings was coined by Benjamin Russell, in the Boston Federalist newspaper, Columbian Centinel following Monroe's visit to Boston, Massachusetts, as part of his good-will tour of the United States.

By act of the U.S. Congress (March 3), the Alabama Territory is created by splitting the Mississippi Territory in half, on the day the Mississippi constitution is drafted, four months before Mississippi became a U.S. state.
President James Monroe visits Worthington.
The independent government of Venezuela is established by Simón Bolívar.
"Tug", the first tugboat, was launched by the Woods Brothers, Port Glasgow.
The first Seminole War begins in Florida.
Mississippi admitted to the United States.
Mathew and Peter Westervelt travel from New York and settle on land by Alum Creek near where Main Street is today in the town named after them in 1840, Westerville.
Female Tract Society of Worthington and its Vicinity organized with Cynthia Kilbourne as president.

Philander Chase moves to Worthington to become the first rector of St. John's Episcopal Church. He concurrently serves as rector of Episcopal churches in Columbus and Delaware and as principle of Worthington Academy.

Lithium (3) In Stockholm, Johan August  Arfwedson knew the chemist Jöns Jakob Berzelius and received access to his private laboratory, where he discovered the element lithium during analysis of the mineral petalite.
Venus occults Jupiter. It is the last occultation of one planet by another before November 22, 2065.
Percy Bysshe Shelley's Ozymandias is published pseudonymously in London.
Chile proclaims its independence from Spain.
Easter Sunday in Western Christianity falls on its earliest possible date. In Western Christianity, it will not occur on this date again until 2285.
Battle of Miccosukee, Florida: General Andrew Jackson defeats chief Kinhagee.

The United States Congress adopts the flag of the United States as having thirteen red and white stripes, and one star for each state (twenty), with additional stars to be added whenever a new state is added to the Union.

Brooks Brothers, the oldest men's clothier in the United States, opens its first store on the northeast corner of Catherine and Cherry Streets in New York City, where the later South Street Seaport stands.
The Rush–Bagot Disarmament treaty is ratified by the U.S. Senate. The treaty between the United States and the United Kingdom limits naval armaments on the Great Lakes and Lake Champlain.

At least 34 people are killed in Switzerland, when the melting of a glacier releases the natural dam of Lac de Mauvoisin, sending the waters of the lake and the Dranse River into the valley of Bagnes.
Rev. Chase is elected Bishop of the newly organized Episcopal Diocese of Ohio.

The Bank of the United States reverses its policy of expanding credit, and sends notices to its borrowers nationwide demanding immediate repayment of balances due; the defaults during the next six months will trigger the Panic of 1819.

U.S. President James Monroe convenes a cabinet meeting, to discuss whether General Andrew Jackson's unauthorized invasion and conquest of Spanish Florida should be disavowed by the White House. Secretary of State John Quincy Adams persuades the President that the action is justifiable, in stopping terror caused by the Seminole tribes.

French physicist Augustin-Jean Fresnel submits his prizewinning "Memoir on the Diffraction of Light" to the French Academy of Sciences, precisely accounting for the limited extent to which light spreads into shadows, and thereby demolishing the oldest objection to the wave theory of light.

The first newspaper in Cleveland, Ohio is issued by publisher Andrew Logan.[10] Using the original name of the small settlement (population 172), Logan names the weekly paper The Cleaveland Gazette & Commercial Register.
A separate Topographical Bureau of the United States Department of War established.

A treaty between the U.S. and the United Kingdom establishes the boundary between the U.S. and British North America as the 49th parallel, from the Lake of the Woods to the Rocky Mountains, also creating the Northwest Angle.
Illinois admitted to the United States.

The first place of Catholic worship in Ohio was built of logs and located at St. Joseph's, Perry County. This chapel was blessed by Rev. Edward Fenwick and his nephew, Rev. N.D. Young, both natives of Maryland, and receiving their jurisdiction from Bishop Flaget, who was then the only bishop between the Alleghenies and the Mississippi.

Ohio Governor Brown, in his innaugural address, declares that "to increase industry and develop our resources, internal communications (canals) must be improved to provide for the surplus produce of our state a cheaper way to market".

The Christmas carol "Silent Night" (Stille Nacht), with words by the priest Josef Mohr, set to music by organist Franz Xaver Gruber, is first performed at St. Nikolaus Parish Church, in Oberndorf bei Salzburg, Austria.
National Road completed to Wheeling.
Treaty of St. Mary's forces last 2400 Indians in northwest Ohio onto 16 small reservations so the land reserved by Greenville Treaty can be surveyed for white settlement.
U.S. Bank crisis leads to panic of 1819 and economic depression.
Thomas Jefferson founds the University of Virginia.
Christopher Ripley closes the Columbus store of the Worthington Manufacturing Co.
Worthington Academy is re-chartered as Worthington College and a new wing added.
The United States House of Representatives agrees to the Tallmadge Amendment, barring slaves from the new state of Missouri (the opening vote in a controversy that leads to the Missouri Compromise).

French slave ship Le Rodeur sails from Bonny in West Africa to Guadeloupe in the West Indies; in the course of the transatlantic voyage all onboard become blind, and slaves are thrown overboard as a consequence.

The SS Savannah, an American hybrid sailing ship/sidewheel steamer built in 1818, left Savannah Harbor and commenced a historic voyage bound for Liverpool, England. Savannah was the first steamship to cross the Atlantic.

The 7.7–8.2 Mw Rann of Kutch earthquake kills at least 1,543 people in the modern-day Indian state of Gujarat at the Bay of Bengal, causing a 80–150 km (50–93 mi) stretch of land to be raised as much as 6 m (20 ft), creating a natural dam, the Allahbund.
German astronomer Johann Georg Tralles discovers what will be called the Great Comet of 1819.
At Edwardsville, Illinois, the United States concludes a treaty with the Kickapoo tribe, receiving their lands in return for their relocation to Missouri.
Battle of Boyacá: Simón Bolívar is victorious over the Royalist Army in Colombia. Colombia acquires its definitive independence from Spanish rule.
The Carlsbad Decrees are issued throughout the German Confederation.
The USS Congress, commanded by Captain John D. Henley, becomes the first American warship to visit China, landing at Lintin Island, off of the coast of Canton.
The Museo del Prado, one of the world's great art galleries, opens in Madrid. Initially, it has only 311 significant paintings
The SS Savannah returns to the Savannah River from Europe.
Alabama admitted to the United States.
Ezra Griswold Jr. begins publication of the Franklin Chronicle.
The Orange Johnson House expanded in Worthington.

The first confirmed sighting of mainland Antarctica is attributed to Russian expedition led by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen and Mikhail Lazarev, discovering an ice shelf at Princess Martha Coast that later became known as the Fimbul Ice Shelf.
George IV of the United Kingdom ascends the throne, on the death at Windsor Castle of his father George III (after 59 years on the throne), ending the period known as the British Regency.
History of Antarctica: Irish Royal Navy captain Edward Bransfield lands on the mainland of Antarctica.
86 free African American colonists sail from New York City to Freetown, Sierra Leone.

Cato Street Conspiracy: A plot to murder the Cabinet of the United Kingdom is exposed in England; the principals are the last to suffer decapitation, following their hanging for treason outside Newgate Prison in London, on May 1.
The Missouri Compromise becomes law, allowing admission of Missouri and Maine, slave and free states respectively, as U.S. states.
The Royal Astronomical Society is founded in London.
Maine admitted to the United States.
The statue of the Venus de Milo (Aphrodite of Milos, c.150 BC-125 BC) is discovered on the Greek island of Milos, by a peasant named Yorgos Kentrotas.
Hans Christian Ørsted discovers the relationship between electricity and magnetism.
The last hanging, drawing and quartering in Britain is meted out to the Cato Street conspirators for treason (only hanged and beheaded).
HMS Beagle (the ship that will later take young Charles Darwin on his scientific voyage) is launched at Woolwich Dockyard.
National Road funded by Congress from Wheeling to the Mississippi.

Masonic Lodge #4, chartered in Connecticut in 1803 before migration, awards contract to brickmason and lodge member Aurora Buttles to erect a Masonic hall. This building at 634 High St. now serves as a Masonic museum.

Union Chain Bridge, a wrought iron suspension bridge designed by Captain Samuel Brown, opens across the River Tweed, between England and Scotland. Its span of 449 ft (137 m) is the world's longest for a vehicular bridge at this time.
Captain Nathaniel Palmer becomes the first American to see Antarctica.
U.S. presidential election, 1820: James Monroe is re-elected, virtually unopposed.
Columbus, Ohio's population is 1450.
Ohio's population reaches 580,000
James Monroe begins his second term as President of the United States.
Napoleon dies in exile on St. Helen island, guarded by British troops.
A Kentucky slave owner advertises a $500 reward in the Franklin Chronicle for the return of his slave "Isham," reportedly set free at Worthington.
Battle of Carabobo: Simón Bolívar wins Venezuela's independence from Spain.
Procession of workers from the Worthington Manufacturing Company marched from Factory (South) Street to the public square (Village Green), where a 120 foot flagstaff was erected.
Missouri admitted to the United States.
Griswold moves his newspaper to Delaware and renames it the Delaware Patron and Franklin Chronicle.
Twenty subscribers meet at the home of Daniel Upson to incorporate the Presbyterian Society of Worthington.
Organization of the Ohio State Temperance Society.
The first group of freed slaves from the United States arrive to the west coast of Africa, founding Monrovia on April 25.

The Ohio Legislature passes a bill to employ an engineer and appoint commissioners for a proposed canal system to cause examinations, surveys and estimates to be made by the engineer as soon as he could be obtained. A sum not to exceed $6000 was appropriated for this purpose.
Hiram Ulysses Grant is born in Point Pleasant, Clermont County, Ohio.

The American Colonization Society lands at Cape Mesurado on the West African coast, after purchasing 60 miles (97 km) of coastline. The settlement will soon become Monrovia, as the nation of Liberia is established to fill the ACS mission of freeing black American slaves and sending them "back to Africa".

The first iron steamship to go to sea, the 116 ton Aaron Manby built in 1821 by Aaron Manby at the Horseley Ironworks, became the first iron built vessel ever to put to sea when she crossed the English Channel.

Charles Babbage publishes a proposal for a difference engine, a forerunner of the modern computer, for calculating logarithms and trigonometric functions. Construction of an operational version will proceed under British Government sponsorship (1823–32), but it will never be completed
Brazilian independence: Brazil declares its independence from Portugal.
Galileo Galilei's Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems (1632) is permitted by the Roman Catholic Church to be published.
The Galunggung volcano erupts on West Java, and is followed four days later by a second, more violent outburst; the two events kill more than 4,000 people and destroy 114 villages.
The first officially recognised gold is found in Australia, by surveyor James McBrien at Fish River, near Bathurst, New South Wales, predating the Australian gold rushes.

Explorer James Weddell's expedition to Antarctica reaches latitude 74°15' S and longitude 34°16'45" W: the southernmost position any ship had reached before, a record that will hold for more than 80 years.
Franz Liszt, 11, gives a concert, after which he is personally congratulated by Ludwig van Beethoven.
Russian author Alexander Pushkin begins work on his novel Eugene Onegin.
Pope Pius VII dies after a reign of more than 23 years, that began on March 14, 1800; he is remembered for crowning Napoleon Bonaparte as Emperor of France
Medical journal The Lancet is founded by Thomas Wakley in London.
Monroe Doctrine declared.
Methodists build the first church building in Worthington.
After much controversy, Michael Faraday is finally elected as a member of the Royal Society, with only one vote against him.
Simón Bolívar is proclaimed dictator of Peru.
The United States War Department creates the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

The first permanent settlers arrive to construct the new city of Tallahassee, Florida, selected to be the capital of the Florida Territory newly acquired from the Kingdom of Spain; the area was selected because it is roughly equidistant from the territory's main cities, Pensacola and St. Augustine.
Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 (the "Choral") premieres at the Theater am Kärntnertor in Vienna. The deaf composer has to be turned around on the stage, to witness the enthusiastic audience reaction.

Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette and a beloved hero of the American Revolution, departs from the port of Le Havre in France on the ship HMS Cadmus for a triumphant return to the United States; he arrives in New York on August 15.
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the first technological university in the English-speaking world, is founded in Troy, New York.
U.S. presidential election, 1824: None of the four candidates for U.S. President gain a majority of the electoral votes, so the election is thrown into the U.S. House of Representatives.
The First American fraternity, Chi Phi (ΧΦ), is founded at Princeton University.
County Seat moved from Franklinton to Columbus.

The Ohio Legislature passes "An Act to provide for the Internal Improvement of the State of Ohio by Navigable Canals". Two canals are authorized for construction: The Ohio and Erie Canal following the Muskingum-Scioto route from Cleveland to Portsmouth and the Miami and Erie Canal following the Miami River Valley from Dayton to Cincinnati.
The Ohio Legislature enacts the first law requiring tax support for public schools.
The Ohio Legislature addresses a memorial to Congress asking for a donation of land for the Ohio canals, and asking Ohio's Senators and Representatives to work to that end.
John Quincy Adams inaugurated as President.
The great tornado outbreak in Ohio: The Burlington Storm. Seneca County, Ohio.
