At Licking Summit south of Newark, work begins on the Ohio and Erie Canal. Ceremonies include Governers Morrow of Ohio and Clinton of New York. At the same time work began on the Ohio & Erie Canal from Portage Summit (Akron) to Cleveland.
National Road construction commences in Ohio.
Construction begins on the Miami Canal at Middletown, Ohio. Governer Dewitt Clinton of New York is in attendance.
The first steam locomotive, Stephenson's "Locomotion," operates on England's Stockton & Darling Railroad.
Jonathon Knight, a United States Commissioner, arrives in Columbus to complete the survey of the proposed National Road (Rt. 40) between Zanesville and Columbus.
Erie Canal opened, first boat leaves Buffalo.
First Erie Canal boat reaches New York City.
Baltimore in Licking County is founded.
The Ohio Legislature incorporates the Columbus & Sandusky Turnpike. Worthington resident Orange Johnson appointed superintendent for turnpike construction.
Samuel Morey of Oxford, New Hampshire patented the internal combustion engine.

Most of the 135,000 Janissaries revolted against Ottoman Sultan Mahmud II, and after the rebellion was suppressed, its leaders killed, and many members exiled or imprisoned, the Janissary corps was disbanded and replaced with a more modern military force.
The State of Pennsylvania begins work on the "Main Line of Public Works", a succession of trains, canals and inclined planes across the state from East to West.
James H. Hackett became the first American actor to appear abroad as he performed at Covent Garden in London, England.
First all steam powered oceanic vessel, Curracao, crosses the Atlantic.
Governor Trimble and the canal commission boarded a canal boat in Akron and the next day arrived in Cleveland.

A canal boat makes the first trip on the Ohio and Erie Canal, traveling 37 miles from Akron to Cleveland at 3 mph. To get there it descended through 41 locks and passed over 3 aqueducts. This was the most difficult and expensive portion of the canal to construct.
Slavery abolished in New York State.
The first canal boats on the Miami Canal travel from the basin 6 miles north of Cincinnati to Middletown.

Hungarian physicist Ányos Jedlik started experimenting with electromagnetic coils. After Jedlik solved the technical problems of continuous rotation with the invention of the commutator, he called his early devices "electromagnetic self-rotors" - possibly the first DC motor.
A public night school opened in Columbus to combat adult illiteracy, but "all students must furnish their own light".
Millersport in Licking County is founded.

The Sandy and Beaver Canal is incorporated. It extends 73 miles from Bolivar on the Ohio and Erie Canal in Stark County to the mouth of the Little Beaver on the Pennsylvania and Ohio boundary, passing through Stark, Carroll and Columbiana counties. At its summit it passes through a tunnel. Prior to completion the canal failed and was abandoned, except for 6 miles adjacent to the Ohio and Erie Canal.
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad construction begins.
Andrew Jackson inaugurated as President.
James Carrington of Wallingford, CT patented the coffee mill.

At the urging of Rev. Dr. Hoge, pastor of the Worthington Presbyterian Church, the Ohio School for the Deaf was opened in a small building on the corner of High and Broad streets.  Only three pupils were present.
Carroll in Licking County is founded.
Worthington Presbyterian Church purchases lot on the Worthington Village Green from James Kilbourne for $40. A small, "barn-like" church is constructed.
Worthington's first public (as opposed to subscription) school built on the Southeast corner of what is now Oxford and Short Streets.
The Warren County Canal is incorporated to be built by a private company. Seventeen miles long with no locks.
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad opens its first 14 mile horse-drawn segment.
The first commercial railway line is opened, connecting Liverpool with Manchester in England.
Ohio Reformed Medical College is established under the Worthington College charter and utilizing its facility.

George Stephenson used the 4 ft ​8 1⁄2 in gauge (including a belated extra ​1⁄2 in (12.7 mm) of free movement to reduce binding on curves) for the Liverpool and Manchester Railway, which opened this day.
First regularly scheduled passenger service in US using steam power opens at Charleston on the South Carolina Railroad.
Columbus, Ohio's population is 2437.
The population of Cincinnati is 24,831, Zanesville 3,094, Dayton 2,950 and Chillicothe 2,846
First church service held in St. John's Episcopal church, which still stands on the Village Green.
St. John's Episcopal Church building in Worthington completed.
Water first flows through the connecting canal at Lockbourne, Ohio.
The first canal boat arrives in Columbus, "The Governer Brown", from Cincinatti.
First Trinity Episcopal Church built in Columbus.
Ohio and Erie Canal Lock 22 Groveport was built in 1831 to serve the villages of Rarey's Port and Wert's Grove.
The Black Hawk War begins, pushed Sac & Fox Indians across Mississippi.
Cleveland and Portsmouth linked with completion of Ohio and Erie canal.
Land for the Ohio Penitentiary acquired, 15 acres costing $800 total.
The entire 308 mile route of the Ohio-Erie opens to traffic.
William Sturgeon demonstrates the first commutated DC motor.

The Ohio Board of Canal Commissioners state that the Ohio and Erie Canal and Miami and Erie Canal are complete except for the lower lock of Portsmouth, the Southern Termination of the Ohio Canal, and the locks by which the Miami and Erie Canal is to be connected with the Ohio River at Cincinnati.
Cholera epidemic strikes Columbus. Henry Stagg ate his usual hearty Sunday breakfast and shortly after became ill. He died six hours later. By September, 100 deaths are reported.
Slavery abolished in the British Empire.
The National Road reaches Columbus.

The Whetstone river is renamed the Olentangy river by the Ohio State Legislature. The Olentangy River should have been named the Whetstone River. The literal translation of the Delaware Indian name for the Olentangy River - "Kiin ansh ikan Siipu nk" is "Sharp/More and More/Tool/River," or more precisely Whetstone. Both the Native Americans and early settlers used the black Ohio and Olentangy shale found along the river for whetstones to sharpen their tools.
Oberlin College first to admit women as well as men.
The Miami Extension Canal in Ohio is authorized to be built. It will be 114 miles long and connected Dayton to the Auglaize and Maumee Rivers.
The City of Columbus is incorporated by an act of the Ohio Legislature.

The Ohio Legislature authorized the construction of the Wabash and Erie Canal. Designed to connect Indiana's canal system to Lake Erie, the portion from the Ohio-Indiana border to Lake Erie, 67.75 miles long, was built by Ohio after Indiana conveyed ownership of 292,223 acres of land granted it by the Federal Government for canal construction purposes.
The State of Pennsylvania opens the 395 mile long "Main Line of Public Works", a succession of trains, canals and inclined planes. Travel time across Pennsylvania is reduced to 4-1/2 days.
Lancaster inaugurates its $37,000 lateral canal connecting it to the Ohio and Erie Canal.
Thomas Davenport invents the DC electric motor. He patents it in 1837, and uses it to operate a printing press.
Ohio Penitentiary occupied.
The Cincinnati and Whitewater Canal, which extends 90 miles from Cincinnati up Whitewater Creek into Wayne County, IN, is incorporated.
The British Parliment reforms the 1601 Poor Law, slashing aid to the poor, encouraging the rural to move to the cities and find jobs. This marks the beginning of industrial capitalism.
The Village of Worthington is incorporated by the Ohio legislature. James Kilbourne chosen as first Mayor.
The Worthington Anti-Slavery Society is organized with 66 subscribers.
Chief Justice John Marshall of the United States Supreme Court dies in office.
The Great Western Railway recieves its enabling act by the British Parliment.
Texas declares itself independent of Mexico, Stephen Austin and Sam Houston are leaders.
Cherokee Indians forced to relocate from Georgia to across the Mississippi after gold is discovered on their lands.
Oberlin College first to admit African Americans.
Cabinetmaker James Russell begins work on an orrery (mechanical model of the solar system) with orbit of rotating planets 68 feet in diameter.
Oldest portion of what is now the Worthington Inn constructed as a residence for the Rensselaer W. and Laura Kilbourne Cowles family.
Village Council prohibits dead animals, manure, and construction debris from being left on village streets and animals from running at large in the village.
Mexican General Santa Anna besieges the Alamo, all defenders killed including Davy Crocket.
The Warren County Canal's private investors fail, and the state takes over the canal, making it an appendage of the Miami Canal.
Roger Brooke Taney takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
Arkansas admitted to the United States.
Sugar Grove in Licking County is founded.
Charter granted to the Cleveland, Columbus & Cincinnati Railroad
Second Bank of the United States' charter expires.
Michigan admitted to the United States.
Martin Van Buren inaugurated as President.

The Panic of 1837 was an economic depression, one of the sharpest financial crises in the history of the United States. The Panic was built on a speculative fever. The bubble burst this day in New York City, when every bank stopped payment in specie (gold and silver coinage). The Panic was followed by a six-year depression, with the failure of banks and record unemployment levels.
Queen Victoria ascends to the throne of England.
The Ohio State Institution for the Blind opens in the Columbus Presbyterian Church. Only five students were enrolled.
Erie & Kalamazoo Railroad operates first steam locomotive from Toledo to Adrian, Michigan.
William Proctor, an English-American candle maker, and James Gamble, an Irish American soap maker, formed Proctor and Gamble.
Ohio Penitentiary addition completed.
Construction begins on the Wabash and Erie Canal.
Bill Moose, who will live 100 years and become the last Wyandotte Indian in Ohio, is born in northern Ohio.
Victoria becomes Queen of England at age 18.

SS Great Western departs Bristol for New York, was an oak-hulled paddle-wheel steamship, the first steamship (side wheel) purpose-built for crossing the Atlantic, and the initial unit of the Great Western Steamship Company.
The Great Western, a British steam powered ship, arrives in New York.
The Great Western Railway in Britain opens its first 22-1/2 mile section from Paddington Station in London to Maidenhead Station.
Worthington Female Seminary incorporated under the auspices of the Methodist Church and the influence of Rev. Uriah Heath.
Worthington Literati is incorporated to establish a library and lyceum.
Joseph Smith escapes from jail in Liberty, Missouri. He purchases swampy land along the Mississippi neary Quincy Illinois and establishes the city of Nauvoo.
SS Archimedes made her maiden voyage, from London to Sheerness near the mouth of the Thames. Archimedes is notable for being the world's first steamship to be driven by a screw propeller.
Cornerstone laid for the Ohio State House. Takes 22 years to build.
The first Central Ohio Asylum for Lunatics is built on West Broad Street.
Work is begun on the Cincinnati and Whitewater Canal, which extends 90 miles from Cincinnati up Whitewater Creek into Wayne County, IN.
Worthington Medical College closes and relocates in Cincinnati amid economic depression and controversy over rumored cemetery raids to procure cadavers for anatomy classes.
Antarctic Continent found by Comdr. Charles Wilkes of First U.S. Exploring Expedition; named Wilkes Land.
Queen Victoria marries Prince Albert.
SS Archimedes, the world's first steamship to be driven by a screw propeller, is tested by the British Navy against side wheel steamers. They conclude that the screw design is superior.

At 1:17 pm the "Natchez Tornado" killed 317 people and injured 109 along the Mississippi River in Louisiana and Mississippi. The twister moved along the water before making its biggest impact in Concordia Parish, Louisiana, and Adams County, Mississippi. According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the official death toll may not include slaves.
The Great Western railway in Britain reaches a temporary terminus at Wootton Bassett Road west of Swindon and 80.25 miles (129 km) from Paddington.
First Franklin County Courthouse built.
Columbus, Ohio's population is 6048.
Ohio Whig Convention launches "Tippecanoe and Tyler too" campaign of Ohioan William Henry Harrison with parades, ringing bells and firing cannons.
The Warren County Canal, a 17 mile canal with no locks connected to the Miami Canal, is completed at a cost to the state of Ohio of $217,552.
Worthington erects  a log cabin on the public square to show its support for Harrison.
William Henry Harrison inaugurated as President.
William Henry Harrison dies from a cold.
John Tyler inaugurated as President.
First passenger train on the Erie Railroad.

In Britain, Box Tunnel is opened. A special train departed London Paddington and traversed the whole of the Great Western Railway to complete the first rail journey to Temple Meads Station in Bristol in about four hours.
Owners of lots adjacent to the Village square (Village Green) required to build gravel sidewalks.
1st US wire suspension bridge for general traffic opens in Pennsylvania.
Queen Victoria was riding in a carriage along The Mall, London, when John Francis aimed a pistol at her, but the gun did not fire.
Wyandotte Indians, the last tribe in Ohio, are forced to move from their Upper Sandusky reservation to west of the Mississippi River.
Construction is completed on the Wabash and Erie Canal.

Cabinetmaker James Russell completes work on an orrery (mechanical model of the solar system) with orbit of rotating planets 68 feet in diameter. It was exhibited at the American Institute in New York City and several European countries.
Three-story brick building dedicated as home to Worthington Female Seminary.
Edgar Allan Poe's short story "The Tell-Tale Heart" is first published.
The world does not end, contrary to the first prediction by American preacher William Miller.
Naval Battle of Campeche: Naval Battle between the Mexican Navy versus the Texas Navy and the Yucatán Navy. The battle features the most advanced warships of its day.
Nakahama Manjirō lands in New Bedford, Massachusetts, the first known Japanese in the United States.
The first major wagon train for the American Northwest sets out with one thousand pioneers from Elm Grove, Missouri on the Oregon Trail.
Ulysses S. Grant graduates from West Point 21st from a class of 39.
Origin of Latter Day Saint polygamy: Joseph Smith, founder of the Latter Day Saint movement, receives a revelation recommending polygamy.
Mexican President Antonio López de Santa Anna announces that the annexation of Texas by the United States would be considered an act of war by Mexico.
In New York City, Henry Jones and 11 others found B'nai B'rith, the oldest Jewish service organization in the world.
The Kingdom of Hawai`i is officially recognized by the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and July Monarchy France as an independent nation.
The Worthington School moves out of its building on the Village Green.
Columbus & Xenia Railroad Chartered

Joseph Smith excommunicates William Law, Smith's trusted counselor, and Robert Foster, a general of the Nauvoo Legion after disagreements over managing Nauvoo's economy and possibly Smith attempting to marry their wives.

John C. Fremont led an overland expedition west and camped at Las Vegas Springs. His name is remembered today in neon as well as museums and history books. The Fremont Hotel-Casino in Downtown Las Vegas bears his name as does Fremont Street -- the main thoroughfare through the heart of casino-lined Glitter Gulch.
First telegraph message sent from U.S. Supreme Court to Baltimore by S.F.B. Morse, "What hath god wrought?"
Joseph Smith declares martial law in Nauvoo, after his destruction of a printing press riles the populace.
Charles Goodyear was granted patent #3,633 for vulcanized rubber.

Death of Joseph Smith: Joseph Smith, founder of the Latter Day Saint movement, and his brother Hyrum are killed in Carthage Jail, Carthage, Illinois by an armed mob, leading to a succession crisis in the movement. John Taylor, future president of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, is severely injured but survives.
The Great Flood of 1844 hits the Missouri River and Mississippi River.
The U.S. signs the Treaty of Wanghia with Qing dynasty China, the first diplomatic agreement between the two nations in history.
The Great Disappointment: Millerites (including future members of the Seventh-day Adventist Church) find that the Second Coming of Jesus does not occur as predicted by preacher William Miller.
AEP: Columbus installs gas powered streetlights.
The Columbus School District is formed when the State Legislature entrusts the management of the schools in Columbus to a Board of Education.
Florida admitted to the United States.
John Knox Polk inaugurated as President.
Texas votes to join the United States.

The SS Great Britain embarked on her maiden voyage, from Liverpool to New York under Captain James Hosken, with 45 passengers. The ship made the passage in 14 days and 21 hours, at an average speed of 9.25 knots. This was the first Transatlantic crossing of an all iron steamship.
Texas becomes the 28th state.
The Great Potato famine in Ireland. During the famine, about one million people died and a million more emigrated from Ireland, causing the island's population to fall by between 20% and 25%.
The Miami and Erie Canal is completed.
The Miami Extension Canal in Ohio is completed. It is 114 miles long and connected Dayton to the Auglaize and Maumee Rivers.

St. John's first rectory is built just south of the church facing the public square. This building is now known as The Old Rectory, the Worthington Historical Society's headquarters on W. New England Avenue.

The Great Famine (Irish: an Gorta Mór, [anˠ ˈgɔɾˠt̪ˠa mˠoːɾˠ]) or the Great Hunger was a period of mass starvation, disease, and emigration in Ireland between 1845 and 1849. With the greatest impacted areas to the west and south of Ireland, where the Irish language was primarily spoken, the period was contemporaneously known as in Irish: An Drochshaol, loosely translated as the hard-times (or literally, "The Bad Life"). The worst year of the period, that of "Black 47", is known as Irish: Bliain an Drochshaoil. During the famine, about one million people died and a million more emigrated from Ireland,[5] causing the island's population to fall by between 20% and 25%

PRR: The Pennsylvania Railroad Charter Bill is signed by Pennsylvania governer Francis R. Shunk. The company is authorized to raise $7.5 million through the sale of 150,000 shares of stock at $50 each.

Captain Seth B. Thornton and 80 cavalry soldiers are ambushed, with 11 killed , 6 wounded and the rest captured by 1600 Mexican soldiers led by General Anastasio Torrejón. Thornton had been sent by General Zachary Taylor to investigate reports that Torrejón had just crossed the Rio Grande.

Mexican artillery at Matamoros opened fire on Fort Texas, which replied with its own guns. The bombardment continued for 160 hours[55] and expanded as Mexican forces gradually surrounded the fort. Thirteen U.S. soldiers were injured during the bombardment, and two were killed.[55] Among the dead was Jacob Brown, after whom the fort was later named.

Zachary Taylor and 2,400 troops arrived to relieve the fort. However, General Arista rushed north and intercepted him with a force of 3,400 at Palo Alto. The Mexicans are defeated and retreat across the Rio Grande.

The Battle of Resaca de la Palma, one of the early engagements of the Mexican–American War, United States General Zachary Taylor engaged the retreating forces of the Mexican Ejército del Norte ("Army of the North") under General Mariano Arista
The U.S. Congress declares war on Mexico.

34 American settlers seized control of the undefended Mexican government outpost of Sonoma to forestall Castro's plans.[92] One settler created the Bear Flag and raised it over Sonoma Plaza. Within a week, 70 more volunteers joined the rebels' force,[93] which grew to nearly 300 in early July.[94] This event, led by William B. Ide, became known as the Bear Flag Revolt.
Mexico's congress officially declares war on the United States.
Seven sailors and marines landed at Yerba Buena (now San Francisco) and raised the American flag. Later that day in Sonoma, the Bear Flag was lowered and the American flag was raised in its place.
Commodore Robert F. Stockton arrives be sea in Monterey.
Commodore Robert F. Stockton and 400 men enter Los Angeles unopposed.
Antonio López de Santa Anna used political turmoil in Mexico caused by the war with the United States to revive his political career and return from self-imposed exile in Cuba.

The planet Neptune is discovered by Johann Gottfried Galle, of the Berlin Observatory, and Louis d'Arrest, an astronomy student, through mathematical predictions made by Urbain Jean Joseph Le Verrier.

Captain William Mervine landed 350 sailors and Marines at San Pedro. They were ambushed and repulsed at the Battle of Dominguez Rancho by Flores' forces in less than an hour. Four Americans died, with 8 severely injured. Stockton arrived with reinforcements at San Pedro, which increased the American forces there to 800. He and Mervine then set up a base of operations at San Diego.
The planet Neptune's moon, Triton, is discovered by William Lassell, a British astronomer.

Commodore Matthew C. Perry led a detachment of seven vessels along the northern coast of Tabasco state. Perry arrived at the Tabasco River (now known as the Grijalva River) and seized the town Port of Frontera along with two of their ships. Leaving a small garrison, he advanced with his troops towards the town of San Juan Bautista (Villahermosa today).
U.S. Colonel Stephen W. Kearny and his force of about 100 men, who had performed a grueling march across New Mexico and the Sonoran Desert, crossed the Colorado River

100 lancers under General Andrés Pico (brother of the governor), tipped off and lying in wait, fought Kearny's army of about 150 at the Battle of San Pasqual, where 22 of Kearny's men (one of whom later died of wounds), including three officers, were killed in 30 minutes of fighting.
Iowa admitted to the United States.
Three new Columbus schools are financed by a $7,500 levy that passes on the 2nd try.

Articles of Capitulation were signed on by Frémont, Andrés Pico and six others at a rancho at Cahuenga Pass (modern-day North Hollywood).[130] This became known as the Treaty of Cahuenga, which marked the end of armed resistance in California.
In U.S. occupied New Mexico, insurrectionists began the revolt in Don Fernando de Taos, present-day Taos, and nearby Taos Pueblo. 16 Americans are killed by a force of 500 insurrectionists.

General Stephen Watts Kearny and a force of 478 men confront 500 insurrectionist Mexican rebels at  Siege of Pueblo de Taos. Approx. 150 rebels are killed and 400 captured after intense hand to hand combat.
Thomas Edison is born in Milan, Ohio
By an act of congress, ten new infantry regiments are added to the eight existing regiments for the war with Mexico.

Santa Anna personally marched north to fight Taylor with 20,000 men. Taylor, with 4,600 men, had entrenched at a mountain pass called Buena Vista. Santa Anna suffered desertions on the way north and arrived with 15,000 men in a tired state. He demanded and was refused surrender of the U.S. Army

Santa Anna flanked the U.S. positions by sending his cavalry and some of his infantry up the steep terrain that made up one side of the pass, while a division of infantry attacked frontally along the road leading to Buena Vista. Furious fighting ensued, during which the U.S. troops were nearly routed, but managed to cling to their entrenched position, thanks to the Mississippi Rifles, a volunteer regiment led by Jefferson Davis, who formed them into a defensive V formation. The Mexicans had inflicted considerable losses but Santa Anna had gotten word of upheaval in Mexico City, so he withdrew that night, leaving Taylor in control of part of Northern Mexico.
Central Ohio Railroad receives its charter after promotional work which originated in Zanesville.
Alexander W. Doniphan occupied Chihuahua City. British consul John Potts did not want to let Doniphan search Governor Trias's mansion, and unsuccessfully asserted it was under British protection.

General Winfield Scott performed the first major amphibious landing in U.S. history in preparation for the Siege of Veracruz. A group of 12,000 volunteer and regular soldiers successfully offloaded supplies, weapons, and horses near the walled city using specially designed landing crafts. Included in the invading force were Robert E. Lee, George Meade, Ulysses S. Grant, James Longstreet, and Thomas "Stonewall" Jackson.

General Winfield Scott marched westward, toward Mexico City with 8,500 healthy troops, while Santa Anna set up a defensive position in a canyon around the main road about 50 miles (80 km) north-west of Veracruz, near the hamlet of Cerro Gordo.
Nine insurrectionist from the Siege of Pueblo de Taos are hanged by the U.S. Government after drumhead trials.
The Mexican army was routed at Cerro Gordo, near Xalapa. The U.S. Army suffered 400 casualties, while the Mexicans suffered over 1,000 casualties and 3,000 were taken prisoner.

Perry arrived at San Juan Bautista and commenced bombing the city. The attack included two ships that sailed past the fort and began shelling it from the rear. David D. Porter led 60 sailors ashore and seized the fort, raising the American flag over the works. Perry and the landing force arrived and took control of the city around 14:00
Three, six-room school houses are open in Columbus.

With guerrillas harassing his line of communications back to Veracruz, General Winfield Scott decided not to weaken his army to defend Puebla but, leaving only a garrison at Puebla to protect the sick and injured recovering there, advanced on Mexico City on August 7 with his remaining force.
First post office opens in Clintonville. This date is considered the "official birthday" of Clintonville.

Santa Anna made one last attempt to defeat the Americans, by cutting them off from the coast. General Joaquín Rea began the Siege of Puebla, soon joined by Santa Anna, but they failed to take it before the approach of a relief column from Veracruz under Brig. Gen. Joseph Lane prompted Santa Anna to stop him.
Land purchased to build combination market house and city hall
Dr. Asa Lord becomes the Columbus School District's first superintendent.
The Columbus School District hires its first African-American teacher, John Geddes.
The United Brethren Church opens Otterbein University, the first institution of higher learning in the United States to admit women without restrictions.

The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo (Tratado de Guadalupe Hidalgo in Spanish), officially titled the Treaty of Peace, Friendship, Limits and Settlement between the United States of America and the Mexican Republic, is signed in the Villa de Guadalupe Hidalgo (now a neighborhood of Mexico City) between the United States and Mexico to end the Mexican–American War.
Wisconsin admitted to the United States.
The first time a presidential election was held on the same date in every state. Zachary Taylor, a Whig vs. Lewis Cass, a Democrat.

Green Lawn Cemetery was designed by landscape architect Howard Daniels and architect Frank Packard. The cemetery covers 360 acres and provides a habitat for birds and other wildlife. As one of Ohio's oldest and largest cemeteries, Green Lawn is an artistic and historical memorial. The stained glass windows and mosaic artwork in the Chapel came from Tiffany & Co. of New York. Gordon Battelle - founder of Battelle Memorial Institute, Samuel Bush - president of Buckeye Steel castings and great grandfather of President George W. Bush, James Poindexter Ð first African American to be elected to the Columbus City Council, and James Rhodes - the longest serving governor of Ohio, are just a few of the noted individuals to be buried in Green Lawn Cemetery.
The Illinois and Michigan canal connects Chicago and Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River.
The Ohio Legislature creates a state department of common schools for Negro and Mulatto children.
Columbus, Piqua & Indiana Railroad chartered by the state legislature.
Zachary Taylor inaugurated as President.
The canals previously known as the Miami Canal, the Miami Extension Canal and the Wabash and Erie Canal are joined together as the Miami and Erie Canal.
PRR: The first segment of track, 61 miles from Harrisburg to Lewiston opened.
PRR: Track is extended to McVeyton.
The Columbus & Springfield railroad is chartered.
Columbus and Worthington Plank Road is incorporated and improves the old Columbus and Sandusky Turnpike with wood planks.
Rev. Thomas Woodrow, grandfather of future president Woodrow Wilson, becomes minister of the Worthington Presbyterian Church, where he serves until 1857.
The first train to ever run in Columbus runs from Columbus to Xenia, a distance of 54 miles, in three hours and five minutes on the Columbus & Xenia Railroad.

Columbus & Xenia begins regular train service from Columbus, out of a temporary depot on the west side of the Scioto in Franklinton. A wooden bridge across the Scioto wouldn't be finished for another 10 months.
Both houses of the Ohio Legislature take a free ride over the Columbus & Xenia line.
PRR: Track is extended to Mt. Union.
James Kilbourne dies.
Central Market opens
PRR: Track is extended to Huntingdon.
Millard Fillmore inaugurated as President.
California admitted to the United States.
PRR: Track is extended to Duncansville.

PRR: Track is extended at Duncansville to make a connection with the Allegheny Portage Railroad. The PRR takes control of the Harrisburg, Portsmouth, Mount Joy and Lancaster railroad, providing a continuous 173 mile track from Duncansville to Lancaster.
The first Ohio State Fair takes place for 3 days at Camp Washington, two miles north of Cincinnati.
Wooden railroad bridge across the Scioto completed on the Columbus and Xenia Railroad. First train from Cincinnati crosses the new bridge and enters union depot.
The fugitive slave act is passed in Ohio, but only emboldens those who run the underground railroad to move escaped slaves north.
Worthington's Orange Johnson sells land for construction of Columbus' Union Station.
425 passengers board a dignitary train from Columbus to Cleveland on the new Cleveland, Columbus & Cincinnati RR.
The constitution of the state of Ohio is revised, providing for election of judges and again denying voting rights to women and blacks.
Ohio voters ratify the new constitution.
The revised constitution of the state of Ohio goes into effect.
The planet Uranus's moons Ariel and Umbriel are discovered by William Lassell.
German immigrant Simon Lazarus opens a one-room men's clothing store at S. High and Town streets.
The Columbus School District graduates its first high school class.
The Cleveland, Mt. Vernon & Columbus Railroad is chartered.
The CCC railroad line passes the village one mile east of the Public Square.
The construction of the Central Jersey Railroad Company of New Jersey brought new life to the ironworks and the community. A "High Bridge" over the raritan river gives the borough its modern name.
Central Ohio Railroad opens to traffic between Newark and Zanesville
PRR: J. Edgar Thomson is elevated from Chief Engineer to President.
Ohio's first state Capital Building is destroyed in a fire. The brick structure was constructed from clay excavated from an old indian mound at the southwest corner of Mound and High Streets.
PRR: A $3 million dollar bond is issued so construction connecting the eastern and western portions across the Alleghenies and bypassing the Allegheny Portage Railroad could commence.
PRR: Track is opened from Pittsburgh to Johnstown.
National Road construction stops at Vandalia, IL. Plans to extend the road to the Mississippi are abandoned.

George Stoner, a stagecoach driver and Westerville Inn owner, opens a stagecoach stop on State Street. He hides runaway slaves in his stagecoach, takes them to Westerville, and offers them protection in the cellar of his inn at 133 S. State St.
Baltimore & Ohio Railroad completes its road from Baltimore thru Pittsburgh to Wheeling, affording thru service on the Central Ohio Railroad (except for the Ohio River crossing).
The Central Ohio railroad is granted access to the Columbus depot at High & Naughten owned by the Xenia and CCC lines.
Central Ohio Railroad opens to traffic between Newark and Columbus
Franklin Pierce inaugurated as President.
First train runs from Columbus to Urbana on the Columbus, Piqua and Indiana Railroad

American Commodore Matthew Perry entered the waters of what is now Tokyo Bay, Japan, with four armed steamships. Perry's show of military strength forced Japan to open its ports to trade with the West for the first time in more than 200 years.
John Reed Hilliard plats the town of Hilliard.
Gail Borden files a patent for his new milk condensing process.
The Columbus & Springfield railroad completed a 20 mile section from Springfield to London, and then ran out of money and didn't make it to Columbus.
The Little Miami Railroad and the Columbus & Xenia enter a contract where the two roads are operated as one line serving Southwest Ohio.

PRR: Horseshoe curve is opened at Altoona. The engineering marvel was a half mile long, 1800 feet across and rose 122 feet in elevation. Philadelphia to Pittsburgh travel time was shortened by a day and the fare was reduced from $9.50 to $8.00. By the end of 1854, the curve was double tracked.
Commodore Perry returned with an even larger squadron to receive Japan’s answer. The Japanese grudgingly agreed to Perry’s demands, and the two sides signed the Treaty of Kanagawa
Central Ohio Railroad opens to traffic between Zanesville and Bellaire
The Cleveland, Mt. Vernon & Columbus Railroad completes a line from Hudson to the coal fields southwest of Millersburg.
The Columbus & Springfield is leased to the Mad River and Lake Erie Railroad.
The Picqua enters Columbus depot through a switchback.
William Bishop renovates the Cowles family home and opens it as a hotel, Bishop House (now known as the Worthington Inn).
The Union Iron Works in High Bridg,e NJ installs the Nasinyth hammer.
The Warren County Canal, and its associated water rights, is sold for $40,000 to John A. Corwin and R. H. Hendrickson.
The Ohio State Journal complains about numerous accidents and long roadblocks due to trains crossing High Street.
Ohio Canal receipts reach their peak.
International Order of Odd Fellows (I.O.O.F.) Ark Lodge No. 270 established in Worthington.

Plat filed for Morris Addition, Worthington's first subdivision, with 118 lots adjoining the southeast side of the village. Financing by Methodists aims to encourage home ownership for retired ministers and African Americans.
Henry and Dolly Turk become the first African Americans in the village to own their own home.
Sir William Henry Perkins serendipitously discovery the first synthetic organic dye, mauveine, made from aniline. It proves a commercial success and sparks interest in organic dies.
Hurricane: Last Island, La.: 400 died.
Henry Bessemer first described a new steel making process to a meeting of the British Association in Cheltenham which he titled "The Manufacture of Iron Without Fuel."

Worthington Union School, 67 E. Granville Rd., opens. It is the oldest surviving "Union School" in Franklin County and perhaps in Ohio. Primary and intermediate classrooms were on the first floor and the I.O.O.F. Lodge rented the second floor until it was needed for classes.
Work begins on the foundations of the John Roebling suspension bridge in Cincinnati.
Columbus, Piqua & Indiana Railroad extended to Union City.
The State of Ohio takes possession of 6 miles of the Sandy and Beaver Canal. A branch of this canal, the Nimishillin Canal, extends 12 miles to Canton.
The legislature occupies the still uncompleted Ohio State House.
James Buchanan inaugurated as President.
PRR: J. Edgar Thomson purchases the assets of the old canal system and New Portage Railroad for $7.5 million.

In the second day of a hurricane the S.S. Central America sprang a leak at 9 a.m. Passengers were ordered to assist the crew in bailing. The ship sank at about 8 p.m. on Saturday, September 12, about 160 miles east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, drowning a total of 426 passengers and crew, including Captain William Lewis Herndon. Unable to meet payrolls or pay creditors because of the loss of the gold cargo, New York banks began to fail and stores and factories began to close. The failure of the New York Branch of the Ohio Life Insurance and Trust Co. bursts a European speculative bubble in U.S. railroads and loss of confidence in U.S. banks, and ended the boom that followed the Mexican-American war. The depression lasts for three years.
PRR: The New Portage Railroad is closed and its tracks lifted and sent west to complete the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne & Chicago Railroad.
Gail Borden founds the New York Condensed Milk Company, later to become the Borden Company.
Central Ohio Railroad goes into receivership. B&O acquires an interest in the railroad and keeps it going through the Civil War.
Panic of 1857 - initiated by failure of Ohio Life Insurance and Trust Company of Cincinnati.
Worthington's Female Seminary closes as Ohio Wesleyan University in Delaware attracts young women.
Minnesota admitted to the United States.
Westerville incorporated as a village.
Worthington Council purchases 10 acres south of town for Walnut Grove Cemetery.
James Taylor is the first to be buried in Walnut Grove Cemetery.
Oregon admitted to the United States.
Daniel Emmett introduced "I Wish I was in Dixie's Land" (later named "Dixie") in New York City. Just two years later, the song became the Civil War song of the Confederacy.

When the sun rose in the clear, cold sky on Sunday June 5, it revealed a frosty landscape, which was general throughout the state. As the frost disappeared under the sun's rays, the earth took on a scorched appearance. The corn crop, which in a number of places had reached a height of 10 inches, was frozen. Wheat was also killed in places. Potatoes, other garden vegetables and fruit were all "cooked" in most areas.

Drilling at Titusville, Pennsylvania, "Colonel" Edwin Drake strikes oil at a depth of 69.5 feet. Prior to that, oil, which had been used mostly as a lubricant and lamp fuel, had been obtained only at places where it seeped from the ground. Western Pennsylvania witnesses the world's first oil boom.
Candidate for President Abraham Lincoln spoke to a small group of Ohioans from the east terrace of the Statehouse (now the Atrium).

Pro-slavery residents mocked Samuel Patterson and other anti-slavery Wesleyan Methodists, calling their community of East Orange, Africa. On this date, the North Carolina Alston family slaves were sent North to Ohio and freedom. The slaves settled in "Africa", lived in log homes and were employed by anti-slavery farmers. Africa Road remains today, although the town of "Africa" is buried beneath Alum Creek Dam.
A lean-to structure is added to the northwest side of the Columbus depot to provide a dining room.
The "High Bridge" over the Raritan River in High Bridge, NJ is replaced with a fill over two arches, one for the river and one for the road.

Pony Express mail service began -- in St. Joseph, Missouri. The first Pony Express rider was heading for California. The next day, another rider left Sacramento, California heading east for Missouri. Each rider had a 75 to 100 mile run before a switch was made with another rider. The switch was made at one of 190 way stations along the route; each way station being about ten to fifteen miles apart. The Pony Express riders delivered the mail within ten days (similar to our current snail-mail) for postage paid of $5 per ounce. This style of mail service became antiquated within a short two years, being put out to pasture by the advent of the overland telegraph.
South Carolina secedes from the Union.
The population of Columbus reaches 18,554
Mississippi secedes from the Union.
Florida secedes from the Union.
Alabama secedes from the Union.
Georgia secedes from the Union.
Louisiana secedes from the Union.
Kansas admitted to the United States.
Texas secedes from the Union.
Confederate convention meets in Montgomery, Alabama.
Confederate convention adopts preliminary constitution.
Jefferson Davis of Mississippi elected provisional president of the Confederate States of America.
President Abraham Lincoln speaks from the same spot as in 1859 at the Ohio State House.
Abraham Lincoln inaugurated as President.
South Carolina, through General Beauregard demands surrender of Ft. Sumter in Charleston harbor. Major Robert Anderson, USA, refused.
The Civil War begins when Gen. P.G.T. Beauregard fires on Fort Sumter at 4:30 am. By 1865, 346,326 Ohioans will serve, 23,354 will die from disease and 11,237 from battle.
Major Robert Anderson surrenders Ft. Sumter.
President Lincoln calls for 75,000 militia from states by quotas. New York State votes to enlist 30,000 militia for 2 years and $3,000,000 for defense.
Virginia secedes from the Union.
U.S. troops evacuate Harpers Ferry.
The 6th Massachusetts Infantry en route to Washington is attacked in the streets of Baltimore. Four soldiers are killed.
Col. Robert E. Lee resigns from the U.S. army.
Robert E. Lee takes command of the Virginia troops.
Arkansas secedes from the Union.
Brigadier General George B McClellan, dept. of the Ohio, made full General.
Robert E. Lee promoted to Brigadier General.
North Carolina secedes from the Union.
Tennessee secedes from the Union.
Robert E. Lee promoted to Full General of the Confederacy.
In Missouri, Brig. Gen. Nathaniel Lyon drives Confederates under Gen. Sterling Price out of Jefferson City and Boonville.
The 160 acre Camp Chase created "on the National Road four miles west of Columbus".
In Missouri, Col. Franz Sigel was forced back at Carthage.

Battle of Bull Run or Manassas. Brig. Gen. Irvin McDowell attacked Beauregard's forces on the Warrenton Road, pushed them back to Henry House Hill. Confederates were based on Manassas Junction, Va. Gen. Jos. E. Johnston's army from Winchester, including forces commanded by Brig. Gen. Thomas J. Jackson Gen. E. Kirby Smith reinforced Confederates, and with the help of Gen. Jubal Early's brigade routed Federals. Federals lose 2,708 while Confederates lose 1,967.
U.S. Congress authorizes 500,000 for the army.
In Missouri, Brig. Gen. Nathaniel Lyon killed in losing battle against Gen. Sterling Price at Wilson's Creek.

A 300 by 700 foot stockade for Confederate prisoners is constructed at Camp Chase. Prisoner numbers increase to 8000 by 1863. Over 5000 die over 3 years. Camp Chase cemetery at 2900 Sullivant Ave. contains 2,260 Confederate graves.

Captain William Piney and 14 members of the "Olentangy Reserves" muster into Company E of Thomas Worthington Jr.'s 46th Ohio Volunteer Infantry regiment, which trains at Camp Lyon on the old Worthington Manufacturing Co. site southwest of the village.
George B. McClellan made General in Chief, USA upon the retirement of General Winfield Scott.
Prince Albert dies, leaving Queen Victoria heartbroken.
James Clerk Maxwell publishes four papers over the next two years that unifies electricity and magnetism.
The Columbus School District opens its first high school, Central High School, at the corner of Broad and 6th Streets.
Horace Wright builds the house at 137 E. Granville Rd. that is now known as Sharon Memorial Hall.
Village council votes to fence in the public square (Village Green).
Maj. Gen. Henry W. Halleck, Western Dept., sent Brig. Gen. U.S. Grant with 17,000 on river craft of Flag Officer Andrew H. Foote vs. Ft. Henry on the Tennessee River; it fell.
Gen. U.S. Grant rushed troops across 10 mi. of bogs to Ft. Donelson on the Cumberland, sent his "unconditional surrender" message to Brig. Gen. Simon B. Bruckner CSA who gave up with 11,500.
At Pea Ridge, AK, Gen. Samual R. Curtis, USA, defeated Gens. Van Dorn and Price. Casualties USA 1,351, CSA 1,300.
Confederates rebuilt scuttled U.S. frigate Merrimack into ironclad Virginia. Sank Cumberland USN, destroyed Congress USN at Hampton Roads, Va. Three other US ships run aground, including Minnesota.

Monitor, flat decked ironclad, 900 tons, 172 ft. long with revolving turret and two 11 in. guns, built by John Ericsson at $275,000 cost; Lt. John L. Worden commander, crew of 58, badly damaged Virginia, which withdrew.
New Madrid, Mo. captured Mar. 14th by Gen. John Pope.

Beginning of Peninsular Campaign. McClellan moved Army of the Potomac by sea to Fort Monroe, Va, 70 mi. from Richmond. Confederates sent Stonewall Jackson up Shenandoah Valley to divert Federals; Jackson lost at Kernstown, Va but routed Federals at McDowell, Front Royal, Winchester, Cross Keys, Port Republic through June 9th.

Gen. Albert Sidney Johnston CSA, 40,000 from Corinth, Mississippi surprised Grant at Shiloh Church near Pittsburg Landing, Tenn. The 46th O.V.I. Suffers 236 men killed, wounded or missing at the Battle of Shiloh - 40 percent of those present for duty. Deaths include 1st Sgt. Burr and Pvt. Barker of Worthington. Enlistments continue with several local men including Capt. John Skeele joining the 113th O.V.I. that fights from Chickamauga through Sherman's march to the sea.

Confederate Gen. Johnston killed, Gen. Beauregard retreats after Brig. Gen. Don Carlos Buell reinforced Grant with about 20,000. US had 1,734 killed out of 13,047 casualties and CSA had 1,728 killed out of 10,699 casualties.
Island No. 10 surrendered to Pope and Foote with 7,000 men.
New Orleans surrenders to Flag Officer David G. Farragut.
New Orleans turned over to Gen. Benj. F. Butler.
McClellan's advance troops clash with Maj. Gen. James Longstreet at Williamsburg.
Federals capture Confederate naval base; Confederates scuttle ironclad Virginia (former USN Merrimack).
Second US Corp crossed to south side of Chickahominy leaving Third Corp on north side.

Gen. Joseph E. Johnston attacked Second US Corp on south side of Chickahominy, the Battle of Fair Oaks or Seven Pines. Johnston repulsed. Johnston was wounded and Lee took over Army of Northern Virginia.
Gen. J.E.B. Stuart, CSA, led his cavalry on scout around McClellan.
President Lincoln signs the Land-Grant Act for Universities
The Columbus School District requires all students to be immunized against smallpox.
A lean-to structure is added to the southeast side of the Columbus depot to provide offices, and thus increase the waiting area.
Cleveland, Columbus & Cincinnati RR buys the insolvent Springfield, Mt. Vernon and Pittsburgh, thus connecting finally to Cincinnati.
Emancipation Proclamation frees the slaves.
West Virginia admitted to the United States.
Battle of Gettysburg begins
Confederate General John Hunt Morgan and 364 of his men are captured in Columbiana County after terrorizing Indiana and Ohio.
Henry Ford is born on a farm in Greenfield Township, Michigan.
Confederate General John Hunt Morgan and six of his compatriots escape from the Ohio State Penitentiary.
George Stoner sells his inn at 133 S. State St., used as a station on the Underground Railroad since 1852.
The Cincinnati and Whitewater Canal, which extends 90 miles from Cincinnati up Whitewater Creek into Wayne County, IN, is abandoned.
Homer Tuller and Ezra Gilbert are paid to plant 62 trees on the public square (Village Green).
Secretary of War Stanton ordered all remaining Confederates transferred from the Ohio State Penitentiary to the notorious prisoner of war camp, Fort Delaware.

The first travel accident policy was issued. The Travelers Insurance Company (the company with the red umbrella as a logo, remember?) issued the policy to James Batterson, who also received the first general insurance policy issued by the firm in July, 1864.
Chief Justice Roger Brooke Taney of the United States Supreme Court dies in office.
Nevada becomes a state.
Nevada admitted to the United States.
Salmon Portland Chase takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
The Columbus School District's oldest building still standing, the Third Street School in German village, is built. Today it is a hobby shop for senior citizens.
The Steubenville & Indiana Railroad comes in to Columbus Depot over the Central Ohio Railroad tracks from Newark. This later develops into the "Panhandle Route" between Columbus and Pittsburgh.
Methodist congregation replaces their building with a new church adjoining the Female Seminary.

The Civil War winds down when General Robert E. Lee surrenders to U.S. Grant at Appomattox Court House. Four Worthington men were killed during the war - Eli Barker, Henry C. Burr, George McIlvan and Walter A. Tuller.
Andrew Johnson inaugurated as President.
President Abraham Lincoln dies after being shot by John Wilkes Booth the previous night.

The body of Abraham Lincoln was met at the Columbus depot by a civic and military parade, which escorted the funeral car to the State House. The remains lay in state in the rotunda from 9:30 am to 4 pm. By actual count 8000 people an hour passed through the rotunda, and it was estimated that over 50,000 viewed the remains
Built by Reverend Francis X. Specht, St. Mary Church and School were established to meet the needs of a growing German Catholic population on Columbus' South Side.
U.S. national debt is 2.68 billion dollars.
Worthington Village Council prohibits "riding, driving or leading animals" across the public square (Village Green) except on the roads that cross and go around it.
Rudolph Eickemeyer and G. Osterheld of Yonkers, New York patented a blocking and shaping machine for hats.
The last wire for the John Roebling suspension bridge in Cincinnati is strung across the Ohio River.
Central Ohio Railroad property leased to the B&O.

The first pedestrians walk across the John Roebling suspension bridge in Cincinnati. its 1,057-foot span made it the longest suspension bridge in the world, a record it retained until 1883 when Roebling’s most famous project, the Brooklyn Bridge opened.
Lewis family purchases Bishop House (Worthington Inn) and continues to operate it until 1889 as Union Hotel.
William Heath excavates Hopewell mound and finds fragments of pottery, decayed wood, and the remains of two skeletons.
Nebraska admitted to the United States.
The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for $7,200,000, or 2 cents per acre. Critics call it Seward's Folly, but gold is discovered there in 1896.
Wilbur Wright is born in Henry County, Indiana.
The Alaska Territory is transferred from Russia to the United States in a signing ceremony in Sitka.

Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th Tokugawa shōgun, "put his prerogatives at the Emperor's disposal" and resigned 10 days later. This is the beginning of the Meiji Restoration in Japan that leads to its modernization into an industrial state that can challenge the west.

The Mineral Railroad changes its name to the Columbus, & Hocking Valley Railroad. It is chartered to build and operate a line from Columbus thru Lancaster, Logan, Nelsonville and way points to Athens.
Emporer Meiji of Japan formally announces his restoration of power after defeating Shogunate forces in battle in the Boshin War.
Columbus Catholic Diocese formed. Prior to that time Columbus was under the Cincinnati Diocese. Sylvester Horton Rosecrans appointed Bishop.

Helium (2) French astronomer Jules Janssen observes the first evidence of helium as a bright yellow line with a wavelength of 587.49 nanometers in the spectrum of the chromosphere of the Sun during a total solar eclipse in Guntur, India.
Nicholas Aloysius Gallagher appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.
The first Central Ohio Asylum for Lunatics on West Broad Street burns to the ground.
St. Mary of the Springs Catholic School established in Columbus after the original St. Mary's Academy in Somerset burned.
Cleveland, Columbus & Cincinnati RR consolidates with the Bellefontaine Railroad forming the Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati & Indianapolis Railroad (CCC&I).
Construction begins on the Columbus & Hocking Valley Railroad.
Property of the Columbus & Xenia leased to the Little Miami Railroad.
The Union Depot Company is incorporated to build a new union station in Columbus, but remains dormant.
Harvey and Henry Johnson survey and plat the village of Flint and erect a railroad station to serve Flint, Worthington and Westerville.
The Taylor Iron Works is incorporated in High Bridge. Formerly the Union Forge.
Columbus & Hocking Valley Railroad carries a dignitary train from Columbus to Lancaster
Ulysses Simpson Grant inaugurated as President.
Daniel Bakeman, the last surviving soldier of the Revolutionary War, died at the age of 109.
Hilliard incorporated with a population of 280 residents.
The Winged Arrow, a ship provided by the Russian Government, arrives in St. Petersburg with Russians repatrioted from Alaska.
The first freight train from Nelsonville arrives in Columbus on the Columbus & Hocking Valley Railroad with 22 cars holding 12 tons of coal each.
Trinity Episcopal Church at Broad and 3rd St. constructed.
Little Miami and its leased properties leased to the Pittsburgh Cincinnati & St. Louis Railroad.
PRR: The first tests of the Westinghouse air brake on the PRR.

Annetta Johnson St. Gaudens is born. Johnson was the daughter of Harvey Johnson, who, with his twin brother developed the village of Flint. Annetta grew up to be an accomplished sculptor, working as an assistant to the famous sculptor Augustus St. Gaudens. She married Augustus' brother, Louis.
Julia Holt born south of the village. As an editor in Chicago, she wrote freelance stories for women's and religious magazines and newspapers under the pen name Dorothy Deane in the 1890's.
Work begins on the foundation of the Brooklyn Bridge.
Groundbreaking for a new Lunatic Asylum on a huge plot of land west of Columbus, in the Hilltop area, is presided over by Governor Rutherford B. Hayes.
Columbus population 35,000
Franklinton is annexed to Columbus
The population of Columbus reaches 31,274
Columbus & Hocking Valley Railroad completed to Athens.

The Pope's holdings were left in an uncertain situation when Rome itself was annexed by the Piedmont-led forces which had united the rest of Italy, after a nominal resistance by the papal forces. Between 1861 and 1929 the status of the Pope was referred to as the "Roman Question". The successive Popes were undisturbed in their palace, and certain prerogatives recognized by the Law of Guarantees, including the right to send and receive ambassadors. But the Popes did not recognise the Italian king's right to rule in Rome, and they refused to leave the Vatican compound until the dispute was resolved in 1929
Changes in the Ohio Municipal Code mean that Worthington now has a mayor, six council members serving two year terms, and an official town clerk.
Walter Foss paid to erect signboards on the public square (Village Green).
The Union Depot Company becomes active and plans to build a new station a few hundred yards north of the existing Columbus depot.
Water was pumped for the first time from the West Side Pumping Station on the Scioto River.
The first edition of The Daily Dispatch (later, The Columbus Dispatch) - consisting of four pages and costing 3 cents - was printed from rented headquarters at N. High Street and Lynn Alley.
Orville Wright is born in Dayton.
Plans for the new Union Depot are approved.
Central Ohio Railroad (controlled by the B&O) opens a stone and steel bridge across the Ohio River.

Methodist trustees sell the Female Seminary property for its 1839 purchase price of $1,500. John Ogden opens the Ohio Central Normal School to train teachers, and his wife, Anna, begins the first training program in the state for kindergarten teachers.
The new Columbus City Hall opens at a cost of $175,000.
G.B. Brayton of Boston, MA received a patent for the gas-powered street car.
Blackjack Chewing Gum introduced.
CCC&I makes agreements with the Cincinnati & Springfield RR and the Cincinnati Sandusky & Cleveland RR providing control of thru trackage between Cleveland and Cincinnati.
CCC&I takes over the Mad River and Lake Erie Railroad and its leasee, The Columbus & Springfield Railroad.
Columbus & Hocking Valley Railroad extends line into Columbus, and using Columbus, Piqua & Indiana track rights, into Union Station.
Worthington Town Council and Sharon Township Trustees agree to pay $400 for the use of the 1856 school for council meetings. The building, located at 67 E. Granville Rd., became known as Town Hall.
Chief Justice Salmon Portland Chase of the United States Supreme Court dies in office.
Construction of the new Union Depot begins.
Classes begin at the Ohio Agricultural and Mechanical College (later OSU), with 25 students.

In Japan the government instituted nationwide conscription in 1873, mandating that every male would serve for four years in the armed forces upon turning 21 years old, followed by three more years in the reserves.
The Cleveland, Mt. Vernon & Columbus Railroad completed between Cleveland and Columbus.
The Columbus & Springfield Railroad, under the ownership of the CCC&I, is completed from London to Columbus. This provided the CCC&I with a through route from Cincinnati to Columbus.
The Westerville Railroad is constructed, and serves several mills and the Everal Tile Company.
Eliza Trimble Thompson leads Hillsboro church women to march into saloons and kneel in prayer. The tactic spreads and invigorates the temperance movement.
Joseph Glidden invents a practical method for making barbed wire. The invention changes the West.
Silver de-monetized by limiting payment to $5.
Ohio legislature transfers the college property northeast of the public square to the Worthington Board of Education and the buildings are razed.
The Worthington School on Evening Street is completed.
Morrison R. Waite takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

The Eads bridge in St. Louis opens. It is the first bridge erected across the Mississippi south of the Missouri River. A combined railway and road bridge, it is the first large scale structure constructed of steel instead of wrought iron, and the 520 foot spans are the longest in the world.
Chautauqua movement brings educational speakers to rural communities across the country.
Disastrous recession in U.S. due to monetary contraction.
Women's Christian Temperance Union founded in Cleveland.

A new Worthington School is built on the site of former Worthington College to serve as model school for training teachers from Ohio Central Normal School. By 1879 it offers Worthington's first public high school as well as elementary classes.
The new Union Depot is opened for use.
A two lane steel tunnel under the High Street tracks near Union Depot is completed. It was too small and too steep, so many people declined to use it.
McKinley Hospital at 664 Park Street is built.
Monsignor John Joseph Jessing, German immigrant, founds a boysÕ orphanage in Pomeroy.
Columbus Union Depot handles 42 daily trains.
The Columbus & Toledo Railroad chartered.
Alexander Graham Bell utters his famous words "Come here, Watson, I want you." -  thus inventing the telephone.
Groveport's Town Hall completed.
Queen Victoria adds the title of "Empress of India".
Custer's last stand.
The Scioto Valley Railroad completed from Columbus to Chillicothe.
Colorado becomes a state.
Premium soda crackers (later Saltines) introduced.
Rutherford Birchard Hayes inaugurated as President.
Everett J Waring and Thomas G Spencer are the first African-American students to graduate from the Columbus High School.
The Columbus Lunatic Asylum is completed. It is the largest building in the world under one roof.
Monsignor John Joseph Jessing, German immigrant moves the boy's orphanage he founded from Pomeroy to Columbus.
PRR: All iron rails have been replaced by steel on the main line.
The Columbus & Toledo Railroad completed.
The Congress of Berlin begins. Otto Von Bismarck reorders Europe to keep the peace.
The Ohio Agricultural and Mechanical College changes its name to The Ohio State University. The first class of 6 students is graduated.
The Congress of Berlin ends.
St. Joseph's Cathedral consecrated
Bishop Sylvester Horton Rosecrans dies
Bland-Allison Act authorized purchase and minting of silver dollars, restored legal tender to silver dollars, with private contract escape clause.
First Franklin County Courthouse burns under mysterious circumstances.
PRR: The first attempt to beautify Horseshoe Curve includes flower beds and a watchman's shanty designed like a Swiss cottage.
Thomas Edison illuminates a carbon filament light bulb that glowed continuously for 40 hours.
John Ambrose Watterson appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.
Marshfield, Mo.: series of 24 tornadoes demolished city, killing 99 people.
General William T. Sherman delivers his famous "War, it is all Hell" speech to a reunion of Civil War Veterans in Franklin Park.
Brush Electric Company's central power plant dynamos powered arc lamps for public lighting in New York. Located at 133 West Twenty-Fifth Street, it powered a 2-mile (3.2 km) long circuit.
The population of Columbus reaches 51,647
Worthington graduates its first high school class, including 2 girls.
AEP: Electric lighting is installed in The Ohio State Journal office.
James Abram Garfield inaugurated as President.
The Scioto Valley Railroad completed to Coal Grove
A lawyer named Charles Guiteau who was incensed when his application to be the U. S. ambassador to France was denied, shoots President Garfield.
Chester Arthur inaugurated as President.
President Garfield dies.
Pablo Picasso is born in from Liguria, a coastal region of north-western Italy.

A 30 second shootout takes place in Tombstone, Arizona Territory. The gunfight was the result of a long-simmering feud, with Cowboys Billy Claiborne, Ike and Billy Clanton, and Tom and Frank McLaury on one side and town Marshal Virgil Earp, Special Policeman Morgan Earp, Special Policeman Wyatt Earp, and temporary policeman Doc Holliday on the other side.
Pillsbury flour introduced.
The Columbus Hocking Valley & Toledo Railroad formed from The Columbus & Toledo Railroad, The Ohio & West Virginia Railroad and The Columbus & hocking Valley Railroad.

Roderick Maclean, a disgruntled poet apparently offended by Victoria's refusal to accept one of his poems, shot at Queen Victoria as her carriage left Windsor railway station. Two schoolboys from Eton College struck him with their umbrellas, until he was hustled away by a policeman.

The first commercial power plant begins generating electricity in New York City, with a capacity of 0.6 MW. Built by Thomas Edison, the Pearl Street Station. The plant had six, 100 kW dynamos that operated at 110 VDC and could power 1200 lamps each. Each dynamo was driven by a 175 HP steam engine that revolved at 700 rpm.

Ohio River floods. In Cincinnati, 350 homeless people found shelter in a Third Street schoolhouse. On the Licking River in Northern Kentucky, 1,700 barrels of whiskey were afloat after coming dislodged from a boat.
The Brooklyn Bridge opens for traffic.
Bernard H. Kroger opens his first store, The Great Western Tea Company, at 66 East Pearl Street in Cincinnati, Ohio using $350 in borrowed funds.

The island volcano of Krakatau ("Krakatoa") in Indonesia, a virtually unknown volcanic island with a history of violent volcanic activity, exploded with devastating fury. The eruption is one of the most catastrophic natural disasters in recorded history. The effects were experienced on a global scale. Fine ashes from the eruption were carried by upper level winds as far away as New York City. The explosion was heard more than 3000 miles away. Volcanic dust blew into the upper atmosphere affecting incoming solar radiation and the earth's weather for several years. A series of large tsunami waves generated by the main explosion, some reaching a height of nearly 40 meters (more than 120 feet) above sea level, killed more than 36,000 people in the coastal towns and villages along the Sunda Strait on Java and Sumatra islands. Tsunami waves were recorded or observed throughout the Indian Ocean, the Pacific Ocean, the American West Coast, South America, and even as far away as the English Channel.
Franklin County infirmary opens.
Recession in U.S. due to bank contraction of money.

Ohio River floods. In what was the biggest flood of the century (71.1 ft), flooded-out Cincinnati East End residents took shelter in abandoned railroad cars. Mount Washington and Newtown were cut off from the rest of the city.
Miss., Ala., N.C., S.C., Tenn., Ky., Ind.: series of 60 tornadoes caused estimated 800 deaths.
P.T. Barnum leads a parade of elephants, including "Jumbo", across the Brooklyn Bridge.
First Franklin County Courthouse demolished.
Columbus and Cincinnati Midland Railroad dedicated with a trip from Columbus to Cincinnati.
First class of five students graduates from Protestant Hospital Nursing School.
James Poindexter becomes the first African American to serve on the Columbus School Board.
The B&O's Midland Division begins service from Union Depot.
Grover Cleveland inaugurated as President.
The Scioto Valley Railroad goes into receivership.
Second Franklin County Court House corner stone laid.

Andrew Carnegie's $10 million effort to build a rail line parallel to the PRR is halted by J. P. Morgan. This abandoned roadbed with nine partially completed tunnels became the Pennsylvania Turnpike 50 years later.
The State Legislature turns over the former State Fairgrounds to become Franklin Park
Franklin County jail opens.
During the 37th Ohio State Fair, The Ohio State Fair is dedicated at its current site between 11th and 17th avenues.
The American Federation of Labor is created on N. 4th St. Samuel Gompers is elected president.
Frank Julian Sprague invented the first practical DC motor, a non-sparking device that maintained relatively constant speed under variable loads.
Coca-Cola introduced.
The first railroad station built in Hilliard.
Work begins on the foundations of the Eiffel Tower in Paris.

Susanna M. Salter became the first woman mayor in the U.S. She was duly elected by the people of Argonia, KS. Ms. Salter won by a two-thirds majority but didn't even know she was in the running until she went into the voting booth. It seems that her name was submitted by the Women's Christian Temperance Union. Susanna M. Salter received $1 for her year as mayor.
Second Franklin County Courthouse built for the staggering sum of $450,000.
Ball-Mason jars introduced.
Frank Julian Sprague uses electric motors to invent the first electric trolley system in 1887–88 in Richmond, Virginia.
The Columbus & Eastern begins service from Union Depot.
New railroad track installed in 1887 peaks at 12,984 miles.
Dakota and Montana territories, Minn., Nebr., Kans., and Tex.: "Schoolchildren's Blizzard" resulted in 235 deaths, many of which were children on their way home from school.
Franklin County children's home opens.

The Blizzard of 1888 (March 11, 1888 - March 14, 1888) paralyzed the Northeastern United States. In this blizzard, 400 people were killed, 200 ships were sunk, and snowdrifts towered 15 to 50 feet high. Earlier that year, the Great Plains states were struck by the Schoolhouse Blizzard that left children trapped in schoolhouses and killed 235 people.  It was known as the "Great White Hurricane," and it paralyzed the East Coast from the Chesapeake Bay to Maine. Telegraph and telephone wires snapped, isolating New York City, Boston, Philadelphia, and Washington for several days. Two hundred ships were grounded in port, and at least one hundred sailors died. Fire stations were useless, and property loss from the subsequent fires alone were estimated at $25 million.  The days leading up to the storm were unusually mild, with temperatures in the 40s and 50s along the East Coast of the US. Heavy rains started, and on March 12, 1888, the rain changed to heavy snow, the temperature dropped quickly, and the very strong winds started. The storm spanned 36 hours. The National Weather Service estimated that fifty inches of snow fell in Connecticut and Massachusetts and forty inches covered New York and New Jersey. Winds blew up to 48 miles an hour, creating snowdrifts forty to fifty feet high. The resulting transportation emergency led to the creation of the New York subway, approved in 1894 and begun in 1900.
Chief Justice Morrison R. Waite of the United States Supreme Court died in office.
Kaiser Wilhelm II assumes power in Germany.
Melville Weston Fuller takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
Nikola Tesla demonstrates a two phase induction motor to the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.
Jeffrey Mining Products is founded.
Log Cabin syrup introduced.
Monsignor John Joseph Jessing, German immigrant, starts the Collegium Josephinum.

Columbus Streetcar #6 is built by the John Stephenson Co., LTD of New York. Initially horse drawn, it was converted to electric operation in the early 1890's. in 1896 it was sold to Lancaster, OH where it operated until 1937. Currently on display at the Ohio Historical Society in Columbus.
AEP: Electric lighting becomes available in Laredo, TX.
Benjamin Harrison inaugurated as President.
The Eiffel Tower is completed in Paris.

The first electric power transmission line in North America operated at 4000 V, between the generating station at Willamette Falls in Oregon City, Oregon, and Chapman Square in downtown Portland, Oregon for about 13 miles.
Cleveland Cincinnati Chicago & St. Louis Railway created by consolidating the CCC&I with the Indianapolis St. Louis and Chicago Railway. This new road was known as the "BIG FOUR".
The Scioto Valley Traction Company is incorporated.
North Dakota becomes a state.
South Dakota becomes a state.
Montana becomes a state.
Washington becomes a state.
The first interurban rail company in the United States begins operation between Newark and Granville.
McCormick Spices introduced.
Pabst Brewing Co. founded.
B&O Railroad takes control of the Columbus and Cincinnati Midland Railroad.
Louisville, Ky.: twister hit community and caused 76 deaths.
Idaho becomes a state.
Wyoming becomes a state.
The Scioto Valley Railroad acquired by the Norfolk & Western Railroad.
Columbus population 88,000

Dr. Samuel Brubaker Hartman abandons his medical practice to produce a patent medicine called Peruna which cures "catarrh". Peruna contained 28% alcohol and made Hartman a millionaire many times over.
The population of Columbus reaches 88,150
Knox gelatin introduced.
Libby introduces keys to canned meat.
Lipton tea introduced.
Football begins as an organized sport at Ohio State University

General William T. Sherman's funeral train, consisting of an engine and eight cars, all heavily draped and decorated, arrives in Columbus over the Pennsylvania lines at 2:30 pm, greeted by the solemn booming of cannon. A great civic and military parade marched to the station, forming part of a throng of 10,000 people assembled there.

The International Electrotechnical Exhibition opens in Frankfort Am Main, Germany. It features a 175 KM, 15KV transmission line carrying three phase, 300 hp, 40 Hz. power. It was the first long distance line to do so, and proved the economics of 3 phase AC power. The industrial use of electricity ushered in the Second Industrial Revolution.
The Ames Hydroelectric Generating Station becomes the first AC power plant. It transmitted 3000 Volts at 133 Hz over 2.6 miles to drive a 100 HP gold ore crushing mill.
Enrollment at Ohio State University exceeds 500 for the first time
St. Anthony's Hospital, 1450 Hawthorne, is dedicated.
Del Monte founded.
Fig Newton introduced.
Quaker Oats Co. founded.
Taylor Iron & Steel Company was incorporated in High Bridge. Formerly the Taylor Iron Works.
USA pig iron production peaks.
USA building construction peaks and then falls off irregularly thereafter, likely due to overbuilding.
Protestant Hospital opens at Third Avenue and Dennison. The forerunner of Riverside Methodist Hospital.
The Norfolk and Western's extension reaches Coal Grove. Its purchase of the Scioto Valley Railroad in 1890 assures it a corridor to Columbus.
Columbus Terminal and Transfer Railroad Company incorporated.
Collegium Josephinum becomes the only seminary outside of Italy to be titled "pontifical."
Receivers are appointed for the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, which had greatly overextended itself. This is the start of the Panic of 1893.
The Sandusky & Columbus Short Line begins service from Union Depot.
Grover Cleveland inaugurated as President.
US gold reserves fall below $100 million, sparking panic as people rush to convert gold certificates into gold.
The Columbia Exposition opens in New York City. It includes The White City, a demonstration of the potential application of electric lighting.

Jacob S. Coxey, an Ohio steel-mill owner, was forced in the financial panic to lay off forty of his quarry workers. In protested, he marched to Washington with supporters to demand that the government issue $500,000,000 in paper money to fund road projects. Upon arriving in Washington, President Cleveland had him arrested.
National Cordage Company collapses after it is unable to secure enough credit to continue operating. A $50,000 loan was rejected.
Columbus Terminal and Transfer Railroad Company is leased to the Columbus, Sandusky & Hocking Railroad Company for its connection with the depot at Columbus.
Hurricane: Savannah, Ga., Charleston, S.C., Sea Islands, S.C.: at least 1,000 died.
CCC&I signs an agreement with the T&OC permitting the T&OC to cross its tracks near the Asylum Pumping Station. This crossing was known as "Grandview Interlocking".
Edsel Ford is born.
Mt. Carmel Hospital's West State Street building is built.
The "Villa" is opened by Robert M. Turner along the Olentangy River north of Columbus. The amusement park will later become Olentangy Park.
Cream of Wheat introduced.
Good & Plenty candy introduced.
Juicy Fruit gum introduced.
OSU: Hayes Hall, 108 N. Oval Mall, opens. Built to house mechanical arts classes, it is now the oldest remaining building on Campus (as of 2003).
OSU: Orton Hall, 155 South Oval Mall, opens. Houses the University Library, Department of Geology and a Geology Museum.
Toledo & Ohio Central completed from Toledo to Columbus.
Union Depot handles 118 daily trains.
Sherman Silver Purchase Law repealed, U.S. fell into recession.
The old Worthington Academy Building is torn down.
Edward Douglas White is appointed Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
Chili powder introduced.

J.P. Morgan & Co. led a bond offering that helped rescue the United States from a severe two-year economic depression. Morgan led a syndicate of bankers to sell U.S. bonds to buy back gold from foreign investors. The firm offered the bonds for sale at $112.25 and sold out the entire issue in New York within 22 minutes.

Minerva Amusement Park was built and managed by officials of the Columbus Central Railway Company. The president of the line was John J. Shipherd of Cleveland; he named the park for his wife, Minerva.
The battleship USS Texas is commissioned
The Burlington & Mount Holly RR in New Jersey begins first electric operation on 7.15 miles of track. Operation switched to steam in 1901 when the power plant burned down.
The battleship USS Maine is commissioned
White Cross Hospital moves to 700 North Park Street.
The battleship USS Indiana (BB-01) is commissioned
Clinton School, a turreted brick edifice, opens in Clintonville, on the site of the current Clinton Elementary School.
Franklin Park Conservatory erected at Franklin Park. Building previously served in the 1893 Columbian Exposition.
Shredded coconut introduced.
Triscuits introduced.
Mirror Lake is enlarged to its present form at The Ohio State University

Mother Vincentia Erskine exercised the ancient Dominican privilege of requesting a pontifical designation for St. Mary of the Springs, rather than being under the direction of the local Bishop, and the congregation became a Pontifical Institute.
Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo constructs a gothic style station in Canal Winchester.
Construction begins on a new railroad station for Columbus
The Toledo & Ohio Central line is extended to Truro, which connects with CS&H trackage rights forming a route to Thurston.

WCF&N: The Waterloo & Cedar Falls Rapid Transit Company was formed to give local street car service in the Iowa city of Waterloo and town of Cedar Falls, with an 9 mile connecting interurban line. A horse car line in Waterloo and a gasoline line in Cedar Falls were built.
Utah becomes a state.
Utah admitted to the United States.
Madison Square Garden in New York City hosted the season premiere of the Barnum and Bailey Circus. The circus featured a Duryea horseless carriage.
The Summer Olympics open in Athens, Greece. The first international olympic games in modern history.
Toledo & Ohio Central opens its station at 379 West Broad Street.
A collision is staged at Buckeye Park between two trains on the Columbus Hocking Valley & Toledo Railroad.
At 6:30pm the F4-rated "St. Louis Tornado" killed 255 people and injured 1,000 in Missouri and Illinois.
The battleship USS Massachusetts (BB-02) is commissioned
The battleship USS Oregon (BB-03) is commissioned
Gold is discovered in the Klondike by local miners. This is the beginning of the Klondike gold rush.
The Columbus Street and Railroad Company bought "The Villa" and renamed it Olentangy Park. It quickly gained renown as one of the city's most beautiful spots
Cracker Jack introduced.
Tootsie Roll introduced.
AEP: Columbus residents approve a bond levy to build a municipal power plant.
William McKinley inaugurated as President.
William Haas is the first convict executed in the electric chair at the Ohio Penitentiary.
Passenger liner SS Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse launched. 14,349 GT, 22.5 knots.
Konstantin Tsiolkovsky derives the rocket equation in his home 200 miles south of Moscow. His imagination in applying the equation to the problems of spaceflight makes him a father of rocket science.
The battleship USS Iowa (BB-04) is commissioned

Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee procession followed a route six miles long through London and included troops from all over the empire. The procession paused for an open-air service of thanksgiving held outside St Paul's Cathedral, throughout which Victoria sat in her open carriage, to avoid her having to climb the steps to enter the building. The celebration was marked by vast crowds of spectators and great outpourings of affection for the 78-year-old Queen.
The first of thousands of people depart San Francisco for the Klondike Gold Rush.
Enrollment at Ohio State University exceeds 1,000 for the first time
Michigan wins the first Ohio State - Michigan football game, 36-0.
Campbell's condensed soup introduced.
Campbell's tomato soup introduced.
Grape Nuts introduced.
Jell-O introduced.
Columbus Union Station opens.
