The Columbus Hocking Valley & Toledo Railroad goes into receivership.
The American battleship USS Maine is sunk in Havana, Cuba.
Construction of the Battleship Ohio (BB12) is authorized by congress.
The Spanish-American war begins.

The Battle of San Juan Hill. The U.S. attacking forces sustained 205 killed and 1,180 wounded, the Spanish defenders 215 killed and 376 wounded. Lt. Col. Teddy Roosevelt and his rough riders, volunteers made up of western cowboys and elites, charged up the hill and were made famous.
Hostilites end as Spain sues for peace.
William R. Day and other members of the American delegation arrive in Paris for peace negotiations with Spain.
The first session of negotiations between Spain and the United States take place in Paris.
The Spanish-American war ends with the signing of the Treaty of Paris. The Philippines are delivered to the U.S. after a payment of $25 million to the Spanish Government.
New Protestant Hospital opens on Park Street adjacent to Ohio Medical University. The forerunner of Riverside Methodist Hospital.
The Hartman Hotel is built at the corner of Fourth Street and East Main Street.
Nabisco Graham Crackers introduced.
Shredded Wheat introduced.
PRR: Horseshoe Curve is expanded to three tracks.

Neon (10) British chemists Sir William Ramsay and Morris W. Travers discover neon when Ramsay chilled a sample of air until it became a liquid, then warmed the liquid and captured the gases as they boiled off.
HMS Oceanic launched. 17,272 tons, 704 feet, 1710 passengers

Revolts against American rule in the Phillipines explode in violence far exceeding that of the Spanish American War. Although the United States claimed it supported Phillipino independance, it took until after WW II for that to happen.
The Great Arctic Outbreak begins with temperatures of 33 in Los Angeles, 9 F in Portland, Oregon and -9 F in Boise, Idaho.
The Senate approves the Paris Treaty by a vote of 57 to 27. Many Senators are horrified at America's turn toward imperialism.
The lowest temperature ever recorded in Ohio, -39 F, at Milligan. Washington DC recorded a temperature of -8 F.
Fort Logan, Montana, recording an astonishing low of −61°F
The all time low temperature recorded in Florida, -2 F, in Tallahassee.
Ice is seen floating down the Mississippi past New Orleans.
The Columbus Citizen prints its first edition.
The keel of the Battleship Ohio (BB12) is laid.
The boom town of Dawson City in the Canadian Yukon burns to the ground at a loss of $1,000,000.

At 5:40 pm the "New Richmond Tornado" began as a waterspout on Lake St. Croix and moved as a cyclone toward New Richmond, Wisconsin. The F5-rated twister killed 117 people and injured 200. High winds blew a 3,000-pound safe a block away, according to FEMA.
HMS Oceanic maiden voyage.
The VFW was founded in a tailor shop at 286 E. Main Street in Columbus by 13 veterans of the Spanish-American War.
The Columbus Dispatch publishes its first Sunday edition.

The Dussenbury brothers purchase Olentangy Park, which featured a small merry-go-round. The Dussenburys were responsible for the construction of a theater, a dance pavilion and rides such as the loop-the-loop, whirlwind and shoot the chutes.
Wesson oil introduced.
PRR: Horseshoe Curve is expanded to four tracks.
The Columbus Hocking Valley & Toledo Railroad reformed as the Hocking Valley Railroad.
AEP: The Columbus Municipal Power Plant starts generating electricity.
The president of the Hocking Valley RR also became the president of the T&OC, completing the takeover of the T&OC by the Hocking Valley.
The battleship USS Kearsarge (BB-05) is commissioned
A coal mine explosion in West Virginia, U.S.A. kills 50 miners.
The Gold Standard Act is ratified, placing the United States currency on the gold standard.
The arrival of a Russian naval fleet in Korea causes concern to the Imperial Japanese government.
Henry Moeller appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.
The Summer Olympics open in Paris, France.
The battleship USS Kentucky (BB-06) is commissioned
Russia invades Manchuria.
The Boxers attack Belgians, in the Fengtai railway station.
Peacekeepers from various European countries arrive in China, where they join with Japanese forces.
Second Boer War: British soldiers take Pretoria.
Battle of Dagu Forts: Naval forces of the Eight-Nation Alliance capture the Taku Forts, on the Hai River estuary in China.
Boxers gather about 20,000 people near Peking, and kill hundreds of European citizens, including the German ambassador.

A wharf fire at the docks in Hoboken, New Jersey, owned by the North German Lloyd Steamship line, spreads to German passenger ships Saale, Main, and Bremen. The fire engulfs the adjacent piers and nearby ships, killing 326 people.

The Chinese bombarded the town of Blagoveshchensk on the Russian side of the Amur. The Czar's government used the pretext of Boxer activity to move some 200,000 troops into the area to crush the Boxers. The Chinese used arson to destroy a bridge carrying a railway and a barracks on 27 July. The Boxers destroyed railways and cut lines for telegraphs and burned the Yantai mines.
The first zeppelin flight is carried out over Lake Constance, near Friedrichshafen, Germany.

The Taiyuan massacre took place during the Boxer Rebellion in Taiyuan, Shanxi province, North China. Reports at the time alleged that Yuxian, governor of Shanxi, ordered the killings of 45 Christian missionaries and village Christians, including children.

Kaiser Wilhelm II delivers his "Hun Speech" in Bremerhaven on, addressing German troops who were departing to suppress the Boxer rebellion in China. The speech was infused with Wilhelm's fiery and chauvinistic rhetoric and clearly expressed his vision of German imperial power.
King Umberto I of Italy is assassinated by Italian-born anarchist Gaetano Bresci in Monza.
Reuben Campbell is born in Hawaii
An international contingent of troops, under British command, invades Peking and frees the European hostages.
Hurricane: Galveston, Tex., an estimated 6,000 - 8,000 died in hurricane and tidal surge. The Galveston Hurricane is considered the deadliest in U.S. history.
Battle of Pulang Lupa: Filipino resistance fighters defeat a detachment of American soldiers.
Battle of Mabitac: Filipinos under Juan Cailles defeat the Americans, under Colonel Benjamin F. Cheatham.
The battleship USS Alabama (BB-08) is commissioned
Max Planck discovers the law of black-body radiation (Planck's law).
William McKinley is re-elected president, defeating William Jennings Bryan in a rematch.
Michigan and Ohio State tie 0 to 0 at Michigan
The Scioto Valley Traction Company begins surveying at Chillicothe
A large standing stone at Stonehenge falls over, the most recent time this has happened.
The Scioto Valley Traction Company opened offices in the Board of Trade Building in Columbus.
James Fairchild Baldwin founds Grant Hospital at 125 Grant Avenue South.
The population of Columbus reaches 125,560.
The Toledo & Ohio Central acquires the unfinished road of the Columbus Northwestern Railway, which it completed giving it an extension to St. Marys.
Karl Landsteiner develops a system of blood grouping.
Pentecostalism is born, at a prayer meeting at Bethel Bible College in Topeka, Kansas.
The Scioto Valley Traction Company begins surveying at Chillicothe to Circleville west of the Scioto River.
In the first great Texas gusher, oil is discovered at Spindletop in Beaumont, Texas.
Baseball's American League declares itself a Major League.
Queen Victoria's funeral is the largest gathering of European Royalty in history.
The battleship USS Wisconsin (BB-09) is commissioned
J. P. Morgan buys mines and steel mills in the United States, marking the first billion dollar business deal.
Edward VII opens his first parliament of the United Kingdom.
The Pacific Mail Steamship Company's SS City of Rio de Janeiro sinks entering San Francisco Bay, killing 128.

US Steel is formed by combining Andrew Carnegie's Carnegie Steel Company with Gary's Federal Steel Company and William Henry "Judge" Moore's National Steel Company. When it goes public, it becomes the first corporation to have a market capitalization exceeding $1 billion dollars.
William McKinley is sworn in, for a second term as President of the United States.
Earl J. Fisher born.
The Scioto Valley Traction Company begins grading.
Passenger liner SS Kronprinz Wilhelm launched. 14,908 GT, 23 knows.
The Scioto Valley Traction Company begins surveys out of Columbus.
RMS Celtic launched in Belfast. 20904 tons, 14000 hp, 701 ft, 2857 passengers  with 2300 in steerage.
Cleveland's American League franchise, the "Blues," plays its first game.
New York becomes the first U.S. state to require automobile license plates.
The Great Fire of 1901 begins in Jacksonville, Florida.
Panic of 1901: The New York Stock Exchange crashes.
Cuba becomes a United States protectorate.
RMS Lucania is the first Cunard Line ship to receive a wireless radio set.

Emily Hobhouse reports on the genocide in the 45 British concentration camps for Boer women and children in South Africa in which, over an 18-month period, 26,370 people will die, 24,000 of them children under 16.
The first United Kingdom Fingerprint Bureau is established at Scotland Yard, the Metropolitan Police headquarters in London, by Edward Henry.
William Howard Taft becomes Governor-General of the Philippines.
O. Henry is released from prison in Columbus, Ohio, after serving three years for embezzlement from the First National Bank in Austin, Texas.
RMS Celtic maiden voyage.Liverpool to New York.
Discovery Expedition: Robert Falcon Scott sets sail on the RRS Discovery, to explore the Ross Sea in Antarctica.
The first claimed powered flight is made, by German-born American aviator Gustave Whitehead, in his Number 21, in Connecticut.
U.S. Vice President Theodore Roosevelt utters the famous phrase, "Speak softly and carry a big stick", at the Minnesota State Fair.
William McKinley assassination: American anarchist Leon Czolgosz shoots U.S. President William McKinley at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York. McKinley dies 8 days later.

In China, the Qing imperial court agrees to sign the "Boxer Protocol" also known as Peace Agreement between the Eight-Nation Alliance and China. The protocol ordered the execution of 10 high-ranking officials linked to the outbreak and other officials who were found guilty for the slaughter of foreigners in China
Theodore Roosevelt inaugurated as President.
The battleship USS Illinois (BB-07) is commissioned
Elias and Eliza Swick sold approximately 35 acres of the Swick Hotel property at Buckeye Lake to the Columbus, Buckeye Lake and Newark Traction Company for $3,500.
Balangiga massacre: Filipino guerrillas kill more than forty United States soldiers in a surprise attack, in the town of Balangiga in Samar.
U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt invites African American leader Booker T. Washington to the White House. The American South reacts angrily to the visit, and racial violence increases in the region.
Michigan schoolteacher Annie Edson Taylor goes over Niagara Falls in a barrel, and survives.
Michigan beats Ohio State 21 to 0 at Ohio State
Auguste Deter is first examined by German psychiatrist Dr. Alois Alzheimer, leading to a diagnosis of the condition that will carry Alzheimer's name.
U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt delivers a 20,000-word speech to the House of Representatives, asking Congress to curb the power of trusts "within reasonable limits".
Walt Disney is born in Chicago.
The first Nobel Prize ceremony is held in Stockholm, on the fifth anniversary of Alfred Nobel's death.
Guglielmo Marconi receives the first trans-Atlantic radio signal, sent from Poldhu, England, to Newfoundland; it is the letter "S" in Morse code.
The Underwood Model No. 5 typewriter is introduced. It is the most popular typewriter ever made, selling over 3.8 million units through 1939.
The 16 E. Broad St. building opens. 13 stories. Designed by Frank L. Packard.

WCF&N: An interurban line from Waterloo, Iowa to Denver, Iowa, 14 miles, was built. The first high tension transmission line in Iowa, a 22,000 volt line, fed power from the generators in Waterloo to  Glasgow, half way between Waterloo and Denver.
The first college football bowl game, the Rose Bowl between Michigan and Stanford, is held in Pasadena, California.
A train collision in the New York Central Railroad's Park Avenue Tunnel kills 17, injures 38, and leads to increased demand for electric trains, and the banning of Steam locomotives in New York City.
The Carnegie Institution is founded in Washington, D.C., with a $10 million gift from Andrew Carnegie.
The Berlin U-Bahn underground is opened.
U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt prosecutes the Northern Securities Company, for violation of the Sherman Act.
South African Boers win their last battle over the British Army, with the capture of a British general and 200 of his men.
A Circuit Court prevents Thomas Edison from having a monopoly on motion picture technology.

The first motion picture theatre opened in Los Angeles. The Electric Theatre charged a dime to see an hour's entertainment, including the films, "The Capture of the Biddle Brothers" and "New York in a Blizzard".
Tenor Enrico Caruso makes the first million-selling recording, for the Gramophone Company in Milan.
The Preußen, the only five masted full sail ship built, is launched. 11,150 tons, 482 feet
In Saint Vincent, La Soufrière erupts, devastating the northern portion of the island, killing 2,000 people.
In Martinique, Mount Pelée erupts, destroying the town of Saint-Pierre and killing over 30,000.
John Eisenmann's design for the official Ohio flag adopted
Goliad, Tex.: tornado killed 114.
Cuba gains independence from the United States.
The White Star Liner, SS Ionic, is launched.
The Treaty of Vereeniging ends the Second Boer War.
PRR: The posh Pennsylvania Special began running between New York and Chicago with a 20 hour schedule, in competition with the New York Central's Twentieth Century Limited.
Target Corporation, the department store chain, is founded.
The Fillipino Organic Act ends the Phillippino American war by ceding local control to Fillipinos.
The Rolling Mill Mine disaster in Johnstown, Pennsylvania kills 112 miners.

Minerva Amusement Park closes after competition from the new Olentangy Amusement Park causes attendance to plunge. With the closing of the park, as many as 20 streetcars were deposited in what has come to be called the "Streetcar Graveyard;" it was situated north of present-day Minerva Lake Road and just west of the small lake.
Felix Pedro discovers gold in what is now modern day Fairbanks, Alaska.
The Preußen, the only five masted full sail ship built, makes its maiden voyage to Iquique, Chile in 64 days
Passenger liner SS Kaiser Wilhelm II is launched. 19,361 GT, 23.5 knots.
RMS Cedric launched in Belfast. 21073 tons, 14000 hp, 700 ft, 2887 passengers with 2300 in steerage.
Cadillac is founded from the remnants of the Henry Ford Company. It was named after Antoine de la Mothe Cadillac, who founded Detroit, Michigan.
In Martinique, Mount Pelée erupts again, destroying the town of Morne-Rouge, and causing 1,000 deaths.

The first science fiction film, the silent A Trip to the Moon (Le Voyage dans La Lune), is premièred at the Théâtre Robert-Houdin in Paris, France, by actor/producer Georges Méliès, and proves an immediate success.
A stampede at the Shiloh Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama, after a talk by Booker T. Washington, kills 115.
Cadillac's first model is built, a 10 hp machine almost identical to Henry Ford's 1903 Model A.
In the United States, a five-month strike by the United Mine Workers ends.
Michigan beats Ohio State 86 to 0 at Michigan
The second-in-command of Butch Cassidy's Wild Bunch gang, Kid Curry Logan, is sentenced to 20 years hard labor.
The first Aswan Dam on the Nile is completed.
Torgovo-Telegrafnue Agenstvo, as predecessor for Russian News Agency TASS, is officially founded in Sankt Petersburg, Russia.
The battleship USS Maine (BB-10) is commissioned
Scott, Shackleton and Wilson reach the furthest southern point reached thus far by man, south of 82°S.
Buckeye Steel Castings located on Parsons Avenue.
With 40 stores and $1.75 million in annual sales, The Kroger Grocery and Baking Company is incorporated.
OSU: Page Hall, 1810 College Road, opens as the Law School.
Cleveland's American League franchise, renamed the "Broncos" from the "Blues".
Scioto Valley Traction Company, part of the Everett & Moore Syndicate, falls into financial trouble.
Groundbreaking for Columbus Pottery factory adjoining rail tracks east of Chaseland subdivision, formerly Bishop Chase's farm (east of High St, south of St. Michael's Church)."
The Oxnard strike of 1903 becomes the first time in U.S. history, that a labor union is formed from members of different races.
RMS Cedric maiden voyage.Liverpool to New York.
Cuba leases Guantánamo Bay to the United States "in perpetuity".
In New York City, the Martha Washington Hotel, the first hotel exclusively for women, opens.
The Hay–Herrán Treaty, granting the United States the right to build the Panama Canal, is ratified by the United States Senate. The Colombian Senate later rejects the treaty.

The Bounds family sold 65 acres of land to the Columbus, Buckeye Lake and Newark Traction Company for $10,000. The land was purchased with the intent of building an amusement park that became Buckeye Lake Park.
Scioto Valley Traction Company lays its first track at South Parsons Avenue and Smokey Row Road.
PRR: After failing to agree on a contract renewal, and with a federal judge's order, the PRR begins chopping down all of Western Union's telegraph poles on its property.
The Paris–Madrid race for automobiles begins, during which at least 8 people are killed; the French government stops the event at Bordeaux, and impounds all the competitors' cars.
Gainesville, Holland, Ga.: twister caused 98 deaths.
Scioto Valley Traction Company begins laying track on the Lancaster division at Rager.
Serbian King Alexander Obrenović and Queen Draga are assassinated in Belgrade, by the Black Hand (Crna Ruka) organization.
The town of Heppner, Oregon is nearly destroyed by a cloud burst, that results in a flash flood, that kills an estimated 238 people.
Scioto Valley Traction Company begins laying track on the Chillicothe division.
The explosion of a United States Cartridge Company magazine destroys 70 homes, killing 22 residents of Tewksbury, Massachusetts.
The first stock car event is held at the Milwaukee Mile.
The Wreck of the Old 97 Fast Mail train at Stillhouse Trestle, near Danville, Virginia, kills 11 people and inspires a ballad.
First modern World Series: The Boston Red Sox defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, in 8 games.
With the encouragement of the United States, Panama proclaims itself independent of Colombia.
Michigan beats Ohio State 36 to 0 at Michigan
The United States recognizes the independence of Panama.
RMS Baltic launched in Belfast. 23876 tons, 13000 hp, 729 ft, 3000 passengers with 2300 in steerage.
The battleship USS Missouri (BB-11) is commissioned
James Joseph Hartley appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.
Orville and Wilbur Wright make their first powered flight, remaining in the air for almost a minute and traveling 852 feet.
Scioto Valley Traction Company has its first wreck. During a heavy morning fog a work train ran into a standing engine at Prentiss. Several laborers in a box car received broken ribs.
The Iroquois Theatre fire is the deadliest theater fire and the deadliest single-building fire in United States history, resulting in at least 602 deaths.
Harry C. Moores and Stanley M. Ross found the Moores and Ross Milk Company in Columbus, Ohio.
OSU: Brown Hall, 190 W. 17th Ave., opens.
Water sales income from selling canal water to businesses and industries exceeded the income from freight carried on the Erie Canal.
Cleveland's American League franchise, renamed the "Naps" from the "Broncos," in honor of its first star, Napoleon Lajoie.
Scioto Valley Traction Company constructs a power house at Reese just south of Obetz Junction.

WCF&N: The interurban line from Waterloo, Iowa to Denver, Iowa, was extended to Denver Junction where connection was made to the Chicago Great Western Railway. Steam service was inaugurated between Waterloo and Sumner Iowa over the Great Western (leased) thru Waverly to Sumner.

The Chaseland subdivision located just south of Worthington on Chase, Lincoln and Stanton Avenues advertises as a "fine suburban addition location on the picturesque Columbus, Delaware, and Marion interurban line" with lots ranging from $100 to $300." Three houses are built near Lincoln Ave. & Indianola in 1904 (641, 633 & 627 E. Lincoln Ave.) probably for Columbus Pottery workers. Lots in the development sell slowly and few houses are built until the early 1950's.
Picasso paints The Old Guitarist, from his blue period.
A surprise Japanese naval attack on Port Arthur (Lüshun) in Manchuria starts the Russo-Japanese War.
For $10 million, the United States gains control of the Panama Canal Zone.
Russian troops in Korea retreat toward Manchuria, followed by 100,000 Japanese troops.
United States Army engineers begin work on the Panama Canal.
Russian minelayer Amur lays a minefield about 15 miles (24 km) off Port Arthur, and sinks Japan's battleships Hatsuse, 15,000 tons, with 496 crew and Yashima.
PRR: To relieve congestion on the Horseshoe Curve, track is relaid on the portion of the New Portage line between Duncansville and Gallitzin.
A fire aboard the steamboat General Slocum in New York City's East River kills 1,021
RMS Baltic maiden voyage.Liverpool to New York.
Scioto Valley Traction Company tests a car on the downtown interurban loop.
The Summer Olympics open in St. Louis, Missouri.
Scioto Valley Traction Company operates the first car on the Lancaster Division.
Scioto Valley Traction Company begins interurban service between South Parsons Avenue and Canal Winchester.
Scioto Valley Traction Company extends interurban service between South Parsons Avenue and Canal Winchester all the way to Lancaster.
Scioto Valley Traction Company establishes hourly interurban service between South Parsons Avenue and Lancaster.
Scioto Valley Traction Company begins service on the Chillicothe Division between South Parsons Avenue and Circleville.
A Japanese infantry charge fails to take Port Arthur.
Scioto Valley Traction Company extends interurban service to Main Street in Lancaster.
Anne Ryan (later Fisher) is born in Urbana, OH
Scioto Valley Traction Company has its first collision of electric cars, when a passenger car collides with a work train at Buckeye Park. Several passengers are injured and both cars burn.
The battleship USS Virginia (BB-13) is commissioned
The Battleship Ohio (BB12), a 12,500-ton Maine class battleship, is commissioned at San Francisco, California.
Michigan beats Ohio State 31 to 6 at Ohio State
The Russian Baltic Fleet fires on British trawlers it mistakes for Japanese torpedo boats, in the North Sea.
The first underground line of the New York City Subway opens.
Scioto Valley Traction Company begins grading between Circleville and Chillicothe on the Chillicothe Division.
Scioto Valley Traction Company extends interurban service to downtown Columbus, to the interurban station at 36 West Gay Street.

Sir John Ambrose Fleming files a patent for a two-electrode radio rectifier, which he called the thermionic valve; it is also known as the vacuum diode, kenotron, thermionic tube, and Fleming valve. This device is modified in 1907 by Deforest Kelly with the addition of a grid, and makes the radio revolution possible.
The first successful caterpillar track is made
Governor Myron T. Herrick took a special SVTC car from Columbus to Lancaster and back to visit the Boy's Industrial School.
In New York City, the first New Year's Eve celebration is held in Times Square.

Indianola Park constructed near Indianola and North 4th Streets. Contains the largest pool in Ohio, 140 by 238 feet holding 1,800,000 gallons of water, on site of current Indianola Plaza Shopping Center.
Kroger buys 14 Nagel meat markets and a packing house. Meat and groceries are sold under one roof for the first time.

Columbus begins the construction of a dam on the Scioto River just north of Columbus to provide for an adequate water supply. Julian Griggs, the City's chief engineer used a plan developed by Samuel Gray, an engineer from Providence, Rhode Island. The City hired John Gregory, a consulting engineer from New York, to coordinate the building of the dam.
With a grant from Andrew Carnegie, Columbus Main Library is built. It is constructed from Vermont marble and granite in a classic Roman style.
"Carmen Ohio" first sung in public by the Ohio State Glee Club
Columbus Pottery goes bankrupt before construction of the factory is complete.
The Russian Army surrenders at Port Arthur, in Qing Dynasty China.
The Bloody Sunday massacre of peaceful Russian demonstrators, led by Russian Orthodox priest Father Gapon, at the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg, helps trigger the abortive Revolution of 1905.
The Imperial Russian Army opens fire on demonstrators in Riga, Governorate of Livonia, killing 73 and injuring 200 people.
The Battle of Mukden begins in Manchuria.
Tsar Nicholas II of Russia agrees to create an elected assembly (the Duma).
Russian troops begin to retreat from Mukden, after losing 100,000 troops in 3 days.
The Japanese capture of Mukden (now Shenyang) completes the rout of Russian armies in Manchuria.
Mata Hari introduces her exotic dance act in Paris.
Albert Einstein publishes his paper "On a heuristic viewpoint concerning the production and transformation of light", in which he explains the photoelectric effect, using the notion of light quanta.
Scioto Valley Traction Company dissociated from the Everett & Moore Syndicate.
Snyder, Okla.: tornado killed 97.
Albert Einstein submits his doctoral dissertation "On the Motion of Small Particles...", in which he explains Brownian motion.
Las Vegas is founded when 110 acres (0.45 km2), in what later becomes downtown, are auctioned off.
Engine boiler explodes in the Hocking Yard, killing 6 men.
Battle of Tsushima: The Japanese fleet under Admiral Heihachiro Togo destroys the Russian fleet under Admiral Zinovi Petrovich Rozhdestvenski, in a 2-day battle.

The first Columbus Zoo holds its Grand Opening. The zoo occupied 215 acres in Beechwold, and included not only animals, but rides, picnic grounds, merry-go-rounds, billiard halls and a dance pavilion.
OSU: Mendenhall Laboratory, 125 South Oval Mall, opens as "The Physics Building".
Scioto Valley Traction Company completes a bridge across the Scioto River at Chillicothe.
Scioto Valley Traction Company begins regular hourly service on the Circleville-Kingston section.
Scioto Valley Traction Company extends service to Riverside Street in in Chillicothe.

The first Columbus Zoo closes, just four short months after its grand opening. All that remains of the zoo is the Monkey House (now a private residence), Rustic Bridge Road (the kissing bridge) and Elk Drive.
Michigan beats Ohio State 40 to 0 at Michigan
Scioto Valley Traction Company puts its Circleville station, a remodeled store, into service.
Scioto Valley Traction Company establishes regular freight service.
Scioto Valley Traction Company puts its Columbus station, the former Rich Street School Building, into service.
Albert Einstein's "annus mirabilis" papers are published - photoelectric effect, brownian motion, special relativity, mass-energy equivalence.
Olentangy Park adds a Japanese Village, constructed by 40 Japanese workers and brought over from Japan.
The Atlas Building at 8 E. Long St. opens. 12 stories. Designed by Frank L. Packard.
Picasso paints Au Lapin Agile, from his rose period.

Ecuador - An earthquake with a magnitude of 8.8 struck near the coast of Ecuador and Colombia, generating a strong tsunami that killed up to 1,000. It was felt all along the coast of Central America and as far north as San Francisco and west to Japan.
The battleship USS Rhode Island (BB-17) is commissioned
The battleship USS Louisiana (BB-19) is commissioned
The RMS Lusitania is launched. 31,550 tons, 787 feet, 2198 passengers
RMS Adriatic launched in Belfast. 24581 tons, 13000 hp, 729 ft, 3000 passengers with 2300 in steerage.
The RMS Mauretania is launched. 31,938 tons, 790 feet, 2165 passengers
The battleship USS Georgia (BB-15) is commissioned
The battleship USS New Jersey (BB-16) is commissioned
The battleship USS Connecticut (BB-18) is commissioned
Michigan beats Ohio State 6 to 0 at Ohio State
General Curtis E. LeMay born in a cottage with a steep roof near the corner of Acheson and 20th St.
Passenger liner SS Kronprinzessin Cecilie  is launched. 19,400 gt, 24 knots.

AEP: American Gas and Electric, the precursor to American Electric Power is formed in New York City by Richard Breed, a principal stockholder of the American Electric Company, his brother-in-law Harrison Williams and  Sidney Z. Mitchell, a protoge of Thomas Edison with experience in the utility industry.
The 8 E. Broad St. building opens. 17 stories.

OSU: Derby Hall, 154 North Oval Drive, opens. Occupied initially by the Chemistry Department. The two previous Chemistry Buildings were destroyed by fire. Derby Hall was damaged by fire six months after it opened.
OSU: Lord Hall, 124 W. 17th Ave., opens. It is used by the Schools of Mines and Ceramics.
Scioto Valley Traction Company builds a station in Lancaster.

AEP: American Gas and Electric, less than two weeks old, took over from ECA the assets of 20 utilities and assorted companies owned by those utilities, mostly in small communities spread from New Jersey and Wheeling, West Virginia, westward to Marion and Muncie, Indiana.

Ohio River floods. The levee broke in Lawrenceburg, Ind., and the onslaught of water began. It took 750 workers to repair the breach. Aberdeen, Ohio, in Brown County, was cut off. Maysville, Ky., was reeling.
The battleship USS Vermont (BB-20) is commissioned
The battleship USS Kansas (BB-21) is commissioned
AEP: Muncie and Marion Indiana were selected to be joined by a remarkable 25 miles of electric lines, a new distance record.
RMS Adriatic maiden voyage.Liverpool to New York.
The battleship USS Nebraska (BB-14) is commissioned
The RMS Lusitania maiden voyage

The National Bank of Commerce refused to honor checks of Knickerbocker Trust, causing a run on the Knickerbocker Trust. By the end of the next day, the National Bank of North America had failed and runs were sparked on nearly every trust in New York. The resulting downturn in business and tightness of money supply was severe.
Michigan beats Ohio State 22 to 0 at Michigan
Oklahoma becomes a state.
The RMS Mauretania maiden voyage
The "Great White Fleet" sets sail on a round-the-world journey to display American naval power. The Battleship Ohio is among them.
An electrically lighted ball descends in Times Square for the first time.
Franklin County Veterans Memorial Hall built - later houses COSI.
Mercy Hospital, 1400 South High Street, opens.
The Alcorn Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat Hospital opens. First of its kind in Columbus.
The Columbus Panhandles play their first football game. Most of the players are railroad workers, and the Nesser brothers who work as boilermakers make up 5 of the team's players.
Picasso paints Les Demoiselles d'Avignon.
AEP: American Gas & Electric produced 53,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
USS Idaho BB-24 is commissioned.

Confidence in the U.S. Economy is restored after the stock market crash of October 21, 1907. J.P. Morgan organized banks, secured overseas lines of credit and bought shares in companies at depressed prices.

The Collinwood, Ohio school fire (also known as the Lakeview School fire) erupted, killing 172 students, two teachers and one rescuer in one of the deadliest school disasters in United States history.
Benjamin Franklin Tuberculosis Hospital opens.
USS New Hampshire BB-25 is commissioned.
USS Mississippi BB-23 is commissioned.
At 11:45 am the F4-rated "Amite/Pine/Purvis Tornado" killed 143 people and injured 770. The tornado left only seven houses intact in Purvis, Mississippi, and also caused damage in Louisiana.
The Summer Olympics open in London, England.

At 7:40 a.m. local time, a massive explosion (Tunguska event) occurrs near the Podkamennaya (Under Rock) Tunguska River in what is now Krasnoyarsk Krai of Russia. The explosion was most likely caused by the air burst of a large meteoroid or comet fragment at an altitude of 5 to 10 kilometers (3Ð6 mi) above Earth's surface. Different studies yielded varying estimates for the meteor's size, from 50 up to 1200 meters in diameter.
General Motors is founded by William T. Durant.
Henry Ford builds the first Model T.
Scioto Valley Traction Company extends service to Main Street in in Chillicothe.
Michigan beats Ohio State 10 to 6 at Ohio State
The Chicago, Burlington & Quincy gains control of the Colorado & Southern.

Cadillac is the first American car to win the Royal Automobile Club of the United Kingdom's Dewar Trophy by successfully demonstrating the interchangeability of its component parts during a reliability test.
Burglar Walter Edward White climbs over the Ohio Penitentiary wall using bedsheets. His is the last successful escape over the wall from the Pen.
Griggs Dam on the Scioto river completed.
Alonzo J. Bowling becomes the first African American to receive a MA from The Ohio State University
OSU: Ives Hall, 2073 Neil Ave., opens.
OSU: Oxley Hall, 1712 Neil Ave., opens as a women's dormitory.
Scioto Valley Traction Company replaces its store front station with a new station.
The "Great White Fleet" returns from its round-the-world journey to display American naval power.
William Howard Taft inaugurated as President.
Fleetwood Metal Body is founded in Fleetwood, PA to supply car bodies to Cadillac.
The cornerstone for the old student union at Ohio State was laid (now Enarson Hall). This was the first student union at a state university and the fourth in the nation.
Hurricane: La. and Miss.: 350 deaths.
James A. Rhodes born in rural Jackson County.
Michigan beats Ohio State 33 to 6 at Michigan
General Motors purchases Cadillac.
Downtown Columbus Lazarus opens with 933,000 square feet of floor space.

Lazarus moves across the street to a six story, 115,000 square foot store, its current site. The store adds women's clothing and a limited assortment for children. Store includes a moving escalator and chirping canaries.
Olentangy Park adds the Red Devil Rollercoaster and the Whirlwind.
The first Junior High School in the nation opens, Indianola Junior High School. Meant to bridge the gap between elementary and high school.
The Anti-Saloon League moves its headquarters to Westerville.
AEP: Number of Americans with electricity in their homes: 8%
USS South Carolina BB-26 commissioned.
Streetcar strike begins in Columbus.
Columbus is the first city in the United States to collect garbage door to door.
Charles Evans Hughes is appointed Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
A B&O train rolls off the embankment after failing to stop at a red signal at the BO crossing. No fatalities.
Chief Justice Melville Weston Fuller of the United States Supreme Court died in office.

A strict anti-gambling law becomes effective in Nevada. It even forbid the western custom of flipping a coin for the price of a drink. Nevada was the last state to ban gambling, so Americans would have to live without legalized gambling until 1931, when Nevada legalized gambling again.
Streetcar strike ends in Columbus.
Michigan and Ohio State tie 3 to 3 at Ohio State
The Preußen, the only five masted full sail ship built, is wrecked after being struck by the cross channel steamer Brighten 8km south of Newhaven.
Toledo & Ohio Central station at 379 West Broad Street suffers a devastating fire. The roof collapses and all records are destroyed.
Edward Douglas White is elevated from Associate Justice to Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
WCF&N: Electric operation was extended over a newly built track to Waverly and the operation over the Great Western tracks was discontinued.
Columbus builds the city's first garbage reduction and recycling plant in the United States.
First Columbus Boy Scouts camp founded by J. J. Staley
The population of Columbus reaches 181,511
The Chesapeake & Ohio acquires control of the Hocking Valley RR.
World's first air cargo freight shipment arrived at Columbus' Driving Park.
Annetta Johnson St. Gaudens gives 12 acres of her family farm southeast of the Flint Ravine to the Godman Guild to serve as a permanent camp.
The battleship USS Texas is sunk in Chesapeake Bay as a target ship.
IBM is founded in New York City as the Computing, Tabulating, Recording Company.
Beginning of the Wuchang Uprising in China by the military, where dynastic rule is replaced with a Republic.
The battleship USS Texas is decommissioned
Michigan beats Ohio State 19 to 0 at Michigan
Norwegian Roald Amundsen finally reached the Pole following a dramatic race with the Englishman Robert Falcon Scott.
Proctor and Gamble introduced Crisco to the world as "A scientific discovery which will affect every kitchen in America"
Columbus voters pass the first bond issue for city parks and recreation.
The Hartman Building is constructed, 73-87 E. State St. nine stories.
The St. Clair Hospital opens on St. Clair Avenue.
OSU: Enarson Hall, 154 W. 12th Ave., opens. Serves as the first Ohio Union.
Elevation of tracks completed at the Toledo & Ohio Central station at 379 West Broad Street.
The covered bridge that carries Wilson Bridge Road across the Olentangy washes out.
New Mexico admitted to the United States.
The hulk of the USS Maine is refloated in Havana Harbor, Cuba.
Arizona admitted to the United States.
The provisional government of the Republic of China was formed in Nanjing , ending 2000 years of dynastic rule.
The hulk of the USS Maine is sunk with honors in the Gulf of Mexico.
The RMS Titanic sinks after colliding with an iceberg during her maiden voyage from Southampton, UK, to New York City.
Operators on Paint Creek and Cabin Creek (West Virginia) hired the notorious Baldwin–Felts Detective Agency to break the coal miner's strike.
The S.S. Imperator is launched. German. 52,117 tons, 906 feet, 4234 passengers
Standard Oil opens the first filling station in Ohio in the shadow of the Ohio State House at Oak and Young Streets.

Volcano, Katmai, Alaska: A massive eruption ejects 12 km3 of material. Residents of Kodiak, 100 miles from Katmai, were among the first Alaskans to observe the eruption phenomenon. A heavy fall of volcanic ash blanketed the town and created considerable apprehension. Initially, no one knew what caused the ash to fall. It was June 6, yet by 6:30 p.m., the town was obscured in total darkness. At the time of the eruption, lightning struck the Kodiak radio station. The station burned down and all communications with the outside world were severed.
Worthington Council passes resolution to install a public water works and water becomes available throughout the village next year.
Scioto Valley Traction Company opens its new Chillicothe station.
The Summer Olympics open in Stockholm, Sweden.
Miners attacked Mucklow, present-day Gallagher, leaving at least twelve strikers and four guards dead.
Columbus celebrates its 100th anniversary in combination with the Ohio State Fair that week. President William H. Taft gives a speech at the fair.
People gathered at the Ohio Statehouse to celebrate the centennial of the city of Columbus.

Approximately 6,000 unionized miners from across the Kanawha River crossed the river and declared their intent to kill the mine guards and destroy the company operations. Prior to the strike there were 96 coal mines in operation on Paint Creek and Cabin Creek, employing 7500 miners.

The Governor of West Virginia deploys 1,200 state troops in the WV coal strike. Confiscating arms and ammunition from both sides lessened tensions to some degree, but the strikers were forbidden to congregate, and were subject to fast, unfair trials in military court.
Michigan beats Ohio State 14 to 0 at Ohio State
WCF&N: Service extended to LaPorte City, Iowa.
Lazarus passes the $1 million mark in annual sales.
The Hartman Building is increased from 9 to 10 stories, 73-87 E. State St.
Women's suffrage march draws 5,000 protestors to Columbus.
OSU: Ives Hall, 2073 Neil Ave., addition of a horse barn.
OSU: William Thompson Oxley Memorial Library, 1858 Neil Ave., opens.

A new interurban station is opened in Columbus by the Ohio Electric Railway Company at the northwest corner of Rich and 3rd Streets. All interurbans except the SVTC used this terminal. The SVTC continued to use its station across the street on the NE corner.
PRR: The Pennsylvania Limited (formerly the Pennsylvania Special) between New York and Chicago begins operating on a 18 hour schedule.
The Methodist Children's Home Association selects Worthington for its new orphanage and purchases 141 acres north of the village.
The Taylor-Wharton Iron & Steel Company was incorporated as successor to the Taylor Iron & Steel Company.
Ohio River floods. The Ohio River spread out 8 miles wide in the lowlands. Hundreds of families fled in the Mill Creek valley. A call went out for help to relieve ''great want and suffering.''

West Virginia coal miners strike. Mother Jones was arrested in Pratt and charged in military court for inciting riot (reportedly for attempting to read the Declaration of Independence), and, later, conspiracy to commit murder. She refused to recognize the jurisdiction of the military court, and refused to enter a plea. Jones was sentenced to twenty years in the state penitentiary and acquired a case of pneumonia.
Woodrow "Woody" Hayes born in Clifton, Ohio.

The Armory Show opens in New York City. Known as the International Exhibition of Modern Art. The show became an important event in the history of American art, introducing astonished Americans, who were accustomed to realistic art, to the experimental styles of the European avant garde, including Fauvism, Cubism, and Futurism. The show served as a catalyst for American artists, who became more independent and created their own "artistic language."
Woodrow Wilson inaugurated as President.

Easter Sunday: Two moisture-laden low pressure systems began moving up the Ohio River Valley, and rain began falling in substantial quantities which lasted through March 27th. Totals of between 7 and 8 inches were common throughout the Buckeye State. Among the greatest rainfall amounts officially reported were: 11.16 inches at Bellefontaine (Logan County); 10.61 inches at Marion (Marion County); 10:56 inches at Bangorville (Richland County) and 10.15 inches at Wooster (Wayne County). In eastern Nebr. and western Iowa 8 tornadoes resulted in 181 deaths (94 in Omaha, Nebr.).
Ohio's canal system came to an abrupt end. The flood caused the reservoirs to spill over into the canals, destroying aqueducts, washing out banks, and devastating most of the locks.

The Scioto River tops its levies and floods Franklinton and West Columbus. The resulting flood kills 93 people, does $5,622,000 in damage and floods 4,071 private dwellings. In all of Ohio, 428 die and $250 million in property damage.

Dayton, Ohio, was inundated by the waters of the Great Miami River. Hundreds of houses were washed away in Portsmouth, Ohio. A smallpox outbreak was reported in southeastern Indiana. At least 129 people were killed along the Ohio River. In Dayton, the number of dead totaled 454, with 40,000 left homeless.
The S.S. Vaterland is launched. 54282 tons, 950 ft, 1165 passengers.
The S.S. Imperator maiden voyage Cuxhaven to New York.

New WV governor Dr. Henry D. Hatfield was sworn in on March 4 and immediately traveled to the area as his first priority. He released some thirty individuals held under martial law, transferred Mother Jones to Charleston for medical treatment, and in April moved to impose conditions for the strike settlement. Strikers had the choice to accept Hatfield's somewhat favorable terms, or be deported from the state. The Paint Creek miners accepted and signed the "Hatfield Contract" on May 1. The Cabin Creek miners continued to resist, with some violence, until the end of July.
WCF&N: Service extended to Brandon, Iowa.
A full blizzard, 12-24 inches snow in central and eastern Ohio, winds over 75 mph, communication failures, 18 ships lost and 254 sailors dead on the Great Lakes.
WCF&N: Service extended to Urbana, Iowa.
Columbus issues the first automobile licenses.

More than 750,000 people turn out to attend the revival meeting held by evangelist William Ashley "Billy" Sunday. He reportedly converted 18,000 people and raised $21,000 during his seven week stay in Columbus
The Columbus Audubon Society is established, with president James Chase Hambleton.
Women are transferred from the Women's Building at the Ohio Penitentiary to a new Women's Prison in Marysville.
Main Library opens at The Ohio State University
King and Ben Thompson purchase 840 acres of land from James Miller and found "The Country Club District" in what is to become Upper Arlington.
A new viaduct permits the Scioto Valley Traction Company to cross the railroad tracks on Parsons Avenue.
Federal Income Tax Introduced
U.S. central bank established by The Federal Reserve Act.
Potter Lumber Co. is founded adjacent to the railroad. Local carpenters can now buy building supplies and pre-cut houses such as the "Honor Bilt" homes from Sears.
The Michigan Central Station with 18 story tower is dedicated in Detroit, MI.
The Pennsylvania Railroad outshops its first L class Mikado 2-8-2, #1752 at Juniata.
The Columbus City Charter is adopted by the electors.
The S.S. Vaterland has its maiden voyage.
The S.S. Bismarck (German) is launched. 56,551 tons, 956 feet, 2145 passengers.
WCF&N: Service extended to Center Point, Iowa.

The Archduke is assassinated in Sarajevo. 
Assassins Princip and Cabrinovic are taken into custody.

Belgrade wires its condolences to Vienna. 
Serbian Prime Minister Nikola Pasic renounces the Black Hand and orders all public meeting places closed. 
The week long festival celebrating St. Vitus Day festival is cancelled. 
Widespread rioting and looting by Croats and Moslems in Sarajevo directed towards the Serbian population. Good deal of property damage with injuries. 
Austrian Foreign Minister Count Leopold von Berchtold's initial stance is one of moderation; dismiss Belgrade's minister of police, jail all suspected terrorists, and dissolve extremist groups. Austrian army Chief of Staff General Conrad von Hotzendorff wants invasion but needs sixteen days to mobilize his troops. 
The Austrians are aware of a trip by French President Raymond Poincare and Prime Minister Rene Viviani to Russia that will end 23-Jul-1914. It was agreed that no action should take place until then. It would not do to have French and Russians in such close contact during the crisis to follow. 
Hungarian Prime Minister, Count Istvan Tisza, does not want any action that could bring war with Russia. He is in direct conflict with Austrian counterpart, Count Berchtold. 
London newspaper runs headline: "To Hell with Serbia". However, King George V decrees seven days of mourning. 
Not to be outdone, Czar Nicholas II orders twelve days of mourning.
German Ambassador to Vienna, Count Heinrich von Tschirschky, warns Berchtold against employing "hasty measures in settling accounts with Serbia".
Emperor Franz Josef sends a letter to Kaiser Wilhelm II thanking him for his condolences regarding the Archduke's death. The letter contains undertones of the actions to follow.

Archduke Franz Ferdinand is buried. 
Victor Naumann, messenger for the German Foreign Office, arrives in Vienna to assure German support in the event Russia was provoked by Austrian action. 
Foreign Office Chief Alexander Hoyos volunteers to take the letter requesting support, composed by Franz Josef and Berchtold, to Berlin and deliver it to the Kaiser persnally. The letter has been composed with moderation. Hoyos will see that it is interpreted with hostility.

German Foreign Minister Gottlieb von Jagow leaves for his honeymoon in Lucerne. 
Hoyos arrives in Berlin and is accompanied to Potsdam Palace by the Austrian Ambassador to Germany, Count L. de Szogyeny-Marich, where they meet with the Kaiser. The goal of the mission is to secure German backing for any actions Austria-Hungary might take. No notes exist from this meeting but it is widely accepted that they received the promises of support they sought. The blank check had been given. [¿ view text of the 'blank check'] 
All but one of the seven assassins have now been apprehended. Mehmedbasic would be the only member of the assassination team to escape. See Jun-28-1914: Assassination in Sarajevo for more details.

Having completed his meeting with Hoyos and Szogyeny, the Kaiser departs for his annual North Sea cruise. The twenty day cruise had been planned for months and the Kaiser saw nothing in events that would cause him to cancel it. Besides it might appear that something was wrong should the cruise be cancelled.

The Austro-Hungarian Ministerial Council meets to consider the implications of the 'blank check'. Some sort of action will be taken against Serbia. Hungarian Prime Minister Tisza voices reservations on these plans.

Szogyeny, still in Berlin, sends a wire prepared by Hoyos to Tisza and Berchtold. The wire intimates that "The Kaiser would deplore our not taking advantage of the present moment which is favorable to us." Hoyos had fabricated this statement, and by doing so, brought the shadow of the Kaiser to Conrad's cause. Berchtold, detecting a change in the political wind also comes around to Conrad's side. Serbia must be invaded. Hungarian Prime Minister Tisza must be converted to the war camp. Berchtold recommends that Conrad and Minister of War, Baron Alexander von Krobatin, proceed with their vacation plans lest something be suspected.

The Austrians meet to formalize their strategy. A non-ultamatum super-ultimatum will be used. A non-ultimatum in that it will be in the form of a simple timed note; a super-ultamatum in that it will be formulated to generate a refusal. The fate of Serbia has been sealed.

Berchtold dispatches Friedrich von Wiesner to Sarajevo to report on the assassination inquest's findings. 
The Russian minister to Serbia drops dead.

Wiesner wires his findings back to Berchtold: Nothing has been found to implicate the Serbian government in the assassination. Berchtold keeps the findings away from Franz Josef. 
Krobatin leaves for vacation in Bad Gastein as planned.

Berchtold wins over Tisza by promising that no territorial demands will be placed upon Serbia. Berchtold was lying - Serbia had already been partitioned on paper. Tisza had written several letters to Emperor Franz Josef pleading for leniency in dealing with Serbia. Berchtold had these intercepted before they made it to the Emperor. He and Conrad would have the war against Serbia for which they had waited so long. 
Conrad leaves for vacation in Innichen as planned.
Poincare and Viviani depart France for their visit to Russia

Both the Italian and Russian ambassadors in Vienna warn the Russian government in St. Petersburg: Austria is considering decisive action against the Serbs. 
Word of the planned Austrian action against Serbia has hit the diplomatic circuit. The British are now aware that something is up in Austria.
Berchtold visits British Ambassador to Vienna, Sir Maurice de Bunsen. The ambassador notes that the Foreign Minister "was unusually chatty and agreeable."

The Austrian Ministerial Council meets in secret. It is decided that Conrad shall be given his chance and Serbia will be "beaten to earth." 
The Ultimatum to Serbia is drafted.
The ultimatum is delivered to Bad Ischl. Franz Josef get his first look at the "jewel".

Berchtold visits Franz Josef at Bad Ischl to get final approval of the ultimatum to Serbia. Berchtold finesses approval from the Emperor. 
Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Sazonov warns German Ambassador Count Friedrich von Pourtales that Russia will not allow Austria-Hungary to take any military action against Serbia. 
Everything is ready. Now it's just a waiting game until the French president and prime minister end their Russian visit on the 23rd.
After viewing the text of the ultimatum, German Undersecretary Arthur Zimmermann comments that "the note is too sharp."

Austrian Ambassador to Serbia, Baron Vladimir von Giesl, delivers the ultimatum at 6:00 pm sharp. The reply must come within 48 hours. 
Giesl has been instructed to regard any reply as unacceptable. 
Pasic and many of his cabinet are in the southern provinces on a political tour. The Minister of Public Information, Ljuba Jovanovic is the first Serb to see the "note." 
Pasic and the cabinet are called back to Belgrade.

Pasic returns to Belgrade at 5:00 am. 
Giesl and staff begin burning sensitive diplomatic papers and cipher books. They are already preparing for their departure from Belgrade on tomorrow's evening train. 
Prince Alexander urgently wires the Russian Czar for assistance and guidance in the matter. 
Russia advises Pasic to "proceed with extreme caution." [¿ view text of the advice] 
Serbia makes the contents of the ultimatum public in a hope to gain public support. The world is aghast at the contents. They ask for the impossible. 
The Kaiser hears about the ultimatum from his yacht's radio officer who read it in the Norwegian newspaper.

The reply to the note is formulated in such a way as to yield where at all possible. This reply must also win public support. 
The Serbian leadership fears for the worst. Austria will attack no matter what the contents of the reply. Serbia orders general mobilization of it's army at 3:00 pm. Nobody knew it, but, World War I had just begun. 
With a mere 5 minutes to go, Pasic personally delivers the reply to Giesl at 5:55 pm. The reply yields almost everywhere. It might as well have yielded nothing. [¿ view text of the reply] 
The Austrian legation departs Belgrade on the 6:30 pm train as planned. The train is across the Danube and back in the Empire by 6:40 pm. 
The Austrian mobilization order must be signed by Emperor Franz Josef. Berchtold obtains this signature at 7:23 pm by telling the aged Emperor that the Serbs were already attacking. Conrad was given his marching orders. Alarm Day for the Austrian army was set for 27-Jul and troop movements would begin on the day following. 
An oversight: Germany has not been informed of these actions by her ally, Austria-Hungary.

A copy of the ultimatum is wired to Poincare aboard the French battle cruiser France. 
Russia enters state of pre-mobilization. 
Conrad informs Berchtold that he will not be ready for full military action before 15-Aug-1914. Shelling would have to do until then.

Wilhelm cuts short his cruise and returns to Potsdam. 
The British fleet has just completed its summer maneuvers and is preparing to return to routine duty. Churchill orders the fleet to proceed to war stations. The fleet would be ready if the crisis got out of hand. 
Germany officially and publicly advises Austria against British mediation. 
Grey feels out the British cabinet by posing the hypothetical question of Great Britain's entering into a war if France were attacked by Germany. 
The French Chief of Staff, Joffre, and the French War Minister, Adolphe Messimy, express their hopes through the military attache in St. Petersburg that should war break out, the Russians would immediatly take the offensive in East Prussia. 
The French issue standby mobilization orders.

Serbian armed forces Chief of Staff, General Radomir Putnik is taken prisoner in Budapest as he was returning from vacation by train. After being held for a time, he is released on "orders from an all highest level". He is escorted to the Serbian frontier in Conrad's private railroad car. 
11:00 am. One month after the assassination, almost to the minute, Austria telegrams a declaration of war to Serbia. A telegram declaring war? At first Belgrade thinks it is a hoax. [¿ view text of the Austrian declaration of war] 
British Foreign Minister Grey proposes a meeting of French, German, and Italian diplomats in an effort to cool the crisis. No one is interested. 
German Chancellor Theobald von Bethmann-Hollweg admits he was duped by the Austrians and offers his resignation to the Kaiser. The Kaiser refuses stating: "You have cooked this broth, now you will eat it.". The Chancellor vents his frustration with Austria in a wire to the German Ambassador to Vienna, Tschirschky. [¿ view text of the wire] 
Austrian artillery opens up fire on Belgrade from across the Danube. 
Word of the Austrian declaration of war reaches Saint Petersburg late in the afternoon. Maurice Paleologue, French Ambassador to Russia, is quick to assure the Czar that Russia can count on France to the fullest extent.

At 1:00 am the Kaiser and Czar Nicholas II begin the famous Willy-Nilly correspondence via telegram.
The Czar orders mobilization of four military districts: Moscow, Kiev, Odessa, and Kazan. 
Germany demands that Russia demobilize at once. 
The Kaiser wires Saint Petersburg pleading for restraint since he is currently urging Austria to back off. 
The Czar calls off mobilization, for the moment. The Russians decide on only partial mobilization and only against Austria, not Germany. 
Austrian Ambassador, Count Szapary, urges Russian Foreign Minister Sazonov to call off Russian mobilization. During the meeting Sazonov is informed that Austrian monitors are shelling Belgrade from the Danube. The meeting ends in a shouting match and Szapary walks out. 
In London, Grey warns German Ambassador Lichownowsky that British neutrality cannot be counted on.

USS Mississippi BB-23 and USS Idaho BB-24 are sold to Greece after proving to be dissapointments. An attempt to economize, their small size and other design compromises made them poor at steering, stability and sea keeping.

Just past midnight, Bethmann-Hollweg, worried about the true extent of the crisis, summons British Ambassador Edward Goschen in order to strike a bargain. Would Britain stay out if Germany's war with France placed no territorial demands on France or Belgium? The same could not be promised for the French colonies. Goschen discussed this offer with Grey who regarded it as a "disgrace." The answer was no. 
Jagow warns Grey that if Germany mobilizes, France, current threat or not, would be attacked per Germany's war plan. 
At 5:00 pm Austrian Emperor Franz Josef declares full mobilization. 
Bethmann-Hollweg wires his Ambassador in Vienna, Tschirschky, that the Austrians must be made to negotiate some sort of settlement. Occupation of Belgrade would be preferable to war. The Chancellor is convinced that Britain will come in against Germany. 
In a final attempt to avert war, Bethmann-Hollweg goes against earlier German advice and wires Berchtold that he should accept the British offer of mediation. Berchtold declines. 
The Czar changes his mind for the third time: Russia proclaims general mobilization.

Triggered by the Russian general mobilization, at 11:55 am Germany declares Kriegsgefahr Zustand. Danger of war - a state of pre-mobilization. 
Germany issues an ultimatum to Russia: demobilize fully within 12 hours or Germany would begin mobilization and declare war on Russia. 
Germany issues an ultimatum to France: declare neutrality within 18 hours and hand over the frontier forts at Liege and Namur in a show of good faith. 
At 5:15 pm the French cabinet authorizes full mobilization.
In light of Russia failing to meet the terms of the demobilization ultimatum, Germany mobilizes and declares war on Russia.

Germans request free passage through Belgium. 
Germany and Turkey sign a secret treaty of alliance.
Italy declares neutrality.

Germany declares war on France. 
The Belgians refuse the German army passage through their country.

The German army violates Belgian neutrality as the Schlieffen Plan is put into motion. The invasion of France is on. 
The British issue an ultimatum to Germany: withdraw all troops from Belgian soil by midnight or a state of war will exist between the two countries. 
The British Ambassador, Sir Edward Goschen, calls on Bethmann-Hollweg for the final time. The Chancellor tells the ambassador: "just for a scrap of paper Great Britain was going to make war on a kindred nation who desired nothing better than to be friends with her." 
Germany never responds to the the British ultimatum.
Passenger liner SS Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse scuttled in battle.
HMS Oceanic ran aground off the Shetland Islands and was abandoned. Two weeks later it broke up in a storm.
WCF&N: Service extended to Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
New Columbus city charter eliminates the ward system.
OSU: Lazenby Hall, 1827 Neil Ave., opens. Horticulture and Forestry Building.
The Ohio State University acquires the Starling Medical College, moving it to the area around 12th Ave..
Bethel A.M.E. congregation changes its name and builds St. John's A.M.E. Church at 682 E. Plymouth St. The congregation stays there until 2003.
The Brunt Tile and Porcelain Company takes over the Columbus Pottery Building at the eastern end of the Chaseland subdivision southeast of Worthington. C. A. Van Brunt?
Francis Ehrig Patty born.
Cleveland's baseball team is renamed from the "Naps" to the "Indians".

First transcontinental telephone service innaugurated with a ceremonial first call on from four locations: New York City, San Francisco, the White House in Washington, D.C., and Jekyll Island, Ga., where AT&T President Theodore Vail is at the time. Service is available to all telephone customers, but at an initial price of $20.70 for the first three minutes between New York and San Francisco, volume is low.
Jess Willard knocked out Jack Johnson in the 26th round to win the heavyweight boxing championship held in Havana, Cuba.
The RMS Lusitania is sunk
George B. Patty born in Kansas.
Deadly Cincinnati winds: Severe thunderstorm winds collapsed houses and apartments, killed 38.
Chimes are dedicated in Orton Hall at The Ohio State University
Western Pacific Acquires the Boca and Loyalton.
Yuan Shikai dies in China, causing a power vacuum in the Republic government and leading to a period of chaotic warlord rule in China.
Three thousand national guard troops camp out in Upper Arlington, destroying nearly everything that had been built since 1913.
Columbus reorganizes a local chapter of the Red Cross.
The Deshler Hotel at 9 N. High St. is built. Twelve stories.
OSU: Campbell Hall, 1787 Neil Ave., opens. "The Home Economics Building"
Charles Evans Hughes resigned from the Supreme Court to run for president against Woodrow Wilson.
Columbus Union Depot handles the most trains in its history, 160 per day.
New Orleans, Texas & Mexico gains control of the New Iberia & Northern.
The Pennsylvania Railroad outshops its first I1 class, #790 at Juniata.
The Scioto Valley Traction Company adds electric utility service. Distribution lines were installed in rural areas and Canal Winchester, Groveport, Carrol and Lockbourne.
A new Worthington High School designed by architect Frank Packard is built on the school farm lot. The building is now unoccupied and awaiting renovation into an arts complex.
Dr. George T. Harding opens a rest home for women on E. 18th Ave., the forerunner of Harding Hospital.
High Street is paved and a sewage system is installed.
Worthington Fire Department is officially organized.
Worthington Presbyterian Church celebrates its centennial.
AEP: A 33,000 volt transmission line is installed across the Ohio River at Wheeling. It is designed with 6 wires to withstand 1" of ice and 100 mph winds.
Passenger liner SS Kaiser Wilhelm II is seized by the United States and renamed USS Agamemnon.
Passenger liner SS Kronprinz Wilhelm seized by the United States and renamed USS Von Steuben.
The United States declares war on Germany
The S.S. Vaterland becomes the U.S.S. Leviathan

Ohio State's School of Aeronautics opened May 21, 1917, when the first "squadron" or group of 16 cadets reported. At the end of the first two weeks of intensive military training, the squadron undertook five weeks of theoretical and technical instruction in military aeronautics, consisting of signaling, gunnery, airplanes, engines and aerial observation.
Selective Service Act passed by Congress.
Mattoon, Ill.: tornado smashed area, causing 101 deaths.
Eddie Rickenbacker enlists in the U.S. Army.

On "Call to the Colors Day" every church, school, fire, farm and engine bell, along with automobile horns and factory whistles are to be blown for five minutes at 7 a.m. to encourage young men to register for the draft. Seven men from Worthington volunteer for the army.
United States troops arrive in France
Letters Patent 1,232,354 issued to John E. Mair, assignor to The Brunt Tile & Porcelain Company, Columbus, OH for an electrical insulator.
Ohio State's School of Aeronautics first pilot squadron graduated.
Henry Ford incorporated his private company, Henry Ford and Son Inc, to mass-produce Fordson tractors, the first affordable tractor for the average farmer.
Passenger liner SS Kronprinzessin Cecilie is seized by the United States and renamed the USS Mt. Vernon.
Henry Ford II is born.
Worthington Sunday School classes converge on the public square for a flag raising ceremony commemorating the installation of a flag pole.
The former George Stoner inn at 133 S. State St., a stop on the Underground Railroad from 1852-1863, becomes home to the prohibitionist American Issue Publishing Co.
The Columbus, Delaware and Marion allows Worthington to tap its line to provide electric current to local residents.
Addition to St. John's Episcopal Church building in Worthington completed.

AEP: The 180 MW Windsor Power Plant with 9, 30 MW units opens in the West Virginia panhandle. It was the first large steam plant built many miles from it's main source of demand in Canton, which it connected to via a 55 mile, 138,000 volt transmission line. It had the highest steam temperature and pressure of any plant in the world.
St. John's Episcopal Church hosts celebration of the centennial of the founding of the Diocese of Ohio.
Temperatures of -10 to -15 with 40-60 mph winds, wind chills -80 degrees, 10-15 inches of snow with drifts over houses.
Dr. Samuel Brubaker Hartman dies of Pneumonia at the age of 81 at his suite in the Hartman Hotel.

The Ohio River rises to 61.8 feet at Cincinnatti. The flood followed a quick thaw of the river. Huge chunks of ice floated down the Ohio and crushed the hulls of many steamboats, effectively ending the era of steamboat commerce on the Ohio.
107 cases of The Spanish flu are reported at Fort Riley KS.
Ohio State's School for Balloon Officers, the only one of its kind in the nation, begins training 219 men.
Eddie Rickenbacker assigned to the 94th Aero Pursuit Squadron.
Upper Arlington incorporated.
Eddie Rickenbacker's 94th Aero Pursuit Squadron is the first air unit to see combat.
Eddie Rickenbacker shoots down his 5th German plane, thus becoming an ace.

World War I pilot and star Ohio State University athlete Fred William Norton led the 27th "Eagle" Pursuit Squadron in one of the earliest significant American air engagements of World War I. He died from wounds after his Nieuport 28 was shot down in northern France less than three weeks later
Ohio State's School of Aeronautics closed after training roughly 1,300 men.
The Spanish Flue epidemic begins to take off.

200,000 gather for a 4th Liberty Loan Drive in Philadelphia. Days after the parade, 635 new cases of influenza were reported. Within days, the city will be forced to admit that epidemic conditions exist. Churches, schools, and theaters are ordered closed, along with all other places of "public amusement."
Former President Theodore Roosevelt visits General Charles L. Cooper at his home at 160 E. Granville Rd. Cooper was the officer who mustered Roosevelt's Rough Riders into service for the war.
Boston registers 202 deaths from influenza. Shortly thereafter, the city canceles its Liberty Bond parades and sporting events. Churches were closed and the stock market was put on half-days.

In El Paso, Texas, Mayor Charles Davis closed all schools, churches, theaters and other public places. Even funerals could not be held in churches. Health officials denied all requests to reopen them. By the end of the month, 400 will die and nearly 5,000 will be ill.
Philadelphia reports 139 deaths and 636 new cases of the Spanish Flu.
Philadelphia reports 171 deaths and 788 new cases of the Spanish Flu.

Acting upon a recommendation from the U.S. Public Health Service, the Atlanta, GA, City Council declared all public gathering places closed for two months as a precautionary measure against the epidemic of Spanish influenza sweeping the nation. This ban included schools, libraries, churches, and theaters. Street cars were directed to keep all windows open -- except in rain. In a precautionary move, the University of Georgia announced it was indefinitely suspending classes. Back in Augusta, where the epidemic was most active, military officials on this day ordered soldiers to sleep under the stars, and by now everyone was wearing gauze masks during the day. No one was allowed on base except close relatives, and soldiers were restricted from going to Atlanta without a special pass.
Philadelphia reports 250 deaths and 1,481 new cases of the Spanish Flu.
Philadelphia reports 361 deaths and 5,531 new cases of the Spanish Flu.
Philadelphia reports 557 deaths and 4,302 new cases of the Spanish Flu.

In Chicago, in one day, 317 deaths and 2,221 new cases of The Spanish Flu are reported. City and State Health authorities meet to give their final decision on the question of closing of churches, saloons, cabarets, schools, pool rooms and ice cream parlors as a result of influenza.
Philadelphia reports 650 deaths and 2,280 new cases of the Spanish Flu.
Philadelphia reports 711 deaths and 1,686 new cases of the Spanish Flu.
Philadelphia reports 606 deaths and 1,334 new cases of the Spanish Flu.
In Philadelphia, churches reopen as The Spanish Flu epidemic abates.
Eddie Rickenbacker shoots down his 26th and final German plane.
Armistice ends World War I. 6,800 Ohioans died in the war.
The U.S. signs the armistice. Three Worthington men die in WW I. Laurence G. Leasure, Arthur Wolford and William H. Yauger.
In San Francisco, the death toll from The Spanish Flu stands at 2,122.
The Spanish Flu winds down after it has killed 500,000 Americans, infected 20,000,000 and spread to 46 states. Worldwide deaths may have exceeded 100,000,000.
The Pennsylvania Railroad outshops its first N class 2-10-2, #7008. Built by Alco at Brooks.

The Defense Supply Center Columbus is established. The location was chosen because of its proximity to three railroad lines. During World War I, the center was a procurement and distribution point for military equipment and supplies. It became the largest military supply center in the world during World War II, employing more than 10,000 civilians and holding more than 400 Axis prisoners of war in barracks.
The Columbus Urban league is established. Starting in 1917, thousands of African Americans began pouring into Columbus for war work.
OSU: Lord Hall, 124 W. 17th Ave., addition to add more lab space and kilns.
The Ohio Legislature prohibits German instruction below the 8th grade.
WWI ends, U.S. Public debt is $14.59 billions.
Worthington Board of Education drops the study of German from the curriculum.
Worthington Chapter of the Red Cross organized.
The battleship USS Indiana (BB-01) is decommissioned
Eighteenth Amendment establishing prohibition passed.
Ordinance passed to create a sewage system for Worthington.
The battleship USS Massachusetts (BB-02) is decommissioned
The battleship USS Iowa (BB-04) is decommisioned.

The May Fourth Movement is an anti-imperialist, cultural, and political movement growing out of student participants in Beijing, protesting against the Chinese government's weak response to the Treaty of Versailles, especially allowing Japan to receive territories in Shandong which had been surrendered by Germany after the Siege of Tsingtao.
The S.S. Imperator becomes the U.S.S. Imperator at Brest, France.
Ohio ratifies 19th amendment giving women the right to vote.
Treaty of Versailles is signed
Dr. George T. Harding II purchases the Joyce family summer home east of the village and begins to establish the Harding psychiatric hospital.
Hurricane: Fla. keys, La., and southern Tex.: more than 600 killed, mostly lost on ships at sea.
The battleship USS Missouri (BB-11) is decommisioned
Scioto Valley Traction Company runs a special car from Columbus to Chillicothe for General J. J. Pershing, who was most likely headed for Camp Sherman on the west side of the Scioto River.
OSU: McCracken Power Plant, 304 W. 17th Ave., first 3 boilers start up to provide steam heating for campus buildings.
U.S. Public debt rises to $27.39 billions.

Artist Mark Russell remodels home at 5807 N. High and christens it "Green Gables". Russell created murals for the LaVeque Tower and stained class windows for Broad St. Presbyterian Church in Columbus.
The American Legion establishes the Laurence G. Leasure Post.
The Methodist Church holds special service and celebratory dinner for returned soldiers and sailors.
The League of Nations is formed in Geneva Switzerland.
Five killer tornadoes in western counties, 24 dead.
A lighting ceremony and parade celebrate the installation of electric street lights purchased by the Chamber of Commerce for High, Hartford and Pearl Streets.
Starkville, Miss.; Waco, Ala.: tornado killed 88.
The battleship USS Alabama (BB-08) is decommisioned
The battleship USS Maine (BB-10) is decommisioned

The Battle of Matewan (also known as the Matewan massacre) was a shootout in the town of Matewan in Mingo County and the Pocahontas Coalfield mining district, in southern West Virginia. between local coal miners and the Baldwin–Felts Detective Agency.
The battleship USS Wisconsin (BB-09) is decommisioned
The battleship USS Kentucky (BB-06) is decommisioned
The battleship USS Rhode Island (BB-17) is decommisioned
The battleship USS Vermont (BB-20) is decommisioned
The battleship USS Nebraska (BB-14) is decommisioned
The battleship USS Georgia (BB-15) is decommisioned
The battleship USS New Jersey (BB-16) is decommisioned
The battleship USS Kearsarge (BB-05) is decommisioned and converted into a crane ship.
The battleship USS Virginia (BB-13) is decommisioned
The Summer Olympics open in Antwerp, Belgium.
Nineteenth Amendment is ratified, establishing women's suffrage.

The National Football League was born in the Jordan and Hupmobile auto showroom in Canton, Ohio. Akron, Canton, Cleveland and Dayton from the one-month-old American Professional Football Conference joined Hammond, Muncie, Rochester, Decatur, Racine and Rock Island to form the American Professional Football Association (which was eventually re-named the National Football League in 1922). Membership set at $100 each.
The Columbus Panhandles play their first football game as a member of the new NFL. Columbus' "sandlot" players have a hard time competing against other team's college trained players.
The Picway Power Plant of the Columbus Railway Power and Light Company, located on the Scioto River at the Franklin-Pickaway County line, begins operating.
The battleship USS Louisiana (BB-19) is decommisioned
First J.C. Penney store in Columbus opens.
Lazarus adds a building on High Street to the north to make room for new merchandise such as cameras, records and yard goods.
The population of Columbus reaches 237,031
Ohio State University celebrates its 50th anniversary with an enrollment of 8,313
OSU: Brown Hall Annex power plant is shut down.
Ohio Congressman Warren G. Harding is elected President as women vote for the first time.

The Decatur Staleys (later, the Bears) shutout 10 of their 13 opponents in their first year of existence posting at 10-1-2 overall record. The team lost only once to the rival Chicago Cardinals 7-6. Each player was compensated $1,900 for the season.
Masonic Lodge celebrates the centennial of its temple building.
The Godman Guild obtains the remaining 76 acres of Johnson Farm.
Worthington garage, a Ford dealership, burns to the ground. 38 cars destroyed.
Worthington resident Thomas Midgley develops the first high-octane gasoline.
Worthington Seventh-day Adventists begin meeting in the lobby of the Harding Sanitarium.
AEP: Number of Americans with electricity in their homes: 35%
AEP: American Gas & Electric produced 538,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
The battleship USS Massachusetts (BB-02) is scuttled off Pensacolo, Florida.
Columbus City Hall is destroyed by a fire.
Red Army troops invade Georgia, incorporating it into the Soviet Union.
Warren Gamaleil Harding inaugurated as President.
First broadcast of WBAV, later WHKC and finally WTVN 610 radio.
Union Pacific and Oregon Shortline gain joint control of Los Angeles & Salt Lake.
Chief Justice Edward Douglas White of the United States Supreme Court dies in office.
William Howard Taft takes office as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court. He is the only person to have been both President and Chief Justice.
Agents of the Baldwin Felts Detective Agency murder Sid Hatfield and his deputy Ed Chambers on the McDowell County, WV courthouse steps in revenge for the Matewan shootout.

The Battle of Blair Mountain was the largest labor uprising in United States history and one of the largest, best-organized, and most well-armed uprisings since the American Civil War. For five days from late August to early September 1921, in Logan County, West Virginia, some 10,000 armed coal miners confronted 3,000 lawmen and strikebreakers, called the Logan Defenders, who were backed by coal mine operators during the miners' attempt to unionize the southwestern West Virginia coalfields.
The Green Bay Packers play their first regular season game, defeating the Minneapolis Marines 7-6.
Chicago's first radio station WYK, goes on the air. It is a joint venture between utilities magnate Samuel Insull and Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
The battleship USS Kansas (BB-21) is decommisioned
Picasso visits Italy, and paints Seated Nude Drying her Foot, a return to "order".
Cadillac relocates operations to Detroit Assembly, where it will make Cadillacs until 1987.
McKinley Hospital at 664 Park Street becomes the Park View Sanitarium, and also houses nurses for the nearby Protestant (White Cross) Hospital between 1927 and 1930.
Sunshine field, Columbus' first ball field, opens.
The first free cancer clinic in the United States opens in Columbus.
The Hartman Hotel closes and is leased as offices. One tenant includes the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
OSU: Brown Hall, 190 W. 17th Ave., addition.
OSU: McCracken Power Plant, 304 W. 17th Ave., addition, and begins generating electricity.
The Bing Act makes school attendance compulsory from 6 to 16 years of age and forces rural districts to have a high school or pay tuition and transportation to adjacent district high school.
Worthington Chamber of Commerce offers prizes for high school essay contest on the subject of "The History of Worthington".
Worthington Chamber of Commerce purchases motorized fire truck for the village. Volunteers previously used a hand pumper.
The Chicago Staleys are renamed the Chicago Bears.
