Toledo & Ohio Central makes its last stop at the T&OC station at 379 West Broad Street.
The former S.S. Bismarck, now the British HMS Majestic, sets sale for trials.
The battleship USS Ohio (BB-12) is decommisioned
A fire swept through the heart of Buckeye Lake Park, destroying the pool room, rink and arcade buildings. The brunt of the $100,000 loss was born by the Ohio Electric Company, which owned the park.

Buckeye Lake Park, only recently damaged by fire a month ago, was hit by a tornado. The Buckeye Bathing Company bathhouse was blown over. The Canals of Venice and miniature train ride were also destroyed.

German right-wing fanatics assassinated Walter Rathenau, the moderate, able foreign minister. Rathenau was a charismatic figure, and the idea that a popular, wealthy, and glamorous government minister could be shot in a law-abiding society shattered the faith of the Germans, who wanted to believe that things were going to be all right. Rathenau's state funeral was a national trauma. The nervous citizens of the Ruhr were already getting their money out of the currency and into real goods -- diamonds, works of art, safe real estate. Now ordinary Germans began to get out of Marks and into real goods. Hyperinflation begins.
The Chicago Cardinals (later the St. Louis, and then Phoenix Cardinals) play their first regular season game, defeating the Milwaukee Badgers 3-0.
Ohio Stadium dedicated, University of Michigan beats Ohio State 19-0
Clinton School, a turreted brick edifice, is demolished.
Columbus Barracks renamed Fort Hayes.
Protestant Hospital joins the Ohio Methodist Episcopal Conference. Name changed to White Cross Hospital.
Ohio State University goes to the four quarter plan
The battleship USS Wisconsin (BB-09) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Maine (BB-10) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Missouri (BB-11) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Nebraska (BB-14) is sold for scrap.
Land that would later become Shawnee State Park is acquired and opened as the Theodore Roosevelt State Game Preserve.
The Battleship Ohio (BB12) is decommissioned.
The Toledo & Ohio Central is leased to the New York Central.
Union of Socialist Soviet Republics established.
Russia: Kamchatka was struck by a quake with a magnitude of 8.5.
The battleship USS Connecticut (BB-18) is decommisioned
The battleship USS Iowa (BB-04) is sunk by the USS Mississippi (BB-41) near Panama.
Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, OH began the first regular production of balloon tires.
The success of selling electricity causes the Scioto Valley Traction Company to change its name to the Scioto Valley Railway and Power Company.
Broad Street Station in New York City burns. Although service is restored rapidly, the massive car shed is a loss and is soon torn down.

Captain Eddie Rickenbacker attended the dedication ceremonies for Columbus' first airport, Norton Field as Columbus received its first air mail delivery. Norton Field became the headquarters for the 308th Observation Squadron, made up of local reservists
Calvin Coolidge inaugurated as President.
The battleship USS Kansas (BB-21) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Rhode Island (BB-17) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Connecticut (BB-18) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Louisiana (BB-19) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Vermont (BB-20) is sold for scrap.

The German Hyperinflation comes to an end when Hjalmar Schacht, the new head of the German central bank, issues the Rentenmark, which is worth 10 billion of the old marks. All debt, pensions and life insurance policies that existed before 1921 are rendered worthless. The Nazis begin to pick up parlimentary seats in the elections...
Cecille B. DeMille releases "The Ten Commandments", a silent film.
Perkins Observatory groundbreaking. At the time, its telescope was the third largest in the world.
The Dusenbury's, in a financial bind, sell the Olentangy Amusement Park to Max Stear, who also built the Majestic Theater.
The Law & Finance Building at 85 E. Gay St. opens. 13 stories.
The battleship USS Ohio (BB-12) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Virginia (BB-13) is sunk as a target ship off North Carolina
The battleship USS Georgia (BB-15) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS New Jersey (BB-16) is sold for scrap.
Passenger liner SS Kronprinz Wilhelm, renamed USS Von Steuben in 1917, is scrapped.
The battleship USS Kentucky (BB-06) is sold for scrap.
New Orleans, Texas & Mexico gains control of Houston & Brazos Valley.
The lava lake at Halema‘uma‘u, Hawaii began draining, followed by a severe earthquake swarm in lower Puna, 50 km down the east rift zone.
The battleship USS Indiana (BB-01) is sold for scrap.
The battleship USS Alabama (BB-08) is sold for scrap.
The Summer Olympics open in Paris, France.
Hawaii's Kilauea Volcano erupts explosively, throwing 20 tons blocks for miles. Over 50 explosions occur over 2.5 weeks.
New Orleans, Texas & Mexico gains control of the International - Great Northern.
85 dead in Lorain and Sandusky, deadliest Ohio tornado.
In Georgia, Lavrentiy Beria puts down an uprising by killing 12,000 intellectuals and nobels, and exiling 20,000 to Siberia.
Missouri Pacific gains control of New Orleans, Texas & Mexico.
Children's Hospital opens at Livingston Park.
First automatic electric traffic light service in Columbus.
North Broadway United Methodist church in Clintonville opens.
Ohio Bell Telephone takes over most Columbus phone service.
The Hotel Fort Hayes is built. Thirteen stories.
Hamilton Hall, precursor of University Hospitals, opens at OSU
OSU: Bricker Hall, 190 N. Oval Drive, opens. Houses the University President's Office.
OSU: Hagerty Hall, 1775 College Road, opens. College of Business.
OSU: Ives Hall, 2073 Neil Ave., addition of a building and horse barn are joined together.
OSU: The Journalism Building, 141 W. 18th Ave., opens. Houses "The Lantern" newspaper offices and press.
The battleship USS Illinois (BB-07) is decommisioned
St. John's moves rectory and begins construction of the Parish House.
Worthington hires its first chief of police, James Taladay.

AEP: The Philo plant on the Muskingum River begins operation. It operates at 700 deg F and 600 PSI with 40 MW turbine. It is the first in the nation to utilize steam reheat. Its 132 KV transmission line used steel reinforced aluminum conductors.
Harlan Fiske Stone is appointed Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
First Issue of "The Worthington News"
At 1:01 pm the F5-rated "Tri-State Tornado" killed 695 people and injured 2,027. The longest-running tornado on record, it traveled more than 300 miles between Missouri and Indiana.
The battleship USS Oregon (BB-03) is loaned to the state of Oregon as a museum
The New York Giants play their first regular season game, losing to the Providence Steam Rollers 14-0.
New Orleans, Texas & Mexico gains control of San Antonio, Uvalde & Gulf and Asphalt Belt
Moores and Ross took the daring step of producing and marketing milk-based infant formula - a new concept at the time. The product was originally known as Franklin Infant Food.
Columbus branch of the Boy Scouts purchases 130 acres east of the Olentangy five miles south of Delaware for a camp.
O'Shaughnessy Dam was completed. Columbus had a water supply to serve a population of one half million - twice the city's size at the time.
The Neil House is built at 41 S. High St. Twelve stories.
OSU: Arps Hall, 1945 N. High St., is built. Houses University High School.
OSU: Haskett Hall, 156 W. 19th Ave., opens to house the Engineering Experiment Station.
OSU: Mendenhall Laboratory, 125 South Oval Mall, renamed from "The Physics Building" to "Mendenhall Laboratory."
U.S. Route 40 established as transcontinental highway between State Road, DE and San Francisco, CA.
PRR: A stone horseshoe is erected in the park at Horseshoe Curve.
The Cleveland, Mt. Vernon & Columbus Railroad, now known as The Cleveland, Akron & Columbus Railroad, is consolidated into the Pennsylvania, Ohio & Detroit Railroad, part of the Pennsylvania System.
Scopes "monkey trial" in Tennessee vindicates teaching of evolution.
Paul Insley begins publication of the weekly Worthington News.
Presbyterians build current sanctuary. Additional space added in the 1950's for education and administration.
The pottery at the east end of the Chaseland subdivision closes.
Wilson School sold for $2,100. Building becomes a summer retreat known as Sharondale.

Worthington Public Library Association becomes the Worthington School District Library to take advantage of a state law that allows a public library supported to be supported through taxation under the jurisdiction of the board of education.
New Orleans, Texas & Mexico gains control of Sugarland, Asherton & Gulf and Rio Grande City.
The streetcar line in Minerva Park becomes the Columbus Railway Power and Light Company with Charles F. Johnson buying it that same day.
The long closed Minerva Park Amusement park is cleared to site the Village of Minerva Park.
Hurricane: southeast Fla. and Ala.: 243 deaths.
Missouri Pacific gains control of New Orleans & Lower Coast.
New Orleans, Texas & Mexico gains control of Sam Antonio Southern.
The High-Long Building at 5 E. Long St. opens. 12 stories.
The Columbus Panhandles play their last football season.
Methodist Congregation builds its third church (now known as Potter Chapel) at current site.
The last one-room school house in Sharon Twp. Closes on High St.
Texas & Pacific gains control of Abilene & Southern.
Scioto Valley Traction Company establishes parlor car service on the Chillicothe Division.
Beaumont, Sour Lake & Western gains control of Houston North Shore.
Poplar Bluff, Mo.: twister killed 98
Ford Motor Company ceases production of the Model T and begins retooling to make the Model A.
St. John's Episcopal Church purchases Township Hall in Worthington.
Scioto Valley Traction Company establishes parlor car service on the Lancaster Division.
Chicago Heights Terminal Transfer sold to Chicago & Eastern Illinois.
St. Louis, Mo.: a five-minute tornado ripped through the city and caused 79 deaths.
Columbus Zoo opens, with reindeer supplied by the Columbus Dispatch
The first Ford Model A is produced.
Dedication of Worthington Library Building at 752 N. High Street after Mary Deshler donates funds as a memorial to her grandfather, James Kilbourne.

Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association, suggested that Moores & Ross Milk Company change the name of their infant formula from Franklin Infant Food to Similac¨.
AIU/Lincoln LaVeque Tower dedication.
Boy Scout Camp Ro Fre La (Lazarus) opens.
Jeffrey Manufacturing makes the first direct transatlantic phone call from Columbus.
The Buckeye Office Building at 42 E. Gay St. opens. 15 stories.
The Clinton and the Eastern, Ohio's first air-conditioned suburban theaters, open.
First traffic light, and first garbage collection in Worthington.
Worthington Presbyterian Church's current building dedicated.
Scioto Valley Traction Company abandons its power house at Rees.
The one millionth Ford Model A is sold.

At Columbus Union Station, the South Pavilion and its extension are demolished. The stub end of the arcade on the north received a new exterior wall, as did the commercial building on the south, and the driveway received a second leg that looped around the ramp to the lower level; this provided a one-way path to and from the depot  and allowed for a fair bit of parking as well.
A tornado at Buckeye Lake Park tore the front porch off the Buckeye Lake Yacht Club. Six yachts sank or were partially wrecked.
The two millionth Ford Model A is sold.
The Summer Olympics open in Amsterdam, Netherlands.
Hurricane: Lake Okeechobee, southeast Fla.: 1,836 deaths. Second-deadliest U.S. hurricane on record.
The Pioneer Movie Theater opens in the remodeled Wing Garage behind what is now the Worthington Hardware. The building is still standing.

Alexander Fleming discovers penicillin at St. Mary's Hospital in London after noticing a Petri dish containing Staphylococci that had been mistakenly left open was contaminated by blue-green mould from an open window, which formed a visible growth. There was a halo of inhibited bacterial growth around the mould. Once Fleming made his discovery he grew a pure culture and discovered it was a Penicillium mould, now known as Penicillium chrysogenum. Fleming coined the term "penicillin" to describe the filtrate of a broth culture of the Penicillium mould.
"Steamboat Willie" by Walt Disney released. First synchronized sound cartoon in mass release. First Mickey Mouse cartoon released.
RMS Celtic runs aground at Roches Point at Cobh. It is declared a total loss and scrapped in place.
The Valley Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the SVTC, establishes bus service between Columbus and Pomeroy.
B. H. Kroger sells his company stock and retires from active management, and the State Avenue facility expands to add manufacturing.

Grandview's Bank Block ushered in the era of strip mall shopping. It was built by influential developer Don M. Casto. The Bank Block name was chosen because First Citizens Trust (known as Ohio National Bank after 1932) was the first business to sign up as a tenant and remained there until 1964.
Lazarus buys Shillito's in Cincinnati, the oldest department store west of the Alleghenies.

This Ohio Theatre opens. Designed as a Loew's movie house by Scottish architect Thomas W. Lamb, the theatre seats 2,779 within an auditorium noted for its outstanding acoustics and beautiful, ornate Spanish/Baroque decorations.
Voters approve construction of Port Columbus Airport.
Columbus Union Station is extensively remodeled. The foyer and trackage side of the walkway are sealed with masonry, obstructing the view of the trains from High Street.
Worthington Town Council moves its chambers from Township Hall (67 E. Granville Rd.) to new commercial building at 693 High St.
Myers Y. Cooper inaugurated Governor of Ohio
Herbert Clark Hoover inaugurated as President.
Scioto Valley Traction Company cancels parlor car service on the Lancaster Division.
Scioto Valley Traction Company reduces hourly service to 90 minute service on the Lancaster Division.
Mississippi River & Bonne Terre leased by Missouri-Illinois.
Missouri Pacific gains control of Missouri-Illinois.
A tornado heavily damages the Ohio Penitentiary. The wall of a cell block is blown down.
The Colorado River Compact is put into force, allocating the water from the Colorado River to the surrounding states.
Port Columbus Airport opens. Amelia Earhart and others arrive on a Pennsylvania Railroad Airways Limited train and boarded two Ford Tri-Motor airplanes to continue their journey west.
The first recession of the 1930's begins.
The stock market hits its peak, with a Times index of 381.17.  The stock market would not regain this peak until November 23rd, 1954
The Dow loses 31 points ... 7% of its total value.
The stock market crashes. The Dow opened that day at 299.6, but crashed 68.9 points to close at 230.7, losing 23 percent of its value.
The stock market bottoms out at 198.60, followed by a bear market that would last until April 1930
The Valley Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the SVTC, establishes bus service between Columbus and Chillicothe.
The Valley Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the SVTC, adds bus service to Groveport.
Borden Company acquires Casein Company of America, a producer of milk-based resin systems.
Lazarus pools its stock with Filene's of Boston and Abraham & Strauss of Brooklyn to form Federated Department Stores.
James Thurber publishes his first book, "Is Sex Necessary?" with co-author E.B. White.
OSU: Cockins Hall, 1958 Neil Ave., opens. Originally houses the Pharmacy and Microbiology Departments.
Scioto Valley Traction Company reduces 90 minute service to three hour service on the Lancaster Division.
Chief Justice William Howard Taft of the United States Supreme Court retires.
Charles Evans Hughes is elevated from Associate Justice to Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
The planet Pluto is discovered by Clyde W. Tombaugh.
Work begins to replace the train shed at Columbus Union Station with an enclosed concourse.

Leo Hartnett of the Chicago Cubs broke the altitude record for a catch by catching a baseball dropped from the Goodyear blimp 800 feet over Los Angeles, CA. He caught the ball cleanly, saying, "Eeeeeeeeeeeeeooooooooooowwwwwwww!" for posterity. Hartnett reportedly broke something else as well, this day ... his jaw. When catching the ball, the force shattered his jawbone.
The Valley Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the SVTC, adds bus service to Ashville and Kingston.
Fire at the Ohio State Penitentiary kills 320 inmates. Most die from smoke inhalation; damage to the facility is only $11,000.
Scioto Valley Traction Company cancels parlor car service on the Chillicothe Division.
Scioto Valley Traction Company reduces hourly service to two hour service on the Chillicothe Division.
Columbus & Hocking Valley Railroad absorbed into the Chesapeake & Ohio Railroad.
The Valley Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the SVTC, begins using the Union Bus Terminal at 49 East Town Street, abandoning the SVTC station.

Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act passed, placing more stress on the weakening global economy, primarily through the collapse in trade of agricultural products, which strained banks that had lent heavily to farmers.
Scioto Valley Traction Company shareholders vote to abandon passenger and freight service, except service to the Picway power plant.
Minerva Golf Course opens in an attempt to sell lots unsold due to the Great Depression.
Scioto Valley Traction Company ends regular passenger service.
Eddie Rickenbacker awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor by President Herbert Hoover.
Patrick Foley is born in Yonkers, New York.

Cecil George Paine, a pathologist at the Royal Infirmary in Sheffield, attempted to use penicillin to treat sycosis barbae, eruptions in beard follicles, but was unsuccessful. Moving on to ophthalmia neonatorum, a gonococcal infection in infants, he achieved the first recorded cure with penicillin. He then cured four additional patients (one adult and three infants) of eye infections, and failed to cure a fifth.
Denver, Rio Grande & Western gains control of Denver & Salt Lake.
Police headquarters opens as part of the Scioto riverfront development.
Enrollment at Ohio State University exceeds 15,000 for the first time
OSU: Derby Hall, 154 North Oval Drive, has a three story addition added. The University Book Store is housed in the basement.
OSU: McPherson Laboratory of Chemistry, 140 W. 18th Ave., opens.
Three homes are built on Kenyon Brook on lots purchased from Edwin Albaugh, a famous inventor, artist and mechanical genius who had a workshop at this site.
Hoover Dam bid documents made available.
Nevada legalized gambling, making it the only state in the nation to do so.
Transcontinental & Western Air flight 599 crashes near Cottonwood Falls, Kansas, killing all eight aboard; among those killed is Notre Dame University football coach Knute Rockne.
Pitcher Jackie Mitchell was signed by the Chattanooga Baseball Club. Yeah? So? Well, Mitchell was the first woman in organized baseball. Miss Mitchell was 19 years old.
Work is completed on the new Concourse at Columbus Union Station.

Karl Jansky, considered a father of radio astronomy, discovers that a radio signal is coming from a location at the center of the Milky Way, in the direction of the constellation of Sagittarius. This is later shown to be the black hole at the center of the Milky Way galaxy.
RMS Cedric last trip from Liverpool to New York before scrapping.

Britain leaves the gold standard, and the Pound Sterling depreciates by 25%. Despite warning of disaster, the departure proves beneficial to the British economy, as exports become more competitive. Additionally, the Bank of England was now free to engage in money creation, and reduced interest rates from 6.00% to 2.00%.
Maiden flight of the 785 foot long, helium filled Dirigible Akron from the Akron Airdock in Akron, Ohio.
Henry Ford orders all Model A passenger production stopped. Seventy thousand workers are laid off and 22 plants are shuttered. Henry Ford is working on a new V-8 engined replacement.
Missouri Pacific gains control of Doniphan, Kensett & Searcy.
Fleetwood Metal Body relocates from Fleetwood, PA to Detroit, MI.
Construction of The Ohio State Courts building at 65 S. Front St. begins. 14 stories.
OSU: Larkins Hall, 337 W. 17th Ave., opens as the Physical Education Building and Natatorium.
Toledo & Ohio Central station at 379 West Broad Street sold to the Volunteers of America.
Worthington resident Thomas Midgley invents freon - a non-flammable gas used as a refrigerant.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is created to lend $2 billion to troubled financial institutions that were not part of the Federal Reserve System that were solvent in the long-run. By 1941, the RFC would lend out some $9.5 billion to banks, railroads, and mortgage associations, as well as state and local governments.
Henry Ford announces his intention to introduce a 4 cylinder Model B and a new V8 Ford.

Some 3,000 - 5,000 unemployed workers assembled in West Detroit to march on Ford's River Rouge plant to deliver a petition demanding more support. As the march moved up Miller Road and approached Gate 3 the protest turned ugly. The police fired tear gas into the crowd and fire trucks were used to soak the protesters with icy water. When the protesters responded by throwing rocks, the violence escalated rapidly and culminated in the police and plant security guards firing live rounds through the gates of the plant at the unarmed protesters. Four men were killed outright and a fifth died later in the hospital. Up to 60 more were seriously injured.
The first Ford Model 18 (V8) rolls off the assembly line.
Ala., Miss., Ga., Tenn.: outbreak of 33 tornadoes killed 334 (268 in Ala.)
Production of the Ford Model A ceases after sales of 4,000,000 vehicles.
Professor C.G. King of the University of Pittsburgh isolated vitamin C after five years of research.
Southern Pacific gains control of St. Louis-Southwestern (Cotton Belt).

A natural gas explosion killed 11 workers and injured 50 at the Ohio State Courts building at 65 S. Front St. Windows were blown out of their frames, staircases up to the 5th Floor were destroyed and the monumental bronze doors on the west side were blown off their hinges. Repairs cost $700,000.
The former Scioto Valley Traction Company becomes the Ohio-Midland Light and Power Company.
Texas & Pacific gains control of Fort Worth Belt.

The Ohio-Midland Light and Power company moves out of the old Scioto Valley Traction Company station at Rich and 3rd streets. The property is torn down in the fall of 1933 and becomes a Gulf Service Station.
The stock market hits bottom with a Times index of 33.98, a decline of over 89% from its high of 311.90 on September 19, 1929.
The Summer Olympics open in Los Angeles, California.
After playing all home games in League Park, the Indians began play at the mammoth new Cleveland Municipal Stadium.
PRR: The first paved road is opened between Altoona and Horseshoe Curve.
The Colorado River is diverted into tunnels around the Hoover Dam work site.
Red Bird Stadium opens on Mound Street. Columbus baseball player Evar Swanson circles the bases in a national record time of 13.3 seconds.
Worthington Women's Club organized.
Adolf Hitler becomes Chancellor of Germany.
Dedication of Barksdale AFB, near Shreveport, LA. It was the world's largest airfiled at 22,000 acres.
RMS Baltic sails to Osaka for scrapping.
Franklin Delano Roosevelt inaugurated as President.

The Nazi Party would win a narrow majority of seats, but only in coalition with the German National People's Party (DNVP). Though this would be the last free election before World War II, it is not considered to be a fair election, as the Nazi Party's paramilitary organizations waged a campaign of violence, censorship, intimidation, and harassment against all parties that opposed them, as well as surveillance of voting on election day itself.

Executive Order 2039 suspends all banking activity for one week, in response to renewed stress on major New York City banks that threatened another round of bank failures and further deepening of the Depression.

The Emergency Banking Act was enacted, which enabled a restructuring of the banking system. Over 4,000 banks with $3.6 billion in deposits that were deemed irreparably insolvent were closed forever, but by March 15th, banks controlling some 90% of the nation's banking activities were back in business. By the end of March, over $1.1 billion in hoarded cash was deposited into the banking system.

Ohio passes the State Liquor Control Act. The initial legislation created the Ohio Liquor Control Board. This agency was to establish regulations that governed the manufacture, the sale, and the distribution of all legal alcoholic beverages.
Much to everyone's relief, when banks reopened for business, depositors stood in line to return their stashed cash to neighborhood banks.
The New York Stock Exchange recorded the largest one-day percentage price increase ever with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 8.26 points to close at 62.10; a gain of 15.34%.
Beer and wine legalized.
Cininnati's Union Terminal opens.
The first recession of the 1930's ends.

The Ohio State Courts building at 65 S. Front St. opens. 14 stories. The Ohio State Library is located inside. This is one of the largest state libraries in the country, and is decorated with murals by artists such as John F. Holmer of Cincinnati, Rudolf Sheffler of New York , H. H. Wessel of Cincinnati, and Leroy Daniel MacMorris of New York. The faade is Georgia marble decorated with various metals, tilework, colored marble, and numerous mosaics and murals. The building is situated in a landscaped setting overlooking the Scioto River, surrounded by pools, lawns, terraces, and foliage.
First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt informed newspaper reporters that beer would be served at the White House.
The airship Akron crashes into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of New Jersey.
The first operation to remove a lung was performed -- at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis, MO.
First concrete poured on Hoover Dam.
The Ohio State Highway Patrol is founded. Patrolmen are required to work 28 consecutive days for their $100 monthly pay.
The Pittsburgh Pirates (later, the Steelers) play their first regular season game, losing to the New York Giants 23-2.
The Philadelphia Eagles play their first regular season game, losing to the New York Giants 56-0.

Ottawa County, Ohio, Probate Judge P.W. Gulau administered the oath of office for 54 “safety conservators,” or patrolmen, six lieutenants, and Capt. Black. The new officers then scattered immediately to their assigned posts.

The Ohio legislature modified the State Liquor Control Act by creating the Department of Liquor Control. This department was to establish and supervise stores operated by the State of Ohio to sell liquor.
At St. Clair Hospital, Dr. William Method becomes the first black doctor in Columbus to receive hospital privileges.
The Jai Lai Cafe opens at 544 N. High St.
OSU: Boyd Lab, 155 W. Woodruff Ave., opens as a Highway Testing Laboratory for the Ohio Department of Transportation.
Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (US bank guarantor) effective.

The first Big Bear Store opened in a large building across from Ohio State University, on Lane Avenue, in what was once a dance hall, a roller skating rink, and finally a tan bark ring for horse shows - the beginning of self service supermarketing in the Midwest. Big Bear Stores was founded in November 1933, in the depths of depression, by Wayne E. Brown, a dynamic individual with his own vision of the future of food distribution and retailing.

The Burlington Zephyr,  with a top reported speed of 114 mph, sets a new speed record for travelling between Denver, Colorado and Chicago when it made the 1,014 mile trip in just 13 hours and five minutes at an average speed of 77 mph.
The Portsmouth, Ohio Spartans football franchise moves to Detroit and is renamed the Lions.
State record 113 F near Gallipolis, 111 F at Hamilton, Wilmington, and Defiance, 109 degrees at Cincinnati, 106 degrees at Columbus. Hundreds dead from heat. Severe drought the entire summer.
Hoover Dam employment peaks at 5,251 employees.
RMS Adriatic sails to Onomichi, Japan for scrapping.
The Detroit Lions play their first regular season game, defeating the New York Giants 9-0.
RMS Queen Mary launched. 81237 tons, 160000 hp, 2139 passengers.
The Detroit Lions play first of traditional Thanksgiving Day home games, losing to the Bears, 19-16, before 26,000.
Several years after becoming the first U.S. department store to sell goods without a down payment, Lazarus becomes the first store to establish a credit union.
The first Big Bear store opens on West Lane Avenue.
White Castle headquarters established in Columbus.
The federal courthouse opens Downtown on the riverfront.
Severe drought dries up area wells.
First Ohio sales tax (3 percent) imposed.
Gold re-valued at $35 per ounce.
1st Sugar Bowl & 1st Orange Bowl.
Eastern Airlines hires Eddie Rickenbacker as GM.
Port Columbus Airport: Foster Lane began his flying service in the Curtiss Flying Service Hangar with a Driggs Skylark III biplane.
Hurricane: Fla. keys: Labor Day Hurricane; 408 deaths.
Hoover Dam Dedicated by President Roosevelt.
The RMS Mauretania is scrapped
The Ohio State Buckeyes lose to Notre Dame 18-13 in the final seconds of a game in Ohio Stadium.
Christmas Day blizzard. Cold weather, which lasted for a couple days, killed 26 people in Ohio.
The RKO Grand opens at 55 E. State St.
Ohio Staters, Inc. is founded as a student service society
OSU: McCracken Power Plant, 304 W. 17th Ave., new smoke stack built.
Columbus Redbird Mike Ryba enters the record book for playing all nine positions on a professional baseball team.

At 8:55 pm the F5-rated "Tupelo Tornado" killed 216 people and injured 700 in Tupelo, Mississippi. Emergency officials turned a movie theater into a makeshift hospital and sterilized instruments with its popcorn machine, according to FEMA.

At 8:27 am the "Gainesville Tornado" was actually a pair of tornadoes that converged in Gainesville, Georgia. The F4-rated twisters killed 203 people and injured 1,600, and destroyed four city blocks and 750 houses.
RMS Queen Mary maiden voyage from Southampton to Cherbourg to New York.
Hottest week on record, 111 F at Paulding, 110 degrees Bowling Green and Van Wert, all-time highs at Columbus (106 degrees) and Toledo (105 degrees).
The Summer Olympics open in Berlin, Germany.
Jesse Owens wins 4 medals at the Berlin Olympics.
First "Script Ohio" performed at Ohio Stadium.
The Hilliard Light and Power Company, New Washington Electric Company and Wyandotte Light and Power Company merge into the Ohio-Midland Light and Power Company.

For 19 days -- from Jan. 18 until Feb. 5 -- the swirling, muddy waters of the Ohio leapt riverbanks and blanketed one-sixth of a city paralyzed by too much rain and snow. The river reached its highest-ever level of 79.9 ft in Cincinnati on this date. An estimated 100,000 people were left homeless. Local damage reached $20 million in 1937 dollars. In Ohio River towns from Pittsburgh to Cairo, Ill., 385 people were killed, 1 million were left homeless and property losses eclipsed the $500 million mark.

Deutsche Zeppelin Reederei Flight LZ 129, the Zeppelin the Hindenburg, bursts into flames and crashes while attempting a landing at Naval Air Engineering Station Lakehurst in New Jersey; of the 97 people on board, 35 are killed as well as one person on the ground.
Comedian George Carlin is born. God winces.
The second recession of the 1930's begins.
First diesel on the Pennsylvania Railroad, EMD class AA-5 #3908 is rated for 600 hp.
The Washington Redskins (formerly, the Boston Redskins) play their first regular season game, defeating the New York Giants 13-3.
The Hobbit by J.R.R. Tolkien is published.
Filling of the Fort Peck reservoir begins.
"Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" by Walt Disney released.
Indianola Park closes. Later replaced by Indianola Shopping Center.
Olentangy Amusement Park is sold to L. L. LaVeque. The park is torn down and replaced with an apartment complex. Rents run from $30 to $50 per month.

Anne O'Hare McCormick was the first woman to win the Pulitzer Prize for foreign correspondence. She freelanced for Atlantic Monthly and the New York Times before becoming a regular New York Times correspondent in 1922. McCormickÕs career spanned the years before and during World War II, so was able to interview leaders like Benito Mussolini, Adolf Hitler, Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin.
The Scioto Ranch amusement park opens across from the Columbus Zoo. The Olentangy Park amusement center closes. Olentangy Park's Grand Carousel is moved to Scioto Ranch.
Lancaster, Ohio ends trolley service - replaced with buses.
The Ohio-Midland Light and Power company moves to a remodeled old passenger and freight station in Canal Winchester.

Bill Moose, who claimed to be the last full-blooded Wyandotte Indian, dies. Bill lived on Morse Rd. just west of the railroad crossing and spent much of his time in Worthington.  There's a large boulder monument in his honor at Lane Road and Rt.33 on the banks of the Scioto river. It says "Bill Moose, last of the Wyandots ......Whose death in 1937 marks the passing of the Indians from this territory"
Samuel and Cornelia Vest Corbin renovate the Central House and re-open it as the New England Inn.
Picasso paints Guernica in protest of the brutal Nazi bombing in Spain.
Indonesia: An 8.5 magnitude earthquake in the Banda Sea generated tsunamis causing great damage on Banda and Kai, volcanic islands in eastern Indonesia.

Worthington's first U.S. government post office building at 597 High Street features "Scioto Company Settler," a terra cotta relief sculptured by Vernon T. Carlock as part of the New Deal's Public Works of Art Project.
The former S.S. Vaterland which became the USS Leviathan in 1917 is sold for scrapping.
The second recession of the 1930's ends.
First Bridgeport Turret Milling Machine shipped, to Precision Castings Corp. of Syracuse, N.Y.
Hurricane: Long Island, N.Y., and southern New England: New England Hurricane; 600 deaths.
The Fort Peck dam on the upper Missouri river in Montanna failed during construction, taking the lives of 8 men, 6 of whom were never found and are entombed in the structure.
RMS Queen Elizabeth launched. 83673 tons, 200000 hp, 2283 passengers.

British prime minister Neville Chamberlain returns from a trip to Munich where he agreed to allow Hitler to annex the Sudetenland in exchange for a promise not to attack Poland. Chamberlain holds up a paper and declares 'Peace for our time".
The former S.S. Imperator is scrapped.
Barney H. Kroger dies at age 78.
Anna Marie Hahn becomes the first woman electrocuted at the Ohio Penitentiary.
Eddie Rickenbacker raises $3 million and purchases Eastern Airlines.
Olentangy Park is sold to L. L. LaVeque, and was turned into the Olentangy Village apartment complex. Today the only reminder of the park is the swimming pool at Olentangy Village.
"Block O" cheering section established
Deluth & Iron Range and Deluth, Missabe & Northern merge creating Deluth, Missabe & Iron Range.
Last interurban passenger service in Columbus.
The Toledo & Ohio Central, which was leased to the New York Central, now is merged with the New York Central.
Artist Ben Shahn photographs Worthington and Linworth as part of the Farm Security Administration project to document rural life in the U.S. during the Great Depression.
Worthington Junior High School, the town's first intermediate school, opens in a $190,000 "colonial style" building at 50 E. Granville Rd.
John W. Bricker inaugurated Governor of Ohio
Eileen Foley is born.
Nazis take Czechoslovakia.
Spanish Civil war ends.
Glenn Miller recorded his theme song, "Moonlight Serenade", for Bluebird Records. Previously, the Miller theme had been "Gone with the Dawn" and, before then, "Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep".
Nazis sign 'Pact of Steel' with Italy.
Nazis and Soviets sign peace treaty.
Britain and Poland sign a Mutual Assistance Treaty.
British fleet mobilizes; Civilian evacuations begin from London.
Germany invades Poland
Britain, France, Australia and New Zealand declare war on Germany.
British Royal Air Force attacks the German Navy.
Ludwig Bemelmens' childrens book "Madeline" is published.
United States proclaims neutrality; German troops cross the Vistula River in Poland.
Canada declares war on Germany; Battle of the Atlantic begins.
Soviets invade Poland.
Warsaw surrendors to Nazis.
The former S.S. Bismarck, now the British HMS Majestic, caught fire at the dock and sank.
Nazis and Soviets divide up Poland.
Nazis begin "Euthenasia" on sick and disabled in Germany.
Assassination attempt on Hitler fails.
Soviets attack Finland.
Soviet Union expelled from the League of Nations.
Alex Campbell is born in Honolulu, HI
Lazarus dedicates its State Street service building - including an employee recreation center, increasing the company complex to more than 761,000 square feet.
Clintonville Electric opens for business to sell General Electric appliances.
First television broadcast demonstration in Columbus.
OSU: Post Office Addition added to the Journalism Building, 141 W. 18th Ave.
The sports scene includes the Columbus Rainbows, a new roller-derby team.
Worthington Foods is established by the Seventh Day Adventists as a vegetarian food processing facility.
Rationing begins in Britain.
Jack William Nicklaus born in Columbus
Howard Landis Bevis appointed President of The Ohio State University
Colonial Hills Model Home opens to the public at 36 East Southington Ave.
Finland signs a peace treaty with Soviets.
Germans bomb Scapa Flow naval base near Scotland.
RMS Queen Elizabeth maiden voyage from Southampton to Cherbourg to New York.
Nazis invade Denmark and Norway.
Nazis invade France, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands; Winston Churchill becomes British Prime Minister.
Holland surrenders to the Nazis.
Evacuation of Allied troops from Dunkirk begins.
Belgium surrenders to the Nazis.
Germans bomb Paris; Dunkirk evacuation ends.
Norway surrenders to the Nazis; Italy declares war on Britain and France.
Germans enter Paris.
Marshal Petain becomes French Prime Minister.
Hitler and Mussolini meet in Munich; Soviets begin occupation of the Baltic States.
The first large-scale bombing attack on Britain was at night, when small raids scattered between Yorkshire and Kent involved in total 100 bombers
France signs an armistice with the Nazis.
Hitler tours Paris.
Britain recognizes Gen. Charles de Gaulle as the Free French leader.
German U-boats attack merchant ships in the Atlantic.
The first daylight bombing raids of Britain by Germany in Hull in Yorkshire and Wick, Caithness
French Vichy government breaks off relations with Britain.
Hitler's popularity in Germany reaches its zenith as war fever sweeps Germany.
The Blitz bombing of London begins. London will be bombed for 56 of the next 57 days.
London is hit with a large daylight bombing attack.
Hitler plans Operation Sealion (the invasion of Britain).
Soviets take Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.
Kathleen Fisher is born.
Italians occupy British Somaliland in East Africa.
18 coal ships and 4 destroyers have been sunk so far by German airplanes in British coastal waters.
German bombing offensive, operation Aldertag, against airfields and factories in England. The Germans are ineffective at knocking out coastal radars.
Air battles and daylight raids over Britain as operation Aldertag nears its zenith.
Hitler declares a blockade of the British Isles.

"The Hardest Day" as losses on both sides of the air battle peak. Luftwaffe units flew a total of 970 sorties and lost 71 aircraft. The British flew 927 sorties and lost 31 fighters and 28 aircraft on the ground.

Göring ordered attacks on aircraft factories. Sixty raids on the night of 19/20 August targeted the aircraft industry and harbours, and bombs fell on suburban areas around London: Croydon, Wimbledon and the Maldens.
First German air raids on Central London.
Britain is now losing fighters and pilots faster than they can be replaced.

First British air raid on Berlin. 81 bombers of Bomber Command were sent out to raid industrial and commercial targets in Berlin. Clouds prevented accurate identification and the bombs fell across the city, causing some casualties among the civilian population as well as damage to residential areas.
Mobile & Ohio and Gulf, Mobile & Northern merge creating Gulf, Mobile & Ohio.
On this day only, the Germans destroy more aircraft than they lost. Losses were 325 German and 248 British.
In a public speech, Hitler condemned the bombing of Berlin and presented the planned attacks on London as reprisals.
Britains figher losses fall below those of production and remain so for the rest of the war.
The German Blitz against Englands cities begins.
Passenger liner SS Kronprinzessin Cecilie, renamed the USS Mt. Vernon, is scrapped.
Italians invade Egypt.

Massive German air raids on London, Southampton, Bristol, Cardiff, Liverpool and Manchester. Two massive waves of German attacks were decisively repulsed by the RAF by deploying every aircraft in 11 Group. Sixty German and twenty-six RAF aircraft were shot down. The action was the climax of the Battle of Britain. 9/15 is known as "Battle of Britain Day"
United States military conscription bill passed.
Hitler postpones operation Sea Lion indefinately (the invasion of Britain) as Luftwaffe losses mount over Britain.
Tripartite (Axis) Pact signed by Germany, Italy and Japan.
Enrollment at Ohio State University exceeds 17,000 for the first time
German troops enter Romania.
The Fort Peck dam on the upper Missouri river in Montanna is completed.
Germans postpone Operation Sealion until Spring of 1941.
Italy invades Greece.
The RAF fields 1,796 pilots, an increase of over 40% from July 1940's count of 1,259 pilots. German bomber strength peaks at 1,423 level bombers.
Roosevelt re-elected as U.S. president.
A torpedo bomber raid cripples the Italian fleet at Taranto, Italy.
57 men died when three freighters sank in Lake Michigan.

Mild weather ahead of an intense low pressure system tracking from Kansas to western Wisconsin was quickly followed by a raging blizzard. Many people were caught off-guard by the severity of the storm and particularly the plunging temperatures. Sixty degree temperatures during the morning of November 11 were followed by single-digit readings by the morning of November 12. These very cold temperatures and snow amounts were very unusual for this early in the season. Up to 26 inches of snow fell in Minnesota, while winds of 50 to 80 mph and heavy snows were common over parts of the states of Wisconsin, South Dakota, Nebraska, Minnesota, Iowa and Michigan. These winds were responsible for whipping up 20 foot drifts. A total of 144 deaths were blamed on the storm, most of which were duck hunters along the Mississippi River.
Germans bomb Coventry, England.
Hungary joins the Axis Powers.
Greeks defeat the Italian 9th Army.
Romania joins the Axis Powers.
British begin a western desert offensive in North Africa against the Italians.

Hitler authorizes a plan to invade the Soviet Union. Originally called "Operation Otto", it is eventually called "Operation Barbarosa". The operation stemmed from Nazi Germany's ideological aims to conquer the western Soviet Union so that it could be repopulated by Germans, to use Slavs as a slave-labour force for the Axis war effort, and to seize the oil reserves of the Caucasus and the agricultural resources of Soviet territories.
One of the largest single raids in the bombing of British cities, in which almost 3,000 civilians died.
Massive German air raid on London.
Riverside Auto Theater opens as the first drive-in theater.
Clinton School adds an annex building to house High School students.
Poindexter Village, the first U.S. metropolitan housing project, dedicated by President Roosevelt.
OSU: Baker Hall dormitory, 93 and 129 West 12th Ave, opens.
OSU: Larkins Hall, 337 W. 17th Ave., addition adds Library space to the South Side.
OSU: Lord Hall, 124 W. 17th Ave., as part of a W.P.A. project a lab space addition is made.
Passenger liner SS Kaiser Wilhelm II, renamed USS Agamemnon in 1917, is scrapped.
The Ohio State University golf course opens.
Tobruk in North Africa falls to the British and Australians.
British forces advance into Italian Somaliland in East Africa.
German General Erwin Rommel arrives in Tripoli, North Africa.
First units of German 'Afrika Korps' arrive in North Africa.
Eastern Air Lines Flight 21 crashes while descending to land at Atlanta, Georgia killing 16 of 25 aboard; World War I hero and Eastern Air Lines president Eddie Rickenbacker is among the survivors.
British forces arrive in Greece.
William Foley is born.
President Roosevelt signs the Lend-Lease Act.
A coup in Yugoslavia overthrows the pro-Axis government.
Germans relocate aircraft to the front with Russia and the Blitz tails off.
The first contract for advertising on a commercial FM radio station began on W71NY in New York City.

The El Rancho Las Vegas opens on 57 acres of land with a simple sign lifted on stone pillars advertising the new resort. A neon-lit windmill was located on top of the casino. "Stop at the Sign of the Windmill" was one of its slogans. Added was a gas station to encourage people to stop. The El Rancho Vegas inaugurated the winning combination of gambling, dining, entertainment and vacation amenities that has become the basis of the casino gaming industry.
Pro-Axis regime set up in Iraq.
Nazis invade Greece and Yugoslavia.
USS North Carolina BB-55 commissioned.
Rommel attacks Tobruk.
Yugoslavia surrenders to the Nazis.
Greece surrenders to the Nazis.
German attack on Tobruk is repulsed.
Deputy Fuer Rudolph Hess flies to Scotland.
Heavy German bombing of London; British bomb Hamburg.
USS Washington BB-56 commissioned.
Operation Brevity begins (the British counter-attack in Egypt).
Sinking of the British ship Hood by the Bismarck.
Sinking of the Bismarck by the British Navy.
Pro-Allied government installed in Iraq.
Allies invade Syria and Lebanon.
Harlan Fiske Stone is elevated from Associate Justice to Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
United States freezes German and Italian assets in America.
Germany attacks the Soviet Union as Operation Barbarossa begins.
Germans capture Minsk.
Nazi SS Einsatzgruppen begin mass murder.
Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes of the United States Supreme Court retires.
Stalin finally speaks to the Russian people, and calls for a scorched earth policy.
Germans cross the River Dnieper in the Ukraine.
Mutual Assistance agreement between British and Soviets.
British occupy Syria.
Roosevelt freezes Japanese assets in United States and suspends relations.
Gring instructs Heydrich to prepare for the Final Solution.
Abandoned Scioto Valley Traction Company power house at Rees is torn down.
United States announces an oil embargo against aggressor states.
Production of Model T engines ceases at Ford Motor Co.
Roosevelt and Churchill announce the Atlantic Charter.
Nazi siege of Leningrad begins.
The Battle of Yelnya is the first Red Army victory since the Germans invaded Russia in June.
Nazis order Jews to wear yellow stars.
First experimental use of gas chambers at Auschwitz.
The Red Army takes Yelnya.
Nazis take Kiev.
Fire destroys the tipple and loading machinery at the Worthington Coal Co. On the same day, a 250 acre grass fire roars through Colonial Hills.
Nazis murder 33,771 Jews at Kiev.
Operation Typhoon begins (German advance on Moscow).
Stalin ordered the evacuation of the Communist Party, the General Staff and various civil government offices from Moscow to Kuibyshev  Samara), leaving only a limited number of officials behind.
Germans take Odessa.
"Dumbo" by Walt Disney released.
Germans take Kharkov.
Germans reach Sevastopol.
The Wehrmacht stops its offensive against Moscow to resupply and wait for the muddy roads to improve.
Second diesel on the Pennsylvania Railroad, EMD #3909 is rated for 1000 hp.
Red Army Troops perform the traditional military parade through Moscow, marching directly to the front after.
British aircraft carrier Ark Royal is sunk off Gibraltar by a U-boat.
The Wehrmacht resumes its offensive against Moscow because the ground is frozen, resolving the mud problem.
Germans take Rostov.
The Germans take Stalinogorsk, south of Moscow.
The Germans take Klin, north of Moscow.
The Germans take Solnechnogorsk, north of Moscow but south of Klin.

German tanks approached Kashira, a city controlling a major highway to Moscow from the south. In response, a Soviet counterattack was launched the following day. General Belov's 2nd Cavalry Corps, supported by hastily assembled formations, which included 173rd Rifle Division, 9th Tank Brigade, two separate tank battalions, and training and militia units,[62] halted the German advance near Kashira.

The German 7th Panzer Division seized a bridgehead across the Moscow-Volga Canal—the last major obstacle before Moscow—and stood less than 35 km (22 mi) from the Kremlin, but a powerful counterattack by the 1st Shock Army drove them back.
Russia drains reservoirs around Moscow, flooding 30 - 40 villages, in hopes of breaking up ice on the Volga river to prevent the Germans from crossing it.

Because of the resistance on both the northern and southern sides of Moscow, the Wehrmacht attempted a direct offensive from the west along the Minsk-Moscow highway near the city of Naro-Fominsk. This offensive had limited tank support and was directed against extensive Soviet defenses. After meeting determined resistance from the Soviet 1st Guards Motorized Rifle Division and flank counterattacks staged by the 33rd Army, the German offensive stalled and was driven back four days later in the ensuing Soviet counteroffensive.

A German reconnaissance battalion came to the town of Khimki—some 30 km (19 mi) away from the Kremlin in central Moscow reaching its bridge over the Moscow-Volga Canal as well as its railway station. This marked the closest approach of German forces to Moscow.
German attack on Moscow is abandoned.
Soviet Army launches a major counter-offensive around Moscow.
The cornerstone is laid for Maple Grove United Methodist Church in Clintonville.
Hitler issues the Night and Fog decree. Suspected underground agents and others would now vanish without a trace into the night and fog.
The Japanese attack Pearl Harbor

Hitler signed his directive No.39, ordering the Wehrmacht to assume a defensive stance on the whole Russian front. German troops were unable to organize a solid defense at their present locations and were forced to pull back to consolidate their lines.
United States and Britain declare war on Japan.
Germany declares war on the United States.
Russia retakes Solnechnogorsk north of Moscow.
Russia retakes Klin north of Moscow.
Rommel begins a retreat to El Agheila in North Africa.

Furious that his army had been unable to take Moscow, Hitler dismissed his commander-in-chief, Walther von Brauchitsch and takes personal command of the German Army. Hitler surrounded himself with staff officers with little or no recent combat experience.
Hitler cancelled the withdrawal of the Wehrmacht in Russia and ordered his soldiers to defend every patch of ground, "digging trenches with howitzer shells if needed.

Hitler dismisses Heinz Guderian, commander of the 2nd Panzer Group in Russia, along with 40 other generals. He was transferred to the reserve pool. Guderian held hard feelings on the matter against Field Marshal Günther von Kluge, the commander of Army Group Centre, who he felt had failed to support him.

Air Force Plant # 85 was constructed for $14 million in 1941 in Columbus, Ohio under the sponsorship of the Defense Plant Corporation (DPC). During World War II, the plant employed over 24,000 people and produced over 3,500 naval aircraft under contracts with Curtiss-Wright Corp.
Ohio's first FM radio station (W45CM) begins operating in Columbus.

To lengthen the holiday shopping season, Fred Lazarus Jr., grandson of Simon Lazarus, launches a campaign to move Thanksgiving to the fourth Thursday in November. The idea is supported by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Construction begins on Lockbourne Air Force Base.
The first parking meters appear on Columbus streets.
OSU: Converse Hall, 221 Tuttle Park Pl, opens as a Military Shop & Classroom Facility.
Cloyd Acton, a Preble County legislator, influenced the state legislature to buy the primevil Hueston Woods. This later became Hueston Woods State Park.
Upper Arlington achieves city status.
Declaration of the United Nations signed by 26 Allied nations.
Rose Bowl played in North Carolina due to Japanese threat-Oregon 20, Duke 16.
Germans begin a U-boat offensive along east coast of USA.
SS Leader Heydrich holds the Wannsee Conference to coordinate the "Final Solution of the Jewish Question."
Rommel's counter-offensive from El Agheila begins.
First American forces arrive in Great Britain.
All civilian auto production stops.
Martha Dale Patty is born in Independence, Kansas.
USS South Dakota BB-57 commissioned.
Puu Kukui in Hawaii recorded nearly 9 feet (101 inches) of rainfall, which stands as the greatest precipitation total ever recorded in one month in the United States.
Glenn Miller and his orchestra recorded "American Patrol" for Victor Records. The jitterbug tune became one of Miller's most requested hits.
The General Electric I-A jet engine runs for the first time producing 1250 lb of thrust. It is the first jet engine to operate in America. Based on the British Whittle engine.
USS Indiana BB-58 commissioned.
A bathtub is cast on this day which will be installed in the new house at 554 Kenbrook Drive, Worthington, OH 43085
German air raids begin against cathedral cities in Britain.
Bath is bombed.
Japanese-Americans sent to relocation centers.
German summer offensive begins in the Crimea.
USS Massachusetts BB-59 commissioned.
Rommel begins an offensive against the Gazala Line.
Fort Peck reservoir reaches minimum operating level.
SS Leader Heydrich attacked in Prague.
First thousand bomber British air raid (against Cologne).
Battle of Midway
Heydrich dies of wounds.
Germans besiege Sevastopol.
Nazis liquidate Lidice in reprisal for Heydrich's assassination.

PRR: Four highly trained Nazi saboteurs came ashore to Long Island from a submarine, and a few nights later, four more landed in Florida. Within 2 weeks the FBI has siezed all eight, along with large amounts of explosives and $100,000 in cash. Among their 12 targets were aircraft and aluminum plants and key railroad installations such as bridges, Penn Station in New York and Horseshoe Curve. With its military value now openly acknowledged, the Curve was fenced off and placed under 24 hour guard.
Production begins at the Ford Willow Run airplane factory.
Rommel captures Tobruk.
Eisenhower arrives in London.
Rommel reaches El Alamein near Cairo, Egypt.
OSU Trustees purchase land for a new airport.
Mass murder of Jews by gassing begins at Auschwitz.
First Battle of El Alamein.
Germans take Sevastopol.
Soviet resistance in the Crimea ends.
Germans begin a drive toward Stalingrad in the USSR.
In northwest Pennsylvania, the town of Smethport recorded nearly 3 feet of rain (34.30 inches) in just 12 hours. This is the biggest 12-hour rainfall total in United States history.
First deportations from the Warsaw Ghetto to concentration camps; Treblinka extermination camp opened.
British General Bernard Montgomery takes command of Eighth Army in North Africa.

After a hearing before a military commission, six of the eight Nazi saboteurs who arrived on June 13, 1942, were executed. The other two received long prison sentences in exchange for their testimony.
Stalin and Churchill meet in Moscow.
"Bambi" by Walt Disney released.
USS Alabama BB-60 commissioned.
First all-American air attack in Europe.
Massive German air raid on Stalingrad.
Rommel driven back by Montgomery in the Battle of Alam Halfa.
Construction of the Pentagon begins.
Battle of Stalingrad begins.
Hitler orders the execution of all captured British commandos.
The Alaska Highway is officially completed, although it will take until 1943 before it is open to general traffic.

The Hotel Last Frontier opens, and is the first truly "themed" casino that encouraged patrons to lose themselves in a fantasy world of Old West nostalgia while vacationing and gambling within the casino.
Operation Supercharge (Allies break Axis lines at El Alamein).
The first airplane lands at Ohio State's new airport.
Operation Torch begins (U.S. invasion of North Africa).
Germans and Italians invade unoccupied Vichy France.
Soviet counter-offensive at Stalingrad begins.
A fire at the Cocoanut Grove nightclub in Boston clamed a total of 492 lives (which was 32 more than the building's authorized capacity) and injuring hundreds more.
Professor Enrico Fermi sets up an atomic reactor in Chicago.
Rommel withdraws from El Agheila.
Soviets defeat Italian troops on the River Don in the USSR.
British Foreign Secretary Eden tells the British House of Commons of mass executions of Jews by Nazis; U.S. declares those crimes will be avenged.
Battle of the Barents Sea between German and British ships.
Cocoanut Grove fire survivers are the first burn patients to be treated with the new drug penicillin.
Ohio State's airport designated a Naval Aviation Cadet Training Center
The Pennsylvania Railroad outshops its first J1 class locomotive, #6450 at Altoona.
Duke Ellington performs in the Palace Theatre.
The Alcorn Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat Hospital closes. It was the first of its kind in Columbus.
The last Downtown Sears Roebuck store closes.
OSU: Converse Hall, 221 Tuttle Park Pl, adds 2nd and 3rd floors. Serves as a Military Shop & Classroom Facility.
Gasoline, sugar and coffee rationing begins.
Colonial Hills and Dales subdivision is platted south of Worthington with restrictive covenants prohibiting African Americans. A number of its first homes were occupied by Curtiss Wright workers.
Worthington Women's Club commissions four wrought iron markers that stand at the boundary of the original village.
Germans begin a withdrawal from the Caucasus.
Soviets begin an offensive against the Germans in Stalingrad.
Casablanca conference between Churchill and Roosevelt. During the conference, Roosevelt announces the war can end only with an unconditional German surrender.
Montgomery's Eighth Army takes Tripoli.
First bombing raid by Americans on Germany (at Wilhelmshaven).
Germans surrender at Stalingrad in the first big defeat of Hitler's armies.
Soviet troops take Kursk.
Battle of Kasserine Pass between the U.S. 1st Armored Division and German Panzers in North Africa.
Soviets re-take Kharkov.
Nazis arrest White Rose resistance leaders in Munich.
Battleship Iowa BB-61 commissioned
Germans begin a withdrawal from Tunisia, Africa.
Germans re-capture Kharkov.
Battle of Atlantic climaxes with 27 merchant ships sunk by German U-boats.
Montgomery's Eighth Army breaks through the Mareth Line in Tunisia.
Axis forces in Tunisia begin a withdrawal toward Enfidaville as American and British forces link.
Waffen SS attacks Jewish resistance in the Warsaw ghetto.
Allies take Tunisia.
Surrender of Axis Forces in North Africa
German and Italian troops surrender in North Africa.
British air raid on the Ruhr.
Jewish resistance in the Warsaw ghetto ends.
Dnitz suspends U-boat operations in the North Atlantic.
Battleship New Jersey BB-62 commissioned
Edsel Ford dies from stomach cancer.
Pointblank' directive to improve Allied bombing strategy issued.
Himmler orders the liquidation of all Jewish ghettos in Poland.
Germans begin their last offensive against Kursk.
Allies land in Sicily.
Allies bomb Rome.
Americans capture Palermo, Sicily.
British bombing raid on Hamburg.
Mussolini arrested and the Italian Fascist government falls; Marshal Pietro Badoglio takes over and negotiates with Allies.
Allied air raid causes a firestorm in Hamburg.

A rainfall total of 13.80 inches was estimated to have fallen near Burnsville, WV over the course of just one hour. A total of 23 people were killed by the floods, and numerous homes were swept away. Damage estimates at the time were around $1.3 million.
Germans evacuate Sicily.
American daylight air raids on Regensburg and Schweinfurt in Germany; Allies reach Messina, Sicily.
Soviet troops recapture Kharkov.
Italian surrender is announced.
Allied landings at Salerno and Taranto.
Germans occupy Rome.
Germans rescue Mussolini.
Mussolini re-establishes a Fascist government.
Allies enter Naples, Italy.
Italy declares war on Germany; Second American air raid on Schweinfurt.
OSU Trustees name Ohio State's new Airport Don Scott field after a football star who died in combat.
Russians recapture Kiev in the Ukraine.
Large British air raid on Berlin.
Roosevelt, Churchill, Stalin meet at Teheran.
Soviets launch offensives on the Ukrainian front.

Colossus Mark I computer in operation at Bletchley Park near Milton Keynes in Buckinghamshire. Colossus used thermionic valves (vacuum tubes) to perform Boolean and counting operations. Colossus is thus regarded as the world's first programmable, electronic, digital computer, although it was programmed by switches and plugs and not by a stored program.
Henry Ford II, recently released as an ensign from the U.S. Navy, is made an Executive Vice President at Ford.
First civilian use of penicillin at Doctor's Hospital.
OSU: Johnston Lab, 176 W. 19th Ave., opens as the War Research Laboratory.
Meat, cheese and butter rationing begin.
Soviet troops advance into Poland.
First attack toward Cassino, Italy.
Allies land at Anzio.
Leningrad relieved after a 900-day siege.
Allies bomb the monastery at Monte Cassino.
Germans counter-attack against the Anzio beachhead.
Soviet troops begin an offensive on the Belorussian front; First major daylight bombing raid on Berlin by the Allies.
Second Allied attempt to capture Monte Cassino begins.
British drop 3000 tons of bombs during an air raid on Hamburg, Germany.
Soviet troops begin an offensive to liberate Crimea.
Battleship USS Wisconsin BB-64 commissioned
Soviet troops recapture Sevastopol.
Allies attack the Gustav Line south of Rome.
Germans surrender in the Crimea.
Germans withdraw to the Adolf Hitler Line.
Germans retreat from Anzio.
Allies enter Rome.
D-Day landings.
Soviet offensive against the Finnish front begins.
Nazis liquidate the town of Oradour-sur-Glane in France.
Battleship USS Missouri BB-63 commissioned
First German V-1 rocket attack on Britain.
Operation Bagration begins (the Soviet summer offensive).
W.Va., Pa., Md.: 4 tornadoes caused 153 deaths.
U.S. troops liberate Cherbourg.
Battle of the Hedgerows' in Normandy; Soviets capture Minsk.

In Hartford, CT  one hundred sixty-seven people died as a result of a Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey circus blaze, which broke out while several thousand were under the big top for an afternoon performance. Flames spread instantly along the canvas of the tent, since it had been waterproofed with a mixture of gasoline and paraffin.
British and Canadian troops capture Caen.
U.S. troops reach St. L.
German assassination attempt on Hitler fails.
Soviet troops liberate first concentration camp at Majdanek.
Operation Cobra (U.S. troops break out west of St. L).
Soviet troops take Brest-Litovsk. U.S. troops take Coutances.
Polish Home Army uprising against Nazis in Warsaw begins; U.S. troops reach Avranches.
Anne Frank and family arrested by the Gestapo in Amsterdam, Holland.
Germans begin a major counter-attack toward Avranches.
Operation Dragoon begins (the Allied invasion of Southern France).
Resistance uprising in Paris.
Soviet offensive in the Balkans begins with an attack on Romania.
Allies encircle Germans in the Falaise Pocket.
Liberation of Paris.
Slovak uprising begins.
Soviet troops take Bucharest.
Verdun, Dieppe, Artois, Rouen, Abbeville, Antwerp and Brussels liberated by Allies.
Finland and the Soviet Union agree to a cease-fire.
Hurricane: N.C. to New England: 390 deaths, 344 of which were at sea.
U.S. troops reach the Siegfried Line.
Operation Market Garden begins (Allied airborne assault on Holland).
Soviet troops occupy Estonia.
Warsaw Uprising ends as the Polish Home Army surrenders to the Germans.
Soviet troops capture Riga.
Allies liberate Athens; Rommel commits suicide.
30 blocks of Cleveland OH burn after a liquid gas factory explodes.
Diocese of Steubenville carved out of Diocese of Columbus.
Massive German surrender at Aachen.
Last use of gas chambers at Auschwitz.
Michael Joseph Ready appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.
French troops drive through the 'Beffort Gap' to reach the Rhine.
French capture Strasbourg.
Civil War in Greece; Athens placed under martial law.
Battle of the Bulge in the Ardennes begins.
Waffen SS murder 81 U.S. POWs at Malmedy.
Patton relieves Bastogne.
Battle of the Bulge in the Ardennes ends.
Soviet troops besiege Budapest.
First Ohio shipment of penicillin arrives in Columbus.
The administration of then Columbus Mayor James A. Rhodes purchased the 161 acre Miller farm for $75,000. The future site of Whetstone Park.
Les Horvath, Ohio State Back, wins the Heisman trophy.
United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference at Bretton Woods, NH., charters IMF.
Germans withdraw from the Ardennes.
U.S. 1st and 3rd Armies link up after a month long separation during the Battle of the Bulge.
Soviet troops capture Warsaw.
Soviet troops liberate Auschwitz.

The MV Wilhelm Gustloff was sunk by Soviet submarine S-13 in the Baltic Sea while evacuating German civilians, killing 9,400 people of the estimated 10,600 on board, which makes it the largest loss of life in a single ship sinking in history.
5,000th Bridgeport Miller sold (Machinery Sales of Calif.)
Roosevelt, Churchill, Stalin meet at Yalta.

The SS General von Steuben was torpedoed by the Soviet submarine S-13 in the Baltic during Operation Hannibal and sunk. It has been estimated there were around 4,000 deaths, including 2,600 wounded German soldiers.
Dresden is destroyed by a firestorm after Allied bombing raids.
Last German offensive of the war begins to defend oil fields in Hungary.

Ohio River floods. The Mill Creek barrier dam failed, sending Ohio River water up the already flooded valley. Northern Kentucky counted 12,000 people homeless. Portsmouth fought a losing battle to erect a levee.
Allies take Cologne and establish a bridge across the Rhine at Remagen.
Soviet troops capture Danzig.
Ohio State University offers its first flight training at Don Scott airport.
U.S. troops encircle Germans in the Ruhr; Allied offensive in North Italy.
Harry S. Truman inaugurated as President.
Allies liberate Buchenwald and Belsen concentration camps; President Roosevelt dies. Truman becomes President.
Metro Parks is established.
Soviet troops begin their final attack on Berlin; Americans enter Nuremberg.
German forces in the Ruhr surrender.
Soviets reach Berlin.
Mussolini is captured and hanged by Italian partisans; Allies take Venice.
U.S. 7th Army liberates Dachau.
Adolf Hitler commits suicide.
Allies discover stolen Nazi art and wealth hidden in salt mines.
German troops in Italy surrender.
Unconditional surrender of all German forces to Allies.

V.E. Day. Governor Frank J. Lausche orders "liquor places" closed for 24 hours. Downtown stores, offices and restaurants close. The Downtown celebration is described as "tame" compared with the 1918 Armistice.
Hermann Goring is captured by members of the U.S. 7th Army.
SS Reichsfuhrer Himmler commits suicide; German High Command and Provisional Government imprisoned.
A fan trip using an old freight motor was taken on the Scioto Valley Traction Company.
Allies divide up Germany and Berlin and take over the government.
United Nations Charter is signed in San Francisco.
U.S., British, and French troops move into Berlin.
Colonial Hills Civic Association hosts its first Fourth of July celebration.
First atomic bomb is exploded in New Mexico and yields 19 kilotons.
Potsdam Conference begins.
Atlee succeeds Churchill as British Prime Minister.
First atomic bomb dropped, on Hiroshima, Japan.
Soviets declares war on Japan and invade Manchuria.
Second atomic bomb dropped, on Nagasaki, Japan.
Japanese agree to unconditional surrender.
V.J. Day. WW II ends. 20,000 Ohio serviceman and twenty Worthington area men died in the war.
Japanese sign the surrender agreement;  V-J (Victory over Japan) Day.
Henry Ford II becomes the president of Ford Motor Company, succeeding his grandfather Henry Ford.
United Nations is officially born.
Sharon Township voters approve a five-year levy to support a war memorial.
Nuremberg war crimes trials begin.

ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer) is the first electronic general-purpose computer at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. It is Turing-complete, digital and able to solve "a large class of numerical problems" through reprogramming.
The first diesel passenger engines are introduced on the Pennsylvania Railroad, E7 units #5900-5901.
The Ohio-Midland Light and Power Company becomes the Ohio-Midland Rural Electric Corporation.
WWII ends, U.S. Public debt is $258.68 billions, IMF is instituted, World Bank founded.
Atlanta, Birmingham & Coast merged into Atlantic Coast Line.
The Allies recognize the Austrian republic with its 1937 borders, and divide the country into four occupation zones.
The first meeting of the United Nations is held, at Methodist Central Hall Westminster in London.

Project Diana bounces radar waves off the Moon, measuring the exact distance between the Earth and the Moon, and proves that communication is possible between Earth and outer space, effectively opening the Space Age.
Enver Hoxha declares the people's republic of Albania with himself as dictator.
Charles de Gaulle resigns as head of the French provisional government.
The United Nations Security Council holds its first session, at Church House, Westminster in London.
The Bell XS-1 is test flown for the first time (unpowered), with Bell's chief test pilot Jack Woolams at the controls.
Charles De Gaulle resigns from the post of French president.
The Bell X-1 (XS-1) makes its first flight.
The United Mine Workers rejoins the American Federation of Labor.

St. Michael, the first and only Catholic parish in Worthington, was established by Bishop Michael J. Ready, with Reverend John P. Byrne as it Pastor. Bishop Ready realigned parish boundaries of Immaculate Conception to form St. Michael and Our Lady of Peace parishes.
Yugoslavia's new constitution, modeling the Soviet Union, establishes six constituent republics (Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia).
The Kingdom of Hungary becomes a republic, heavily influenced by the Soviet Union.
Trygve Lie of Norway is picked to be the first United Nations Secretary General.
The first Mass was held in the seminary chapel of the Pontifical Seminary Josephinum. 128 parishioners attended the first Mass
ENIAC (for "Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer"), the first general-purpose electronic computer, is unveiled at the University of Pennsylvania.
Canada indicts 22 communist agents.
Juan Peron is elected a president of Argentina.
In Philadelphia, General Electric strikers and police clash.
Ho Chi Minh is elected the President of North Vietnam.
In his speech in Fulton, Missouri, Winston Churchill talks about the Iron Curtain.
Ho Chi Minh signs an agreement with France which recognizes Vietnam as an autonomous state in the Indochinese Federation and the French Union.
Clement Attlee promises independence to India as soon as they can agree on constitution.

Winston Churchill visits Columbus with Harry S. Truman. In a speech before the Federal Council of Churches of Christ, Truman talks about the importance of spirituality in the atomic age. Churchill discusses postwar problems and American financial aid to Britain.
A 14-meter high tsunami strikes Hilo, Hawaii - 173 dead, thousands injured.
Japanese Lt. General Masaharu Homma is executed outside Manila in the Philippines for leading the Bataan Death March.
In Japan, women vote for the first time in parliamentarian elections.
The League of Nations has its last meeting. It transfers its financial reserves, building in Geneva and archives to the United Nations.
War crimes trial begins in Tokyo - accused include Hideki Tojo, Shegenori Togo and Hiroshi Oshima.

St. Michael's Parish purchases the Chase Mansion on the east side of North High Street, immediately north of Selby Boulevard. The stately old mansion was converted into a combination church, school, and rectory.
Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering (later renamed Sony) is founded with about 20 employees.
In a referendum Italians decide to turn Italy from a monarchy into a Republic. After this referendum the king of Italy Umberto II di Savoia was exiled. Women vote for the first time.
The Basketball Association of America is formed in New York City.
Donald J. Trump is born at the Jamaica Hospital in the borough of Queens, New York City.
Fred Vinson takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
A B-29 drops a 21 kt atomic bomb over ships anchored in Bikinia Atoll for test Able.  Part of Operation Crossroads and the first nuclear test in the Pacific.
After over 400 years, the Philippines achieves full independence.
The bikini is introduced.
Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini becomes the first American saint to be canonized.
Chief Justice Harlan Fiske Stone of the United States Supreme Court dies in office.
King David Hotel bombing: Irgun Zvai Leumi bombs King David Hotel in Jerusalem, headquarters of the British civil and military administration killing 90.

Nuclear testing: In the first underwater test of the atomic bomb, the surplus USS Saratoga is sunk near Bikini Atoll in the Pacific Ocean when the United States detonates the 21 kt "Baker Day" device 90 feet underwater.
At Club 500 in Atlantic City, New Jersey, Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis stage their first show as a comedy team.
Baker nuclear explosion at Bikini Atoll. First underwater detonation of an atomic bomb. Part of Operation Crossroads.
The Dumont Television network goes on the air.
Father John Byrne and two Joliet Franciscan sisters opened Saint Michael Elementary School at 64 East Selby Blvd with forty-four pupils in attendance.

The All-America Football Conference begins regular season play as the Cleveland Browns beat the Miami Seahawks 44-0 before 60,135 at Cleveland's Municipal Stadium. The Browns, coached by future Hall of Famer Paul Brown, go on to a 12-2 record and win the first of their four AAFC championships before four of the league's teams join the NFL in 1950.
The Los Angeles Rams (formerly, the Cleveland Rams since 1936) play their first regular season game, losing to the Philadelphia Eagles 25-14.

Mensa, an international organization for people with a high intelligence quotient (IQ), is founded by Roland Berrill, an Australian-born lawyer, and Dr Lancelot Ware, an English biochemist and lawyer, in Oxford.

A Berlin-bound 4 engine Douglas C-54 named 'Flagship New England' crashed into a mountainside outside of Stephenville, Newfoundland and Labrador. The flight, operated by American Overseas Airlines, was carrying many wives and children of US Army personnel serving in post-war Germany. All 39 people on board died. At the time, it was the worst accident of its kind among US civilian airlines.
The Noakhali genocide of Hindus in Bengal begins, at the hands of Muslim mobs.
The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is founded.
Nuremberg Trials: Founder of the Gestapo and recently convicted Nazi war criminal, Hermann Gring, poisons himself hours before his scheduled execution.

Admiral William T. Blandy, his wife and with Rear Admiral Frank J. Lowry pose for a photograph next to an Atomic Bomb Cake at the Officers’ Club of the Army War College in Washington, D.C. The occasion was to mark the disbanding of Joint Army-Navy Task Force Number One, the body that organized and oversaw the first post-war atomic tests in the Pacific. The photo appears in the Washington Post society page on 11/7 and causes an uproar.
Vietnamese riot in Haiphong and clash with French troops. French cruiser Suffren opens fire. 6000 Vietnamese killed.
A branch of the Exchange National Bank in Chicago, Illinois opens the first ten drive-up teller windows.
A fire at the Winecoff Hotel in Atlanta, United States kills 119.
UNICEF founded.

In Hanoi, 30,000 Viet Minh launch their first large-scale attack against the French. Thus begins an eight year struggle known as the First Indochina War. "The resistance will be long and arduous, but our cause is just and we will surely triumph," declares Viet Minh military commander Vo Nguyen Giap. "If these [people] want a fight, they'll get it," French military commander Gen. Etrienne Valluy states.
Frank Capra's It's a Wonderful Life, featuring James Stewart, Donna Reed, Lionel Barrymore, Henry Travers and Thomas Mitchell, is released in New York.
The first artificial, self-sustaining nuclear chain reaction in Europe is initiated, within the Soviet (Russian) nuclear reactor F-1.
Bugsy Siegel opens the Flamingo Hotel.
President Harry Truman officially proclaims an end of hostilities in World War II.
Kroger Grocery and Baking Company officially becomes The Kroger Co.
Lazarus opens a housewares and appliance store at the former site of Columbus Auditorium.
At the Downtown Columbus Woolworth's, a cup of coffee costs a nickel, and a Swiss steak lunch 35 cents.
The first All American Jersey Sale is held in Columbus. Forty eight cows are sold for $114,225. Except for 1949 and 1950, the event would take place annually in Columbus for the next 30 years.
The Lazarus Annex opens in the renovated Columbus Auditorium.
Trustees of the Sharon Township Memorial purchase the Wright home at 137 E. Granville Rd. to become the Sharon Memorial Hall.
Proctor and Gamble introduces the first heavy duty laundry detergent, Tide.
The Columbus Metropolitan Parks board receives its first funds.
Proceedings of the United States Congress are televised for the first time.
USS Alabama BB-60 decommissioned.
USS South Dakota BB-57 decommissioned.
Percival Prattis becomes the first African American news correspondent allowed in the United States House and Senate press gallery.
USS Massachusetts BB-59 decommissioned.
The Big Story" was first heard on NBC radio. It stayed on the air for eight years.
Henry Ford dies.

At 6:05 pm the F5-rated "Woodward Tornado" wreaked havoc across parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas. The tornado, which killed 181 people and injured 970, was reportedly more than a mile wide in places.
Alton merged into Gulf, Mobile & Ohio.
Pere Marquette merged into Chesapeake & Ohio.
USS Washington BB-56 decommissioned.
President Truman authorizes Operation Sandstone, a test of new nuclear weapons designs in the Pacific Test Range.
USS North Carolina BB-55 decommissioned.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation agrees to lend $15,500,000 dollars to Donald Strandlund to start the Lustron prefabricated housing company. Mr. Strandlund raises an additional $850,000 from outside investors.
