The United States secured an agreement with the United Nations to govern the islands of Micronesia as the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands, a strategic trusteeship territory. This is the only such trusteeship ever granted by the United Nations.[1] The Trust Territory comprised about 2,000 islands spread over 3,000,000 square miles (7,800,000 km2) of the North Pacific Ocean. Five days later, the United States Atomic Energy Commission established the Pacific Proving Grounds.
Bugsy Siegel is killed after the Flamingo Hotel is judged to be a failure by mob boss Salvatore "Lucky" Luciano. Ironically, the Flamingo later turns out to be an unqualified success.
A fire broke out shortly after midnight in the Buckey Lake Park midway. Many concession stands were destroyed.
Hurricane: southeast Fla., La., Miss., Ala.: 51 killed.
The Baltimore Colts play their first regular season game, defeating the Brooklyn Dodgers 16-7 (football).
USS Indiana BB-58 decommissioned.
"Fun and Fancy Free" by Walt Disney released.

The French conduct Operation Lea, a series of attacks on Viet Minh guerrilla positions in North Vietnam near the Chinese border. Although the Viet Minh suffer over 9000 causalities, most of the 40,000 strong Viet Minh force slips away through gaps in the French lines.
The War Asset Administration assigns part of  the unused 1,500,000 square foot Curtiss-Wright Airplane Factory in Columbus to the Lustron Corporation.
Dr. John Bardeen, Dr. Walter Brattain and Dr. William Shockley invent the transistor at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, NJ.
Howard Vollum and Jack Murdock form the Tektronix Company and release their first product, the $795 model 511 10 MHz Oscilloscope. By 1960, Tektronix would become Oregon's largest manufacturing firm.
Lazarus opens its first parking garage.
First city income tax in Columbus.
The Delphi General Motors Fisher Body Plant opens.
The St. Clair Hospital closes on St. Clair Avenue and is converted into the St. Clair Hotel.

White Cross Hospital purchases land at West North Broadway and Olentangy River Road for new hospital. Plans call for initial 125 bed maternity hospital with morel units to be built if fund raising is successful.
WRFD radio begins broadcasting.
First electrified trolley buses arrive in Columbus.
Land leased in Worthington to start the Ohio Railway Museum.  Ohio Public Service car #21 moved to property
First test of Operation Sandstone (X-Ray) on Enjebi island, a 37 kt device detonated from a 200 foot tower.

Ohio River floods. West Newport prayed its 10-foot sandbag barrier would hold out. On old Front Street in Covington, water seeped into the second floor of homes. Water climbed to just a few feet below the Roebling Suspension Bridge.
Second test of Operation Sandstone (Yoke) on Enewetak Atol, a 49 kt device detonated from a 200 foot tower.
Third test of Operation Sandstone (Zebra) on Enewetak Atol, a 18 kt device detonated from a 200 foot tower.

Joe DiMaggio hits three consecutive home runs for the New York Yankees in a 6Ð5, first-game win against the Indians. The first two home runs are off Bob Feller. Behind Don Black, the Indians take the nightcap, 5-1, to preserve first place.
The Pennsylvania Railroad completes dieselization west of Baltimore and Harrisburg for all passenger trains.

The Cleveland Indians draws 82,781 for a doubleheader, a major-league record for a regular season game that will be broken by the same club in 1954. The Indians will attract 2.6 million for the season, surpassing the Yankees, 1947 attendance.

In his first full season as a pitcher, Bob Lemon of the Cleveland Indians pitches a no-hitter, beating the Detroit Tigers 2-0 in front of 49,628 at Briggs Stadium. Lemon has only two scares: Dale Mitchell makes a miraculous catch of a George Kell drive in the fourth and Ken Keltner makes a great stop behind 3B in the fifth.

The Indians stun the baseball world by signing Satchel Paige, fabulous veteran Negro League pitcher. The move is ridiculed by some as a Bill Veeck publicity stunt, and A.G. Spink in The Sporting News editorializes, "Veeck has gone too far in his quest for publicity. . . . To sign a hurler at Paige's age is to demean the standards of baseball in the big circuits." The 42-year-old Paige will answer the critics the next day, getting a relief decision in a 8Ð6 win over New York in a DH sweep. He will finish at 6Ð1. Paige is the oldest player to debut in the majors, but not the first 40-year-old: Chuck Hostetler in 1944 was 40.
The Summer Olympics open in London, England.
Delaware Dam is completed to control the Olentangy River. Located 4 miles north of Delaware, the dam cost $4,307,000 to construct.
The first pieces of enameled steel come out of the ovens at the Lustron Corporation.
The last street car runs in Columbus on Saturday night.
The Cleveland Indians win the World Series, beating the Boston Braves 4 games to 2.
10,000th Bridgeport Miller sold

Hideki Tojo is sentenced to death by International Military Tribunal for the Far East in Tokyo. During the trial, blame for the war was transferred from Emprorer Hirohito to Tojo because the occupiers of Japan needs the Emporer to be exonerated so they could use him to control Japanese society.

Cleveland Indians player-manager Lou Boudreau is selected the AL MVP. Boudreau had almost been traded to the Browns earlier in the year, but protests by fans kept Lou in Cleveland. After the WS win, owner Bill Veeck commented, "Sometimes the best trades are the ones you never make."
The McDonald brothers open an efficient hamburger, french fry and milk shake restaurant at West 14th and 1398 North E Streets in San Bernadino.

Hideki Tojo was hanged for war crimes in Tokyo at Sugamo Prison in Ikebukuro. Also executed are  
* General Kenji Doihara, chief of the intelligence services in Manchukuo
* Kōki Hirota, prime minister (later foreign minister)
* General Seishirō Itagaki, war minister
* General Heitarō Kimura, commander, Burma Area Army
* Lieutenant General Akira Mutō, chief of staff, 14th Area Army
* General Iwane Matsui, commander, Shanghai Expeditionary Force and Central China Area Army
First Columbus Lustron house unveiled.
North American Aviation leases the Curtiss-Wright Airplane Factory to meet increased demand for the F-86 aircraft.
Don Eisele, the future astronaut, graduates from West High School.
The Clarmont restaurant opens.
The original North Market burns.
Blacklick Woods Metro Park opens.
OSU: Central Classroom, 2009 Millikin Road, opens.
OSU: Hagerty Hall, 1775 College Road, addition. College of Business.
OSU: Hughes Hall, 1899 College Road, opens. Houses the Music Department.
The planet Uranus's moon Miranda is discovered by Gerard Kuiper.
Ohio Railway Museum founded
St. Louis and San Francisco gains control of Alabama, Tenessee & Northern.
The first freight passenger engines are introduced on the Pennsylvania Railroad, EMD F-3's in ABBA configuration with number series starting at 9500.
U.S. economy in recession.
WBNS 10TV goes on the air

Nebr., Wyo., S.D., Utah, Colo., and Nev.: Actually one of a series of winter storms between Jan. 1 and Feb. 22. Although only 1 ft to 30 in. of snow fell, fierce winds of up to 72 mph created drifts as high as 30 ft. Tens of thousands of cattle and sheep perished.
Lustron homes is refused permission to build prefabricated homes in Minerva Park by the City Council.
The French install Bao Dai as puppet head of state in South Vietnam.
Worthington Village and Sharon Township Local School districts are consolidated.
The first all-black-cast variety show was presented on WENR-TV in Chicago, IL. The show was called "Happy Pappy".
Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis debuted on radio in an NBC program that ran until 1952.
The parkland purchased by Mayor James Rhodes in 1944 is designated Whetstone Park.

A flight from Daet to Manila carrying 13 people (10 passengers, 3 crew) disappeared over the Sibuyan Sea. The Douglas DC-3 crashed, killing all aboard, after suffering a violent explosion in its tail. Two ex-convicts later confessed to planting a time bomb on the aircraft. The plot was intended to kill a male passenger so that his wife could marry another man she was involved with.
The French establish the (South) Vietnamese National Army.
The Soviet Union conducts its first nuclear weapons test.

The Lustron Corporation produces its first mass-produced home. The housing shortage has already shrunk by 2,500,000 units by this time. Also Lustron's price of $10,500 is much higher than the $6,500 originally estimated when pitching the idea to the government.

Canadian Pacific Airlines DC-3 exploded in mid-flight en route from Quebec City to Baie-Comeau, Quebec as the result of an on board bomb, killing all 23 on board. Albert Guay described himself as a jeweller and watchmaker, although at his trial it was suggested that he was more of a watch and jewellery salesman. His marriage to Rita Morel was stormy and he became enamoured of 19-year-old waitress Marie-Ange Robitaille. In those days Quebec was strictly Catholic and divorce was almost impossible. Guay first considered poison but later decided on the airplane bombing. The day of the flight he took out a $CAD10,000 insurance policy on his wife, a considerable sum at that time, which he attempted to collect three days later. There was also a prior $5000 policy dating from 1942. He was hanged for the crime on January 12, 1951.

The grand opening of the first section of Town & Country shopping center in Whitehall. Its 31 shops and services included JCPenney, Kroger, Kresge's, Gray Drugs, and Richman Brothers. Known to some as the "Miracle Mile" and to others as "Casto's Folly," Town & Country had many obstacles to overcome. One major hurdle was convincing major retailers to venture off the main downtown arteries of metropolitan cities and into an unknown concept in merchandising, the regional shopping center. Persistent negotiations between shopping center pioneer Don M. Casto, Sr. and national retailers James Cash Penney and Sebastian Kresge finally landed commitments for stores in this remote suburban location. Their commitments resolved the daunting task of convincing Columbus Railway Power & Light Co., which controlled public transportation at the time, to extend bus service to the suburban shopping center. Casto also insisted on radical innovations for his retailers that were only reluctantly accepted Ð like requiring stores to stay open until 9:00 p.m. six nights a week (since an estimated 70% of sales would be transacted between 5:00 and 9:00 p.m.) and having neon signs that could be seen from the street during all hours of operation. Two of Town & Country's original tenants, Sam's Shoe Service and Swan Cleaners, continue to operate at the center.

Mao Zedong's Communist forces defeat Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Army in the Chinese civil war. Mao's victory ignites American anti-Communist sentiment regarding Southeast Asia and will result in a White House foreign policy goal of "containment" of Communist expansion in the region.
Wheeling & Lake Erie leased by New York, Chicago & St. Louis "Nickle Plate Road".
Battelle Memorial Institute agrees to help engineer Chester Carlson develop an electrostatic copying process. Battelle joined forces with a small New England company no known as Xerox
WLWC (Channel 3) goes on the air as Columbus' first television station.
OSU: 1314 Kinnear Rd. Research opens.
OSU: Central Service Building, 2003 Millikin Road, opens.
With the creation of the Ohio Department of Natural Resources and the Division of Parks and Recreation, Shawnee became a state park and forest.
Columbus Railway Power and Light Company work car 067 donated to Ohio Railway Museum.
The planet Neptune's moon Nereid is discovered by Gerard Kuiper.
The Ohio Legislature creates the Ohio Turnpike Commission, which authorizes $326 million in bonds to build a 241 mile highway across the northern part of the state.
Sharon Township Fire Station constructed on west side of High Street between the Village Green and Stafford.
The Ohio State University Buckeyes win the Rose Bowl, defeating California 17-14.
Ho Chi Minh begins offensive against French troops in Indo-China.
The writer, George Orwell, dies after a three-year battle against tuberculosis.

The People's Republic of China and the Soviet Union recognize Ho Chi Minh's Democratic Republic of Vietnam. China then begins sending military advisors and modern weapons to the Viet Minh including automatic weapons, mortars, howitzers, and trucks. Much of the equipment is American-made and had belonged to the Chinese Nationalists before their defeat by Mao. With the influx of new equipment and Chinese advisors, General Giap transforms his guerrilla fighters into conventional army units including five light infantry divisions and one heavy division.

In America, the era of 'McCarthyism' erupts as Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin gives a speech claiming the U.S. State Department harbors Communists. As a consequence of McCarthyism, no U.S. politician is willing to appear to be 'soft' on Communism.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation files foreclosure action against the Lustron Corporation, which is losing $1,000,000 per month.

The term "McCarthyism" is originated by the Washington Post's editorial cartoonist Herbert Block. The cartoon depicted four leading Republicans trying to push an elephant (the traditional symbol of the Republican Party) to stand on a teetering stack of ten tar buckets, the topmost of which was labelled "McCarthyism".
Whetstone Park officially dedicated on Memorial Day.

Northwest Airlines Flight 2501 with 58 people on board disappears without a trace. The plane was at around 3,500 feet (1070 m) over Lake Michigan about 20 miles NNW of Benton Harbor, Michigan when it vanished off the radar screens after requesting descent to 2,500 feet (760 m). A widespread search was commenced including searching and dragging the bottom of Lake Michigan with sonars and trawlers but to no avail. Other than some light debris found on the surface no trace of the plane or its occupants was ever found.
The New York Central makes its T&OC line one of the first to be upgraded from steam engines to diesels.

President Harry S. Truman orders U.S. ground troops into Korea following Communist North Korea's invasion of the South. In his message to the American people, Truman describes the invasion as a Moscow-backed attack by "monolithic world Communism."

United States military involvement in Vietnam begins as President Harry Truman authorizes $15 million in military aid to the French. American military advisors will accompany the flow of U.S. tanks, planes, artillery and other supplies to Vietnam. Over the next four years, the U.S. will spend $3 Billion on the French war and by 1954 will provide 80 percent of all war supplies used by the French.
India & Tibet: Two thousand homes, temples and mosques were destroyed in a quake measuring 8.6. Hardest hit was the Brahmaputra Basin in northeast India. At least 1,500 people were killed.
Central of Georgia acquires control of Savannah & Atlanta.

The Lustron Corporation shuts down its Columbus plant and goes out of business. In its short history it lost $37,500,000 of Reconstruction Finance Corporation money and produced 2,500 enameled steel homes, many of which still stand today.
General Giap begins his main attack against French outposts near the Chinese border. As the outposts fall, the French lose 6000 men and large stores of military equipment to the Viet Minh.
The San Francisco 49ers play their first regular season game, losing to the New York Yanks 21-17.
The U.S. establishes a Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Saigon to aid the French Army.
Eastern U.S.: Storm of the Century generated heavy snow and hurricane-force winds across 22 states and claimed 383 lives. Damages estimated at $70 million.
The "Snow Bowl." Michigan defeats Ohio State 9 to 3 during a blizzard. It is Wes Fesler's last game as coach.
Bank One opens the first drive-through bank in Columbus

Curtiss-Wright Aviation ceases operation. Ownership of the factory is transferred from the Air Force to the Navy, which transfers the plant to North American Aviation control as the Naval Industrial Reserve Aircraft Plant.
Employment at the North American Aviation plant at 1,600.
James Thurber publishes "The Thirteen Clocks"
Enrollment at Ohio State University exceeds 25,000 for the first time
OSU: Caldwell Lab, 2024 Neil Ave., opens. Houses the Department of Electrical Engineering.
OSU: Smith Laboratory of Physics, 174 W. 18th Ave., opens.
Vic Janowicz, Ohio State Back, wins the Heisman trophy.

20,000 Viet Minh under Gen. Giap begin a series of attacks on fortified French positions in the Red River Delta (extending from Hanoi to the Gulf of Tonkin). The open areas of the Delta, in contrast to the jungle, allow French troops under the new command of Gen. Jean de Lattre to strike back with devastating results from the 'De Lattre Line' which encircles the region. 6000 Viet Minh die while assaulting the town of Vinh Yen near Hanoi in the first attack, causing Giap to withdraw.
Woody Hayes accepts the football coaching position at Ohio State University.
The keel is laid for the 666 foot, 30,800 ton John G. Munson in Manitowoc, WI.
In the second attack, Giap targets the Mao Khe outpost near Haiphong. But Giap withdraws after being pounded by French naval gunfire and air strikes. 3000 Viet Minh are killed.
The keel is laid for the car ferry S.S. Badger at the Manitowoc, WI shipyard,
Dedication of Beale AFB, east of Yuba, CA. It had been used as a bombing range since 1948, and an army base since October 1942.

Giap makes yet another attempt to break through the De Lattre Line, this time in the Day River area southeast of Hanoi. French reinforcements, combined with air strikes and armed boat attacks result in another defeat for Giap with 10,000 killed and wounded. Among the French causalities is Bernard de Lattre, the only son of General De Lattre.
Hays, Kansas is submerged after 11" of rain causes the Big Creek to overflow.
Giap begins a general withdrawal of Viet Minh troops from the Red River Delta.
The U.S. Census Bureau dedicates it's first computer, a UNIVAC 1101.
Heavy rain continues in Kansas, setting the stage for record breaking floods in July.
A period of heavy rain over Kansas drops 8 - 16" over the next 5 days.
Kansas and Missouri: The greatest amount of destruction by flood experienced in the Midwest as of that date, with 1,000,000 acres underwater in Kansas and 926,000 in Missouri.

A Canadian Pacific Airlines Douglas C-54A-10-DC departed Vancouver, British Columbia for Anchorage, Alaska but disappeared en route without a trace. Eventually, all 37 on board would be declared legally dead.
The Bell X-1/A/B/D makes its first flight.
A period of 20 days with no precipitation, or only a trace, in the State of Ohio, begins. This is a record for lack of precipitation during the main growing season.

A period of 20 days with no precipitation, or only a trace, in the State of Ohio, ends. This is a record for lack of precipitation during the main growing season. 1951 is the second driest summer ever in Ohio (1933 is the driest).
Blendon Woods Metro Park opens.
Forty-nine nations sign the Japanese Peace Treaty in San Francisco, officially ending World War II and re-establishing Japanese sovereignty.
Gen. De Lattre travels to Washington seeking more aid from the Pentagon.
President Truman signs an act formally ending World War II, after having Congress abolish the state of war with Germany
The Bell X-1 (XS-1) makes its last flight.
"I Love Lucy" premiers.
French forces link up at Hoa Binh southwest of Hanoi as Gen. De Lattre attempts to seize the momentum and lure Giap into a major battle.
Stricken by cancer, ailing Gen. De Lattre is replaced by Gen. Raoul Salan. De Lattre returns home and dies in Paris two months later, just after being raised to the rank of Marshal.

Giap begins a careful counter-offensive by attacking the French outpost at Tu Vu on the Black River. Giap now avoids conventional warfare and instead wages hit and run attacks followed by a retreat into the dense jungles. His goal is to cut French supply lines. By year's end, French causalities in Vietnam surpass 90,000.

A Miami Airlines Curtiss C-46F-1-CU departed Newark, New Jersey bound for Tampa, Florida but caught fire and crashed in Elizabeth, New Jersey attempting to return to the airport. All 56 people on board died.

The ERA 1101, later renamed UNIVAC 1101, is a computer system designed and built by Engineering Research Associates (ERA). Its (initial) military model, the ERA Atlas, was the first stored-program computer that was moved from its site of manufacture and successfully installed at a distant site. 46 Computers are sold.
"Dragnet" premiers.
During Lazarus' centennial year, Lazarus stages a yearlong "Look to Lazarus" TV show, featuring celebrity visitors to the store.

Similac Concentrated Liquid, the first infant formula available in a form other than powder in the United States, was introduced by M&R Dietetic Laboratories. It soon became the most popular product in the U.S. infant-formula market.
Baldwin Tower at Grant Medical Center, 300 E. Town St., opens. 16 stories.
The Columbus Symphony Orchestra has its first performance.
OSU: Enarson Hall, 154 W. 12th Ave., remodeled to house student services and the health center.
OSU: Fry Hall, 338 W. 10th Ave., opens. Serves as the Optometry Building.
OSU: William Thompson Oxley Memorial Library, 1858 Neil Ave., adds wings to the North and South sides, and a 13 story book stack to the west side.
Erie Railroad gas-electric #5012 purchased and moved to the Ohio Railway Museum.
Woody Hayes becomes head football coach at The Ohio State University.
Medick Estates annexed to Worthington
Worthington Seventh-day Adventists build church at north end of Griswold Street.
The Olentangy River crests at 15.30 feet in Worthington, the second highest crest in its history.
French supply lines to Hoa Binh along the Black River are cut. The road along Route Coloniale 6 is also cut.
Truce talks aimed at ending fighting in the Korean War are deadlocked.
The French withdraw from Hoa Binh back to the De Lattre Line aided by a 30,000 round artillery barrage. Casualties for each side surpassed 5000 during the Black River skirmishes.
The Manitowoc Shipyard lays the keel of the 12,000 ton John J. Boland III.
Ark. and Tenn.: 28 tornadoes caused 204 deaths.

Harry Belafonte recorded his first songs for RCA Victor at Manhattan Center in New York City. Hugo Winterhalter backed up the singer with an 18-piece orchestra. Among the sides recorded were "A-Roving" and "Chimney Smoke".
The Boeing B-52 bomber makes its first test flight.
The IBM 701 Electronic Data Processing Machine, known as the Defense Calculator while in development, is IBM’s first commercial scientific computer.
The Bell X-2 makes its first flight.

On her maiden voyage on July 3, 1952, the SS United States broke the transatlantic speed record held by RMS Queen Mary for the previous 14 years by over 10 hours, making the maiden crossing from the Ambrose lightship at New York Harbor to Bishop Rock off Cornwall, UK in 3 days, 10 hours, 40 minutes at an average speed of 35.59 knots (65.91 km/h; 40.96 mph).
The Summer Olympics open in Helsinki, Finland.

A Douglas DC-3 operated by the Brazilian airline TAN left Rio Verde headed for Goiania with 24 people aboard (20 passengers, 4 crew). The aircraft never reached its destination after suffering a mid-air explosion caused by a bomb.
Manitowoc Shipyard delivers the John G. Munson to Bradley Transportation Line, a subsidiary of United States Steel.

Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant: The U.S. Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) selects Scioto Township, a rural area occupied by family-owned farms, as the site for a new gaseous diffusion plant to produce highly enriched uranium, U-235, for use in military reactors and nuclear weapons production.
Great Britain conducts its first nuclear weapons test in Australia.
"The Ozzie and Harriet Show" premiers.
Giap now attempts to draw the French out from the De Lattre Line by attacking along the Fan Si Pan mountain range between the Red and Black Rivers.
Ground is broken for the Ohio Turnpike.

The French counter Giap's move by launching Operation Lorraine targeting major Viet Minh supply bases in the Viet Bac region. But Giap outsmarts the French by ignoring their maneuvers and maintains his position along the Black River.
"The Halloween Riot". A riot at the Ohio Penitentiary results in severe damage to the facility and one prisoner shot.
Ivy Mike was the codename given to the first test of a full-scale thermonuclear device which yielded 10.4 megatons. It was the first full test of the Teller–Ulam design, a staged fusion device.
Russia - An earthquake with a magnitude of 9.0 generated a tsunami which struck the Hawaiian islands. No lives were lost.
The French cancel Operation Loraine and withdraw back toward the De Lattre Line but must first fight off a Viet Minh ambush at Chan Muong.
Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant: Groundbreaking.
President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower fulfilled his campaign promise to visit Korea to begin the process of ending the Korean War.
"The Abbott and Costello Show" premiers.
Employment at the North American Aviation plant at 18,000. The plant produced the F-100 Supersaber, RF-6 Vigilante, T-2 Buckeye, T-28 Trojan, and OV-10 Bronco.
J C Penney opens its first suburban store at Central Point Shopping Center. Penney's is the first downtown store to open a branch in the suburbs.
The first Parade of Homes is held.
Thirty two acres of the 161 acre Whetstone Park are set aside for the Columbus Park of Roses.
Kansas City Public Service Burney #1545 is donated to Ohio Railway Museum.
Port Columbus Airport's east-west runway was extended from 4,500 to 8,000 feet, touted as "the longest runway in the Midwest".
Elsie Wilson tract (Wilson Hills subdivision) annexed to Worthington.
George Snyder leases the New England Inn, adds an antiques shop and renames the property the Old Worthington Inn
New Worthington High School (now the central portion of Thomas Worthington High School) is built on original school farm to accommodate rapid growth after World War II.
Taylor Wharton is acquired by the Harsco Corporation.
Dwight David Eisenhour inaugurated as President.
Soviet leader Josef Stalin dies. The outspoken Nikita Khrushchev eventually succeeds him.
The car ferry S.S. Badger, 410 feet, 6650 tons, makes it's first voyage on Lake Michigan.
"TV Guide" was published for the first time -- from Radnor, Pennsylvania (near Philadelphia). The publication reached a circulation of 1,500,000 readers in its first year.
The first planting of the Columbus Park of Roses is completed.

At 4:10 pm the "Waco Tornado," an F5-rated twister that killed 114 people and injured 597 was the deadliest tornado ever recorded in Texas. The 1/3-mile-wide tornado touched down nearly 10 miles south of Waco, damaging 600 businesses, 850 homes and 2,000 cars.

The McDonald brothers first franchisee was Neil Fox, a distributor for General Petroleum Corporation. Fox's stand, the first with Meston's golden arches design, opened at 4050 North Central Avenue at Indian School Road in Phoenix, Arizona
The Columbus Park of Roses opens to the public.

At 8:30 pm the "Flint Tornado" killed 115 people and injured 844. The F5-rated tornado was the deadliest twister ever recorded in Michigan. The tornado caused $19 million in damages at the time, which translates to about $125 million in today's dollars.
Worcester, Mass.: tornado hit town, causing 90 deaths.

Lavrentiy Beria was arrested and held in an undisclosed location near Moscow. Khrushchev prepared an elaborate ambush, convening a meeting of the Presidium, where he suddenly launched a scathing attack on Beria, accusing him of being a traitor and spy in the pay of British intelligence. Beria was taken completely by surprise.

The Korean War ends as an armistice is signed dividing the country at the 38th parallel into Communist North and Democratic South. The armistice is seen by many in the international community as a potential model for resolving the ongoing conflict in Vietnam.
Korean armistice is signed. Ohio casualties include 1,777 dead and 4,837 wounded.
The keel is laid for the 606 foot, 12,000 ton Detroit Edison II in Manitowoc, WI.
State of Ohio officially admitted to the union, retroactively to 03/01/1803
The first REDSTONE research and development missile was flight tested.
Chief Justice Fred Vinson of the United States Supreme Court died in office.
The Columbus Park of Roses is officially dedicated.
The John J. Boland III is delivered by the Manitowoc Shipyard to the American Steamship Company.
Earl Warren takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

The UNIVAC 1103 or ERA 1103, a successor to the UNIVAC 1101, is a computer system designed by Engineering Research Associates and built by the Remington Rand corporation. It was the first computer for which Seymour Cray was credited with design work
"The Whetstone Venture," an elaborate pageant in celebration of Worthington's sesquicentennial, is performed on the ball fields between Stafford Avenue and Morning Street.

The French under their new commander Gen. Henri Navarre begin Operation Castor, the construction of a series of entrenched outposts protecting a small air base in the isolated jungle valley at Dien Bien Phu in northwest Vietnam. Gen. Giap immediately begins massing Viet Minh troops and artillery in the area, sensing the potential for a decisive blow against the French. Giap's troops manually drag 200 heavy howitzers up rugged mountain sides to target the French air base. The French, aware of Giap's intentions, mass their own troops and artillery, preparing for a showdown, but have grossly underestimated Giap's strength.
Lavrentiy Beria is executed by General Pavel Batitsky after a show trial.
Lane Avenue Shopping Center opens.
Northern Lights Shopping Center opens.
Cincinnati & Lake Erie #119 purchased and moved to Ohio Railway Museum.
Ohio Public Service #64 donated and moved to Ohio Railway Museum.
Ohio Railway Museum car barn complete.
Sharon Township Fire Department purchases its first emergency squad vehicle.
The Soviet Union begins design work on the R-7 rocket, which will eventually launch the world's first satellite into orbit.
NBC broadcasts the 1954 Tournament of Roses Parade in color, the first nationwide color television broadcast.
Thirty-five people are missing, feared dead, after a BOAC Comet jet airliner crashes into the Mediterranean.
Chicago based Admiral introduces the Admiral C1617A color television.

Bell Lab's TRADIC (for TRAnsistor DIgital Computer or TRansistorized Airborne DIgital Computer) was the first transistorized computer in the USA. It had 684 Bell Labs Type 1734 Type A cartridge transistors and 10,358 germanium point-contact diodes. The TRADIC was small and light enough to be installed in a B-52 Stratofortress.

David Edgerton opens Insta Burger King on March 1, located at 3090 NW 36th Street, Miami, selling 18¢ broiled hamburgers and 18¢ milkshakes. Three months later, on June 1, Jim McLamore matches Mr. Edgerton's capital and the co-founders form a corporation called Burger King of Miami, Inc.

CBS journalist Edward R. Murrow, in an episode of his documentary series See It Now, exposes the methods of the Junior Senator from Wisconsin, Joseph R. McCarthy. The March 9, 1954 show consisted primarily of clips of McCarthy speaking. In these clips, McCarthy accuses the Democratic party of "twenty years of treason" (1933-1953, makes a similar accusation against the Administrations of Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Harry Truman), and berates witnesses, including an Army general.  Murrow said "We will not walk in fear, one of another. We will not be driven by fear into an age of unreason if we dig deep in our history and doctrine and remember that we are not descended from fearful men, not from men who feared to write, to speak, to associate and to defend causes which were for the moment unpopular. We can deny our heritage and our history, but we cannot escape responsibility for the result. There is no way for a citizen of the Republic to abdicate his responsibility."

Outnumbering the French nearly five-to-one, 50,000 Viet Minh under Gen. Giap begin their assault against the fortified hills protecting the Dien Bien Phu air base. Giap's artillery pounds the French and shuts down the only runway, thus forcing the French to rely on risky parachute drops for re-supply. Giap's troops then take out their shovels and begin construction of a maze of tunnels and trenches, slowly inching their way toward the main French position and surrounding it.
20,000th Bridgeport Miller shipped.

The siege at Dien Bien Phu occurs as nearly 10,000 French soldiers are trapped by 45,000 Viet Minh. French troops soon run out of fresh water and medical supplies. The French urgently appeal to Washington for help. The U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff now consider three possible military options: sending American combat troops to the rescue; a massive conventional air strike by B-29 bombers; the use of tactical atomic weapons. President Eisenhower dismisses the conventional air raid and the nuclear option after getting a strong negative response to such actions from America's chief ally, Britain. Eisenhower also decides against sending U.S. ground troops to rescue the French, citing the likelihood of high casualty rates in the jungles around Dien Bien Phu. No action is taken.
Carl "Bobo" Olson defeated Kid Gavilan to retain the world middleweight boxing title.
Maestro Arturo Toscanini conducted his last concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in New York City. Toscanini ended a 17-year association with the orchestra.
The General Electric CT-100 color television is available.
IBM announces the IBM 704 Data Processing System, the world’s first mass produced computer to feature floating point arithmetic hardware.
Construction begins on the Straights of Mackinac bridge, linking the lower and upper peninsulas of Michigan.

At 5:30 p.m., 10,000 French soldiers surrender at Dien Bien Phu. By now, an estimated 8000 Viet Minh and 1500 French have died. The French survivors are marched for up to 60 days to prison camps 500 hundred miles away. Nearly half die during the march or in captivity. France proceeds to withdraw completely from Vietnam, ending a bitter eight year struggle against the Viet Minh in which 400,000 soldiers and civilians from all sides had perished.

The Geneva Conference on Indochina begins, attended by the U.S., Britain, China, the Soviet Union, France, Vietnam (Viet Minh and representatives of Bao Dai), Cambodia and Laos, all meeting to negotiate a solution for Southeast Asia.
After ground tests and a review of 100 designs, final design for the R-7 rocket was approved by Sergei Korolev in the Soviet Union.
The Boeing 707 (367-80) makes its first test flight.

The Geneva Accords divide Vietnam in half at the 17th parallel, with Ho Chi Minh's Communists ceded the North, while Bao Dai's regime is granted the South. The accords also provide for elections to be held in all of Vietnam within two years to reunify the country. The U.S. opposes the unifying elections, fearing a likely victory by Ho Chi Minh.
The Lord of the Rings by J.R.R. Tolkien is published.

The beginning of construction on the St. Lawrence Seaway is marked in a ceremony including Robert H. Saunders of Ontario Hydro, Canadian Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York.
Hurricane: N.C. to New England: Carol killed 60 in Long Island & New England area.
"Lassie" premiers.
"The Tonight Show" premiers with host Steve Allen.
The Victory Bell in Ohio Stadium was first rung after a game against the University of California.
Hurricane: S.C. to N.Y.: Hazel killed 95 in U.S.; about 400 - 1,000 in Haiti; 78 in Canada.

Following the French departure from Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh returns after spending eight years hiding in the jungle and formally takes control of North Vietnam. In the South, Bao Dai has installed Ngo Dinh Diem as his prime minister. The U.S. now pins its hopes on anti-Communist Diem for a democratic South Vietnam. It is Diem, however, who predicts "another more deadly war" will erupt over the future of Vietnam. Diem, a Roman Catholic in an overwhelmingly Buddhist country, encourages Vietnamese Catholics living in Communist North Vietnam to flee south. Nearly one million leave. At the same time, some 90,000 Communists in the south go north, although nearly 10,000 Viet Minh fighters are instructed by Hanoi to quietly remain behind.
Colonial Hills subdivision is annexed to Worthington giving the community the 5,000 residents needed to achieve city status.
The Two Towers by J.R.R. Tolkien is published.
Dow Jones surpasses 381.17, the previous high set 25 years ago just before the Great Depression.
The Senate votes to "condemn" Senator Joseph McCarthy on both counts by a vote of 67 to 22, with the Democrats unanimously in favor of condemnation and the Republicans split evenly.

Rush Creek Village in Worthington is incorporated with covenants to protect the natural environment. Martha and Richard Wakefield, who along with designer Ted Fossen, brought Frank Lloyd Wright's organic architectural concept to central Ohio, begin to build their house in Rush Creek.
Dr. Samuel Sheppard is found guilty of murdering his wife. His conviction is overturned in 1966.

The IBM Naval Ordnance Research Calculator (NORC) was a one-of-a-kind first-generation (vacuum tube) computer built by IBM for the United States Navy's Bureau of Ordnance. It went into service in December 1954[1] and was likely the most powerful computer at the time.[
First color television installed in Columbus
WHKC Radio becomes WTVN.
Detroit Street Railways donated and moved to Ohio Railway Museum.
St. Michael School in Worthington built with 11 classrooms, a cafeteria and a kitchen. The Chase Mansion is converted into a convent for Joliet Franciscan Sisters who staffed the school.
Swiminc, a subscription organization, opens Worthington's first public swimming pool.
Worthington City Hall, located next to the northwest quadrant of the public square, becomes the first building in the city constructed specifically for municipal government.
Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant: First operations begin while plant is still under construction.
The Buckeyes win the Rose Bowl, beating Southern California 20-7.
The first direct shipment of U.S. military aid to Saigon arrives. The U.S. also offers to train the fledgling South Vietnam Army.
Crews of workers begin arriving at Tyuratam in Kazakhstan to begin construction of the Baikonur Cosmodrome.
The Dumont television network drops most of its programming.
Fred Astaire appeared on television for the first time on "The Toast of the Town", with host, Ed Sullivan. Already an established dancer in films, Astaire was quick to become a TV sensation as well.
Richard J. Daley was elected mayor of Chicago, IL, starting one of the most colorful political careers not only of the Windy City, but anywhere.
All 19 people aboard a Lockheed L-049 of Air India were killed when the plane crashed after a bomb exploded in flight.
The Manitowoc Shipyard delivers the Detroit Edison II to the American Steamship Company.
Ray Kroc's first McDonald's restaurant opened at 400 North Lee Street in Des Plaines, Illinois, near Chicago. Kroc bought the rights to franchise McDonalds nationally.
The Worthington Historical Society is founded.

The IBM 608 Transistor Calculator, a plugboard-programmable unit, was the first IBM product to use transistor circuits without any vacuum tubes and is believed to be the world's first all-transistorized calculator to be manufactured for the commercial market.
A fan trip on the Scioto Valley Traction Company using two borrowed N & W passenger cars is made in conjunction with the abandonment of the line between Groveport and Lockbourne.

Scioto Valley Traction Company makes last coal delivery to the Picway Power Plant. A tie in to the N & W railroad south of Lockbourne and to the C & O at Lockbourne permit diesel delivered coal. Ohio Midland continues this service.

Operation Wigwam involved a single test of the Mark 90 "Betty" 30 kt nuclear bomb at a depth of 2000 feet underwater, in an area that is 12000 feet deep. It was conducted about 500 miles (800 km) southwest of San Diego, California.
Udall, Kans.: tornado killed 80.
Franklin County children's home demolished.
Prime Minister Diem wages a violent crackdown against the Binh Xuyen organized crime group based in Saigon which operates casinos, brothels and opium dens.
Chrysler Corporation received the first industrial contract for the REDSTONE missile.
"Lady and the Tramp" by Walt Disney released.
Worthington Historical Society is organized, evolving from a study group of the Worthington Women's Club.
Disney Land, built on 160 acres at a cost of $17,500,000 opens in California.
Ho Chi Minh visits Moscow and agrees to accept Soviet aid.
Hurricane: N.C. to New England: Diane took 184 lives and cost $8.3 million ($5.5 billion).
The battleship USS Kearsarge (BB-05), which has been a crane ship since 1920, is sold for scrap.
Los Angeles: 8-day run of 100¡-plus heat left 946 people dead.
"Gunsmoke" premiers.
"Hoover Dam" on the Big Walnut Creek dedicated in memory of brothers, Charles and Clarence Hoover, who both served the City of Columbus Waterworks.
The Ohio Turnpike is completed. On opening day, 44,000 motorists traversed the route.
"Captain Kangaroo" premiers.

United Airlines Flight 409 crashes. The aircraft crashed into Medicine Bow Peak, near Centennial, Wyoming while en route on October 6, 1955, killing all 66 people on board (63 passengers, 3 crew members.) Passengers included members of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, and military personnel. At the time, this was the worst crash in U.S. commercial aviation history.
The Return of the King by J.R.R. Tolkien is published.

Bao Dai is ousted from power, defeated by Prime Minister Diem in a U.S.-backed plebiscite which was rigged. Diem is advised on consolidating power by U.S. Air Force Col. Edward G. Lansdale, who is attached to the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).

The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed with Diem as its first president. In America, President Eisenhower pledges his support for the new government and offers military aid. Diem assigns most high level government positions to close friends and family members including his younger brother Ngo Dinh Nhu who will be his chief advisor. Diem's style of leadership, aloof and autocratic, will create future political problems for him despite the best efforts of his American advisors to popularize him via American-style political rallies and tours of the countryside.

United 629 was a Douglas DC-6B en route from Denver, Colorado, to Portland, Oregon. Nine minutes after takeoff, the aircraft was destroyed by a bomb composed of 25 sticks of dynamite. All 44 passengers and crew were killed in the crash. A man named Jack Graham was arrested for the act. Graham's mother was on the plane and he hoped to claim $37,500 of life insurance policies that he had bought from vending machines at the airport just before departure. Ironically, the policies were invalid since his mother had not signed them. Graham was put to death in the gas chamber little more than a year after the bombing.
Franklin County Veterans Memorial Auditorium and Exhibit Hall opens
The Bell X-1E makes its first flight.

In North Vietnam, radical land reforms by Communists result in land owners being hauled before "people's tribunals." Thousands are executed or sent to forced labor camps during this period of ideological cleansing by Ho Chi Minh. In South Vietnam, President Diem rewards his Catholic supporters by giving them land seized from Buddhist peasants, arousing their anger and eroding his support among them. Diem also allows big land owners to retain their holdings, disappointing peasants hoping for land reform.
St. Anthony's and St. Francis hospitals merge.
The Columbus Jets baseball team is organized.
The Jai Lai Cafe moves from 544 N. High St. to Olentangy River Road.
The Ohio Bell Building at 111 N. 4th St. opens. 14 stories.
WOSU-TV has its first broadcast.
OSU: Baker Commons Dining Hall added to Baker Hall.
OSU: The Agriculture Administration Building, 2120 Fyffe Road, opens.
OSU: The Electroscience Lab, 1320 Kinnear Road, opens. Initially named The Antenna Building.
Marble Cliff Quarries Company steam engine #1 donated and moved to Ohio Railway Museum.
Howard Cassady, Ohio State Back, wins the Heisman trophy.
The Macklin Hotel, next to the Toledo & Ohio Central Station, was raised.
Architecturally compatible addition built on the south side of New England Lodge No. 4. The original hall is renovated as a museum.
Colonial Hills Elementary School opens.
Worthington Industries founded.

AEP places the Kyger Creek (5 units, 1000 MW) and Clifty Creek (6 units 1300 MW) power plants into operation. The power requirements of the Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Power Plant which needed 16 billion kw per year (2000 MW, more than New York City).

Diem launches a brutal crackdown against Viet Minh suspects in the countryside. Those arrested are denied counsel and hauled before "security committees" with many suspects tortured or executed under the guise of 'shot while attempting escape.'

Nikita Khrushchev gives a secret speech entitled "On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences" at the 20th Congress of the Communist Party. The speech was sharply critical of the reign of the deceased General Secretary and Premier Joseph Stalin, particularly with respect to the purges which had especially marked the last years of the 1930s.

After days of rioting caused by Krushchev's speech criticizing Joseph Stalin, the Soviet Army puts down protests in Stalin's birth region, Georgia. The Communist Party USA alone lost more than 30,000 members within weeks of its publication. The speech was also a major cause of the Sino-Soviet split in which China (under Chairman Mao Zedong) and Albania (under First Secretary Enver Hoxha) condemned Khrushchev as a revisionist.

Gulf Coast Lines (New Orleans, Texas & Mexico, Beaumont, Sour Lake & Western, Orange & NorthWestern, New Iberia & Northern, Iberia, St. Mary & Eastern, St. Louis, Brownsville & Mexico, International-Great Northern, San Antonio Southern, San Antonio, Uvalde & Gulf, Asphalt Belt, San Benito & Rio Grande Valley, Sugar Land,  Houston & Brazos Valley, and Houston North Shore) absorbed into Missouri Pacific.
Ampex demonstrates the VR-1000, which was the first of Ampex's line of 2 inch Quadruplex videotape recorders at the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters in Chicago.
The last French soldier leaves South Vietnam. The French High Command for Indochina is then dissolved.
"As The World Turns" soap opera premiers.
The battleship USS Illinois (BB-07) is sold for scrap.
Alabama outlaws the NAACP.
Federal-Aid Highway Act of 1956 signed by President Eisenhower

United Airlines Flight 718, a DC-7, flying from Los Angeles to Chicago and TWA Flight 2, a Constellation flying from Los Angeles to Kansas City collided over the Grand Canyon. The 58 passengers and crew on the DC-7, and the 70 passengers and crew on the Constellation were all killed. The pilots were flying in uncontrolled airspace; the crash was attributed to the pilots not seeing each other.
In just 60 seconds, 1.23 inches of rain fell in Unionville, Maryland. A world record.
The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus has its last performance under a tent in Pittsburgh, PA.
On land that would later become Hueston Woods State Park, an earthen dam is completed across Four Mile Creek, creating Acton Lake.
To meet a surge in demand for coal, the Pennsylvania Railroad employs J1 and leased Sante Fe 2-10-4s on the Sandusky branch between Columbus and Sandusky.
The deadline passes for the unifying elections set by the Geneva Conference. Diem, backed by the U.S., had refused to participate.
Novice Gail Fawcett appointed President of The Ohio State University
The last broadcast on the Dumont television network, a boxing match.
The Bell X-2 makes its last flight.

Norfolk and Western's experimental steam turbine #2300 The Jawn Henry arrives at Joyce avenue yard in Columbus at 12:20 pm after hauling 13,500 tons of coal from Portsmouth, Ohio. Engine leaves for Portsmouth pulling 175 empties at 3:32 pm.

Norfolk and Western's experimental steam turbine #2300 The Jawn Henry arrives at Joyce avenue yard in Columbus with a loaded coal train and departs with a string of empties. ItÕs the second trip to Columbus on N&W's Scioto Valley Division for the experimental loco.

Norfolk and Western's experimental steam turbine #2300 The Jawn Henry arrives at Joyce avenue yard in Columbus at 12:09 pm after hauling 13,500 tons of coal from Portsmouth, Ohio. Engine leaves for Portsmouth pulling 175 empties at 3:04 pm. This is its third and final visit to Columbus.
JUPITER-C Missile RS-27, a modified REDSTONE, achieved the first deep penetration of space with an altitude of more than 680 miles and a range of over 3,300 miles.
Worthington officially becomes a city with voters approving a charter providing for a city council/city manager government.
Cecile B. DeMille's The Ten Commandments is released to theaters. It is partly a remake of DeMille's 1923 silent film of the same name.
The battleship USS Oregon (BB-03), which has been on display as a museum in Oregon since 1925, is sold for scrap.
The Summer Olympics open in Melbourne, Australia.
CBS's Douglas Edwards and the News is the first television show to use tape delay, with an Ampex Quadruplex magnetic tape recorder.
Peasant unrest in North Vietnam resulting from oppressive land reforms is put down by Communist force with more than 6000 killed or deported.
The Montgomery Bus Boycott ends with the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling that buses must be integrated.
The first gorilla born in captivity, at the Columbus Zoo, named Colo

The TX-0, for Transistorized Experimental computer zero is an early fully transistorized computer and contained a then-huge 64K of 18-bit words of magnetic core memory. Built by MIT, it will be replaced with the TX-2 in 1958, and the PDP-1 in 1960.

In the Soviet Union, the Ural-1 computer is based on vacuum tubes (valves), with the hardware being able to perform 12,000 floating-point calculations per second. One word consisted of 40 bits and was able to contain either one numeric value or two instructions.
Moores & Ross created a new division, Ross Laboratories, to continue the development of Similac infant formulas.
Elvis Presley performs in Columbus for the first time.
WCBE, the Columbus Public Schools board-owned radio station, goes on the air.
OSU: Arps Hall, 1945 N. High St., has two additions built.
OSU: Drinko Hall, 55 W. 12th Ave., opens. Houses the law school & library.
OSU: St. John Arena, 410 Woody Hayes Drive, opens. Designed to accommodate 13,200 spectators for basketball games.
Columbus Union Station down to 42 daily trains.
Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant: Plant is fully operational.
Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis & Omaha leased by the Chicago & North Western.
William O'Neill inaugurated Governor of Ohio

The Soviet Union proposes permanent division of Vietnam into North and South, with the two nations admitted separately to the United Nations. The U.S. rejects the proposal, unwilling to recognize Communist North Vietnam.
Northeast Airlines Flight 823 crashes during a snowstorm shortly after takeoff from LaGuardia Airport killing 20.

The Asian flu starts in southwest China, possibly having originated in 1956 in Vladivostok, Russia, then spreads throughout the Pacific. Globally it affects 10 percent to 35 percent of the population, but overall mortality is much lower than in the 1918 epidemic, about 0.25 percent.
"The Mickey Mouse Club" premiers.
Alaska: An earthquake measuring 9.1 hit the Andreanof Islands. On Umnak Island, Mount Vsevidof erupted after being dormant for 200 years, generating a 15-metre high tsunami that continued to Hawaii.
Osama Bin Ladin is born in the Saudi Arabian city of Jeddah.
OSU: Mershon Auditorium, 1871 North High Street, opens.

The U.S. Army Ballistic Missile Agency, Redstone Arsenal, Ala., began studies of a large clustered-engine booster to generate 1.5 million pounds of thrust, as one of a related group of space vehicles. During 1957-1958, approximately 50,000 man-hours were expended in this effort.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy died from acute hepatitis in Bethesda Naval Hospital at the age of 48.

Diem pays a state visit to Washington where President Eisenhower labels him the "miracle man" of Asia and reaffirms U.S. commitment. "The cost of defending freedom, of defending America, must be paid in many forms and in many places...military as well as economic help is currently needed in Vietnam," Eisenhower states. Diem's government, however, with its main focus on security, spends little on schools, medical care or other badly needed social services in the countryside. Communist guerrillas and propagandists in the countryside capitalize on this by making simple promises of land reform and a better standard of living to gain popular support among peasants.
Oroville Dam groundbreaking.
PRR: Engine No. 1361, a K-4 class 4-6-2, is dedicated as a static display at Horseshoe Curve.
Hurricane: southwest La. and northern Tex.: Audrey wiped out Cameron, La., causing 390 deaths.
AMC manufacturers the last Hudson Hornet automobile.
The economy falls into recession.
Full scale production of the Ford Edsel begins.

Western 39 was a multi-stage flight on a route from Minneapolis to Salt Lake City to Cedar City to Las Vegas to Los Angeles. A passenger named Saul Binstock flew from Burbank, California, to Las Vegas and never left the airport terminal prior to boarding the Western Air Lines flight back to Los Angeles. The Convair CV-240 had just taken off carrying 16 people (13 passengers, 3 crew) when Binstock locked himself into the aft lavatory and set off a dynamite bomb. Though he was killed and the blast created a 6 x 7 ft (1.8 x 2.1 m) hole in the fuselage, the plane managed to land safely with no further injuries. Binstock had purchased two life insurance policies totaling $125,000 shortly before his suicide, and his body was found the next day with several fingers on his left hand missing.
"American Bandstand" premiers with host Dick Clark and guest Billy Williams & The Chordettes.
Nashville, Chattanooga & St. Louis merged into Lousiville & Nashville.
Premier episode of The Big Record, the first television show broadcast in color for the entire 1957-1958 season.

The Kyshtym disaster occurred in Ozyorsk, Chelyabinsk Oblast, a closed city built around the Mayak plant when a tank of high level nuclear waste exploded. The disaster spread hot particles over more than 52,000 square kilometres (20,000 sq mi), where at least 270,000 people lived.
The Soviet Union launches Sputnik I, the world's first artificial satellite, using an R-7 rocket.

Jupiter-C Missile RS-40 a modified redstone, was successfully launched. Its nose cone was the first to be recovered from outer space. The nose cone carried the first missile mail ever delivered over intermediate range ballistic missile (IRBM) range.
The keel is laid for the 666 foot, 14,000 ton Adam E. Cornelius III in Manitowoc, WI.
Viet Minh guerrillas begin a widespread campaign of terror in South Vietnam including bombings and assassinations. By year's end, over 400 South Vietnamese officials are killed.
Miles Davis releases "Miles Ahead"

The Straights of Mackinac bridge, linking the lower and upper peninsulas of Michigan, opens to traffic. It will remain the longest suspension bridge in the world from cable anchor to cable anchor until 1998.
The Secretary of Defense directed that DA modify two JUPITER-C missiles (modified REDSTONEs) and attempt to place an artificial earth satellite in orbit by March 58.
Clarence George Issenmann appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.

The Army Ballistic Missile Agency completed and forwarded to higher authority the first edition of A National Integrated Missile and Space Vehicle Development Program, which had been in preparation since April 1957. Included was a "short-cut development program" for large payload capabilities, covering the clustered-engine booster of 1.5 million pounds of thrust to be operational in 1963. The total development cost of $850 million during the years 1958-1963 covered 30 research and development flights, some carrying manned and unmanned space payloads. One of six conclusions given in the document was that "Development of the large (1520 K-pounds thrust) booster is considered the key to space exploration and warfare." Later vehicles with greater thrust were also described
Saturn I first proposed. Von Braun produces 'Proposal for a National Integrated Missile and Space Vehicle Development Plan'. First mention of 1,500,000 lbf booster (Saturn I).
Von Braun produces 'Proposal for a National Integrated Missile and Space Vehicle Development Plan'. First mention of 1,500,000 lbf booster (Saturn I)
Norfolk and Western's experimental steam turbine #2300 The Jawn Henry is removed from service after its turbine is destroyed by a loose packing seal. The engine was subsequently scrapped.

A team of employees at the North American Aviation plant adapt the Navaho missile's navigation system for submarine use. The submarine Nautilus uses this system to navigate under the North Pole in 1958.
Burger King introduces the Whopper; charges $0.37.
James Thurber publishes "The Wonderful O"
The Secret Santa fund is founded to provide new toys for needy children.
OSU: Baker Hall dormitory, 93 and 129 West 12th Ave, west wing added.
OSU: Kinnear Road Center, 1099, 1121 & 1125 Kinnear Rd., buildings B & D open. Built by the Mid-West Volkswagen distributorship and sold to the Ohio College Library Center (OCLC) in 1975.
OSU: Smith Laboratory of Physics, 174 W. 18th Ave., addition.
Hueston Woods becomes a State Park.
Columbus & Southern Electric Company #2 donated and moved to Ohio Railway Museum.
Kansas City Public service Company #068 donated and moved to Ohio Railway Museum.
St. Michael Church in Worthington rectory with a three room office wing and a two-car garage was completed, replacing a leased house that served as rectory at 28 W. Stanton Ave.
St. John's sells the 80-acre farm reserved by the Scioto Company to support Episcopal Church to developers for Kilbourne Village subdivision.
AEP: The Philo plant on the Muskingum River installs unit #6, which operates at 1150 deg F and 4000 PSI with a single unit producing a record 107 MW. The plant now has a capacity of 495 MW.
OSU goes to the Rose Bowl and beats Oregon State, 10-7.
Litchfield & Madison merged into Chicago & Northwestern.
The Bell X-1/A/B/D makes its last flight.
ABMA successfully launched JUPITER-C Missile RS-29, a modified REDSTONE, which placed EXPLORER I--the first U.S. satellite--into earth orbit.
Explorer I launched. First American satellite.
The economy stops shrinking and starts growing again.

Johnny Mathis' album, "Johnny's Greatest Hits", on Columbia Records, made it to the pop music charts for the first time. The LP remained on the charts for a record 490 weeks (nearly 9-1/2 years!) The record began its stay at number one (three weeks) on June 9, 1958.
The Bell X-1E makes its last flight.
The Straights of Mackinac Bridge is formally dedicated.
A coordinated command structure is formed by Communists in the Mekong Delta where 37 armed companies are being organized.
Congress enacts legislation to allow the states to extend unemployment benefits.
ARPA gives Von Braun team contract to develop Saturn I (called 'cluster's last stand' due to design concept).
A REDSTONE missile was fired to an altitude in excess of 200,000 feet and a nuclear device of a megaton was detonated. This was the first such accomplishment by the United States.

The Advanced Research Projects Agency ARPA provided the Army Ordnance Missile Command (AOMC) with authority and initial funding to develop the Juno V (later named Saturn launch vehicle. ARPA Order 14 described the project: "Initiate a development program to provide a large space vehicle booster of approximately 1.5 million pounds of thrust based on a cluster of available rocket engines. The immediate goal of this program is to demonstrate a full-scale captive dynamic firing by the end of calendar year 1959." Within AOMC, the Juno V project was assigned to the Army Ballistic Missile Agency at Redstone Arsenal Huntsville, Ala.
Saturn design studies authorized to proceed at Redstone Arsenal for development of 1.5-million-pound-thrust cluster first stage.
A letter contract was signed by NASA with NAA's Rocketdyne Division for the development of the H-1 rocket engine, designed for use in a clustered-engine booster.

Letter contract for the development of the Saturn H-1 rocket engine A letter contract was signed by NASA with NAA's Rocketdyne Division for the development of the H-1 rocket engine, designed for use in a clustered-engine booster.
Jack Kilby at Texas Instruments successfully demonstrated the first working integrated circuit.
The new $4 million terminal building at Port Columbus Airport was dedicated and passengers boarded Piedmont Airlines Flight 90 bound for Parkersburg, West Virginia in a DC-3.
AEP announces it will move its headquarters from Church Street to a new building at 2 Broadway, a half-mile south, which Sporn called a “strikingly handsome building.”
Union Pacific gains control of Spokane International.

The new National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) announced Project Mercury, its first major undertaking. The objectives were threefold: to place a human spacecraft into orbital flight around Earth, observe human performance in such conditions, and recover the human and the spacecraft safely.
The telegraph office in the yard office of the T&OC at 1094 McKinley Ave. was closed
33 men died on Lake Michigan with the sinking of the Carl D. Bradley.
Saturn H-1 engine first full-power firing The H-1 engine successfully completed its first full-power firing at NAA's Rocketdyne facility in Canoga Park, Calif.
American Gas and Electric changes its name to American Electric Power.
Borden, Inc. renames its growing chemical operation Borden Chemical Company.
The first International House of Pancakes opens in Toluca Lake, California.
Columbus city income tax in effect.
The Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric building on N. Front Street opens, Columbus' first modern, glass skyscraper.
WMNI Radio begins broadcasting.
OSU: Caldwell Lab, 2024 Neil Ave., addition.
OSU: Larkins Hall, 337 W. 17th Ave., library renovated to house Naval ROTC.
Worthington Presbyterian Church demolishes the remaining portions of the original 1829 church to install an addition.
Castro leads Cuba to victory as Fulgencio Batista flees to Dominican Republic.
Luna I becomes the first man made object to escape earth's gravity. Misses the moon and goes into orbit around the sun.
Alaska becomes a state.
Michael V. Disalle inaugurated Governor of Ohio
NASA issued a request to ABMA for eight REDSTONE missiles to be used in PROJECT MERCURY.
The Olentangy River crests at 15.68 feet in Worthington, an all time record.
A huge flood displaces 2000 people from their homes. Millions in damage on the East and West sides of Columbus.
Booster name changed from Juno V to Saturn The Army proposed that the name of the large clustered-engine booster be changed from Juno V to Saturn, since Saturn was the next planet after Jupiter.

The Army proposed that the name of the large clustered-engine booster be changed from Juno V to Saturn, since Saturn was the next planet after Jupiter. Roy W. Johnson, Director of the Advanced Research Projects Agency, approved the name on February 3.
First launch of a Titan 1 by the Air Force. Only the first stage is fired with a dummy for the 2nd stage. It reaches 50 miles in altitude and 200 miles down range.
The USAF launched its first test Titan I missile.
The Soviet Union's first strategic-missile unit became operational at Plesetsk in north-west Russia.
Second launch of a Titan 1 with a dummy first stage.
Pioneer 4 launched. First American deep space probe. Passed within 37,300 miles of the moon.

The armed revolution begins as Ho Chi Minh declares a People's War to unite all of Vietnam under his leadership. His Politburo now orders a changeover to an all-out military struggle. Thus begins the Second Indochina War.
Third launch of a Titan 1 with a dummy first stage.

At a press conference in Washington, D.C., on April 9, 1959, NASA introduced the Mercury Seven to the public, Scott Carpenter, L. Gordon Cooper, Jr., John H. Glenn, Jr., Virgil I. "Gus" Grissom, Walter M. Schirra, Jr., Alan B. Shepard, Jr., and Donald K. "Deke" Slayton.

Flying between the Mexican cities of Mexicale and Guaymas, a Curtiss C-46 carrying 26 people (21 passengers, 5 crew) crashed near Puerto Kino. The plane had exploded and caught fire in mid-air, and it is believed that a bomb was the cause.
The keel is laid for the 730 foot, 12,000 ton Edward L. Ryerson in Manitowoc, WI.
Construction begins on the Tōkaidō Shinkansen, the first high speed rail line in Japan.

The St. Lawrence Seaway opens for shipping, linking the Atlantic Ocean to the Great Lakes. Overall, the project cost 470 million US dollars of which $336.2 million were paid by Canada and $133.8 million by the United States. Income from the operating the Seaway is thus shared accordingly.

The first Rocketdyne H-1 engine for the Saturn arrived at the Army Ballistic Missile Agency (ABMA ). The H-1 engine was installed in the ABMA test stand on May 7, first test-fired on May 21, and fired for 80 seconds on May 29. The first long-duration firing - 151.03 seconds - was on June 2.
Fourth and final launch of a Titan 1 with a dummy first stage.
First successful static firing of an H1 rocket engine for the Saturn I rocket.

North Vietnamese establish the Central Office of South Vietnam (COSVN) to oversee the coming war in the South. Construction of the Ho Chi Minh trail now begins. The trail will eventually expand into a 1500 mile-long network of jungle and mountain passes extending from North Vietnam's coast along Vietnam's western border through Laos, parts of Cambodia, funneling a constant stream of soldiers and supplies into the highlands of South Vietnam. In 1959, it takes six months to make the journey, by 1968 it will take only six weeks due to road improvements by North Vietnamese laborers, many of whom are women. In the 1970s a parallel fuel pipeline will be added.
Construction of the first Saturn launch area, Complex 34, began at Cape Canaveral, FIa.
The Manitowoc Shipyard delivers the Adam E. Cornelius III to the American Steamship Company.
The North American X-15 makes its first flight.
The official opening ceremonies of the St. Lawrence Seaway are held in the presence of Queen Elizabeth II (representing Canada) and President Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Two U.S. military advisors, Maj. Dale Buis and Sgt. Chester Ovnand, are killed by Viet Minh guerrillas at Bien Hoa, South Vietnam. They are the first American deaths in the Second Indochina War which Americans will come to know simply as The Vietnam War.
The Pennsylvania Railroad takes its last steam engine out of service, an 0-6-0 Switcher number 5244.
4000 Viet Minh guerrillas, originally born in the South, are sent from North Vietnam to infiltrate South Vietnam.
"Bonanza" premiers.

The first attempt to launch a Titan 1 with a live second stage ends in disaster when the missile was released from LC-19 before it had built up sufficient thrust. Liftoff thus occurred 3.9 seconds earlier than intended, causing one of the pad umbilicals to be prematurely jerked free as the missile lifted. Another umbilical sent an automatic cutoff command and the Titan fell back onto the pad.
Miles Davis releases "Kind of Blue", considered by many Jazz Critics to be a masterpiece of both the artist and the genre.
Hawaii becomes a state.
Darby Creek Metro Park established.

A Douglas DC-3 carrying 16 people (13 passengers, 3 crew) took off from Mexico City bound for Merida, Mexico. During flight, a detonation in the passenger cabin started a fire and forced an emergency landing at Poza Rica. A male passenger was suspected of carrying the bomb aboard, and he was the only fatality after he was blown from the plane at an altitude of 11,000 ft (3,350 m).
Eddie Rickenbacker forced out of the CEO spot at Eastern Airlines, in part because of his refusal to replace prop planes with jets.
"The Twilight Zone" premiers.

After a meeting with officials concerned with the missile and space program, President Dwight D. Eisenhower announced that he intended to transfer to NASA control the Army Ballistic Missile Agency's Development Operations Division personnel and facilities. The transfer, subject to congressional approval, would include the Saturn development program.
President Eisenhower announced his intention of transferring the Saturn project to NASA, which became effective on March 15, 1960.

National Airlines Flight 967 crashes into the Gulf of Mexico while on a flight from Tampa to New Orleans; reportedly caused by a bomb planted on the aircraft by Dr. Richard Spears in an attempt to collect insurance on one of the passengers. Spears was never charged due to lack of evidence. All 42 onboard were presumed killed in the accident.
Ford ends production of the Edsel automobile.
The Columbus Citizen and Ohio State Journal merge to form the Columbus Citizen Journal.
Virginian merged into Norfolk and Western.
The second attempt to launch a Titan 1 with a live second stage ends in disaster when vibration trips the self destruct system relay and the rocket explodes on the pad.
Charleston & Western Carolina merged into Atlantic Coastline.

The IBM 7090 is a second-generation transistorized version of the earlier IBM 709 vacuum tube mainframe computer that was designed for "large-scale scientific and technological applications". The 7090 uses a 36-bit word length, with an address space of 32,768 words (15-bit addresses). It operates with a basic memory cycle of 2.18 μs, using the IBM 7302 Core Storage core memory technology.

Ross Laboratories introduces Similac¨ With Iron, the first iron-fortified infant formula in the U.S. It came in both powder and concentrated liquid forms. Today, iron-fortified formula is the preferred source of nutrition during the first year of life if breastfeeding is not chosen.
The first xerographic copy machine comes on the market.
Golda May Edmonston becomes the first woman elected to Columbus City Council, later becoming the first female council president and acting mayor.
OSU: Drinko Hall, 55 W. 12th Ave., addition. Houses the law school & library.
OSU: Hopkins Hall, 128 N. Oval Mall, opens. Houses the Departments of Art and Art Education.
OSU: Lord Hall, 124 W. 17th Ave., a fire destroys part of the roof.

A Douglas DC-6B flying from New York City to Miami, Florida, disintegrated in mid-air and crashed in North Carolina, killing all 34 aboard (29 passengers, 5 crew). The aircraft apparently crashed due to the detonation of a dynamite bomb in the vicinity of row 7. It is believed that a passenger named Julian Frank committed suicide when he set off the bomb in his lap or under his seat. Frank was under investigation for fraud and embezzlement and had purchased life insurance policies worth $1 million before the crash.
COLUMBUS' NEW SERVICE DIRECTOR, ERNEST STORK, PROMISES TO FIGHT TO KEEP THE PROPOSED COLS OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY OUTSIDE GAHANNA AND DUBLIN AND ON THE NORTH SIDE OF WORTHINGTON.
Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe and Pennsylvania Railroad gain joint control of Teledo, Peoria & Western.
The Hartman Theatre, on E. State Street, hosts the world premiere of the Thurber Carnival.
OSU: Bolz Hall, 2036 Neil Avenue Mall, opens as a Department of Civil Engineering classroom building.
The Titan I missile has its first successful flight with a live second stage after the previous two attempts resulted in explosions on the launch pad.
The second attempt at a Lot C Titan I launch failed at T+52 seconds when the guidance compartment collapsed, causing the RVX-3 reentry vehicle to separate
France conducts its first nuclear weapons test in Algeria.
CONSTRUCTON OF THE COLUMBUS-CINCINNATI SECTION OF OHIO'S PROPOSED NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY IS TABLED INDEFINITELY.

Eleven companies submitted contract proposals for the Saturn second stage (S-IV): Bell Aircraft Corporation; The Boeing Airplane Company; Chrysler Corporation; General Dynamics Corporation, Convair Astronautics Division; Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc.; Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation; Lockheed Aircraft Corporation; The Martin Company; McDonnell Aircraft Corporation; North American Aviation, Inc.; and United Aircraft Corporation.
The German Village Society is formed.
OSU: Denney Hall, 164 W. 17th Ave., opens. Houses the College of Arts and Sciences and the English Department.
CHANCES ARE SLIM THAT AN 81-MILE STRETCH OF OHIO'S NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY BETWEEN COLS AND RT 18 WILL BE OPEN THIS SUMMER, DUE TO BAD WEATHER AND FINANCIAL DIFFICULTIES.
THE SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO DISCLOSES PLANS FOR A SECOND COLUMBUS STORE IN A PROPOSED 277-ACRE SHOPPING CENTER NORTHEAST OF MORSE RD AND THE NORTH FREEWAY (Northland).

The Army Ballistic Missile Agency's Development Operations Division and the Saturn program were transferred to NASA after the expiration of the 60-day limit for congressional action on the President's proposal of January 14. (The President's decision had been made on October 21, 1959.) By Executive Order, the President named the facilities the "George C. Marshall Space Flight Center." Formal transfer took place on July 1.
The Ohio State University basketball team wins the NCAA championship
Two of Saturn's first-stage engines passed initial static firing test of 7.83 seconds duration at Huntsville, Ala.
Miles Davis releases "Sketches of Spain"
The first U.S. weather satellite was launched. "TIROS I" was put into orbit and soon meteorologists saw the first pictures of a midlatitude cyclone over the northeastern United States.
Four of the eight H-1 engines of the Saturn C-1 first-stage booster were successfully static-fired at Redstone Arsenal for seven seconds.
NASA announced the selection of the Douglas Aircraft Company to build the second stage (S-IV) of the Saturn C-1 launch vehicle.

All eight H-1 engines of the Saturn C-1 first stage ground-tested simultaneously At Redstone Arsenal, all eight H-1 engines of the first stage of the Saturn C-1 launch vehicle were static-fired simultaneously for the first time and achieved 1.3 million pounds of thrust.

Eighteen distinguished nationalists in South Vietnam send a petition to President Diem advocating that he reform his rigid, family-run, and increasingly corrupt, government. Diem ignores their advice and instead closes several opposition newspapers and arrests journalists and intellectuals.
Universal military conscription is imposed in North Vietnam. Tour of duty is indefinite.
THE BELL SOUND DIVISION OF THOMPSON, RAMO, WOOLDRIDGE, INC, 555 MARION RD, ANNOUNCES PLANS TO BUILD A NEW MANUFACTURING PLANT ON HUNTLEY RD, WORTHINGTON
CONSTRUCTION OF THE 80-MILE STRETCH OF THE NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY EXTENDING NORTH OF COLS IS BESET WITH DELAYS; COMPLETION BY THE AUG 15TH DEADLINE DOUBTFUL.
SS France launched. 66343 tons, 1037 ft, 175000 hp, 2044 passengers.
RACKOFF ASSOCIATES, CONSULTING ENGINEERS, SAY THE EAST FREEWAY WILL COST $30 MILLION, AN INCREASE OF $10 MILLION OVER PREVIOUS PLANS, AND WILL HAVE SIX LANES INSTEAD OF FOUR.
COLUMBUS MEMBERS OF THE TRANSPORT WORKERS UNION JOIN A SYSTEM-WIDE WORK STOPPAGE ON THE PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD; THE MOVE HAS NO IMMEDIATE EFFECT ON RAILROAD OPERATIONS.
Chile: An earthquake measuring 9.5 struck Santiago and Concepcion, triggering tidal waves and volcanic eruptions. Some 5,000 people were killed and 2 million made homeless.
EARL HENSON, 38, J P MEREDITH, AND G W STEELE ARE INJURED WHEN LOOSE RAILROAD CARS DEMOLISH A SMALL OFFICE BUILDING AT PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD YARD B ALONG SUNBURY RD.
Assembly of the first Saturn flight booster, SA-1, began at Marshall Space Flight Center.

Eight H-1 engines of the first stage of the Saturn C-1 launch vehicle were static-fired for 35.16 seconds, producing 1.3 million pounds of thrust. This first public demonstration of the H-1 took place at Marshall Space Flight Center.
DR ROBERT SMITHWOOD, 35, OF 814 GRISWOLD ST, WORTHINGTON, A PHYSICIAN ASSOCIATED WITH THE HARDING SANITARIUM, DIES OF HODGKIN'S DISEASE
50,000th Bridgeport Miller came off the assembly line
Complete eight-engine static firing of Saturn successfully conducted for 110 seconds at MSFC, the longest firing to date.
SEARS INVITES LAZARUS TO BUILD A STORE ON THE SEARS TRACT ON MORSE ROAD, BUT LAZARUS HAS NOT ACCEPTED THE INVITATION.

Saturn C-1 first stage completed test series The Saturn C-1 first stage successfully completed its first series of static tests at the Marshall Space Flight Center with a 122-second firing of all eight H-1 engines.
The Saturn C-1 first stage successfully completed its first series of static tests at the Marshall Space Flight Center with a 122-second firing of all eight H-1 engines.
The El Rancho Las Vegas burns. This first modern Las Vegas casino was not rebuilt.
First concrete poured at the Glen Canyon Dam.
An upper deck for automobiles is added to the S.S. Badger.

LC-20 hosted its first Titan I launch when Missile J-2, an operational prototype, was flown. Unfortunately, a broken hydraulic line caused the Titan's engines to gimbal hard left almost as soon as the tower was cleared. The missile pitched over and flew onto a near-horizontal plane when Range Safety sent the destruct command at T+11 seconds. The burning remains of the Titan impacted 300 meters from the pad in an enormous fireball. The piece of plumbing responsible for the missile failure was retrieved—it had popped out of its sleeve resulting in loss of first stage hydraulic pressure.
ABOUT 100 LAYOFFS MADE BY THE PENNYSYLVANIA RAILROAD ARE PART OF A COMPANY-WIDE PROGRAM OF FURLOUGHS ACCORDING TO A COLUMBUS SPOKESMAN.
COLUMBUS LOSES ITS FIGHT TO PREVENT THE NEW YORK CENTRAL RAILROAD CO FROM DISCONTINUING TRAIN NO 321 BETWEEN COLUMBUS AND CINCINNATI .
"The Dick Van Dyke Show" premiers.
38 CARS IN AN 88-CAR PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD FREIGHT TRAIN DERAIL AND TEAR UP HALF A MILE OF TRACKS BETWEEN TRABUE AND ROBERTS ROADS.
The Manitowoc Shipyard delivers the Edward L. Ryerson to the Inland Steel Company. It is the last lake freighter built in Manitowoc.
AN 80-MILE SECTION OF THE STATE'S NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY BETWEEN RTS 161, NORTH OF COLUMBUS, AND 18, NEAR MEDINA, OPENS FOR TRAFFIC.

Joseph Kittinger jumps out of a balloon at an altitude of 102,800. Using a drogue parachute for stabilization, he fell for 14-1/2 minutes and reached a maximum speed of 614 mph before opening his parachute at 14,000 feet. He set records for highest balloon ascent, highest parachute jump, longest drogue-fall (14 min), and fastest speed by a human through the atmosphere
The Summer Olympics open in Rome, Italy.
Hurricane: Fla. to New England: Donna killed 50 in the U.S.; 115 deaths in Antilles, mostly from flash floods in Puerto Rico.
Big Bear opens its "Store of the Future" at Graceland Shopping Center. It is the largest supermarket in the state of Ohio.
