The Southern gains control of Central of Georgia, includes control of Savannah & Atlanta.
MEMBERS OF LOCAL 2005 OF THE TRANSPORT WORKERS UNION PICKET UNION STATION AS THE TWU STRIKE SHUTS DOWN THE PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD FOR THE FIRST TIME IN THE RAILROAD'S HISTORY.
THE UNION DEPOT CO ACCUSES THE TRANSPORT WORKERS UNION OF CONTEMPT OF A COURT ORDER ISSUED TO POST NOTICES OF THE RESTRAINING ORDER OBTAINED BY THE DEPOT CO.
THE TRANSPORT WORKERS UNION ANNOUNCES PLANS TO PICKET PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD SIGNAL TOWERS RUN BY THE ORDER OF RAILROAD TELEGRAPHERS.
The Denver Broncos play their first regular season game, defeating the Boston Patriots 13-10.
The New England Patriots play their first regular season game, losing to the Denver Broncos 13-10.
The San Diego Chargers play their first regular season game, defeating the Dallas Cowboys 21-20.
The Buffalo Bills play their first regular season game, losing to the New York Titans 27-3.
The New York Titans (later to become the Jets) play their first regular season game, defeating the Buffalo Bills 27-3.
The Oakland Raiders play their first regular season game, losing to the Houston Oilers 37-22.
U S DISTRICT COURT CLEARS THE WAY FOR A REFERENDUM VOTE NOV 8 IN WORTHINGTON ON AN ORDINANCE REZONING TWO TRACTS NORTH OF THE METHODIST CHILDREN'S HOME.
NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON A SETTLEMENT ENDING THE 12-DAY-OLD STRIKE THAT HAD SHUT DOWN THE PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD FOR THE FIRST TIME IN 114 YEARS OF OPERATION.
THE PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD WILL RESUME PASSENGER SERVICE OUT OF COLUMBUS WITH THE DEPARTURE OF THE SPIRIT OF ST LOUIS.
The Dallas Cowboys play their first regular season game, losing to the Pittsburgh Steelers 35-28.
"The Flintstones" premiers.
"The Andy Griffith Show" premiers.
Comedian George Carlin makes his first television appearance with his partner Jack Burns on the (Jack Paar) Tonight Show.
Delaware, Lackawanna & Western and Erie merge creating Erie-Lackawanna.
The Chicago Cardinals move to St. Louis and play their first regular season game, defeating the L.A. Rams 43-21.

A Soviet R-16 missile explodes on the pad, killing at least 100 workers and Mitrofan Ivanovich Nedelin, the chief of the project. A short circuit in the replaced main sequencer caused the second-stage engine to fire while being tested before launch. This detonated the first stage fuel tanks directly below, destroying the missile in an enormous explosion.
A Titan I missile sets a distance record of 6100 miles.
FIVE COMPANIES CLAIM THAT THE PROPOSED $30 MIL EAST FREEWAY WILL MAKE THEIR PROPERTIES ALONG ALUM CREEK USELESS; THEY ARE THE ONLY ONES TO QUESTION THE RIGHT-OF-WAY ALIGNMENT.
Norfolk & Western gains control of Atlantic & Danville and renames it Norfolk, Franklin & Danville.
Minneapolis & St. Louis merged into Chicago & Northwestern.
Chrysler discontinues the DeSoto brand, replacing it with the Chrysler Newport.

DEC delivered the first PDP-1 to Bolt, Beranek and Newman (BBN). The PDP-1 uses 2,700 transistors and 3,000 diodes.[4] It is built mostly of DEC 1000-series System Building Blocks, using micro-alloy and micro-alloy diffused transistors with a rated switching speed of 5 MHz. The System Building Blocks are packaged into several 19-inch racks, and weighs 1,600 lbs.

A failed coup against President Diem by disgruntled South Vietnamese Army officers brings a harsh crackdown against all perceived 'enemies of the state.' Over 50,000 are arrested by police controlled by Diem's brother Nhu with many innocent civilians tortured then executed. This results in further erosion of popular support for Diem. Thousands who fear arrest flee to North Vietnam. Ho Chi Minh will later send many back to infiltrate South Vietnam as part of his People's Liberation Armed Forces. Called Viet Cong by Diem, meaning Communist Vietnamese, Ho's guerrillas blend into the countryside, indistinguishable from South Vietnamese, while working to undermine Diem's government.
First of new series of static firings of Saturn considered only 50 percent successful in 2-second test at MSFC.
Hilliard achieves city status with a population of 5,633.

Palaemon, a 180-foot barge built to transport the Saturn launch vehicle from MSFC to Cape Canaveral by water, was formally accepted by MSFC Director from Maj. Gen. Frank S. Besson, Chief of Army Transportation.
Mercury-Redstone 1 (MR-1) was successfully launched, proving the system's operational capabilities in a space environment.
The National Liberation Front is established by Hanoi as its Communist political organization for Viet Cong guerrillas in South Vietnam.
After the addition of parking garages and warehouses southwest of the store, Lazarus adds 300,000 square feet.
OSU: Evans Lab, 88 W. 18th Ave., opens.
OSU: Fry Hall, 338 W. 10th Ave., addition. Serves as the Optometry Building.
OSU: Koffolt Laboratories, 140 W. 19th Ave., opens. Department of Chemical Engineering.
OSU: Maintenance Building, 2000 Tuttle Park Place, opens.
OSU: The Animal Science Building, 2029 Fyffe Road, opens.
OSU: Wiseman Hall, 400 & 410 West 12th Ave., opens.
Land acquisition is begun for Salt Fork State Park.
Worthington's population is 9,239.
Duluth, South Shore & Atlantic, Minneapolis, St. Paul & Sault St. Marie and Wisconsin Central merge creating SOO line.
1st AFL Championship Game, Houston Oilers beat Los Angeles Chargers 24-16.
A NEW YORK CITY ENGINEERING FIRM RECOMMENDS THE NORTHERN LINE OF THE PROPOSED COLUMBUS OUTERBELT TO BE LOCATED SOUTH OF WORTHINGTON.
"Mister Ed" premiers.
FRANKLIN COUNTY REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION APPROVES CONSULTANT'S RECOMMENDED ROUTE FOR PROPOSED OUTERBELT HIGHWAY NORTH OF MORSE RD.
John Fitzgerald Kennedy inaugurated as President.
COMMON PLEAS JUDGE HENRY HOLDEN CLEARS WAY FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE NORTHLAND SHOPPING CENTER ON MORSE ROAD AT KARL ROAD.
"One Hundred and One Dalmations" by Walt Disney released.

Wernher von Braun, Director of Marshall Space Flight Center, proposed that the Saturn C-1 launch vehicle be changed from a three-stage to a two-stage configuration to meet Apollo program schedules. The planned third stage (S-V) would be dropped
SERVICE DIRECTOR ERNEST STORK SAYS THAT ROUTING OF THE PROPOSED OUTERBELT SOUTH OF WORTHINGTON WOULD LEAVE NORTHERN SECTION OF COLS WITH NO RELIEF FROM HEAVY TRUCK-TRAFFIC.
The second Mercury-Redstone (MR-2) test flight carried a chimpanzee named Ham into space.
PTA OF THE SCHOOL FOR THE BLIND PLANS TO TAKE ITS CASE AGAINST THE PROPOSED LOCATION OF THE OUTERBELT THROUGH SCHOOL GROUNDS, GOES BEFORE THE STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION.
The Kahiki restaurant at 3583 E. Broad St. opens.

Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev pledges support for "wars of national liberation" throughout the world. His statement greatly encourages Communists in North Vietnam to escalate their armed struggle to unify Vietnam under Ho Chi Minh.
A CROWD OF 400 NORTH SIDE RESIDENTS AND THEIR WESTERN NEIGHBORS TAKE EXCEPTION TO ARGUMENTS FOR LOCATING THE OUTERBELT SOUTH OF WORTHINGTON.
EVERETT PRESTON, DIRECTOR OF THE OHIO DEPT OF HIGHWAYS, REVEALS THAT THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT WILL BE ROUTED NORTH OF WORTHINGTON IF THAT IS WHERE THE CITY OF COLUMBUS WANTS IT.
FIVE-MAN COMMITTEE OF THE STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION UNANIMOUSLY OBJECTS TO LOCATING NORTHERN LEG OF CITY'S OUTERBELT THROUGH THE STATE SCHOOLS FOR THE BLIND AND DEAF GROUNDS.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY IS DELUGED BY LETTERS PROTESTING THE ROUTE OF THE OUTERBELT DIVIDING THE STATE DEAF AND BLIND SCHOOLS WITH A SIXLANE HIGHWAY THROUGH ITS GROUNDS.
First flight model of Saturn booster (SA-1) installed on static test stand for preflight checkout, Marshall Space Flight Center, Huntsville.
THE CITY PLANNING COMMISSION VOTES 3-2 TO APPROVE A ROUTE NORTH OF WORTHINGTON FOR THE NORTHERN HALF OF THE $104 MILLION OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY.
DEMOCRATIC CITY COUNCILMEN ROBERT L VAN HEYDE AND ROBERT H SMITH LEAVE NO DOUBT THEY FAVOR AN OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY ROUTE THROUGH THE GROUNDS OF THE SCHOOLS OF THE DEAF AND BLIND.
DONALD R KNISELY, 32, 2950 WESTMOOR DR, IS KILLED WHEN THE PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD'S "SPIRIT OF ST LOUIS" SMASHES HIS CAR AT THE N HAGUE AVE CROSSING.
CITY COUNCIL DEMOCRATS WANT A ROUTE SOUTH OF WORTHINGTON FOR THE OUTERBELT BUT WON'T COME OUT DEFINITELY FOR A ROUTE THROUGH THE STATE SCHOOLS FOR THE DEAF AND BLIND.
Yuri Gagarin becomes the first man to orbit the earth in Vostok I.
The first successful flight qualification test of the Saturn SA-1 booster took place in an eight-engine test lasting 30 seconds.
Mercury-Redstone 3: Alan B. Shepard, Jr, 15 minutes, 28 seconds, Suborbital flight that successfully put the first American in space.

A Lockheed 1649A Starliner operated by Air France was carrying 78 people (69 passengers, 9 crew) on a flight from Brazzaville, Congo, to Paris, France. During a leg from Chad to Marseilles, the aircraft crashed into the Sahara Desert in Libya killing all aboard. The cause of the crash was traced to a nitrocellulose bomb that detonated in mid-air.
THE CITY AIRPORT COMMISSION SUPPORTS EFFORTS TO MOVE THE PROPOSED ROUTE FOR THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY AT LEAST A MILE AWAY FROM PORT COLUMBUS.
COLUMBUS CITY PLANNING COMMISSION REJECTS A SUBDIVISION ON JAMES RD, NORTH OF PETZINGER RD, AND PLANS TO PURCHASE THE LAND FOR THE EAST FREEWAY PROJECT.

Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson visits President Diem in South Vietnam and hails the embattled leader as the 'Winston Churchill of Asia.' President Kennedy sends 400 American Green Beret 'Special Advisors' to South Vietnam to train South Vietnamese soldiers in methods of 'counter-insurgency' in the fight against Viet Cong guerrillas. The role of the Green Berets soon expands to include the establishment of Civilian Irregular Defense Groups (CIDG) made up of fierce mountain men known as the Montagnards. These groups establish a series of fortified camps strung out along the mountains to thwart infiltration by North Vietnamese.

Collapse of a lock in the Wheeler Dam below Huntsville on the Tennessee River interdicted the planned water route of the first Saturn space booster from Marshall Space Flight Center to Cape Canaveral on the barge Palaemon.

Huge Saturn launch complex at Cape Canaveral dedicated in brief ceremony by NASA, construction of which was supervised by the Army Corps of Engineers. Giant gantry, weighing 2,800 tons and being 310 feet high, is largest movable land structure in North America.
MAYOR WESTLAKE'S CITY ADMINISTRATION, STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION, BLIND AND DEAF SCHOOL PTAS AND OTHER GROUPS FAVOR THE ROUTE NORTH OF WORTHINGTON FOR PROPOSED COLS OUTERBELT.
RECOMMENDATIONS FOR AN OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY NORTH OF WORTHINGTON AND SEVERAL EAST-WEST CROSS-TOWN ROUTES ARE PART OF A MASTER PLAN PREPARED BY A ST LOUIS, MO, PLANNING FIRM.
THE BILL TO PERMIT CONSTRUCTION OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT THROUGH THE STATE SCHOOLS OF THE BLIND AND DEAF IS HAVING TROUBLE FINDING A SPONSOR IN THE OHIO SENATE.
GOV MICHAEL DISALLE SPEAKS AGAINST A BILL INTRODUCED BY SENATOR ROBERT R SHAW WHICH WOULD GIVE HIM POWER TO DECIDE PLACEMENT OF THE PROPOSED COLUMBUS OUTERBELT.
A Navy YFNB barge was obtained by NASA to serve as a replacement for the Palaemon in transporting of the Saturn booster to Cape Canaveral.
Mercury-Redstone 4: Virgil I. Grissom, 15 minutes, 37 seconds, Also suborbital; successful flight but the spacecraft sank shortly after splashdown. Last manned flight of a Redstone Rocket.
A PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD EXECUTIVE PROPOSES REMOVAL OF COLUMBUS' UNION STATION FROM ITS PRESENT N HIGH ST SITE TO A LOCATION ADJACENT TO THE SPRING-SANDUSKY INTERCHANGE.
CIVIC LEADERS HAIL THE PROPOSED RELOCATION OF UNION STATION BY PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD AS A TREMENDOUS BOOST FOR DOWNTOWN COLUMBUS DEVELOPMENT.

NASA invited 12 companies to submit prime contractor proposals for the Apollo spacecraft by October 9: The Boeing Airplane Company, Chance Vought Corporation, Douglas Aircraft Company, General Dynamics/Convair, the General Electric Company, Goodyear Aircraft Corporation, Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, McDonnell Aircraft Corporation, The Martin Company, North American Aviation, Inc., and Republic Aviation Corporation.
First Saturn (SA-1) booster began water trip to Cape Canaveral on Navy barge Compromise after overland detour around Wheeler Dam.
Gherman Titov becomes the second man to orbit the earth in Vostok II.
THE NEW YORK CENTRAL RAILROAD SEEKS PERMISSION TO DISCONTINUE 2 PASSENGER TRAINS BETWEEN CLEVELAND-COLUMBUS-CINCINNATI AND 1 TRAIN BETWEEN CLEVELAND AND COLUMBUS.

Navy barge Compromise, carrying first Saturn booster, stuck in the mud in the Indian River just south of Cape Canaveral. Released several hours later, the Saturn was delayed only 24 hours in its 2,200-mile journey from Huntsville.
AFTER PURCHASING LAND FOR THE EAST FREEWAY AND THE FULTON AND PARSONS EXPRESSWAYS, COLUMBUS IS PLANNING TO MOVE 6815 FAMILIES; MANY FAMILIES ARE WORRIED.
NORTH FREEWAY IS OPENED SOUTH TO 11TH AVE; PARKING RESTRICTIONS ARE ORDERED ON 11TH AVE TO PREVENT TRAFFIC TIE-UPS DURING OHIO STATE FAIR WEEK.
THE GROGAN UNDERPASS OF THE NORTH FREEWAY IS ONLY 53% COMPLETE WHILE THE REMAINDER OF THE $13.8 MILLION PROJECT IS 79% COMPLETE.
Hurricane: Tex. coast: Carla devastated Tex. gulf cities, taking 46 lives.
THE HILLIARD CITY COUNCIL APPROVES FILING AN APPROPRIATION SUIT AGAINST THE PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD TO ACQUIRE A WATER WELL THE RAILROAD OWNS.
COUNTY CMSNRS INSTRUCT THE COUNTY PROSECUTOR TO HANDLE THEIR DEFENSE AGAINST THELMA MORSE, 255 KENBROOK DR, A TELEPHONE OPERATOR FOR THE COUNTY WHO IS FIGHTING ABOLISHMENT OF HER JOB.
The Minnesota Vikings play their first regular season game, defeating the Chicago Bears 37-13. Quarterback Fran Tarkenton debuts.
Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color premiers with An Adventure in Color and Mathmagic Land.
FIRE DESTROYS A TWO-STORY BUILDING AT THE LINWORTH FARMERS EXCHANGE ON RT 161 A MILE WEST OF WORTHINGTON; SEVERAL FIRE DEPARTMENTS ASSIST DUBLIN DEPT IN CONTAINING THE FIRE.
GOV MICHAEL V DISALLE SAYS THE OUTERBELT WILL GO NORTH OF WORTHINGTON, AND THAT HE PLANS TO START WORK ON A NEW STATE OFFICE BUILDING BEFORE THE FIRST OF THE YEAR.

On the sixth anniversary of the Republic of South Vietnam, President Kennedy sends a letter to President Diem and pledges "the United States is determined to help Vietnam preserve its independence..."  President Kennedy then sends additional military advisors along with American helicopter units to transport and direct South Vietnamese troops in battle, thus involving Americans in combat operations. Kennedy justifies the expanding U.S. military role as a means "...to prevent a Communist takeover of Vietnam which is in accordance with a policy our government has followed since 1954." The number of military advisors sent by Kennedy will eventually surpass 16,000.

Largest known rocket launch to date, the Saturn I 1st stage booster, successful on first test flight from Atlantic Missile Range. With its eight clustered engines developing almost 1.3 million pounds of thrust at launch, the Saturn (SA-1) hurled waterfilled dummy upper stages to an altitude of 84.8 miles and 214.7 miles down range. In a postlaunch statement, Administrator Webb said: "The flight today was a splendid demonstration of the strength of our national space program and an important milestone in the buildup of our national capacity to launch heavy payloads necessary to carry out the program projected by President Kennedy on May 25.".
The Soviet Union detonates a 50 megaton hydrogen bomb. It is the largest bomb ever detonated.
Texas & New Orleans absorbed into Southern Pacific.

The conflict widens as 26,000 Viet Cong launch several successful attacks on South Vietnamese troops. Diem then requests more military aid from the Kennedy administration. To get a first-hand look at the deteriorating military situation, top Kennedy aides, Maxwell Taylor and Walt Rostow, visit Vietnam. "If Vietnam goes, it will be exceedingly difficult to hold Southeast Asia," Taylor reports to the President and advises Kennedy to expand the number of U.S. military advisors and to send 8000 combat soldiers. Defense Secretary McNamara and the Joint Chiefs of Staff recommend instead a massive show of force by sending six divisions (200,000 men) to Vietnam. However, the President decides against sending any combat troops.
UNITED AUTO WORKERS LOCAL 30 GOES ON STRIKE AT THE COLUMBUS AUTO PARTS CO, 575 E HUDSON ST WHEN THEIR THREE-YEAR CONTRACT EXPIRES; ABOUT 350 PRODUCTION WORKERS ARE IDLED.
ENGINEERING STUDIES ARE MADE ON A POSSIBLE LOCATION OF THE NORTHERN LEG OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY SYSTEM THROUGH BEECHWOLD.
James Grover Thurber died of a blood clot in New York City.
DEMOCRATIC COLUMBUS CITY COUNCILMEN RESTATE THEIR STAND FOR AN OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY SOUTH OF WORTHINGTON; CANDIDATES FOR ELECTION DECLINE TO SUPPORT A `SPECIFIC ROUTE'.
CITY COUNCIL DEMOCRATS ARE CHALLENGED FOR IGNORING A SURVEY SHOWING A MAJORITY OF CLINTONVILLE AND BEECHWOLD RESIDENTS FAVOR AN OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY NORTH OF WORTHINGTON.

NASA announced that the Chrysler Corporation had been chosen to build 20 Saturn first-stage (S-1) boosters similar to the one tested successfully on October 27 . They would be constructed at the Michoud facility near New Orleans, La. The contract, worth about $200 million, would run through 1966, with delivery of the first booster scheduled for early 1964.
THE CITY EXPECTS AGREEMENT FROM TWO RAILROADS, NEW YORK CENTRAL AND PENNSYLVANIA, FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE EAST NORTH BROADWAY AND MORSE RD RAILROAD UNDERPASS PROJECTS.
"The Mike Douglas Show" premiers.

Viet Cong guerrillas now control much of the countryside in South Vietnam and frequently ambush South Vietnamese troops. The cost to America of maintaining South Vietnam's sagging 200,000 man army and managing the overall conflict in Vietnam rises to a million dollars per day.

In 1961, physicist John Larry Kelly, Jr used an IBM 704 computer to synthesize speech, an event among the most prominent in the history of Bell Labs. Kelly's voice recorder synthesizer (vocoder) recreated the song " Daisy Bell", with musical accompaniment from Max Mathews.
IBM introduces the "Selectric Typewriter" which replaced typebars with a "golf ball" rotating print head. The even text produced made the units very popular.
Park Towers at 1620 E. Broad St. opens. 16 stories.
Starling Medical College and St. Francis Hospital on East State Street are torn down to make way for the new Grant complex.
The Sheraton at 50 N. 3rd St. opens. 16 stories.

White Cross Hospital moves to current site at corner of West North Broadway and Olentangy River Road. Name changed to Riverside Methodist Hospital. Riverside School of Nursing affiliates with Ohio Northern University.
OSU: 33 W. 11th Ave. (Ohio Legal Center) opens.
OSU: Goss Lab, 1925 Coffey Road, opens. Part of the Veterinary complex.
Westerville achieves city status.
Ray Kroc bought out the McDonald brothers for $2.7 million, aiming at making McDonald's the number one fast-food chain in the country.
President Kennedy speaks at the Buckeye Building at the Ohio State Fairgrounds in Columbus in honor of Ohio Governor Michael DiSalle's birthday, and endorsement.
Eugene Andreev parachutes from an altitude of 80,381 feet in Volsk, Russia, setting a world record for the longest free fall jump.
At least 2,000 people are feared dead after a huge avalanche in the Peruvian Andes engulfs nine villages.
During a press conference, President Kennedy is asked if any Americans in Vietnam are engaged in the fighting. "No," the President responds without further comment.
SS France maiden voyage from Cherbourg to New York.
MACV, the U.S. Military Assistance Command for Vietnam, is formed. It replaces MAAG-Vietnam, the Military Assistance Advisory Group which had been established in 1950.
DEVELOPER DON M CASTO ANNOUNCES THE SIGNING OF A LONG-TERM LEASE WITH THE F W WOOLWORTH CO FOR A WOOLCO DEPARTMENT STORE TO BE LOCATED IN GRACELAND SHOPPING CENTER.
The Filet-O-Fish sandwich, billed as "the fish that catches people", was introduced in McDonald's restaurants.
Mercury-Atlas 6: John H. Glenn, Jr., 04 hours, 55 minutes 23 seconds, Three-orbit flight that placed the first American into orbit.

The presidential palace in Saigon is bombed by two renegade South Vietnamese pilots flying American-made World War II era fighter planes. President Diem and his brother Nhu escape unharmed. Diem attributes his survival to "divine protection."
THE COLS METROPOLITAN PARK BOARD ANNOUNCES PLANS TO ESTABLISH A NEW PARK OF AT LEAST 200 ACRES IN THE CHESTNUT RIDGE AREA OF NORTHWESTERN FAIRFIELD CO NEAR LITHOPOLIS.
MAYOR WESTLAKE ANNOUNCES THAT THE CITY HAS WON APPROVAL FOR INCREASING THE PROPOSED EAST FREEWAY TO EIGHT LANES.
OHIO HIGHWAYS DIR HAS NO OBJECTIONS TO THE RECOMMENDED OUTERBELT ROUTE NORTH OF WORTHINGTON AND EAST OF GAHANNA; AFFECTED SUBURBS ARE ALSO PLEASED.
OHIO HIGHWAYS DIR HAS NO OBJECTIONS TO THE RECOMMENDED OUTERBELT ROUTE NORTH OF WORTHINGTON AND EAST OF GAHANNA; AFFECTED SUBURBS ARE ALSO PLEASED.
The first Titan II missile is launched from Cape Canaveral.
Comedians George Carlin and Jack Burns part ways. End of Burns and Carlin, beginning of Carlin's solo career.

Operation Sunrise begins the Strategic Hamlet resettlement program in which scattered rural populations in South Vietnam are uprooted from their ancestral farmlands and resettled into fortified villages defended by local militias. However, over 50 of the hamlets and are soon infiltrated and easily taken over by Viet Cong who kill or intimidate village leaders. As a result, Diem orders bombing raids against suspected Viet Cong-controlled hamlets. The air strikes by the South Vietnamese Air Force are supported by U.S. pilots, who also conduct some of the bombings. Civilian causalities erode popular support for Diem and result in growing peasant hostility toward America, which is largely blamed for the unpopular resettlement program as well as the bombings.

DEC launches the LINC 12 bit computer, the world's first minicomputer. DEC sold 21 of the first design units for $43,600 each. LincTape could store 400K. the basic LINC had only 1024 12-bit words of core memory (RAM)--and the big, expanded LINC had only 2048—normal operations depended heavily on swapping to and from LINCtape.
WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BOARD DECIDES TO OPPOSE TWO LAND TRANSFERS THAT MIGHT TAKE TAX MONEY FROM ITS SCHOOL DISTRICT.
GAHANNA COUNCIL TAKES STEPS TO BLOCK PUBLIC HEARINGS ON LOCATION OF THE OUTERBELT AND REFUSES TO APPROVE RELOCATION OF RT 62 UNTIL FINAL DECISION IS MADE ON RUNWAY AT PORT COLS.

Race jockey Eddie Arcaro retired with a career record of 15,327 victories for total winnings of $12,265,455. Arcaro was the first jockey to win 3,000 races and the first to ride five Kentucky Derby winners. In the Derby, Arcaro rode these mounts to the Winner's Circle: Lawrin, Whirl-a-Way, Hoop Jr., Citation and Hill Gail.
MAYOR WESTLAKE DECLARES THAT COLUMBUS "IS NOT PLAYING GAMES" WITH GAHANNA IN A DISPUTE OVER LOCATION OF THE PROPOSED OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY.
WESTERVILLE'S PRELIMINARY MASTER PLAN OKAYS RECOMMENDED ALIGNMENT OF THE OUTERBELT NORTH OF DEMPSEY RD, BUT SUGGESTS TRYING TO GAIN ADDITIONAL ACCESS TO OUTERBELT AT SCHROCK RD.

Second suborbital test of Saturn I. The Saturn SA-2 first stage booster was launched successfully from Cape Canaveral. The rocket was blown up intentionally and on schedule about 2.5 minutes after liftoff at an altitude of 65 miles, dumping the water ballast from the dummy second and third stages into the upper atmosphere. The experiment, Project Highwater, produced a massive ice cloud and lightning-like effects. The eight clustered H-1 engines in the first stage produced 1.3 million pounds of thrust and the maximum speed attained by the booster was 3,750 miles per hour. Modifications to decrease the slight fuel sloshing encountered near the end of the previous flight test were successful.
COURT ACTION IS COMPLETE TO ALLOW RAZING OF SEMINARY APARTMENTS IN WORTHINGTON TO BUILD A SUPER-DUPER, BUT WORTHINGTON METHODIST CHURCH OBJECTS TO ITS PLANNED SUNDAY OPERATIONS.

The first commercial jet airliner to be sabotaged was Continental 11 en route from Chicago to Kansas City to Los Angeles. The Boeing 707 carried 45 people (37 passengers, 8 crew) when a dynamite bomb hidden in a towel container under the washbasin in the right rear lavatory detonated. The blast caused the plane's tail to break away from the rest of the fuselage and the aircraft went out of control, crashing near Unionville, Missouri, and taking the lives of everyone aboard. Responsibility was blamed on a passenger named Thomas Doty who had a criminal record and purchased a large life insurance policy shortly before the flight.
OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HIGHWAYS IS STUDYING THE POSSIBILITY OF BUILDING RT 62 SOUTH OF GAHANNA IN ORDER TO BYPASS THE VILLAGE AND SET UP AN ALIGNMENT WITH THE OUTERBELT.
COLS UTILITIES DIR HOWARD JOHNSTON PLANS TO FILE SUIT IN AN EFFORT TO COMPEL THE NEW YORK CENTRAL RAILROAD "TO GIVE COLUMBUS REASONABLE DAYLIGHT SERVICE BY A FULL SCALE TRAIN"
ERNEST G FRITSCHE & CO STARTS CONSTRUCTION ON A NEW COLUMBUS COMMUNITY OF 1200 HOMES, TO BE CALLED DEVONSHIRE, ON 300 ACRES NORTHEAST OF RT 161 AND THE NORTH FREEWAY.
Pennsylvania Railroad gains control of Lehigh Valley.
Mercury-Atlas 7: M. Scott Carpenter, 04 hours, 56 minutes, 5 seconds, Confirmed the success of Mercury-Atlas 6 by duplicating flight.
Viet Cong organize themselves into battalion-sized units operating in central Vietnam. Defense Secretary McNamara visits South Vietnam and reports "we are winning the war."
COLUMBUS AND SUBURBAN OFFICIALS TO SPEAK AT A PUBLIC HEARING ON A MAJOR SECTION OF THE NORTHERN PART OF THE PROPOSED OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY.
REPRESENTATIVE OF DE LEUW, CATHER AND BRILL, CONSULTING ENGINEERS, PROPOSES FOUR INTERCHANGES IN THE PROPOSED ROUTE OF THE NORTH LEG OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT.
COLUMBUS SCHOOL DISTRICT GAINS APPROXIMATELY 550 ACRES FROM WORTHINGTON, WASHINGTON LOCAL AND UPPER ARLINGTON BUT LOSES 251 ACRES IN HAMILTON TOWNSHIP.
Comedian George Carlin makes his first solo television appearance on the Tonight Show with Mort Sahl (Paar had left, Carson had not started yet).
Rwanda becomes independent from Belgium.
Sam Walton opens the first Wal-Mart Discount City store in Rogers, Arkansas, at the corner of Walnut and Eighth Streets.
MERGER OF NEW YORK CENTRAL AND PENNSYLVANIA RAILROADS IS EXPECTED TO RESULT IN NEW FACILITIES, FASTER SERVICE FOR COLUMBUS SHIPPERS AND A JOB LOSS OF 850 OVER 5 YEARS.
The Declaration on the Neutrality of Laos signed in Geneva by the U.S. and 13 other nations, prohibits U.S. invasion of portions of the Ho Chi Minh trail inside eastern Laos.
SOLLIE L MILLER, 31, OF 318 KENBROOK DRIVE, OWNER OF THE 11TH AVENUE BAR, ACCIDENTALLY SHOT HIMSELF IN THE RIGHT LEG WITH A .22 CALIBER PISTOL WHILE OPENING THE BAR.
President Kennedy signs the Foreign Assistance Act of 1962 which provides "...military assistance to countries which are on the rim of the Communist world and under direct attack."
Vostok 3 and Vostok 4 come within 3 miles of each other, the first dual spacecraft mission.
CITY TRAFFIC ENGINEER JOHN L GALLAGHER RECOMMENDS BAN ON PARKING OR STOPPING ON 5TH AVE FROM OLENTANGY RIVER RD TO ST CLAIR AVE WHEN NORTH FREEWAY OPENS TO 5TH AVE IN AUGUST.
The second stage (S-IV) of the Saturn C-1 launch vehicle was successfully static-fired for the first time in a ten-second test at the Sacramento, Calif., facility by the Douglas Aircraft Company.
Mariner 2 successfully flies by Venus.
JET SERVICE FROM COLUMBUS TO THE WEST IS INAUGURATED AS A TWA AIRLINER TAKES OFF FOR CHICAGO AFTER CEREMONIES PRESIDED OVER BY MAYOR RALSTON WESTLAKE.
North Freeway opens as far south as 5th Avenue.
A U.S. Special Forces camp is set up at Khe Sanh to monitor North Vietnamese Army (NVA) infiltration down the Ho Chi Minh trail.
ASTRONAUT JOHN GLENN, JR, VISITS THE OHIO STATE FAIR AS THE CENTRAL ATTRACTION OF YOUTH DAY.
OHIO STATE FAIR OFFICIALS PREDICT THAT TOTAL 1962 FAIR ATTENDANCE WILL BE 300,000; SPACE SCIENCE PROGRAMS, INCLUDING THE SHOWING OF NASA FILM "YOUR SHARE IN SPACE" ARE CREDITED.
PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD CREWS BEGIN TO RETRIEVE TWO DIESEL LOCOMOTIVES FROM THE FOOT OF AN EMBANKMENT AT NELSON RD AND AVALON PL WHERE THEY LANDED AFTER A THREE-TRAIN WRECK.
DUBLIN VILLAGE OFFICIALS ASK COUNTY COMMISSIONERS AND THE STATE HIGHWAY DEPT TO REVAMP PLANS FOR THE NORTHERN LEG OF THE PROPOSED OUTERBELT HIGHWAY TO ADD ANOTHER INTERCHANGE.
A THREE-ALARM FIRE LEVELS THE PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD STOCKYARDS, A COMPLEX OF SHELTERS AND PENS WHICH COVERS A CITY BLOCK NEAR JAMES RD AND E 5TH AVE, CAUSING $21,000 DAMAGE.
WOOLCO OPENS IN GRACELAND SHOPPING CENTER.
THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HIGHWAYS OPENS BIDS ON THE FIRST SECTION OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY, WHICH HAS BEEN DESIGNATED AS I-270.
"The Jetsons" premiers.
WESTERVILLE CITY MANAGER THOMAS BAY IS EXPECTED TO URGE TWO ADDITIONAL OUTERBELT AND FREEWAY EXCHANGES NEAR THE SUBURB IF COUNCIL APPROVES THE CITY'S MASTER PLAN.
ABC broadcasts its first color television shows - The Flintstones, The Jetsons and Beany and Cecil.
Johnny Carson becomes host of "The Tonight Show."
"McHale's Navy" premiers.
"MISSING LINK" IN THE NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY SYSTEM, NEAR FORT HAYES MILITARY RESERVATION, WILL OPEN BEFORE THE 11/1 TARGET DATE.
CUBAN MISSILE CRISIS: A U-2 reconnaissance aircraft, piloted by Richard Heyser, reveals several SS-4 nuclear missiles in Cuba.
CUBAN MISSILE CRISIS:President Kennedy addresses the American public and announces his resolve to implement naval blockade on Cuba.
CUBAN MISSILE CRISIS: Adlai Stevenson confronts the Soviets at the U.N. but they refuse to answer. American military forces are instructed to set DEFCON 2.
THE COLUMBUS AUTO PARTS CO QUIETLY OBSERVES A HALF CENTURY OF PRODUCING PARTS FOR THE AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY UNDER CONTINUOUS MANAGEMENT OF THE SAME FAMILY.
CUBAN MISSILE CRISIS: In a speech aired on Radio Moscow, Khrushchev announces the dismantling of Soviet missiles in Cuba. The crisis is over.
Mercury-Atlas 8: Walter M. Schirra, Jr., 09 hours, 13 minutes, 11 seconds, Six-orbit engineering test flight.
Grumman is awarded the Lunar Module contract by NASA.

Saturn SA-3 is launched at 17:45:02 from Launch Complex 34. The only hold in the countdown sequence was for 45 minutes due to a power failure in ground support equipment.[4] This mission was the first time the Saturn I rocket was launched with a full load of propellant, carrying approximately 750,000 pounds (340,000 kg) of fuel.
WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BOARD COMMITS $1.1 MILLION FOR CONSTRUCTION OF WILSON HILL ELEMENTARY SCHOOL AND EVENING ST ELEMENTARY SCHOOL.
The Jeep Grand Wagoneer is introduced by Kaiser Automotive. It will be produced mostly unchanged until 1991.
THE MONTHLY EXPRESSWAY REPORT SAYS THAT THE CITY'S INNERBELT EXPRESSWAY SYSTEM SHOULD BE READY FOR USE BY THE END OF 1964.
SHARON TWP AND DUBLIN FIREMEN BATTLE A FIRE IN THE HISTORIC SEMINARY APARTMENTS, 582 HIGH ST IN WORTHINGTON, WHICH WAS BEING RAZED TO MAKE ROOM FOR A PARKING LOT.
Lenny Bruce was arrested on stage at the legendary Gate of Horn folk club in Chicago.
PEARL E MASHETER SAYS COMPLETION OF OHIO'S NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY WILL BECOME A HIGH PRIORITY WHEN HE BECOMES HIGHWAY DIRECTOR ON 1/14/63.
Detroit, Toledo & Ironton gains control of Ann Arbor.
A Howard Johnson's is built at 999 East Dublin Granville Road. Many years later, the restaurant becomes the Elephant Bar, while the hotel portion becomes a Travelodge.

The DEC PDP-4 is an 18-bit machine of which "approximately 54 were sold" and was a compromise: "with slower memory and different packaging" than the PDP-1, but priced at $65,000 - considerably less than its predecessor (about half the price).
Alum Creek Dam is authorized by Congress in the Flood Control Act of 1962.
First McDonalds Restaurant opens in Columbus.
OSU: Campbell Hall, 1787 Neil Ave., addition. "The Home Economics Building"
OSU: Hopkins Hall, 128 N. Oval Mall, addition.
OSU: Kinnear Road Center, 1099, 1121 & 1125 Kinnear Rd., buildings A & C open. Built by the Mid-West Volkswagen distributorship and sold to the Ohio College Library Center (OCLC) in 1975.
OSU: The Mathematics Building, 231 W. 18th Ave., opens.
Construction begins on St. Michael's Church in Worthington.
Columbus Union Station is down to 21 trains per day.
Interstate 270 is certified as a "future route".
Interstate 70 is certified by the federal government. Planning for construction can now begin.

Ohio Midland (SVTC's successor) discontinues diesel coal service to the Picway Power Plant. Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric picked up diesel operations until the mid 1960's when coal deliveries were switched from rail to truck.
Passenger railroad service to Hilliard is terminated.
The Ohio-Midland Rural Electric Corporation merged with the South Central Electric Co.
Wilson Hill Elementary School opens.
Worthington Historical Society purchases vacant and vandalized Federal style home at 956 High Street for renovation.
Worthington Methodist Church purchases the old Female Seminary site for expansion.

A Viet Cong victory in the Battle of Ap Bac makes front page news in America as 350 Viet Cong fighters defeat a large force of American-equipped South Vietnamese troops attempting to seize a radio transmitter. Three American helicopter crew members are killed. The South Vietnamese Army is run by officers personally chosen by President Diem, not for their competence, but for their loyalty to him. Diem has instructed his officers to avoid causalities. Their primary mission, he has told them, is to protect him from any coups in Saigon.
COLUMBUS-BORN WRITER, JAMES THURBER, UNVEILS THE BRONZE PLAQUE IN HIS HONOR AT THE OPENING OF THE THURBER VILLAGE SHOPPING CENTER.
James A. Rhodes inaugurated Governor of Ohio
The Worthington Historical Society purchases the Orange Johnson House from developers of Toll Gate Square.
Chessapeake & Ohio gains control of the Baltimore & Ohio.
The S.S. Badger and S.S. Spartan have trouble with winter ice on Lake Michigan for the first time in their careers.
The Boeing 727 makes its first test flight.
Ohio State's school of aviation becomes the Department of Aviation and begins granting degrees.
The Olentangy River crests at 11.68 ft, the fifth highest on record.

North American completed construction of Apollo boilerplate (BP) 9, consisting of launch escape tower and CSM. It was delivered to MSC on March 18, where dynamic testing on the vehicle began two days later. On April 8, BP-9 was sent to MSFC for compatibility tests with the Saturn I launch vehicle.

The first stage of the Saturn SA-5 launch vehicle was static fired at MSFC for 144.44 seconds in the first long-duration test for a Block II S-1. The cluster of eight H-1 engines produced 680 thousand kilograms (1.5 million pounds) of thrust. An analysis disclosed anomalies in the propulsion system. In a final qualification test two weeks later, when the engines were fired for 143.47 seconds, the propulsion problems had been corrected.
Donald Reinbolt is the last of 315 convicts executed in the electric chair at the Ohio Penitentiary.
CONSULTING ENGINEERS' NEW $16,440,000 PLAN FOR THE LONG-STALLED OLENTANGY FREEWAY IS NOT ACCEPTABLE TO THE CITY AND OSU.
The Beatles release "Please Please Me"

Fourth suborbital test of Saturn I (SA-4). The S-I Saturn stage reached an altitude of 129 kilometers (80 statute miles) and a peak velocity of 5,906 kilometers (3,660 miles) per hour. This was the last of four successful tests for the first stage of the Saturn I vehicle. After 100 seconds of flight, No. 5 of the booster's eight engines was cut off by a preset timer. That engine's propellants were rerouted to the remaining seven, which continued to burn. This experiment confirmed the "engine-out" capability that MSFC engineers had designed into the Saturn I.
NASA Crawler Transporter: Fabrication begins at the Marion Power Shovel Company in  Marion, Ohio.
"Best Foot Forward" opened in New York City. Liza Minelli was the lead actress in this off-Broadway revival of the show which enjoyed a run of 224 performances.
THE STATE SPOTLIGHTS FR CO'S INTERSECTION OF THE SOUTH FREEWAY (I-71) AND RT 104 AS THE WORST TRAFFIC ACCIDENT SPOT IN OHIO DURING 1962.
WORTHINGTON'S 159-YEAR-OLD MONUMENT TO ITS FOUNDING FATHERS IS ABOUT TO BE DESTROYED: THE GRISWOLD HOMESTEAD IS IN THE PROCESS OF BEING SOLD AND BUYER PLANS TO DEMOLISH IT.
COLUMBUS METROPOLITAN PARK BOARD ACQUIRES 440 ACRES IN NORTHEAST FR CO FOR ITS SPRING HOLLOW METROPOLITAN PARK.
THE OHIO TURNPIKE COMMISSION BECOMES PART OF A TASK FORCE TO COMPLETE THE NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY I-71.
OHIO'S NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY WILL BE OPEN TO TRAFFIC FROM CINCINNATI TO CLEVELAND IN THE FALL OF 1966: FORCE EXPEDITING CONSTRUCTION OF I-71.
The New York Titans change their name to the New York Jets.
JAMES W SHOCKNESSY, HEADING A TASK FORCE TO COMPLETE THE NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY, TELLS STATE AND FEDERAL OFFICIALS HE WANTS THE OHIO RIVER TO LAKE ERIE ROUTE COMPLETED IN THREE YEARS.
"General Hospital" soap opera premiers.
WOOLCO DEPARTMENT STORE, GRACELAND SHOPPING CENTER, IS THE 4TH STORE CITED FOR VIOLATION OF A NEW CITY ORDINANCE BANNING SALE OF GOODS FROM COMMUNIST COUNTRIES.
AN OHIO DEPT OF HIGHWAYS PLANNER TELLS CITY OFFICIALS THE STATE HAS NO MONEY FOR THE PROPOSED $16 MILLION OLENTANGY FREEWAY PROJECT.
PLANS FOR A 1300-ACRE INDUSTRIAL AREA BETWEEN SCHROCK AND PARK RDS, NORTH OF THE PRESENT WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIAL PARK, ARE ANNOUNCED BY WILLIAM MCGOHAN, PRES OF COL-WORTH REALTY CO.
"Dr. No" featuring Sean Connery as James Bond released in the United States.
A TASK FORCE HEADED BY OHIO TURNPIKE CHAIRMAN JAMES W SHOCKNESSY OFFICIALLY STARTS WORK ON THE JOB OF COMPLETING THE NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY I-71.
Mercury-Atlas 9: L. Gordon Cooper, Jr., 34 hours, 19 minutes, 49 seconds, Last Mercury mission; completed 22 orbits to evaluate effects of one day in space.
WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BOARD OPPOSES THE REGIONAL PLANNING CMSN PROPOSAL THAT A ROAD BE BUILT FROM WORTHINGWAY SUBDIVISION SOUTH TO RT 161 THROUGH THE WEST SIDE OF HIGH SCHOOL GROUNDS.
THREE CONFLICTING PLANS FOR THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY ROUTE ALIGNMENT FACE COLUMBUS, STATE HIGHWAY AND OSU OFFICIALS.
DR JOHN HERRICK, OSU DIR OF PLANNING, CHARGES THAT COLUMBUS WOULD TRADE OSU'S EDUCATIONAL EFFECTIVENESS FOR DOLLAR SAVINGS ON AN OLENTANGY FREEWAY ROUTE.

Buddhists riot in South Vietnam after they are denied the right to display religious flags during their celebration of Buddha's birthday. In Hue, South Vietnamese police and army troops shoot at Buddhist demonstrators, resulting in the deaths of one woman and eight children. Political pressure now mounts on the Kennedy administration to disassociate itself from Diem's repressive, family-run government. "You are responsible for the present trouble because you back Diem and his government of ignoramuses," a leading Buddhist tells U.S. officials in Saigon.

Governer George Wallace of Alabama blocks the entrance to the University of Alabama to prevent two black students from enrolling. Wallace declares "segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever."
Medgar Evers, an NAACP worker in Mississippi, is murdered by white supremacist Byron de la Beckwith.
NASA Crawler Transporter: Formal approval of crawler concept for moving rockets.
C&O RAILWAY CO APPROVES PRELIMINARY PLANS FOR A ROAD UNDERPASS AND A 50 MPH TRAIN SPEED AT A RUN-AROUND DURING CONSTRUCTION OF THE PROPOSED $1.4 MILLION W NORTH BROADWAY EXTENSION.
Valentina Tereshkova becomes the first woman in space.

Buddhist demonstrations spread. Several Buddhist monks publicly burn themselves to death as an act of protest. The immolations are captured on film by news photographers and shock the American public as well as President Kennedy. Diem responds to the deepening unrest by imposing martial law. South Vietnamese special forces, originally trained by the U.S. and now controlled by Diem's younger brother Nhu wage violent crackdowns against Buddhist sanctuaries in Saigon, Hue and other cities. Nhu's crackdowns spark widespread anti-Diem demonstrations. Meanwhile, during an American TV interview, Nhu's wife, the flamboyant Madame Nhu, coldly refers to the Buddhist immolations as a 'barbecue.' As the overall situation worsens, high level talks at the White House focus on the need to force Diem to reform.
The Southern gains control of the Georgia & Florida.
South Vietnamese General Tran Van Don, a Buddhist, contacts the CIA in Saigon about the possibility of staging a coup against Diem.
PEARL E MASHETER, DIRECTOR OF THE OHIO DEPT OF HIGHWAYS, SAYS HE FAVORS PORT COLUMBUS OUTERBELT ROUTE, A ROUTE OPPOSED BY COLUMBUS SERVICES DIRECTOR ERNEST H STORCK.
WORK STARTS ON AN $81,000 OHIO FUEL GAS CO PIPELINE CONSTRUCTION PROJECT TO EXTEND NATURAL GAS SERVICE TO THE GREEN MEADOWS INN ON RT 23 NORTH OF WORTHINGTON.
SAFETY DIRECTOR ALBERT G GILES, ORDERS LANE LINES, MARKINGS AND SIGNS BE INSTALLED IMMEDIATELY ON ALL "OFF" RAMPS ALONG THE NORTH FREEWAY FOLLOWING COMPLAINTS BY MOTORISTS.
SIXTH PLAN SUBMITTED BY STILSON & ASSOCIATES, LTD FOR THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY IS CALLED TOO COSTLY BY ERNEST H STORK, CITY SERVICE DIRECTOR.
Toll Gate Square incorporated. Toll Gate Square was the first condominium plat filed in Franklin County.

In what was to have been an acceptance test, the Douglas Aircraft Company static fired the first Saturn S-IV flight stage at Sacramento, Calif. An indication of fire in the engine area forced technicians to shut down the stage after little more than one minute's firing. A week later the acceptance test was repeated, this time without incident, when the vehicle was fired for over seven minutes. (The stage became part of the SA-5 launch vehicle, the first complete Saturn I to fly.)
ROY LICHTENSTEIN OF NEW YORK CITY, JUDGES THE 1963 OHIO STATE FAIR FINE ARTS EXHIBITION; LICHTENSTEIN IS AN OSU GRADUATE AND TAUGHT IN THE SCHOOL OF ART, 1947-51.
The new U.S. ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge arrives in South Vietnam.
A U.S. State Department message sent to Ambassador Lodge is interpreted by Lodge to indicate he should encourage the military coup against President Diem.

Ambassador Lodge meets President Diem for the first time. Under instructions from President Kennedy, Lodge tells Diem to fire his brother, the much-hated Nhu, and to reform his government. But Diem arrogantly refuses even to discuss such matters with Lodge. President Kennedy and top aides begin three days of heated discussions over whether the U.S. should in fact support the military coup against Diem.
Dr. Martin Luther King delivers his "I Have A Dream" speech in Washington, DC.

Lodge sends a message to Washington stating "...there is no possibility, in my view, that the war can be won under a Diem administration." President Kennedy then gives Lodge a free hand to manage the unfolding events in Saigon. However, the coup against Diem fizzles due to mistrust and suspicion within the ranks of the military conspirators.
COLUMBUS & SOUTHERN OHIO ELECTRIC CO, THE CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC CO, AND DAYTON POWER AND LIGHT FORM A VAST POWER POOL TO MEET GROWING DEMANDS OF CUSTOMER

During a TV news interview with Walter Cronkite, President Kennedy describes Diem as "out of touch with the people" and adds that South Vietnam's government might regain popular support "with changes in policy and perhaps in personnel." Also during the interview, Kennedy comments on America's commitment to Vietnam "If we withdrew from Vietnam, the Communists would control Vietnam. Pretty soon, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, Malaya, would go..."

The 19,000-square-foot, two-building Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio is officially opened. The Hall's charter class of 17 enshrinees are inducted: Sammy Baugh, Bert Bell, Joe Carr, Dutch Clark, Harold "Red" Grange, George Halas, Mel Hein, Wilbur "Pete" Henry, Cal Hubbard, Don Hutson, Curly Lambeau, Tim Mara, George Preston Marshall, John "Blood" McNally, Bronko Nagurski, Ernie Nevers and Jim Thorpe.
The Kansas City Chiefs play their first regular season game, beating the Denver Broncos 59-7.
THE CITY TRAFFIC COMMISSION APPROVES THE INSTALLATION OF A TRAFFIC SIGNAL AT THE NORTHBOUND EXIT RAMP OF THE NORTH FREEWAY AND RT 161.
A record period of 48 days with no precipitation, or only a trace, in the State of Ohio, begins.

The Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham is bombed by the KKK. Four African American girls die in the blast, sparking armed conflict between blacks and whites. Although bombings of black churches had been occurring throughout the Deep South and particularly in Birmingham since 1948, this tragic event galvanizes the Civil Rights Movement.
ENGINEER C T CASSEL, 420 LINWOOD AVE, GETS A TICKET FOR $25 WHEN HIS PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD TRAIN BLOCKS LINCOLN AVE AT A CROSSING IN NORTH COLUMBUS FOR ALMOST AN HOUR.
"The Fugitive" premiers. Based on the famous Cleveland case of Dr. Samuel Sheppard.
JAMES W SHOCKNESSY, COORDINATOR ON THE I-71 NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY, ANNOUNCES FEDERAL APPROVAL OF A NEW DESIGN FOR THE FREEWAY IN CLEVELAND.

President Kennedy sends Ambassador Lodge a mixed messaged that "no initiative should now be taken to give any encouragement to a coup" but that Lodge should "identify and build contacts with possible leadership as and when it appears."

Lodge informs President Kennedy that the coup against Diem appears to be on again. The rebel generals, led by Duong Van "Big" Minh, first ask for assurances that U.S. aid to South Vietnam will continue after Diem's removal and that the U.S. will not interfere with the actual coup. This scenario suits the White House well, in that the generals will appear to acting on their own without any direct U.S. involvement. President Kennedy gives his approval. The CIA in Saigon then signals the conspirators that the United States will not interfere with the overthrow of President Diem.
"From Russia With Love" featuring Sean Connery as James Bond released in the United States.
MORSE RD UNDERPASS IS OPENED.
WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BOARD APPROVES PRELIMINARY PLANS FOR NEW ELEMENTARY SCHOOL TO BE LOCATED IN BROOKSIDE ESTATES.
Prompted by concerns over public relations fallout if the coup fails, a worried White House seeks reassurances from Ambassador Lodge that the coup will succeed.
Ambassador Lodge reports a coup is "imminent."
An increasingly nervous White House now instructs Lodge to postpone the coup. Lodge responds it can only be stopped by betraying the conspirators to Diem.
A record period of 48 days with no precipitation, or only a trace, in the State of Ohio, ends.

Lodge has a routine meeting with Diem from 10 a.m. until noon at the presidential palace, then departs. At 1:30 p.m., during the traditional siesta time, the coup begins as mutinous troops roar into Saigon, surround the presidential palace, and also seize police headquarters. Diem and his brother Nhu are trapped inside the palace and reject all appeals to surrender. Diem telephones the rebel generals and attempts, but fails, to talk them out of the coup. Diem then calls Lodge and asks "...what is the attitude of the United States?" Lodge responds "...it is four thirty a.m. in Washington, and the U.S. government cannot possibly have a view." Lodge then expresses concern for Diem's safety, to which Diem responds "I am trying to restore order." At 8 p.m., Diem and Nhu slip out of the presidential palace unnoticed and go to a safe house in the suburbs that belongs to a wealthy Chinese merchant.

At 3 a.m., one of Diem's aides betrays his location to the generals. The hunt for Diem and Nhu now begins. At 6 a.m., Diem telephones the generals. Realizing the situation is hopeless, Diem and Nhu offer to surrender from inside a Catholic church. Diem and Nhu are then taken into custody by rebel officers and placed in the back of an armored personnel carrier. While traveling to Saigon, the vehicle stops and Diem and Nhu are assassinated. At the White House, a meeting is interrupted with the news of Diem's death. According to witnesses, President Kennedy's face turns a ghostly shade of white and he immediately leaves the room. Later, the President records in his private diary, "I feel that we must bear a good deal of responsibility for it." Saigon celebrates the downfall of Diem's regime. But the coup results in a power vacuum in which a series of military and civilian governments seize control of South Vietnam, a country that becomes totally dependent on the United States for its existence. Viet Cong use the unstable political situation to increase their hold over the rural population of South Vietnam to nearly 40 percent.
CHIEF EXECUTIVES OF COLUMBUS, OSU, AND OHIO HIGHWAY DEPARTMENT REACH COMPROMISE AGREEMENT ON THE ROUTE OF THE NEW OLENTANGY FREEWAY.
E NORTH BROADWAY AVE UNDERPASS IS OPENED.
COLUMBUS' FIRST NEW DOWNTOWN HOTEL IN AT LEAST 30 YEARS, THE $8.5 MILLION, 22-STORY COLUMBUS PLAZA, OPENS WITH DEDICATION CEREMONIES.
UNION CEMETERY ASSOCIATION PROMISES TO "FIGHT TO THE LAST DITCH" TO STOP THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY FROM TAKING NEARLY SEVEN ACRES OF CEMETERY LAND.
The Beatles release "With the Beatles"
FIFTY-ONE CARS OF A PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD FREIGHT TRAIN DERAIL WEST OF TRABUE RD, RUPTURING TANKERS CARRYING CHEMICALS, AND CAUSING A FIRE IN SEVERAL CARS.
Lyndon Baines Johnson inaugurated as President.
President John F. Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas, TX by Lee Harvey Oswald.

President Johnson declares he will not "lose Vietnam" during a meeting with Ambassador Lodge in Washington. By year's end, there are 16,300 American military advisors in South Vietnam which received $500 million in U.S. aid during 1963.

Interstate 71's Brent Spence bridge, connecting Ohio and Kentucky across the Ohio River, opens. The double decker bridge cost $10 million and is 1,736 feet long. Named for Newport native Brent Spence (1874-1967), a congressman for 32 years.
OHIO HIGHWAY SAFETY DIRECTOR WARREN C NELSON STARTS NEGOTIATIONS WITH OHIO EXPOSITIONS COMMISSION FOR SITE ON STATE FAIRGROUNDS FOR NEW STATE HIGHWAY PATROL ACADEMY.
Studebaker - Packard's South Bend plant ceased production.
NASA Crawler Transporter: Marion has 90% of design complete, plans to ship parts to Florida in March, 1964.
SAFECRACKERS ABANDON CAR, WEAPONS, AND EXPLOSIVES WHEN SURPRISED BY WORTHINGTON POLICE AT SEALTEST DAIRY DISTRIBUTING PLANT, 6580 HUNTLEY RD.
Columbus' second modern, glass skyscraper, the Sheraton Hotel, opens at 50 N. 3rd St.
Doctors Hospital West opens on W. Broad Street.

The Christopher Inn at 300 E. Broad Street is built. A round 14 story tower, the Christopher Inn was reminiscent of the Capitol Records Building in Hollywood. The Christopher Inn stood for only 25 years, the shortest lifespan of any highrise in Columbus.
The first Donatos Pizza opens on Thurman Avenue.
The Key Bank Building at 88 E. Broad St. opens. 20 stories.
Evening Street Elementary School opens.
DEC releases the PDP-5 minicomputer, a 12 bit machine. At a cost of only $27,000, market demand soars and over 1000 are sold.
ACCORDING TO ENGINEERING STUDIES, CHANGING CONSTRUCTION PROPOSALS IN THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY TO ANSWER RIVERSIDE HOSPITAL COMPLAINTS WOULD INCREASE COSTS BY $600,000.
NEW FEDERAL LAW REQUIRING INTERSTATE EXPRESSWAYS BE BUILT FOR TRAFFIC 20 YEARS AHEAD CAUSES TWO MONTHS DELAY IN THREE SECTIONS OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT.
THE TWENTY-FIVE ROOM HISTORIC GRISWOLD HOUSE AT 778 NORTH HIGH ST, WORTHINGTON, IS TO BE DESTROYED AND REPLACED BY A MODERN MEDICAL BUILDING.

First first mission of Block II Saturn with two live stages. SA-5, a vehicle development flight, was launched from Cape Kennedy Complex 37B at 11:25:01.41, e.s.t. This was the first flight of the Saturn I Block II configuration (i.e., lengthened fuel tanks in the S-1 and stabilizing tail fins), as well as the first flight of a live (powered) S-IV upper stage. The S-1, powered by eight H-1 engines, reached a full thrust of over 680,400 kilograms (1.5 million pounds) the first time in flight. The S-IV's 41,000 kilogram (90,000-pound-thrust cluster of six liquid-hydrogen RL-10 engines performed as expected. The Block II SA-5 was also the first flight test of the Saturn I guidance system.
General Minh is ousted from power in a bloodless coup led by General Nguyen Khanh who becomes the new leader of South Vietnam.
Storms dump 3" of rain over Columbus and Worthington, ending an extended dry period. Part of a larger system that dumps 4" - 5" of rain all along the Ohio River Valley.
THE SOUTH HALF OF THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY WILL HAVE SIX INSTEAD OF FOUR LANES EXCEPT FOR THE STRETCH FROM HIGH ST (RT 23) ACROSS THE SCIOTO RIVER TO THE SOUTH FREEWAY (I-71).

Defense Secretary McNamara visits South Vietnam and states that Gen. Khanh "has our admiration, our respect and our complete support..." and adds that, "We'll stay for as long as it takes. We shall provide whatever help is required to win the battle against the Communist insurgents." Following his visit, McNamara advises President Johnson to increase military aid to shore up the sagging South Vietnamese army. McNamara and other Johnson policy makers now become focused on the need to prevent a Communist victory in South Vietnam, believing it would damage the credibility of the U.S. globally. The war in Vietnam thus becomes a test of U.S. resolve in fighting Communism with America's prestige and President Johnson's reputation on the line. The cost to America of maintaining South Vietnam's army and managing the overall conflict in Vietnam now rises to two million dollars per day.
Storms dump 4" across Central Ohio, and 5" locally north of Columbus.
The Olentangy River crests at 12.66 ft, the third highest on record.

The Ohio River floods. Thousands of refugees fled flooded lowlands. At least 775 people spent the night in local shelters, and 110,000 were homeless in a five-state area. A house on Second Avenue in Dayton, Ky., caught fire and burned to the water line.
The U.S. National Security Council recommends the bombing of North Vietnam. President Johnson approves only the planning phase by the Pentagon.
JERRIE MOCK TAKES OFF FROM PORT COLUMBUS, AIMING FOR THE FIRST WOMAN'S SOLO FLIGHT AROUND THE WORLD AND TWO NEW AVIATION RECORDS.

Alaska: At 5:36 pm Alaska Standard Time, an earthquake and ensuing tsunami claimed 125 lives and caused about $311 million in property loss. The quake, measuring 9.2, was felt over a large area of Alaska and in parts of western Yukon Territory and British Columbia, Canada. A tsunami generated by the quake wiped out Crescent City, California, killing 11 people and washing away 29 city blocks.
Ohio's Center of Science and Industry (COSI) opens in the old Veterans Memorial, 280 E. Broad St.
Secret U.S.-backed bombing raids begin against the Ho Chi Minh trail inside Laos, conducted by mercenaries flying old American fighter planes.
CITY SERVICE DIR WARREN CREMEAN REVERSES THE STAND OF HIS PREDECESSOR AND DECLARES THE CITY FAVORS THE NORTHEAST SEGMENT OF THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY WEST OF GAHANNA.

The Beatles set an all-time record on the Top 100 chart of "Billboard" magazine this day. All five of the top songs were by the British rock group. In addition, The Beatles also had the number one album as "Meet the Beatles" continued to lead all others. The LP was the top album from February 15 through May 2, when it was replaced by "The Beatles Second Album". It was estimated at the time that The Beatles accounted for 60 percent of the entire singles record business during the first three months of 1964. The top five singles by The Beatles this day were:
1) Can't Buy Me Love
2) Twist and Shout
3) She Loves You
4) I Want to Hold Your Hand
5) Please Please Me
"What song was number six?" you ask. "Suspicion" by Terry Stafford.
GAHANNA COUNCIL PRESIDENT ROBERT ROBY IS HAPPY ABOUT THE RECENT DECISION TO LOCATE THE OUTERBELT WEST OF THE VILLAGE, BUT HE WOULD LIKE TO SEE A SLIGHT REVISION IN THE ROUTE.
The System/360 was announced by IBM.
SERVICE DIRECTOR WARREN J CREMEAN'S REQUEST TO BRING IN THE PLANNED NORTHEAST OUTERBELT SECTION, BETWEEN E BROAD ST AND RT 3, WINS TENTATIVE APPROVAL.
Gemini 1 launched. First test of the Gemini spacecraft. It spends 3 days in orbit, and then (purposfully) burns up on reentry.
"The Red Door Tavern" opens for business in Grandview.
OSU MAINTAINS ITS STAND ON RELOCATION AROUND THE CAMPUS OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY AND TRUSTEES URGE PRESIDENT FAWCETT TO "PRESS VIGOROUSLY" FOR A DECISION ON THE ISSUE.
JERRIE MOCK COMES HOME FROM A JOURNEY NO WOMAN HAS MADE BEFORE AND RETURNS TO A HOMETOWN WELCOME WORTHY OF HER ACHIEVEMENT.
PROGRESS ON I-71 IS LAUDED BY GOVERNOR RHODES AS THE NORTH-SOUTH FREEWAY TASK FORCE PASSES THE ONE-YEAR MARK.
FRANKLIN CO TRAFFIC ENGINEER OFFICIALS URGE QUICK ACTION ON THE STALLED OLENTANGY FREEWAY PROJECT, CITING OLENTANGY RIVER RD TRAFFIC PROBLEMS AS "THE BIGGEST HEADACHE".
UNION CEMETERY WOULD DROP ITS OBJECTION TO THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY ROUTE IF A SHORT TUNNEL UNDER THE FREEWAY CONNECTS ITS PROPERTIES NEAR OLENTANGY RIVER RD AND W NORTH BROADWAY.
FR CO AND COLS OFFICIALS DISCUSS MAKING A RECREATIONAL OR PARK AREA OF 24 COUNTY-OWNED ACRES ALONG ALUM CREEK, SOUTH OF LIVINGSTON AVE, WHICH WILL BE LANDLOCKED BY EAST FREEWAY.
REMNANTS OF INSULATING MATERIAL INFECTED WITH ANTHRAX SPORES ARE REMOVED FROM THE SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO STORE UNDER CONSTRUCTION AT NORTHLAND SHOPPING CENTER AND BURNED.

Saturn I Launch. Apollo Saturn Mission A-101, using CM BP-13 atop SA-6 Saturn I launch vehicle, launched at Cape Kennedy, Fla., to prove spacecraft/launch vehicle compatibility. Boilerplate CSM, LM adapter, LES. LES jettison demonstrated.

President Johnson's aides begin work on a Congressional resolution supporting the President's war policy in Vietnam. The resolution is shelved temporarily due to lack of support in the Senate, but will later be used as the basis of the Gulf of Tonkin resolution.
Father Byrne celebrates the first Mass in St. Michael's Church in Worthington, as part of the ceremonies for the 1964 Graduation class from St. Michael elementary school.

As 56,000 Viet Cong spread their successful guerrilla war throughout South Vietnam, they are reinforced by North Vietnamese Army (NVA) regulars pouring in via the Ho Chi Minh trail. Responding to this escalation, President Johnson approves Operation Plan 34A, CIA-run covert operations using South Vietnamese commandos in speed boats to harass radar sites along the coastline of North Vietnam. The raids are supported by U.S. Navy warships in the Gulf of Tonkin including the destroyer U.S.S. Maddox which conducts electronic surveillance to pinpoint the radar locations.

General Maxwell D. Taylor, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is appointed by President Johnson as the new U.S. ambassador to South Vietnam. During his one year tenure, Taylor will have to deal with five successive governments in politically unstable South Vietnam. President Johnson also appoints Lt. Gen William C. Westmoreland to be the new U.S. military commander in Vietnam. Westmoreland is a West Point graduate and a highly decorated veteran of World War II and Korea.
President Johnson signs the Civil Rights Bill, calling for, among other things, the integration of public places which had previously been whites-only.
BERWICK RESIDENTS COMPLAIN THAT TRUCKS WORKING ON THE EAST FREEWAY ARE WORKING PRACTICALLY ALL NIGHT, CREATING NOISE AND DIRT.
BAKER & HICKEY CO, 2170 EAKIN RD, AND CHAPIN & CHAPIN, INC OFFER LOW BID OF $4.1 MILLION TO BUILD THE EAST FREEWAY SECTION ACROSS ALUM CREEK TO JAMES RD.
RESTRAINING ORDER GRANTED FRANKLIN AUTO PARTS CO STOPS ACQUISITION ACTION ON 4.9 ACRES FOR THE EAST FREEWAY, CAUSING A DELAY IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF A VITAL SECTION.
The Beatles release "A Hard Day's Night"
WORTHINGTON FOODS INC'S NEW RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BUILDING, 900 PROPRIETORS RD, WORTHINGTON, EMPLOYS MORE THAN 100 IN PRODUCTION & DISTRIBUTION OF VEGETARIAN FOODS.
CITY ATTORNEY ASKS JUDGE JOSEPH M HARTER TO EITHER DROP HIS ORDER HALTING A KEY SECTION OF THE EAST FREEWAY PROJECT OR SET BOND TO COVER LOSSES TO TAXPAYERS.
FRANK WILLIAMS, DEPUTY STATE HIGHWAY DIRECTOR DRAWS A RADICAL NEW PATH FOR THE NORTHEAST QUADRANT OF THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY BETWEEN COLUMBUS AND GAHANNA.
JUDGE JOSEPH M HARTER REFUSES TO LIFT A RESTRAINING ORDER HALTING WORK ON THE EAST FREEWAY THAT HE ISSUED ON BEHALF OF THE FRANKLIN AUTO PARTS CO.

Senator Barry Goldwater is chosen as the Republican nominee for president at the Republican National Convention in San Francisco. During his acceptance speech Goldwater declares, "Extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice." Goldwater is an arch conservative and virulent anti-Communist whose campaign rhetoric will impact coming White House decisions concerning Vietnam. Above all, Johnson's aides do not want the President to appear to be 'soft on Communism' and thus risk losing the November presidential election. But at the same time, they also want the President to avoid being labeled a 'war monger' concerning Vietnam.
Race riot in Harlem, NY began after James Powell was shot and killed by police Lieutenant Thomas Gilligan. Reports counted one dead rioter, 118 injured, and 465 arrested.
WORK RESUMES ON EAST FREEWAY AS THE RESULT OF A COMPROMISE BETWEEN FRANKLIN AUTO PARTS CO AND R W WANDER INC.
A three day race riot erupts in Rochester, NY.
AN ESTIMATED $3000 IS STOLEN FROM THE CAR OF REV LEROY JENKINS, HIS NIGHT'S COLLECTION FROM A TENT REVIVAL, AT THE OHIO EXPOSITION CENTER PARKING LOT.

In the Gulf of Tonkin, as part of Operation Plan 34A, South Vietnamese commandos in unmarked speed boats raid two North Vietnamese military bases located on islands just off the coast. In the vicinity is the destroyer U.S.S. Maddox.

Three North Vietnamese patrol boats attack the American destroyer U.S.S. Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin ten miles off the coast of North Vietnam. They fire three torpedoes and machine-guns, but only a single machine-gun round actually strikes the Maddox with no causalities. U.S. Navy fighters from the carrier Ticonderoga, led by Commander James Stockdale, attack the patrol boats, sinking one and damaging the other two. At the White House, it is Sunday morning (twelve hours behind Vietnam time). President Johnson, reacting cautiously to reports of the incident, decides against retaliation. Instead, he sends a diplomatic message to Hanoi warning of "grave consequences" from any further "unprovoked" attacks. Johnson then orders the Maddox to resume operations in the Gulf of Tonkin in the same vicinity where the attack had occurred. Meanwhile, the Joints Chiefs of Staff put U.S. combat troops on alert and also select targets in North Vietnam for a possible bombing raid, should the need arise.

The Maddox, joined by a second destroyer U.S.S. C. Turner Joy begin a series of vigorous zigzags in the Gulf of Tonkin sailing to within eight miles of North Vietnam's coast, while at the same time, South Vietnamese commandos in speed boats harass North Vietnamese defenses along the coastline. By nightfall, thunderstorms roll in, affecting the accuracy of electronic instruments on the destroyers. Crew members reading their instruments believe they have come under torpedo attack from North Vietnamese patrol boats. Both destroyers open fire on numerous apparent targets but there are no actual sightings of any attacking boats.

Although immediate doubts arise concerning the validity of the second attack, the Joint Chiefs of Staff strongly recommend a retaliatory bombing raid against North Vietnam. Press reports in America greatly embellish the second attack with spectacular eyewitness accounts although no journalists had been on board the destroyers. At the White House, President Johnson decides to retaliate. Thus, the first bombing of North Vietnam by the United States occurs as oil facilities and naval targets are attacked without warning by 64 U.S. Navy fighter bombers. "Our response for the present will be limited and fitting," President Johnson tells Americans during a midnight TV appearance, an hour after the attack began. "We Americans know, although others appear to forget, the risk of spreading conflict. We still seek no wider war." Two Navy jets are shot down during the bombing raids, resulting in the first American prisoner of war, Lt. Everett Alvarez of San Jose, California, who is taken to an internment center in Hanoi, later dubbed the "Hanoi Hilton" by the nearly six hundred American airmen who become POWs.

Opinion polls indicate 85 percent of Americans support President Johnson's bombing decision. Numerous newspaper editorials also come out in support of the President. Johnson's aides, including Defense Secretary McNamara, now lobby Congress to pass a White House resolution that will give the President a free hand in Vietnam.

During a meeting in the Senate, McNamara is confronted by Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon who had been tipped off by someone in the Pentagon that the Maddox had in fact been involved in the South Vietnamese commando raids against North Vietnam and thus was not the victim of an "unprovoked" attack. McNamara responds that the U.S. Navy "...played absolutely no part in, was not associated with, was not aware of, any South Vietnamese actions, if there were any..."

In response to the two incidents involving the Maddox and Turner Joy, the U.S. Congress, at the behest of President Johnson, overwhelmingly passes the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution put forward by the White House allowing the President "to take all necessary steps, including the use of armed force" to prevent further attacks against U.S. forces. The Resolution, passed unanimously in the House and 98-2 in the Senate, grants enormous power to President Johnson to wage an undeclared war in Vietnam from the White House. The only Senators voting against the Resolution are Wayne Morse, and Ernest Gruening of Alaska who said "all Vietnam is not worth the life of a single American boy."
SCHAAF DAIRY FARM ALONG RT 33, A HISTORIC FARMING LANDMARK IS DUE FOR DESTRUCTION TO MAKE WAY FOR THE EAST-WEST FREEWAY.
Northland Mall opens.
FRANKLIN COUNTY BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS RECEIVES $104,000 FROM THE CITY AND STATE AS PAYMENT FOR COUNTY OWNED LAND TO BE USED FOR THE EAST FREEWAY.

In Saigon, students and Buddhist militants begin a series of escalating protests against General Khanh's military regime. As a result, Khanh resigns as sole leader in favor of a triumvirate that includes himself, Gen. Minh and Gen. Khiem. The streets of Saigon soon disintegrate into chaos and mob violence amid the government's gross instability.

President Johnson is nominated at the Democratic National Convention. During his campaign he declares "We are not about to send American boys nine or ten thousand miles away from home to do what Asian boys ought to be doing for themselves."
"Mary Poppins" by Walt Disney released.
Philadelphia race riot - 341 people were injured, 774 people were arrested and 225 stores were damaged or destroyed in the three days of rioting.
The first Titan III missile is launched from Cape Canaveral.
GOV RHODES PARTICIPATES IN A GROUNDBREAKING CEREMONY FOR TWO NEW BUILDINGS AT THE STATE FAIRGROUNDS, NAMING THEM THE FRANK J LAUSCHE YOUTH CENTER AND THE MYERS Y COOPER ARENA.
DR ALBERT B SABIN, DEVELOPER OF AN ORAL POLIO VACCINE, PRESENTS AWARDS TO 100 OHIO HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS PARTICIPATING IN THE YOUTH SCIENCE EXHIBIT AT THE OHIO STATE FAIR.
President Johnson assembles his top aides at the White House to ponder the future course of action in Vietnam.
PLANS ARE BEGUN FOR A STATE HISTORY CENTER ON THE STATE FAIRGROUNDS TO COMBINE THE OHIO STATE MUSEUM, NOW AT 15TH AVE AND HIGH ST, AND THE STATE ARCHIVES, 1234 E BROAD ST.
FRANK WILLIAMS OF THE OHIO DEPT OF HIGHWAYS SAYS THE COMPLETE COLUMBUS INNERBELT SHOULD BE OPEN TO TRAFFIC OCT 31, 1964 AND THE FIRST SECTION OF THE OUTERBELT BY OCT 15.
Two disgruntled South Vietnamese generals stage an unsuccessful coup in Saigon.
"Bewitched" premiers.
Saturn I launch. Apollo systems test. Third orbital test. First closed-loop guidance test.
"The Addams Family" premiers.

AS-102 (also designated SA-7) was the seventh flight of the Saturn I launch vehicle, which carried the boilerplate Apollo spacecraft BP-15 into low Earth orbit. The test lasted for five orbits (about seven and a half hours). The spacecraft and its upper stage completed 59 orbits before reentering the atmosphere and crashing in the Indian Ocean on September 22, 1964.
"Flipper" premiers.
"The Man from U.N.C.L.E." premiers.
WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BOARD PROPOSES A $1.25 MILLION BOND ISSUE TO FINANCE A 13-ROOM ADDITION TO GRANVILLE JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL.
"The Munsters" premiers.
Texas & Pacific gains control of Kansas, Oklahoma & Gulf; Oklahoma City-Ada-Atoka sold to Atchison Topeka & Santa Fe.
"Gomer Pyle, U.S.M.C." premiers.
"Gilligan's Island" premiers.
The Tokaido Shinkansen high speed rail line is completed, with the first train travelling from Tokyo to Shin-Osaka at 210 km/h (130 mph)
The Summer Olympics open in Tokyo, Japan.
Voskhod I carries the first 3-man crew into orbit.
Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev is ousted from power, replaced by Leonid Brezhnev as leader of the U.S.S.R.

New York, Chicago & St. Louis (Nickel Plate Road) merged into Norfolk & Western. Wabash and Pittsburg & West Virginia leased by Norfolk & Western. Norfolk & Western gains control of Akron, Canton & Youngstown as well.
China detonates its first nuclear weapon.
OHIO HIGHWAY DEPARTMENT OFFICIALS SPEED UP PURCHASE OF LAND NEEDED TO CONSTRUCT COLUMBUS OUTERBELT.
In a ceremony on the parade field at Redstone Arsenal, the REDSTONE missile was ceremonially retired.
The first section of Interstate 71 to open is between Interstate 270 in Columbus and a point a mile within Hamilton County near the Warren County line.

The first attack by Viet Cong against Americans in Vietnam occurs at Bien Hoa air base, 12 miles north of Saigon. A pre-dawn mortar assault kills five Americans, two South Vietnamese, and wounds nearly a hundred others. President Johnson dismisses all recommendations for a retaliatory air strike against North Vietnam.
OBETZ COUNCIL APPROVES STATE HIGHWAY DEPT PLANS TO LOCATE THE OUTERBELT INSIDE THE VILLAGE LIMITS.
THE U S BUREAU OF PUBLIC ROADS REJECTS LONGSTANDING COLUMBUS AND STATE PLANS TO WIDEN I-71 TO SIX LANES, BUT GIVES PERMISSION TO BUILD THE OUTERBELT INTERCHANGE FOR SIX LANES.

With 61 percent of the popular vote, Democrat Lyndon B. Johnson is re-elected as President of the United States in a land-slide victory, the biggest to date in U.S. history, defeating Republican Barry Goldwater by 16 million votes. The Democrats also achieve big majorities in both the U.S. House and Senate.
Comedian Lenny Bruce is found guilty of obscenity for a performance in New York City on April, 1964 at the Caf Au Go Go in Greenwich Village. He is sentenced to four months in prison.
Mariner 3 is launched towards Mars on a Atlas LV-3 Agena-D, but the payload fairing fails to separate, causing the probe to run out of power and have too low a velocity to approach Mars correctly.
AN ORDINANCE WHICH WOULD PERMIT DEVELOPMENT OF A PREVIOUSLY INACCESSIBLE SECTION OF THE COLONIAL HILLS SUBDIVISION IS INTRODUCED IN WORTHINGTON CITY COUNCIL.
A TOUGH NEW FEDERAL POLICY STATES THAT THE US BUREAU OF PUBLIC ROADS WILL ONLY PAY FOR A GRAVEL ROAD TO SERVE PROPERTIES WEST OF BRICE RD ALONG THE EAST FREEWAY.
RAILROAD COAL TRAIN DERAILS ABOUT NINE MILES NORTHEAST OF WORTHINGTON.
Mariner 4 is launched towards Mars on a Atlas LV-3 Agena-D rocket.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The first crawler assembly is complete.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The crawlerway is ready for testing.

At the White House, President Johnson's top aides, including Secretary of State Dean Rusk, National Security Advisor McGeorge Bundy, and Defense Secretary McNamara, recommend a policy of gradual escalation of U.S. military involvement in Vietnam.
The Beatles release "Beatles for Sale"
COLUMBUS PLANNING COMMISSION RECOMMENDS THAT THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY (RT 315) BE BUILT WEST OF OSU ALONG THE CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO RAILWAY TRACKS.

A Douglas DC-3 was carrying 17 people (13 passengers, 4 crew) between the Bolivian cities of Tipuani and La Paz when the plane crashed in the Andes Mountains. The impact had been caused when a bomb blast in the aft passenger cabin blew off the plane's tail. It is believed that a passenger used the bomb to commit suicide for insurance money, and no one survived.
NEW YORK CENTRAL TRAIN IS DERAILED NORTHEAST OF GEORGESVILLE RD AND SULLIVANT AVE; TANKER CAR CONTAINING ETHYLENE OXIDE EXPLODES, INJURING 45 PERSONS, INCLUDING 25 FIREMEN.
WORTHINGTON COUNCIL GIVES CONSENT TO OHIO HIGHWAY DEPT TO PROCEED WITH CONSTRUCTION OF OUTERBELT (I-270) THROUGH THE CITY.
WORTHINGTON COUNCIL GIVES CONSENT TO OHIO HIGHWAY DEPT TO PROCEED WITH CONSTRUCTION OF OUTERBELT (I-270) THROUGH THE CITY.

Another military coup occurs in Saigon by the South Vietnamese army. This time Gen. Khanh and young officers, led by Nguyen Cao Ky and Nguyen Van Thieu, oust older generals including Gen. Minh from the government and seize control.

An angry Ambassador Taylor summons the young officers to the U.S. embassy then scolds them like schoolboys over the continuing instability and endless intrigues plaguing South Vietnam's government. Americans, he had already warned them, are "tired of coups." Taylor's behavior greatly offends the young officers. Gen. Khanh retaliates by lashing out in the press against Taylor and the U.S., stating that America is reverting to "colonialism" in its treatment of South Vietnam.
"Goldfinger" featuring Sean Connery as James Bond released in the United States.
WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BD ANNOUNCES 3 WINNING BIDDERS TO CONSTRUCT 24-CLASSROOM JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL IN WORTHINGWAY SUBDIVISION.

Viet Cong terrorists set off a car bomb explosion at the Brinks Hotel, an American officers' residence in downtown Saigon. The bomb is timed to detonate at 5:45 p.m., during 'happy hour' in the bar. Two Americans are killed and 58 wounded. President Johnson dismisses all recommendations for a retaliatory air strike against North Vietnam. By year's end, the number of American military advisors in South Vietnam is 23,000. There are now an estimated 170,000 Viet Cong/NVA fighters in the 'People's Revolutionary Army' which has begun waging coordinated battalion-sized attacks against South Vietnamese troops in villages around Saigon.
WORTHINGTON'S NEW 500,000 GALLON WATER TANK GOES INTO SERVICE.
THE 12/13/64 DERAILMENT OF A NEW YORK CENTRAL TRAIN IN WESTERN FRANKLIN CO IS ATTRIBUTED TO "A BURNED OUT JOURNAL BOX ON A GONDOLA CAR"; TOTAL DAMAGE IS NOW SET AT $65,000.
Donald Campbell sets a boat speed record of 276.33 mph in the Bluebird K7 jet powered hydrofoil on Lake Dumbleyung in Western Australia.

10,000 NVA soldiers arrive in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam via the Ho Chi Minh trail, carrying sophisticated weapons provided by China and the Soviet Union. They shore up Viet Cong battalions with the weapons and also provide experienced soldiers as leaders.
Ross Laboratories merged with Abbott Laboratories, one of the world's largest healthcare corporations.
Western Electric introduces touch tone dialing.
The Columbus Center at 100 E. Broad St. opens. 25 stories.
OSU student Marjorie Cocoziello is jailed for not paying a $5 jaywalking fine, sparking protests at police headquarters.
OSU: Boyd Lab, 155 W. Woodruff Ave, is extensively remodeled and assigned to the Department of Engineering Mechanics.
OSU: Bradford Commons, 153 W. 12th Ave., opens. Serves as a dining hall.
OSU: Caldwell Lab, 2024 Neil Ave., addition.
OSU: Fontana Lab, 116 W. 19th Ave., opens. Part of the Chemical Engineering complex.
OSU: The Electroscience Lab, 1320 Kinnear Road, addition.
Silver is de-monetized. All coins now made from copper-nickel alloy.
Brookside Elementary School opens.
MANY OWNERS OF EXPENSIVE HOMES OVERLOOKING THE OLENTANGY RIVER VALLEY PROTEST CONSTRUCTION OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY.
ABOUT 150 WORTHINGTON AREA RESIDENTS CALL THE PROPOSED OLENTANGY FREEWAY FROM THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY TO DOWNTOWN COLUMBUS A WASTE OF TAXPAYERS' MONEY.
$2 MIL EXCHANGE OF PROPERTIES INVOLVING COLUMBUS AND SOUTHERN OHIO ELECTRIC, DAYTON POWER & LIGHT AND CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC, TAKE PART IN $8 MIL STEAM GENERATING PLANT
WORTHINGTON CITY COUNCIL TO ENDORSE CONSTRUCTION OF THE OLENTANGY EXPRESSWAY THROUGH THE SUBURB, COUNTER TO THE AIMS OF A 300-PLUS MEMBER CIVIC ASSOCIATION.
CONSTRUCTION OF THE FIRST PART OF THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY WITHIN THE CITY LIMITS IS FIRST AMONG PROJECTS IN CITY ENGINEER ROBERT WERNER'S 1965 CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS BUDGET.
Gemini 2 suborbital launch to test heat shield.
John Joseph Carberry appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The crawler moved under its own power for the first time.
Sir Winston Churchill dies at the age of 90 with his wife Lady Clementine Churchill and other members of the family at his bedside.

General Khanh seizes full control of South Vietnam's government. Johnson aides, National Security Advisor McGeorge Bundy and Defense Secretary Robert McNamara, send a memo to the President stating that America's limited military involvement in Vietnam is not succeeding, and that the U.S. has reached a 'fork in the road' in Vietnam and must either soon escalate or withdraw.
Operation Game Warden begins U.S. Navy river patrols on South Vietnam's 3000 nautical miles of inland waterways.
Alaska: Measuring 8.7, the quake generated a tsunami reported to be about 10.7 metres high on Shemya Island.
National Security Advisor McGeorge Bundy visits South Vietnam for the first time. In North Vietnam, Soviet Prime Minister Aleksei Kosygin coincidentally arrives in Hanoi.
Viet Cong guerrillas attack the U.S. military compound at Pleiku in the Central Highlands, killing eight Americans, wounding 126 and destroying ten aircraft.

I've had enough of this," President Johnson tells his National Security advisors. He then approves Operation Flaming Dart, the bombing of a North Vietnamese army camp near Dong Hoi by U.S. Navy jets from the carrier Ranger. Johnson makes no speeches or public statements concerning his decision. Opinion polls taken in the U.S. shortly after the bombing indicate a 70 percent approval rating for the President and an 80 percent approval of U.S. military involvement in Vietnam. Johnson now agrees to a long-standing recommendation from his advisors for a sustained bombing campaign against North Vietnam. In Hanoi, Soviet Prime Minister Kosygin is pressured by the North Vietnamese to provide unlimited military aid to counter the American "aggression." Kosygin gives in to their demands. As a result, sophisticated Soviet surface-to-air missiles (SAMs) begin arriving in Hanoi within weeks.
CITY PLANNING COMMISSION RECOMMENDS THAT THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HIGHWAYS LIFT DRIVEWAY ACCESS LIMITATIONS ALONG SOUTH HIGH ST BETWEEN OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY AND WILLIAMS RD.

A Saturn I vehicle SA-9 launched a multiple payload into a high 744 by 496 km (462 by 308 mi) earth orbit. The rocket carried a boilerplate (BP) CSM (BP-16) and, fitted inside the SM, the Pegasus I meteoroid detection satellite. This was the eighth successful Saturn flight in a row, and the first to carry an active payload. BP-16's launch escape tower was jettisoned following second-stage S-IV ignition. After attaining orbit, the spacecraft were separated from the S-IV. Thereupon the Pegasus I's panels were deployed and were ready to perform their task, i.e., registering meteoroid impact and relaying the information to the ground.
Another military coup in Saigon results in General Khanh finally ousted from power and a new military/civilian government installed, led by Dr. Phan Huy Quat.
Malcolm X is assassinated.
