General Westmoreland requests two battalions of U.S. Marines to protect the American air base at Da Nang from 6000 Viet Cong massed in the vicinity. The President approves his request, despite the "grave reservations" of Ambassador Taylor in Vietnam who warns that America may be about to repeat the same mistakes made by the French in sending ever-increasing numbers of soldiers into the Asian forests and jungles of a "hostile foreign country" where friend and foe are indistinguishable.

Operation Rolling Thunder begins as over 100 American fighter-bombers attack targets in North Vietnam. Scheduled to last eight weeks, Rolling Thunder will instead go on for three years. The first U.S. air strikes also occur against the Ho Chi Minh trail. Throughout the war, the trail is heavily bombed by American jets with little actual success in halting the tremendous flow of soldiers and supplies from the North. 500 American jets will be lost attacking the trail. After each attack, bomb damage along the trail is repaired by female construction crews. During the entire war, the U.S. will fly 3 million sorties and drop nearly 8 million tons of bombs, four times the tonnage dropped during all of World War II, in the largest display of firepower in the history of warfare. The majority of bombs are dropped in South Vietnam against Viet Cong and North Vietnamese Army positions, resulting in 3 million civilian refugees due to the destruction of numerous villages. In North Vietnam, military targets include fuel depots and factories. The North Vietnamese react to the air strikes by decentralizing their factories and supply bases, thus minimizing their vulnerability to bomb damage.

"Bloody Sunday." Voting rights advocates attempt to march from Selma, Alabama to the state capital. Governer Wallace had tried to prevent the march by calling on the highway patrol. State troopers hold back the marchers with tear gas, clubs, and extreme violence.
The first U.S. combat troops arrive in Vietnam as 3500 Marines land at China Beach to defend the American air base at Da Nang. They join 23,000 American military advisors already in Vietnam.
President Johnson authorizes the use of Napalm, a petroleum based anti-personnel bomb that showers hundreds of explosive pellets upon impact.

Operation Market Time, a joint effort between the U.S. Navy and South Vietnamese Navy, commences to disrupt North Vietnamese sea routes used to funnel supplies into the South. The operation is highly successful in cutting off coastal supply lines and results in the North Vietnamese shifting to the more difficult land route along the Ho Chi Minh trail.
CONSTRUCTION WILL BE DELAYED FOUR MONTHS ON THE MASSIVE WORTHINGTON BYPASS SECTION OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY.
A. Leonov takes the first spacewalk.
CITY ENGINEER ROBERT WERNER HOLDS OUT THE POSSIBILITY THAT ALL OR A LARGE PART OF THE EAST FREEWAY WILL BE OPEN TO TRAFFIC BY THE END OF THIS YEAR.

A second Selma-to-Montgomery March begins, this time under the protection of a federal court order. More than 25,000 march to the Alabama Capitol Building to ask Wallace to remove all remaining obstacles to black voter registration. Although the 15th Amendment prohibited racial discrimination in voting, state laws and practices were in place which made it difficult, if not impossible, for blacks to register to vote.
Gemini 3: Gus Grisson and John Young fly the first two-man Gemini-Atlas rocket for 3 orbits.
FRANK C MEDICK, 89, DEVELOPER OF MEDICK ESTATES IN WORTHINGTON AND FOUNDER AND BOARD CHMN OF MEDICK-BARROWS CO, DIES AT HIS HOME, 340 TUCKER DR.
Groundbreaking ceremony held for the Justin S. Morrill and Abraham Lincoln  towers, 26 story dormitories on the campus of Ohio State University.
Viet Cong terrorists bomb the U.S. embassy in Saigon.
Installation of five F1 engines is completed  in the static test stand at the Marshall Space Center.
NASA Crawler Transporter: Road tests, mating and modifications.

At the White House, President Johnson authorizes sending two more Marine battalions and up to 20,000 logistical personnel to Vietnam. The President also authorizes American combat troops to conduct patrols to root out Viet Cong in the countryside. His decision to allow offensive operations is kept secret from the American press and public for two months.
Bob Dylan appeared on the pop music charts for the first time. "Subterranean Homesick Blues" entered the Top 40 at number 39. The song stayed on the charts for eight weeks.
HOPING TO THWART VANDALS, WORTHINGTON SCHOOL SUPT H C MCCORD PLACES FOUR BOULDERS IN FRONT OF THE HIGH SCHOOL AND INVITES STUDENTS TO VENT THEIR DECORATIVE ENTHUSIASM ON THEM.

President Johnson delivers his "Peace Without Conquest" Speech at Johns Hopkins University offering Hanoi "unconditional discussions" to stop the war in return for massive economic assistance in modernizing Vietnam. "Old Ho can't turn that down," Johnson privately tells his aides. But Johnson's peace overture is quickly rejected.

The Houston Astrodome, the world's first air conditioned domed stadium, opens in Houston, Texas. The Houston Astros play the New York Yankees. The stadium featured a transparent steel roof and was air conditioned, and could hold 42,217 fans.
A 16 second firing of the center F1 engine is completed in the static test stand at the Marshall Space Center.
Midwest Great Lakes region: tornadoes in Iowa, Ill., Ind., Ohio, Mich., and Wis. caused 256 deaths.
Numerous tornadoes kill 55 in Ohio, F4 storm in Toledo.
A SOUTH FREEWAY BOTTLENECK IS BECOMING AS CONGESTED AS NORTH FREEWAY TRAFFIC, BUT FEDERAL HIGHWAY ENGINEERS REFUSE TO HELP THE STATE HIGHWAY DEPT SOLVE THE PROBLEM.
A thousand tons of bombs are dropped on Viet Cong positions by U.S. and South Vietnamese fighter-bombers.
The first static test of all five first stage Saturn V F1 Engines in the static test stand at the Marshall Space Center. They fire for 16 seconds and generate 7.5 million poinds of thust.

In Washington, 15,000 students gather to protest the U.S. bombing campaign. Student demonstrators will often refer to President Johnson, his advisors, the Pentagon, Washington bureaucrats, and weapons manufacturers, simply as "the Establishment."
ONE OF THE WORST TRAFFIC JAMS IN CENTRAL OHIO HISTORY BACKS UP VEHICLES ON SOUTHBOUND I-71, DUE TO ROAD CONSTRUCTION THAT FUNNELED TRAFFIC INTO ONE LANE.

In Honolulu, Johnson's top aides, including McNamara, Gen. Westmoreland, Gen. Wheeler, William Bundy, and Ambassador Taylor, meet and agree to recommend to the President sending another 40,000 combat soldiers to Vietnam.
TRAFFIC HELICOPTER CRASHES INTO AN EMBANKMENT AT THE EAST FREEWAY CONSTRUCTION SITE NEAR KENTON AND BOWMAN AVES, SLIGHTLY INJURING CARL WENDELKEN, 39, AND GEORGE DENNISON, 31.
President Johnson announces Americans in Vietnam are eligible for combat pay.
The first U.S. Army combat troops, 3500 men of the 173rd Airborne Brigade, arrive in Vietnam.
The second successful static firing of 5 F1 rocket engines in the static test stand at the Marshall Space Center. The duration is 15 seconds.
GOV RHODES AND TRUSTEES OF OHIO HISTORICAL SOCIETY PLAN AN $8 MILLION OHIO HISTORICAL CENTER ON TEMPLE OF GOOD WILL PROPERTY IN THE CIVIC CENTER, NORTH OF THE FEDERAL BUILDING.
Viet Cong over-run South Vietnamese troops in Phuoc Long Province north of Saigon and also attack in central South Vietnam.

The first bombing pause is announced by the U.S. in the hope that Hanoi will now negotiate. There will be six more pauses during the Rolling Thunder bombing campaign, all with same intention. However, each time, the North Vietnamese ignore the peace overtures and instead use the pause to repair air defenses and send more troops and supplies into the South via the Ho Chi Minh trail. May 13, 1965 - Viet Cong attack the U.S. special forces camp in Phuoc Long. During the fighting, 2nd Lt. Charles Williams, earns the Congressional Medal of Honor by knocking out a Viet Cong machine-gun then guiding rescue helicopters, while wounded four times.
DEPUTY OHIO HIGHWAY DIR FRANK M WILLIAMS ADMITS PLANS FOR 1965 COLUMBUS OUTERBELT CONSTRUCTION WERE TOO AMBITIOUS--ONLY 3 OF 8 PROJECTS WILL START ON TIME.
U.S. bombing of North Vietnam resumes.
The third successful static firing of 5 F1 rocket engines in the static test stand at the Marshall Space Center. The duration is 40 seconds and the outer engines are gimbeled for the first time.

DEC releases the PDP-8 minicomputer. At $18,000 each, it is the cheapest computer mass marketed. The PDP-8 used 12 bits for its arithmetic, memory word size, and memory address. The PDP-8's basic configuration had a main memory of 4,096 twelve-bit words, the maximum that could be addressed with twelve bits. The memory was magnetic-core memory with a cycle time of 1.5 microseconds (0.6 MHz).
FRANKLIN CO CMSNRS DECIDE THAT TUTTLE RD WILL REMAIN A THROUGH STREET, INSTEAD OF BEING BISECTED BY THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY.
OHIO STATE HIGHWAY DEPT PAYS CITY LOT PRICES OF $11,562 AN ACRE FOR PASTURELAND IT NEEDS FOR THE WESTERVILLE BYPASS SECTION OF THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY.

Pegasus 2 was a meteoroid detection satellite. The Saturn I launch vehicle (SA-8) placed the spacecraft, protected by a boilerplate CSM (BP-26), into a 740-by-509-km (460-by-316-mi) orbit. Once in orbit, the dummy CSM was jettisoned. Pegasus 2, still attached to the second stage of the launch vehicle, then deployed its 29-m (96-ft) winglike panels. Within several hours, the device began registering meteoroid hits.
SHELDON YERIAN OF NEW ALBANY, COLUMBUS TRANSIT CO TROLLEY DRIVER FOR 30 YEARS, DRIVES THE FINAL REGULAR RUN ON A TRACKLESS ELECTRIC TROLLEY LINE IN COLUMBUS.
HIGHBANKS METROPOLITAN PARK, EAST OF THE OLENTANGY RIVER, NORTH OF WORTHINGTON, IS AN AS YET UNDEVELOPED WILDERNESS AREA WITH GREAT POTENTIAL.
TEN-YEAR-OLD WORTHINGTON STEEL CO, 6500 HUNTLEY RD, WORTHINGTON, ACQUIRES 5 ACRES FOR A STEEL STORAGE CENTER, FREEING SPACE FOR NEW MACHINERY AND INCREASED STEEL PROCESSING.
MISS RUTH GRISWOLD, 88, FORMER WORTHINGTON RESIDENT, DIES IN BERKELEY, CALIF, WHERE SHE HAS LIVED SINCE HER FAMILY RESIDENCE, THE HISTORIC GRISWOLD INN, WAS TORN DOWN IN 1964.
Gemini 4: Ed White makes the first American spacewalk from his Gemini space capsule.
ANHEUSER-BUSCH OFFICIALS CONSIDER 3 SITES FOR PLANNED $50 MILLION BREWERY: EAST OF LOCKBOURNE RD; WILLIAMS RD WEST OF OBETZ; EAST OF WORTHINGTON, NORTH OF RT 161.
Nguyen Cao Ky takes power in South Vietnam as the new prime minister with Nguyen Van Thieu functioning as official chief of state. They lead the 10th government in 20 months.
First launch of a Titan IIIC rocket. It introduced large strap on solid rocket boosters.
ANHEUSER-BUSCH, INC, ANNOUNCES IT HAS TAKEN OPTION ON ABOUT 260 ACRES OF LAND IN SHARON TWP, BOUNDED BY SCHROCK RD, OUTERBELT RIGHTOF-WAY, WORTHINGTON CITY LIMITS, AND I-71.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The hydraulic jacking and leveling system is ready for testing when the crawler picks up its first load,  a mobile launcher.
MAYOR SENSENBRENNER SAYS HE WILL REFUSE WATER AND SEWER SERVICE TO ANHEUSER-BUSCH BREWERY UNLESS THE SHARON TWP SITE, ADJACENT TO WORTHINGTON, COMES INTO COLUMBUS.
Viet Cong stage a mortar attack against Da Nang air base and destroy three aircraft.

Canadian Pacific 21 departed Vancouver for Whitehorse. The Douglas DC-6B crashed in British Columbia after the plane's tail section broke away from the rest of the fuselage. Investigators suspect that a passenger mixed acid and gunpowder in the aft lavatory setting off an explosion in the passenger compartment. The crash killed all 52 aboard (46 passengers, 6 crew). The motive for the bombing is believed to be a suicide-for-insurance scheme.
Henry Cabot Lodge is reappointed as U.S. ambassador to South Vietnam.
Mariner 4 makes its closest approach to Mars at 9,486 km. The first successful flyby of a spacecraft of Mars.
Comedian George Carlin does his first Merv Griffin Show appearance. Performed "The Indian Sergeant." (Eventually 29 Griffin shows.)
President Johnson meets with top aides to decide the future course of action in Vietnam.
MAYOR SENSENBRENNER VETOES AN ORDINANCE ASKING FOR ADDITIONAL OLENTANGY FREEWAY ALIGNMENT STUDIES.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The crawler moved a launch umbilical tower about one mile on two stretches of road, one surfaced with washed gravel and the other with crushed granite.
NASA Crawler Transporter: Pieces of bearing races, rollers and retainers from the crawler's traction support roller assembly are found on the track.

During a noontime press conference, President Johnson announces he will send 44 combat battalions to Vietnam increasing the U.S. military presence to 125,000 men. Monthly draft calls are doubled to 35,000. "I have asked the commanding general, General Westmoreland, what more he needs to meet this mounting aggression. He has told me. And we will meet his needs. We cannot be defeated by force of arms. We will stand in Vietnam." "...I do not find it easy to send the flower of our youth, our finest young men, into battle. I have spoken to you today of the divisions and the forces and the battalions and the units, but I know them all, every one. I have seen them in a thousand streets, of a hundred towns, in every state in this union?working and laughing and building, and filled with hope and life. I think I know, too, how their mothers weep and how their families sorrow."

NASA launches Pegasus 3, third of the meteoroid detection satellites, as scheduled at 8:00 a.m. EST, from Cape Kennedy. As earlier, an Apollo spacecraft (boilerplate 9) served as the payload's shroud. This flight (SA-10) marked the end of the Saturn I program, which during its seven-year lifetime had achieved 10 straight successful launches and had contributed immeasurably to American rocket technology.
LBJ signs the Medicare Law at the Harry S. Truman library. Former President Truman and his wife Bess attend.
Tenth and final launch of a Saturn I (Juno V) rocket.
Gulf, Colorado & Santa Fe and Panhandle & Santa Fe merged into the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe.
COLUMBUS JOINS CITIES IN 8 OTHER STATES THAT HAD SIGHTINGS OF UNIDENTIFIED FLYING OBJECTS (UFOS) THAT HAVE BEEN PLAGUING THE COUNTRY FOR THE PAST 3 DAYS.

The destruction of suspected Viet Cong villages near Da Nang by a U.S. Marine rifle company is shown on CBS TV and generates controversy in America. Earlier, seven Marines had been killed nearby while searching for Viet Cong following a mortar attack against the air base at Da Nang.
RESIDENTS OF GLENBROOK SUBDIVISION ARE IRKED BECAUSE THE SUBDIVISION LOST ALL DIRECT ACCESS TO LIVINGSTON AND COLLEGE AVE BECAUSE OF EAST FREEWAY CONSTRUCTION.
President Johnson asks Congress for an additional $1.7 billion for the war.
CITY AND STATE OFFICIALS AGREE TO KEEP THE EAST FREEWAY CLOSED UNTIL IT CAN BE USED TO KELTON AND MILLER AVES.
Viet Cong destroy two million gallons of fuel in storage tanks near Da Nang.
First full duration, 150 second firing of five Saturn F1 engines in the static test stand at the Marshall Space Center. The engines generate 7.5 million pounds of thrust.
The Beatles release "Help"
STATE CONTROLLING BOARD AUTHORIZES OSU TO SPEND $900,000 TO BUY THE LAND REMAINING IN THE UNIVERSITY'S DORMITORY COMPLEX SITE NORTH OF WOODRUFF AVE
President Johnson signs the Voting Rights Bill.
The U.S. conducts major air strikes against the Viet Cong.
The first successful full duration firing of five J-2 engines in the Saturn S-II stage in Santa Susana, California. The engines fired for 360 seconds

Watts riots in Los Angeles. Over the course of six days, 31,000 and 35,000 adults participated in the riots.Over the six days, there were 34 deaths, 1,032 injuries, 3,438 arrests, and over $40 million in property damage.
Pacific Electric absorbed into the Southern Pacific.
The first successful full duration firing of the Saturn S-IVB third stage, including engine restart after 30 minutes, in Sacramento.

Operation Starlite begins the first major U.S. ground operation in Vietnam as U.S. Marines wage a preemptive strike against 1500 Viet Cong planning to assault the American airfield at Chu Lai. The Marines arrive by helicopter and by sea following heavy artillery and air bombardment of Viet Cong positions. 45 Marines are killed and 120 wounded. Viet Cong suffer 614 dead and 9 taken prisoner. This decisive first victory gives a big boost to U.S. troop morale.
Gemini 5 launched: Gordon Cooper, Charles Conrad, 128 orbits.
ANDREW D RODGERS III, DESCENDANT OF LUCAS SULLIVANT, PRAISES THE OHIO HISTORICAL SOC FOR SEEKING THE CIVIC CENTER SITE FOR ITS $8 MILLION NEW OHIO HISTORICAL CENTER.
Hurricane: southern Fla. and La.: Betsy killed 75 people and cost more than $1.4 ($8.5) billion.

President Johnson signs a law criminalizing draft card burning. Although it may result in a five year prison sentence and $1000 fine, the burnings become common during anti-war rallies and often attract the attention of news media.
Combined Action Platoons are formed by U.S. Marines utilizing South Vietnamese militia units to protect villages and conduct patrols to root out Viet Cong guerrillas.
SEN FRANK J LAUSCHE PARTICIPATES IN THE DEDICATION OF A BUILDING IN HIS HONOR AT THE OHIO STATE FAIRGROUNDS, THE NEW $720,000 YOUTH EXHIBITS BUILDING.
"My Mother the Car" premiers. Possibly the worst sitcom of all time.
"Lost in Space" premiers.
"Hogan's Heroes" premiers.
"Get Smart" premiers.
"I Dream of Jeannie" premiers.
SEWER SUPT CARL SCHOENE SAYS ENGINEERS ARE TRYING TO DETERMINE HOW TO STOP FLOODING IN THE 17TH AVE UNDERPASS NEAR THE OHIO STATE FAIRGROUNDS.
Comedian George Carlin does his first Mike Douglas Show appearance. "Indian Sergeant." (Eventually 22 Douglas shows.)
GOVERNOR RHODES ENDS HIS `WONDERFUL WORLD OF OHIO' TOUR WITH VISITS TO THE COLUMBUS ZOO, THE HISTORIC ORANGE JOHNSON HOUSE, AND THE WORTHINGTON RAILROAD MUSEUM.
NBC and CBS starts broadcasting its evening lineup in color television, as color becomes an asset in the ratings war.
LESTER A BURCHMAN, WOOLWORTH PRESIDENT AND L F DAVIS, VICE PRESIDENT ASSEMBLE FOR OPENING OF A WOOLCO IN THE GREAT WESTERN SHOPPING CENTER, W BROAD AND WILSON ROADS.
THE TOLEDO-COLUMBUS PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD FREIGHT TRAIN JUMPS THE NORFOLK & WESTERN OWNED TRACKS JUST NORTH OF WEBER ROAD CAUSING MASSIVE TRAIN DAMAGE AND BLOCKING TWO TRACKS.
"Hang on Sloopy" first played at Ohio Stadium, OSU playing Illinois
GOVERNOR RHODES ANNOUNCES THAT THE FAIRGROUND COLISEUM WILL BE DEDICATED DURING 1966'S FAIR AS THE JAMES M COX COLISEUM.
THREE CARS OF A NEW YORK CENTRAL RAILROAD FREIGHT TRAIN JUMP THE TRACKS AND OVERTURN IN THE RAILROAD'S MAIN LINE JUST NORTH OF THE WILSON BRIDGE ROAD CROSSING.
WORTHINGTON COUNCIL APPROVES OF $500,000 RETIREMENT CENTER AT HARTFORD STREET AND E STAFFORD AVE; COUNCIL GRANTS REQUEST OF CHURCHES TO REDUCE SQUARE FOOTAGE OF UNITS.
Anti-war rallies occur in 40 American cities and in international cities including London and Rome.
RAYMOND C BLACKBURN, 45, THE ONLY AFRICAN AMERICAN MAN ON THE OHIO SENATE IS KILLED WHEN CAR OVERTURNS ON THE MEDIAL STRIP OF THE SOUTH FREEWAY I-71 SOUTH OF FRANK ROAD.
North Vietnamese Army troops attack the U.S. Special Forces camp at Plei Me in a prelude to the Battle of Ia Drang Valley in South Vietnam's Central Highlands.
OHIO HISTORICAL SOCIETY TRUSTEES APPROVE OF GOVERNOR RHODES' RECOMMENDATION THAT THE OHIO HISTORICAL CENTER BE BUILT ON STATE FAIRGROUNDS; TEMPLE OF GOOD WILL OFFER WITHDRAWN.
Brutus Buckeye makes his first appearance. The costume was one large head, almost completely covering the person inside, and legs, and was made out of 40 pounds of fiberglass.
25,000 march in Washington in support of U.S. involvement in Vietnam. The marchers are led by five Medal of Honor recipients.
WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BOARD AGREES TO BUY CONDEMNED PROPERTY, AT 799 HARTFORD ST, ADJOINING JAMES KILBOURNE JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL.
OHIO HISTORICAL SOCIETY COMMITTEE PREFERS NEW SITE ON STATE FAIRGROUNDS BETWEEN I-71 AND THE NEW HIGHWAY PATROL ACADEMY.
OHIO HIGHWAY DEPT REPORTS THAT THE FIRST SECTION OF COLUMBUS' EAST FREEWAY (I-70), BETWEEN PARSONS AND OHIO AVES, IS COMPLETED, BUT WILL NOT BE PUT INTO USE UNTIL 7/66.

The Battle of Ia Drang Valley marks the first major battle between U.S. troops and North Vietnamese Army regulars (NVA) inside South Vietnam. American Army troops of the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile) respond to the NVA threat by using helicopters to fly directly into the battle zone. Upon landing, the troops quickly disembark then engage in fierce fire fights, supported by heavy artillery and B-52 air strikes, marking the first use of B-52s to assist combat troops. The two-day battle ends with NVA retreating into the jungle. 79 Americans are killed and 121 wounded. NVA losses are estimated at 2000.
WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BOARD APPROVES PLANS FOR 4-CLASSROOM ADDITION OF COLONIAL HILLS ELEMENTARY SCHOOL.

The American success at Ia Drang is marred by a deadly ambush against 400 soldiers of the U.S. 7th Cavalry sent on foot to occupy nearby Landing Zone 'Albany.' NVA troops that had been held in reserve during Ia Drang, along with troops that had retreated, kill 155 Americans and wound 124.
FRANKLIN CO ENGINEER ANNOUNCES PLANS FOR 2 NEW BRIDGES ON WILLIAMS RD OVER ALUM AND BIG WALNUT CREEKS, TO COINCIDE WITH CONSTRUCTION OF THE OUTERBELT HIGHWAY.
France launches its first satellite. Astérix weighs 92 pounds. The launcher was the Diamant A.
In Washington, 35,000 anti-war protesters circle the White House then march on to the Washington Monument for a rally.
After visiting Vietnam, Defense Secretary McNamara privately warns that American casualty rates of up to 1000 dead per month could be expected.
THE ARCHITECTURAL FIRM OF IRELAND AND ASSOCIATES IS CHOSEN TO DESIGN THE NEW OHIO HISTORICAL CENTER ON THE STATE FAIRGROUNDS NORTH OF 17TH AVE.
The Beatles release "Rubber Soul"
Gemini 7 launched: Frank Borman, James Lovell, 220 orbits.
In Saigon, Viet Cong terrorists bomb a hotel used by U.S. military personnel, killing eight and wounding 137.

Defense Secretary McNamara tells President Johnson that the North Vietnamese apparently "believe that the war will be a long one, that time is their ally, and that their staying power is superior to ours.
The New York Times reveals the U.S. is unable to stop the flow of North Vietnamese soldiers and supplies into the South despite extensive bombing.
THE COLUMBUS & SOUTHERN OHIO ELECTRIC CO, CINCINNATI GAS AND ELECTRIC CO, AND DAYTON POWER AND LIGHT CO PLAN TO BUILD A JOINTLYOWNED PLANT NEAR ABERDEEN ON THE OHIO RIVER
MAYOR SENSENBRENNER ORDERS ALL MARKET STALLS AT CENTRAL MARKET CLOSED BY THE END OF THE MONTH; ATTORNEYS FOR THE CENTRAL MARKET ASSN ARE EXPECTED TO FILE SUIT TO STOP THE CLOSING.
Gemini 6 launched: Walter Schirra, Thomas Stafford, 16 orbits, rendezvous with Gemini 7.
DANA B BOLIN, 49, OF ATHENS, OHIO, IS KILLED AND ABOUT 30 PEOPLE ARE INJURED IN THE CRASH OF NEW YORK CENTRAL'S OHIO STATE LIMITED PASSENGER TRAIN IN WORTHINGTON.
President Johnson and top aides meet to decide the future course of action.
"Thunderball" featuring Sean Connery as James Bond released in the United States.

The second pause in the bombing of North Vietnam occurs. This will last for 37 days while the U.S. attempts to pressure North Vietnam into a negotiated peace. However, the North Vietnamese denounce the bombing halt as a "trick" and continue Viet Cong terrorist activities in the South. By year's end U.S. troop levels in Vietnam reached 184,300. An estimated 90,000 South Vietnamese soldiers deserted in 1965, while an estimated 35,000 soldiers from North Vietnam infiltrated the South via the Ho Chi Minh trail. Up to 50 percent of the countryside in South Vietnam is now under some degree of Viet Cong control.
NASA Crawler Transporter: Marion reinstalled the support roller shafts.
Sawyers Tower East at 521 North Sawyer Blvd. Opens. 15 story housing project for seniors.
The Canterbury residential tower in Grandview at 3440 Olentangy River Road opens.
The Norwood Amusement Park is demolished.
The Ohio Arts Council holds its first meeting.
OSU: Evans Lab, 88 W. 18th Ave., addition.
First Ohioans inducted into the armed services during the Vietnam war.
First modern housing development built in Pickerington.
Port Columbus Airport achieves "International" status with the installation an official customs inspector and USDA approved incinerator
Worthington Board of Education acquires the Old Rectory, which had been moved to Hartford Street, for use as administrative offices.
Medicare goes into effect.
All US cigarette packs have to carry "Caution Cigarette smoking may be hazardous to your health.
COLUMBUS' INDECISION ON OLENTANGY FREEWAY PROJECT  PUTS SERIOUS CRIMP IN STATE'S EFFORT TO EXPEDITE WORK ON THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY.
"Batman" premiers.

During his State of the Union address before Congress, President Johnson comments that the war in Vietnam is unlike America's previous wars, "Yet, finally, war is always the same. It is young men dying in the fullness of their promise. It is trying to kill a man that you do not even know well enough to hate...therefore, to know war is to know that there is still madness in this world."
The Dow Jones Industrial Average trades briefly above 1,000 for the first time.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The crawler successfully transported a mobile launcher approximately one mile to the Vehicle Assembly Building.

Operation Masher marks the beginning of large-scale U.S. search-and-destroy operations against Viet Cong and NVA troop encampments. However, President Johnson orders the name changed to the less aggressive sounding 'White Wing' over concern for U.S. public opinion. During the 42 day operation in South Vietnam's Bon Son Plain near the coast, troopers of the U.S. 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile) once again fly by helicopters directly into battle zones and engage in heavy fighting. 228 Americans are killed and 788 wounded. NVA losses are put at 1342. The term 'search-and-destroy' is used by the media to describe everything from large scale Airmobile troop movements to small patrols rooting out Viet Cong in tiny hamlets. The term eventually becomes associated with negative images of Americans burning villages.

Citing Hanoi's failure to respond to his peace overtures during the 37 day bombing pause, President Johnson announces bombing of North Vietnam will resume. Senator Robert F. Kennedy criticizes President Johnson's decision to resume the bombing, stating that the U.S. may be headed "on a road from which there is no turning back, a road that leads to catastrophe for all mankind." His comments infuriate the President.
THE 10TH MCDONALD'S IN COLUMBUS, LOCATED AT 1972 N HIGH ST, IN THE OSU DISTRICT, OFFERS NOT ONLY DRIVE-IN DINING BUT SEATING INSIDE FOR 140 PERSONS.
TRUSTEES OF THE OHIO HISTORICAL SOCIETY TO DISCUSS NEGOTIATIONS FOR BUYING A 58-ACRE SITE ON THE STATE FAIRGROUNDS FOR A NEW $10 MIL OHIO HISTORICAL CENTER.

Influential newspaper columnist Walter Lippmann lambastes President Johnson's strategy in Vietnam, stating, "Gestures, propaganda, public relations and bombing and more bombing will not work." Lippmann predicts Vietnam will divide America as combat causalities mount.
"Winnie the Pooh and the Honey Tree" by Walt Disney released.
President Johnson and South Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Cao Ky meet in Honolulu.
CONSTRUCTION OF THE FIRST SEGMENT OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY IS EXPECTED TO START THIS SUMMER, POSSIBLY IN JULY OF 1966.
AS-201 launched, a Saturn 1B test flight, suborbital.
OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HIGHWAYS TO START CONSTRUCTION PLANS IMMEDIATELY TO WIDEN THE NORTH FREEWAY FROM EAST NORTH BROADWAY TO THE OUTERBELT.
HARVEY WALKER, WORTHINGTON PLANNING CONSULTANT, FILES SUIT IN HIS CONTINUING ATTEMPT TO BLOCK COLS ANNEXATION OF A TRACT OF LAND WHICH INCLUDES THE SITE OF ANHEUSER-BUSCH.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, chaired by Sen. J. William Fulbright, holds televised hearings examining America's policy in Vietnam. Appearing before the committee, Defense Secretary McNamara states that U.S. objectives in Vietnam are "not to destroy or overthrow the Communist government of North Vietnam. They are limited to the destruction of the insurrection and aggression directed by North Vietnamese against the political institutions of South Vietnam."
CITY COUNCIL PLACES THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY ALIGNMENT ARGUMENT ON THE 5/3 BALLOT.
An attempt to repeal the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution fails in the U.S. Senate by a vote of 92 to 5. The attempt was led by Sen. Wayne Morse.
The U.S. reveals that 20,000 acres of food crops have been destroyed in suspected Viet Cong villages. The admission generates harsh criticism from the American academic community.

South Vietnamese Buddhists begin a violent campaign to oust Prime Minister Ky following his dismissal of a top Buddhist general. This marks the beginning of a period of extreme unrest in several cities in South Vietnam including Saigon, Da Nang and Hue as political squabbling spills out into the streets and interferes with U.S. military operations.
Gemini 8 launched: Neil Armstrong, David Scott. 6.5 orbits.
The last Studebaker automobile rolled off the Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, assembly line. Production in the USA ceased on December 20, 1963.
The last "Ozzie and Harriet Show" is broadcast.
Anti-war protests are held in New York, Washington, Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston and San Francisco.
NASA Crawler Transporter: Both crawlers are operational.

Timothy Leary spoke at New York's Town Hall and compared LSD to a microscope saying that the drug is to psychology what the microscope is to biology, making not just a few to wonder, "What's he smokin?"
The first game ever played on Astroturf is played at the Houston Astrodome. Houston played the Los Angeles Dodgers.

B-52 bombers are used for the first time against North Vietnam. Each B-52 carries up to 100 bombs, dropped from an altitude of about six miles. Target selections are closely supervised by the White House. There are six main target categories; power facilities, war support facilities, transportation lines, military complexes, fuel storage, and air defense installations.
Viet Cong attack Tan Son Nhut airport in Saigon causing 140 casualties while destroying 12 U.S. helicopters and nine aircraft.
OPPONENTS OF THE PROPOSED ALIGNMENT OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY CHARGE THAT THE RIVER ROUTE WILL PROVE DANGEROUS FOR MOTORISTS BECAUSE OF FOG.
CONTRACTOR FOR THE EAST FREEWAY ASSURES STATE HIGHWAY OFFICIALS HE WILL MAKE EVERY EFFORT TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT TO ALUM CREEK DR BEFORE THIS YEAR'S OHIO STATE FAIR.
CITY OFFICIALS PREPARE TO PUSH FOR A MID-JUNE OPENING FOR THE EAST FREEWAY TO THE KELTON-MILLER AVES INTERCHANGE.
Don Coffey is born.
The first car, an Impala, rolls off the assembly line at the GM Lordstown Plant near Youngstown.
A WORTHINGTON CITIZENS COMMITTEE HEADED BY FRANK P WELLING, 117 W NEW ENGLAND ST, SEEKS IN A LAST MINUTE ATTEMPT TO BLOCK THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY'S PATH THROUGH WORTHINGTON.
Secretary of Defense McNamara privately reports the North Vietnamese are infiltrating 4500 men per month into the South.
OLENTANGY FREEWAY ISSUE PASSES BY UNOFFICIAL 418 VOTE MARGIN; CITY AND COUNTY OFFICIALS LOOK AT POSSIBILITY THAT NEWLY ANNEXED AREAS OF COLS WERE ILLEGALLY PREVENTED FROM VOTING.
A STRIKE BY OHIO STEEL ERECTORS LOCAL 172, IN ITS 5TH DAY, THREATENS DELAY OF EAST FREEWAY OPENING AS WORK STOPS ON SIX ESSENTIAL FREEWAY BRIDGES.

High speed rail - The U.S. Department of Transportation worked with the Pennsylvania Railroad, Budd Company, General Electric and Westinghouse to develop an electric multiple unit high speed passenger train. An initial order of 50 Budd Metroliner cars was placed with a target service date of October 1967. Service was to operate at 110 mph.
OHIO BOARD OF EDUCATION AGAIN REFUSES TO GIVE COLUMBUS A ROUTE THROUGH STATE SCHOOLS FOR THE DEAF AND BLIND PROPERTY FOR THE MORSE RD EXTENSION TO THE PROPOSED OLENTANGY FREEWAY.

Political unrest intensifies as South Vietnamese troops loyal to Prime Minister Ky over-run renegade South Vietnamese Buddhist troops in Da Nang. Ky's troops then move on to Hue to oust renegades there. Ky's actions result in a new series of immolations by Buddhist monks and nuns as an act of protest against his Saigon regime and its American backers. Buddhist leader Tri Quang blames President Johnson personally for the situation. Johnson responds by labeling the immolations as "tragic and unnecessary."
WORTHINGTON OPPOSITION TO OLENTANGY FREEWAY GROWS WITH OVER 700 SIGNATURES ON INITIATIVE PETITION FOR DEVELOPMENT OF PARKS ALONG THE OLENTANGY RIVER WITHOUT RIVER REALIGNMENT.
JAMES D PINNEY, OF 43 W GRANVILLE RD, WORTHINGTON, RETIRED FARMER AND REAL ESTATE MAN AND DESCENDANT OF WORTHINGTON PIONEER, ABNER PINNEY, DIES AT AGE 90.
WORTHINGTON PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH DISCOVERS IT IS HOLDING 150TH ANNIVERSARY 11 YRS LATE; OLD RECORDS SHOW IT WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1805, MAKING IT OLDEST PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH IN FR CO.
The cultural revolution begins in China when a condemnation of Beijing University intellectuals is read over the radio at the behest of Chairman Mao Zedung.
Gemini 9 launched: Thomas Stafford, Eugene Cernan. 47 orbits.
A three-page anti-war advertisement appears in the New York Times signed by 6400 teachers and professors.
CONTROVERSY SURROUNDING THE DEMISE OF 115-YEAR-OLD CENTRAL MARKET ENDS AS THE COLS LANDMARK IS RAZED TO MAKE WAY FOR AN OFFICE BLDG AS PART OF MARKET-MOHAWK URBAN RENEWAL.
Political unrest in South Vietnam abates following the crackdown on Buddhist rebels by Prime Minister Ky, including the arrest of Buddhist leader Tri Quang. Ky now appeals for calm.
WORTHINGTON CITY COUNCIL TAKES 1ST STEP IN PARK AND RECREATION DEVELOPMENT PLAN ALONG EAST SIDE OF OLENTANGY RIVER WITH ORDINANCE APPROVING PURCHASE OF 38 ACRES FOR $35,000.
NO ONE IS SERIOUSLY INJURED IN A 10-VEHICLE CRASH ON I-71 UNDER THE CLEVELAND AVE BRIDGE, IN WHICH A GASOLINE TANKER BURNS WITH SUCH INTENSE HEAT THAT THE BRIDGE GIRDERS BUCKLE.

Citing increased infiltration of Communist guerrillas from North Vietnam into the South, the U.S. bombs oil depots around Hanoi and Haiphong, ending a self-imposed moratorium. The U.S. is very cautious about targeting the city of Hanoi itself over concerns for the reactions of North Vietnam's military allies, China and the Soviet Union. This concern also prevents any U.S. ground invasion of North Vietnam, despite such recommendations by a few military planners in Washington.

Widespread use of the term Black Power started during a protest march through Mississippi begun by James Meredith, who had been the first black to attend the University of Mississippi. Meredith was wounded by a sniper during the march and had to be hospitalized. Leaders of several civil rights organizations, including Carmichael and Martin Luther King, Jr., took up the march. Along the route, Carmichael and SNCC activists exhorted marchers by demanding, "What do you want?" and then leading the response, "Black Power!"
AS-203 launched, a Saturn 1B test flight, suborbital, test hydrogen systems.
Hanoi Radio reports that captured American pilots have been paraded though the streets of Hanoi through jeering crowds.
The U.S. intensifies bombing raids against portions of the Ho Chi Minh trail winding through Laos.

Chicago West Side riots. Over 30 people injured during the riots, including six firemen and six policemen who had been shot. A pregnant 14-year-old and 28-year-old man were killed by stray bullets from shootouts between police and snipers.[5] More than 200 people were arrested on July 14 alone.
Operation Hastings is launched by U.S. Marines and South Vietnamese troops against 10,000 NVA in Quang Tri Province. This is the largest combined military operation to date in the war.
Gemini 10 launched: John Young, Michael Collins. 43 orbits.
Hough riots in Cleveland. During the riots, four African Americans were killed and 50 people were injured. There were 275 arrests and numerous incidents of arson and firebombings.
THE THOMAS MIDGELY ESTATE, N OF WORTHINGTON, IS SEALED; THE ESTATE WAS RAZED TO MAKE WAY FOR THE OUTERBELT.
PORT COLUMBUS OFFICIAL ASKS GAHANNA VILLAGE COUNCIL FOR PERMISSION TO MOVE THE PLANNED OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY SLIGHTLY NORTH OF ITS PROPOSED ALIGNMENT THROUGH THE SUBURB.
GAHANNA MAYOR BERNARD N MURRAY SAYS THE CITY OF COLUMBUS HAS "MOTIVES OTHER THAN THOSE THAT APPEAR ON THE SURFACE" FOR WANTING TO ALTER THE PATH OF THE PROPOSED OUTERBELT.
For the first time, the U.S. bombs NVA troops in the Demilitarized Zone, the buffer area separating North and South Vietnam.
WORTHINGTON LAW DIRECTOR RICHARD BRENTLINGER RULES AN INITIATIVE PETITION TO BLOCK THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY THROUGH WORTHINGTON "INSUFFICIENT"
GAHANNA VILLAGE COUNCIL VOTES 6-1 AGAINST PORT COLUMBUS' REQUEST TO MOVE THE PLANNED OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY SLIGHTLY NORTH OF ITS PROPOSED ALIGNMENT THROUGH THE SUBURB.
THE WORTHINGTON BOARD OF EDUCATION ANNOUNCES THAT THE PROPOSED $900,000 WORTHINGTON ESTATE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL WILL BE BUILT USING THE SAME BASIC PLANS USED FOR BROOKSIDE SCHOOL.

Comedian Lenny Bruce was found dead at the age of 40 in the bathroom of his Hollywood Hills home. A syringe and burned bottle cap were found nearby, along with various other narcotics paraphernalia. His official cause of death was acute morphine poisoning caused by an accidental overdose.
The Beatles release "Revolver"
THE U S BUREAU OF PUBLIC ROADS REFUSES TO PROVIDE FUNDS TO EXTEND LINWORTH RD NORTH ACROSS THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY TO HARD RD.
U.S. jets attack two South Vietnamese villages by mistake, killing 63 civilians and wounding over 100.
EIGHTEEN CARS OF A PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD FREIGHT TRAIN DERAIL NEAR RT 42, AT THE UNION MADISON COUNTY BORDER NEAR PLAIN CITY.
MATERIAL SHORTAGE KEEPS A SECTION OF THE EAST FREEWAY FROM OPENING IN TIME FOR THE STATE FAIR.
OPPONENTS OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY ALIGNMENT IN COLUMBUS FILE A BRIEF IN COMMON PLEAS COURT TO ORDER A NEW ELECTION.
Groundbreaking for Anheuser-Busch Brewery on Shrock Rd.
AS-202 launched, A Saturn 1B test flight, suborbital, test Apollo heat shield.
EXTENSIVE WATER PUMPING FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE BIG WALNUT CREEK TRUNK SEWER, EASTLAND SHOPPING CENTER & THE EAST FREEWAY CAUSES WATER SHORTAGES IN SE COLUMBUS AREAS.
THE NEWLY OPENED SECTION OF THE EAST FREEWAY (I-70) IS A TRAFFIC NIGHTMARE; CITY TRAFFIC EXPERTS FORESEE NO SOLUTION UNTIL THE SUPER ROAD IS EXTENDED EAST TO JAMES RD.
Hanoi announces China will provide economic and technical assistance.

Race riots rock Dayton after the murder of African American Lester Mitchell by an unknown white assailant. There were numerous injuries and more than 500 arrests.  Trains were re-routed and police estimated property damage to be about $250,000.
During a visit to neighboring Cambodia, French President Charles de Gaulle calls for U.S. withdrawal from Vietnam.
The Miami Dolphins play their first regular season game, losing to the Oakland Raiders 23-14.
Star Trek: The Man Trap - Series and Season One Premier
The Atlanta Falcons play their first regular season game, losing to the L.A. Rams 19-14.
Gemini 11 launched: Charles Conrad, Richard Gordon. 44 orbits.
"Family Affair " premiers.
The heaviest air raid of the war to date occurs as 500 U.S. jets attack NVA supply lines and coastal targets.

Operation Attleboro occurs involving 20,000 U.S. and South Vietnamese soldiers in a successful search-and-destroy mission 50 miles north of Saigon near the Cambodian border. During the fighting, an enormous weapons cache is uncovered in a hidden base camp in the jungle. 155 Americans are killed and 494 wounded. North Vietnamese losses are 1106.
Star Trek: Charlie X
THE COLUMBUS METROPOLITAN PARK BOARD FILES A REQUEST WITH THE OHIO DEPT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO DEVELOP AND OPERATE A RECREATION AREA AT BIG DARBY CREEK DAM.
"Mission: Impossible" premiers.
Star Trek: Where No Man Has Gone Before
The U.S. reveals jungles near the Demilitarized Zone are being defoliated by sprayed chemicals.
Star Trek: The Naked Time
The U.S. 1st Air Cavalry Division conducts Operation Irving to clear NVA from mountainous areas near Qui Nhon.
The Soviet Union announces it will provide military and economic assistance to North Vietnam.
COLLEGE PARK RESIDENTS IN GAHANNA OPPOSE COLS' PROPOSAL TO MOVE I-270 FURTHER NORTH OF PORT COLUMBUS.
Star Trek: The Enemy Within

The Columbus Checkers, the city's first-ever-professional hockey team and a member of the now defunct International Hockey League, plays the Chicago Blackhawks at the Ohio Expo Fairgrounds Coliseum for an exhibition game.
Star Trek: Mudd's Women
A DISPUTE BETWEEN DUBLIN AND THE STATE OVER OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY CONSTRUCTION NEAR DUBLIN HIGH SCHOOL IS REMEDIED BY THE ERECTION OF SCHOOL SAFETY SIGNS BY OHIO DEPT OF HIGHWAYS.
Star Trek: What Are Little Girls Made Of?

President Johnson conducts a conference in Manila with America's Vietnam Allies; Australia, Philippines, Thailand, New Zealand, South Korea and South Vietnam. The Allies pledge to withdraw from Vietnam within six months if North Vietnam will withdraw completely from the South.
President Johnson visits U.S. troops at Cam Ranh Bay. This is the first of two visits to Vietnam made during his presidency.
Star Trek: Miri
The Ohio College Association approved the Ohio College Library Center as recommended by the Committee of Librarians, the Committee of Presidents and the OCA Executive Committee
Israel conducts a non-nuclear implosion test at Al-Naqab in the Negev to test its nuclear detonation system.
Star Trek: Dagger of the Mind
"The Velvet Underground" plays the Valleydale Ballroom in Columbus, Ohio
Defense Secretary McNamara is confronted by student protesters during a visit to Harvard University.
GAHANNA OFFICIALS REFUSE TO CONSIDER PROPOSAL TO MOVE OUTERBELT FARTHER NORTH OF PORT COLUMBUS UNLESS ACCESS TO THE AREA IS PROVIDED BY A BRIDGE OVER GOSHEN LANE.
Midterm elections. George H.W. Bush won his first election ever, as a U.S. Representative for Texas,[39] and Baltimore County Executive Spiro Agnew as Governor of Maryland.

John Lennon of The Beatles first met Yoko Ono, a 33-year old Japanese conceptual artist, at the Indica Gallery in London, where her work was being featured in an exhibit sponsored by art dealer Robert "Groovy Bob" Fraser.
Star Trek: The Corbomite Maneuver
Buckeye Lake Park is hit by high winds, which send its elderly wooden roller coaster plunging into the water.
George Coe Campbell born at Riverside Hospital
Gemini 12 launched: James Lovell, Buzz Aldrin. 63 orbits.
A U.S. Air Force 551st Airborne Early Warning and Control Wing EC-121H Warning Star crashed in the Atlantic Ocean off Nantucket, Massachusetts, killing the entire 19-man crew.

Five men who were digging a grave at a cemetery near Clendenin, West Virginia, claimed to see a man-like figure fly low from the trees over their heads. This is often identified as the first known sighting of what became known as the Mothman.
UNION CEMETERY CO FILES SUIT AGAINST CITY OF COLUMBUS, OHIO HIGHWAY DIRECTOR, AND PLANNING CONTRACTOR TO PREVENT THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY FROM PASSING THROUGH ITS LAND.
The New York Times reports that 40 percent of U.S. economic aid sent to Saigon is stolen or winds up on the black market.

Israel launched a major raid against the Jordanian administered West Bank town of as-Samu, in response to a Fatah-implemented roadside bomb attack which had killed three members of the Israeli security forces near the southern Green Line border. In the resulting skirmish, scores of Jordanian security forces were killed and 125 homes razed. This raid was one of several factors that led to the 1967 Six-Day War.

A U.S. Air Force C-141 Starlifter, part of the 86th Military Airlift Squadron and piloted by Captain Howard Geddes became the first jet aircraft to land in Antarctica, touching down on a runway carved out of the ice, at Williams Field on McMurdo Sound. The jet had completed a roundtrip flight of the 2,200-mile (3,543-km) each way to and from Christchurch, New Zealand.
HORTH AND MOSSER CONSTRUCTION CO, OF SOLON, SUBMITS LOW BID FOR 5.5 MI SECTION OF COLS OUTERBELT (I-270), FROM S HIGH ST TO A POINT SOUTH OF INTERSECTION OF HAMILTON AND REFUGEE.

Gemini 12, with James A. Lovell and Buzz Aldrin), splashed down safely in the Atlantic Ocean, 600 km east of the Bahamas, less than three miles from the aircraft carrier USS Wasp, bringing an end to the Gemini program to make way for the Apollo manned program set to land on the Moon.

The second, and most famous "Mothman" sighting took place when a pair of married couples in Point Pleasant, West Virginia reported seeing "a flying man with a 10-foot wingspan who flies after cars at 100 miles per hour"
A Cleveland jury finds Dr. Sam Sheppard not guilty of killing his wife, Marilyn, in 1954. (Sheppard served 10 years in prison before the verdict was overturned.)
WORTHINGTON PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH, IN COOPERATION WITH NATIONAL CHURCH RESIDENCES, PLANS TO BUILD A RETIREMENT CENTER AT THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF STAFFORD AVE AND HARTFORD ST.
Star Trek: The Menagerie Part 1

Roman Catholics in the United States are no longer be required to abstain from meat on Fridays, as a national conference of Roman Catholic cardinals, archbishops and bishops voted in Washington to revoke a requirement of abstinence that had been in effect for 11 centuries.

Baseball pitching legend Sandy Koufax surprised the sporting world when he confirmed a report by San Diego Union reporter Phil Collier that he was retiring from the sport at the height of his career, because of severe arthritis in his elbow.
The Buckeye Lake Hotel suffered $75,000 of damage in a fire.

Project HARP, the High Altitude Research Project and a collaboration of the U.S. and Canadian armed forces, achieved its highest success when it used a large cannon ("the HARP gun") to fire a projectile into outer space. The "shell" was the Martlet 3 rocket, and the cannon, designed by Gerald Bull, sent it to an altitude of 178.6 kilometers (111 miles). As a military historian would note in 2011, "It was, and remains, a world record for any fired projectile."
Cabaret, one of the most popular musicals on Broadway, opened at the Broadhurst Theatre.

The first international computer chess competition between the United States and the Soviet Union began between the Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics at Moscow, and Stanford University in Palo Alto, California. The Soviet Minsk M-20 computer had a program developed by a team led by Georgy Adelson-Velsky and Vladimir Arlazarov; the Kotok-McCarthy program, created by Alan Kotok and John McCarthy, used an IBM 7090 computer.[119] Four games were played simultaneously between the two computers, and the moves were communicated by telegram. Eventually, with two wins and two draws, ITEP defeated Stanford, 3-1.
All 30 passengers and crew aboard a Douglas DC-3 were killed when the aircraft crashed at Aden, Yemen. An in-flight bomb detonation was determined to have caused the crash.
Star Trek: The Menagerie Part 2
The Beatles began recording their classic Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band album, starting with "Strawberry Fields Forever".

Comedian George Carlin records his first solo comedy album, "Take Offs and Put Ons" at The Roostertail, Detroit (RCA Victor LSP-3772). Released 1967, receives Grammy nomination. Includes "Indian Sergeant," "Wonderful WINO," "Daytime Television."
The highest total score NFL game ever, 113 points. The Redskins defeat the Giants 72-41.
Reclusive billionaire Howard Hughes moved from Boston to Las Vegas, where he leased the top two floors of the Desert Inn.

The Soyuz program began in the Soviet Union with the unmanned launch of a new series of space vehicles. In order to disguise the mission's true purpose, the launch was initially referred to as Kosmos 133. Eventually, the first capsule would be automatically destroyed in orbit after experiencing problems with its orientation system.
Daniel J. Morrell sinks in Lake Huron killing 28 crew members.
GAHANNA CITY COUNCIL CONSENTS TO MOVING OF THE OUTERBELT FARTHER NORTH OF PORT COLUMBUS; CONDITIONS OF THE GAHANNA RESOLUTION ARE DETAILED.
WORTHINGTON RESIDENTS PETITION TO BLOCK THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE CITY AND TO HAVE THE OLENTANGY SHORES SET ASIDE AS A NATURAL AREA.
RAYMOND C SHAFFER OF FREDERICKTOWN AND HIS FAMILY FLEE FROM THEIR CAR SECONDS BEFORE IT IS STRUCK BY A TRAIN AT THE RT 161 CROSSING OF THE CHESAPEAKE & OHIO RAILWAY IN LINWORTH.
North Vietnam rejects a proposal by President Johnson for discussions concerning treatment of POWs and a possible exchange.
Star Trek: The Conscience of the King
REVISED PLANS FOR THE WIDENING OF RT 161 FROM THE NORTH FREEWAY TO CLEVELAND AVE ARE APPROVED BY FEDERAL, STATE, AND COLUMBUS OFFICIALS.
The village of Caudat near Hanoi is leveled by U.S. bombers resulting in harsh criticism from the international community.
Walt Disney dies in Los Angeles.
GENERAL ELECTRIC CO TAKES TITLE TO THE VACANT TRW, INC, PLANT ALONG HUNTLEY RD IN NORTHEASTERN WORTHINGTON; THE PURCHASE PRICE IS NOT REVEALED.
Star Trek: Balance of Terror

AEP:  American Electric Power, announces it was soliciting bids for “a major nuclear power plant in southwestern Michigan on the shore of Lake Michigan.” Estimated price tag: $130 million.  It will be named the Donald C. Cook Nuclear Plant. The actual cost was $3,300 million, and it produced 2.2 GW of power. It is located 11 miles south of St. Joseph, Michigan.
FRANKLIN CO COMMISSIONERS REVEAL THEY ARE CONSIDERING THE PURCHASE OF A LARGE TRACT SURROUNDED BY I-71, JACKSON PIKE, AND THE OUTERBELT FOR A LANDFILL DUMP OPERATION.
BIDS TOTALING MORE THAN $808,000 ARE AWARDED BY THE WORTHINGTON SCHOOL BOARD FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE WORTHINGTON ESTATES ELEMENTARY SCHOOL AND ADDITIONS TO BROOKSIDE ELEMENTARY.
THE OWNERS OF 90 ACRES BORDERED BY I-71, I-270, AND RT 104 OFFER TO SELL IT TO FRANKLIN COUNTY FOR $325,000 FOR USE AS A SANITARY LANDFILL .
The Martin Marietta X-23A PRIME makes its first flight.
FEDERAL HIGHWAY FUND CUTS DELAY CONSTRUCTION OF THREE SECTIONS OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY (I-270) FOR AT LEAST SIX MONTHS.
WORTHINGTON CITY PLANNERS CHOOSE A 35-BLOCK CENTRAL SECTION OF THE CITY TO BE PRESERVED AS A CENTRAL OHIO SHOWCASE OF NEW ENGLAND ARCHITECTURE.
Facing increased scrutiny from journalists over mounting civilian causalities in North Vietnam, the U.S. Defense Department now admits civilians may have been bombed accidentally.

The U.S. mounts a large-scale air assault against suspected Viet Cong positions in the Mekong Delta using Napalm and hundreds of tons of bombs. By year's end, U.S. troop levels reach 389,000 with 5008 combat deaths and 30,093 wounded. Over half of the American causalities are caused by snipers and small-arms fire during Viet Cong ambushes, along with handmade booby traps and mines planted everywhere in the countryside by Viet Cong. American Allies fighting in Vietnam include 45,000 soldiers from South Korea and 7000 Australians. An estimated 89,000 soldiers from North Vietnam infiltrated the South via the Ho Chi Minh trail in 1966.
REPLICA OF AN 1890 RAILROAD STATION AT THE OHIO RAILWAY MUSEUM, 930 PROPRIETORS RD IN WORTHINGTON OPENS.
Star Trek: Shore Leave
MARGO FRESHWATER, 18, OF WORTHINGTON, AND GLENN NASH, 38, A MEMPHIS, TN, LAWYER, ARE HELD IN MISSISSIPPI IN CONNECTION WITH THE MURDER OF CAB DRIVER CARLIE SURRATT.
Ross Laboratories introduces a soy-protein isolate formula, Isomil, to meet infant feeding needs. Pedialyte begins distribution in the U.S. as the first ready-to-feed oral electrolyte solution.
OSU: Archer House dormitory, 2130 Neil Ave., opens.
OSU: Oxley Hall, 1712 Neil Ave., converted to office space. Now occupied by the Departments of Linguistics, International Studies, and International Student Affairs.
Martin Luther King Jr. visits Cleveland and addresses several groups during a two-day stay.
St. Mary of the Springs Catholic School closes.
The Ohio State University baseball team wins the NCAA championship
Construction of the northern portion of I-270, the Columbus Outerbelt, defines Worthington's northern boundary and limits geographical growth.
Interstate 71 completed through Columbus.
Worthington Estates Elementary School opens.
Worthingway Middle School opens.
Medicaid goes into effect.

Operation Bolo was as a success as the United States Air Force shot down five (and perhaps as many as seven) North Vietnamese MiG-21 jets in the largest air battle fought in the Vietnam War up to that time.
Ronald Reagan becomes governer of California.
Chessapeake & Ohio gains control of the Chicago, South Shore & South Bend.
"Light My Fire" by the Doors is released.

Jack Ruby, 55, the Dallas nightclub proprietor who killed accused presidential assassin Lee Harvey Oswald on live television on November 24, 1963, died in Dallas of a pulmonary embolism after being diagnosed with terminal lung cancer.
Star Trek: The Galileo Seven
James A. Rhodes begins his second term as Governor of Ohio

President Johnson delivered the annual State of the Union address to Congress, and told the gathered legislators "I recommend to the Congress a surcharge of 6 percent on both corporate and individual income taxes--to last for 2 years or for so long as the unusual expenditures associated with our efforts in Vietnam continue."
The second run of "Dragnet" premiers.
Star Trek: The Squire of Gothos

Organized by counterculture publisher Allen Cohen and artist Michael Bowen, the Human Be-In took place at the Polo Grounds in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park, with 20,000 hippies gathering in the Haight-Ashbury district to see performances by the Grateful Dead, poet Allen Ginsberg, comedian Dick Gregory, activist Jerry Rubin, and psychologist and LSD advocate Timothy Leary, who urged the audience to "turn on, tune in, and drop out".[89] Media coverage of the event introduced the American public to the hippie movement and set the stage for what would be described as "The Summer of Love"

The Rolling Stones appeared on The Ed Sullivan Show for the second time, but only after acceding to a demand by Sullivan to alter the words of their hit song, "Let's Spend the Night Together". After Sullivan reportedly said, "Either the song goes or the Stones go," Mick Jagger sang the refrain as "Let's spend some time together.
$3 MIL VOLKSWAGEN CO ADMINISTRATIONWAREHOUSE COMPLEX IN DUBLIN NEAR THE OUTERBELT (I-270) AND RT 33 IS UNDER CONSTRUCTION.

Albert DeSalvo, the "Boston Strangler", was convicted of numerous crimes other than the 13 homicides of which he had been accused, and was sentenced to life in prison. F. Lee Bailey argues that his client is insane.
Star Trek: Arena
Star Trek: Tomorrow Is Yesterday
A fire on the launch pad kills Apollo I astronauts Gus Grissom, Ed White & Roger Chaffee.
The British rock group Pink Floyd got its first professional recording contract when it was signed by EMI.

At a press conference in New York, California lawyer Gary Davidson announced the formation of the 10-team American Basketball Association, set to be a competitor to the 10-team National Basketball Association. Former NBA star George Mikan was introduced as the first ABA Commissioner. The ten franchises identified were Indianapolis, Minneapolis, New Orleans, New York and Pittsburgh in an eastern division, and Anaheim, Dallas, Houston, Kansas City, and Oakland in a western division.
Star Trek: Court Martial
"The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour" premiers.
Star Trek: The Return of the Archons

The Beatles released the songs "Penny Lane" and "Strawberry Fields Forever" on the same 45 rpm record as a "double A-sided" single in the United States, with a release in the UK four days later.[64] Both were about locations in Liverpool.[65] Sales where the record was displayed as "Penny Lane" would make it be #1 in the U.S. for the week ending March 18, while its flip side would peak at #8.
Star Trek: Space Seed

New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison announced at a press conference that he believed that the assassination of John F. Kennedy had been a conspiracy, and that his office had been working on the seeking an indictment over "the possible role of some individuals in New Orleans", adding that "arrests will be made."
J. Robert Oppenheimer, 62, American atomic physicist, died of throat cancer.
APPROXIMATELY 30 PRIVATE TRASH HAULING FIRMS TO HIKE FEES 25 PERCENT MARCH 1 WHEN COUNTY'S NEW DUMP OPENS AT RT 104 NEAR THE OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY.
Star Trek: A Taste of Armageddon
Born - Jonathan Ive, British software designer for Apple Corporation, for products including the iPhone, the iPod, the iPad, and the Apple Watch; in Chingford.
OSU: Hitchcock Hall, 2070 Neil Ave., opens. Houses the College of Engineering.
Star Trek: This Side of Paradise

U.S. President Lyndon Johnson announced that Soviet Union Prime Minister Alexei Kosygin had agreed to discussions between the two nations to limit the number of offensive and defensive nuclear missiles that each side would possess.
100,000th Bridgeport Miller came off the assembly line
UNION CEMETERY ASS0CIATION OBTAINS PERMANENT INJUNCTION BARRING THE CITY OF COLUMBUS AND OHIO DEPT OF HIGHWAYS FROM RUNNING THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY THROUGH CEMETERY PROPERTY.

Jimmy Hoffa, President of the International Teamsters Union, began an 8-year federal prison sentence at the United States Penitentiary near Lewisburg, Pennsylvania, three years after his conviction for attempting to bribe a jury.
Star Trek: The Devil in the Dark

The Velvet Underground's groundbreaking first album, The Velvet Underground & Nico, was released. Initially a commercial failure, it would receive widespread critical and commercial acclaim in later years.
THE METROPOLITAN PARK BOARD OBTAINS AN OPTION TO BUY STONEY CREEK GOLF COURSE SOUTH OF REYNOLDSBURG FOR $475,000.

Nine executives and scientists of the West German pharmaceutical company Chemie Gruenenthal were indicted on criminal charges in Aachen for breaking German drug laws because of thalidomide. Company President Hermann Wirtz was the most prominent defendant, and the nine faced a maximum sentence of five years in prison. Chief Prosecutor Heinrich Gierlich told reporters that 5,000 babies had been born crippled between 1957 and 1962 as a result of thalidomide poisoning.
WESTERVILLE CITY COUNCIL PLEDGES THAT IT WILL NOT INTERFERE WITH THE BUILDING OF A COLUMBUS SANITARY SEWER TRUNK LINE TO SERVICE THE ANHEUSER-BUSCH BREWERY NEAR WORTHINGTON.
THE ADENA INDIAN MOUND, EAST OF OLENTANGY RIVER AND BETHEL RDS AND WEST OF THE RIVER, IS IN DOUBLE JEOPARDY FROM THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY AND THE MORSE RD EXTENSION.
The supertanker Torrey Canyon ran aground, releasing 32 million gallons of oil, much of which washed up on the Cornish coast.

The first demonstration of "slow motion instant replay" on television was shown to viewers of ABC Wide World of Sports who had tuned in to see the finals of the "World Series of Skiing" at Vail, Colorado.

Charles Manson was released from the Terminal Island prison in California after being incarcerated since 1960 and ordered to complete a 1957 prison sentence. Telling the authorities that "prison had become his home", that he had nowhere to go, and that he "didn't think he could adjust to the world outside", Manson asked to stay, but was released on schedule at 8:15 in the morning. Upon his release, he relocated to San Francisco, settled in the Haight-Ashbury neighborhood, and spent 1967's "Summer of Love" forming the group of followers known as "The Manson Family".
Star Trek: Errand of Mercy

NASA halted further training for three scheduled U.S. manned space missions and disbanded their three-member crews, pending an overhaul of the Apollo program in light of the January 27 fire that killed the astronauts of Apollo 1. Wally Schirra, Donn F. Eisele and Walter Cunningham had been the backup crew for Apollo 1 and would have been part of a rescheduled mission. James McDivitt, David Scott and Rusty Schweickart had been set for a summer launch of Apollo 2, and Frank Borman, Michael Collins and William Anders would have been on Apollo 3 in the autumn.[109] Schirra, Eisele and Cunningham would go up together on Apollo 7 in 1968; McDivitt, Scott and Schweickart would test the lunar module on Apollo 9 in 1969; Borman and Anders would orbit the Moon (with Jim Lovell) on Apollo 8 in 1968; and Collins would remain in lunar orbit on the Apollo 11 mission in 1969 with Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin.

A 32-man patrol of the Bolivian Army was ambushed by rebel guerrillas commanded by Che Guevara of Cuba. The attack took place near the guerrilla base at Ñancahuazú in southeastern Bolivia, and in addition to killing seven soldiers and taking two officers and nine soldiers prisoner, Guevara's men also captured an arsenal of 16 Mauser rifles, three 60-mm mortars, a 30 caliber machine gun, two submachine guns and two Uzi machine pistols, 2,500 rounds of ammunition, 64 mortar shells, and the Bolivian Army's operations plan.

The board of directors of the 45-year old Douglas Aircraft Company voted to accept a $68.7 million offer from McDonnell Aircraft Corporation to purchase its stock, after the Douglas company had run deeply into debt during the research and development of its DC-10 jetliner.
A Cubana flight from Havana to Mexico City crashed shortly before landing. All 10 people (6 passengers, 4 crew) aboard the Antonov An-12 were killed in the impact that was blamed on a bomb blast.

Flying an X-15 experimental aircraft, U.S. Air Force Major William "Pete" Knight made the fastest flight of a powered aircraft, at a speed of Mach 6.72 (4,520 miles (7,270 km) per hour. The mark remains unsurpassed

BEA CY284 was a de Havilland Comet 4 that departed Athens, Greece, bound for Cyprus. While flying at 29,000 ft (8,840 m), a bomb detonated. All 66 people (59 passengers, 7 crew) aboard were killed. It is believed the bomb was placed by terrorists hoping to kill the general in command of the Cyprus army who was to be aboard but cancelled shortly before departure.

Students at the University of Wisconsin–Madison demonstrate over the efforts of Dow Chemical to use the university campus for recruiting new employees; 76 people are injured in the ensuing riot.
Roger Patterson and Robert Gimlin filmed an unidentified animal near Bluff Creek, California, which has been claimed to be "Bigfoot" or "Sasquatch".

An American Airlines Boeing 727 departed Chicago when a small explosion occurred one hour and 42 minutes after takeoff. The blast was caused by a crude homemade bomb located in the aft baggage hold. None of the 78 passengers and crew were injured and the plane was able to land safely.

Neil Armstrong was forced to eject from Lunar Landing Research Vehicle #1's from about 200 feet (60 m) altitude after a control problem, and had about four seconds on his full parachute before landing on the ground unhurt.

Presidential Candidate George Wallace is shot by twenty-one-year-old Arthur Bremer in Laurel, Maryland, paralyzing him below the waist. Bremer's diary, published after his arrest as "An Assassin's Diary," showed that Bremer's assassination attempt was not motivated by politics, but by a desire to become famous.

George W. Bush admitted to the Texas National Guard on the same day he applied. This despite a waiting list of over a year and a half and over 100,000 long waiting list across the nation. Bush was able to avoid going to Viet Nam, where the death rate had climbed to 350+ per day.

"The Mother of All Demos" was presented by Douglas Engelbart at the Association for Computing Machinery / Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (ACM/IEEE)—Computer Society's Fall Joint Computer Conference in San Francisco.  The 90-minute presentation essentially demonstrated almost all the fundamental elements of modern personal computing: windows, hypertext, graphics, efficient navigation and command input, video conferencing, the computer mouse, word processing, dynamic file linking, revision control, and a collaborative real-time editor (collaborative work).

Buckeye Lake Park was sold to Diversified Amusement Industries for $1,000,000 to improve it and convert it to a Country & Western theme. However, Diversified failed to raise enough capital through stock offerings, and had a bad weather year in 1969, so Buckeye Lake Park was closed permanently in 1970.

Columbus City Council passed an ordinance funding a road that would run from Indianola in the east, through the State School for the Blind property, cross High Street at Bill Moose Run, then continue along the north edge of Graceland Shopping Center before angling over to meet Bethel.  Concerned citizens gathered enough signatures to put this ordinance on the ballot and the ordinance was overturned by the voters.  This successful referendum means the City cannot ever build such a road except by a vote of the citizens.

Clevelands's Cuyahoga River catches fire. Although the fire is put out after only 30 minutes and only does about $50,000 worth of damage to some railroad bridges, Time Magazine runs an article that makes Cleveland the butt of jokes and prompts national outrage that eventually leads to the 1972 Clean Water Act.
Chief Justice Earl Warren retires from the United States Supreme Court.
Warren E. Berger takes office as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.
CEREMONIES AT 10 A M ON JULY 2 WILL OFFICIALLY OPEN THE INITIAL SECTION BETWEEN THE GOODALE EXPRESSWAY AND KINNEAR ROAD OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY.
McDonalds introduces a new mansard roof for indoor seating.

Second launch attempt of the Soviet N1 rocket. A turbo pump burst on #8 engine, causing a cascade of problems. The N1 cleared the launch tower then toppled over and fell back onto the launch pad.

The thunderstorm of July 4-5 is the most intense and widespread summer thunderstorm recorded in Ohio. About 14 inches of rain fell in less than 24 hours at several locations, and about 4 inches fell throughout an area of 6000 mi2 in north-central Ohio. The storm was accompanied by extensive lightning and wind gusts of as much as 100 mph. The storm moved into Ohio from Lake Erie on the evening of July 4th, while thousands of people were gathered along the shore to observe fireworks. Of the several hundred small boats on the lake, many were capsized and 3 people drowned. Forty one people died from the storm: 25 drowned, 8 were killed by falling trees, 6 were electrocuted by fallen wires, 1 was killed by lightning, and 1 died of other storm-related injuries. Total damage was estimated at $66 million.
Apollo 11 launched: Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, Michael Collins. First manned lunar landing.
Wapakoneta, Ohio, native Neil Armstrong becomes the first man to walk on the moon.

GOV JAMES RHODES SAYS NO ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES WILL BE SERVED AT THE OHIO STATE FAIR AS LONG AS HE IS GOVERNOR.
A PENN CENTRAL RAILROAD SPOKESMAN CONFIRMS THE BEELINER PASSENGER TRAIN, WHICH FORMERLY RAN BETWEEN CLEVELAND AND CINCINNATI, NOW STOPS IN COLUMBUS.

7 CARS OF A PENN CENTRAL RR FREIGHT TRAIN DERAIL UNDERNEATH THE MAPLE ST VIADUCT BETWEEN FRONT AND HIGH STS.
FORMER OHIO WILDLIFE DIVISION OFFICIAL FLOYD CHAPMAN LEADS VOLUNTEER EFFORT TO CLEAN UP RUSH CREEK IN THE WORTHINGTON AREA.

The SS United States, no longer profitable due to competition from jets, is layed up in New York.

POLICE SAY TRAFFIC ON THE NORTH FREEWAY SOUTH OF E 5TH AVE IS CONGESTED BECAUSE SIGNS OFFER SOUTHBOUND MOTORISTS FIVE DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS IN WHICH TO TRAVEL, CONFUSING DRIVERS.
West Columbus Yard and the yard office at 1094 McKinley Ave. was closed. Operations were relocated to the new Buckeye Yard NW of the intersection of I-70 and I-270 on the West Side.
"On Her Majesty's Secret Service" featuring George Lazenby as James Bond released in the United States.

During final approach at Nha Trang, Vietnam, a bomb exploded aboard a Douglas DC-6B blasting a 5 ft (1.5 m) hole in the fuselage near the port cabin washroom. The plane's hydraulic system failed so the landing gear had to be lowered manually and the flaps would not deploy. As the stricken plane touched down, it overran the end of the runway striking several houses and a school. The impact killed 10 of the 77 people aboard as well as 24 victims on the ground.

The world's first quartz watch is released - The Astron wristwatch, formally known as the Seiko Quartz-Astron 35SQ, was the world's first "quartz clock" wristwatch, i.e., one based on a quartz crystal oscillator. Within one week 100 gold watches had been sold, at a retail price of 450,000 yen (US$1,250) each (at the time, equivalent to the price of a medium-sized car).
First Columbus Bob Evans restaurant opens.
Work is begun on the Zimmer Nuclear Power Plant at Moscow, Ohio
Nazareth Towers at 300 E. Rich St. opens. 14 story residence for seniors.
The Deshler Hotel at 9 N. High St. is demolished.

The Ohio Theater is in such disrepair that it is slated for demolition. The citizens of central Ohio mounted a "Save the Ohio" campaign, an unprecedented effort that raises more than $2,000,000 in less than twelve months from hundreds of supporters.
Texas Instruments Silentwriter 700 invented.
OSU: Bevis Hall, 1050 Carmack Road, opens.

Swissair SR330 left Zrich, Switzerland, for Tel Aviv, Israel, carrying 47 people (38 passengers, 9 crew). The Convair CV-990 suffered an explosion about nine minutes after takeoff due to a bomb triggered by change in atmospheric pressure that had been placed in the aft cargo hold. As the crew attempted to turn the plane back towards the airport for an emergency landing, smoke clouded the cockpit and electrical power was lost. The aircraft crashed shortly thereafter with no survivors. The militant group Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine claimed responsibility for the bombing.

On the same day as the Swissair bombing, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine detonated a second bomb aboard an Austrian Airlines Caravelle airliner traveling from Frankfurt, Germany, to Vienna, Austria. The bomb, located inside a mailbag due to be carried to Israel on a later flight, exploded about 20 minutes after takeoff. Though a 6 ft_ (0.6 m_) hole was torn in the bottom of the fuselage, the aircraft landed safely at Frankfurt and none of the 38 people (33 passengers, 5 crew) aboard were injured.
RANCO PLANS $5 MILLION MANUFACTURING COMPLEX ALONG WORTHINGTON-GALENA RD JUST NORTH OF COLUMBUS OUTERBELT
Great Northern, Northern Pacific and Chicago, Burlington & Quincy merge creating Burlington Northern; also leased Spokane, Portland & Seattle.
Kelly Marie Foley born at Mt. Carmel Hospital, Columbus, Ohio
The Martin Marietta X-24A makes its first powered flight.
Kansas, Oklahoma & Gulf absorbed into Texas & Pacific (Missouri Pacific).
Apollo 13 launched: James Lovell, Fred Haise, Jack Swigert. Mission fails when oxygen tank explodes in the service module. Lunar landing aborted but crew recovered.
Hawker Siddeley HS-748 crashed near Manila, Philippines, after a bomb exploded in the aft cargo hold. The crash killed all 36 passengers and crew.
China launches its first satellite. Dongfanghong I weighed 384 lbs. The launcher was the Long March 1, which weighed 179,830 lbs.
The IHL Columbus Checkers hockey team suspends operations due to low attendance.
High speed rail - Amtrak increases daily Metroliner service to 8 round trips daily.
Ohio National Guard troops kill 4 students at Kent State University.
Protests in the wake of the Kent State Shootings close The Ohio State University.
PUBLIC FINDS THE OLD SAYING "YOU CAN'T GET THERE FROM HERE" IS TRUE WITH OPENING OF NEW SECTIONS OF COLS OUTERBELT AND THE WEST FREEWAY.
WORTHINGTON, COLS AND MID-OHIO REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION OFFICIALS SEEK ACCORD ON PROPOSED OLENTANGY PARKWAY; BIKEWAYS AND TRAILS FROM DOWNTOWN COLS TO NORTH OF 161.
IBM announces the System/370 computer.
DEC releases the PDP-11/20. It is the first of the 16 bit PDP-11 minicomputer series.
A MULTI-MILLION DOLLAR EXPANSION PROGRAM AT WORTHINGTON FOODS, INC, 900 PROPRIETORS RD, INCLUDES A 75,000 SQ FT ADDITION AND LARGE PURCHASES OF NEW EQUIPMENT.
CHILDREN PLAYING WITH MAIN TRACK SWITCH MAY HAVE CAUSED DERAILMENT OF NORFOLK AND WESTERN RAILWAY FREIGHT TRAIN NEAR OAKLAND PARK AVE.
Yes releases "Time and a Word"
OUTERBELT EXPRESSWAY (I-270)-W BROAD ST INTERCHANGE OPENING POSSIBLE BY MID AUGUST; OPENING EXPECTS TO REDUCE TRAFFIC BURDEN ON W BROAD ST (RT 40).
8.5 MILE STRETCH OF OUTERBELT, I-270, BETWEEN I-70 WEST AND SOUTH FREEWAY, WILL OPEN 8/17.

Evel Knievel attempts to jump over cars at the Pocono International Raceway but crashes on landing. Evel suffered a cracked vertebrae, a broken right hand and a re-broken shoulder. He jumped again a few weeks later in New Jersey.
HILLIARD CITIZENS SEEK UNDERPASS ON HILLIARD CEMETERY RD TO RELIEVE THE TRAFFIC CONGESTION THAT DEVELOPS IN THE AREA BECAUSE OF TRAIN TRAFFIC.
COLS CITY COUNCIL COMES OUT OF SUMMER RECESS AND APPROPRIATES $1,589,292 AS THE CITY'S SHARE OF CONSTRUCTION OF THE WEST FREEWAY BETWEEN GRANDVIEW AVE AND THE OUTERBELT.
Construction of Alum Creek Dam begins.
NASA cancels the Apollo 18 & Apollo 19 missions due to budget cuts in the 1971 budget.
"The Flip Wilson Show" premiers with guest star David Frost.
"The Mary Tyler Moore Show" premiers.
The first regular season Monday Night Football game was aired on ABC. The Cleveland Browns defeated the New York Jets 31-21 as 85,703 fans pack Cleveland's Municipal Stadium.
2 MORE SECTIONS OF OUTERBELT I-270 WILL OPEN WITHIN THE NEXT 2 MONTHS, SAYS OH DEPT OF HIGHWAYS CHIEF RICHARD JACKSON; WILL LINK RT 3 AND RT 161, RT 33 AND E FREEWAY.
B G DINAS CO ENTERS APPARENT LOW BID FOR WEST FREEWAY CONSTRUCTION FROM I-270 TO EAST OF GRANDVIEW AVE; $17,825,671 BID IS MOST EXPENSIVE SINGLE HIGHWAY PROJECT IN OHIO HISTORY.
FINAL PLANS WERE FILED WITH THE STATE HIGHWAY DEPARTMENT FOR THE $12 MILLION OLENTANGY FREEWAY SECTION BETWEEN HENDERSON ROAD AND THE OUTERBELT.
FINAL PLANS WERE FILED WITH THE STATE HIGHWAY DEPARTMENT FOR THE $12 MILLION OLENTANGY FREEWAY SECTION BETWEEN HENDERSON ROAD AND THE OUTERBELT.
The Columbus Jets, a Pittsburgh Pirates minor league team, play their last game.
World's first observation of a neutrino in a hydrogen bubble chamber at Argonne National Laboratory.

Most of the Marshall University football team, its coaches, 25 team boosters and the flight crew, a total of 75 people, are killed in a plane crash on approach to Huntington, WV airport. They were returning from a game in North Carolina.
Lockheed L1011 first flight.
A MISSING LINK IN THE COLS OUTERBELT OPENS TO TRAFFIC NOV 20, ALLOWING EAST-WEST TRAFFIC TO PASS COLS; THE 3.2 MILE LINK BETWEEN RT 33 AND I-70 BEATS A THANKSGIVING DEADLINE.
The Soviet LK lunar lander is tested in earth orbit for the first time.
THE ST CONTROLLING BD APPROVES A PACT UNDER WHICH OSU WILL RECEIVE $1.7 MIL IN COMPENSATION FOR LOSS OF 69.5 ACRES OF UNIVERSITY LAND IN PATH OF OLENTANGY FREEWAY.
The Soviet LK lunar lander is tested in earth orbit for the second time.
The Columbus Dispatch ceases publication for 11 days due to a strike.
A fire in Tucson, Arizona kills 29 people at the Pioneer International Hotel.
A fire on the pier at Buckeye Lake Park spread to Park Terrace and destroyed the Sky Room, Marine Lounge and Submarine Room.
Completion of South Building at Riverside Methodist Hospital, adding 350 beds. Six operating rooms added to surgery suite.
Construction begins on The Continental Center at 150 E. Gay St. 26 stories.

St. Mary of the Springs Mother House (16 stories) at 2320 Airport Drive opens. Has a chapel on the 1st floor, and another on the 10th overlooking Port Columbus International Airport. Built in the shape of a cross, with windows on the inside corners. Designed to house young women attending Ohio Dominican College.
The former St. Anthony's Hospital, 1450 Hawthorne, is demolished.
The Midland Building at 250 E. Broad St. opens. 21 stories.
The old White Cross Hospital building at 700 North Park Street is demolished.
University Hospitals East at 1450 Hawthorne Ave. opens. 18 stories.
OSU: Biological Sciences Building, 484 W. 12th Ave., opens as a research facility for the Department of Biological Sciences.
OSU: Hayes Hall, 108 N. Oval Mall, placed on the National Registry of Historic Places.
OSU: Meiling Hall, 370 W. 9th Ave., opens as the Medical Administration Building.
OSU: Orton Hall, 155 South Oval Mall, placed on the National Registry of Historic Places.
Columbus Union Station is down to 10 trains per day.
Interstate 270 completed 2 miles south of route 40 west of Columbus to route 40 west of Columbus and route 33 east of Columbus to route 23 south of Columbus.
Perry Middle School opens on Snouffer Road.
Presbyterians develop Stafford Village as Worthington's first retirement community for senior citizens.
Worthington's population peaks at 15,326.
Cigarette advertisements banned on TV.
John J. Gilligan inaugurated Governor of Ohio
"All In The Family" premiers.
General Idi Amin seizes power while President Milton Obote is away on a foreign visit - troops seal off Entebbe airport.
Apollo 14 launched: Alan Shepard, Stuart Roosa, Edgar Mitchell. Third manned lunar landing.
Alabama, Tennessee & Northern absorbed into the St. Louis & San Francisco.
Rolls Royce falls into receivership. They announce they cannot produce the RB-211 engine for the Lockheed L1011.
Decimal Day in the United Kingdom and Ireland. British decimalisation. Under the new system, the pound was retained but was divided into 100 new pence, denoted by the symbol p.
The Central Ohio Transit Authority is formed by local county and municipal governments.
Yes releases "The Yes Album"
Miss., La., Ark., Tenn.: series of 10 tornadoes resulted in 121 deaths.
The Soviet LK lunar lander is tested in earth orbit for the third time.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the founding father of Bangladesh gives a speech at the Ramna Race Course in Dhaka to a gathering of over two million people calling for Bangladeshi independance.

Veterans stadium in Philadelphia, PA was dedicated this day. It was the largest baseball park in the National League. A total of 56,371 fans could come out to see the Phillies play baseball or the Eagles play football. The stadium has been nicknamed the Vet.
Lt. John Kerry, spokesman for Viet Nam Veterans Against the War, testifies in front of Sen. Fullbright's foreign relations committee. He presents a litany of atrocities witnessed by veterens.
Amtrak takes over most inter-city passenger trains (holdouts - Southern, Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific, GA and Denver, Rio Grande & Western).
Mariner 8 is launched towards Mars on a Atlas-Centaur SLV-3C but the rocket tumbles due to a failed rate gyro and falls into the Atlantic Ocean.
Mars 2 is launched by the Soviet Union towards Mars on a Proton K with Blok D upper stage rocket.
Mars 3 is launched by the Soviet Union towards Mars on a Proton K with Blok D upper stage rocket.
Mariner 9 is launched towards Mars on a Atlas SLV-3C Centaur-D rocket.
Georgia & Florida, Savannah & Atlanta and Wrightsville & Tenille absorbed into Central of Georgia (the Southern).
The Martin Marietta X-24A makes its last flight.
WORTHINGTON STEEL CO COMPLETES PURCHASE AGREEMENT TO ACQUIRE THE MACHINERY NOW USED BY LENNOX INDUSTRIES INC FOR PRODUCTION OF STEEL AND ALUMINUM PRESSURE CYLINDERS.
FOUR MEN ARE IN CUSTODY AND ANOTHER IS BEING SOUGHT AFTER INDICTMENTS ON CHARGES OF THEFT OF $80,000 IN DIAMONDS FROM THE GENERAL ELECTRIC CO DIAMOND FACTORY IN WORTHINGTON.
THE OPENING OF E MAIN ST (RT 40) OVER THE OUTERBELT IS SCHEDULED FOR 6/21, AND WORK ON E MAIN ST-NOE-BIXBY RD INTERSECTION MAY ALSO BE COMPLETED BY THAT DATE.
