Comedian George Carlin records his second album "FM & AM  at Cellar Door, Washington, D.C. (Little David 7214). Released January, 1972. Album goes Gold and wins Grammy award. Includes "The Hair Poem," "Divorce Game," "Shoot (Shit with two O's)", and "Let's Make A Deal."
Third launch attempt of the Soviet N1 rocket. Instability around the base of the rocket started a roll that broke the vehicle apart at T+48 seconds.
Evel Knievel jumps over nine cars and a truck at Madison Square Garden. Evel performed four nights. Kelly and Robbie also made their appearances at their Dad's performance.
TRAFFIC SURVEY BEING RUN WILL DETERMINE IF NEXT OUTERBELT LINK--FROM RT 161 SOUTH TO MORSE RD--WILL OPEN IN TWO WEEKS OR BE CLOSED FOR AT LEAST ANOTHER MONTH.
Apollo 15 launched: David Scott, Alfred Worden, James Irwin. Fourth manned lunar landing. First use of lunar rover.
Chicago, Indianapolis & Louisville - (Monon) merged into the Louisville & Nashville.
The U.S. Senate approves a loan guarantee to the Lockheed Corporation which is required by the bankrupt Rolls Royce corporation to deliver the L1011's RB-211 engines.
The Soviet LK lunar lander is tested in earth orbit for the fourth and final time.
PLANS FOR A $10.8 MIL SHOPPING CENTER, CALLED WORTHINGTON SQUARE, AND AN OFFICE PARK, ON 30 ACRES NEAR WILSON BRIDGE RD AND HIGH ST, IS SET TO MOVE OUT OF PRELIMINARY STAGE.
An empty Boeing 707 was parked at Madrid, Spain, when a bomb in an aft lavatory exploded. The blast tore a 3 ft (1 m) long hole in the top of the fuselage but no one was harmed.
Ohio University's Alden Library enters the first catalog entry into Worldcat.
544 Kenbrook is sold to Gertie McClary.
President Nixon dedicates the new Air Force Museum at Wright Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, OH.
OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HIGHWAYS HAS CANCELLED CONSTRUCTION OF $11.3 MILLION SEGMENT OF OLENTANGY FREEWAY BECAUSE STATE CANNOT AFFORD TO PAY ITS SHARE OF COST.
THE OHIO HOUSE VOTES TO REPEAL A 69 YEAR OLD RAILROAD FULL CREW LAW, ALLOWING RAILROADS TO SET THE SIZE OF TRAIN CREWS AGAIN.
THE WORTHINGTON MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION APPROVES PLANS FOR A $10.8 MILLION SHOPPING CENTER AND OFFICE COMPLEX AT WORTHINGTON SQUARE.
STATE HIGHWAY OFFICIALS BELIEVE THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT BETWEEN THE EAST FREEWAY AND E MAIN ST COULD BE OPENED TO TRAFFIC BEFORE SNOW AND COLD SHUT DOWN THE CONSTRUCTION SEASON.
WORTHINGTON CITY COUNCIL ENACTS 1% INCOME TAX WITH MOST OF INCOME MARKED FOR CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS.
COMPLETION OF COLUMBUS OUTERBELT HINGES ON VOTER PASSAGE OF A $10.4 MIL EXPRESSWAY ISSUE INCLUDED IN THE $37 MIL BOND PACKAGE ON THE NOV 2 BALLOT.
ONE OF SIX CITY MONEY ISSUES ON COLUMBUS BALLOTS SEEKS APPROVAL FOR $10.35 MILLION IN BONDS TO FINANCE STREET AND HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION INCLUDING COMPLETION OF THE OUTERBELT.
The Electric Company premiers on PBS.
WORTHINGTON CITY OFFICIALS PUT AN END TO VEHICULAR TRAFFIC IN THE OLENTANGY RIVER PARKLAND ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE RIVER.
BID OPENINGS FOR ONE OF TWO SECTIONS OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT NOT UNDER CONSTRUCTION COULD BE DELAYED FURTHER BECAUSE OF INCOMPLETE PLANS.
Britain launches its first satellite. Prospero weighs 146 lbs. The launcher was the Black Arrow R3.
THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT (I-270) WAS OPENED TO TRAFFIC FROM THE EAST FREEWAY (I-70) NORTH TO E MAIN ST SEVERAL WEEKS AHEAD OF SCHEDULE.
A NEW SECTION OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT (I-270) WAS OPENED TO TRAFFIC FOUR DAYS BEFORE ELECTIONS, WITH CONSIDERABLE PERIMETER WORK TO BE FINISHED.
The Grateful Dead play to a sold-out audience at The Ohio Theater.
A CHANGE IN NAME FROM THE WORTHINGTON STEEL CO TO WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES, INC, APPROVED BY THE COMPANY'S SHAREHOLDERS.
"The Electric Company" premiers on PBS.
The S.S. Badger was laid up due to coal strike.
Ralph Perk becomes Mayor of Cleveland.
Hunter S. Thompson publishes "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas: A Savage Journey to the Heart of the American Dream"
High speed rail - Amtrak increases daily Metroliner service to 12 round trips daily.
Intel releases the 4004 to market, the world's first microprocessor.
A SUIT TO ACQUIRE UNION CEMETERY LAND FOR THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY STILL IS NOT RESOLVED, ALTHOUGH IT HAS BEEN 2 YEARS SINCE A SPECIAL OHIO LAW TO ALLOW TAKING THE LAND TOOK EFFECT.
Mariner 9 enters orbit around Mars, the first spacecraft to do so.

A Caravelle III airliner operated by the Taiwan carrier China Airlines was on a flight from Taipei to Hong Kong when the plane mysteriously vanished. The jet crashed into the sea off the coast of Penghu Island killing all 25 passengers and crew. Though never proven, a bomb is considered the most probable cause of the crash.
Yes releases "Fragile"

Mars 2 (Soviet Union) enters Martian orbit, the second spacecraft to do so. An attached lander becomes the first man made object to touch the surface of Mars. It crashes into the surface because the entry angle was too steep and the parachute failed to deploy.
BIDS ARE TO BE OPENED December 14 FOR ONE OF TWO SECTIONS OF THE COLUMBUS OUTERBELT (I-270) NOT UNDER CONTRACT; BID OPENING FOR THE LAST SECTION IS TENTATIVELY SET FOR JANUARY 18.
Mars 3 (Soviet Union) enters Martian orbit. An attached lander touches down successfully but loses contact 14.5 seconds after landing.
W L JOHNSON CONSTRUCTION CO AND ASSOCIATES, LOCKBOURNE, OFFERS LOW BID FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE OUTERBELT FROM SOUTH OF EAST BROAD TO NORTH OF EAST BROAD.
"Diamonds Are Forever" featuring Sean Connery as James Bond released in the United States.
THE COLUMBUS AND FRANKLIN COUNTY METROPOLITAN PARK DISTRICT HAS APPLIED FOR $729,000 IN FEDERAL FUNDS TO DEVELOP HIGHBANKS RESERVATION.
Worst hotel fire in history kills 163 at Taeyokale Hotel in Seoul.
Georgia, Ashburn, Sylvester & Camilla merged into Georgia Northern (the Southern).
Live Oak, Perry & Gulf merged into Live Oak, Perry & South Georgia (the Southern).
Lazarus opens at Kingsdale Shopping Center.
Columbus crime rate is nearly 30% above the national average.
Construction of The Rhodes State Office Tower at 30 E. Broad St. begins. 41 stories.
The Columbus Public Schools obtains 50 acres of the Fort Hayes Campus.
The Hartman building is demolished.
The Hartman Theatre attached to the Hartman Building at 73-87 E. State St. is torn down.
OSU: Cockins Hall, 1958 Neil Ave., remodeled from a laboratory to a general classroom space.
OSU: The Allied Medical Professions Building, 1583 Perry Street, opens.
The original University Hall at Ohio State is raised and replaced with a replica.
Ohio state income tax approved.
The IHL tries again with the Columbus Seals hockey team.
Central Ohio Transit Authority (COTA) formed when the privately owned Columbus Transit Company (CTC) threatened to end service. COTA does not take over operations until 1/1/1974.

Interstate 270 completed from route 71 south of Columbus to 2 miles south of route 40 west of Columbus, route 33 west of Columbus to route 23 north of Columbus, route 3 north of Columbus to route 161 east of Columbus, and route 70 east of Columbus to route 33 east of Columbus.
Interstate 70, route 29 to route 270 completed.
President Nixon decrees wage and price controls, closes international "gold window."
Officescape 270 opens with Toledo Scale as its anchor tenant.
Worthington enacts a 1% income tax.
Worthington Square Shopping Center construction begins.
RMS Queen Elizabeth catches fire in Hong Kong while being refurbished and capsizes

JAT 364 departed Stockholm, Sweden, for Belgrade, Yugoslavia carrying 23 passengers and 5 crew. While flying over Czechoslovakia, the Douglas DC-9 suffered an explosion in the forward cargo hold. The resulting explosive decompression ripped the plane apart. The blast was caused by a homemade bomb believed to have been planted by a Croatian extremist group called Ustasji.
McDonalds serves the first official corporate Egg McMuffin in Belleville, NJ.
More than 50% of Americans now own color televisions, so the networks drop their "in color" announcement before shows.
MEMBERS OF UNITED AUTO WORKERS LOCAL 30, REPRESENTING ABOUT 380 EMPLOYEES OF COLUMBUS AUTO PARTS AT HUDSON ST AND I-71, REMAIN ON STRIKE.
Evel Knievel successfully cleared 12 cars on his Harley at the Cow Palace in San Francisco, CA.
The union authorizes a string at the GM Lordstown Plant near Youngstown. Grievences are centered around the speed up of the assembly line and the poor design of the work flow.
Evel Knievel crashed while attempting to clear 12 cars at the Cow Palace in San Francisco, CA. Just prior to the jump, he got into a fight with a Hell's Angel who gave him the finger from the stands.

While parked at the airport in Las Vegas, Nevada, with no one aboard, a Boeing 707 operated by TWA was so badly damaged by a bomb blast that the aircraft had to be written off. The device had been placed in the right rear part of the cockpit. The plot was organized by an unknown person or group that had earlier threatened to blow up TWA aircraft unless paid $2 million.
"The Godfather" is released.
A COLUMBUS MAN, MAURICE KITSMILLER, 43, IS SENTENCED TO PRISON ON CHARGES INVOLVING THE THEFT OF INDUSTRIAL DIAMONDS FROM THE WORTHINGTON GENERAL ELECTRIC PLANT.
The strike at the GM Lordstown Plant near Youngstown is ended. GM agrees to stop speeding up the line.
Pacific Great Eastern renamed British Columbia Railway.
Actor Burt Reynolds appeared, um, nekkid as a jaybird in "Cosmopolitan" magazine. This issue of "Cosmo" became an instant collector's item and an additional 700,000 copies had to be printed.
PLANS ARE CERTIFIED FOR A NUCLEAR POWER GENERATING PLANT TO BE BUILT BY COLUMBUS AND SOUTHERN OHIO ELECTRIC CO; THE PLANT, THE WILLIAM ZIMMER STATION, TO BE IN CINCINNATI.
Michael Crichton publishes "The Terminal Man"
Apollo 16 launched: Charles Duke, Ken Mattingly, John Young. Fifth manned lunar landing.
Columbus Union Station is down to 2 trains per day, one in each direction between New York and Kansas City.

A LAN Chile flight from Panama City, Panama, to Miami suffered an explosion about one hour and 18 minutes after takeoff. The Boeing 727 was carrying 50 people (40 passengers, 10 crew). The blast was caused by a crude pipe bomb planted in the ice water fountain service compartment. Though the plane experienced a rapid decompression, no one was harmed and the pilots made an emergency landing at Montego Bay, Jamaica.
Skylab 1 launched: Pete Conrad, Joseph Kerwin, Paul Weitz. Repaired damaged Skylab workshop and stayed for 28 days.
Kings Island Amusement Park opens off of Interstate 71 north of Cincinnati. Two million people visited the 150-acre park in its first season.

Comedian George Carlin records his third album "Class Clown" at Santa Monica Civic Auditorium, California (Little David 1004). Released, September, 1972. Includes "How Much is That Dog Crap in the Window"," "I Used to Be Irish Catholic," and "Seven Words You Can Never Say on TV." Gold album.
The lodge opens at Salt Fork State Park.
Hurricane: northwest Fla. to N.Y.: Agnes caused 117 deaths (50 in Pa.). Damages estimated at over $2.1 ($8.6) billion. Still the worst natural disaster ever in Pa.

A total of 81 people (71 passengers, 10 crew) were killed when Cathay Pacific CX700Z crashed in Vietnam. The Convair CV-880 had departed Bangkok for Singapore and on to Hong Kong. During the second leg of the journey, an explosive device hidden in a suitcase under a seat on the right side of the cabin detonated. A Thai police officer was accused of planting the bomb to kill his daughter and her fiance, but he was acquitted due to lack of evidence.
NEWEST COLUMBUS BURGER KING OUTLET AT 3200 OLENTANGY RIVER RD IS TESTING IDEAS THAT MAY BE PART OF EVERY BURGER KING OPENED IN THE FUTURE.
Atari established in California. First arcade game is Pong.
GRACE BRETHREN CHURCH OF COLUMBUS, 6675 WORTHINGTON-GALENA RD, WINS ZONING VARIANCE TO BUILD A 200-PUPIL, TWO-STORY ELEMENTARY SCHOOL TO BE BUILT ACROSS FROM THE CHURCH.
OSU: McCampbell Hall, 1581 Dodd Drive, opens. Houses the Nisonger Center for Mental Retardation and Developmental Studies.
VISITORS TO COSI WILL SOON BE ABLE TO VISIT A COAL MINE, THANKS TO SPONSORSHIP BY JEFFREY MINING MACHINE CO; EXHIBIT WILL SHOW GROWTH OF THE INDUSTRY FROM BEGINNING TO PRESENT.
New York City: 891 people died in 14-day heat wave.
WOODEN GUARDRAIL POSTS REPLACING STEEL ONES ON SOUTH FREEWAY BUT VICE VERSA IS HAPPENING ALONG I-70 IN EASTERN OH; CONTRACTORS HAVE OPTION OF WHICH TYPE OF POST THEY WANT TO USE.

Comedian George Carlin is arrested at Summerfest in Milwaukee for using indecent language in front of wheelchair-bound children. Narrowly escapes a big cocaine bust by giving cocaine to the Siegal-Schwall Band while exiting stage. Band thrilled.
THE SECTION OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY THAT RUNS FROM SOUTH OF KINNEAR RD NORTH TO ACKERMAN RD WILL OPEN BY STATE FAIR TIME.
The contract is awarded for the construction of the Space Shuttles Columbia & Challenger.
1.9 MILE SECTION OF OLENTANGY FREEWAY COSTING $6.5 MIL OPENS FROM KINNEAR RD TO ACKERMAN RD.
Illinois Central and Gulf, Mobile & Ohio merge creating Illinois Central Gulf.
Yes releases "Close to the Edge"

A Boeing 707 of Israel's El Al had just taken off from Rome, Italy, bound for Tel Aviv when a bomb hidden in a portable record player exploded in the aft baggage compartment. The airline had adopted reinforced cargo containers that reduced the bomb's effectiveness. Though the 200 grams of explosive blew a hole through the baggage hold, the aircraft landed safely at Rome and none of the 148 people aboard were injured.
A MILLION-DOLLAR-AN-ACRE "CITY WITHIN A CITY" IS UNDER CONSTRUCTION ON 60 ACRES ON THE FAR NORTH SIDE, TO INCLUDE HOTELS, CONDOMINIUMS, APARTMENT, AND A FRENCH MARKET.
The Summer Olympics open in Munich, Germany.
CONSTRUCTION IS TO BEGIN 8/28 ON THE LAST SEGMENT OF I-270; SCHEDULED COMPLETION DATE IS 11/30/74.
AN 18-MILE-LONG BICYCLE AND HIKING TRAIL TO RUN FROM FRANK RD TO THE NORTHERN BORDER OF WORTHINGTON ALONG THE SCIOTO AND OLENTANGY RIVERS IS PLANNED TO BE DONE BY 1977.
NTSB rule for 5 mph bumpers on passenger cars goes into effect.
Harold Leroy Enarson appointed President of The Ohio State University
George W. Bush is suspended from flying in the National Guard due to failure to take his medical exam.
MR AND MRS DONALD KING OF 267 LOVEMAN AVE ARE SEEKING THE OWNER OF A SCHNAUZER THAT BIT THEIR SON JEFFREY IN A SMALL PARK ON PARK BLVD IN COLONIAL HILLS.
"Maude" premiers.
"The Waltons" premiers.
"The Bob Newhart Show" premiers.
"M*A*S*H" premiers.
Peter Gabriel dons costumes for the first time at a Genesis gig before 2000 fans at the National Stadium in Dublin, Ireland.
"Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids" premiers.
The Worthington Historical Society opens the Orange Johnson House to the public.
FIVE CARS OF A 54-CAR PENN CENTRAL FREIGHT TRAIN DERAILED WHEN ONE OF THE CARS LOST A WHEEL EAST OF THE HARPER RD CROSSING IN WESTERN FRANKLIN COUNTY; THERE WERE NO INJURIES.

Cleveland Mayor Ralph Perk became the subject of national ridicule when he accidentally set his hair on fire while he attempted to use a welder's torch for a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a convention in Cleveland
Amy Elizabeth Campbell born in Cleveland.
DERAILMENT OF 12 COAL CARS ON PENN CENTRAL TRAIN WEST OF OUTERBELT BRIDGE NEAR GRENER AVE AND BUCKEYE YARDS SPILLS 840 TONS OF COAL.
Seaboard Coast Line gains control of Louisville & Nashville.
Genesis play Supper's Ready for the first time on stage at Brunel University.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 1,000 for the first time.
DESPITE CITIZEN OPPOSITION AND A SPLIT VOTE AMONG CITY COUNCIL MEMBERS, THE CONTROVERSIAL MODERN-LOOKING LANDCO BUILDINGS RECEIVE PERMITS TO BUILD AT 6666 N HIGH IN WORTHINGTON.
THOMAS PHILIP DEE, 29, OF 1055 STRIMPLE AVE, A FORMER GENERAL ELECTRIC CO EMPLOYEE, PLEADS GUILTY TO STEALING INDUSTRIAL DIAMONDS MADE AT THE COMPANY'S WORTHINGTON PLANT.
WORTHINGTON CITY RECREATION DEPT IS FACING ADAMANT OPPOSITION TO A PROPOSED OLENTANGY RIVER PARK FROM LOCAL RESIDENTS, WHO WANT SOME CHANGES MADE IN THE PLANS.

Fourth and final launch attempt of the Soviet N1 rocket. The planned shutdown of the inner 6 engines at T+90 caused a shock wave in the fuel lines that burst them. The vehicle broke up at T+107 seconds.
Benjamin Franklin Tuberculosis Hospital closes.
Apollo 17 launched: Eugene Cernan, Ronald Evans, Harrison Schmitt. Sixth and last manned lunar landing.
An experimental scanner checkout system is tested in a Kroger supermarket.
Max & Erma's opens its first restaurant, at 739 S. 3rd St. in German Village.
The Maramor restaurant and night club, 137 E. Broad St., is leveled.
Equipment is installed at Bolton Field to permit Instrument Landings.
Columbus Metro Parks completes purchase of 1,048 acres for Highbanks Metro Park.
OSU: Lincoln Tower, 1800 Canon Drive, bottom 3 floors converted to office space and dining hall closed.

In Urbancrest, Ellen Walker Craig-Jones was the first woman African-American in the United States to be elected mayor. During her term, she oversaw many modernization projects, including streetlight and street sign installation, street rebuilding and a $3 million housing project.
Boston & Providence merged into the Penn Central.
Interstate 270 completed from route 161 east of Columbus to 2 miles south of route 161 east of Columbus and route 40 east of Columbus to route 70 east of Columbus.
President Nixon orders a halt to American bombing in North Vietnam - following peace talks in Paris.
President Richard Nixon appears on national television to announce "peace with honour" in Vietnam.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls below 1,000 and will not close above it for a sustained period until October, 1982.
FIRE CAUSES $25,000 DAMAGE TO THE HOME OF MR AND MRS JAMES MURRAY AT 511 LOVEMAN S.
Providence & Worchester resumes independent operation.
A TWO-MILE FREEWAY TO LINK THE PROPOSED OHIO CENTER WITH THE OLENTANGY EXPRESSWAY ON THE WEST AND THE NORTH FREEWAY ON THE EAST IS PROPOSED BY DOWNTOWN PLANNER VINCENT PONTE.
The Chessie System is formed from the merger of the C&O, B&O and Western Maryland railroads.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The crawler carried the first Saturn IB to the launch pad for the Skylab 2 mission.

Comedian George Carlin records his fourth album "Occupation: Foole" at Circle Star Theater, San Carlos, California (Little David 1005). Released October, 1973. Nominated for Grammy award. Includes "White Harlem," "New York Voices," and "Childhood Cliches." Gold album.
All 62 passengers and crew aboard a Douglas C-54D were killed when a bomb exploded in the plane's forward cargo hold. The aircraft crashed at Ben Me Thuot, South Vietnam.

Motorola manager Martin Cooper placed a cellular phone call (in front of reporters) to Dr. Joel S. Engel, head of research at AT&T's Bell Labs. This began the era of the handheld cellular mobile phone.
A Hawker Siddeley HS-748 carrying 33 people crashed near Patabangan, Philippines, after a bomb exploded aboard.

A tornado hit the Bash Recreation Center in Dublin causing between $100,000 and $150,000 damage. It touched down again at Galena (Delaware County) damaging a brick yard. It's final damage was at Sunbury, also in Delaware County. There were no injuries or fatalities.
CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT TO ALLOW A STATE LOTTERY IS APPROVED BY OHIO VOTERS.
Skylab launched: Orbital workshop placed in orbit, but damaged during launch.
Yes releases "YesSongs"

An Aeroflot flight from Moscow to Chita in Siberia was hijacked with 100 passengers and crew aboard. When the hijacker's demands were not met, he set off a bomb in the passenger cabin. The Tu-104A broke up at 30,000 ft (9,145 m) and crashed near Chita with no survivors.
The first Soyuz-U flight took place, carrying as its payload Kosmos 559, a Zenit military surveillance satellite.
AGREEMENT IS REACHED TO BUILD UNDERPASS ON HILLIARD-CEMETERY RD AT THE PENN CENTRAL CROSSING BETWEEN NORWICH ST AND LUXAIR AVE TO HELP REMOVE WORST TRAFFIC BOTTLENECK IN CITY.

A tornado strikes the North American Rockwell Corporation and The Defense Construction Supply Center in Columbus (Franklin County). Damage to both of these facilities was put at $3,300,000. One person was injured.
5 CARS OF 96-CAR FREIGHT TRAIN DERAIL IN PENN CENTRAL RAILROAD RECEIVING YARD ABOUT 0.5 MILES NORTH OF FISHER RD.
A HIGH-ACCIDENT RAMP CONNECTING THE OUTERBELT AND THE NORTH FREEWAY IS TO BE RESURFACED TO REDUCE SKIDDING AND WILL BE RECONDITIONED IN A SAFETY UPGRADING OF THE OUTERBELT.
Edward John Herrmann appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.
"Live and Let Die" featuring Roger Moore as James Bond released in the United States.
COTA acquires the assets of the Columbus Transit Company.
TRAIN PASSENGER SERVICE WILL BE GONE FROM COLUMBUS WITHIN A MONTH IF AMTRAK HAS ITS WAY--EFFECTIVE 8/2, IT INTENDS TO ELIMINATE THE NATIONAL LIMITED AND FLORIDIAN LINES.
THE ONLY REMAINING BUILDING OF THE DEFUNCT WORTHINGTON MANUFACTURING CO, WHICH DID BOOMING BUSINESS IN THE WAR OF 1812 ERA, IS PLACED ON NAT'L REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES.
Eddie Rickenbacker dies.
OHIO SENATE PASSES BY 30-1 MARGIN A BILL TO SET UP A STATE LOTTERY COMMISSION TO DESIGN AND OPERATE THE LOTTERY APPROVED BY OHIO VOTERS IN THE MAY ELECTION.
Skylab 2 launched: Alan Bean, Jack Lousma, Owen Garriott. Stayed for 59.5 days.
The Martin Marietta X-24B makes its first flight, an unpowered glide flight.
AMTRAK SPOKESPERSON SAYS CONGRESS AND U S DEPT OF TRANSPORTATION ARE TO BLAME FOR PROPOSAL TO STOP LAST PASSENGER TRAIN SERVING COLS.
The Olentangy River from Delaware Dam to the old Wilson Bridge Road is designated a scenic river by the State of Ohio.
Bonhomie & Hattiesburg Southern and Fernwood, Columbia & Gulf merge into the Illinois Central Gulf.
AMTRAK'S ANNOUNCEMENT THAT IT IS WITHDRAWING ITS REQUEST TO ELIMINATE THE NATIONAL LIMITED PASSENGER TRAIN WHICH SERVES COLUMBUS AND DAYTON HAS BEEN APPLAUDED BY PUCO.
NORTHERN FRANKLIN CO RESIDENTS AND REPRESENTATIVES OF ANHEUSER-BUSCH BREWERY, 700 SCHROCK RD, CLASH OVER ODORS PRODUCED BY THE PLANT'S GRAIN DRYING PROCESS.
George W. Bush is given an honorable discharge from the National Guard, despite not showing up for duty since early 1972.

Vice President Spiro T. Agnew resigns and pleads guilty to one count of tax evasion. He was sentenced to a fine of $10,000 and a period of unsupervised probation. He is the first Vice President since John C. Calhoun in 1832 to resign from office. Agnew took bribes for road contracts while a county commissioner in Maryland, and bribe payments continued while he was Governor of Maryland, and Vice President.
High speed rail - Amtrak increases daily Metroliner roundtrips to 15, the all time high for the service.

WBAI-FM radio in New York plays George Carlin's "Filthy Words" cut from "Occupation Foole" album. Lone professional moralist complains to FCC which issues a Declaratory Order against station. Station goes to court.
Evel Knievel successfully jumps over 50 stacked cars at L.A. Coliseum. It is his first appearance on ABC's Wide World of Sports.
The Martin Marietta X-24B makes its first powered flight.
Skylab 3 launched: Gerald Carr, Edward Gibson, William Pogue. Stayed for 84 days.
Representative Gerarld Ford of Michigan is confirmed by a votes in the Senate and the House to be the Vice President.
Yes releases "Tales from Topographic Oceans"
FACED WITH LOSING $370,000 IN STATE HIGHWAY FUNDS, THE WORTHINGTON CITY COUNCIL APPROVES THE LONG-DELAYED PROPRIETORS RD IMPROVEMENT PROJECT.

Pan Am 110 was a Boeing 707 preparing to leave Rome, Italy, for Beirut, Lebanon with 177 people aboard. Departure was delayed when a group of Palestinian gunmen stormed the terminal and across the tarmac towards the aircraft. The men threw two phosphorous bombs onto the plane killing 30 passengers. The attackers went on to take five hostages, kill a customs agent, and hijack a Lufthansa Boeing 737. The plane flew to Damascus and then Kuwait before one of the hostages was killed and the terrorists escaped. They were eventually arrested and convicted, and the attack was traced to Abu Nidal's Fatah group.
First Red Roof Inn opened by James Trueman.
Ross Laboratories introduces Ensure, the first lactose-free medical nutritional product in the U.S.
Wendy's Old Fashioned Hamburger's second location in Columbus offers the first successful drive-through window.
Mercy Hospital, 1430 South High Street, erects a new building.
The Continental Center at 150 E. Gay St. opens. 26 stories.

The Motorists Mutual Building at 471 E. Broad St. opens. 21 stories. Overlooks the Topiary Garden, a three-dimensional topiary model of the scene in George Seurat's painting "Sunday Afternoon on the Island of Grand Jatte". The garden was sponsored by Motorists Mutual, and is 2 blocks south of the building.
The Rhodes State Office Tower at 30 E. Broad St. opens. 41 stories.
Town Center at 140 E. Town St. opens. 17 stories.
Beck Forest Preserve established.
High Banks Metro Park opens.

OSU: Mershon Center, 1501 Neil Avenue, built, initially to house "The Academy for Contemporary Problems" funded by the Federal Government. In the early 80's the Academy's funding was not renewed and the building was purchased by the Cranston Group. When the Cranston Group became insolvent, the University bought the building back in 1989 and completely renovated it in 1993.
At Hueston Woods State Park, the old-growth forest becomes a state nature preserve.

Last U.S. troops withdrawn from Vietnam. Ohio had 2,993 servicemen killed during the war. Four Worthington men were killed; George Bonnell III, William H Condit Jr., Charles Jeffrey Freeland and William J Hrinko.
The IHL Columbus Seals hockey team are put up for sale.
Interstate 71 completed from Norwood to Kenwood.
Alternative Linworth School launched.
Hunter S. Thompson publishes "Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail '72"
Central Ohio Transit Authority (COTA) begins transit service to Central Ohio.
Norfolk Southern merged into Carolina & Northwestern (Southern).
"Happy Days" premiers.
The General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon makes its first flight at Edwards Air Force Base, California.
Fire breaks out in the Joelma Building in São Paulo, Brazil; 177 die, 293 are injured, 11 die later of their injuries.
THREE MEMBERS OF A WORTHINGTON FAMILY ARE FOUND SHOT TO DEATH AT THEIR MANSION HOME; DEAD ARE ROBERT CHASE, 44, HIS WIFE, JOAN, 42, AND THEIR SON, ROBERT WHITTIER AMES, 17.
Heiress Patty Hearst is kidnapped outside her Berkeley, California apartment by the Symbionese Liberation Army.
"Good Times" premiers.
After a record 84 days in orbit, the crew of Skylab 4 returns to Earth.

Sagitarius A* is discovered by astronomers Bruce Balick and Robert Brown using the baseline interferometer of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory. It is the black hole at the center of the Milky Way galaxy.
Evel Knievel successfully jumps over 11 Mack Trucks in North Richmond Hill, Texas. Shown on ABC's Wide World of Sports.
Turkish Airlines Flight 981 travelling from Paris to London crashes in a wood near Paris, killing all 346 aboard. This becomes the deadliest single aircraft accident with no survivors..
People magazine's first issue released in the U.S. with Mia Farrow on the cover.
The Brady Bunch is cancelled after five seasons on ABC.
End of five-month oil embargo by most OPEC nations against the United States, Europe and Japan which had caused the 1973 oil crisis.
A Caravelle III airliner on the ground at Bastia, France, was heavily damaged when an explosion occurred in the forward landing gear compartment. No one was injured.
The Terracotta Army of Qin Shi Huang is discovered at Xi'an, China.
"Little House on the Prairie" premiers.
A two day super outbreak of tornados begins across the midwest. In Xenia, 32 people are killed in a massive F5 tornado. Overall, 319 people die during the outbreak.
Hank Aaron ties Babe Ruth for the all-time home run record with his 714th at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati.
Stephen King publishes Carrie, his first novel.
Swedish pop group ABBA's song Waterloo wins the 1974 Eurovision Song Contest in Brighton, England, UK.
Hank Aaron became the all-time MLB home run leader with his 715th at Atlanta in front of a national television audience.
As "Tania", Patty Hearst is photographed wielding an M1 carbine while robbing the Sunset District branch of the Hibernia Bank in San Francisco.

Guillaume Affair: exposure of an East German spy Günter Guillaume within the West German government, leading to the resignation of West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. He is replaced with Helmut Schmidt.
Design of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System begins.

In what would later grow into the French TGV high speed rail, the Z 7001 experimental electric self-propelled unit, nicknamed "Zebulon", began tests to see how a high speed train could pick up current using a pantograph. The Z 7001 top speed was 309 km/h (192 mph).
India conducts its first nuclear weapons test.

Rush plays its first concert in the United States at the Northside Drive-In near Lansing, Mich. Billed as a 12 hour music festival featuring Dr. John, it is a rain soaked disaster. Dr. John doesn't even show, and of the expected crowd of 30,000 only about 1,300 show up.
The N1 rocket program is cancelled before a fifth test flight could take place, planned for August, 1974.
Muirfield Golf Course opens
Rockwell began construction on the first shuttle, Orbiter Vehicle (OV)-101, which would later be named Enterprise.

The Cleveland Indians stage an ill-advised Ten Cent Beer Night for a game against the Texas Rangers at Cleveland Municipal Stadium. Cleveland forfeits after alcohol-fueled mayhem and violence spreads from the stands onto the field.
GENERAL ELECTRIC CO RELOCATES ITS CHEMICAL AND METALLURGICAL DIVISION TO 500 W WILSON BRIDGE RD; OFFICE REPRESENTS OPERATIONS CENTER OF GE ENTERPRISES ON 3 CONTINENTS.
RAILROAD'S BRIDGE THAT DELAYED CONSTRUCTION OF THE FINAL SECTION OF THE OUTERBELT TAKES FORM BETWEEN E BROAD ST AND HAMILTON RD.

A bomb explodes in Westminster Hall, the oldest part of the British Houses of Parliament. The hall's annex, housing offices and a canteen, is destroyed by the bombing, attributed by police to the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.
Robert S. Duncan becomes the first black appointed to the federal court in Columbus.
Elvis plays St. John Arena on The Ohio State University campus.
The bar code, or UPC symbol is used for the first time. Printed on a pack of Wrigley's gum, it is first scanned at a Marsh Supermarket in Troy, Ohio.
Isabel Perón is sworn in as the first female President of Argentina, replacing her sick husband Juan Perón, who dies 2 days later.

Two weeks after the attraction's opening, an 18-year-old employee is crushed to her death while working on America Sings at Disneyland. This is the first casualty to occur to an employee at a Disney Park.

Comedian George Carlin records his fifth album "Toledo Window Box" at Paramount Theater, Oakland, California (Little David 3003). Released November, 1974. Includes "God," "A Few More Farts," and "Nursery Rhymes." Gold album.
4 FAST FOOD FRANCHISES HAVE BEEN GRANTED IN OSU'S OHIO UNION BEGINNING THIS FALL; MCDONALD'S, SHAKEY'S PIZZA, TIKI HUT AND SWEET SHACK WILL OCCUPY FIRST FLOOR OF UNION.
Philippe Petit crosses between Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York City high-wire walking.
Richard Nixon resigns and Gerald Rudolph Ford is inaugurated as President.
The Ohio State Lottery begins operation, with tickets costing $0.50 each.

Shortly after landing in Rome, a fire broke out in the aft baggage compartment of a TWA flight. The fire was caused by a bomb that had malfunctioned. No one was injured. The attempt may have been a precursor to the bombing of TWA 841 less than two weeks later.
Evel Knievel successfully jumps over 13 Mack Trucks at the Canadian National Exposition. Shown on ABC's Wide World of Sports.

TWA 841 was a Boeing 707 that left Tel Aviv, Israel, for New York City. The flight made a scheduled stopover in Athens, Greece, before heading on its second leg to Rome, Italy. Just 18 minutes after takeoff, the plane crashed into the Ionian Sea killing 88 people (79 passengers, 9 crew). Subsequent investigation concluded that the plane was brought down by a bomb hidden in the aft cargo hold that caused a structural failure. A group in Lebanon claimed responsibility for the bombing, and the Abu Nidal terrorist organization is believed to have been behind the attack.

Evel Knievel attempted to jump the Snake River Canyon in what he called his skycycle. He unfortunately didn't make it across the 1/4 mile canyon, but he survived one of his most dangerous stunts yet. Shown on ABC's Wide World of Sports.
The Worthington Historical Society obtains the deed to the Jeffers Indian Mound on Plesenton Drive from Herman P. Jeffers.
SEVEN SCHOOL BUSES ARE DESTROYED IN A FIRE AT A BUS GARAGE ABOUT 100 TO 200 YARDS FROM PERRY MIDDLE SCHOOL IN WORTHINGTON; THE LOSS IS AT LEAST $50,000.
CITY ENGINEER THEODORE WALLACE SAYS COLUMBUS SHOULD USE $3 MILLION IN CITY FUNDS, RESERVED FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY, FOR OTHER ROAD PROJECTS INSTEAD.
GAHANNA'S COLLEGE PARK SUBDIVISION RESIDENTS, WHO LIVE A FEW HUNDRED YARDS FROM THE OUTERBELT, SAY THEY WERE PROMISED A NOISE BARRIER BUT IT HAS NOT BEEN BUILT.
AN UNTERMINED AMOUNT OF CASH IS TAKEN IN A HOLDUP AT THE TRAIN STATION, 4430 INDIANOLA AVE.

The Rumble in the Jungle takes place in Kinshasa, Zaire, where Muhammad Ali knocks out George Foreman in eight rounds to regain the Heavyweight title, which had been stripped from him seven years earlier.
Franklin County Court House demolished.
The German electronic band Kraftwerk releases their studio album Autobahn.
China's attempt to launch the new Long March 2 rocket fails.
The United Nations General Assembly grants the Palestine Liberation Organization observer status.
Yes releases "Relayer"
In a rare (and final) public performance, former Beatle John Lennon joins Elton John on stage at Madison Square Garden in New York City.
WEATHER WILL DETERMINE WHETHER THE OUTERBELT SECTION BETWEEN RT 62 AND HAMILTON RD WILL BE FINISHED BY MID-DECEMBER, EASING TRAFFIC CONGESTION IN GAHANNA.
The first use of a Soyuz-U to launch a crewed mission. Soyuz 16 is a preparatory flight for the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project (ASTP).
"The Godfather, part II" is released.
"The Man With The Golden Gun" featuring Roger Moore as James Bond released in the United States.
The first B1 bomber prototype is flown.
Darwin, Australia is almost completely destroyed by Cyclone Tracy.
OSU: Dulles Hall, 230 W. 7th Ave., opens. Houses College of Humanities Offices.
Dungeons & Dragons fantasy tabletop role-playing game, designed by Gary Gygax and Dave Arneson, is first released, in the United States.
Rubik's Cube puzzle is invented by Hungarian architecture professor Ernő Rubik.
Burger King unveils the "HAVE IT YOUR WAY¨" campaign, created by BBDO.
The Anheuser-Busch brewery is modernized, increasing its capacity from 1.8 to 6.4 million barrels per year.
Construction of Alum Creek Dam completed. The dam is a rolled, earth filled embankment 10,000 feet in length with a maximum height of 93 feet.
Construction of One Nationwide Plaza begins. 40 stories.
Jeffrey Mining Products is sold to Dresser Industries.
The Borden Building at 180 E. Broad St. opens. 34 stories.

OSU: Mount Hall, 1050 Carmack Road, opens as general classroom space. The original design called for 13 buildings to be built on the West Campus and function as a Campus for freshmen before the students were moved to the main campus. The West Campus concept was abandoned in the late 80's. The building now houses offices such as Minority Affairs.
OSU: The Journalism Building, 141 W. 18th Ave., completely remodeled.
Deer Creek opens as an official State Park.
The Joliet Franciscan Sisters leave St. Michael's Parish in Worthington.
THE IHL Columbus Seals hockey team are bought by Al Savill and renamed The Columbus Owls.
Interstate 270 completed from 2 miles south of route 161 east of Columbus to route 62 and route 16 to route 40 east of Columbus.
Interstate 70, Route 270 to route 40, 3 miles west of downtown Columbus completed.
Worthington Parks and Recreation Board created.
James A. Rhodes begins his third term as Governor of Ohio
"The Jeffersons" premiers.
"Barney Miller" premiers.
McDonalds opens the first drive through window in Sierra Vista, Arizona.
Illinois Northern absorbed into the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe.
The first Xerox Sigma 9 minicomputer goes online at OCLC.
PICKERINGTON POLICE CONTINUE THEIR SEARCH FOR VANDALS WHO DERAILED SEVENTEEN CARS OF A PENN CENTRAL FREIGHT TRAIN.

Comedian George Carlin records his sixth album "An Evening with Wally Londo, Featuring Bill Slazso" recorded at (Little David 1008). Released October, 1975. Nominated for Grammy award. Includes "Teenage Masturbation," "Bodily Functions," "High on the Plane," and an early, incomplete version of "Baseball and Football." No more gold.
WORTHINGTON CITY COUNCIL APPROVES LEGISLATION TO BEGIN DEVELOPMENT OF THE OLENTANGY RIVER PARKLANDS.
Construction begins on the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System. The 48" pipeline is designed to carry crude oil from the north slope of Alaska 800 miles south to the port of Valdez.
DEC releases the PDP-11/70, the most advanced PDP-11 yet.
Microsoft is founded in Albuquerque, NM by Bill Gates and Paul Allen.
In Camobidia, Phnom Penh falls to the Khmer Rouge.
Alum Creek Dam: After an inspection, concern is expressed about the safety of the spillway monoliths, specifically against sliding due to seems of clay embedded in the shale under the dam.
"Starsky and Hutch" premiers.
The aircraft carrier CVN 68 Nimitz is commissioned.
WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC MOVES INTO $6.5 MILLION, 4 BUILDING COMPLEX ON DEARBORN DR.
FREEDOM SPECIAL: AMERICAN FREEDOM TRAIN WILL COME TO COLUMBUS THIS WEEK, SERVING AS A CATALYST FOR THE CENTRAL OHIO BICENTENNIAL OBSERVANCE.
FREEDOM TRAIN IS THE STAR OF THE SHOW AT DCSC STARTING 5/22, BUT TRAVELING MUSEUM WILL HAVE A SUPPORTING CAST OF EXHIBITS AND TALENTS OF CENTRAL OHIO RESIDENTS ON DISPLAY.
THRONGS OF SCHOOL CHILDREN LINE UP TO BOARD THE AMERICAN FREEDOM TRAIN AFTER A SMALL STARTING CROWD INITIALLY APPEARS FOR ITS OPENING AT DCSC.
THE AMERICAN FREEDOM TRAIN HAS A SELLOUT CROWD FOR THE SECOND MORNING OF ITS TEN-DAY STOPOVER AT DCSC.
COMPROMISE RESOLVES IMPASSE IN PLAN TO ROUTE THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY THROUGH UNION CEMETERY: CEMETERY WILL GIVE UP 23 ACRES OF LAND, AND FREEWAY WILL SHIFT NORTH OF ORIGINAL ROUTE.
COLS RECREATION AND PARKS DIRECTOR MELVIN DODGE REVEALS A PLAN TO CONVERT ANTRIM QUARRY INTO A SCENIC PARK TO SERVE NORTHWEST COLS, WORTHINGTON AND UPPER ARLINGTON.
Evel Knievel crashes while attempting to jump over 13 double-tiered busses in England's Wembley Stadium. Shown on ABC's Wide World of Sports.
AEP places the Philo power plant on standby. The 51 year old plant is not as efficient as other units in the AEP fleet, and the 1973-75 recession reduced electricity demand.
Michael Crichton publishes "The Great Train Robbery"
COST OF THE ENTIRE OLENTANGY FREEWAY WAS ESTIMATED AT $20 MILLION IN 1965--NOW THE SECTION FROM ACKERMAN RD TO HENDERSON RD ALONE WILL COST THAT MUCH.

A BAC One-Eleven departed Legaspi carrying 64 people (59 passengers, 5 crew) bound for Manila. As the plane descended for landing, a bomb detonated in the right lavatory in the aft passenger cabin. The blast created a large hole 4.3 x 13 ft (1.3 x 4 m) across and killed one passenger, but the plane landed safely.
FR CO METROPOLITAN PARKS OFFICIALS PARLAY 37.6 ACRE GIFT INTO 91.3 ACRES THAT WILL BECOME REGIONAL GARDEN CENTER KNOWN AS INNISWOOD GARDENS.

A Boeing 707 was on the ground in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, following a flight from Karachi. After the passengers had disembarked, a bomb exploded under a seat in the cabin ripping a 3 x 4 ft (0.9 x 1.2 m) hole in the fuselage. No one was hurt in the blast.
THE LAST SECTION OF THE OUTERBELT IS EXPECTED TO OPEN 8/20, SAYS THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION, UNLESS THE IRONWORKERS STRIKE DELAYS CONSTRUCTION.
Apollo-Soyuz launched: T. Stafford, V. Brand, D. Slayton (USA), A. Leonev, V. Kubasov (USSR).
LIGHTNING CAUSES A $90,000 FIRE WHICH HEAVILY DAMAGES THREE CONDOMINIUM UNITS IN THE TOLL GATE SQUARE COMPLEX AT 900 HIGH ST IN WORTHINGTON.
The Rolling Acres Mall in Akron opens.

Banlgadesh coup - a group of junior army officers invaded the presidential residence with tanks and killed Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, his family and personal staff. Khondaker Mustaq Ahmed becomes President.
Viking 1 is launched on an a Titan/Centaur rocket. It contains an orbiter and lander headed to Mars.
The Pontiac Silverdome in Detroit opens. The Detroit Lions defeat the Kansas City Chiefs 27-24.
AEP: Unit 1 of the Donald C. Cook nuclear plant is commissioned. 1045 MW.
HILLIARD RESIDENTS APPROVE THE CONSTRUCTION OF A RAILROAD UNDERPASS ON HILLIARD-CEMETERY RD, WEST OF NORWICH ST, AT A PUBLIC HEARING.
OCLC moves into the Kinnear Road Complex at 1125 Kinnear Rd.
Viking 2 is launched on an a Titan/Centaur rocket. It contains an orbiter and lander headed to Mars.
"Welcome Back Kotter" premiers.
"Saturday Night Live" premiers with guest host George Carlin (loaded on cocaine all week long) and musicians Janis Ian and Billy Preston.
Evel Knievel jumped over 14 Greyhound buses in the King's Island parking lot, setting a world record.
Khondaker Mustaq Ahmed is toppled only 4 months after assuming power in Bangladesh by Khondaker Mustaq Ahmed.
Khondaker Mustaq Ahmed is killed in yet another coup in Bangladesh. Major General Ziaur Rahman takes power.
The SS Edmund Fitzgerald was lost with her entire crew of 29 men on Lake Superior, 17 miles north-northwest of Whitefish Point, Michigan.
GEORGE W CROOK, 57, OF 751 GARRETT DR, DIED IN GRANT HOSPITAL; HE WAS THE PRESIDENT OF THE OHIO RAILWAY MUSEUM AT WORTHINGTON.
Toledo & Ohio Central station at 379 West Broad Street suffers a devastating fire.
The Martin Marietta X-24B makes its last flight.

Sony introduces the Betamax, the first popular home VCR. Cost $2295 with one-hour 1/2-inch tape cassettes for $15.95. Sony sought to created a standardized format by getting 7 other companies to agree to produce machines that would play the Beta cassettes.
One Day at a Time premiers.
Riverside Methodist Hospital School of Nursing moves to Ohio Wesleyan University.
OSU: Independence Hall, 1923 Neil Ave., opens. Built as part of the University Hall complex, contains a huge auditorium and a few offices.
OSU: Kinnear Road Center, 1099, 1121 & 1125 Kinnear Rd., acquired by the Ohio College Library Center (OCLC).
Archie Griffin becomes the only player to win two Heisman trophies.
I-270 Outerbelt completed after numerous delays at a cost of $150 million.
Interstate 71 entire route completed.
St. John's Episcopal Church purchases Township Hall in Worthington.

MEA 438 was a Boeing 720 en route from Beirut, Lebanon, to Dubai, United Arab Emirates. While flying over northeastern Saudi Arabia at 37,000 ft (11,275 m) a bomb detonated in the forward baggage hold. The crash killed all 81 people aboard.
"Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman" premiers.
"Laverne and Shirley" premiers.

The Communist Party of Kampuchea (CPK) promulgated the Constitution of Democratic Kampuchea. Under their rule until 1979, 1/4 of the population would be murdered, all private property abolished and cities emptied in an attempt to turn all citizens into peasants. Victims included such class enemies as rich capitalists, professionals, intellectuals, police and government employees (including most of Lon Nol's leadership),[33] along with ethnic minorities such as Chinese, Vietnamese, Lao and Cham.

A recruit falls ill at Fort Dix, New Jersey, and dies the following day. Under orders from Gerald Ford, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Atlanta launches an inoculation project against "swine flu," the disease responsible for 20 million deaths in 1918-1919. The vaccinations lead to Guillain-Barre syndrome, an ascending paralysis, in 100,000 people and kills 5 percent of those afflicted.
WORTHINGTON OFFICIALS EXPECT WORK TO BEGIN WITHIN A MONTH ON MCCORD PARK.
THE BUILDERS OF THE COLS CONVENTION CENTER ARE WARNED BY STATE OFFICIALS TO "WEIGH THE POTENTIAL OF A CATASTROPHE" THAT COULD BE CAUSED BY A TRAIN DERAILMENT IN THE CENTER.
The King Dome in Seatle opens.
Michael Crichton publishes "The Eaters of the Dead"
Apple Computer is founded in Cupertino, CA by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak.

Penn Central, Lehigh Valley, Central Railroad of New Jersey, Erie Lackawana, Reading, Lehigh & Hudson River, Lehigh & New England, Chicago River & Indiana, Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Lines, BCK, New York & Long Branch, Mt. Hope Mineral, Buffalo & Erie, Columbus & Indianapolis, Ironton, Lackawanna & Wyoming Valley, NJ, P&A, TPT, Wharton & Northern and Raritan River merge creating Conrail.
The Seattle Sounders soccer team play their first game in the Seattle King Dome.
WORTHINGTON CITY OFFICIALS ATTEMPT TO LEARN PUBLIC'S FEELINGS ABOUT A PROPOSED $756,400 COMMUNITY CENTER, TENTATIVELY PLANNED FOR THE CITY'S NORTH SIDE.
THE QUESTION NO LONGER APPEARS TO BE WHETHER GAHANNA RESIDENTS WHOSE HOMES BORDER THE OUTERBELT WILL GET A NOISE BARRIER--JUST WHEN.
ROSALYNN CARTER GREETS WORKERS AT THE COLUMBUS AUTO PARTS PLANT AS SHE CAMPAIGNS FOR HER HUSBAND, DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE JIMMY CARTER.
Tampa & Gulf Coast absorbed into Seaboard Coast Line.
The Grand Teton Dam in Idaho fails, which resulted in widespread downstream destruction, millions of dollars in claims and recrimination over the construction of the dam.
Viking 1 is inserted into orbit around Mars.
FORT HAYES, CREATED BY AN ACT OF CONGRESS IN 1861, IS BECOMING A $6 MIL CAREER CENTER FOR STUDENTS FROM COLUMBUS, UPPER ARLINGTON, GRANDVIEW HTS, WESTERVILLE AND WORTHINGTON.
The Summer Olympics open in Montreal, Canada.
Viking 1 lands on Mars.
Eldon Joersz sets an airplane speed record of 2193.2 mph at Beale Air Force Base in California.

At 3:42 a.m. a magnitude 7.8 earthquake hit the sleeping city of Tangshan, in northeastern China. The very large earthquake, striking an area where it was totally unexpected, obliterated the city of Tangshan and killed over 240,000 people - making it the deadliest earthquake of the twentieth century.
WORTHINGTON'S PARK SYSTEM WILL GROW BY ANOTHER 17 ACRES WHEN THE BOARD OF EDUCATION APPROVES THE SALE OF LAND ADJACENT TO PERRY MIDDLE SCHOOL.
THE CITY OF GAHANNA MAY SEEK AN INJUNCTION TO CLOSE THE PORTION OF THE OUTERBELT BORDERING THE CITY UNTIL A PROMISED NOISE BARRIER IS BUILT BY THE STATE.
Viking 2 is inserted into orbit around Mars.
OHIO DEPT OF TRANSPORTATION RELENTS UNDER PRESSURE AND WILL MAKE SPECIFIC PROPOSALS TO THE GAHANNA CITY COUNCIL FOR A NOISE BARRIER ALONG THE OUTERBELT.
COLUMBUS WILL CLOSE ITS SOUTH SIDE LANDFILL AND MOVE THE OPERATION TO THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE OUTERBELT AND THE WEST FREEWAY IN SEPTEMBER.
OSU: Three Jesse Owens Recreation Centers, 2151 Neil Ave., 75 W. 11th Ave., 1301 Carmack Rd., open.
Viking 2 lands on Mars.
George W. Bush is arrested for drunk driving.
Seven masked men planted dynamite explosives aboard a Boeing 707 parked at Ajaccio, France. No one was injured in the subsequent blast but the plane was destroyed.
JVC unveils its VHS (Video Home System) half-inch videocassette recorder format at Hotel Okura, Tokyo. This system eventually beats out the Betamax to become the home video standard.
The Seattle Seahawks play their first regular season game, losing to the St. Louis Cardinals 30-24.
The Tampa Bay Buccaneers play their first regular season game, losing to the Houston Oilers 20-0.
The Seattle Seahawks play their first game in the Seattle King Dome.
Construction is completed by Rockwell on OV-101 Enterprise.
Seaboard Coast Line gains control of Durham & Southern.

Comedian George Carlin records his seventh album "On The Road" at Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, Los Angeles (Little David 1075). Released April, 1977. Includes "Death and Dying," "How's Your Dog?" "Rules, Rules, Rules," and "Supermarkets."
AMTRAK OFFICIALS IN WASHINGTON SAY IT MAY BE A LONG TIME BEFORE THE TEMPORARY PASSENGER TRAIN STATION AT THE COLUMBUS CONVENTION CENTER HAS ITS PROBLEMS RESOLVED.

A Cubana flight was headed from Barbados, via Trinidad, to Havana, Cuba. The Douglas DC-8 carrying 73 people (48 passengers, 25 crew) exploded in flight and spun downward crashing off the coast of Bridgetown, Barbados. The aircraft is believed to have been destroyed by two time bombs using dynamite or C-4 explosives that set off an uncontrollable fire in the aft cabin. The plot was traced to anti-Castro Cuban exiles and Venezuelan secret police who reportedly had links to the Central Intelligence Agency in the United States.
Chicago & Eastern Illinois and Texas & Pacific merged into Missouri Pacific.
REACTION TO CONSTRUCTION OF THE TWO REMAINING SECTIONS OF OLENTANGY FREEWAY IS DIVIDED; THE CONTRACT TO BUY 24 ACRES FOR FREEWAY RIGHTOF-WAY FROM UNION CEMETERY IS SIGNED.

The Battelle Commons group begins a secret demolition of the Columbus Union Station's ornate arcade, at 6:00pm Friday night. This is done to pre-empt any public debate about preserving the landmark structure.
THE FEDERAL HIGHWAY ADMINISTRATION APPROPRIATES $18,000 FOR PLANNING A NOISE BARRIER BETWEEN THE OUTERBELT AND GAHANNA'S COLLEGE PARK SUBDIVISION.
Evel Knievel successfully jumps over 7 Greyhound buses at the Kingdome in Seatle, Washington. Shown on ABC's Wide World of Sports.

The 3rd Sigma 9 goes online at OCLC and 2 million records have been added to the database. This continues on until 1986 when the fifteenth Sigma 9 is connected and the database contains 15 million bibliographic records.
The French government places the first order for TGV high speed rail after successful testing of the Z 7001 Zébulon experimental high speed train.
USS Los Angeles SSN-688 commissioned.
OBTAINING DAYLIGHT PASSENGER TRAIN SERVICE IN OHIO IS ON THE MAIN AGENDA OF THE OHIO ASSOCIATION OF RAIL PASSENGERS.
THE BATTELLE MEMORIAL INSTITUTE FOUNDATION ANNOUNCES A $1 MIL GRANT TO THE METROPOLITAN PARK DISTRICT OF COLUMBUS AND FRANKLIN COUNTY FOR FACILITIES AT DARBY CREEK METRO PARK.
Lake Erie freezes over, setting a record for the earliest time in the season.
The last All American Jersey Sale is held in Columbus. Thirty six cows are sold for $95,000. The event moved to Louisville, Kentucky the following year.
The St. Clair Hotel on St. Clair Avenue closes.
OSU: Haskett Hall, 156 W. 19th Ave., remodeled. Houses the Media Arts Laboratories.
OSU: Larkins Hall, 337 W. 17th Ave., massive addition adds gymnasiums, pools and handball courts.
Former Joliet Franciscan Sisters convent at St. Michael's Parish in Worthington becomes the Vianney Residence, a home for retired priests. Father Byrne retires.
Columbus Union Station demolished.
Interstate 70, entire route completed.
Ohio's last commuter train, the Cleveland to Youngstown shuttle, is shut down.
Originally designated as a parallel route for Interstate 71 through Columbus, the corridor is recertified as Interstates 315 and 670.
State Route 315 completed from I-70 to 3 miles north of downtown.
The first Cray supercomputer, the CRAY-1, is installed at Los Alamos Laboratory in New Mexico. It cost $8,800,000 and was capable of 100-160 MFLOPS.
VIA Rail Canada created as a Canadian National subsidiary.
"Fantasy Island" premiers.
Gary Gilmore, the convicted murderer, is executed by firing squad in the Utah state prison, Salt Lake City.
AFTER 16-YRS OF PLANNING, NEGOTIATING, COURTFIGHTING, RENEGOTIATING AND REPLANNING, HIGHWAY OFFICIALS HOPE 1977 IS THE YR FINAL STEPS ARE TAKEN TO COMPLETE THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY.
James Earl Carter, Jr. inaugurated as President.

Blizzard of 77 begins. January 1977 average temperature for Ohio of 11.9 degrees was 17 degrees below average, below freezing all month at most sites, coldest winter known, fuel shortages, deep snows. Buffalo, N.Y.: "Blizzard of 1977" dumped about 7 in. of new snow on top of 30-35 in. already on the ground. With winds gusting to 70 mph, drifts were as high as 30 ft. Death toll reached 29, and seven western N.Y. counties were declared a national disaster area.
The Commodore PET 2001 is introduced for $3,287 by Commodore.
Blizzard of 77 ends.
Comedian George Carlin tapes an episode of "Welcome Back Kotter." Integrity slipping fast. Acting not an issue, it's TV.
"Grizzly Adams" premiers.
ROBERT TAGGART, 44, JAMES P ROSS, 55, AND THE PILOT, JOHN B WICK, 42, ESCAPE SERIOUS INJURY WHEN THE TWIN-ENGINE PIPER NAVAHO THEY WERE RIDING IN CRASHES IN A WORTHINGTON FIELD.
MORE THAN 600 EMPLOYEES OF THE COLUMBUS AUTO PARTS CO, EAST HUDSON ST, STAY OFF THEIR JOBS AFTER 41 MEMBERS OF ONE UNION CALL A STRIKE.
Alum Creek Dam: Bids are opened for the installation of 53 anchor cables to be embedded in the base of the dam to prevent it from sliding forward and failing.

First George Carlin HBO stand-up concert special, "On Location: George Carlin at USC," taped at USC, Los Angeles, complete with elaborate "language disclaimer" by Shana Alexander. Includes, "Monopoly," "Dogs & Cats," "Names," "Supermarkets," and "Words."
"Eight is Enough" and "Three's Company" premier.
Final episode of Sanford and Son.
STRIKING UNITED AUTO WORKERS AT COLUMBUS AUTO PARTS CO, E HUDSON ST AND THE NORTH FREEWAY, RETURN TO WORK IN COMPLIANCE WITH A COURT ORDER.
The Seattle Mariners play their first game in the Seattle King Dome.
The last new episode of The Electric Company on PBS. Reruns will continue until 1985.

At 9:17 am, the last train to depart Union Station leaves for Kansas City. Henceforth trains would stop at a small metal depot east of the Fourth Street Viaduct. The cost of maintaining Columbus Union Station was simply too high to be justified by only two trains per day.
The Apple II computer is introduced for $1,298 by Apple at the first West Coast Computer Faire.
"Star Wars" released.
A devastating fire swept through the Beverly Hills Supper Club in Southgate, Ky. The fire was discovered shortly before 9 p.m., burned most of the night and killed 165 people.
Work is completed on the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System. Total cost is about $8 billion dollars.
PAGES FROM A TELEPHONE BOOK, PAMPHLETS AND CLOTHING APPARENTLY ARE USED TO IGNITE A FIRE THAT CAUSES $15,000 DAMAGE TO PERRY MIDDLE SCHOOL, 2341 SNOUFFER RD.
The first oil moves through the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System. When full, the pipeline holds 9,059,057 barrels, and delivers 2.136 million barrels per day on average.
The movie "Pumping Iron", starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, is released.
USS Baton Rouge SSN-689 commissioned.
USS Philadelphia SSN-690 commissioned.
President Jimmy Carter cancels the B-1A bomber program.
Yes releases "Going for the One"
First oil tanker (ARCO Juneau) carrying oil from the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System departs Valdez Harbour.
Radio Shack (Tandy) announces the Level 1 Model I TRS-80 (4KB RAM, 4KB ROM, keyboard, black-and-white video display, and tape cassette), at a price of $599.
"The Spy Who Loved Me" featuring Roger Moore as James Bond released in the United States.
Alexandr Fedotov sets a world altitude record of 123,523 feet in a Mig E-266M at Podmoskovnoe, Russia.
THE OHIO DEPT OF TRANSPORTATION GIVES THE CITY OF COLUMBUS THE APPROVAL NEEDED TO ACQUIRE THE LAND NECESSARY TO COMPLETE THE LONG-DELAYED OLENTANGY FREEWAY.
Steven W. Leininger, architect for the TRS-80 computer, provides an overview of the design choices for the TRS-80 Model I computer at the San Diego Computer Society meeting.

Youngstown Sheet and Tube shuts down, abruptly throwing 5,000 people out of work and ending decades of steel production in Youngstown, Ohio. The day is ever remembered as "black Friday" in Youngstown.
"Lou Grant" premiers.
Alum Creek Dam: Completion of the installation of 53 anchor cables to be embedded in the base of the dam to prevent it from sliding forward and failing.
The aircraft carrier CVN 69 Dwight D. Eisenhower is commissioned.
DEC releases the VAX 11/780, the first of the VAX line of minicomputers. The VAX architecture is 32 bit, compared to the 16 bit PDP-11 it replaces.
"The Incredible Hulk" premiers.
Dennis Kucinich becomes Mayor of Cleveland.
The Saturday Night Fever Soundtrack album featuring the Bee Gee's is released.
CONRAIL TRAIN DERAIL ALONG E 5TH AVE, WEST OF HAMILTON RD, AND BLOCK THE MAIN EAST-WEST TRACKS INTO COLUMBUS.

The ".22 Caliber Killers" murder their first victims, two women at Forkers Cafe in Newark, Ohio, some distance outside the city of Columbus in Licking County. The victims, 37-year-old Joyce Vermilion and 33-year-old Karen Dodrill, were shot multiple times as they walked out the rear door of the cafe, shortly after its closing at 2:30 a.m.
USS Memphis SSN-691 commissioned.

In Westwego, Louisiana a two hundred and fifty-foot grain elevator exploded spectacularly, taking the lives of 36 workers. During the early morning hours at the Continental Grain Company's facility, a high concentration of the volatile dust ignited from a spark that occurred in the grain elevators head house. Within milliseconds additional grain dust combusted, causing multiple explosions within the adjacent silos that virtually destroyed the facility. The head house fell a hundred feet onto an adjoining cinder block building full of employees. The incident in Westwego remains the deadliest grain dust explosion of the modern era.
The Commodore PET 2001 becomes available to consumers.
2,000th BURGER KING¨ restaurant opens in Hawaii, putting locations in all 50 states.
The National City Bank building at 155 E. Broad St. opens. 24 stories.
OSU: Kinnear Road Center, 1099, 1121 & 1125 Kinnear Rd., buildings E opens. Part of OCLC.
OSU: Lincoln Tower, 1800 Canon Drive, the lower 14 floors are now converted to office space.
OSU: Page Hall, 1810 College Road, partially renovated. Houses Business School offices and the Business Library.
OSU: William Thompson Oxley Memorial Library, 1858 Neil Ave., addition of a 4 story building on the West side.
The Columbus Clippers play their first game.

The IHL Columbus Owls are forced to play their post season in Troy, Ohio due to lack of available facilities in Columbus. Disgusted with lack of support in Columbus, management moves the team to Dayton.
Worthington Arts Council founded.
Worthington Parks and Recreation Department constructs Community Center on Highland Ave.
Robin Cook publishes "Coma"
Texas Pacific - Missouri Pacific Terminal RR of New Orleans absorbed into the Missouri Pacific.
THE NEW $811,000 WORTHINGTON COMMUNITY CENTER AT 360 HIGHLAND AVE OPENS ITS DOORS THIS WEEK
WORTHINGTON PUBLIC LIBRARY'S BOARD AGREES TO A COMPROMISE WITH THE WORTHINGTON CITY COUNCIL ON REZONING LIBRARY PROPERTY AT LARRIMER AVE AND HIGH STREET.
FIRE GUTS THE HOME OF CHARLES GRAMLY, 447 SOUTH SELBY BLVD; DAMAGE IS ESTIMATED AT $20,000.

At midnight it is 40 degrees and rainy in Columbus. The storm arrived in Central Ohio around 3 am with 60 mph winds, and by 7 am temperatures were in the single digits and 30,000 Columbus residents were without power. Transportation came to a halt across Ohio for days, 51 died, 6000 motorists were stranded on roads. Gov. Rhoads called out 5000 National Guard troops, and damages and costs exceeded a quarter billion dollars.
MOST SCHOOLS ARE OPEN AND LIVES SOMEWHAT BACK TO NORMAL AS CENTRAL OHIOANS TURN THEIR ATTENTION FROM THE WEATHER TO THE POTENTIAL LOSS OF ELECTRIC POWER.

Eastern U.S.: "Blizzard of 1978" battered the East Coast, particularly the Northeast; claimed 54 lives and caused $1 billion in damage. Snowfall ranged from 2-4 ft in New England, plus nearly 2 ft of snow already on the ground from an earlier storm.

The ".22 Caliber Killers" strike again. 52-year-old Robert "Mickey" McCann; his mother, 77-year-old Dorothy Marie McCann; and McCann's girlfriend, 26-year-old Christine Herdman, were found dead in McCann's house at 4187 Ongaro Drive, a semi-rural area just outside the city of Columbus, in Franklin County.
The first satellite for the GPS system is launched.
THE WORTHINGTON BOARD OF EDUCATION TURNS OVER 75 ACRES OF SCHOOL DISTRICT LAND TO WESTERVILLE SCHOOLS BECAUSE LAND IS ISOLATED FROM REST OF WORTHINGTON DISTRICT.
USS Omaha SSN-692 commissioned.
USS Cincinnati SSN-693 commissioned.
AFTER SEVENTEEN YEARS, THE CITY OF COLUMBUS HURDLES THE LAST BARRIER PREVENTING THE COMPLETION OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY.
Pacific Fruit Express dissolved equally to Southern Pacific and Union Pacific.
VIA Rail Canada becomes separate crown corporation.
"Dallas" premiers.

The ".22 Caliber Killers" strike again. Jenkin T. Jones, 77 is gunned down in his rural home, just outside of Granville, Ohio, Jones had been shot a total of six times, twice to the head.  It was later discovered that all four of the victim's dogs had been killed as well.
"Maude" final episode.

The ".22 Caliber Killers" strike again. Rev. Gerald Fields is killed while working part-time as a security guard at the Wigwam, a private club in northwest Fairfield County, which is just southeast of the city of Columbus.
The ".22 Caliber Killers" strike again. Victims are 47-year-old Jerry L. Martin and his wife, 50-year-old Martha. The Martins' home was located at 3823 Morse Road in Franklin County.
NOISE BARRIERS FROM THE OUTERBELT ARE ERECTED IN GAHANNA; CITY THREATENED TO SUE OHIO DEPT OF TRANSPORTATION IF BARRIERS WERE NOT ERECTED.
WORTHINGTON, JAMES LORIMER WIELDS SYMBOLIC SHOVELS IN GROUNDBREAKING FOR THE NEW THREE-MILE SECTION OF THE OLENTANGY FREEWAY.
AEP: Unit 2 of the Donald C. Cook nuclear plant is commissioned. 1168 MW, brings the plant capacity up to 2.2 GW.
The planet Pluto's moon Charon is discovered by James W. Christy, a U.S. Naval Observatory scientist.
The Worthington Historical Society relocates the Episcopal Rectory to 50 West New England Avenue and uses it to house a library, collections and offices.
USS Groton SSN-694 commissioned.
GAHANNA'S $400,000 FREEWAY NOISE BARRIER GETS MIXED REVIEW BY RESIDENTS: AND GRAFFITI ARE THEIR MAJOR CONCERNS.
Lee Iacocca is fired by CEO Henry Ford II despite a successful career as the president of the Ford Motor Co.

Second HBO stand-up concert special, "On Location: George Carlin at Phoenix," taped at Celebrity Star Theater, Phoenix. Includes "Death," The Long Newscast," "Time," and "Kids & Parents." Shot in the round; transferred to film for proposed concert/sketch movie (The Illustrated George Carlin). Movie never works out.
MADISON'S OPENS ITS SEVENTH STORE IN THE COLUMBUS AREA IN THE WORTHINGTON SQUARE SHOPPING CENTER; IT IS THE 10TH STORE FOR THE CHAIN.
36 CARS OF A 181-CAR NORFOLK & WESTERN RAILWAY CO FREIGHT TRAIN DERAIL AT A CROSSING FIVE MILES NORTH OF DELAWARE IN AN ACCIDENT THAT WITNESSES SAY COULD HAVE BEEN AVOIDED.

A BAC One-Eleven left Cebu for Manilla with 84 aboard (78 passengers, 6 crew). One passenger was killed when a bomb blast in the left rear lavatory blew a hole in the fuselage. The aircraft landed safely with no additional injuries. The aircraft involved in the incident was the same Philippine airliner that had been bombed in June 1975.
Radio Shack (Tandy) announces the TRS-80 Model I Level II, at a price of $1099.
"Battlestar Galactica" premiers.
Yes releases "Tormato"
VIA Rail Canada assumes operation of CP passenger trains.
Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla elected supreme pontiff-John Paul II .
Abilene & Southern, Texas-New Mexico, New Orleans & Lower Coast, Ft. Worth Belt, Missouri-Illinois, St. Joseph Belt and Union Terminal absorbed into the Missouri Pacific.
"Diff'rent Strokes" premiers.
OBETZ' OLD INTERURBAN TRAIN STATION MAY BE SAVED BY THE COLUMBUS LANDMARKS FOUNDATION IN ORDER TO MOVE IT TO THE COLUMBUS ZOO.
WORTHINGTON CITY ENGINEER RICHARD HAMMER SAYS ENGINEERS REPAIRING GREENWICH ST HAVE FOUND THE REPAIRS WILL BE MORE EXTENSIVE AND COSTLY THAN ORIGINALLY PLANNED; RESIDENTS ARE IRATE.
The ".22 Caliber Killers" strike again. 56-year-old Joseph Annick is shot five times in the chest and stomach, while working in his garage.

The case of the ".22 Caliber Killers" breaks wide open when 17-year-old Cheryl Young, an employee of Woolco Department Store in Columbus, noticed that a customer's credit card was on a list of stolen cards the manager had posted on the register.  Managerial trainee Jeff Slovak detained the man who had given her the card, 38-year-old Gary Lewingdon, until authorities arrived at the scene.  The credit card Lewingdon attempted to use belonged to Annick and had been reported stolen by investigators.

In the case of the ".22 Caliber Killers", Gary and Thaddeus Lewingdon were indicted.  Gary was facing 20 felony counts, including 10 counts of murder, while Thaddeus was looking at 17 counts, including nine counts of murder.
USS Birmingham SSN-695 commissioned.
Vietnam invades Kampuchea (Cambodia) with the intention of destroying the regime.
Woody Hayes is fired after punching an opposing player in the Sugar Bowl
Intel releases the 8086 microprocessor.
Savko Plastic Pipe & Fittings Co. opens the Bath and Brass showroom at 683 E. Lincoln Ave.
Columbus City Schools desegregation ordered by Judge Robert Duncan.
One Nationwide Plaza opens. 40 stories.
The Clintonville Academy is founded.
OSU: Hayes Hall, 108 N. Oval Mall, completely renovated. Now houses the Art and Art History Departments.
Construction of a new library begins at the corner of Hartford and Stafford Streets.
Ohio Historical Society archaeologists excavate area near the base of the Hopewell mound and find evidence of holes where posts has supported two or three prehistoric buildings.
Worthington Historical Society moves old Episcopal rectory to 55 W. New England Ave., and begins renovation for its office, library, gift shop and doll museum.
COLUMBUS MAY USE OBETZ TRAIN STATION AS HISTORIC TOUCH TO A NEW BUILDING AT THE COLUMBUS ZOO.
Vietnamese troops enter Phnom Penh in Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge leadership flees to Khao Larn camp in Trat Province in Thailand.
James A. Rhodes begins his fourth term as Governor of Ohio
The Shah of Iran flees the country following months of increasingly violent protests against his regime.
The contract is awarded for the construction of the Space Shuttles DISCOVERY and ATLANTIS.
Pluto moves along its eccentric orbit closer to the Sun than Neptune.

China invades Vietnam with 200,000 troops and 200 tanks. The Chinese army captured Cao Bằng and Lao Cai after three weeks and Lạng Sơn after a month. The invasion is spurred by China's displeasure over Vietnam conquering its ally Cambodia, and to prove that Russia cannot protect its ally.
A Douglas DC-3 crashed at Barentu, Ethiopia, after a bomb exploded aboard. All five passengers and crew were killed.
THE HISTORIC TWO-VOLUME BIBLE, PRINTED IN NUREMBERG, GERMANY, BY ANTON KONBERGER IN 1483, RESTS IN THE PONTIFICAL COLLEGE JOSEPHENIUM LIBRARY IN WORTHINGTON.
USS New York City SSN-696 commissioned.

After facing unexpectedly harsh resistance, Chinese forces withdraw from Vietnam. They also promised the Soviet Union their incursion would be limited, and had to keep their word to prevent a wider war on the Soviet-Chinese border.
Jane Byrne became the first female mayor in Chicago's history.
OCLC buys the land that the Kilgour building sits on. OCLC was spread out in 5 separate buildings across Columbus.
The final episode of All In The Family.
Northern Tex. and southern Okla.: 11 tornadoes caused 59 deaths.
Idi Amin flees from Uganda to Libya, and exile, after the capture of Kampala by UNLA and Tanzanian Defense Forces.

An Indian Airlines flight from Trivandrum was descending to land at Madras (now Chennai) when an explosion went off in the forward lavatory. The aircraft overran the end of the runway. Though the right side of the plane caught fire, all 67 occupants (61 passengers, 6 crew) evacuated safely. All survived but the 737 was written off because of damage sustained.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The crawler transported space shuttle Enterprise, with external tank and two inert solid rocket boosters to Launch Pad A for fit check.
The Apple II computer is discontinued by Apple.
Radio Shack (Tandy) announces the TRS-80 Model II, at a price of $3450
VisiCalc is released at the West Coast Computer Fair for Apple II. It is the first "killer app" and accelerates growth of the personal computer industry.
Groundbreaking for the OCLC Kilgour Building in Dublin, Ohio.
THE "GAHANNA 5," MEMBERS OF COLS CHAPTER OF NAT'L ORG FOR WOMEN, ARE ARRESTED AFTER BEING CAUGHT PAINTING ANTI-RAPE AND PRO-FEMINIST SIGNS ON THE OUTERBELT NOISE BARRIER.
The Apple II Plus is released for $1,195 by Apple.
Air show to celebrate 50 years at Port Columbus International Airport

At Comiskey Park in Chicago, Illinois, a promotion entitled "Disco Demolition Night" was held where a crate filled with disco records was blown up on the field. The playing field was so damaged by the explosion and by the fans that the White Sox were required to forfeit the second game to the Tigers. A lot of the anger against Disco was rooted in racism and homophobia by 18-34 year old white males during a time of social change and economic downturn.
"Moonraker" featuring Roger Moore as James Bond released in the United States.
Tropical Storm Claudette drops 42" of rain in 24 hours on Alvin, TX (south of Houston), the most rain recorded in 24 hours in the United States.
Paul Volcker became the 12th Chairman of the Federal Reserve System.

The Rosemont Horizon Arena sports complex located in Rosemont, Illinois, collapses during the final phases of construction. Five construction workers fell down with the roof and died instantly, fifteen others were injured. Of the 966 girder bolts needed for the arches already installed, only 444 were in place. Of the 444 bolts that were in place, 338 had no nuts.
Hurricane: Caribbean to New England: David caused five U.S. deaths; 1,200 in the Dominican Republic.
Hurricane: Ala. and Miss.: Frederic devastated Mobile, Ala., and caused $2.3 ($4.9) billion in damage overall.

In a talk at the Fayzieah School in Qom, Khomeini warned pro-imperialist opponents: "Those who are trying to bring corruption and destruction to our country in the name of democracy will be oppressed. They are worse than Bani-Ghorizeh Jews, and they must be hanged. We will oppress them by God's order and God's call to prayer."
Israel and South Africa conduct a joint test of a small 2-3 kiloton nuclear weapon in the Indian Ocean.

The National Limited (formerly the Spirit of St. Louis) makes its final stop in Columbus. This ends train passenger service to Columbus that first began in 1850 and peaked at 160 passenger trains per day in 1916.

Paul Volcker calls a secret emergency Federal Open Markets committee meeting to decide on better methods for controlling money, credit expansion, and inflation. By April, 1980, the federal funds rate will peak at 17.9%.
THE WORTHINGTON BOARD OF EDUCATION HIRES THE GULKNECHT CONSTRUCTION CO OF 716 S 5TH AVE FOR THE $188,000 REMODELING AND EXPANSION OF COLONIAL HILLS ELEMENTARY SCHOOL.
The Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation laid off 30,000 factory workers, swelling the industry's layoffs to 120,000.

American 444 was a Boeing 727 carrying 78 people (72 passengers, 6 crew) and headed from Chicago to Washington DC. Thirty minutes into flight, a mail bomb hidden in a wooden box in the cargo hold ignited. The device produced large amounts of smoke but failed to detonate. The bomb was built by Ted Kaczynski, better known as the Unabomber.
Employment at the North American Rockwell plant is down to 2,000
Columbus Public Schools are desegregated by court order. This is accomplished peacefully.
The Federal Glass Co. on the south side closes.
The Franklin County Municipal Court at 375 S. High St. opens. 19 stories.
Port Columbus International Airport completes a $70 million renovation.
San Diego & Arizona Eastern sold to San Diego Metro-Transit Development Board.
Jimmy Carter proclaims a grain embargo against the USSR with the support of the European Commission.
USS Indianapolis SSN-697 commissioned.
Jimmy Carter authorizes legislation giving $1.5 billion in loans to bail out the Chrysler Corporation.
In Saudi Arabia, 63 Islamist insurgents are beheaded for their part in the siege of the Great Mosque in Mecca

The Pittsburgh Steelers win their fourth National Football League championship in six seasons, defeating the Los Angeles Rams 31–19 in Super Bowl XIV at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, California. The game was shown to the Americans held hostage in Iran.
Andrei Sakharov, Soviet scientist and human rights activist, is arrested in Moscow.
The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad is ordered liquidated due to bankruptcy and debt owed to creditors.
Six United States diplomats, posing as Canadians, manage to escape from Tehran, Iran, as they board a flight to Zürich, Switzerland, on Swissair.
NASA Crawler Transporter: The original shoe quantity was supplemented with 228 new shoes per crawler from foundries in Bay City, MI and Kobe, Japan.
Abscam: FBI personnel target members of the Congress of the United States in a sting operation.
The New Mexico State Penitentiary riot takes place; 33 inmates are killed and more than 100 inmates injured.
Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini names Abolhassan Banisadr as president of Iran.
The 1980 Winter Olympics open in Lake Placid, New York.
AC/DC frontman Bon Scott dies after a night of heavy drinking in London.
The United States Olympic Hockey Team defeats the Soviet Union in the semifinals of the Winter Olympics, in the Miracle on Ice.
PUCO is asked to reconsider rate hikes linked to Zimmer nuke plant operation
Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini states that Iran's parliament will decide the fate of the American embassy hostages.
The Voyager 1 probe confirms the existence of Janus, a moon of Saturn.
Pierre Trudeau returns to office as Prime Minister of Canada.
The Soviet Union's first rock music festival starts.
Fifty people are killed at the Plesetsk Cosmodrome in Russia, when a Vostok-2M rocket explodes on its launch pad during a fueling operation.
PUCO refuses to reconsider rate hike given to help pay for Zimmer nuclear power plant
U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that the United States will boycott the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow because of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan.
Archbishop Óscar Romero is killed by gunmen while celebrating Mass in San Salvador.
A mine lift cage at the Vaal Reefs gold mine in South Africa falls 1.9 kilometres (1.2 mi), killing 23.
Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific ceases operations.
The Mariel boatlift from Cuba begins.
The final episode of Hawaii Five-O
The United States severs diplomatic relations with Iran and imposes economic sanctions
Last contact with Viking 2 on Mars.
SS France rechristened SS Norway.
Iron Maiden's debut self-titled album Iron Maiden is released in the U.K.
The Pennsylvania Lottery is rigged by six men including the host of the live TV drawing, Nick Perry.

Operation Eagle Claw, a commando mission in Iran to rescue American embassy hostages, is aborted after mechanical problems ground the rescue helicopters. Eight United States troops are killed in a mid-air collision during the failed operation.
Data General announces the MV/8000 Eclipse, a 32 bit minicomputer with a 4GB address space designed to compete against the Digital Equipment Corporation VAX.
Six Iranian-born terrorists take over the Iranian embassy in London, England.
The Federal Funds Rate peaks at 17.9%, driving the U.S. economy into a deep recession and setting of the Savings and Loan Crisis.
"About that Urban Renaissance...", an article by journalist Dan Rottenberg in Chicago, contains the first recorded use of the word "yuppie"
Iranian Embassy siege: SAS retakes the Embassy on May 5; one terrorist survives.
Paul Geidel, convicted of second-degree murder in 1911, is released from prison in Beacon, New York, after 68 years and 245 days (the longest-ever time served by an inmate).
In Florida, the Liberian freighter Summit Venture hits the Sunshine Skyway Bridge over Tampa Bay. A 1,400 feet (430 m) section of the bridge collapses and 35 people (most in a bus) are killed.
The Norco shootout takes place in California.
American Electric Power purchases the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company.
American mobster Henry Hill is arrested for drug possession.
A Tampa, Florida court acquits four white police officers of killing Arthur McDuffie, a black insurance executive, provoking three days of race riots in Miami.

At 8:32 a.m. Pacific Daylight Time, a magnitude 5.1 earthquake shook Mount St. Helens. The bulge and surrounding area slid away in a gigantic rockslide and debris avalanche, releasing pressure, and triggering a major pumice and ash eruption of the volcano. Thirteen-hundred feet (400 m) of the peak collapsed or blew outwards. As a result, 24 square miles (62 square Km) of valley was filled by a debris avalanche, 250 square miles (650 square km) of recreation, timber, and private lands were damaged by a lateral blast, and an estimated 200 million cubic yards (150 million cubic meters) of material was deposited directly by lahars (volcanic mudflows) into the river channels. Fifty-seven people were killed or are still missing.
Miami riots. In the end, 18 men and women died, while 350 people, some of them children, were hurt and 600 were arrested. Property destruction exceeded $100 million.
Voters in Quebec reject by a vote of 60% a proposal to seek independence from Canada.
"The Empire Strikes Back" released.
Pac-Man, the best-selling arcade game of all time, is released in Japan.
Indianapolis 500: Johnny Rutherford wins for a third time in car owner Jim Hall's revolutionary ground effect Chaparral car; the victory is Hall's second as an owner.
The Apple III computer is released for $4,340 by Apple. The first 14,000 units have to be recalled because they are unstable.
Buckeye Lake is incorporated as a village.
The first 24-hour news channel, Cable News Network (CNN) is launched.
A series of deadly tornadoes strikes Grand Island, Nebraska, causing over $300m in damage, killing five people and injuring over 250.
George Campbell graduates from 8th grade at High Bridge Middle School, High Bridge, NJ.
The 1980 United States heat wave claims 1,700 lives through September 6th.
Tim Berners-Lee begins work on ENQUIRE,[10] the system that will eventually lead to the creation of the World Wide Web in fall 1990.
Grand Trunk Western gains control of Detroit, Toledo & Ironton.
U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs Proclamation 4771, requiring 18- to 25-year-old males to register for a peacetime military draft, in response to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan.
Central and eastern U.S.: an estimated 1,700 people were killed during the summer in a long heat wave and drought. Damages totaled about $20 billion.
Red, White & Boom makes its debut.
A wave of strikes begins in Lublin, Poland.

Western Wisconsin Derecho: A severe and destructive thunderstorm strikes four counties in western Wisconsin, including the city of Eau Claire. It causes over $250 million in damage and one person is killed.

Former California Governor and actor Ronald Reagan is nominated for U.S. President, at the 1980 Republican National Convention in Detroit. Influenced by the Religious Right, the convention also drops its long-standing support for the Equal Rights Amendment, dismaying moderate Republicans.
The Summer Olympics open in Moscow, Russia.
The album Back in Black is released by the Australian band AC/DC.
Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, deposed Shah of Iran, dies in Cairo.
China's population hits one billion people.
Radio Shack (Tandy) announces the TRS-80 Model III, at a price of about $699 to $2499. Also announces the Pocket Computer I, at a price of about $229 and the Color Computer, at a price of about $399.
