Vigdís Finnbogadóttir becomes 4th President of Iceland, the world's first democratically directly elected female president.
A terrorist bombing at the Bologna Centrale railway station in Italy kills 85 people and wounds more than 200.
Hurricane: Caribbean to Tex. Gulf: Allen killed 28 in U.S.; over 200 in Caribbean.
Lech Wałęsa leads the first of many strikes at the Gdańsk Shipyard in the Polish People's Republic.
Hurricane Allen (category 3) pounds southeastern Texas.
U.S. President Jimmy Carter defeats Senator Edward Kennedy to win renomination, at the 1980 Democratic National Convention in New York City.
Yes releases "Drama"
In one of aviation's worst disasters, 301 people are killed when Saudia Flight 163 catches fire in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
Route 315 is readied in spite of rain delays.

Victory of the strike in Gdańsk Shipyard, Poland. The Gdańsk Agreement is signed, opening a way to start the first free (i.e. not state-controlled) trade union in the communist bloc, "Solidarity" (Solidarność).
MS-DOS released by Microsoft
The Gotthard Road Tunnel opens in Switzerland as the world's longest highway tunnel at 16.3 kilometres (10.1 mi), stretching from Göschenen to Airolo beneath the Gotthard Pass.

Passengers were disembarking a Boeing 727 in Sacramento, California, when a small cardboard box in the cargo hold detonated. The explosion injured two cargo handlers but none of the 44 passengers and crew were harmed.
A U.S. Air Force LGM-25C Titan II ICBM loaded with a 9 megaton W-53 Nuclear Warhead had a liquid fuel explosion inside its silo in Damascus, Arkansas.
Iraq launches an attack on Iran, beginning the Iran-Iraq war.
Oktoberfest bombing: 13 people are killed and 211 injured in a right-wing terror attack in Munich (West Germany).
The Mariel boatlift officially ends.
Digital Equipment Corporation, Intel and Xerox introduce the DIX standard for Ethernet, which is the first implementation outside of Xerox and the first to support 10 Mbit/s speeds.
The S.S. Badger left Milwaukee for the last time, ending service there.  Captain John Bissell in command.
Elisabeth blast furnace demolished at Bilston Steelworks marking the end of iron and steel production in the Black Country of England.
British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher delivers her famous "The lady's not for turning" speech.
The Staggers Rail Act is enacted, deregulating American railroads.
China conducts the world's last atmospheric test of a nuclear weapon.
Oklahoma, Kansas & Texas created by purchasing Herington, KS to Dallas, TX from Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific.
In continuous production since 1962, the last MG MGB roadster rolls off the assembly line at the Abingdon-on-Thames (England) factory, ending production for the MG Cars marque.
Rowland C. W. Brown named OCLC CEO.
The Polish government recognizes Solidarity.
"This Old House" premiers.
Chessie System (Chessapeake & Ohio, Baltimore & Ohio and Western Maryland) combines with the Seaboard Coast Line to create the CSX Corp.

Republican challenger and former Governor Ronald Reagan of California defeats incumbent Democratic President Jimmy Carter to become the 40th President-Elect of the United States, 1 year after the beginning of the Iran hostage crisis.

The NASA space probe Voyager I makes its closest approach to Saturn, when it flies within 77,000 miles (124,000 km) of the planet's cloud-tops and sends the first high resolution images of the world back to scientists on Earth.
The Gang of Four trial begins in China.
St. Louis and San Francisco merged into Burlington Northern.
84 people died and 679 were injured as a result of a fire at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas, Nevada.  This was the second largest life-loss hotel fire in United States history.

A missionary (Jean Donovan) and three Roman Catholic nuns (Maura Clarke, Ita Ford, Dorothy Kazel), all Americans, are murdered by a military death squad in El Salvador while doing charity work during that country's civil war.
English musician John Lennon is murdered by Mark David Chapman outside the Dakota.
"Magnum, P.I." premiers.
Four people are murdered and four others are injured by two armed robbers at Bob's Big Boy on La Cienega Boulevard in Los Angeles, in what is one of the city's most brutal crimes ever.
During a summit on the island of Bali, OPEC decides to raise the price of petroleum by 10%.

A Caravelle of TAC left Rio Hacha, Colombia, on its first scheduled flight following 17 months of maintenance. The flight was bound for Medelln with 70 people aboard (63 passengers, 7 crew). Five minutes after takeoff, an explosion set off a fire on the right side of the tail causing the plane to lose control and crash. It is unknown whether a bomb caused the crash but it is suspected.
Karl Dönitz, former German naval admiral and last head of state of Nazi Germany dies at his home in Aumühle, West Germany of a heart attack at the age of 89.
NASA Crawler Transporter: A crawler moved space shuttle Columbia out to Launch Pad 39A for STS-1 mission.
Olentangy Village Bowling Lanes burn. The bowling alley had the first automatic pinsetters in the United States.
Worthington Industries acquires Buckeye Steel Castings.
ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus gives its first concert.
The Hartman Building is demolished, 73-87 E. State St. Ten stories.
The Hyatt Regency at 350 N. High St. opens. 20 stories.
OSU: Orton Hall, 155 South Oval Mall, renovated.
OSU: Wiseman Hall, 400 & 410 West 12th Ave., adds floor 3 & 4 to be the Comprehensive Cancer Center.
Indian Creek Valley absorbed into B&O.
Michael Crichton publishes "Congo"
Northern Alberta Railways merged into Canadian National.
"Dynasty" premiers.
"Hill Street Blues" premiers.
Ronald Wilson Reagan inaugurated as President.
The 52 American hostages held at the US embassy in Tehran for more than 14 months arrive in West Germany on their way home to the United States.
Radio Shack (Tandy) ceases production of the Model I due to its failure to comply with FCC Radio Frequency Interference rules
OCLC moves from 1125 Kinnear Rd. to 6565 Kilgour Place.

On an already completed part near Pasilly, a French TGV high speed train established the world speed record for rail transport at 380 km/h (236 mph). In regular service speed would be limited to 260 km/h (160 mph), later to 270 km/h.
USS Bremerton SSN-698 commissioned.
PRR: The No. 2 track on Horseshoe Curve was pulled up as a Conrail cost cutting move, leaving three tracks remaining.
President Reagan is shot by John Hinckley outside a Washington DC hotel.
STS-1 Columbia launched: John Young, Robert Crippen. First orbital test flight of a space shuttle.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its maiden flight. Mission STS-1.
USS San Francisco SSN-711 commissioned.
USS Jacksonville SSN-699 commissioned.

Bangladesh Prime Minister Ziaur Rahman is assasinated by 12 army officers while visiting Chittagong to arbitrate in a clash between the local leaders of his political party, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. The officers are later captured and executed, either immediately or after a brief trial.
Quanah, Acme & Pacific absorbed into Burlington Northern.

An F0 tornado touched down near Indianola and North Broadway. It's width was 100 feet, it traveled for one mile and did $2,500 in damage. Part of an outbreak of 24 tornados, which killed 4 and destroyed Cardington, Ohio, doing $25,000,000 in damage. This is the closest a tornado has come to Colonial Hills since records were kept in 1950.
GTI (Guilford Transportation Industries) purchases MEC
The Stealth Fighter F-117 takes its first flight.
"For Your Eyes Only" featuring Roger Moore as James Bond released in the United States.
McDonalds introduces Chicken McNuggets in select markets. Supply chain problems prevent national roll out until 1983.
USS Dallas SSN-700 commissioned.

The first IBM PC is released. It ran on a 4.77 MHz Intel 8088 microprocessor and came equipped with 16 kilobytes of memory, expandable to 256k. The PC came with one or two 160k floppy disk drives and an optional color monitor. The price tag started at $1,565
No one remained aboard a Boeing 720 that had arrived in Beirut, Lebanon, following a flight from Tripoli, Libya, when a large bomb exploded. The 5000 grams of dynamite destroyed the plane.
Edward Harrington Jennings appointed President of The Ohio State University
Illinois Terminal merged into Norfolk & Western.
D&S (Durham & Southern) absorbed into SBD
The Boeing 767 makes its first test flight.
The commercial launch of TGVs on the Paris-Lyon line, five days after the official inauguration by the President of the French Republic, François Mitterrand.
Internet protocol IPv4 is described in RFC 791 by DARPA.
Detroit & Toledo Shore Line merged into Grand Trunk Western.

A Boeing 737 was being unloaded at Cairo, Egypt, following a flight from Malta when a porter and three security guards were injured by bomb blasts. Two explosive devices hidden in parcels exploded about 15 minutes apart. A third bomb was located later but did not detonate. None of the passengers and crew were harmed.
USS La Jolla SSN-701 commissioned.
The strategic missile submarine SSBN 726 Ohio is commissioned.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 2nd flight. Mission STS-2.
Congregation Beth Tikvah moves from Clintonville to a new building on Olentangy River Road.

A Boeing 727 of the Nicaraguan airline Aeronica was about to board for a flight from Mexico City to San Salvador, El Salvador. As passengers were preparing to embark, a bomb hidden between the cabin wall and the furthest aft passenger seat on the left aisle exploded. The blast injured the captain, two stewardesses, and an airport mechanic. The plane was also seriously damaged with a 3 ft (0.9 m) hole torn in the fuselage.
USS Phoenix SSN-702 commissioned.
Construction of the American Electric Power building at 1 Riverside Plaza begins. 31 stories.
The Firstar Tower at 175 S. 3rd St. opens. 13 stories.
The Neil House is demolished at 41 S. High St. to make way for the 37 story Huntington Center.
Two Nationwide Plaza opens at 280 N. High St. 18 stories.
The Celeste Center opens.
Slate Run Metro Park and Slate Run Living Historical Farm opens.
OSU: Kottman Hall, 2021 Coffey Road, opens. School of Natural Resources, Department of Horticulture and Crop Science.
State Route 315 completed.
Public debt is $1,028.73 billions, economy goes into recession, massive deficit spending begins.
Liberty Elementary School opens.
Akron, Canton & Youngstown absorbed into Norfolk & Western.
Kentucky & Indiana Terminal absorbed into the Southern.
Ronald Reagan revives the B1 bomber program as the B1-B designed to carry cruise missiles. One hundred units are ordered.
USS Boston SSN-703 commissioned.
North American Rockwell gets an order to produce 100 B-1B Bombers.
"Late Night with David Letterman" premiers.
The Boeing 757 makes its first test flight.
USS Atlanta SSN-712 commissioned.
The aircraft carrier CVN 70 Carl Vinson is commissioned.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 3rd flight. Mission STS-3.
"Cagney & Lacey" premiers.
John Chancellor stepped down as anchor of the "The NBC Nightly News". Roger Mudd and Tom Brokaw assumed roles as coanchors.
Part of a ramp under construction collapsed during concrete pouring operations near the Indiana Harbor and Ship Canal, killing fourteen highway workers and injuring eighteen more.
Norfolk Southern Corporation created by Norfolk & Western and Southern.
The SOO Line gains control of Minneapolis, Northfield & Southen.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 4th flight. Mission STS-4.
Zimmer visit merely "a tour," according to PUCO chairman
The last Checker Cab rolls off the Checker Motors assembly line. Ineffecient and out of date, sales had fallen to 1,000 per year.
USS Baltimore SSN-704 commissioned.

A Boeing 747 of Pan Am was on a flight from Tokyo when a bomb hidden under a seat cushion detonated. The explosion killed a 16 year old passenger, tore a hole in the floor, and also damaged the cabin ceiling and overhead luggage bins. Despite the damage, the aircraft landed safely at Honolulu, Hawaii, with no further injuries.
The Commodore PET 2001 is discontinued by Commodore.
The Commodore 64 is introduced for $595 by Commodore.
The strategic missile submarine SSBN 727 Michigan is commissioned.
"Family Ties" premiers.
USS Houston SSN-713 commissioned.
"Knight Rider" premiers.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 1,000 and stays there.
Zimmer nuclear plant cost draws criticism from Greg Kostelac
Seaboard Coast Line gains control of Georgia.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 5th flight. Mission STS-5.
Last contact with Viking 1 on Mars.
The Union Pacific gains control of the Missouri Pacific and Western Pacific.
Louisville & Nashville absorbed into Seaboard Coast Line, name changed to Seaboard System controlled by CSX.
The Apple II Plus is discontinued by Apple.

Atari releases E.T. The Extraterrestrial video game. The author, Howard Warshaw, was given only five weeks to write the game and it flopped. This is marked as the beginning of a downward spiral in the video game market known as the 1983 Video Game Crash.
The CRAY-2 supercomputer is introduced. It is capable of 1.9 TFlops and uses a unique Fluorinert waterfall cooling system.
The former grounds of Buckeye Lake Amusement Park become an Ohio State Park.
Intel releases the 80286 microprocessor.
Marysville Honda Plant dedicated.
Woolco goes out of business.
OSU: Kinnear Road Center, 1099, 1121 & 1125 Kinnear Rd., acquired by the University from OCLC.
St. Michael's in Worthington builds a gymnasium addition.
USS City of Corpus Christi SSN-705 commissioned.
Richard F. Celeste inaugurated Governor of Ohio
"Fraggle Rock" premiers.
The Lisa is released for $9,995 by Apple.
"The A-Team" premiers.
The Apple IIe is released for $3,509 by Apple.
Ohio has the highest unemployment rate since the Great Depression, 14.2 percent.
Volcano, Kilauea, Hawaii: The most recent eruption begins, and lasts until the present day, making Kilauea one of the world's most active volcanos.
James Anthony Griffin appointed Bishop of the Columbus Diocese.
"M*A*S*H" last show - "Goodbye, Farewell and Amen"
Spratley foresees halt in customers' Zimmer funding
Radio Shack (Tandy) announces the Model 100 (Notebook), at a price of about $799.
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its maiden flight. Mission STS-6.
Western Maryland absorbed into the Baltimore & Ohio.
USS Albuquerque SSN-706 commissioned.
USS Norfolk SSN-714 commissioned.
"The Return of the Jedi" released.
Radio Shack (Tandy) announces the Model IV, at a price of about $1,999
"Octopussy" featuring Roger Moore as James Bond released in the United States.
The strategic missile submarine SSBN 728 Florida is commissioned.
First launch of a LGM-118 Peacekeeper Missile from Vandenburg Air Force Base in California.
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its 2nd flight. Mission STS-7.
GTI purchasis Boston & Maine.
Hurricane: Galveston and Houston, Tex.: Alicia caused 21 deaths and $2 ($3.4) billion in damages.

While boarding passengers at Rome for a flight to Damascus, Syria, a fire started aboard a Boeing 727. The fire was set off by a glass bottle containing flammable liquid that was placed under a seat near the right overwing emergency exit. The fire consumed the interior of the plane doing considerable damage, but no one was hurt.
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its 3rd flight. Mission STS-8.

Gulf Air 771 left Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, for Karachi, Pakistan, aboard a Boeing 737 carrying 117 people (111 passengers, 6 crew). The aircraft exploded shortly after takeoff and crashed in the desert near Mina Jebel Ali in the UAE. A bomb in the baggage compartment caused the fatal crash. The terrorist Abu Nidal took responsibility to convince nations in the region to pay him protection money and avoid future attacks. Both the UAE and Kuwait paid Nidal off shortly thereafter.
Zimmer cost may reach $3.5 billion
USS Portsmouth SSN-707 commissioned.
The last Lockheed L1011 takes its first flight. Only 250 were produced over its brief production lifespan.
"Never Say Never Again" featuring Sean Connery as James Bond released in the United States.
PUCO chairman Michael Del Bane predicts Zimmer audit
Woody Hayes dots the "I" at Ohio Stadium.
USS Buffalo SSN-715 commissioned.
Yes releases "90125"
Zimmer may raise Columbus residents' bills by 50%, Spratley claims

The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company, hoping to overcome objections of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said it would ask permission to switch prime contractors on its troubled Zimmer nuclear power plant. The utility said it would ask the commission if it could retain the Bechtel Power Company as constructor of the Zimmer plant, replacing the Henry J. Kaiser Construction Company of Oakland, Calif. Kaiser has been reported under investigation by the N.R.C. and all safety-related work was stopped more than a year ago at the plant, in Moscow, Ohio. Bechtel is the project director at Zimmer. A Kaiser spokesman, Harold Lauth, said the company had no comment about the switch, except to say that he had been expecting it.
The highest scoring game since the NFL merged with the AFL in 1970. Seattle defeats Kansas City 51-48.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 6th flight. Mission STS-9.
Judge Duncan orders The Ohio Penitentiary closed due to its poor condition.
American Electric Power moves its headquarters from New York City to a new Columbus 31 story building at 1 Riverside Plaza.
The American Electric Power building at 1 Riverside Plaza opens. 31 stories.
The Columbia Gas Building at 200 Civic Center Drive S. opens. 15 stories.
Trash burned for the first time at the Columbus Trash Burning Power Plant.
OSU: The Electroscience Lab, 1320 Kinnear Road, addition.
Showe Builders Inc. purchase the Old Worthington Inn, and after a $3.5 million renovation and expansion reopens it as the Worthington Inn.
AT&T's 22 owned Bell system companies divests into 8 companies.
Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe absorbs Texas, Pacific & Western.
Grand Trunk Western absorbs Detroit, Toledo & Ironton.
GTI gains control of the Delaware & Hudson.
Spratley calls for a halt to construction at Zimmer
C&SOE raps Spratley for his Zimmer stand

An Air France Boeing 747 was carrying 261 passengers and crew when an explosion rocked the aircraft shortly after leaving Karachi, Pakistan. The blast created a hole in the right aft cargo compartment causing rapid decompression. The pilots made an emergency descent and landing at the airport with no injuries.
Apple Computer's iconic 1984 advertisement for the Macintosh personal computer runs during the Super Bowl.
System 1 released by Apple.
The Macintosh 128K is released for $2,495 by Apple.
C&SOE blames Spratley for Zimmer delays
The Lisa 2 is released for $3,495 by Apple.

Work is halted on the Zimmer Nuclear Power Plant at Moscow, Ohio after expenditure of $1.7 billion and the plant is 97% complete. Another $3 billion is estimated for completing the remaining 3%. The decision is eventually made to convert the plant to coal.
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its 4th flight. Mission STS-41-B.
Astronauts Bruce McCandless II and Robert L. Stewart make the first untethered space walk.

The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company said it planned to proceed with conversion of the troubled Zimmer nuclear power plant to burn coal, although it acknowledged some doubt about the chances for success.
The strategic missile submarine SSBN 729 Georgia is commissioned.
Governments within Zimmer service area seek help of Mayor Rinehart and City Council in monitoring plant
Legislator Michael Schwarzwalder to seek Zimmer facts on conversion to coal-burning plant
Zimmer conversion costs sought by Ohio Consumers' Counsel William Spratley
Zimmer "whistleblower" Tom Applegate quizzed by U S Secret Service agents

A Douglas DC-8 was traveling from Brazzaville, Congo, to Paris. While the aircraft was parked on the apron during a stopover in N'Djamena, Chad, a small explosive device went off in the baggage compartment. The 23 people (18 passengers, 5 crew) aboard at the time were evacuated without injury. Twenty minutes later, a second bomb detonated in the central baggage hold destroying the aircraft.
USS Minneapolis-Saint Paul SSN-708 commissioned.
N.C. and S.C.: 22 tornadoes caused 57 deaths.
The Baltimore Colts are relocated to Indianapolis.
John Thompson became the first black coach to lead his team to the NCAA college basketball championship. Georgetown's Hoyas defeated Houston 84-75 in Seattle for the win.
Bob Bell retired as Bozo the Clown on WGN-TV in Chicago, IL. Bell was an institution in the Windy City since making his first appearance in 1960. Pinto Colvig was the original Bozo.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers used his patented 12-foot skyhook in the fourth quarter to become the all-time NBA regular season scoring leader this night. He broke the previous mark held by Wilt Chamberlain who had 31,419 points. Kareem broke the scoring record on a pass play from Magic Johnson and with three Utah Jazz players guarding him. The Lakers won, 129-115.
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its 5th flight. Mission 41-C.
United States researchers announce their discovery of the AIDS virus.
The Apple IIc is released for $1,295 by Apple.
The Apple III computer is discontinued by Apple.
Zimmer earnings draw fire from Consumers' Counsel William A Spratley
The Soviet Union announces it will boycott the Summer Olympics in Los Angelese.
USS Salt Lake City SSN-716 commissioned.
Final episode of One Day at a Time.
The Big Darby Creek is designated Scenic by the State of Ohio.
Zimmer troubles spark power plant legislation by Rep Michael A Fox
USS Hyman G. Rickover SSN-709 commissioned.
The Summer Olympics open in Los Angeles, California.
USS Providence SSN-719 commissioned.
The PKK officially calls for an uprising against Turkey.
John DeLorean is acquitted of all eight charges of possessing and distributing cocaine.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its maiden flight. Mission 41-D.
The last prisoners are moved from The Ohio Penitentiary.
Amtrak absorbs the Washington Terminal Co.
The Macintosh 512K is released for $2,795 by Apple.
Spratley challenges rate hike for CG&E, says it's for Zimmer debt
"The Cosby Show" premiers.
Panel: Owners must absorb Zimmer costs
Checks are on the way from Zimmer refund
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its 6th flight. Mission 41-G.
The strategic missile submarine SSBN 730 Henry M. Jackson is commissioned.
USS Chicago SSN-721 commissioned.
North American Rockwell's B-1B makes its first flight.
Prime Minister of India Indira Gandhi is assassinated by her two Sikh security guards in New Delhi.
DEC releases the VAX 8600, which had a CPU with an 80 ns cycle time (12.5 MHz) implemented with emitter coupled logic (ECL) macrocell arrays (MCAs). It replaces the VAX 11/780.
Ronald Reagan defeats Walter F. Mondale with 59% of the popular vote.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 2nd flight. Mission 51-A.
USS Olympia SSN-717 commissioned.

A methyl isocyanate leak from a Union Carbide pesticide plant in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, India, kills more than 8,000 people outright and injures over half a million (with more later dying from their injuries the death toll reaches 23,000+) in the worst industrial disaster in history.
USS Pittsburgh SSN-720 commissioned.
Worthington organizes local VFW with headquarters at Sharon Memorial Hall.
Riverside Methodist Hospital Elizabeth Blackwell Center opens, providing women's health services.
The  Hyatt on Capitol Square at Columbus City Center at 75 E. State St. opens. 22 stories.
The Capitol South Building at 65 E. State St. opens. 26 stories.
The Doubletree Hotel Guest Suites Columbus at 50 S. Front St. opens. 15 stories. Part of te Huntington Center.
Inniswoods Metro Park opens.
Mt. Carmel St. Ann's Hospital opens in Westerville.
Tide laundry detergent is made available in liquid form.
The Macintosh XL, a modified Lisa 2, is relead for $3,995 by Apple.
Alaska Railroad transferred from federal to state ownership.
USS Augusta SSN-710 commissioned.
Noon temperatures -19 degrees at Dayton, -15 degrees at Columbus and Cincinnati, -11 degrees at Toledo and Cleveland, combined with winds 20-30 mph gave wind chills to -80 degrees.

The LAB flight left La Paz, Mexico, for Santa Cruz, Bolivia. While en route with 127 occupants (120 passengers, 7 crew), a passenger entered the forward lavatory carrying a suitcase. Inside the suitcase was dynamite that exploded, killing the passenger. The Boeing 727 landed safely at Santa Cruz with no additional fatalities.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 3rd flight. Mission 51-C.
An electrical surge knocks out communcation with Salyut 7.

The Security and Exchange Commission shuts down ESM Government Securities, Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Home State Savings Bank of Cincinatti Ohio incurred $150 million in losses, and experienced $100 million in panic withdrawls as word spread.
Home State Bank is closed by Ohio Governor Richard Celeste because the Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund could not cover depositor losses.
A Lockheed L-1011 TriStar was on the ground at Dubai following a flight from Karachi, Pakistan, when a bomb exploded in one of the baggage holds. No one was harmed in the blast.

Ohio Governor Dick Celeste declared a three-day banking holiday for the 70 other savings institutions covered by the Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund. They were then told to remain closed until they obtained federal deposit insurance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation or Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, or until they merged. This is a seminal event in the Savings and Loan Crisis.

The long-awaited album, "We Are the World", was finally released. Eight rock stars donated previously unreleased material for the LP. Three-million copies of the award-winning single of the same name had already been sold. The song, "We Are the World", was number five, and moving up, on the "Billboard" magazine pop singleÕs chart this day.

The NCAA Rules Committee adopted the 45-second shot clock for menÕs basketball, to begin in the 1986 season. It was an effort to thwart the end-of-game stalls that kept opposing teams from scoring in close contests.
The famed Brown Derby restaurant in Hollywood closed on this day, after 57 years. All of the furnishings were kept, including famous Booth #5 -- where Clark Gable proposed to Carole Lombard.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 4th flight. Mission 51-D.
In England at Acorn Computer, the first samples of the ARM2 chip are received and work. This processor family will evolve into the Apple A series of processors.
The Macintosh XL is discontinued by Apple.
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its 7th flight. Mission 51-B.
System 2 released by Apple.
"A View To A Kill" featuring Roger Moore as James Bond released in the United States.
The strategic missile submarine SSBN 731 Alabama is commissioned.
27 tornadoes in Ohio and Pennsylvania resulted in 756 deaths. Estimated damages were $450 million. 11 dead in Trumbull County, one F5 tornado.
A Soyuz spacecraft manages to dock with the dead Salyut 7. When they entered the spacecraft, they found ice cold air and a frozen station.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 5th flight. Mission 51-G.

The deadliest terror attack prior to September 11, Air India 182 was a flight from Montreal to London to Delhi to Bombay. The Boeing 747 carried a total of 329 (307 passengers, 22 crew) when it disappeared over the Atlantic Ocean south of Ireland. A bomb located in the forward cargo hold had detonated at an altitude of 31,000 feet (9,500 m) causing rapid decompression and break-up of the plane. A second bomb was also to be transferred aboard another Air India flight but exploded at the Tokyo airport killing two baggage handlers. The attacks were blamed on a Sikh separatist group named Babbar Khalsa, but only one person was convicted on charges related to the attack after almost 20 years of investigation and prosecution by Canadian authorities.
The last episode of The Jeffersons airs.
USS Honolulu SSN-718 commissioned.
Gulf & Mississippi created by Illinois Central Gulf line sale.
USS Key West SSN-722 commissioned.
The Commodore Amiga is introduced for $1,295 by Commodore.
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its 8th flight. Mission 51-F.

PRR: Horseshoe Curve becomes the first section on Conrail to have its spikes replaced by Pandrol track clips. This was a success, and Pandrol track clips are installed on all Conrail curves of 2 degrees or sharper.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 6th flight. Mission 51-I.
PRR: Engine No. 1361, a K-4 class 4-6-2, is removed from static display at Horseshoe Curve for restoration by Altoona's Railroaders Memorial Museum. PRR GP-9 No. 7048 was installed in its place.
Steve Jobs is fired from Apple by the Board after clashing with John Sculley over pricing of Macintosh Office.
The Macintosh 128K is discontinued by Apple.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its maiden flight. Mission 51-J.
Hurricane: "Juan" struck La. and the Southeast. Though only a category 1 hurricane, it caused severe flooding and $1.5 ($2.4) billion in damages; 63 lives were lost.

Intel releases the 80386 DX. It supports clock frequencies of up to 33 MHz and can address up to 4 GB of memory and virtual memory of up to 64 TERABYTES! It also includes a bigger instruction set than the 80286. At the date of release the fastest version ran at 20 MHz and achieved 6.0 MIPs. It contained 275,000 transistors.
Hilliard sees smoother traffic flow ahead with the planned underpass for Cemetery Road.
A bomb hidden in a vinyl tote bag exploded aboard a Boeing 727. The blast occurred in the forward baggage hold while being unloaded and there were no fatalities.
The Space Shuttle CHALLENGER is launched on its 9th flight. Mission 61-A.
USS Oklahoma City SSN-723 commissioned.
Yes releases "9012Live: The Solos"
Zimmer cost plan hit by gubernatorial candidate Dennis Kucinich
Kucinich rejects Zimmer settlement plan in which builders absorb loss as "robbing" of consumers

About 20,000 people are feared dead after a volcanic eruption in northern Colombia. Four towns in the Andes region are reported to have been buried when ash spewed out of the volcano, Nevado del Ruiz, causing a mudslide.
Windows 1.0 released by Microsoft
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 2nd flight. Mission 61-B.
USS Louisville SSN-724 commissioned.
Chicago, Central & Pacific created by Illinois Central Gulf line sale.
The Columbus Citizen Journal prints its last edition.

A Boeing 727 preparing to land at Athens, Greece, was badly damaged by a bomb explosion. The device consisted of 1 lb of plastic explosive placed under a seat cushion. The detonation blew a 24 ft_ (2.25 m_) hole in the fuselage resulting in a rapid decompression of the cabin that sucked four people out to their deaths. Another five people suffered injuries but 110 passengers and crew survived and the plane landed safely. The bomb had been placed aboard during a previous flight by a Lebanese woman. Upon her arrest, the woman admitted that she worked for Abu Nidal and the attack was in retaliation for America's involvement in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process and skirmishes between the US and Libya.
Three people were killed and 229 injured when La Belle discothèque was bombed in the Friedenau district of West Berlin. by Libya.
The Macintosh 512K is discontinued by Apple.
The Macintosh 512Ke is released for $2,599 by Apple.
The United States bombs Libya. The raid is in retaliation for the West Berlin discotheque bombing. The raid kills 60 Libyans. Ghadaffi is warned by Italy's Prime Minister and escapes just in time.

Air Lanka UL512 left London with stops in Zrich, Switzerland, and Dubai before reaching Colombo, Sri Lanka. The Lockheed L-1011 was parked at the terminal preparing to continue on to the Maldives Islands when an explosive concealed in an onboard cargo crate exploded. The blast ripped the plane in half killing 21 and injuring 41 of the 128 passengers and crew. The bomb was most likely planted by Tamil rebels to sabotage peace talks between the Tamils and the Sri Lankan government.
Soyuz T-15 docks with the Salyut 7 Space Station 29 hours after leaving the MIR Space Station and traveling 4000 miles to reach it.

An Airbus A300 carryinh 239 people (223 passengers, 16 crew) was cruising at 33,000 ft (10,060 m) over Tosa Bay off the coast of Japan when an explosion occurred in the aft lavatory on the left of the cabin. The heavily damaged aircraft managed to land safely at Osaka with no fatalities. The cause of the blast was a hand grenade a passenger was attempting to smuggle into Japan that exploded in the lavatory.
USS San Juan SSN-751 commissioned.

North American Rockwell's Columbus plant is the main subassembly point for the B-1B Nacelle, Wing Carry Through, and Forward Intermediate Fuselage assembly. The plant is also the assembly plant for the OV-10 and MX Peacekeeper guidance section structure, as well as the Shuttle Aft bodyflap, crew module components, and windshield canopy assembly.

Woodrow "Woody" Hayes dies. In 33 years, his college teams won 238 games, suffered 72 defeats and 10 ties. He crafted two national championships, one in 1954 and the second in 1978. He held 13 Big Ten titles or co-titles and molded 58 All-American players.

Calling it the first launching of a television network in almost 40 years, the FOX Broadcasting Corporation, under the direction of media and publishing baron, Rupert Murdoch, started with two Sunday night offerings. OK. Who said one was "The Simpsons"?, "Married......With Children" and "The Tracey Ullman Show" were the beginnings of the FOX lineup.

Two spans of the I-90 Schoharie Creek Bridge in Amsterdam, NY fell into the flooded Schoharie Creek. Five vehicles plunged into the creek and 10 people died. The National Transportation Safety Board concluded that the bridge footings were vulnerable to scour, a form of deterioration around the base of the piers, and to a relatively shallow foundation. The I-90 collapse focused national attention on the vulnerability of bridges to failure from scour.

KAL 858 was a Boeing 707 departing Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, via Bangkok, Thailand, for Seoul, South Korea. The plane mysteriously vanished over the Andaman Sea near Thailand while carrying 115 people (104 passengers, 11 crew). South Korean officials claim that a pair of North Korean agents who disembarked from the aircraft at Abu Dhabi left a radio and a liquor bottle in the overhead luggage bin at row 7. Contained within the radio was C-4 while the liquor bottle held PLX explosives. The two agents were arrested shortly after the bombing but one committed suicide. The second claimed the attack had been ordered by Kim Jong-il, the current leader of North Korea, but firm evidence has remained elusive.

An EMBRAER EMB-110 crashed near Johannesburg, South Africa, killing all 17 aboard (15 passengers, 2 crew). The plane had been preparing to land when a nitroglycerine and ammonium nitrate bomb exploded. Pan Am 103 departed London bound for New York City when the Boeing 747 was destroyed over Lockerbie, Scotland. The plane was brought down by 340 to 450 grams of plastic explosives hidden in a radio cassette player that was detonated in the forward cargo hold. The bombing killed 270 people including 243 passengers, 16 crewmembers, and 11 residents of Lockerbie.

In China, reform politician Hu Yaobang suddenly died of a heart attack, setting off the events that would lead to the Tiananmen Square protest and massacre.
In the case of the ".22 Caliber Killers", 52-year-old Thaddeus Lewingdon dies of lung cancer.
A center turret explosion aboard the battleship USS Iowa kills 47 crewman and severely damages the gun.

In China, President Yang Shangkun and Premier Li Peng met with Deng at the latter's residence. Deng endorsed a hardline stance and said an appropriate 'warning' must be disseminated via mass media to curb further demonstrations.

In China, the party's official newspaper People's Daily issued a front-page editorial titled "It is necessary to take a clear-cut stand against disturbances." The language in the editorial effectively branded the student movement to be an anti-party, anti-government revolt. The article enraged students, who interpreted it as a direct indictment on the protests and its cause.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 4th flight. Mission STS-30.

In China, students began a hunger strike, two days before the highly publicized state visit by Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. Knowing that the welcoming ceremony for Gorbachev was scheduled to be held on the Square, student leaders wanted to use the hunger strike there to force the government into meeting their demands.

In China, the weight of taking decisive action fell on paramount leader Deng Xiaoping. Matters came to a head during a Politburo Standing Committee meeting at Deng's residence.[44] At the meeting, Zhao Ziyang's concessions-based strategy, which called for the retraction of the April 26 Editorial, was thoroughly criticized.[70] Li Peng, Yao Yilin and Deng asserted that by making a conciliatory speech to the Asian Development Bank on 4 May, Zhao exposed divisions within the top leadership and emboldened the students.[70][71][72] Deng warned that "there is no way to back down now without the situation spiraling out of control", and so "the decision is to move troops into Beijing to declare martial law"[73] as a show of the government's no-tolerance stance.
In China, Premier Li Peng hastily announced martial law in the early morning hours.

In China, the 38th Army, led by interim commander Zhang Meiyuan, began to advance from military office compounds in Shijingshan and Fentai District in western Beijing along the western extension of Chang'an Avenue toward the Square to the East.[48] This army, with 15,099 soldiers included tank and artillery units, encountered civilian protesters along Chang'an Avenue at Wukesong, Gongzhufen, Muxidi, Fuxingmen, Xidan, Liubukou and the Square itself. At about 10:00 p.m., the 38th Army opened fire on protesters at the Wukesong intersection on Chang'an Avenue, about 10 km west of Square. Around 3000 civilians died.

In China, the suppression of the protest was immortalized outside of China via video footage and photographs of a lone man standing in front of a column of tanks leaving Tiananmen Square via Chang'an Avenue. The "Tank Man", as it became known, became one of the most iconic photographs in the 20th century. As the tank driver tried to go around him, the "Tank Man" moved into the tank's path. He continued to stand defiantly in front of the tanks for some time, then climbed up onto the turret of the lead tank to speak to the soldiers inside. After returning to his position in front of the tanks, the man was pulled aside by a group of people.
In China, the Beijing Public Security Bureau released an order for the arrest of 21 students who they identified as leaders of the protest.

UTA 772 left Brazzaville, Congo, for Chad aboard a Douglas DC-10 carrying 171 people (156 passengers, 15 crew). About 45 minutes after takeoff, the plane broke up over the Sahara Desert and crashed in Niger following the explosion of a bomb in the forward cargo hold. Libya was blamed for the attack in retaliation for France's support of Chad during conflicts between the two African nations. Libya eventually admitted responsibility for the bombing and agreed to pay compensation to the families of the victims.

Avianca 203 was a Boeing 727 that took off from Bogot, Colombia, bound for Cali. Just five minutes into flight, a bomb on the floor of the starboard side of the passenger cabin at seat 15F detonated. The blast ignited vapors in an empty fuel tank causing a massive explosion that ripped the plane apart. The crash killed all 107 aboard (101 passengers, 6 crew) as well as 3 people on the ground. The Medelln drug cartel claimed responsibility for the attack as an attempt to kill presidential candidate Cesare Gaviria. Gaviria was not aboard but the group's chief assassin was later convicted for the bombing.

Volcano, Pinatubo, Phillipines:  A massive eruption ejects 10 km3 of material. The largest ash cloud is carried by upper level winds to the west and circled the globe in 22 days. The cloud spread laterally to cover a broad equatorial band from about 10degreesS to 20degreesN latitude and contaminated some of the world's busiest air traffic corridors.

The discontinuation of the catalogue and the shuttering of 113 stores were part of a larger revamp that cost the company 50,000 jobs.

In Russia, President Yeltsin dissolved the country's legislature. n response, the parliament declared the president's decision null and void, impeached Yeltsin and proclaimed vice president Aleksandr Rutskoy to be acting president.
In Russia, anti-reform demonstrators removed police cordons around the parliament and, urged by their leaders, took over the Mayor's offices and tried to storm the Ostankino television centre.

In Russia, the army stormed the Supreme Soviet building in the early morning hours of 4 October by Yeltsin's order, and arrested the leaders of the resistance. Offically, 187 were killed and 437 wounded.

Rwandan President Habyarimana and the Burundian President are killed when Habyarimana's plane is shot down near Kigali Airport. Hutu extremists, suspecting that the Rwandan president is finally about to implement the Arusha Peace Accords, are believed to be behind the attack. The killings begin that night.

The Rwandan Armed Forces (FAR) and Hutu militia (the interahamwe) set up roadblocks and go from house to house killing Tutsis and moderate Hutu politicians. Thousands die on the first day. Some U.N. camps shelter civilians, but most of the U.N. peackeeping forces (UNAMIR--United Nations Assistance Mission in Rwanda) stand by while the slaughter goes on. They are forbidden to intervene, as this would breach their "monitoring" mandate. On this day, ten Belgian soldiers with UNAMIR, assigned to guard the moderate Hutu Prime Minister, are tricked into giving up their weapons. They are tortured and murdered.

The Tutsi Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF) launches a major offensive to end the killings and rescue 600 of its troops surrounded in Kigali. The troops had been based in the city as part of the Arusha Accords.
The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 6th flight. Mission STS-59.

France and Belgium send troops to rescue their citizens. American civilians are also airlifted out. No Rwandans are rescued, not even Rwandans employed by Western governments in their embassies, consulates, etc.

At the Don Bosco school, protected by Belgian UNAMIR soldiers, the number of civilians seeking refuge reaches 2,000. That afternoon, the U.N. soldiers are ordered to withdraw to the airport. Most of the civilians they abandon are killed.
One week after the murder of the ten Belgian soldiers, Belgium withdraws from UNAMIR.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 3.75

The U.N. Security Council votes unanimously to withdraw most of the UNAMIR troops, cutting the force from 2,500 to 270. The International Red Cross estimates that tens, perhaps hundreds of thousands of Rwandans are now dead.
China Airlines Flight 140, an Airbus A300, crashes while landing at Nagoya, Japan, killing 264 people.

South Africa holds its first fully multiracial elections, marking the final end of the last vestiges of apartheid. Nelson Mandela wins the elections and is sworn in as the first democratic president the following month.

The U.N. Security Council passes a resolution condemning the killing, but omits the word "genocide." Had the term been used, the U.N. would have been legally obliged to act to "prevent and punish" the perpetrators. Tens of thousands of refugees flee into Tanzania, Burundi and Zaire. In one day, 250,000 Rwandans, mainly Hutus fleeing the advance of the Tutsi RPF, cross the border into Tanzania.

The Tutsi RPF forces capture Kigali. The Hutu government flees to Zaire, followed by a tide of refugees. The French end their mission and are replaced by Ethiopian U.N. troops. The RPF sets up an interim government of national unity in Kigali. Although disease and more killings claim additional lives in the refugee camps, the genocide is over. An estimated 800,000 Rwandans have been killed in 100 days.

The Bell Curve is published by Richard Herrnstein and Charles Murray. The main theses were, first, that changes in the economy over the course of the 20th century had made brains much more valuable in the job market; second, that from the 1950s onward, colleges had become much more efficient in finding cognitive talent wherever it was and shipping that talent off to the best colleges.

PAL434 was a multi-stage flight that first left Manila, Philippines, for Cebu aboard a Boeing 747. During the flight, a Middle Eastern passenger disappeared into the lavatory where he assembled the components of a small bomb. The device detonated four hours later, killing Ikegami and nearly tearing him in two while injuring ten others. The man responsible for building and placing the bomb was Ramzi Yousef who had also masterminded the World Trade Center bombing in 1993.

The dormant Soufriere Hills volcano erupts on the Caribbean island of Montserrat. The capital, Plymouth, is destroyed and tow-thirds of the island's population is forced to flee abroad. Another eruption in June, 1997 destroyed the W.H. Bramble airport and killed 19 people.

O. J. Simpson is found not guilty of double murder for the deaths of former wife Nicole Simpson and Ronald Goldman.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 18th flight. Mission STS-73.
Quebec independentists narrowly lose a referendum for a mandate to negotiate independence from Canada.
The last signal is received from NASA's Pioneer 11 spacecraft.
The Macintosh Color Classic is discontinued by Apple.
The Cleveland Browns announced their intention to move to Baltimore for the 1996 season.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 15th flight. Mission STS-74.
The Republican House led by Newt Gingrich shuts down the Federal Government. The American people are not amused.
A United Nations tribunal charges Radovan Karadžić and Ratko Mladić with genocide during the Bosnian War.
"Goldeneye" featuring Pierce Brosnan as James Bond released in the United States.
Bethlehem Steel closes its Bethlehem Pennsylvania plant after 140 years of operation, laying off 1800 workers.
The Dayton Agreement to end the Bosnian War is reached at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio (signed December 14).
HTML 2.0 was published
NASA's Galileo Probe enters Jupiter's atmosphere.
The aircraft carrier CVN 74 John C. Stennis is commissioned.
THE GROUND ROUND LOCATED AT 2690 E DUBLIN GRANVILLE RD HAS BEEN LOCKED DOWN, LEAVING TWO OTHERS OPEN; INSIDERS SAY THE COMPETITION FROM CHILI'S HASTENED THE CLOSING.
The Cleveland Browns play their last regular season game, losing 21-24 to the Jacksonville Jaguars. The franchise is moved to Baltimore the following year.
The Dayton Agreement is signed in Paris, officially ending the Bosnian War.
Fed Funds Rate down 1/4 to 5.50
The lowest ever United Kingdom temperature of −27.2 °C (−17.0 °F) is recorded at Altnaharra in the Scottish Highlands. This equals the record set at Braemar, Aberdeenshire in 1895 and 1982.
Netscape releases Javascript (formerly named Livescript) along with Netscape Navigator 3.0
OSU: Newman & Wolfrom Chemistry Lab, 100 W. 18th Ave., opens.
The CRAY T-90 is introduced, the last vector based supercomputer built by Cray, as parallelism took over the market.
Borden, Inc. is acquired by the investment firm of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts and Company. Over the next several years, dairy, packaging, food and other business operations were sold.
Federated (Lazarus) merges with Rich's and Goldsmith's and moves its headquarters to Atlanta.
Grant Medical Center and Riverside Methodist Hospital merge to become Grant/Riverside Methodist Hospitals.
Eddie George, Ohio State Back, wins the Heisman trophy.
OSU: Mendenhall Laboratory, 125 South Oval Mall, completely renovated.
Concourse "C" completed at Port Columbus International Airport.
Interstate 670 completed from I-71 to I-270 on Columbus' west side.
The first convoy of American combat troops arrives in Northern Bosnia to try to keep the peace between Bosnian Serbs and Muslims.
Hamas operative Yahya Ayyash is assassinated by an Israeli Shabak-planted, bomb-laden cell phone.

Eastern U.S.: heavy snow paralyzed the Appalachians, the mid-Atlantic, and the Northeast. 187 were killed in the blizzard and in the floods that resulted after a sudden warm-up. Damages reached $3 billion.
Serious fighting breaks out between Russian soldiers and rebel fighters in Chechnya.
The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 10th flight. Mission STS-72.

The North Cape oil spill occurs as an engine fire forces the tugboat Scandia ashore on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, Rhode Island. The North Cape Barge is pulled along with it and leaks 820,000 gallons of home heating oil.
France undertakes its last nuclear weapons test.
Java JDK 1.0 released.
Colombo Central Bank bombing: an explosives-filled truck rams into the gates of the Central Bank in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing at least 86 people and injuring 1,400.
Fed Funds Rate down 1/4 to 5.25

AT&T’s lays off 40,000 workers. The reductions were part of the telecom giant’s plan to split itself into three separate companies that would focus on communications services, telecommunications equipment, and computers.
The NFL approves the Cleveland Browns plan to move to Baltimore.

A Chinese Long March 3B rocket carrying Intelsat 708 destroys a nearby village at T+23 seconds, killing as many as 500 on the ground. The accident was caused by a short circuit of the guidance platform.
A Chicago-bound Amtrak train, the Capitol Limited, collides with a MARC commuter train bound for Washington, D.C., killing 11 people.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 19th flight. Mission STS-75.
Cuban fighter jets shoot down two American aircraft belonging to the Cuban exile group Brothers to the Rescue. Cuban officials assert that they invaded Cuban airspace.
I-270 NORTHERN OUTERBELT WILL GET AN EIGHTLANE HIGHWAY INSTEAD OF SIX LANES WHEN THE FREEWAY IS WIDENED IN A THREE-YEAR PROJECT TO BEGIN IN 1998.
The Bosnian government declares the end of the Siege of Sarajevo.
Silicon Graphics merges with Cray Computers.

Investor Sam Freshman, who owned and operated the Continent through much of its heyday, loses control of it when a partnership headed by the Bass family of Texas gets control of the mortgage on the Continent and several other Columbus properties and forecloses on the portfolio. It is all downhill for the Continent from here on out.

Dunblane massacre: Unemployed former shopkeeper Thomas Hamilton walks into the Dunblane Primary School in Scotland and opens fire, killing sixteen infant school pupils and one teacher before committing suicide.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 16th flight. Mission STS-76.
The International Monetary Fund approves a $10.2 billion loan to Russia for economic reform.
Baltimore's NFL franchise, formerly the Cleveland Browns, was officially renamed the Ravens after a Baltimore Sun telephone poll received a record number of calls supporting the name Ravens.
THE GROUND ROUND AT 5090 N HIGH STREET CLOSES AFTER A RUN SINCE THE 1970'S.
The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 11th flight. Mission STS-77.
John Declan Coffey is born in Columbus, OH
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 20th flight. Mission STS-78.
MAYOR LASHUTKA SETS THE CITY'S LIMIT; IS WILLING TO PAY $27 MILLION TO FINISH THE SPRING-SANDUSKY INTERCHANGE, WHICH IS HALF THE MONEY THE STATE IS DEMANDING.
COLUMBUS AUTO PARTS LAND REMAINS IN LIMBO OVER TAXES AND LIENS; THE OHIO HISTORICAL SOCIETY AND THE OHIO EXPOSITIONS COMMISSION ARE INTERESTED IN BUYING THE PROPERTY.
The strategic missile submarine SSBN 742 Wyoming is commissioned.
The Summer Olympics open in Atlanta, Georgia.
MORPC HAS PLANS FOR A "SINGLE-POINT URBAN INTERCHANGE" AT I-270 AND SAWMILL RD; IT'S EXPECTED TO SAVE MONEY BY USING LESS LAND AND SPEED TRAFFIC FLOW BY USING ONE LIGHT.
Apple cancels the Copeland O/S, intended to be a successor to System 7.
The Baltimore Ravens play their first regular season game, defeating the Oakland Raiders 19-14.
Hurricane: N.C. and Va.: Fran took 37 lives and caused more than $3.2 ($3.6) billion in damage.
The aircraft carrier CVN 75 Harry S. Truman is commissioned.
The American Society of Mechanical Engineers designated the propulsion system of the S.S. Badger  a mechanical engineering landmark.
The Union Pacific gains control of the Southern Pacific.
"Everybody Loves Raymond" premiers.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 17th flight. Mission STS-79.
U.S. President Bill Clinton signs the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty at the United Nations.
In Afghanistan, the Taliban capture the capital city of Kabul, after driving out President Burhanuddin Rabbani and executing former leader Mohammad Najibullah.
Yes releases "Keys to Ascension"
Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government is dismissed by President Farooq Leghari after widespread allegations of corruption.
The Mars Surveyor is launched towards Mars on a Delta II rocket.
Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 collides in mid-air with Kazakhstan Airlines Il-76 in New Delhi, India, resulting in the loss of 349 lives.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 21st flight. Mission STS-80.
An ice storm strikes the U.S., killing 26 directly and hundreds more from accidents. A powerful windstorm blasts Florida with winds gusts up to 90 mph.
Work begins on Javascript ECMAScript 1
The Mars Pathfinder lander is launched towards Mars on a Delta II rocket.
Tung Chee-hwa is appointed to become the new leader of Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese rule on July 1, 1997 at the end a 99-year lease to the United Kingdom.
The Houston Oilers play their last game in the Houston Astrodome before 15,000 fans.
"The Melting Pot" opens at 5090 N. High St. It is Columbus' first full service restaurant that emphasizes fondue.
Taliban forces retake the strategic Bagram Air Base, solidifying their buffer zone around Kabul.
Cub Foods closes its Cub Too grocery store in Graceland Shopping Center.
The Commodore Amiga is discontinued by Commodore.
The Columbus Lunatic Asylum is demolished to make way for the modern Ohio Department of Transportation buildings.
U.S. Health Corporation becomes OhioHealth, whose mission is "To improve the health of those we serve."
Clear Creek Metro Park opens. It is the largest park in the Metro Parks system.
OSU: The Galbreath Equine Center, 685 Tharp Street, opens. Part of the Veterinary Hospital complex.
Michael Crichton publishes "Airframe"
Howard Stern Radio Show premieres in Columbus OH on WBZX 99.7 FM.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 18th flight. Mission STS-81.
HTML 3.2 was published
A Delta II rocket carrying a military GPS payload explodes, shortly after liftoff from Cape Canaveral.
Yasser Arafat returns to Hebron after more than 30 years, and joins celebrations over the handover of the last Israeli-controlled West Bank city.
On their way to Lebanon, two Israeli troop-transport helicopters collide, killing 73.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 22nd flight. Mission STS-82.
Java JDK 1.1 released.
In Roslin, Scotland, scientists announce that an adult sheep named Dolly had been successfully cloned, and was born in July 1996.
Apple Newton: eMate 300 introduced for $799.
North Hollywood shootout: Two robbers wearing kevlar body armor armed with AK-47s containing armor-piercing bullets injure 17 police officers and civilians in a gun battle.
Rain begins over the Ohio River Valley that will total up to 10 inches in some areas over the next three days.
In Albania, after the collapse of pyramid investment schemes, civil unrest causes Prime Minister Aleksandër Meksi to resign,
In Albania, President Sali Berisha declared a state of emergency.
U.S. President Bill Clinton bans federal funding for any research on human cloning.
The Ohio River floods Cincinnati, flooding River Front Stadium and wiping Falmouth, KY on the Licking River off the map.
In Albania, all major population centers were engulfed in demonstrations and foreign countries began to evacuate their citizens.
The Comet Hale–Bopp makes its closest approach to Earth.
Apple Newton: Newton Message Pad 2000 introduced. It offers an improved 480 x 320 pixel display with 16 levels of grayscale.
In San Diego, 39 Heaven's Gate cultists commit mass suicide at their compound.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 5.50

In Albania, The Tragedy of Otranto took place when the Albanian ship Kateri i Radës sank in a collision with the Italian naval vessel Sibilla in the Strait of Otranto and at least 57 Albanians, aged 3 months to 69 years, lost their lives
Demolition of the Ohio Penitentiary begins. Replaced by the Columbus Blue Jackets arena. The actual cell blocks which housed Ohio's worst criminals for 150 years is now the site of a parking garage.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 22nd flight. Mission STS-83.
In Albania, a multinational peacekeeping force, led by Italy helps the Albanian government restore law and order during the Albanian Civil War.
The Red River of the North breaks through dikes and floods Grand Forks, North Dakota, and East Grand Forks, Minnesota, causing US$2 billion in damage.

In Albania, The Krrabë Event (Albanian: Ngjarja e Krrabës) was the theft of gold of the Albanian state treasury. The treasury, hidden in tunnels near Krrabë, consisted of 340 kilograms of gold, banknotes, and other items.
CUB FOODS PLANS TO SELL ITS REMAINING STORES TO KROGER.
IBM's Deep Blue defeats Garry Kasparov in the last game of the rematch, the first time a computer beats a chess World champion in a match.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 19th flight. Mission STS-84.
U.S. President Bill Clinton issues a formal apology to the surviving victims of the Tuskegee Study of Untreated Syphilis in the Negro Male and their families.
Central Tex.: multiple tornadoes, including one particularly strong twister that devastated the town of Jarrell, caused 29 deaths and an estimated $20 million in damage.
The 13-kilometer Confederation Bridge, the world's longest bridge spanning ice-covered waters, opens between Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick, Canada.
In Denver, Colorado, Timothy McVeigh is convicted on 15 counts of murder and conspiracy for his role in the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.
Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot orders the killing of his defense chief, Son Sen, and 11 of Sen's family members, before Pol Pot flees his northern stronghold.
A jury sentences Timothy McVeigh to death for his part in the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.
Bloomsbury Publishing publishes J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone in London.
Javascript ECMAScript 1 released.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 23rd flight. Mission STS-94.
The Mars Pathfinder lands successfully on Mars and deploys the Sojourner rover, the first rover deployed on another planet.

A Fokker 100 operated by the Brazilian airline TAM was en route from Sao Jos dos Campos to Congonhas carrying 60 people (55 passengers, 5 crew). The plane was climbing through 7,875 ft (2,400 m) after takeoff when a bomb exploded underneath seat 18D. The small bomb contained just seven ounces of explosive but the blast and decompression blew a 6.5 ft (2 m) hole in the fuselage. The passenger in seat 18E was pulled from the plane and died, but the remainder of the occupants survived after an emergency landing at So Paulo. A failed suicide attempt was blamed as the motive.

In London, scientists report their DNA analysis findings from a Neanderthal skeleton, which support the out of Africa theory of human evolution, placing an "African Eve" at 100,000 to 200,000 years ago.
Spree killer Andrew Cunanan shoots fashion designer Gianni Versace dead outside Versace's Miami residence.
The F. W. Woolworth Company closes after 117 years in business.
USS Seawolf SSN-21 commissioned.
OS 8 released by Apple.
Kansas City-based AMC, the nation's third-largest movie theater operator, opens a 5,000-seat theater complex at the Crosswoods development north of Worthington

The Asian Financial Crisis begins with the collapse of the Thai currency. Indonesia, South Korea and Thailand were most affected, although the Philipines, Malaysia and Hong Kong suffered as well. In Viet Nam, hardliners were able to use the crisis to slow reform and regain control for several years.
Tuttle Crossing Mall opens.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas complete a merger.
Jeanne Calment, the oldest person ever, dies at age 122 years 164 days in Arles, France.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 23rd flight. Mission STS-85.
In Albania, UN troops depart after stabilizing the country. The collapse of Albania and violence by gangs cost 2000 lives, 5000 wounded and did $200,000,000 in damage.
The last system deployed as part of the WSR-88D "NexRad" program was installed in North Webster, Indiana.
Diana, Princess of Wales is taken to a hospital after a car accident shortly after midnight, in the Pont de l'Alma road tunnel in Paris.
The Tennessee Titans play their first regular season game, defeating the Oakland Raiders 24-21.
The strategic missile submarine SSBN 743 Louisiana is commissioned.
The planet Uranus's moons Caliban and Sycorax are discovered in images obtained by the Hale 5-meter telescope at Palomar Observatory.
The funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, takes place at Westminster Abbey, watched by over two billion people worldwide.
Steve Jobs rejoins Apple as interim CEO after Apple buys Next Computers.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 20th flight. Mission STS-86.
Last contact from the Mars Pathfinder lander on Mars.

Loomis Fargo Bank Robbery: The second largest cash robbery in U.S. history ($17.3 million, mostly in small bills) occurs at the Charlotte, North Carolina office of Wells Fargo. An FBI investigation eventually results in 24 convictions and the recovery of approximately 95% of the stolen cash.

Andy Green sets the first supersonic land speed record for the ThrustSSC team, led by Richard Noble of the UK. ThrustSSC goes through the flying mile course at Black Rock Desert, Nevada at an average speed of 1,227.985 km/h (763.035 mph).
NASA launches the Cassini–Huygens probe to Saturn.
The first color photograph appears on the front page of The New York Times.
The Toyota Prius, the first hybrid vehicle to go into full production is unvieled in Japan.
The Cleveland Indians lose the World Series to the Florida Marlins, 3 games to 4.
Yes releases "Keys to Ascension 2"
Telecom companies WorldCom and MCI Communications announce a US$37 billion merger to form MCI WorldCom, the largest merger in U.S. history.
Ramzi Yousef is found guilty of masterminding the 1993 World Trade Center bombing.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 24th flight. Mission STS-87.
Yes releases "Open Your Eyes"

In Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, representatives from 121 countries sign a treaty prohibiting the manufacture and deployment of anti-personnel land mines. However, the United States, the People's Republic of China, Russia, South Korea and 32 other nations do not sign and/or ratify the treaty.
The Toyota Prius, the first hybrid vehicle to go into full production goes on sale in Japan.
The Mars Surveyor is inserted into orbit around Mars.
HTML 4.0 was published
"Tomorrow Never Dies" featuring Pierce Brosnan as James Bond released in the United States.
Intel releases the Pentium II microprocessor.

Lazarus signs a deal to renovate parts of the Downtown store to accommodate offices for the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency. Plans call for reducing store space athe four building complex considerably and converting it to leased offices.
The Adams Mark Hotel at 50 N. 3rd St. is reconstructed. 16 stories.
OSU: Three Jesse Owens Recreation Centers, 2151 Neil Ave., 75 W. 11th Ave., 1301 Carmack Rd., remodeled to enclose overhead doors.
John Richard Sisson (acting) appointed President of The Ohio State University
Russia begins to circulate new rubles to stem inflation and promote confidence.
The Lunar Prospector spacecraft is launched into orbit around the Moon, and later finds evidence for frozen water, in soil in permanently shadowed craters near the Moon's poles.
Ramzi Yousef is sentenced to life in prison for planning the first World Trade Center bombing in 1993.
The Drudge Report breaks the story about U.S. President Bill Clinton's alleged affair with Monica Lewinsky, which would lead to the House of Representatives' impeachment of him.
The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 12th flight. Mission STS-89.
"Unabomber" Ted Kaczynski pleads guilty in the United States, and accepts a sentence of life without the possibility of parole.
President Clinton denies allegations he had an affair with 24-year-old intern Monica Lewinsky and rejects accusations he asked her to lie on oath.
DEC is acquired by Compaq.
Cavalese cable car disaster: a United States military pilot causes the deaths of 20 people near Trento, Italy, when his low-flying EA-6B Prowler severs the cable of a cable-car.
The 1998 Winter Olympics are held in Nagano, Japan.
Borden sells Columbus Coated Fabrics and its 450 employees to a Bethesda, Md.-based buyout and specialty finance company.
Apple Newton: Production officially ends.
A massacre in Likoshane, FR Yugoslavia starts the Kosovo War.
The struggling Continent is sold by the Bass family to Dallas based Benton Co. for $21 million.
Titanic becomes the first film to gross US$1 billion.
Data sent from the Galileo probe indicates that Jupiter's moon Europa has a liquid ocean under a thick crust of ice.
NASA announces that the Clementine probe orbiting the Moon has found enough water in polar craters to support a human colony and rocket fueling station.
Apple Newton: eMate 300 discontinued.
The High-Z Supernova Search Team becomes the first team to publish evidence that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate.
George and Kelly Campbell close on 554 Kenbrook Drive.
In Japan, the Akashi Kaikyō Bridge linking Shikoku with Honshū and costing about US$3.8 billion, opens to traffic, becoming the largest suspension bridge in the world.

Good Friday Agreement: 1 hour after the end of the talks deadline, the Belfast Agreement is signed between the Irish and British governments and most Northern Ireland political parties, with the notable exception of the Democratic Unionist Party.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 25th flight. Mission STS-90.
Jay Jordan is named CEO of OCLC.
Henry Campbell is born in Houston, TX
India conducts three underground nuclear tests in Pokhran, including one thermonuclear device.
The first euro coins are minted in Pessac, France. Because the final specifications for the coins were not finished in 1998, they will have to be melted and minted again in 1999.
The Galaxy IV communications satellite fails, leaving 80–90% of the world's pagers without service.

Suharto (elected 1967) resigns, after 32 years as President of Indonesia and his 7th consecutive re-election by the Indonesian Parliament (MPR). Suharto's hand-picked Vice President, B. J. Habibie, becomes Indonesia's third president.
Pakistan conducts its first nuclear weapons test.
European Central Bank established, replacing the European Monetary Institute.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 24th flight. Mission STS-91.
Eschede train disaster: an Intercity-Express high-speed train derails between Hanover and Hamburg, Germany, causing 101 deaths.
Windows 98 released by Microsoft
Kuala Lumpur International Airport officially opened, becoming the new international gateway into Malaysia.
Javascript ECMAScript 2 released.
William English Kirwan appointed President of The Ohio State University
Japan launches a probe to Mars, joining the United States and Russia as an outer space-exploring nation.
Sydney water crisis involved the suspected contamination by the microscopic pathogens cryptosporidium and giardia of the water supply system of Greater Metropolitan Sydney.

U.S. embassy bombings: the bombings of the United States embassies in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and Nairobi, Kenya, kill 224 people and injure over 4,500; they are linked to terrorist Osama bin Laden, an exile of Saudi Arabia.

On it's maiden flight, the Delta III rocket explodes when software adapted from the Delta II caused a guidance failure during first-stage flight. The failure and subsequent vehicle motion depleted the hydraulic fluid used for steering.
A McDonnell Douglas MD-11 airliner (Swissair Flight 111) crashes near Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia, after taking off from New York City en route to Geneva; all 229 people on board are killed.
Benjamin Coffey is born in Columbus, OH
Google, Inc. is founded in Menlo Park, California, by Stanford University PhD candidates Larry Page and Sergey Brin.
St. Louis Cardinals first baseman Mark McGwire hits his 62nd home run of the season, thus breaking the single season record of 61 which had been held by Roger Maris since 1961.
George Wallace dies at the age of 79 in Montgomery, Alabama.

Iranian President Mohammad Khatami retracts a fatwa against Satanic Verses author Salman Rushdie that was in force since 1989 stating that the Iranian government will "neither support nor hinder assassination operations on Rushdie".

Office towers swayed in Columbus, and a statue of Beatle John Lennon briefly gyrated at ClevelandÕs Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum shortly before 4 p.m., as shocks from an earthquake rolled across the state.
Fed Funds Rate down 1/4 to 5.25
Europol is established when the Europol Convention signed by all of its member states comes into force.

Indictment and arrest of Augusto Pinochet: General Augusto Pinochet, Chilean dictator from 1973 to 1990, is indicted for human rights violations he committed in Chile by Spanish magistrate Baltasar Garzón. 6 days later British police place him under house arrest during his medical treatment in the UK.
Fed Funds Rate down 1/4 to 5.00
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 25th flight. Mission STS-95.
Hurricane Mitch makes landfall in Central America, killing an estimated 11,000 people.

Voters defeat proposition 39, a plan to connect Morse and Bethel Roads by demolishing 40 homes south of Graceland Shopping Center. The pro-39 issue is almost entirely funded by automobile dealerships on Morse Road.
Fed Funds Rate down 1/4 to 4.75
Voyager 1 overtakes Pioneer 10 as the most distant man-made object from the Solar System, at a distance of 69.419 AU (1.03849×1010 km).
A Russian Proton rocket is launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, carrying the first segment of the International Space Station, the 21-ton Zarya Module.
George and Kelly fly to Phoenix and drive a rental car to Winslow. They stay at Mom and Dad's house there and meet John, Vicki and baby Henry as well.
Mom and Dad Campbell, George and Kelly, and John, Vicki and baby Henry drive from Winslow to the El Tovar lodge at the rim of the Grand Canyon.
We drive from the Grand Canyon back to Winslow.
George and Kelly drive from Winslow to Phoenix and fly back to Columbus.

The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 13th flight. Mission STS-88. It carries the first American component to the International Space Station, the 25,600 pounds (11,600 kg) Unity module on STS-88. It docks with Zarya two days later.
Hugo Chávez, politician and former member of the Venezuelan military, is elected President of Venezuela.
Java J2SE 1.2 released.
USS Connecticut SSN-22 commissioned.
The Yugoslav Army ambushes a column of 140 Kosovo Liberation Army militants attempting to smuggle arms from Albania into Kosovo, killing 36.
U.S., U.K. launch "Operation Desert Fox" bombing campaign to destroy suspected Iraqi nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs.
The U.S. House of Representatives forwards articles of impeachment against President Clinton to the Senate, making him the second president to be impeached in the nation.
Khmer Rouge leaders apologize for the post-Vietnam War genocide in Cambodia that killed more than one million people in the 1970s.
Nancy F. Hollistor inaugurated Governor of Ohio (interim for 11 days)
In the Eurozone, the currency rates of this day are fixed permanently.
Downtown Columbus Lazarus floor space reduced from 933,000 square feet to 300,000 square feet.
The 34 Story, 570,000-square-foot East Broad Street, Borden Office Tower is sold to Trizac Hahn for $47.85 million.
The Fifth Third Center at 21 E. State St. opens. Fifth Third Center is a new construction tower added to the 1928 landmark Beggs Building, designed by Miller & Reeves.
The Greater Columbus Convention Center is expanded.
The Godman Guild sells a scenic easement for Camp Mary Orton to Franklin County Metro Parks. The easement will allow Metro Parks to preserve the land in its natural state.
OSU: Fisher Hall, 2100 Neil Ave., opens. Houses the College of Business.
OSU: Gerlach Hall, 2108 Neil Ave., opens. Part of the Fisher College of Business.
A white oak in Dysart Woods near Athens, Ohio, is felled by a storm. It is found to be 373 years old, making it the oldest known tree east of the Mississippi. Its seed germinated in 1625!
Pickerington's population reaches 8,000
Public debt of U.S. reaches $5.6 trillions.
a $1.6 million screetscape project is completed in downtown Worthington.
City Council votes to spend $20,000 to purchase Alfred Tibor's "First Flight", Worthington's first piece of city-owned public art.
Old Worthington Library renovations completed.
The euro currency is established and the European Central Bank assumes its full powers.
All non computer businesses are spun off from Hewlett Packard into Agilent Technologies.
A major snowstorm buries Kenbrook Drive.
The Mars Polar Lander is launched by NASA.
Robert A. Taft II inaugurated Governor of Ohio
AEP issues a contract to demolish Big Muskie.
Tenn. and Ark.: a series of tornadoes left 17 dead. Damages were estimated at $1.3 billion.
The China News Service announces new government restrictions on Internet use aimed especially at Internet cafés.
Unarmed Guinean immigrant Amadou Diallo is shot dead by New York City police officers on an unrelated stake-out, sparking outrage in the city.
King Hussein of Jordan dies from cancer, and his son Abdullah II inherits the throne.
Pluto moves along its eccentric orbit further from the Sun than Neptune.
Moderate Iraqi Shiite cleric Mohammad Mohammad Sadeq al-Sadr is assassinated.

The Franklin County commissioners sign off on the name Bill Moose Run for a small North Side stream that flows into the Olentangy River near Graceland Shopping Center. Bill Moose, who died in 1937 at the age of 100, was the last full blooded Wyandotte Indian in Ohio.
While trying to circumnavigate the world in a hot air balloon, Colin Prescot and Andy Elson set a new endurance record after being aloft for 233 hours and 55 minutes.

In a military court, United States Marine Corps Captain Richard J. Ashby is acquitted of the charge of reckless flying which resulted in the deaths of 20 skiers in the Italian Alps, when his low-flying EA-6B Prowler hit a gondola cable.
A fire in the Mont Blanc Tunnel kills 39 people, closing the tunnel for nearly three years.
NATO launches air strikes against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, marking the first time NATO has attacked a sovereign state.
Enron energy traders allegedly route 2,900 megawatts of electricity destined for California to the town of Silver Peak, Nevada, population 200.
The Melissa worm attacks the Internet.
Kosovo War: A U.S. F-117 Nighthawk is shot down by Yugoslav forces.
"Futurama" premiers.
For the first time, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above the 10,000 mark, at 10,006.78.
Benchmark Development purchases the former Columbus Auto Parts site at Hudson St. & I-71 for $1.4 million.
The Dallas based Benton Co., owner of the Continent, is unable to raise financing to revitalize the property. Amresco, Benton Co.'s financier, takes the property back.
Nunavut, an Inuit homeland, is created from the eastern portion of the Northwest Territories to become Canada's third territory.
Two Libyans suspected of bringing down Pan Am Flight 103 in 1988 are handed over to Scottish authorities for eventual trial in the Netherlands. The United Nations suspends sanctions against Libya.
In Laramie, Wyoming, Russell Henderson pleads guilty to kidnapping and felony murder, in order to avoid a possible death penalty conviction for the apparent hate crime killing of Matthew Shepard.
Bill Gates's personal fortune makes him the wealthiest individual in the world due to the increased value of Microsoft stock.
Columbine High School massacre: Two Littleton, Colorado, teenagers, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, open fire on their teachers and classmates, killing 12 students and 1 teacher, and then themselves.
SpongeBob SquarePants premiers on Nickelodeon.

Okla. and Kans.: unusually large twister, thought to have been a mile wide at times, killed 44 people and injured at least 748 others in Okla. A separate tornado killed another 5 and injured about 150 in Kans. Damages totaled at least $1 billion.

The second launch of a Delta III, carrying the Orion 3 satellite (Hughes HS601 model), ended in failure. The second stage engine experienced a pressure anomaly and rupture, and shut down while its second burn was underway, leaving the payload in a useless orbit.
Kosovo War: in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, three Chinese embassy workers are killed and twenty others wounded when a NATO B-2 aircraft bombs the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.
Explosive charges are used to demolish Big Muskie.
The first Welsh Assembly in over 600 years opens in Cardiff.
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 26th flight. Mission STS-96.
The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in The Hague, Netherlands indicts Slobodan Milošević and four others for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Kosovo.
Two Swedish police officers are wounded by bank robbers armed with automatic firearms, and later executed with their own service pistols in Malexander, Sweden.
Napster, a music downloading service, debuts.
The King of Bhutan allows television transmissions to commence in the Kingdom for the first time, coinciding with the King's Silver Jubilee.
Kosovo War: NATO suspends its air strikes after Slobodan Milošević agrees to withdraw Yugoslav forces from Kosovo.
Texas Governor George W. Bush announces he will seek the Republican Party's nomination for President of the United States.
