Easton Town Center opens
Joshua Coffey is born in Columbus, OH
In Rome, Hicham El Guerrouj runs the fastest mile ever recorded, at 3:43.13.

Accor SA, the French-based owner of the Motel 6 chain, has left the light on for Hillard-based Red Roof Inns Inc. Accor acquires the Hilliard-based economy lodging chain for $1.12 billion in cash and assumed debt.
Microsoft becomes the first company to have a market capitalization exceeding five hundred billion dollars.
Off the coast of Martha's Vineyard, a plane crashes piloted by John F. Kennedy Jr., killing him, his wife Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy, and her sister Lauren Bessette.
Mercury program: Liberty Bell 7 – piloted by Gus Grissom in 1961 – is raised from the Atlantic Ocean.
Falun Gong is banned in the People's Republic of China under Jiang Zemin.

Demolition of the Columbus Auto Parts factory on Hudson Ave. and I-71 begins. A Lowes, Aldi and Big Boy will be built there.
Hundreds of Chechen guerrillas invade the Russian republic of Dagestan, triggering a short war.
Vladimir Putin is appointed Prime Minister of Russia, serving President Boris Yeltsin.
In Belgrade, tens of thousands of Yugoslavs rally to demand the resignation of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milošević.

OSU: Mason Hall, 250 W. Woodruff Ave., opens. Houses the Business Library.
The first of a series of Russian apartment bombings occurs. Subsequent bombings occur on September 13 and 16, while a bombing on September 22 fails.
The newly reformed Cleveland Browns play their first regular season game, losing 43-0 to the Steelers.

Hurricane: Bahamas to New England: Floyd and associated flooding caused at least 57 deaths including one in the Bahamas. Hardest-hit N.C. suffered 36 Floyd related deaths. Damage estimated at $4.5 ($4.6) billion.

An affiliate of Preferred Real Estate Investments Inc. of Conshohocken, Pa., pays $1.5 million for the 11.64-acre former Jeffrey Mining Manufacturing Company site.

Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif attempts to dismiss Army Chief General Pervez Musharraf, who is out of the country. The generals lead a coup d'état, ousting Sharif's administration, and Musharraf takes control of the government.
OS 9 released by Apple.
The Albert Einstein mosaic is dedicated at the new COSI located in the renovated Central High School on West Broad Street.
NASA loses one of its probes, the Mars Climate Orbiter.
Australians defeat a referendum proposing the replacement of the Queen and the Governor General with a President to make Australia a republic.

The ExxonMobil merger is completed, forming the largest corporation in the world.
A permanent 0.25 percent sales tax approved for COTA, its first permanent funding source.
Michael Crichton publishes "Timeline"
NASA lost radio contact with the Mars Polar Lander, moments before the spacecraft entered the Martian atmosphere.
NASA launched the Terra platform into orbit, carrying 5 Earth Observation instruments, including ASTER, CERES, MISR, MODIS and MOPITT.

Sony Pictures Animation releases Stuart Little. $300,135,367
The sovereignty of Macau is transferred from the Portuguese Republic to the People's Republic of China after 442 years of Portuguese settlement.
Northern and western Europe: two back-to-back hurricane-force storms left 97 people dead. Winds reaching 120 mph uprooted trees, disrupted transportation, and left millions of homes without power.
The Seattle Seahawks play their last game in the Seattle King Dome.
The U.S. turned over complete administration of the Panama Canal to the Panamanian Government, as stipulated in the Torrijos–Carter Treaties of 1977.
Boris Yeltsin resigned as President of Russia, leaving Prime Minister Vladimir Putin as the acting President.
Boris Yeltsin unexpectedly resigns as President of Russia. Vladimir Putin becomes the acting President.

Riverside Methodist Hospital ranked fifth in the country for the most patient admissions.

OSU: McPherson Laboratory of Chemistry, 140 W. 18th Ave., gutted and remodeled.

After a wildly successful run 8 year run, The Columbus Chill play their last game in Columbus. In a perfect blend of showmanship and gamesmanship the Chill earned the division crown by defeating the Dayton Bombers 5-0. In the franchise's 191st and final sellout, Chill fans did not go home disappointed.
America Online announces an agreement to purchase Time Warner for $162 billion (the largest-ever corporate merger).
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes at 11,722.98 (at the peak of the Dot-com bubble).

First Launch of an Atlas IIIB rocket featuring a Russian RD-180 Engine

Mom and Dad Campbell from NJ, and John, Vicki and Henry Campbell from TX, visit George and Kelly.
The sinking of the nuclear-powered Oscar-class submarine Kursk took place during the first major Russian naval exercise in more than ten years, in the Barents Sea, killing all 118 personnel on board.

The third and final flight of a Delta III launched a 4,348 kg (9,586 lb) satellite simulator into a 180.76 × 20,694 km orbit. While the apogee was 2,710 km lower than the targeted 185 × 23,404 km, and somewhat a partial failure, it was within the allowable 3,000 km margin of error and demonstrated the propellant depletion shutdown capability of the DCSS, modified versions of which would become the second stage of the Delta IV.
The Kahiki restaurant closes. The East Broad Street building, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places, is torn down and replaced with a Walgreens Drug Store.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 22nd flight. Mission STS-106.
Nationwide Arena's first event, the Soul to Soul" Tour featuring Tim McGraw and Faith Hill.
The Summer Olympics open in Sydney, Australia.
The Columbus Blue Jackets play the Detroit Red Wings in their first exhibition game in Nationwide Arena.
The Columbus Blue Jackets play the Chicago Blackhawks in their first regular season game in Nationwide Arena.

The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 15th flight. Mission STS-97.
Prairie Oaks Metro Park opens.
High speed rail - Amtrak's Acela Express makes it inaugural revenue run.
Mary Campbell is born in Houston, TX
Kelly has an ultrasound of baby Alex.
Intel releases the Pentium IV microprocessor.

The Miranova Condominiums at 1 Miranova Place opens. 26 stories. Almost all the building's windows face north, looking up the Scioto River towards downtown. Tallest residential building in the state of Ohio.
A $92 million parking garage addition completed at Port Columbus International Airport.
IntelliJ Idea 1 released.

Easton restaurants "Planet Hollywood" and the "All-Star Cafe" close.
Apple introduces the Titanium PowerBook G4 line, nicknamed TiBooks. With a 15" display, they have 500MHz CPU's.
George Walker Bush inaugurated as President.

OS X 10.0 Cheetah released by Apple.
The Mars Odyssey orbitor was launched towards Mars on a Delta II rocket.

The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 16th flight. Mission STS-100.

Timken closes its Columbus railroad bearing manufacturing plant, throwing 219 employees out of work. The Canton-based steel maker said production of tapered roller bearings now made at the Columbus plant will be moved to other Timken facilities within the next 12 months.

The Canon Powershot A10 1.6 MP, 6x optical zoom camera is released.

571 Kenbrook is sold to Chris and Amy Hunter for $142,000

Hurricane: Gulf Coast to southern New England: tropical storm Allison caused severe flooding, especially around Houston, where 20,000 residents were evacuated from their homes. Damage estimated at $5 billion (actual cost); 41 deaths.

Chrysler assembles the last Plymouth branded car, a neon. The Plymouth brand is retired.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 24th flight. Mission STS-104.
Columbus Coated Fabrics shuts down, locks out its employees and refuses to pay their last paycheck or severance. Over 450 out of work since Borden sold CCF in 1998.
Alexander Joseph Campbell born at 3:00 am at Riverside Methodist Hospital in Columbus, Ohio.

Borden Foods, an affiliate of Borden Inc., closes its Columbus headquarters and Polaris research-and-development facility by the end of the year, closing the doors on what a year ago had been a work force of about 300 employees.

At the behest of Osama Bin Laden, Muslim militants attack and destroy the World Trade Center Towers and damage The Pentagon by flying hijacked airliners into them. Another hijacked plane, possibly headed for the Capitol Building, crashes in Pennsylvania when the passengers fight to take the plane back. Over 3,000 Americans are murdered.

An overall economic slowdown and the 9/11 terrorist attacks slammed air travel and prompted Boeing to lay off 31,000 workers.

A drunken Daniel Lewis punctures the Trans-Alaska Pipeline with a bullet from a high powered hunting rifle. Nearly 300,000 gallons of oil spray out of the hole and the pipeline is shut down for 2 days for repairs. The pipline supplies 15% of America's daily oil needs. Lewis, who has an extensive criminal history, was sentenced to 16 years in prison plus 10 years for Federal firearms violations.
Bethlehem Steel files for bankruptcy.
The Mars Odyssey orbiter is inserted into orbit around Mars.
Windows XP released by Microsoft
George and Alex visit Kelly at Sarcom.
Fed Funds Rate down 1/2 to 2.00
543 Loveman (the white house behind Gertie's) is sold to Paul Mielke for $107,000.
The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 17th flight. Mission STS-108.
Fed Funds Rate down 1/4 to 1.75
Linux 2.5.1 released.

Shortly after the September 11 attacks, a terrorist named Richard Reid boarded a Boeing 767 headed from Paris to Miami. As the plane flew across the Atlantic Ocean, Reid attempted to detonate a bomb that he had carried aboard in his shoes. His shoes were later found to contain 100 grams of plasticized TATP and PETN explosives strong enough to blow a large hole in the fuselage that most likely would have doomed the aircraft. A flight attendant first noticed Reid's actions and tried to stop him, but a group of flight attendants and passengers was ultimately needed to subdue the suicide bomber. The flight diverted to Boston where Reid was arrested, and he has since been sentenced to life in prison.
Intel releases the Itanium microprocessor. First 64 bit Intel processor.
The Anheuser-Busch brewery is modernized, increasing its capacity from 6.4 to 9.8 million barrels per year.
Columbus Community Hospital (formerly Mercy Hospital), 1430 South High Street, closes.
A direct connection was added from the Ohio Turnpike to Interstate 77 at the Cleveland Interchange (173).
The Detroit Lions play their final game at the Pontiac Silverdome.
After 26 years of operation in greater Columbus, Rite Aid Corp. sells nine Central Ohio Rite Aid retail stores and the prescription files from 11 others to Woonsocket, R.I.-based CVS Corp.
The Limited Inc. and Intimate Brands Inc. announced Tuesday that it will close all of its stores at the Northland Mall location on Morse Road due to the steady decrease in business.

President George Bush's State of the Union address labels Iraq part of the "axis of evil," and vows that the U.S. Òwill not permit the world's most dangerous regimes to threaten us with the world's most destructive weapons.Ó
In his State of the Union address, President Bush declares Iraq, Iran and North Korea and their terrorist allies constitute an "axis of evil" that threatens world peace.
Ford eliminates 35,000 jobs in conjunction with the phasing out of its Ford Escort, Mercury Cougar compact car, Mercury Villager minivan, and the Lincoln Continental.
Java J2SE 1.4 released.
6.3 MP EOS D60 released
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 27th flight. Mission STS-109.

The Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. begins illuminating the "Budweiser" and "Bud Light" signs recently installed on two grain towers at its Columbus brewery. The neon signs, easily visible from Interstate 71 and I-270, will be turned on permanently.
Hewlett Packard acquires Compaq, which has struggled since acquiring Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC).
Alex goes to his first Home and Garden Show at the State Fairgrounds.
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 25th flight. Mission STS-110.
Mom and Dad Campbell and Mom and Dad Foley pose for a photograph with baby Alex.

President Bush publicly introduces the new defense doctrine of preemption in a speech at West Point. In some instances, the president asserts, the U.S. must strike first against another state to prevent a potential threat from growing into an actual one: ÒOur security will require all AmericansÉ[to] be ready for preemptive action when necessary to defend our liberty and to defend our lives.Ó
The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 18th flight. Mission STS-111.
George, Kelly and Alex visit GG's house.
The Columbus Dispatch is redesigned to fit on the new industry standard 50 inch web.

St. Mary of the Springs Mother House (16 stories) at 2320 Airport Drive is torn down. Originally designed to house young women entering the order and attending Ohio Dominican College, the building now is home to 67 sisters whose average age is 79. It will be replaced with a new, three story $18 million residence building.
OS X 10.2 Jaguar released by Apple.
The Houston Texans play their first regular season game, defeating the Dallas Cowboys 19-10.

President Bush addresses the UN, challenging the organization to swiftly enforce its own resolutions against Iraq. If not, Bush contends, the U.S. will have no choice but to act on its own against Iraq.
11.1 MP EOS 1Ds released
The Space Shuttle ATLANTIS is launched on its 26th flight. Mission STS-112.
Congress authorizes an attack on Iraq.

One day after celebrating its 100th anniversary at the Parsons Avenue site, Buckeye Steel Castings runs out of cash and shuts down, sending 700 workers out the door. About 40 workers volunteer to work for free to shut down the furnaces in an orderly fashion to prevent damage to the facility. Buckeye subsequently defaults on the worker's final paychecks, although executives are pay $192,000 in bonuses after the bankruptcy sale.
Northland Mall closes.
545 Kenbrook is sold to John Milling for $125,000
Fed Funds Rate down 1/2 to 1.25
The UN Security Council unanimously approves resolution 1441 imposing tough new arms inspections on Iraq.
Central and southeast U.S.: series of more than 70 tornadoes across 9 states from Miss. to Pa. killed 36 people.
UN weapons inspectors return to Iraq for the first time in almost four years.
"Die Another Day" featuring Pierce Brosnan as James Bond released in the United States.
The Space Shuttle ENDEAVOUR is launched on its 19th flight. Mission STS-113.
Michael Crichton publishes "Prey"
President Bush approves the deployment of U.S. troops to the Gulf region.
North Korea evicts nuclear inspectors, removes monitoring equipment and begins reprocessing 8000 fuel rods into nuclear warheads.

An equity sponsor group, comprised of Texas Pacific Group, Bain Capital and Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, purchases Burger King for $1.5 billion. This is the first time the company has been privately held since 1967.
Apple introduces the Aluminum PowerBook G4 line, nicknamed AlBooks. With 12", 15" and 17" display options, they have 867MHz CPU's.
Columbus City Council approves the purchase of the vacant Northland Mall for $7.5 million.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA is launched on its 28th flight. Mission STS-107.
In his State of the Union address, President Bush announces that he is ready to attack Iraq even without a UN mandate.

Amid increased competition and declining sales, Kmart announced workforce reductions along with the closure of 326 stores. At the time, the discount retailer was undergoing a massive reorganization as part of its Chapter 11 bankruptcy; the year before, it had cut 22,000 jobs and shuttered 283 stores.
The Space Shuttle COLUMBIA burns up during reentry. All hands are lost.

In a UN weapons inspections report on Iraq, chief inspector Hans Blix indicates that slight progress has been made in Iraq's cooperation with the weapons team. Anti-war nations interpret this as a sign that inspections are yielding modest results and should continue; pro-war nations see it as Iraq's continued defiance of the international community, which is viewed as a threat to world peace and can only be remedied through force.
The U.S. and Britain's intense lobbying efforts among UN Security Council members to shore up support for a strike on Iraq yield only two additional supporters (Spain and Bulgaria).
3.25 MP EOS D30 released by Canon.
George flies to Chicago to meet Dad Campbell, who is riding Amtrak from NJ. They are there to attend the C.E.R.A. convention, and tour the South Shore and CTA lines.
George and Dad Campbell ride the South Shore from Chicago to South Bend, IN and back. A tour of the shops is provided. An excellent day!
George and Dad Campbell ride the CTA on a chartered car, riding over seldom used track and hearing lectures on station history.
George and Dad head back home from Chicago.

The war against Iraq begins 5:30 a.m. Baghdad time (9:30 p.m. EST, March 19), when the U.S. launches Operation Iraqi Freedom. A decapitation attack attempts to target Saddam Hussein and other Iraqi leaders. A second round of air strikes is launched against Baghdad later that day, and U.S. ground troops enter the country, crossing into southern Iraq from Kuwait.

The major phase of the war begins with heavy aerial attacks on Baghdad and other cities. The campaign, publicized in advance by the Pentagon as an overwhelming barrage meant to instill shock and awe, is actually more restrained.
Troops march within 50 miles of Baghdad. They encounter strong resistance from Iraqi soldiers and paramilitary fighters along the way, particularly in towns such as Nasiriya and Basra.
About 1,000 paratroopers land in Kurdish-controlled Iraq to open a northern front.

U.S. Marines and Army troops launch first attack on Iraq's Republican Guard, about 65 miles outside Baghdad. Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld deflects criticism that the U.S. has not deployed enough Army ground troops in Iraq.
Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld says "We know where [the weapons of mass destruction] are. They're in the area around Tikrit and Baghdad and east, west, south and north somewhat."

Buckeye Steel Castings emerges from bankruptcy under former management as Columbus Steel Castings.  Only 235 will be employed at a starting wage of $9/hr. Former workers made $16/hr to start, and management refuse to rehire them, instead recruiting in Fairfield County.
Special operations forces rescue Pfc. Jessica Lynch from a hospital in Nasiriya. She was one of 12 members of the 507th Ordnance Maintenance Company captured by Iraqi troops on March 23.
U.S. tanks roll into the Iraqi capital and engage in firefights with Iraqi troops. Resistance weaker than anticipated. Heavy Iraqi casualties.
British forces take control of Basra, Iraq's second-largest city.

Baghdad falls to U.S. forces, but sporadic fighting continues throughout the capital. Looters pillage government buildings, museums, hospitals, and stores. Statue of Saddam Hussein symbolically toppled.
Kirkuk falls to Kurdish fighters.

Secretary Rumsfeld says, in response to mass looting across Iraq, "Think what's happened in our cities when we've had riots, and problems, and looting. Stuff happens!  Freedom's untidy, and free people are free to make mistakes and commit crimes and do bad things. They're also free to live their lives and do wonderful things, and that's what's going to happen here."
Alex takes part in the Easter Egg Hunt at Selby Park.
Marines rescue five U.S. soldiers captured by Iraqi troops on March 23 in Nasiriya, and two pilots who had been shot down on March 24 near Karbala.
Major fighting in Iraq is declared over by the Pentagon, after U.S. forces take control of Tikrit, Saddam Hussein's birthplace. Saddam Hussein's whereabouts remain unknown.
Gen. Jay Garner, appointed by the U.S. to run post-war Iraq, meets with various Iraqi leaders to begin planning the new Iraqi federal government.
Bush signs $79 billion supplemental spending bill for Iraq.
George, Kelly and Alex visit the Dawes Arboretum to admire the crabapple trees in full bloom.
USAID Administrator Andrew Nastios Claims Rebuilding of Iraq Could Be Accomplished With $1.7 Billion.
The U.S. declares an end to major combat operations.
[M]y fellow Americans: Major combat operations in Iraq have ended. Bush appears in front of Mission Accomplished banner after landing on the CVN Lincoln. What a moron.
Southern and midwestern U.S.: a record-breaking number of more than 400 tornadoes in 10 days killed 42.

Paul Wolfowitz says "The truth is that, for reasons that have a lot to do with the U.S. government bureaucracy, we settled on the one issue that everyone could agree on which was weapons of mass destruction as the core reason [to go to war]"
At 4:00am in the westbound lanes of I-270 near I-71, the windshield and hood of a car that ran out of gas are hit by a bullet. It is the first attack by Charles McCoy Jr., the highway shooter.

A new civil administrator takes over in Iraq. U.S. diplomat Paul Bremer replaces Jay Garner, who was seen as ineffective in stemming the continuing lawlessness and violence taking place throughout Iraq.
The S.S. Badger was re-christened during a ceremony celebrating her 50th year of service.

UN Security Council votes to lift 13 years of sanctions on Iraq. Resolution 1483 also gives the U.S. and Britain broad power to run Iraq's government and economy until an Iraqi government is in place.
George, Kelly, Alex and Mom and Dad Foley attend the Worthington Memorial Day Parade.
George Bush says "We found the weapons of mass destruction." This statement proves to be untrue.
Penn Traffic Co., the parent of Big Bear supermarkets, files Chapter 11 Bankruptcy. It is the company's second Chapter 11 reorganization attempt in four years.

In separate speeches, U.S. secretary of state Colin Powell and British prime minister Tony Blair deny that intelligence about Iraq's weapons of mass destruction was distorted or exaggerated to justify an attack on Iraq. Both administrations face mounting questions because no weapons of mass destruction (WMD) have been found. Each had claimed that Iraq's WMD were an imminent threat to world security.

GRB High Street Partners, an affiliate of David J. Glimcher Co., purchased the 28-acre former ChemLawn and CheckFree corporate campus off Route 23 north of Worthington from Worthington Industries Inc. for $7.75 million. Plans are to redevelope the site.
The Mars Express orbiter is launched towards Mars on a Soyuz-FG/Fregat.

Rumsfeld blames Iraq problems on pockets of dead-enders, saying "In those regions where pockets of dead-enders are trying to reconstitute, Gen. Franks and his team are rooting them out. In short, the coalition is making good progress."
The Mars Spirit rover is launched towards Mars on a Delta II rocket.
The Central Ohio Transit Authority stops selling bus ridership passes through Big Bear stores following the supermarket chain's decision to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month.
Iraq's interim governing council, composed of 25 Iraqis appointed by American and British officials, is inaugurated. American administrator Paul Bremer, however, retains ultimate authority.

About 1,300 troops launch Operation Desert Scorpion, combatting organized Iraqi resistance against American troops near Faluja. U.S. and British troops face continued attacks; about one American soldier has been killed per day since the end of combat was declared. It is the largest of several offensives.
Fed Funds Rate down 1/4 to 1.00
Construction begins on a Walgreen's Drug Store at the southwest corner of High Street and Morse Road. A transmission repair business and Alwood Florist are torn down to make way.

Tesla Motors is founded by Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning. They are inspired to start an electric vehicle company after General Motors cancelled their EV-1 electric vehicle prototype that same year.
President Bush says "There are some who feel like Ñ that the conditions are such that they can attack us there. My answer is, bring them on."
Joseph Wilson writes op-ed in the New York Times, "It did not take long to conclude that it was highly doubtful that any such [yellowcake] transaction had ever taken place."

Bush administration concedes that evidence that Iraq was pursuing a nuclear weapons program by seeking to buy uranium from Africa, cited in January State of the Union address and elsewhere, was unsubstantiated and should not have been included in speech. Over summer Tony Blair faces even stronger criticism than his American counterpart concerning flawed intelligence.
The Mars Opportunity rover is launched towards Mars on a Delta II rocket.

Condoleezza Rice: Doubts about Iraq intel were not communicated to Bush: "All that I can tell you is that if there were doubts about the underlying intelligence in the NIE, those doubts were not communicated to the President."
The aircraft carrier CVN 76 Ronald Reagan is commissioned.
Bush says he had good intelligence before the war: "I think the intelligence I get is darn good intelligence. And the speeches I have given were backed by good intelligence."

Gen. John Abizaid, commander of allied forces in Iraq who replaced retiring general Tommy Franks on July 7, calls continued attacks on coalition troops a "guerrilla-type campaign" and says soldiers who will replace current troops may be deployed for year-long tours.
Saddam Hussein's sons, Uday and Qusay Hussein, die in firefight in a Mosul palace.
The front maple tree is chopped down because it was dying. Was planted in the late 70's.
OSU: Hagerty Hall, 1775 College Road, completely gutted.
OSU: Page Hall, 1810 College Road, gutted and remodeled.
The Ohio Railway Museum tears down the dilapidated train shed.

Violence returned to the streets of Baghdad with a vengeance when at least 11 people were killed in a massive car bomb explosion outside the Jordanian embassy, leading to fears that guerrilla fighters may now be turning their attention towards so-called soft targets.
U.S. combat and noncombat casualties reach 255 at 100-day mark after declared end of combat on May 1; 43 British have died.
Suicide bombing destroys UN headquarters in Baghdad, killing 24, including top envoy Sergio Vieira de Mello, and wounding more than 100.
6.3 MP EOS 300D (Rebel) released by Canon.
The Canon Powershot A80 4.0 MP, 3x optical zoom camera is released.

The U.N. special representative in Iraq [Sergio Vieira de Mello] and at least 16 others died Tuesday in a bomb explosion that ripped through the organization's headquarters in Baghdad. At least 100 people were wounded.
A bomb kills one of Iraq's most important Shi'ite leaders, Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, as well as about 80 others, and wounds 125.
Lazarus stores are renamed Lazarus-Macy's.

A secret report for the Joint Chiefs of Staff lays the blame for setbacks in Iraq on a flawed and rushed war-planning process that "limited the focus" for preparing for post-Saddam Hussein operations.
Keel laid for the aircraft carrier CVN 77 George H. W. Bush. Commissioning expected in 2009.
Continued violence and slow progress in Iraq lead to President Bush's announcement that $87 billion is needed to cover additional military and reconstruction costs.
Penn Traffic Co., the parent of Central Ohio's Big Bear and Big Bear Plus stores, dismisses 100 supervisors and administrators, including 22 in the Columbus area.
George and Alex visit Marion Station.
Interstate 670 completed as section between High Street and the Spring Sandusky Interchange opens. The interstate system in Columbus is finally completed.
The abandoned Elephant Bar is torn down on Rt. 161 near I-71.
Drug Emporium's parent company, Snyder's Drug Stores Inc., files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and will sell or close its Drug Emporium subsidiary, including the store at Graceland.
Casto Company presents plans to the Clintonville Area Commission to build a Target store at the southeast corner of the Graceland Shopping Center.

Value City Department Stores announces it will move its corporate headquarters into the old Lazarus store at Northland. The move brings with it 686 jobs, 110 of them new positions. At a cost of $21 million, Lazarus will be remodeled and the old mall spaces torn down.
According to an interim report by David Kay, the lead investigator searching for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, no WMDs have been found as yet.
White House reorganizes its reconstruction efforts in Iraq, placing National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice in charge and diminishing the role of the Pentagon.
The Ohio College Advantage Plan suspends the sale of tuition credits after plan is projected to be insolvent by 2014.
COTA opens a Park-and-Ride lot at the northeast corner of High Street and Morse Road.
The new, colorized twenty dollar bill begins circulating. First color American currency.

Penn Traffic announces it is closing the following Big Bears by the end of the year, with a loss of 325 jobs: 3680 E. Broad St., 6867 E. Broad St., 2700 Bethel Road (at Sawmill), 920 Hamilton Road, and 5419 Roberts Road.
China launches its first manned mission, the Shenzhou 5, with Lt. Col. Yang Liwei, 38, aboard.
The Defense Department eliminates 322 computer jobs from an agency at the Defense Supply Center in the Columbus suburb of Whitehall.

The UN Security Council unanimously approves the U.S. and UK resolution on Iraq's reconstruction, which supports an international force in the country under U.S. authority. Several countries originally opposed the resolution unless Washington agreed to a faster timetable for transferring power to the Iraqis, but in the end voted for the resolution without requiring changes.
Lazarus-Macys announces it will close Columbus' downtown Lazarus in August of 2004, after 95 years of operation.
The final day of the store fixture clearance sale at Northland Mall.

A yearlong State Department study predicted many of the problems that have plagued the American-led occupation of Iraq, according to internal State Department documents and interviews with administration and Congressional officials.

The Madrid Conference, an international donors' conference of 80 nations to raise funds for the reconstruction of Iraq, yielded $13 billion in addition to the $20 billion already pledged by the United States. This amount fell short of the overall target of raising $56 billion, the figure the World Bank and the UN estimated that Iraq needs over the next four years.
OS X 10.3 Panther released by Apple.
Bill Kaiser weds Joyce Depp in Columbus, OH
Four coordinated suicide attacks in Baghdad kill 43 and wounded more than 200. Targets included the headquarters of the Red Crescent (Islamic Red Cross) and three police stations.

In the single deadliest strike since the Iraq war began, guerrillas shoot down an American helicopter, killing 16 U.S. soldiers and injuring 21 others. Over the course of the month, additional attacks make it the bloodiest since the war began: at least 75 U.S. soldiers die.
Bush signs $87 billion supplemental spending bill into law.
Penn Traffic Co. plans to sell 11 Big Bear supermarkets to Kroger Co., including five stores in Central Ohio, and may go as far as closing the division.
The Bush Administration reverses policy. In a deal with the Iraqi Governing Council, it agrees to transfer power to an interim government in early 2004.
The new Lane Avenue suspension bridge opens for traffic.
Richard Perle suggests Iraq war was illegal: "I think in this case international law stood in the way of doing the right thing"

Gail Knisley, 62, of Washington Court House is killed when a bullet enters the driver's side door of her friend's car as they travel east on I-270 near I-71. It is the 13th shooting by Charles McCoy Jr. and the first fatality.
Bush makes surprise Thanksgiving visit to Iraq, poses with fake turkey.
The French TGV high speed train system serves it's one billionth passenger.
Giant Eagle purchases 7 Big Bear stores at an auction for $47 million. Kroger's offer from November 12th is rejected.
Directive issued by Paul Wolfowitz, deputy secretary of defense, bars France, Germany, and Russia from bidding on lucrative contracts for rebuilding Iraq, creating a diplomatic furor.
Iraq's deposed leader Saddam Hussein is captured by American troops. The former dictator was found hiding in a hole near his hometown of Tikrit and surrendered without a fight.
Saddam Hussein is captured in a hole near a mud hut in Iraq by the American 4th infantry.
Penn Traffic begins "store closing" sales at all of its Big Bear locations.
George, Kelly and Alex decorate the Christmas Tree.
Saddam is captured. L. Paul Bremmer says: "Ladies and gentlemen. We got him!"
Kaufman's announces it is building a new store at Eastland Mall. The sale of Eastland Mall to Glimcher is also announced.
Linux 2.6 released.
The Mars Express orbiter is inserted into orbit around Mars. The Beagle lander is released, but fails to respond after entering the atmosphere and is presumed lost.

A powerful earthquake struck southeastern Iran, killing 26,271 people, injuring 20,000, leaving 60,000 homeless and destroying much of the city of Bam. The USGS National Earthquake information center is reported a magnitude of 6.6 for the quake, which was located just southwest of the city. About 60 percent of the buildings in Bam were destroyed. The old quarter and a 2,000-year-old citadel (severely damaged by the earthquake) were built primarily of mud brick.
The Mars Spirit rover successfully lands on the surface of Mars.

The Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the most influential Shiite cleric in Iraq, says members of the country's interim government must be selected by direct vote. He opposes the U.S. plan to hold regional caucuses. While caucuses are less democratic than direct elections, the United States has argued that it would be impossible to ensure free and safe elections on such a tight timetableÑthe U.S. plans to hand control of the government to Iraqis on June 30.

President Bush announces Project Constellation, a plan to build a new NASA spacecraft capable of reaching the moon and Mars. Bush announced that the first goal will be to return the Space Shuttle to flight safely, and consistent with the recommendations of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board. Once construction of the International Space Station (ISS) is complete, the Space Shuttle will be retired by 2010 to make way for a new spacecraft. "Our second goal," Bush went on, "is to develop and test a new spacecraft, the Crew Exploration Vehicle, by 2008, and to conduct the first manned mission no later than 2014. The Crew Exploration Vehicle will be capable of ferrying astronauts and scientists to the Space Station after the shuttle is retired. But the main purpose of this spacecraft will be to carry astronauts beyond our orbit to other worlds. This will be the first spacecraft of its kind since the Apollo Command Module."
Burlington Coat Factory announces that it is closing its Graceland location and moving to the former Builders Square at 3575 Dublin Granville Road.
Tens of thousands of Shiites hold a peaceful demonstration in Basra in support of direct elections.
Lazarus-Macy's announces it is closing its "underperforming" Westerville store.
500 U.S. soldiers dead in Iraq since the invasion.

The United States asks the UN to intercede in the dispute over the elections process in Iraq. Shiite leader Ayatollah al-Sistani, at the center of the debate, has refused to meet with American officials. The UN weighs sending election experts to determine whether there is enough time to prepare for direct elections. About 100,000 Shiites march in Baghdad and other cities in support of Ayatollah al-Sistani's demand for direct elections. It is the largest protest since the occupation of Iraq.

CIA officers in Iraq are warning that the country may be on a path to civil war, current and former U.S. officials said Wednesday, starkly contradicting the upbeat assessment that President Bush gave in his State of the Union address.
The Mars Opportunity rover successfully lands on the surface of Mars.
Demolition of Northland Mall begins.
Iraq Survey Group inspector David Kay reports "It turns out that we were all wrong, probably in my judgment, and that is most disturbing."
8.2 MP EOS 1D MkII released by Canon.

David Kay, the former head of the U.S. weapons inspection teams in Iraq, informs a senate committee that no WMD have been found in Iraq and that prewar intelligence was "almost all wrong" about Saddam Hussein's arsenal. His report sets off a firestorm of allegations: did the U.S. receive bad intelligence, or did the Bush administration manipulate the intelligence to build the case for war, or both? About 109 Iraqis are killed by suicide bombings in Erbil.
Elon Musk joins the board of Tesla Motors.
Under pressure from both sides of the political aisle, President Bush calls for an independent commission to study the country's intelligence failures.
109 Iraqis die in suicide bomb attacks in Kurdish-held Irbil.
Graceland Big Bear closes for good. All Big Bear stores are now closed.
About 54 Iraqis are killed in a car bombing while applying for jobs at a police station. The next day an attack kills about 47 outside an army recruiting center.

U.S. Military uncovers letter addressed to senior al-Qaida operatives seeking help in waging a Òsectarian warÓ Brigadier general Mark Kimmit: ÒThere is clearly a plan on the part of outsiders to come into this country and spark civil war, breed sectarian violence and try to expose fissures in the society.Ó
UN envoy Lakhdar Brahimi, on a fact finding mission to Iraq to assess the feasibility of direct elections, meets with Ayatollah al-Sistani.

Charles McCoy Jr., the highway shooter, fires his 24th and final shot from a highway overpass hitting the front fender of a sport utility vehicle on I-70 in Licking County. Soon after, Charles McCoy Jr.'s guns are confiscated by his father.
The renovated Ohio State Courts building at 65 S. Front St. is rededicated as the Ohio Judicial Center.
During a press-conference at the ITAR TASS news agency, Yuri Koptev revealed that RKK Energia, had been working on a brand-new vehicle called Kliper (Clipper) since 2000.

U.N. Secretary-General Kofi announces the results of its report about Iraqi elections, concluding that elections cannot be held before the end of June, that the June 30 date for the handover of sovereignty must be respected, and that we need to find a mechanism to create the caretaker government and then prepare the elections sometime later in the future.
Chalabi declares that he and Bush administration have been Òheroes in error.Ó
Zachary John Campbell is born at 4:06pm at Riverside Methodist Hospital in Columbus, Ohio.

UN envoy Brahimi issues a report to the Security Council concluding that the earliest that credible, direct elections could be held in Iraq would be late 2004 or early 2005. He outlined several possible options for structuring an interim government that would rule the country after the June 30 hand over and until the results of elections in 2004 or 2005. He recommended that Iraqis themselves draw up a plan for the makeup of this provisional government.
Preen herbicide is applied to the garden beds and Scotts w/Halts is applied to the lawn.
Tulip shoots can be seen in the front bed.

Suicide attacks in Karbala on Shiite Islam's most holy feast day killed more than 85 and wound 233 others. It is believed that the perpetrators are attempting to foment unrest between Shiites and Sunnis.
Started digging up the back-of-house bed. Applied Miracle Grow weed preventer. Tulip shoots in back bed.
John Kerry defacto democratic presidential nominee after Super Tuesday wins. John Edwards drops out of race.
Worthington School Levy, 6.5 mill, passes 52 to 48%.
The former chief UN weapons inspector Hans Blix has declared that the war in Iraq was illegal, dealing another devastating blow to Tony Blair.

Dollar General, 127 Graceland Blvd, closes because Target bought the property. Demolition of the south side of Graceland Shopping Center is scheduled to begin in the late spring to make way for a new Target store.

The Iraqi Governing Council signs interim constitution, which includes a bill of rights, a system of checks and balances, and a military subordinate to civilian rule. The signing was delayed by several days when Shiites objected that Kurds, a minority, were given too much power in the interim constitution.
An unnamed relative of Charles McCoy Jr. tips police that his father is holding guns taken from his son, and his son may be the highway shooter.
Crocus flowers appear in the front bed, white flowers near the white fence and purple flowers in the middle of the front bed.
Police identify Charles McCoy Jr. as the highway shooter after ballistic tests from guns provided by his father match bullet fragments gathered in the shootings.
Zachary smiled at me.
Thompson announces that it will shut down its Circleville Television Tube plant by summer, costing 545 jobs.
Major snowstorm - 4 inches.
Columbus Steel (formerly Buckeye Steel) eliminates 134 jobs.
Charles McCoy Jr., the highway shooter, is arrested in Las Vegas.

At least 27 people are killed and 41 wounded in the car bombing of a hotel in Baghdad. The bombing came just two days before the anniversary of the first American attack on Baghdad that launched the war last year.

Jay Garner, the US general abruptly dismissed as Iraq's first occupation administrator after a month in the job, says he fell out with the Bush circle because he wanted free elections and rejected an imposed program of privatization.
Zachary John Campbell baptized at St. Michael's Catholic Church.
Mom & Dad Campbell visit and meet Zachary.
Bush jokes at the Radio and Television Correspondents Association Dinner: "Those weapons of mass destruction have got to be somewhere."
Grass is noticeably greener. Crocuses in full bloom. Magnolia tree starting to bloom.
Coalition forces close radical cleric Moktada al-Sadr's rabidly anti-American newspaper, Al Hawaz.
Rose garden installation completed. Added nine roses and landscape cloth to back yard.
Iraqi mob kills and mutilates four America civilian contract workers and then drags them through the streets of Falluja, a city west of Baghdad that is part of the Sunni triangle.
Began mulching west side of backyard. Crocuses are done. Magnolia blooming thinly.

U.S. troops begin assault on Falluja in response to March 31 assassination of four U.S. civilian contractors. 
Coordinated attacks by Shiites in several southern Iraqi cities are launched in Kufa, Karbala, Najaf, al-Kut, and Sadr City. The militias are led by radical cleric Moktada al-Sadr.
Mulching of the yard COMPLETE!
An American contract worker, Thomas Hamill, taken hostage. In all, more than 20 foreigners kidnapped in Iraq.
Magnolia in full glory.

U.S. orders a cease-fire in Falluja to give political discussions a chance to break the cycle of violence. Two members of the Iraqi Governing Council resign in protest of American offensive in Falluja.
Demolition of the former Coyle Music, Dollar General and original Big Bear store begins at Graceland Shopping Center.
Alex reads a book to Zachary.
Magnolia rapidly shedding flower petals.
The Bush administration agrees to a UN proposal to replace the Iraqi Governing Council with a caretaker government when the U.S. returns sovereignty to Iraqis on June 30.
The number of hostages taken by various Iraqi guerrillas reaches about 40.
Allergies hit hard.

Bob Woodward reveals CIA Director George Tenet said there was a slam dunk case against Iraq: "About two weeks before deciding to invade Iraq, President Bush was told by CIA Director George Tenet there was a slam dunk case that dictator Saddam Hussein had unconventional weapons, according to a new book by Washington Post journalist Bob Woodward."

The new Linden Elementary School opens, replacing the existing school at Cleveland Avenue and Westerville Ave. This is the first new school in the Columbus School District since Avalon Elementary was opened in 1977. The three story, 70,300 sq. ft. building cost $10.7 million.
Five suicide car bombings strike near police stations in the southern city of Basra, killing at least 74 people.
Crab Apple Tree blooms.

In policy shift, U.S. announces that some Iraqi Baath Party officials who had been forced out of their jobs after the fall of Saddam Hussein will be allowed to resume their positions. About 400,000 people lost their jobs, including teachers and members of the military, depleting Iraq of skilled and experienced workers to rebuild the country.

The new control tower at Port Columbus International Airport opens. The $24 million control tower is now staffed. Construction started in July 2001. About 70 people now work in the new building as air traffic controllers and facilities and administrative staff. The tower will serve Port Columbus, while the radar room will serve all airports within 35 miles of Columbus.
Crab Apple Tree begins shedding flower petals.

UN envoy Lakhdar Brahimi reports to the UN Security Council that by the end of May he will select a transitional government to run Iraq until elections are held in 2005. Proposed government will include a president, two vice presidents, a prime minister, and a consultative conference made up of about 1,500 Iraqis. The government will have limited control over Iraq, and would not be authorized to enact news laws.
Images of torture at Abu Ghraib are revealed.
The last General Motors Oldsmobile brand vehicle, an Alero, rolls off the assembly line.
Big Lots moves from the south side to the north side of Graceland Shopping Center, the former home of the Rite Aid Drug Store at 260 Graceland Blvd.

The appalling physical and sexual abuse and humiliation of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison near Baghdad comes to light when photographs are released by the U.S. media. The images spark outrage around the world, especially in the Middle East. Abu Ghraib was a notorious prison and torture center during the rule of Saddam Hussein. The Pentagon has been investigating these and other allegations of abuse since January. Criminal charges have been filed against seven U.S. soldiers. 
In an attempt to restore peace in Falluja, U.S. Marines transfer security of the volatile city to a former Iraqi general.

Kellog announces that it plans to close the Worthington Foods Plant on Proprieter's Road and consolidate production in their Zanesville facility. Three hundred jobs will be lost. Kellog complains that the Worthington facility is older, land locked and cannot be efficiently expanded. The plant produces the Morningstar and Loma Linda brands.

Bush says daily life of Iraqis is improving: "One year later [after Mission Accomplished], despite many challenges, life for the Iraqi people is a world away from the cruelty and corruption of Saddam's regime. At the most basic level of justice, people are no longer disappearing into political prisons, torture chambers, and mass graves Ñ because the former dictator is in prison, himself. And their daily life is improving."

The Starbucks at 530 N. High St. catches fire at 3:24 a.m. The roof and attic are destroyed. This building formerly housed the Montanna Bread Co. and before that was a Friendly's Restaurant. The fire is ruled an arson.
George Bush appears on two Arab television stations to condemn the prisoner abuse.

Appearing on Arab TV, Bush expresses sorrow over prisoner abuse: "The American people are just as appalled at what they have seen on TV as Iraqi citizens have. The Iraqi citizens must understand that."
The rebuilt Lane Avenue Shopping Center holds its grand reopening.
Nicholas Berg, an American contractor, is beheaded by Iraqi militants, who claim the grisly murder was in retaliation for the treatment of Iraqi prisoners.

The 16 story Baldwin Tower at Grant Medical Center is imploded to make way for 18 new operating rooms. The tower was built in 1968, named for Doctor James Baldwin who founded Grant Medical Center in 1900, and originally housed the nursing school.
A nest with four Robin's eggs is discovered in the arbor rose bush.
Video released showing Nicholas Berg, an American contractor, being beheaded by Iraqi militants.
The locust tree blooms
Plans are announced to replace the existing Ohio Union with a modern, $100,000,000 student union.
A suicide bomber kills the head of Iraq's Governing Council, Izzedin Salim, and six other people.
Four baby Robins are observed in the nest in the arbor rose bush.
Peonies bloom
Alex's rose blooms.
The volunteer rose blooms.
The Locust tree sheds flower petals like mad.
Gas prices in Ohio hit a record $2.13
Kroger announces it is converting its 42,462 sq. ft. Worthington Square Mall store into a Fresh Fair premium supermarket, at a cost of $3 million. Work to be completed by March, 2005.
After seven weeks of fighting in Najaf, U.S. forces and the militias loyal to Moktada al-Sadr reach a truce.

Iyad Allawi is designated prime minister of the Iraqi interim government. A Shiite neurologist, Alawi has close ties to the CIA, and many observers inside and outside Iraq say Alawi's selection is a sign of the U.S.'s continued attempt to assert control over the country.

Four Blackwater contractors killed and their bodies mutilated in Fallujah. The group were shot and burnt in their cars, before a cheering crowd dismembered the corpses and hung two of them from a bridge.

Ghazi al-Yawer, a Sunni Muslim, is chosen president, a largely ceremonial post. The Governing Council decided to dissolve itself immediately rather than wait for the official handover of sovereignty on June 30, making way for a cabinet of 33 Iraqis, including Sunnis, Shiites, Kurds, and Christians. New government includes former members of the governing council, former militants, professionals, and opponents of Saddam Hussein.
The arbor red rose bush is at its peak.
The Japanese Lilac is at its peak.
Former President Ronald Reagan dies at age 93.
Kroger announces it is building a new Marketplace store at Graceland Shopping Center.
Mom & Dad Campbell celebrate their 40th wedding anniversary with The Foley's, the Texas Campbells and the Kaisers at Der Dutchman Restaurant in Plain City.
Spaceship One, designed by Burt Rutan, funded by Paul Allen and flown by Mike Melvill, achieves an altitude of 100 km and speed of Mach 2.9. It is the first privately funded spaceflight in history.
U.S. transfers sovereignty to Iraq. Bush's response: "Let freedom reign!"
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 1.25

A small 3.3 magitude earthquake occurred at 12:03 a.m EDT 9 miles ENE of Painesville, Lake County, Ohio. It was strongly felt at Painesville, Madison, and Perry, Ohio. No damages were reported. Many residents reported a loud boom followed by a sharp jolt and brief, but intense shaking. This is the second earthquake this year in the general area of Painesville. On March 14, 2004 a 2.4 magnitude earthquake was centered near Fairport Harbor.
Grandma Fisher celebrates her 100th birthday with all 10 of her great grandchildren in attendance at her home in Westgate.
Martha Stewart is sentenced to five months in prison and two years probation for insider trading.
The Village of New Rome is dissolved by Common Pleas Judge David Cain.
Clintonville Electric is sold and relocates to a former Rite-Aid drug store on Bethel Road.
The Campbells, Coffeys and Foleys begin a 7 day vacation in a cabin at Hueston Woods State Park.
Work begins on a second interchange north of Polaris.
Techneglas goes out of business, laying off 382 workers at its 727 E. Jenkins Ave. plant.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 1.50
Tropical Storm: Bonnie, hits Appalachicola on the Florida Panhandle, Xx killed.
Hurricane: Charlie, category 4, hits near Fort Myers, Florida. Twenty killed.
The Summer Olympics open in Athens, Greece.
The downtown Columbus Lazarus store closes.
Greyhound Bus eliminates 269 stops in 13 states from Chicago to Seattle. High insurance costs and low ridership since 9-11 are sited as reasons.
8.2 MP EOS 20D released by Canon.

A wave of terror attacks on Russia began with a pair of bombings aboard two airliners. The first was Volga-AviaExpress 1303, a Tu-134 flying from Moscow to Volgograd. Contact with the plane was lost about 26 minutes after takeoff when witnesses on the ground reported seeing a large explosion. All 43 occupants (34 passengers, 9 crew) were killed. Later investigation found that the crash was caused by a female suicide bomber named Amanta Nagayeva who was from the separatist region of Chechnya.

Minutes after the Volga-AviaExpress crash, a Siberia Airlines flight from Moscow to Sochi also disappeared. The Tu-154 was carrying 46 people (38 passengers, 8 crew) and reportedly broadcast a hijack warning shortly before crashing. There were no survivors. The attack was also due to a female Chechen suicide bomber named Satsita Dzhebirkhanova. A group named Islambouli Brigade initially claimed responsibility for the two bombings, but leading Chechen terrorist Shamil Basayev denied this and took responsibility for organizing the attack. A week after the two airline attacks, a bomb at the Moscow subway station killed 10 people. Shortly thereafter, the Beslan hostage crisis in September led to the deaths of 335.
The Solid Waste Authority of Central Ohio approves paying $1.25 million to demolish most of the trash-burning plant on the city's South Side, shuttered since 1994.
Lee's install new privacy fence.
Bush acknowledged for the first time that he made a miscalculation of what the conditions would be in postwar Iraq.

Bush says "Had we had to do it over again, we would look at the consequences of catastrophic success - being so successful so fast that an enemy that should have surrendered or been done in escaped and lived to fight another day."

American Electric Power announces plans to build at least one "clean-coal" plant by 2010 in response to environmentalist and shareholder demands to release pollution-reduction plans, the company said Tuesday. The plant, which would convert coal into a gas and pass it through pollutant-removal equipment before it is burned, was recommended by a board of directors subcommittee that was formed as part of an agreement with shareholders.
Reconstruction of High Street between Arcadia and Torrence in Clintonville begins. Includes new sidewalks, trees and lights.

NASA awards $27 million worth of contracts to 11 companies to prepare proposals for the design of the new Crew Exploration Vehicle. Contracts focus on a Lunar landing. The new space system is named CONSTELLATION by NASA.
Amtrak exits the mail hauling business, laying off 300 employees and closing several stations. Service will be ended to Akron, Youngstown and Fostoria in March 2005.
Hurricane: Frances, category 2, hits Florida's east coast near Sewall's Point. 23 killed.
Work begins on expanding the sanctuary of Worthington Presbyterian Church.
Death toll of U.S. soldiers in Iraq reaches 1,000.

Citing bad weather, a weak economy and the loss of customers to increased competition, FrankÕs Nursery & Crafts Inc. filed chapter 11 bankruptcy and will close its stores by Christmas. Frank's began in Detroit in the 1940s and once had 257 stores in 15 states.
The Village of New Rome officially ceases to exist.
Fisher family reunion in honor of Grandma Fisher's 100th birthday.
Lazarus announces that its name will be officially changed to Macy's in January, 2005.
Bush administration requests that the Senate shift $3.4 billion of the $18.4 billion Iraqi aid package meant for reconstruction work to improving security measures.

Intelligence report delivered to Bush warns of civil war. BushÕs response: the CIA is Òjust guessingÓ: A classified National Intelligence Estimate prepared for President Bush in late July spells out a dark assessment of prospects for Iraq, government officials said Wednesday. The estimate outlines three possibilities for Iraq through the end of 2005, with the worst case being developments that could lead to civil war, the officials said.

When pressed on whether he viewed the invasion of Iraq as illegal, Kofi Anan said: ÒYes, if you wish. I have indicated it was not in conformity with the UN charter from our point of view, from the charter point of view, it was illegal.Ó
Hurricane: Ivan, category 3, hits Gulf Shores, Alabama. Including Bahamas, 90 killed.
George, Kelly, Alex and Zach have a picnic at the Park of Roses.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 1.75
8.2 MP EOS 1Ds MkII released by Canon.
Bush: "I saw a poll that said the right track/wrong track in Iraq was better than here in America."
A swarm of small earthquakes is detected in the lava dome area of Mount St. Helens.
The Murrin girls (Julie, Tasha and Sammy) spend the night when Cheryl goes to the hospital on false labor.
Finished planting front bulb garden.
Hurricane: Jeanne, category 3, hits Florida near Stewart. Including Haiti, over 2000 are killed.

The same intelligence unit that produced a gloomy report in July about the prospect of growing instability in Iraq warned the Bush administration about the potential costly consequences of an American-led invasion two months before the war began, government officials said Monday.
Seismic activity at Mount St. Helens suddenly increases, generating four earthquakes per minute. Geologists assign a 70% probability of a near term eruption within days to months.
Java J2SE 5 released.
The Worthington smoking ban goes into effect.
Mount St. Helens blows smoke and steam 10,000 feet into the air.

Mount St. Helens shows signs of magma movement, including another blast of steam and ash followed by a continuous 50 minute long earthquake. At 2pm a notice of volcano level 3 alert was issued, the most serious level.
Mount St. Helens blasts a massive steam cloud into the air at 10 am.
L. Paul Bremmer: "We never had enough troops on the ground."
Saddam Hussein did not possess stockpiles of illicit weapons at the time of the U.S. invasion in March 2003 and had not begun any program to produce them, a CIA report concludes.
The price of oil hits $54/bbl - a new record. Hurricane damage in the Gulf of Mexico and a strike in Nigeria are blamed.
Fall leaves, especially maples, at their peak. Magnolia still green.
Polls show the Presidential race between George W. Bush and John Kerry is a tie.
Plans are announced to convert the former Checkfree office complex on North High Street into 219 Apartments and five commercial sites.
Trees are trimmed at Indianola Park.

A 6.8 earthquake strikes Niigata Prefecture in Japan, 125 miles north of Tokyo. Twenty three killed, seven missing and 2100 injured. The quake caused 52 landslides, damaged or cut roads in 211 places, and damaged or destroyed 1,206 commercial or public buildings and at least 2,583 homes, according to Japan's National Police Agency.
USS Virginia SSN-774 commissioned. It is the first ship of the Virginia Class.
Thanksgiving dinner at Grandma Fisher's house.
The New York Times reports that about 380 tons of powerful explosives disappeared from military installation called Al Qaqaa sometime after the U.S.-led war began in March 2003.
The Goodyear Blimp flies noisily over the house.

In the case of the ".22 Caliber Killers", 64-year-old Gary Lewingdon died of heart failure. This closes the book on the heinous 1977-78 murder spree that left 10 dead and terrorized central Ohio; his accomplice and brother Thaddeus died in prison of lung cancer on April 17, 1989.
George W. Bush defeats John F. Kerry 59.4 to 55.9 million votes.
Giant Eagle announces that it is slashing prices to remain competitive in the Columbus market.
Hard times continue in Circleville as Plastech Engineered Products Inc closes its plant, laying off 110 people.
An assault on the rebel stronghold of Falluja begins.

U.S. forces launch all-out assault on Fallujah. "The U.S. military said 10 troops and two members of IraqÕs security forces were killed in the first two days of the battle, the largest military operation since the U.S.-led invasion last year. U.S. and Iraqi leaders hope the assault will break the grip of insurgents who have held Fallujah for nearly seven months."

The first Soyuz-2 carrier rocket, in the Soyuz-2.1a configuration, was launched from the Plesetsk Cosmodrome in Russia. The rocket followed a sub-orbital trajectory, with the third stage and boilerplate payload re-entering over the Pacific Ocean.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 2.00
Yassar Arafat dies of massive stroke at age 75 in a French military hospital.
The Kroger Marketplace opens at 199 Graceland Blvd, replacing the Big Bear Plus that closed on February 8th. The 100,000 sq. ft. store is the first Kroger Marketplace in the midwest and employs 300.
Kohler enamels what is to become the new cast iron bathtub in the old bathroom.

NASA's X-43A research vehicle screamed into the record books again today, demonstrating an air-breathing engine can fly at nearly 10 times the speed of sound. Preliminary data from the scramjet-powered research vehicle show its revolutionary engine worked successfully at nearly Mach 9.8, or 7,000 mph, as it flew at about 110,000 feet.

Discount retailer Kmart Holding Corp. (KMRT.O) will buy department store operator Sears, Roebuck & Co. (S.N) in a surprise $11 billion deal that creates the third-largest U.S. retailer. The new company, Sears Holdings, will have about $55 billion in annual revenue and nearly 3,500 retail stores. The companies, both of which have been struggling, said in a joint statement the merger, expected to be finalized by next March, was expected to generate significant cost savings but could also trigger sales of ``nonstrategic real estate assets.
The second highest total score NFL game, 106 points. The Bengals defeat the Browns 58-48. See 11/27/66 for the highest total score game.

A $4,950 contract is signed with Jack Woods Plumbing to renovate the old bathroom at 554 Kenbrook Drive. The bathtub and sink will be replaced. The cast iron and galvanized drains will be replaced with PVC and the main drain casting, which is cracked, will also be replaced. A passive recirculation line for the hot water system will be installed to eliminate the wait for hot water anywhere in the house. As part of this project, I will tile the floor and walls of the old bathroom to upgrade its look.

Jack Woods Plumbing begins work on the bathroom renovation. The toilet, sink and bathtub are removed. The date on the underside of the tub indicates that it was cast on 4/20/42, making it 62 years old!
The subfloor of the old bathroom is removed. New joists are added to support the edges and two layers of 1/2" plywood are installed. I throw my back out doing this. :(
Michael Crichton publishes "State of Fear"
Donald Rumsfeld: "As you know, you go to war with the Army you have. They're not the Army you might want or wish to have at a later time."
Five people are shot and killed at the Alrosa Villa. Former Pantera guitarist "Dimebag" Darrell Abbott, three others and the gunman, Nathan Gale, of Marysville, are killed.
A new Kohler bathtub is installed in the old bathroom. A passive hot water recirculation line is installed, but doesn't work.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 2.25

Installation of a new high efficiency furnace and air conditioner is completed. The exhaust for the new furnace is routed out the side of the garage, bypassing the old chimney. In addition, a separate vent for the hot water heater is installed, rendering the old chimney obsolete. Plans are to remove it below the roof line and seal the roof, possibly in the spring.
Blasts kill at least 64 in Iraq's holy cities.
A snow and ice storm hits Columbus, knocking out our power at 3am. A generator is purchased from the Lowes on Hudson Ave. to power the furnace. The power comes back on at 8 pm.
The early morning temperature dips to -10 degrees.

At 7:58m EDT a massive 9.0 earthquake struck off the west coast of Northern Sumatra. It is the world's largest earthquake since 1964 (Prince William Sound, Alaska, magnitude 9.2) and the fourth largest since 1900. Massive tsunamis wipe out coastal areas across Southeast Asia as far as 1,000 miles away, killing more than 226,000 people, seriously injuring 500,000 and leaving 5,000,000 homeless. The missing includes 7,000 European tourists.
A storm dumps 5"+ of rain on Central Ohio.
A storm dumps 3"+ of rain on Central Ohio.
WMD search in Iraq is declared over: "U.S. inspectors have ended their search for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq in recent weeks, a U.S. intelligence official told CNN."
Outside temperature reaches 65 degrees(!).

Nine Ohio reservoirs are filled to record volumes in the wake of heavy rains that have soaked Ohio. Bolivar Reservoir in Stark and Tuscarawas counties was 56 feet higher than its normal winter level. Dillon Reservoir in Muskingum County was 53 feet higher; Mohawk Lake in Coshocton and Knox counties was 79 feet higher; Wills Creek Lake in Coshocton and Muskingum counties was 35 feet higher; and Charles Mill in Ashland and Richland counties was 23 feet higher. In addition, Atwood Lake in Carroll and Tuscarawas counties and Dover Reservoir in Tuscarawas County are expected to break records before the water level drops next week.

Delaware Lake rises to within 18 inches of the top of the dam, a record pool level of 944 feet, 34 feet above normal winter pool level. Water is released from the dam at 4300 cubic feet per second through the normal spillway gates and the level stabilizes without requiring the flood gates to open. It is a close call, as opening the flood gates would have caused a record flood on the Olentangy River.
30 Marines, Sailor Die In Copter crash in Iraq, the deadliest single event for U.S. forces since the invasion.
Delaware Lake returns to the normal winter pool level of 910 feet.

U.S. loses track of nearly $9 billion in Iraqi funds: "The CPA provided less than adequate controls for approximately $8.8 billion of Development Fund for Iraq (DFI) funds provided to Iraqi ministries through the national budget process."
Iraqis vote to form a Transitional National Assembly
The Canon Powershot A520 4.0 MP, 4x optical zoom camera is released.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 2.50
Final flight of an Atlas III rocket with a Russian RD-180 engine.
8.0 MP EOS 350D (Rebel XT) released by Canon.
USS Jimmy Carter SSN-23 commissioned.
Car bombs kill at least 114 Iraqis in Hilla.
Army missed its February recruiting goal by more than 27 percent, the first time in almost five years that the Army failed to meet a monthly target.
Death toll of U.S. troops in Iraq hits 1,500.
Martha Stewart is released from a correctional facility in West Virginia after serving five months for security fraud.

The Lazarus brand ends its 153-year run in Columbus . The retail chain's parent, Cincinnati-based Federated Department Stores Inc., announces that all Lazarus-Macy's stores will become Macy's stores today. Federated added the "-Macy's" name to Lazarus in August of 2003, and said in September it would drop "Lazarus" completely.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 2.75
Silberman-Robb commission, the presidential commission on Iraqi WMD, concludes: "[T]he intelligence community was dead wrong in almost all of its prewar judgments."
Heavy snow in Worthington.
In a speech to Parliment, Vladimir Putin says the collapse of the Soviet Union was the greatest geopolitical disaster of the 20th century.

Airbus A380 prototype flies for the first time. The prototype departed runway 32L of Blagnac International Airport in Toulouse with a flight crew of six headed by test pilot Jacques Rosay, carrying 22 short tons (20 metric tons) of flight test instrumentation and water ballasts. The take-off weight of the aircraft was 421 tonnes (464 short tons); although this was only 75% of its maximum take-off weight, it was the heaviest take-off weight of any passenger airliner ever flown.
OS X 10.4 Tiger released by Apple.

Downing Street Memo revealed: "Bush wanted to remove Saddam, through military action, justified by the conjunction of terrorism and WMD. But the intelligence and facts were being fixed around the policy."
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 3.00
Bush signs supplemental spending bill, providing nearly $76 billion for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Dick Cheney: "I think they're in the last throes, if you will, of the insurgency."

The head of manned space program of the European Space Agency, ESA, who conducted talks with Russian space officials in Moscow, said that his agency would support the Kliper project, according to the Russian press. Nikolai Moiseev, Deputy Chief of Russian Space Agency, Roscosmos, was quoted as saying that the Kliper system would be adapted for launches from Russian facilities, as well as from the European space port in Kourou, French Guiana. According to Russian space officials, with the European support, the Kliper could fly "no later than" 2011 rather than "after 2012" launch date quoted previously.
The Army National Guard, a cornerstone of the U.S. force in Iraq, missed its recruiting goal for at least the ninth straight month in June and is nearly 19,000 soldiers below its authorized strength.

Seven boils are found downstream of the Salt Fork Dam near Cambridge in Guernsey County. This follows a single boil that was discovered in February and repaired with a gravel and rock filter. Experts order the lake level slowly lowered by 4 feet over several months. This is in addition to 1 foot of lowering in April. As the water level drops, park visitors will be unable to use Salt Fork's two beaches, six boat-launch ramps and nearly 470 docks.
Cheney revises "last throes" comment: "If you look at what the dictionary says about throes, it can still be a violent period the throes of a revolution.
Rumsfeld: 'Insurgencies tend to go on five, six, eight, 10, 12 years.'
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 3.25
Tesla Motors signs a contract with Group Lotus to produce "gliders" for the Tesla Roadster.
Death toll rises to 100 in suicide blast in Iraq
The Space Shuttle DISCOVERY is launched on its 31st flight. Mission STS-114.

Federated (Macy's) merges with May Department Stores. They announce the closing of Kaufmann's stores at Polaris Fashion Mall and Tuttle Crossing. The new Kaufmann's under construction at Eastland Mall will become a Macy's and the existing Macy's (formerly the Lazarus) in Eastland Mall will be closed.

NASA decides that the Space Shuttle will be replaced by a dual launch system derived from Space Shuttle components. A heavy lift rocket designed around the Space Shuttle External Tank will be 40 stories tall and capable of placing 125 tons into orbit. The unmanned rocket will use 5 space shuttle engines and cost $500,000,000 per launch, about the same as a typical space shuttle launch today.
Cindy Sheehan camps out at Bush's Texas ranch
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 3.50
The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter is launched towards Mars on a Delta II.
First launch of an Atlas V rocket.
8.2MP EOS 1D MKIIn released by Canon.
12.8 MP full frame EOS 5D released by Canon.

Category 4 hurricane Katrina strikes the gulf coast and passes just East of New Orleans. Biloxi and Gulfport are destroyed. A surge of water into Lake Ponchertrain tops the 17th Street and Industrial canals. The levi's soon fail and New Orleans begins to flood.
New Orleans is 80% under water. Thousands are dead. More than 12,000 people are in the Superdome which has lost power.
Nearly 1,000 Shiites killed in mass stampede during religious festival.
Mayor Nagin of New Orleans calls for an evacuation of the entire city. Conditions in the Superdome worsen, and armed gangs begin shooting at police and rescuers.

In New Orleans, as many as 45,000 refugees now occupy the Superdome and ajacent Convention Center. Law and order completely breaks down, armed thugs take over the Convention Center, and dozens of bodies (many elderly who succombed to the heat and lack of food and water) lay untended. Bloated bodies float in the feet of water surrounding the Superdome.
Evacuees from flooded New Orleans are housed at the Houston Astrodome.

In New Orleans, heavily armed troops secure the Superdome and Convention Center, a massive bus evacuation begins to empty the Superdome and food and water are supplied. Commercial airliners begin flying people out of the airport, which is filled with evacuees from the hospitals. President Bush tours the gulf coast, but is only able to fly over New Orleans due to poor security there. President Bush is pummelled with criticism for the poor response to the humanitarian disaster in New Orleans.

Fewer than 2000 people are left in the Superdome as the evacuation to Houston's Astrodome picks up speed. The water level in New Orleans stabilizes, but the Army Corps of Engineers estimates that it will take 80+ days to pump the city dry.
Damage estimates from hurricane Katrina reach $100 billion dollars with an estimated 10,000 dead.
Chief Justice William H. Rhenquist dies of thyroid cancer.

Levy repair is completed on the 17th Street and Industrial canals in New Orleans. Large pumps begin dewatering the city. The 82nd Airborne secures the French Quarter. Texas stops accepting new refugees as the number there tops 130,000 in shelters and 100,000 in hotels.

Colin Powell, on his pre-war speech to the UN: "It's a blot. I'm the one who presented it on behalf of the United States to the world, and [it] will always be a part of my record. It was painful. It's painful now."
IBM announces the IBM System Z9 computer.

NASA formally announces that the Crew Exploration Vehicle will fly in 2010, and will be used to visit the International Space Station. A moon landing, utilizing a second, heavy lift rocket, is scheduled for 2018.
The last of 50 LGM-118 Peacekeepers is removed from service after only 19 years after they were deployed.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 3.75

The Army is closing the books on one of the leanest recruiting years since it became an all-volunteer service three decades ago, missing its enlistment target by the largest margin since 1979 and raising questions about its plans for growth.
IAEA chief Mohamed El Baradei, who disputed U.S. pre-war assertions that Saddam HusseinÕs regime in Iraq had an active atomic weapons program, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
Iraqis vote to ratify draft constitution.
Last launch of Titan IV missile.
American military death toll reaches 2,000.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 4.00
Powerful new evidence emerged yesterday that the United States dropped massive quantities of white phosphorus on the Iraqi city of Fallujah during the attack on the city in November 2004.
U.S. Senate votes 79-19 to demand regular reports from the White House on progress towards a phased pullout of troops from Iraq.

Rep. John Murtha (D-PA) calls for U.S. troop withdrawal from Iraq: "The war in Iraq is not going as advertised. It is a flawed policy wrapped in illusion. The American public is way ahead of us. The United States and coalition troops have done all they can in Iraq, but it is time for a change in direction. Our military is suffering. The future of our country is at risk. We cannot continue on the present course."

General Motors announces it is closing four assembly plants and eliminating 30,000 jobs. Due to high gas prices, it's large SUV's and trucks aren't selling, and it is trying to pivot to more fuel efficient vehicles.
Visit Air Force Museum
National Strategy for Victory In Iraq unveiled by White House
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 4.25
Iraqis vote to elect members of Iraqi Assembly. The United Iraqi Alliance, the Shiite MuslimÕs most powerful party, won a majority of the seats.
Bush: '[M]uch of the intelligence turned out to be wrong.'
12 miners were killed in the Sago Mine disaster in West Virginia
Approximately 140 killed in Iraq, one of the bloodiest days since the U.S.-led invasion of the country in 2003.
US House Majority Leader Tom DeLay announced he would give up his effort to remain in his post, after he was indicted in Texas on a felony money-laundering charge
Apple introduces the MacBook Pro. It replaces the G4 PowerBook and features an Intel CPU.
Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf became Liberian president and first elected female president in Africa
Much to America's chagrin, Hamas won the majority of seats in the Palestinian Legislative Council.
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 4.50
Samuel Alito sworn in as US 110th Supreme Court justice
Egyptian ferry carrying over 1,400 people sunk in the Red sea
Syrian demonstrators over the publication of the Prophet Muhammad cartoons attacked the Danish and Norwegian embassies in Damascus
The 2006 Winter Olympics opened in Turin, Italy
Vice President Dick Cheney accidentally shot and wounded fellow hunter
Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas officially asked Hamas to form a government under leadership of Ismail Haniya
8.2 MP EOS 30D released by Canon.
NASA proposes names for the Project Constellation spacecraft. Crew Capsule: "Altair". Lunar Module: "Artemis".  Crew Launch Vehicle: "Ares I". Cargo Launch Vehicle: "Ares V".
USA and India signed a nuclear agreement during a visit of George W. Bush in India
Visit Air Force Museum
South Dakota signed into law a bill banning most abortions
The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter is inserted into orbit around Mars.
At least 250,000 people protested in France against a new labour laws.
The first World Down Syndrome Day.
About half a million people protested against plans to criminalize undocumented workers in Los Angeles, California
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 4.75
George's red Lincoln Town Car Designer is built in Wixom, Michigan.
Delphi announces 21 of its 26 plants will close, including plants in Columbus, Kettering, Dayton (2), Morraine and Sandusky.
A military C-5 cargo plane crashed near Dover Air Force Base in Delaware, all 14 people on board survived with non-life threatening injuries
Tornado killed at least 11 people in Tennessee, USA.
Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was declared permanently incapacitated, formally ending his premiership.
An earthquake with a magnitude of 7.7 jolted Kamchatka peninsula, Russia.
Porter Goss resigned as CIA director

Merit Financial - Subprime Lender in Washington State collapses. The company was started in 2001 by former Huskies football player Scott Greenlaw, who apparently ran the company like a frat house. This is the first of hundreds of subprime mortgage lenders to be listed on the now famous site ml-implode.com
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 5.00
Ray Nagin was re-elected mayor of New Orleans
Enron former Chief Executive Jeffrey Skilling and founder Kenneth Lay are found guilty of conspiracy and fraud
Goldman Sachs CEO replaced John Snow as the US treasury secretary
Montenegro declared independence
The US Senate blocked a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage
Ground is broken for I-270, 161, Sunbury road interchange improvement.
A 6.3 magnitude earthquake hit Japan, injuring 5
Warren Buffett donated about $37bn to Bill Gates' charitable foundation
Fed Funds Rate up 1/4 to 5.25
A car bomb in northeastern Baghdad marketplace killed 62 people and wounded 114 others
Chechen warlord Shami Basayev was killed by Russian security agents
After Lebanon's Hezbollah guerrillas kidnapped two Israeli soldiers, Israel launched attack on Lebanon
A tsunami triggered by an earthquake with a magnitude of 7.7 killed over 100 people on the island of Java, Indonesia
The Tesla Roadster concept is unveiled to the public for the first time.
Two car bombers in Kirkuk city courthouse and Baghdad market killed least 50 people and wounded 165 others.
