Floyd Landis from USA won the 2006 Tour de France, and Tiger Woods won the PGA Championship
Countrywide Financial announces that it's net income is up 27.6% over the same quarter last year.
Cuban leader Fidel Castro has temporarily handed power to his brother Raul.
Fed Funds Rate held steady at 5.25.
At least 34 people are killed and 108 others wounded by a suicide bomber in a holy Shiite city of Najaf, Iraq.
NASA announces that the Crew Exploration Vehicle will be called "Orion". Orion will be launched atop an Ares I rocket.
10.1 MP EOS 400D (Rebel Xti) released by Canon.
At least 19 people were killed and 30 others were wounded in explosion on an oil pipeline 100 miles south of Baghdad, Iraq

NASA announces that Lockheed Martin has been selected to construct the Orion Spacecraft. The Orion contract calls for Lockheed Martin to get $3.9 billion through 2013 for designing, developing, testing and evaluating the new craft and building two for initial flights into space. A second stage, from 2009 to 2019, provides $3.5 billion for building an unspecified number of manned ships to go to the space station and the moon, and some cargo-only versions for supplying the station. The contract also includes $750 million for engineering work to modify or improve the ships.
Steve Irwin, "Crocodile Hunter" was killed by a stingray barb that pierced his chest
Japan's Princess Kiko has given birth to a baby boy
At least 33 people died and 100 were wounded in dual explosions near a mosque in the western Indian city of Malegaon
USS Texas SSN-775 commissioned.
The Pope's speech at a German university angered Muslims around the world.

HP today introduced the HP 50g graphing calculator, which offers more connectivity options and greater configurability so users can share and work with mathematical data in the way that best suits their needs.
Military coup in Thailand.
23 died and 10 were injured when an elevated magnetic train crashed near Lathen in north-western Germany
Republican congressman Mark Foley resigned over an explicit e-mail scandal
Sony Pictures Animation releases Open Season. $197,309,027
A gunmen killed 5 young girls and wounded 6 more in Amish school in Pennsylvania
North Korea announced it had carried out a nuclear test
A small aircraft crashed into New York building, Yankees baseball pitcher Cory Lidle was killed, along with his flight instructor
Economist Muhammad Yunus and his Grameen Bank won the Nobel Peace Prize
US population reaches 300 million people
First operational launch of a Soyuz-2 rocket. MetOp-A is Europe's first polar orbiting satellite used for operational meteorology.
Fed Funds Rate held steady at 5.25
Countrywide Financial announces that it is cutting 2500 jobs (5%) amidst a sudden slump in loan origination volume.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said he will not run for 3rd term
High speed rail - Amtrak discontinues Metroliner service as Acela Express service takes over.
Jack Nicklaus dots the "I" at Ohio Stadium.
Former South African president Pieter Willem Botha died in age of 90
Last contact with the Mars Surveyor orbiter around Mars.
Steve Fossett flies non-stop for 25,766 miles to encircle the earth without landing.
Former Iraqi president Saddam Hussein was sentenced to death by hanging
Anne Ryan Fisher dies at the age of 102.
Democrats win the 2006 US midterm elections and won control of both House of Representatives and the Senate
Windows Vista released by Microsoft
Donald Rumsfeld resigns as US defense secretary
Former KGB spy Alexander Litvinenko dies in a London hospital after he was poisoned with polonium-210
Michael Crichton publishes "Next"
Three car bombs exploded in Baghdad, Iraq, killing at least 50 people and wounded 90 others
Hugo Chavez was re-elected Venezuela's president
Chile's former dictator Augusto Pinochet died in age of 91
Java SE 6 released.
"You" was named as Time magazine's Person of the Year for the growth and influence of user-generated content on the internet
Robert gates sworn in as the new US Defence Secretary
A Libyan court sentenced five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor to death for knowingly infecting hundreds of Libyan children with HIV
Former US president Gerald Ford died at age of 93
Ted Strickland becomes Governor of Ohio.
Fed Funds Rate held steady at 5.25

Global banking giant HSBC Holdings (HBC), the third largest subprime lender in the U.S., disclosed on Feb. 7 that full-year 2006 impairment charges at its U.S. mortgage unit would be 20% higher than the $8.8 billion or so that analysts had been projecting.

New Century Financial (NEW), the nation's second largest lender to subprime borrowers, said it expected to report a loss for the fourth quarter, and that it would have to restate its financial results for the first three quarters of 2006.
Paul Tibbets, the pilot of the US bomber that dropped the first atomic bomb on Japan on Aug 6, 1945, died on Thursday at age 92, a newspaper reported.
BusinessWeek Magazine publishes an article entitled "Subprime Time Bomb", beginning mainstream press interest in the issue.
Another subprime lender, ResMAE, filed for bankruptcy on Feb. 13, bringing the total failures to 21 since December.
The DOW falls 417 points as fears over slowing international growth overwhelm the market.

The original Wendy's Restaurant at 257 East Broad Street closes. It opened in 1969, and lost money after COSI moved from across the street to its new location on the Central High School campus in 1999.
Fed Funds Rate held steady at 5.25
USS Hawaii SSN-776 commissioned.
Anne Rose Campbell is born.
The last Lincoln Town Car rolls off the assembly line at the Wixom, Michigan plant.
Sony Pictures Animation releases Surfs Up. $149,044,471

Merrill Lynch threatens to sell $800 million of mortgage securities seized from Bear Stearns Cos. Hedge funds, creating a market panic because this would cause the value of the funds to be actually "marked to market" rather than "marked to model".
iPhone iOS 1 released by Apple.
iPhone released by Apple
Visit Air Force Museum

In a letter sent to investors, Bear Stearns Asset Management reported that its Bear Stearns High-Grade Structured Credit Fund had lost more than 90% of its value, while the Bear Stearns High-Grade Structured Credit Enhanced Leveraged Fund had lost virtually all of its investor capital. The larger Structured Credit Fund had around $1 billion, while the Enhanced Leveraged Fund, which was less than a year old, had nearly $600 million in investor capital.
The two Bear Stearns mortgage backed hedge funds filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy. Bear Stearns effectively wound down the funds and liquidated all of its holdings.
The Mars Phoenix lander is launched towards Mars on a Delta II rocket.
The DOW falls 387 points as credit fears overwhelm the market.
Countrywide Financial taps an 11 billion dollar line of credit as losses in subprime mortgages mount.

Countrywide Financial depositors stand in line outside Los Angeles bank branches to withdraw their money. Countrywide announces that it will only make "conforming" loans from now on, essentially exiting the subprime lending business and calling its future viability into question.
10.1 MP EOS 40D released by Canon.
The Canon Powershot A720 8.0 MP, image stabilized 6x optical zoom, Digic III camera is released.
SS Norway, formally SS France, is scrapped.

New leaks out that Citigroup, JP Morgan and Bank of America are planning to create a $75 billion superfund to purchase SIV assets, primarily mortgage-backed securites, that have no value on the open market. This is an attempt to save bank balance sheets from having to incur losses by artificially maintaining the value of these now worthless securities.

Citigroup reports a stunning loss due to the subprime collapse. Citigroup said that it was writing down $3.55 billion in the third quarter, including $1.35 billion on leveraged loans, $1.56 billion on CDO's and $640 million on bad trading bets. Analysts call for CEO Charles O. Prince III to resign.
IntelliJ 7 released.

JP Morgan Chase reported that it was taking an overall writedown of $1.8 billion in the quarter. Included in that were $1.3 billion related to leveraged loans, or those meant to finance leveraged buyouts, and about $500 million for losses related to collateralized debt obligations and its mortgage pipeline.

Merrill Chief Executive Officer Stan O'Neal told shareholders yesterday that the New York-based firm had a loss of $2.24 billion, the biggest in its 93-year history, after reducing the value of mortgages and asset-backed bonds.

Former Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan doubts that the SIV "superfund" proposed by Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson will work. He feels it is better to let the market price the securites and take the losses now.

Motorists in the Rt. 161 and I-270 area on the Northeast Side this morning can expect to drive on a redesigned ramp that includes a 440-foot-long tunnel and some other new sections of the Northeast Expressway Transformation project. The Ohio Department of Transportation planned to open the Rt. 161 west ramp to I-270 south last night. The ramp includes the tunnel, the first of its kind in central Ohio. In addition to the new ramp and tunnel, the westbound lanes of the rebuilt interchange at Sunbury Road and Rt. 161 also were expected to open last night. The interchange is similar to the one at Sawmill Road and I-270.
New tunnel is opened at the Rt. I-270, 161 Sunbury road interchange improvement.
OS X 10.5 Leopard released by Apple.
The Fed cuts the funds rate another 1/4 point, down to 4.50.
Custom home builder C.V. Perry files for bankruptcy.
Demolition of Jubilee Foods at 912 North High Street begins.
21.1 MP  full frame EOS 1Ds Mark III release (scheduled as of 11/8/07) by Canon.
Seattle-based WaMu, one of the nation’s largest home lenders, announced a major restructuring of its mortgage-related businesses closing many mortgage offices and laying off 3000 workers.
The Delphi plant on West Broad Street is closed. The remaining 426 workers, including 273 hourly employees will be laid off. In 2006, 500 workers at the plant took an early buyout and retired.
Stock markets around the world plunge; the U.S. markets are closed on Monday for a holiday.
The Federal Reserve executes an emergency 0.75% rate cut to send the Federal Funds rate down to 3.5%.
USS New Hampshire SSN-778 commissioned.
IBM announces the IBM System z10 computer.
The first Tesla Roadster is delivered to Elon Musk.
The first European Space Agency Automated Transfer Vehicle, a cargo spacecraft for the International Space Station, launches from Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana.
The Federal Reserve bails out Bear Stearns with a $29 billion dollar loan.
General production of the Tesla Roadster begins.
J.P. Morgan buys Bear Stearns for a mere $2/share, 1/10th the market value a week ago.
Bhutan holds its first-ever general elections following the adoption of a new Constitution which changed the country from an absolute monarchy to a multiparty democracy.

Employees reacted with shock, anger and tears to Washington Mutual’s announcement Tuesday that it will lay off 3,000 workers and close its home-loan centers, while local mortgage brokers said they are surprised and concerned the company will no longer accept loans from them.
Wendy's International is sold to Nelson Peltz, the owner of Arby's Restaurants. It has been six years since Dave Thomas died. Thomas' daughter Wendy complains bitterly about the deal.

John H. McConnell dies at age 84. McConnell founded Worthington Industries in 1955, which grew to be a $3 billion dollar company with 8,000 employees. McConnell payed for the McConnell Heart Center at Riverside Hospital and was the majority owner of the Columbus Blue Jackets hockey team.
The Chaitén volcano in Chile enters a new eruptive phase for the first time since around 1640.
Cyclone Nargis passes through Myanmar, killing more than 138,000 people.
USS North Carolina SSN-777 commissioned.
An earthquake measuring 7.9 on the moment magnitude scale strikes Sichuan, China, killing an estimated 87,000 people.
The Mars Phoenix lander successfully lands on Mars.
The Legislature Parliament of Nepal votes overwhelmingly in favor of abolishing the country's 240-year-old monarchy, turning the country into a republic.
Bobb Chevrolet closes its new car dealership.
iPhone 3G released by Apple.
The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope is launched.
The Tesla Model S is announced in a press release.
Ron Rush Lincoln Mercury at 2350 Morse Road closes its doors after accepting a buyout from Ford. It opened there in the 1960's.
Íngrid Betancourt and 14 other hostages are rescued from FARC rebels by Colombian security forces
IndyMac is siezed by Federal Bank Regulators after panicked depositors line up outside its branches.
iOS 2 released by Apple.
Radovan Karadžić, the first president of the Republika Srpska, is arrested in Belgrade, Serbia, on allegations of war crimes, following a 12-year-long manhunt.
Javascript ECMAScript 4 is abandoned.
Eleven mountaineers from international expeditions die on K2, the second-highest mountain on Earth in the worst single accident in the history of K2 mountaineering.
Georgia invades the breakaway state of South Ossetia, sparking a war with Russia as the latter intervenes in support of the separatists in both South Ossetia and Abkhazia.
The Summer Olympics open in Beijing, China.

High Street fronting the Huntington Center has been reopened after a falling pane of glass prompted police to seal off a stretch of the busy downtown Columbus thoroughfare this morning. The Columbus Division of Police said no injuries were reported from the falling glass. Officials didnÕt know how far the pane fell or why it tumbled to the street, but police said it was reported to them that a bird had struck the window.
The final minor league baseball game is played at Cooper Stadium (formerly Red Bird Stadium), after 76 continuous years of play.
PhoneGap is developed as a group project at iPhone Dev Camp in San Francisco
Google Chrome is released

The Federal Government siezes Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Government takes control of the mortgage giants, putting the liability of more than $5 trillion of mortgages onto the backs of U.S. taxpayers.
George's first tweet.

The proton beam is circulated for the first time in the Large Hadron Collider, the world's largest and highest-energy particle accelerator, located at CERN, near Geneva, under the Franco-Swiss border.
Lehman Brothers Says it's Actively Looking to be sold. Shares of the investment bank plunge 45% as traders feared it was having a difficult time finding a suitor.
Hurricane Ike makes landfall in Galveston, Texas

The remnants of Hurricane Ike strike Central Ohio around 4pm, with high winds causing major tree damage and power outages. There were several official winds reported at 75 miles per hour, or hurricane force including in Columbus.  It is estimated that Ike did more than 1 billion dollars damage in the Buckeye state, and was the costliest storm since the Xenia tornado in 1974. In Ohio, more than 2.5 million people lost power due to winds associated with Ike, and sadly 7 people lost their lives due to storm-related deaths.
Bank of America Says it Will Buy Merrill Lynch for $29 a Share. After walking away from Lehman Brothers, the bank said it would pay $50 billion for the brokerage house.

Lehman Brothers Files for Bankruptcy. This is the largest bankruptcy filing in the history of the United States, at $639 billion. After a weekend of feverish negotiations, potential buyers such as Bank of America (BAC: 22.79, +1.92, +9.19%) and Barclays (BCS: 15.75, +0.55, +3.61%) walk away, leaving Lehman and its CEO, Dick Fuld, with basically no other options.

Government Announces $85 Billion Emergency Loan to Rescue AIG. Feds say a failure of the company could be devastating to the financial markets as well as the economy. This is in exchange for a nearly 80% equity stake in the company.

Barclays Makes Deal With Lehman to Buy North American Banking Division. The British bank, which had passed on buying Lehman before it filed for bankruptcy, picks up the failed firm's North American investment banking and trading operations for $250 million.
Canon EOS 5D Mark II announced by Canon.

Bush Administration Announces Bailout Plan to Confront Crisis. Congress is asked to give the administration new powers to execute a plan that could cost taxpayers billions to buy toxic debt and bad mortgages. Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke and Treasury Secretary Paulson hold meetings with lawmakers over weekend to convince them to approve the measures.

Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley to Become Bank Holding Companies. The Federal Reserve approves transformation of Morgan Stanley (MS: 18.10, +8.42, +86.98%) and Goldman Sachs (GS: 111.00, +22.20, +25.00%) into bank holding companies from investment banks in order to increase oversight and allow them to access the Fed's discount window.

Bernanke and Paulson Testify on Capital Hill on Bailout. The Fed Chairman says, 'If financial conditions fail to improve for a protracted period, the implications for the broader economy could be quite adverse.'
Google announces the Android Operating System.

Washington Mutual Becomes Largest Thrift Failure With $307 Billion in Assets. JPMorgan (JPM: 41.99, +0.35, +0.84%) agrees to pay $1.9 billion for the banking operations, but doesn't take ownership of the holding company.

Citigroup Acquires Wachovia's Banking Operations. The FDIC helps broker a deal allowing Citigroup (C: 15.75, +1.64, +11.62%) to buy the bulk of Wachovia's (WB: 5.85, +0.70, +13.59%) banking operations for $2.1 billion in stock. At the same time, several European banks are nationalized or infused with huge amounts of cash to keep them running.

Bailout Package Put Up for House Vote Is Rejected 228-205. The $700 billion rescue bill is defeated in the House of Representatives, despite of warnings from the president, as well as leaders in both parties, that the legislation is necessary to stave off a meltdown.

Dow Falls 777.68 Points; Largest One-Day Point Drop in History. The index sees its largest one-day point loss ever after the House votes down the rescue plan. The S&P 500 has its largest point drop ever and second-largest percentage drop in history.
Global financial crisis: U.S. President George W. Bush signs the revised Emergency Economic Stabilization Act into law, creating a 700 billion dollar Treasury fund to purchase failing bank assets.
Canon 15.1 MP EOS 50D released by Canon.
Apple introduces the second generation MacBook Pro. It features an aluminum unibody.
The Android Operating System is released to the public.
The Rolling Hills Mall in Akron closes.
Satoshi Nakamoto published "Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System"
Last contact with the Mars Phoenix lander.
IntelliJ 8 released.

Graham Ford, 707 West Broad Street, closes its doors. It opened there in 1971. Other dealerships to close or move out of downtown in recent years include Columbus Cadillac on East Long Street, Jack Schmidt Oldsmobile and Famley Oestreicher Chrysler Dodge Plymouth on East Main Street, Bob White Oldsmobile, Winders Chevrolet, Kaufman Pontiac and Hutchins Chrysler Plymouth, which all operated in the Short North, and Hugh White Honda on East Broad Street.
The Columbus Crew wins the MLS championship, beating the New York Red Bulls 3-1 at the Home Depot Center in Carson, California.
Members of Lashkar-e-Taiba carry out four days of coordinated bombing and shooting attacks across Mumbai, killing 164 people.
Intel announces Nehelem based on 45 nanometer technology.

As the credit crisis took hold of Wall Street, Citigroup announced 50,000 job cuts—more than half of a which were the result of planned divestitures. At the time, Citigroup CEO Vikram Pandit, who’d been in his job less than a year, said “there is nothing easy about these decisions and the impact on our people. We do this because we must and not because we want to.”
Intel releases the Core i7 processor.
Bernard Madoff is arrested after his $65 billion dollar investment fund is revealed to be a Ponzi Scheme. His 4,800 investors lose their money and he goes to jail.

The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda finds Théoneste Bagosora and two other senior Rwandan army officers guilty of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes and sentences them to life imprisonment for their role in the Rwandan genocide.
GM's Morraine Truck Assembly Plant in Dayton shuts down, throwing 2400 out of work.
The first block of the blockchain of the decentralized payment system Bitcoin, called the Genesis block, was established by the creator of the system, Satoshi Nakamoto.
US Airways Flight 1549 ditches in the Hudson River in an accident that is known to be the Miracle on the Hudson. Over 155 people on board are rescued.
Barack Obama is sworn in as the 44th President of the United States, becoming the first African-American to hold the office.
The Icelandic government and banking system collapse; Prime Minister Geir Haarde immediately resigns.

Circuit City , which had been the nation’s No. 2 electronics retailer, had been hit by historically low holiday sales in 2008 and the credit crunch, which restricted its ability to borrow. The company was in bankruptcy when it announced the closing of its 567 stores, eliminating all of its 34,000 jobs.
Former Serbian president Milan Milutinović is acquitted by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia regarding war crimes during the Kosovo War.

General Motors layed off 50,000 wokers as it prepared to enter Chapter 11 bankruptcy and sought federal aid. The car company also closed five factories in conjunction with the cuts and announced plans to phased out its Hummer brand and scale back its Pontiac line. At the time, the automaker was reeling from the global recession and competition from Japanese manufacturers.
NASA's Kepler Mission, a space photometer that will search for extrasolar planets in the Milky Way galaxy, is launched from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station.
In Fargo, North Dakota the Red River crests at 40.84 feet, causing massive flooding.
Uber is founded in San Francisco California by Travis Kalanick.

North Korea launches a rocket from its Tonghae Satellite Launching Ground, which it says is carrying the Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2 satellite, prompting an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council.

Baby Shaker' game pulled from Apple's iPhone App Store. The public relations debacle hurts Apple stock, and sparks Steve Jobs to tell his app reviewer "You are stupid, and you hire stupid people." Al Gore, a board member, also asked Apple's approval manager for their process that could let something like this through.
Android 1.5 Cupcake released by Google
Chrysler declares bankruptcy.
The last Oldsmobile, an Alero, rolls off the assembly line. The Oldsmobile brand is retired.
Byers Dublin Dodge, 6851 Village Pkwy., Dublin is closed by Chrysler as part of its bankruptcy.
General Motors announces that 1100 dealerships will be dropped from its network. The dealerships must be closed by October, 2010.
North Korea announces that it has conducted a second successful nuclear test in North Hamgyong Province. The United Nations Security Council condemns the reported test.
General Motors discontinues the Hummer brand.
General Motors files for bankruptcy.
General Motors announces the sale of the Saturn Group to Penske Automotive. The sale eventually falls through, and the Saturn brand is discontinued.
With its sale to Fiat blessed by the Supreme Court, Chrysler exits bankruptcy.
The outbreak of the H1N1 influenza strain, commonly referred to as "swine flu", is deemed a global pandemic.
iOS 3 released by Apple.
Bernard Madoff is sentenced to 150 years in prison for swindling 24,000 investors out of $65 billion in a ponzi scheme.
General Motors exits bankruptcy as the "New GM", retaining the profitable assets of the old GM. The "Old GM" is held by Motors Liquidation Company.

Citigroup reports a profit of $4.28 billion by using an accounting trick to record a $6.7 billion dollar gain from its purchase of Smith Barney. Its banking business lost $2.4 billion as credit costs exploded. The sick bank required a $45 billion bailout last fall from the Treasury when it collapsed.
The Islamic extremist group Boko Haram initiates an uprising in Bauchi State, Nigeria and quickly spreads throughout the northern part of the country.
Typhoon Morakot hits Taiwan, killing 673 and stranding more than 1,000 via the worst flooding on the island in half a century.
OS X 10.6 Snow Leopard released by Apple.
Android 1.6 Donut released by Google
Sony Pictures Animation releases Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs. $243,006,126
A 7.6 Mw earthquake strikes Sumatra, Indonesia, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), leaving at least 1,115 people dead.
Intel releases the Core i5 processor.
Production of General Motors Saturn brand vehicles ends.
18.0 MP EOS 7D released by Canon.
The aircraft carrier CVN-77 George H. W. Bush is commissioned.
Paleontologists announce the discovery of an Ardipithecus ramidus fossil skeleton, deeming it the oldest remains of a human ancestor yet found.
Windows 7 released by Microsoft
Android 2.1 Eclair released by Google
Ares IX was launched carrying a boilerplate command module.
First version of what would become NodeJS was introduced by Ryan Dahl at the first European JSConf. Originally called io.js
Having analyzed the data from the LCROSS lunar impact, NASA announces that it has found a "significant" quantity of water in the Moon's Cabeus crater.
The keel of the USS Gerald Ford CVN-78 aircraft carrier is laid down. It is the first in its class, and features a higher power, electrical design.
The last General Motors Pontiac brand vehicle rolls off the assembly line.
The UNFCCC's 2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference is held in Copenhagen, Denmark.
IntelliJ 9 released.
A series of attacks in Baghdad, Iraq kill at least 127 people and injure at least 448 more.
Visit Air Force Museum
Canon EOS 1D Mark IV released by Canon.
Javascript ECMAScript 5 released.
The tallest man-made structure to date, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, is officially opened.
Earthquake in Haiti kills 230,000 people and leaves more than a million homeless.
The npm package manager for NodeJS is introduced.
Intel releases the Core i3 processor.
The sculpture L'Homme qui marche I by Alberto Giacometti sells in London for £65 million (US$103.7 million), setting a new world record for a work of art sold at auction.
George, Zach and Alex go to YMCA Camp Willson for a Y-Tribes winter campout.
George gets his first Smart Phone, an Android device with a slide out keyboard.
Two trains collide in the Halle train collision in Halle, Belgium, killing 19 and injuring 171 people.
The cupola is installed on the International Space Station by the crew of the Space Shuttle Endeavour.
General Motors completes the sale of Saab to Spyker Automotive.
An 8.8-magnitude earthquake occurs in Chile, triggering a tsunami over the Pacific and killing at least 525.
Last contact with the Mars Spirit Rover
North Korea sinks the RKS Cheonan off the west coast near Baengnyeong Island in the Yellow Sea, killing 46 seamen.
USS New Mexico SSN-779 commissioned.

First launch of the Minotaur IV rocket, which consists of four stages and is capable of placing 3,825 lb of payload into a Low Earth orbit. It uses the first three stages of the Peacekeeper missile, combined with a new upper stage.
The President of Poland, Lech Kaczyński, is among 96 killed when their airplane crashes near Smolensk, Russia.
Volcanic ash from one of several eruptions beneath Mount Eyjafjallajökull, an ice cap in Iceland, begins to disrupt air traffic across northern and western Europe.

The Deepwater Horizon oil drilling platform explodes in the Gulf of Mexico, killing 11 workers. The resulting Horizon oil spill, one of the largest in history, spreads for several months, damaging the waters and the United States coastline, and prompting international debate and doubt about the practice and procedures of offshore drilling.

Standard & Poor's downgrades Greece's sovereign credit rating to junk 4 days after the activation of a €45-billion EU–IMF bailout, triggering the decline of stock markets worldwide and of the euro's value, and furthering a European sovereign debt crisis.
Hewlett Packard buys Palm.
The eurozone and the International Monetary Fund agree to a €110 billion bailout package for Greece. The package involves sharp Greek austerity measures.
George, Zach and Alex go to YMCA Camp Oty-Okwa for a Y-Tribes spring campout.
Nude, Green Leaves and Bust by Pablo Picasso sells in New York for US$106.5 million, setting another new world record for a work of art sold at auction.
The 2010 Flash Crash, a trillion-dollar stock market crash, occurs over 36 minutes, initiated by a series of automated trading programs in a feedback loop.
Protests in Bangkok, Thailand, end with a bloody military crackdown, killing 91 and injuring more than 2,100.
Android 2.2 Froyo released by Google.
Tesla Motors announces it will build the Model S in the abandoned Nummi assembly plant in Fremont, CA.
SpaceX launches the first Falcon 9 rocket.
iOS 4 released by Apple.
iPhone 4 released by Apple
Julia Gillard is elected unopposed in a Labor Party leadership ballot and sworn in as the first female Prime Minister of Australia following the resignation of Kevin Rudd.
Illumination Animation releases Despicable Me. $543 million

WikiLeaks, an online publisher of anonymous, covert, and classified material, leaks to the public over 90,000 internal reports about the United States-led involvement in the War in Afghanistan from 2004 to 2010.
Approximately one-fifth of Pakistan's total land area was affected by floods, killing 2000 and affecting 20,000,000 people.
USS Missouri SSN-780 commissioned.
Construction begins on the replacement of the I-17 Jeremiah Morrow Bridge across the Little Miami River valley.
33 miners in the San José copper mine in the Atacama desert found themselves trapped in a collapsed shaft 2,300 ft. (700 m) under the earth.
The EOS 60D released by Canon.
Germany pays war reparations for World War I.
The Chilean miners trapped at the San Jose copper mine are brought to the surface.
Microsoft introduces Windows Phone 7, the first Windows Phone O/S.
The International Space Station surpasses the record for the longest continuous human occupation of space, having been continuously inhabited since November 2, 2000 (3641 days).
An earthquake and consequent tsunami off the coast of Sumatra, Indonesia, kills over 400 people and leaves hundreds missing.
General Motors phases out the Pontiac brand.
The G-20 summit is held in Seoul, South Korea. Korea becomes the first non-G8 nation to host a G-20 leaders summit.
Burmese opposition politician Aung San Suu Kyi is released from her house arrest after being incarcerated since 1989.
Eurozone countries agree to a rescue package for the Republic of Ireland from the European Financial Stability Facility in response to the country's financial crisis.

North Korea shells Yeonpyeong Island, prompting a military response by South Korea. The incident causes an escalation of tension on the Korean Peninsula and prompts widespread international condemnation. The United Nations declares it to be one of the most serious incidents since the end of the Korean War.
WikiLeaks releases a collection of more than 250,000 American diplomatic cables, including 100,000 marked "secret" or "confidential".
Android 2.3 Gingerbread released by Google
Intellij 10 released.
The attempted suicide of Mohamed Bouazizi, a street vendor in Tunisia, triggers the Tunisian Revolution and the wider Arab Spring throughout the Arab world.
The first total lunar eclipse to occur on the day of the Northern winter solstice and Southern summer solstice since 1638 takes place.
The last Mercury Grand Marquis rolls off the Ford assembly line. The Mercury brand is retired by Ford.
U.S. Representative Gabrielle Giffords and eighteen others were shot during a constituent meeting held in a supermarket parking lot in Casas Adobes, Arizona, in the Tucson metropolitan area.
John Kasich becomes Governor of Ohio.
Intel announces Sandy Bridge based on 32 nanometer technology.
Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak resigned and handed over power to the military after massive anti-government protests in Tahrir Square, Cairo.
Android 3.0 Honeycomb released by Google.
The WSR-88D "NexRad" at Vance Air Force Base in Enid, Oklahoma is the first operational WSR-88D modified to utilize dual polarization technology.
Google Chrome v10
An earthquake and Tsunami hits Japan near Tōhoku, causing meltdowns at three reactors in the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant complex.
Motors Liquidation Company exists bankrupty. MLC was formed to handle the Chapter 11 bankruptcy of General Motors.
Illumination Animation releases Hop $184 million

A Tornado outbreak across the Southern States kills over 337 people and destroys 10,000 homes and buildings. At around 5:10 p.m. CDT, a very large and exceptionally destructive tornado struck Tuscaloosa, Alabama. About 40 minutes later, a tornado from the same parent supercell, possibly the same tornado, struck the northern suburbs of Birmingham, Alabama.
Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, are married at Westminster Abbey in London.
npm 2.0.0 released
Osama Bin Ladin is killed by Navy Seals in Abbottabad, Pakistan.
U.S. President Barack Obama announces that Osama bin Laden, the founder and leader of the militant group Al-Qaeda, was killed.
Groundbreaking for the George Voinovich bridge to replace the worn out Innerbelt Bridge across the industrial flats in Cleveland, Oh.
Former Bosnian Serb Army commander Ratko Mladić, wanted for genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity, is arrested in Serbia.
The last Cadillac DTS rolls off GM's Detroit Hamtramck assembly line.
Preparations begin for expected major flooding along the Missouri River in North Dakota.
The Dakota Dunes are evacuated. Residents are told to expect to be out of their homes for two months.
The Ft. Calhoun Nuclear Plant is surrounded by water and suffers a fire in its switch room, prompting a level 2 alert by the nuclear regulatory commission.
Fort Peck dam in Nebraska on the upper Missouri river reaches a record level of 2234 feet above sea level, surpassing the previous record set in 1975, with a record flow of 65,000 CFS.
Oahe Dam releases 160,000 cubic feet per second into the Missouri River with 200,000 cubic feet per second inflow.
Yes releases "Fly From Here"
Javascript ECMAScript 5.1 released.
The National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency reported that 265 square miles (690 km2) of Nebraska has been inundated by floods on the Missouri and the Platte River.
OS X 10.7 Lion released by Apple.
Linux 3.0 released.
Anders Behring Breivik kills 77 people at a youth camp on the small Norwegian island of Utoya.
Java SE 7 released.
Sony Pictures Animation releases The Smurfs Movie. $563,749,323
Juno, the first solar-powered spacecraft on a mission to Jupiter, is launched from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station.

A magnitude 5.8 earthquake hit the Piedmont region of Virginia at 1:51 pm. The epicenter, in Louisa County, was 38 mi northwest of Richmond. The Washington Monument was closed until 2014 due to damage. In Columbus the Huntington Center was briefly evacuated, and occupants on the upper floors of the Rhodes State Office Tower and the Vern Riffe State Office Tower reported feeling strong shaking. George felt the earthquake in his car while stopped at a light on the northbound I-71 exit ramp to Morse Road.
India and Bangladesh sign a pact to end their 40-year border demarcation dispute.
Bank of America lays off 30,000 workers.

Occupy Wall Street holds its first protest in Zuccotti Park, located in New York City's Wall Street financial district, receiving global attention and spawning the Occupy movement against social and economic inequality worldwide.
China launches Tiangong-1, it's first space station.
The last Lincoln Town Car rolls off the Ford assembly line.
Intel announces Ivy Bridge based on 22 nanometer technology.
Adobe PhoneGap code donated to the Apache Foundation to create Apache Cordova
Steve Jobs, CEO of Apple, dies of cancer.
iOS 5 released by Apple.
Canon EOS 1D-X released by Canon.
Muammar Gaddafi is killed by rebels after taking shelter in a drainage ditch in Misrata.

After an emergency meeting in Brussels, the European Union announces an agreement to tackle the European sovereign debt crisis which includes a writedown of 50% of Greek bonds, a recapitalisation of European banks and an increase of the bailout fund of the European Financial Stability Facility totaling to €1 trillion.
USS California SSN-781 commissioned.
Shenzhou 8, unmanned, docks with Tiangong-1.
The Mars Curiosity rover is launched towards Mars on an Atlas V rocket.
Sony Pictures Animation releases Arthur Christmas. $147,419,472
The United Kingdom severs diplomatic relations with Iran and expels diplomats, less than 24 hours after protesters attacked the British embassy in Tehran.
IntelliJ 11 released.
A hot air balloon crashes near Carterton, New Zealand, killing all 11 people on board.
The passenger cruise ship Costa Concordia sinks off the coast of Italy due to the captain Francesco Schettino's negligence and irresponsibility. There are 32 confirmed deaths.
Tesla Roadster production ceases after the last of the original 2500 Lotus gliders was sold.
Illumination Animation releases Doctor Suess' The Lorax. $348 million

The Diamond Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II marks the 60th anniversary of her accession to the thrones of the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, and the 60th anniversary of her becoming Head of the Commonwealth.
Greek government-debt crisis: Eurozone finance ministers reach an agreement on a second, €130-billion Greek bailout.

In Sanford, Florida, George Zimmerman fatally shot Trayvon Martin, a 17-year-old African American high school student. Zimmerman, a 28-year-old mixed race Hispanic man was the neighborhood watch coordinator for the gated community where Martin was temporarily living and where the shooting took place.
The Raspberry Pi computer is released.
George's first day at OCLC.
Canon EOS 5D Mark III released by Canon.
After 246 years since its first publication, the Encyclopædia Britannica discontinues its print edition.
Google releases Golang 1, the Go programming language.

Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3, a North Korean Earth observation satellite, explodes shortly after launch. The United States and other countries had called the impending launch a violation of United Nations Security Council demands.[12] The launch was planned to mark the centenary of the birth of Kim Il-sung, the founder of the republic.
A pastel version of The Scream, by the Norwegian painter Edvard Munch, sells for US$120 million in a New York City auction, setting a new world record for an auctioned work of art
Vladimir Putin is elected President of Russia.
President Obama endorses gay marriage in an interview with ABC news.
Tokyo Skytree, the tallest self-supporting tower in the world at 634 metres high, is opened to the public.
Hewlett Packard announces plans to lay off approximately 27,000 employees, after posting a profit decline of 31% in the second quarter of 2012.
USS Mississippi SSN-782 commissioned.
Jack Blount is chosen as OCLC's new CEO.
Apple introduces the third generation of MacBook Pros. It introduced the Retina Display.

Shenzhou 9, a Chinese spacecraft carrying three Chinese astronauts, including the first-ever female, docks manually with orbiting module Tiangong-1, making them the third country, after the United States and Russia, to successfully perform the mission.
OCLC's board reverses course. Jack Blount is out and Jay Jordan resumes in the CEO position.
The Tesla Model S is released for sale.
Penn State assistant coach Jerry Sandusky was found guilty on 45 counts of molesting children and sentenced to 60 years in prison.
Google Chrome v20
The Supreme Court upholds the Affordable Care Act.
Supreme Court Upholds Health Care Law, 5-4, in Victory for Obama.
CERN announces the discovery of a new particle with properties consistent with the Higgs boson after experiments at the Large Hadron Collider.
Android 4.1 Jelly Bean released by Google.
A mass shooting occurred inside a Century 16 movie theater in Aurora, Colorado. Twelve people were killed and seventy others were injured,
Adobe PhoneGap 2.0 released.
OS X 10.8 Mountain Lion released by Apple.
The Summer Olympics open in London, England.
In the worst power outage in world history, the 2012 India blackouts leave 620 million people without power.
George officially starts at OCLC.
The Mars Curiosity rover successfully lands on Mars.

While making remarks on rape and abortion on August 19, 2012, Missouri GOP Senate candidate Todd Akin made the claim that women victims of what he described as "legitimate rape" rarely experience pregnancy from rape.
Football: Jonathan Alder at TWHS 28-6 loss
IBM announces the System zEnterprise computer.
Hurricane Isaac strikes Louisiana.
Sony Pictures Animation releases The Pirates! In an Adventure With Scientists! $123,054,041

Football: TWHS at Westerville Central 0-41 loss

Canada officially cuts diplomatic ties with Iran by closing its embassy in Tehran, and orders the expulsion of Iranian diplomats from Ottawa, over support for Syria, nuclear plans and human rights abuses.
An assault in Benghazi, widely blamed on a group with suspected links to al-Qaeda, killed U.S. Ambassador Chris Stephens and three other Americans.

Austrian skydiver Felix Baumgartner becomes the first person to break the sound barrier without any machine assistance during a record space dive out of the Red Bull Stratos helium-filled balloon from 128,000 ft equaling 24 miles (39 km) over Roswell, New Mexico in the United States.
Seven paintings worth $25 million are stolen from the Kunsthal in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
Football: TWHS at Hilliard Davidson 14-42 loss
Sandy developed from a tropical wave in the western Caribbean Sea.
The Olentangy River practically runs dry as drought grips the area.
Indiana Republican Senate candidate Richard Mourdock said that when a woman is impregnated during a rape “it’s something God intended.”
Sandy hits Cuba as a Category 3 hurricane.
Windows 8 released by Microsoft
Football: Olentangy Liberty at TWHS 17-35 loss

Sandy moved ashore near Brigantine, New Jersey, just to the northeast of Atlantic City, as a post-tropical cyclone with hurricane-force winds. Its storm surge hit New York City flooding streets, tunnels and subway lines and cutting power in and around the city. Damage in the United States amounted to $71.4 billion.
Windows Phone 7 is replaced by Windows Phone 8
Barack Obama is reelected President of the United States.
IntelliJ 12 released.
In Qatar, the UN Climate Change Conference agrees to extend the Kyoto Protocol until 2020
North Korea launches its first satellite. Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2 weighed 220 lbs. The launcher was the Unha-3.
Armed with a high-powered rifle, 20-year-old Adam Lanza forced his way into Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., and shot dead 20 children — all ages 6 and 7 — and six staff members.
242 young people (range between 18 and 25) die in a nightclub fire in the Santa Maria, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.
Former New York City mayor Ed Koch dies.
North Korea conducts its third underground nuclear test, prompting widespread condemnation and tightened economic sanctions from the international community.
A meteor explodes over the Russian city of Chelyabinsk, injuring 1,489-1,492 people and damaging over 4,300 buildings.
The selectors API is added to the DOM, allowing the document.querySelector and document.querySelectorAll commands to find elements using CSS selectors, similar to how jQuery does it.
npm 3.0.0 released
Pope Francis became the first pope to emerge from Latin America.
The European Union agrees to a €10 billion economic bailout for Cyprus.

Two Chechnya-born Islamist brothers (one of whom was a United States citizen) explode two bombs at the Boston Marathon in Boston, Massachusetts, in the United States, killing 3 and injuring 264 others.
An explosion at a fertilizer plant in West, Texas, killed 15 people, nine of whom were first responders.
The 2013 Savar building collapse, one of the worst industrial disaster in the world, kills 1,134 people in Bangladesh.
Amanda Berry revealed that she, Michelle Knight and Gina DeJesus had been kidnapped and held captive by Ariel Castro in Cleveland.
Google announces that Android Studio, based on IntelliJ's platform, will be the new IDE for developing Android apps.
In a study published in the scientific journal Nature, researchers from Oregon Health & Science University in the United States describe the first production of human embryonic stem cells by cloning.
Intel announces Haswell based on 22 nanometer technology.

Former CIA employee Edward Snowden discloses operations engaged in by a U.S. government mass surveillance program to news publications and flees the country, later being granted temporary asylum in Russia.
Shenzhou 10 docks with Tiangong-1, the second docking with Tiangong-1
Skip Prichard becomes OCLC's new CEO.
The EOS 70D released by Canon.
Amid mass protests across Egypt, President Mohamed Morsi is deposed in a military coup d'état, leading to widespread violence.
Illumination Animation releases Despicable Me 2. $970 million
A Boeing 777 operated by Asiana Airlines crash landed because the pilot-in-training landed the plane too short on the runway, killing three Chinese girls, one run over by a first responder truck.

Following the military coup in Egypt, two anti-coup camps are raided by the security forces, leaving 2,696 dead.[40] The raids were described by Human Rights Watch as "one of the world's largest killings of demonstrators in a single day in recent history".
Two opposition-controlled areas in the suburbs around Damascus, Syria were struck by rockets containing the chemical agent sarin. Estimates of the death toll range from at least 281 people to 1,729.

Houston voters reject a $200 million bond issue to renovate the Houston Astrodome.
Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda), one of the strongest tropical cyclones on record, hits the Philippines and Vietnam, causing devastation with at least 6,241 dead.

Three Studies of Lucian Freud, a series of portraits of Lucian Freud by the British painter Francis Bacon, sells for US$142.4 million in a New York City auction, setting a world record for an auctioned work of art.
The westbound half of the George Voinovich bridge opens in Cleveland, Oh.
BitCoin closes above $500 for the first time.
BitCoin closes above $1,000 for the first time, a value it won't see again until January 2017.

Former South African president and leader of the anti-apartheid movement Nelson Mandela dies.
Chinese unmanned spacecraft Chang'e 3, carrying the Yutu rover, becomes the first spacecraft to "soft"-land on the Moon since 1976 and the third ever robotic rover to do so.

A one year old boy is believed to be the first victim of an Ebola outbreak that will go on to ravage western Africa.

The XXII Olympic Winter Games are held in Sochi, Russia. Slopestyle events are introduced for the first time.
The EOS 1200D (Rebel T5) is released by Canon.

Ukrainian revolution: The Verkhovna Rada (Ukrainian parliament) votes to remove President Viktor Yanukovych from office, replacing him with Oleksandr Turchynov, after days of civil unrest leaving around 100 people dead in Kiev.
Docker 0.3 released.

Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, a Boeing 777 airliner en route to Beijing from Kuala Lumpur, disappears over the Gulf of Thailand with 239 people on board. The aircraft is presumed to have crashed into the Indian Ocean.
repo: George starts work on the OCLC Python Authentication Library
Russia formally annexes Crimea after President Vladimir Putin signs a bill finalizing the process.
During an emergency meeting, the United Kingdom, the United States, Italy, Germany, France, Japan, and Canada temporarily suspend Russia from the G8.
The United Nations General Assembly passes Resolution 68/262, recognizing Crimea within Ukraine’s international borders and rejecting the validity of the 2014 Crimean referendum.
Spring Boot 1.0 released.
An estimated 276 girls and women are abducted and held hostage from a school in Nigeria.
Korean ferry MV Sewol capsizes and sinks after an unmanageable cargo shift, killing 304 people, mostly high school students.
United States President Barack Obama's new economic sanctions against Russia go into effect, targeting companies and individuals close to Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Online charter-school giant ECOT says the state can’t base its funding on records showing how much time students log in for online classwork because they don’t show the work students do offline. But ECOT has consistently told the state auditor that log books and teacher grade books that would document offline student work don’t exist. State auditors have had to rely on signed certification forms from teachers that say students have been offered at least 920 hours of “educational opportunities.”

After an NSA cyber hacking tool Eternal Blue was stolen from the NSA by the Shadow Brokers, the NSA tipped off Microsoft which issued a security patch on this day. However, not everyone updates their computers and attacks based on Eternal Blue cripple Baltimore in May, 2019.
